Roberts, Jr. and David Widger\r\n\r\n*** START OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK IVANHOE ***\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIvanhoe\r\n\r\nA Romance\r\n\r\nby Sir Walter Scott\r\n\r\n\r\nContents\r\n\r\n INTRODUCTION TO IVANHOE.\r\n DEDICATORY EPISTLE\r\n\r\n CHAPTER I.\r\n CHAPTER II.\r\n CHAPTER III.\r\n CHAPTER IV.\r\n CHAPTER V.\r\n CHAPTER VI.\r\n CHAPTER VII.\r\n CHAPTER VIII.\r\n CHAPTER IX.\r\n CHAPTER X.\r\n CHAPTER XI.\r\n CHAPTER XII.\r\n CHAPTER XIII.\r\n CHAPTER XIV.\r\n CHAPTER XV.\r\n CHAPTER XVI.\r\n CHAPTER XVII.\r\n CHAPTER XVIII.\r\n CHAPTER XIX.\r\n CHAPTER XX.\r\n CHAPTER XXI.\r\n CHAPTER XXII.\r\n CHAPTER XXIII.\r\n CHAPTER XXIV.\r\n CHAPTER XXV.\r\n CHAPTER XXVI.\r\n CHAPTER XXVII.\r\n CHAPTER XXVIII.\r\n CHAPTER XXIX.\r\n CHAPTER XXX.\r\n CHAPTER XXXI.\r\n CHAPTER XXXII.\r\n CHAPTER XXXIII.\r\n CHAPTER XXXIV.\r\n CHAPTER XXXV.\r\n CHAPTER XXXVI.\r\n CHAPTER XXXVII.\r\n CHAPTER XXXVIII.\r\n CHAPTER XXXIX.\r\n CHAPTER XL.\r\n CHAPTER XLI.\r\n CHAPTER XLII.\r\n CHAPTER XLIII.\r\n CHAPTER XLIV.\r\n\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER I.\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER II.\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER XVII.\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER XXI.\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER XXII.\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER XXIX.\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER XXXI.\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER XXXII.\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER XXXIII.\r\n NOTE TO CHAPTER XLI..\r\n FOOTNOTES\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNow fitted the halter, now traversed the cart,\r\nAnd often took leave,\xe2\x80\x94but seemed loath to depart! 1\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Prior.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nINTRODUCTION TO IVANHOE.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Author of the Waverley Novels had hitherto proceeded in an unabated\r\ncourse of popularity, and might, in his peculiar district of\r\nliterature, have been termed _L\xe2\x80\x99Enfant G\xc3\xa2t\xc3\xa9_ of success. It was plain,\r\nhowever, that frequent publication must finally wear out the public\r\nfavour, unless some mode could be devised to give an appearance of\r\nnovelty to subsequent productions. Scottish manners, Scottish dialect,\r\nand Scottish characters of note, being those with which the author was\r\nmost intimately, and familiarly acquainted, were the groundwork upon\r\nwhich he had hitherto relied for giving effect to his narrative. It\r\nwas, however, obvious, that this kind of interest must in the end\r\noccasion a degree of sameness and repetition, if exclusively resorted\r\nto, and that the reader was likely at length to adopt the language of\r\nEdwin, in Parnell\xe2\x80\x99s Tale:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Reverse the spell,\xe2\x80\x99 he cries,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98And let it fairly now suffice.\r\nThe gambol has been shown.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nNothing can be more dangerous for the fame of a professor of the fine\r\narts, than to permit (if he can possibly prevent it) the character of a\r\nmannerist to be attached to him, or that he should be supposed capable\r\nof success only in a particular and limited style. The public are, in\r\ngeneral, very ready to adopt the opinion, that he who has pleased them\r\nin one peculiar mode of composition, is, by means of that very talent,\r\nrendered incapable of venturing upon other subjects. The effect of this\r\ndisinclination, on the part of the public, towards the artificers of\r\ntheir pleasures, when they attempt to enlarge their means of amusing,\r\nmay be seen in the censures usually passed by vulgar criticism upon\r\nactors or artists who venture to change the character of their efforts,\r\nthat, in so doing, they may enlarge the scale of their art.\r\n\r\nThere is some justice in this opinion, as there always is in such as\r\nattain general currency. It may often happen on the stage, that an\r\nactor, by possessing in a preeminent degree the external qualities\r\nnecessary to give effect to comedy, may be deprived of the right to\r\naspire to tragic excellence; and in painting or literary composition,\r\nan artist or poet may be master exclusively of modes of thought, and\r\npowers of expression, which confine him to a single course of subjects.\r\nBut much more frequently the same capacity which carries a man to\r\npopularity in one department will obtain for him success in another,\r\nand that must be more particularly the case in literary composition,\r\nthan either in acting or painting, because the adventurer in that\r\ndepartment is not impeded in his exertions by any peculiarity of\r\nfeatures, or conformation of person, proper for particular parts, or,\r\nby any peculiar mechanical habits of using the pencil, limited to a\r\nparticular class of subjects.\r\n\r\nWhether this reasoning be correct or otherwise, the present author\r\nfelt, that, in confining himself to subjects purely Scottish, he was\r\nnot only likely to weary out the indulgence of his readers, but also\r\ngreatly to limit his own power of affording them pleasure. In a highly\r\npolished country, where so much genius is monthly employed in catering\r\nfor public amusement, a fresh topic, such as he had himself had the\r\nhappiness to light upon, is the untasted spring of the desert;\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMen bless their stars and call it luxury.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nBut when men and horses, cattle, camels, and dromedaries, have poached\r\nthe spring into mud, it becomes loathsome to those who at first drank\r\nof it with rapture; and he who had the merit of discovering it, if he\r\nwould preserve his reputation with the tribe, must display his talent\r\nby a fresh discovery of untasted fountains.\r\n\r\nIf the author, who finds himself limited to a particular class of\r\nsubjects, endeavours to sustain his reputation by striving to add a\r\nnovelty of attraction to themes of the same character which have been\r\nformerly successful under his management, there are manifest reasons\r\nwhy, after a certain point, he is likely to fail. If the mine be not\r\nwrought out, the strength and capacity of the miner become necessarily\r\nexhausted. If he closely imitates the narratives which he has before\r\nrendered successful, he is doomed to \xe2\x80\x9cwonder that they please no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nIf he struggles to take a different view of the same class of subjects,\r\nhe speedily discovers that what is obvious, graceful, and natural, has\r\nbeen exhausted; and, in order to obtain the indispensable charm of\r\nnovelty, he is forced upon caricature, and, to avoid being trite, must\r\nbecome extravagant.\r\n\r\nIt is not, perhaps, necessary to enumerate so many reasons why the\r\nauthor of the Scottish Novels, as they were then exclusively termed,\r\nshould be desirous to make an experiment on a subject purely English.\r\nIt was his purpose, at the same time, to have rendered the experiment\r\nas complete as possible, by bringing the intended work before the\r\npublic as the effort of a new candidate for their favour, in order that\r\nno degree of prejudice, whether favourable or the reverse, might attach\r\nto it, as a new production of the Author of Waverley; but this\r\nintention was afterwards departed from, for reasons to be hereafter\r\nmentioned.\r\n\r\nThe period of the narrative adopted was the reign of Richard I., not\r\nonly as abounding with characters whose very names were sure to attract\r\ngeneral attention, but as affording a striking contrast betwixt the\r\nSaxons, by whom the soil was cultivated, and the Normans, who still\r\nreigned in it as conquerors, reluctant to mix with the vanquished, or\r\nacknowledge themselves of the same stock. The idea of this contrast was\r\ntaken from the ingenious and unfortunate Logan\xe2\x80\x99s tragedy of Runnamede,\r\nin which, about the same period of history, the author had seen the\r\nSaxon and Norman barons opposed to each other on different sides of the\r\nstage. He does not recollect that there was any attempt to contrast the\r\ntwo races in their habits and sentiments; and indeed it was obvious,\r\nthat history was violated by introducing the Saxons still existing as a\r\nhigh-minded and martial race of nobles.\r\n\r\nThey did, however, survive as a people, and some of the ancient Saxon\r\nfamilies possessed wealth and power, although they were exceptions to\r\nthe humble condition of the race in general. It seemed to the author,\r\nthat the existence of the two races in the same country, the vanquished\r\ndistinguished by their plain, homely, blunt manners, and the free\r\nspirit infused by their ancient institutions and laws; the victors, by\r\nthe high spirit of military fame, personal adventure, and whatever\r\ncould distinguish them as the Flower of Chivalry, might, intermixed\r\nwith other characters belonging to the same time and country, interest\r\nthe reader by the contrast, if the author should not fail on his part.\r\n\r\nScotland, however, had been of late used so exclusively as the scene of\r\nwhat is called Historical Romance, that the preliminary letter of Mr\r\nLaurence Templeton became in some measure necessary. To this, as to an\r\nIntroduction, the reader is referred, as expressing the author\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npurpose and opinions in undertaking this species of composition, under\r\nthe necessary reservation, that he is far from thinking he has attained\r\nthe point at which he aimed.\r\n\r\nIt is scarcely necessary to add, that there was no idea or wish to pass\r\noff the supposed Mr Templeton as a real person. But a kind of\r\ncontinuation of the Tales of my Landlord had been recently attempted by\r\na stranger, and it was supposed this Dedicatory Epistle might pass for\r\nsome imitation of the same kind, and thus putting enquirers upon a\r\nfalse scent, induce them to believe they had before them the work of\r\nsome new candidate for their favour.\r\n\r\nAfter a considerable part of the work had been finished and printed,\r\nthe Publishers, who pretended to discern in it a germ of popularity,\r\nremonstrated strenuously against its appearing as an absolutely\r\nanonymous production, and contended that it should have the advantage\r\nof being announced as by the Author of Waverley. The author did not\r\nmake any obstinate opposition, for he began to be of opinion with Dr\r\nWheeler, in Miss Edgeworth\xe2\x80\x99s excellent tale of \xe2\x80\x9cManeuvering,\xe2\x80\x9d that\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrick upon Trick\xe2\x80\x9d might be too much for the patience of an indulgent\r\npublic, and might be reasonably considered as trifling with their\r\nfavour.\r\n\r\nThe book, therefore, appeared as an avowed continuation of the Waverley\r\nNovels; and it would be ungrateful not to acknowledge, that it met with\r\nthe same favourable reception as its predecessors.\r\n\r\nSuch annotations as may be useful to assist the reader in comprehending\r\nthe characters of the Jew, the Templar, the Captain of the mercenaries,\r\nor Free Companions, as they were called, and others proper to the\r\nperiod, are added, but with a sparing hand, since sufficient\r\ninformation on these subjects is to be found in general history.\r\n\r\nAn incident in the tale, which had the good fortune to find favour in\r\nthe eyes of many readers, is more directly borrowed from the stores of\r\nold romance. I mean the meeting of the King with Friar Tuck at the cell\r\nof that buxom hermit. The general tone of the story belongs to all\r\nranks and all countries, which emulate each other in describing the\r\nrambles of a disguised sovereign, who, going in search of information\r\nor amusement, into the lower ranks of life, meets with adventures\r\ndiverting to the reader or hearer, from the contrast betwixt the\r\nmonarch\xe2\x80\x99s outward appearance, and his real character. The Eastern\r\ntale-teller has for his theme the disguised expeditions of Haroun\r\nAlraschid with his faithful attendants, Mesrour and Giafar, through the\r\nmidnight streets of Bagdad; and Scottish tradition dwells upon the\r\nsimilar exploits of James V., distinguished during such excursions by\r\nthe travelling name of the Goodman of Ballengeigh, as the Commander of\r\nthe Faithful, when he desired to be incognito, was known by that of Il\r\nBondocani. The French minstrels are not silent on so popular a theme.\r\nThere must have been a Norman original of the Scottish metrical romance\r\nof Rauf Colziar, in which Charlemagne is introduced as the unknown\r\nguest of a charcoal-man. 2\r\n\r\nIt seems to have been the original of other poems of the kind.\r\n\r\nIn merry England there is no end of popular ballads on this theme. The\r\npoem of John the Reeve, or Steward, mentioned by Bishop Percy, in the\r\nReliques of English Poetry, 3 is said to have turned on such an\r\nincident; and we have besides, the King and the Tanner of Tamworth, the\r\nKing and the Miller of Mansfield, and others on the same topic. But the\r\npeculiar tale of this nature to which the author of Ivanhoe has to\r\nacknowledge an obligation, is more ancient by two centuries than any of\r\nthese last mentioned.\r\n\r\nIt was first communicated to the public in that curious record of\r\nancient literature, which has been accumulated by the combined\r\nexertions of Sir Egerton Brydges and Mr Hazlewood, in the periodical\r\nwork entitled the British Bibliographer. From thence it has been\r\ntransferred by the Reverend Charles Henry Hartshorne, M.A., editor of a\r\nvery curious volume, entitled \xe2\x80\x9cAncient Metrical Tales, printed chiefly\r\nfrom original sources, 1829.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr Hartshorne gives no other authority\r\nfor the present fragment, except the article in the Bibliographer,\r\nwhere it is entitled the Kyng and the Hermite. A short abstract of its\r\ncontents will show its similarity to the meeting of King Richard and\r\nFriar Tuck.\r\n\r\nKing Edward (we are not told which among the monarchs of that name,\r\nbut, from his temper and habits, we may suppose Edward IV.) sets forth\r\nwith his court to a gallant hunting-match in Sherwood Forest, in which,\r\nas is not unusual for princes in romance, he falls in with a deer of\r\nextraordinary size and swiftness, and pursues it closely, till he has\r\noutstripped his whole retinue, tired out hounds and horse, and finds\r\nhimself alone under the gloom of an extensive forest, upon which night\r\nis descending. Under the apprehensions natural to a situation so\r\nuncomfortable, the king recollects that he has heard how poor men, when\r\napprehensive of a bad nights lodging, pray to Saint Julian, who, in the\r\nRomish calendar, stands Quarter-Master-General to all forlorn\r\ntravellers that render him due homage. Edward puts up his orisons\r\naccordingly, and by the guidance, doubtless, of the good Saint, reaches\r\na small path, conducting him to a chapel in the forest, having a\r\nhermit\xe2\x80\x99s cell in its close vicinity. The King hears the reverend man,\r\nwith a companion of his solitude, telling his beads within, and meekly\r\nrequests of him quarters for the night. \xe2\x80\x9cI have no accommodation for\r\nsuch a lord as ye be,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Hermit. \xe2\x80\x9cI live here in the wilderness\r\nupon roots and rinds, and may not receive into my dwelling even the\r\npoorest wretch that lives, unless it were to save his life.\xe2\x80\x9d The King\r\nenquires the way to the next town, and, understanding it is by a road\r\nwhich he cannot find without difficulty, even if he had daylight to\r\nbefriend him, he declares, that with or without the Hermit\xe2\x80\x99s consent,\r\nhe is determined to be his guest that night. He is admitted\r\naccordingly, not without a hint from the Recluse, that were he himself\r\nout of his priestly weeds, he would care little for his threats of\r\nusing violence, and that he gives way to him not out of intimidation,\r\nbut simply to avoid scandal.\r\n\r\nThe King is admitted into the cell\xe2\x80\x94two bundles of straw are shaken down\r\nfor his accommodation, and he comforts himself that he is now under\r\nshelter, and that\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA night will soon be gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nOther wants, however, arise. The guest becomes clamorous for supper,\r\nobserving,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor certainly, as I you say,\r\nI ne had never so sorry a day,\r\n    That I ne had a merry night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nBut this indication of his taste for good cheer, joined to the\r\nannunciation of his being a follower of the Court, who had lost himself\r\nat the great hunting-match, cannot induce the niggard Hermit to produce\r\nbetter fare than bread and cheese, for which his guest showed little\r\nappetite; and \xe2\x80\x9cthin drink,\xe2\x80\x9d which was even less acceptable. At length\r\nthe King presses his host on a point to which he had more than once\r\nalluded, without obtaining a satisfactory reply:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen said the King, \xe2\x80\x98by God\xe2\x80\x99s grace,\r\nThou wert in a merry place,\r\n    To shoot should thou here\r\nWhen the foresters go to rest,\r\nSometyme thou might have of the best,\r\n    All of the wild deer;\r\nI wold hold it for no scathe,\r\nThough thou hadst bow and arrows baith,\r\n    Althoff thou best a Frere.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Hermit, in return, expresses his apprehension that his guest means\r\nto drag him into some confession of offence against the forest laws,\r\nwhich, being betrayed to the King, might cost him his life. Edward\r\nanswers by fresh assurances of secrecy, and again urges on him the\r\nnecessity of procuring some venison. The Hermit replies, by once more\r\ninsisting on the duties incumbent upon him as a churchman, and\r\ncontinues to affirm himself free from all such breaches of order:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMany day I have here been,\r\nAnd flesh-meat I eat never,\r\n    But milk of the kye;\r\nWarm thee well, and go to sleep,\r\nAnd I will lap thee with my cope,\r\n    Softly to lye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nIt would seem that the manuscript is here imperfect, for we do not find\r\nthe reasons which finally induce the curtal Friar to amend the King\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncheer. But acknowledging his guest to be such a \xe2\x80\x9cgood fellow\xe2\x80\x9d as has\r\nseldom graced his board, the holy man at length produces the best his\r\ncell affords. Two candles are placed on a table, white bread and baked\r\npasties are displayed by the light, besides choice of venison, both\r\nsalt and fresh, from which they select collops. \xe2\x80\x9cI might have eaten my\r\nbread dry,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, \xe2\x80\x9chad I not pressed thee on the score of\r\narchery, but now have I dined like a prince\xe2\x80\x94if we had but drink enow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis too is afforded by the hospitable anchorite, who dispatches an\r\nassistant to fetch a pot of four gallons from a secret corner near his\r\nbed, and the whole three set in to serious drinking. This amusement is\r\nsuperintended by the Friar, according to the recurrence of certain\r\nfustian words, to be repeated by every compotator in turn before he\r\ndrank\xe2\x80\x94a species of High Jinks, as it were, by which they regulated\r\ntheir potations, as toasts were given in latter times. The one toper\r\nsays \xe2\x80\x9cfusty bandias\xe2\x80\x9d, to which the other is obliged to reply, \xe2\x80\x9cstrike\r\npantnere\xe2\x80\x9d, and the Friar passes many jests on the King\xe2\x80\x99s want of\r\nmemory, who sometimes forgets the words of action. The night is spent\r\nin this jolly pastime. Before his departure in the morning, the King\r\ninvites his reverend host to Court, promises, at least, to requite his\r\nhospitality, and expresses himself much pleased with his entertainment.\r\nThe jolly Hermit at length agrees to venture thither, and to enquire\r\nfor Jack Fletcher, which is the name assumed by the King. After the\r\nHermit has shown Edward some feats of archery, the joyous pair\r\nseparate. The King rides home, and rejoins his retinue. As the romance\r\nis imperfect, we are not acquainted how the discovery takes place; but\r\nit is probably much in the same manner as in other narratives turning\r\non the same subject, where the host, apprehensive of death for having\r\ntrespassed on the respect due to his Sovereign, while incognito, is\r\nagreeably surprised by receiving honours and reward.\r\n\r\nIn Mr Hartshorne\xe2\x80\x99s collection, there is a romance on the same\r\nfoundation, called King Edward and the Shepherd,4 which, considered as\r\nillustrating manners, is still more curious than the King and the\r\nHermit; but it is foreign to the present purpose. The reader has here\r\nthe original legend from which the incident in the romance is derived;\r\nand the identifying the irregular Eremite with the Friar Tuck of Robin\r\nHood\xe2\x80\x99s story, was an obvious expedient.\r\n\r\nThe name of Ivanhoe was suggested by an old rhyme. All novelists have\r\nhad occasion at some time or other to wish with Falstaff, that they\r\nknew where a commodity of good names was to be had. On such an occasion\r\nthe author chanced to call to memory a rhyme recording three names of\r\nthe manors forfeited by the ancestor of the celebrated Hampden, for\r\nstriking the Black Prince a blow with his racket, when they quarrelled\r\nat tennis:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTring, Wing, and Ivanhoe,\r\nFor striking of a blow,\r\nHampden did forego,\r\nAnd glad he could escape so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe word suited the author\xe2\x80\x99s purpose in two material respects,\xe2\x80\x94for,\r\nfirst, it had an ancient English sound; and secondly, it conveyed no\r\nindication whatever of the nature of the story. He presumes to hold\r\nthis last quality to be of no small importance. What is called a taking\r\ntitle, serves the direct interest of the bookseller or publisher, who\r\nby this means sometimes sells an edition while it is yet passing the\r\npress. But if the author permits an over degree of attention to be\r\ndrawn to his work ere it has appeared, he places himself in the\r\nembarrassing condition of having excited a degree of expectation which,\r\nif he proves unable to satisfy, is an error fatal to his literary\r\nreputation. Besides, when we meet such a title as the Gunpowder Plot,\r\nor any other connected with general history, each reader, before he has\r\nseen the book, has formed to himself some particular idea of the sort\r\nof manner in which the story is to be conducted, and the nature of the\r\namusement which he is to derive from it. In this he is probably\r\ndisappointed, and in that case may be naturally disposed to visit upon\r\nthe author or the work, the unpleasant feelings thus excited. In such a\r\ncase the literary adventurer is censured, not for having missed the\r\nmark at which he himself aimed, but for not having shot off his shaft\r\nin a direction he never thought of.\r\n\r\nOn the footing of unreserved communication which the Author has\r\nestablished with the reader, he may here add the trifling circumstance,\r\nthat a roll of Norman warriors, occurring in the Auchinleck Manuscript,\r\ngave him the formidable name of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf.\r\n\r\nIvanhoe was highly successful upon its appearance, and may be said to\r\nhave procured for its author the freedom of the Rules, since he has\r\never since been permitted to exercise his powers of fictitious\r\ncomposition in England, as well as Scotland.\r\n\r\nThe character of the fair Jewess found so much favour in the eyes of\r\nsome fair readers, that the writer was censured, because, when\r\narranging the fates of the characters of the drama, he had not assigned\r\nthe hand of Wilfred to Rebecca, rather than the less interesting\r\nRowena. But, not to mention that the prejudices of the age rendered\r\nsuch an union almost impossible, the author may, in passing, observe,\r\nthat he thinks a character of a highly virtuous and lofty stamp, is\r\ndegraded rather than exalted by an attempt to reward virtue with\r\ntemporal prosperity. Such is not the recompense which Providence has\r\ndeemed worthy of suffering merit, and it is a dangerous and fatal\r\ndoctrine to teach young persons, the most common readers of romance,\r\nthat rectitude of conduct and of principle are either naturally allied\r\nwith, or adequately rewarded by, the gratification of our passions, or\r\nattainment of our wishes. In a word, if a virtuous and self-denied\r\ncharacter is dismissed with temporal wealth, greatness, rank, or the\r\nindulgence of such a rashly formed or ill assorted passion as that of\r\nRebecca for Ivanhoe, the reader will be apt to say, verily Virtue has\r\nhad its reward. But a glance on the great picture of life will show,\r\nthat the duties of self-denial, and the sacrifice of passion to\r\nprinciple, are seldom thus remunerated; and that the internal\r\nconsciousness of their high-minded discharge of duty, produces on their\r\nown reflections a more adequate recompense, in the form of that peace\r\nwhich the world cannot give or take away.\r\n\r\nAbbotsford, 1_st September_, 1830.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDEDICATORY EPISTLE\r\n\r\n\r\nTO\r\nTHE REV. DR DRYASDUST, F.A.S.\r\nResiding in the Castle-Gate, York.\r\n\r\nMuch esteemed and dear Sir,\r\n\r\nIt is scarcely necessary to mention the various and concurring reasons\r\nwhich induce me to place your name at the head of the following work.\r\nYet the chief of these reasons may perhaps be refuted by the\r\nimperfections of the performance. Could I have hoped to render it\r\nworthy of your patronage, the public would at once have seen the\r\npropriety of inscribing a work designed to illustrate the domestic\r\nantiquities of England, and particularly of our Saxon forefathers, to\r\nthe learned author of the Essays upon the Horn of King Ulphus, and on\r\nthe Lands bestowed by him upon the patrimony of St Peter. I am\r\nconscious, however, that the slight, unsatisfactory, and trivial\r\nmanner, in which the result of my antiquarian researches has been\r\nrecorded in the following pages, takes the work from under that class\r\nwhich bears the proud motto, \xe2\x80\x9cDetur digniori\xe2\x80\x9d. On the contrary, I fear\r\nI shall incur the censure of presumption in placing the venerable name\r\nof Dr Jonas Dryasdust at the head of a publication, which the more\r\ngrave antiquary will perhaps class with the idle novels and romances of\r\nthe day. I am anxious to vindicate myself from such a charge; for\r\nalthough I might trust to your friendship for an apology in your eyes,\r\nyet I would not willingly stand conviction in those of the public of so\r\ngrave a crime, as my fears lead me to anticipate my being charged with.\r\n\r\nI must therefore remind you, that when we first talked over together\r\nthat class of productions, in one of which the private and family\r\naffairs of your learned northern friend, Mr Oldbuck of Monkbarns, were\r\nso unjustifiably exposed to the public, some discussion occurred\r\nbetween us concerning the cause of the popularity these works have\r\nattained in this idle age, which, whatever other merit they possess,\r\nmust be admitted to be hastily written, and in violation of every rule\r\nassigned to the epopeia. It seemed then to be your opinion, that the\r\ncharm lay entirely in the art with which the unknown author had availed\r\nhimself, like a second M\xe2\x80\x99Pherson, of the antiquarian stores which lay\r\nscattered around him, supplying his own indolence or poverty of\r\ninvention, by the incidents which had actually taken place in his\r\ncountry at no distant period, by introducing real characters, and\r\nscarcely suppressing real names. It was not above sixty or seventy\r\nyears, you observed, since the whole north of Scotland was under a\r\nstate of government nearly as simple and as patriarchal as those of our\r\ngood allies the Mohawks and Iroquois. Admitting that the author cannot\r\nhimself be supposed to have witnessed those times, he must have lived,\r\nyou observed, among persons who had acted and suffered in them; and\r\neven within these thirty years, such an infinite change has taken place\r\nin the manners of Scotland, that men look back upon the habits of\r\nsociety proper to their immediate ancestors, as we do on those of the\r\nreign of Queen Anne, or even the period of the Revolution. Having thus\r\nmaterials of every kind lying strewed around him, there was little, you\r\nobserved, to embarrass the author, but the difficulty of choice. It was\r\nno wonder, therefore, that, having begun to work a mine so plentiful,\r\nhe should have derived from his works fully more credit and profit than\r\nthe facility of his labours merited.\r\n\r\nAdmitting (as I could not deny) the general truth of these conclusions,\r\nI cannot but think it strange that no attempt has been made to excite\r\nan interest for the traditions and manners of Old England, similiar to\r\nthat which has been obtained in behalf of those of our poorer and less\r\ncelebrated neighbours. The Kendal green, though its date is more\r\nancient, ought surely to be as dear to our feelings, as the variegated\r\ntartans of the north. The name of Robin Hood, if duly conjured with,\r\nshould raise a spirit as soon as that of Rob Roy; and the patriots of\r\nEngland deserve no less their renown in our modern circles, than the\r\nBruces and Wallaces of Caledonia. If the scenery of the south be less\r\nromantic and sublime than that of the northern mountains, it must be\r\nallowed to possess in the same proportion superior softness and beauty;\r\nand upon the whole, we feel ourselves entitled to exclaim with the\r\npatriotic Syrian\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAre not Pharphar and Abana, rivers of Damascus,\r\nbetter than all the rivers of Israel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYour objections to such an attempt, my dear Doctor, were, you may\r\nremember, two-fold. You insisted upon the advantages which the Scotsman\r\npossessed, from the very recent existence of that state of society in\r\nwhich his scene was to be laid. Many now alive, you remarked, well\r\nremembered persons who had not only seen the celebrated Roy M\xe2\x80\x99Gregor,\r\nbut had feasted, and even fought with him. All those minute\r\ncircumstances belonging to private life and domestic character, all\r\nthat gives verisimilitude to a narrative, and individuality to the\r\npersons introduced, is still known and remembered in Scotland; whereas\r\nin England, civilisation has been so long complete, that our ideas of\r\nour ancestors are only to be gleaned from musty records and chronicles,\r\nthe authors of which seem perversely to have conspired to suppress in\r\ntheir narratives all interesting details, in order to find room for\r\nflowers of monkish eloquence, or trite reflections upon morals. To\r\nmatch an English and a Scottish author in the rival task of embodying\r\nand reviving the traditions of their respective countries, would be,\r\nyou alleged, in the highest degree unequal and unjust. The Scottish\r\nmagician, you said, was, like Lucan\xe2\x80\x99s witch, at liberty to walk over\r\nthe recent field of battle, and to select for the subject of\r\nresuscitation by his sorceries, a body whose limbs had recently\r\nquivered with existence, and whose throat had but just uttered the last\r\nnote of agony. Such a subject even the powerful Erictho was compelled\r\nto select, as alone capable of being reanimated even by \xe2\x80\x9cher\xe2\x80\x9d potent\r\nmagic\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94gelidas leto scrutata medullas,\r\nPulmonis rigidi stantes sine vulnere fibras\r\nInvenit, et vocem defuncto in corpore quaerit.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe English author, on the other hand, without supposing him less of a\r\nconjuror than the Northern Warlock, can, you observed, only have the\r\nliberty of selecting his subject amidst the dust of antiquity, where\r\nnothing was to be found but dry, sapless, mouldering, and disjointed\r\nbones, such as those which filled the valley of Jehoshaphat. You\r\nexpressed, besides, your apprehension, that the unpatriotic prejudices\r\nof my countrymen would not allow fair play to such a work as that of\r\nwhich I endeavoured to demonstrate the probable success. And this, you\r\nsaid, was not entirely owing to the more general prejudice in favour of\r\nthat which is foreign, but that it rested partly upon improbabilities,\r\narising out of the circumstances in which the English reader is placed.\r\nIf you describe to him a set of wild manners, and a state of primitive\r\nsociety existing in the Highlands of Scotland, he is much disposed to\r\nacquiesce in the truth of what is asserted. And reason good. If he be\r\nof the ordinary class of readers, he has either never seen those remote\r\ndistricts at all, or he has wandered through those desolate regions in\r\nthe course of a summer tour, eating bad dinners, sleeping on truckle\r\nbeds, stalking from desolation to desolation, and fully prepared to\r\nbelieve the strangest things that could be told him of a people, wild\r\nand extravagant enough to be attached to scenery so extraordinary. But\r\nthe same worthy person, when placed in his own snug parlour, and\r\nsurrounded by all the comforts of an Englishman\xe2\x80\x99s fireside, is not half\r\nso much disposed to believe that his own ancestors led a very different\r\nlife from himself; that the shattered tower, which now forms a vista\r\nfrom his window, once held a baron who would have hung him up at his\r\nown door without any form of trial; that the hinds, by whom his little\r\npet-farm is managed, a few centuries ago would have been his slaves;\r\nand that the complete influence of feudal tyranny once extended over\r\nthe neighbouring village, where the attorney is now a man of more\r\nimportance than the lord of the manor.\r\n\r\nWhile I own the force of these objections, I must confess, at the same\r\ntime, that they do not appear to me to be altogether insurmountable.\r\nThe scantiness of materials is indeed a formidable difficulty; but no\r\none knows better than Dr Dryasdust, that to those deeply read in\r\nantiquity, hints concerning the private life of our ancestors lie\r\nscattered through the pages of our various historians, bearing, indeed,\r\na slender proportion to the other matters of which they treat, but\r\nstill, when collected together, sufficient to throw considerable light\r\nupon the _vie priv\xc3\xa9e_ of our forefathers; indeed, I am convinced, that\r\nhowever I myself may fail in the ensuing attempt, yet, with more labour\r\nin collecting, or more skill in using, the materials within his reach,\r\nillustrated as they have been by the labours of Dr Henry, of the late\r\nMr Strutt, and, above all, of Mr Sharon Turner, an abler hand would\r\nhave been successful; and therefore I protest, beforehand, against any\r\nargument which may be founded on the failure of the present experiment.\r\n\r\nOn the other hand, I have already said, that if any thing like a true\r\npicture of old English manners could be drawn, I would trust to the\r\ngood-nature and good sense of my countrymen for insuring its favourable\r\nreception.\r\n\r\nHaving thus replied, to the best of my power, to the first class of\r\nyour objections, or at least having shown my resolution to overleap the\r\nbarriers which your prudence has raised, I will be brief in noticing\r\nthat which is more peculiar to myself. It seems to be your opinion,\r\nthat the very office of an antiquary, employed in grave, and, as the\r\nvulgar will sometimes allege, in toilsome and minute research, must be\r\nconsidered as incapacitating him from successfully compounding a tale\r\nof this sort. But permit me to say, my dear Doctor, that this objection\r\nis rather formal than substantial. It is true, that such slight\r\ncompositions might not suit the severer genius of our friend Mr\r\nOldbuck. Yet Horace Walpole wrote a goblin tale which has thrilled\r\nthrough many a bosom; and George Ellis could transfer all the playful\r\nfascination of a humour, as delightful as it was uncommon, into his\r\nAbridgement of the Ancient Metrical Romances. So that, however I may\r\nhave occasion to rue my present audacity, I have at least the most\r\nrespectable precedents in my favour.\r\n\r\nStill the severer antiquary may think, that, by thus intermingling\r\nfiction with truth, I am polluting the well of history with modern\r\ninventions, and impressing upon the rising generation false ideas of\r\nthe age which I describe. I cannot but in some sense admit the force of\r\nthis reasoning, which I yet hope to traverse by the following\r\nconsiderations.\r\n\r\nIt is true, that I neither can, nor do pretend, to the observation of\r\ncomplete accuracy, even in matters of outward costume, much less in the\r\nmore important points of language and manners. But the same motive\r\nwhich prevents my writing the dialogue of the piece in Anglo-Saxon or\r\nin Norman-French, and which prohibits my sending forth to the public\r\nthis essay printed with the types of Caxton or Wynken de Worde,\r\nprevents my attempting to confine myself within the limits of the\r\nperiod in which my story is laid. It is necessary, for exciting\r\ninterest of any kind, that the subject assumed should be, as it were,\r\ntranslated into the manners, as well as the language, of the age we\r\nlive in. No fascination has ever been attached to Oriental literature,\r\nequal to that produced by Mr Galland\xe2\x80\x99s first translation of the Arabian\r\nTales; in which, retaining on the one hand the splendour of Eastern\r\ncostume, and on the other the wildness of Eastern fiction, he mixed\r\nthese with just so much ordinary feeling and expression, as rendered\r\nthem interesting and intelligible, while he abridged the long-winded\r\nnarratives, curtailed the monotonous reflections, and rejected the\r\nendless repetitions of the Arabian original. The tales, therefore,\r\nthough less purely Oriental than in their first concoction, were\r\neminently better fitted for the European market, and obtained an\r\nunrivalled degree of public favour, which they certainly would never\r\nhave gained had not the manners and style been in some degree\r\nfamiliarized to the feelings and habits of the western reader.\r\n\r\nIn point of justice, therefore, to the multitudes who will, I trust,\r\ndevour this book with avidity, I have so far explained our ancient\r\nmanners in modern language, and so far detailed the characters and\r\nsentiments of my persons, that the modern reader will not find himself,\r\nI should hope, much trammelled by the repulsive dryness of mere\r\nantiquity. In this, I respectfully contend, I have in no respect\r\nexceeded the fair license due to the author of a fictitious\r\ncomposition. The late ingenious Mr Strutt, in his romance of\r\nQueen-Hoo-Hall, 5 acted upon another principle; and in distinguishing\r\nbetween what was ancient and modern, forgot, as it appears to me, that\r\nextensive neutral ground, the large proportion, that is, of manners and\r\nsentiments which are common to us and to our ancestors, having been\r\nhanded down unaltered from them to us, or which, arising out of the\r\nprinciples of our common nature, must have existed alike in either\r\nstate of society. In this manner, a man of talent, and of great\r\nantiquarian erudition, limited the popularity of his work, by excluding\r\nfrom it every thing which was not sufficiently obsolete to be\r\naltogether forgotten and unintelligible.\r\n\r\nThe license which I would here vindicate, is so necessary to the\r\nexecution of my plan, that I will crave your patience while I\r\nillustrate my argument a little farther.\r\n\r\nHe who first opens Chaucer, or any other ancient poet, is so much\r\nstruck with the obsolete spelling, multiplied consonants, and\r\nantiquated appearance of the language, that he is apt to lay the work\r\ndown in despair, as encrusted too deep with the rust of antiquity, to\r\npermit his judging of its merits or tasting its beauties. But if some\r\nintelligent and accomplished friend points out to him, that the\r\ndifficulties by which he is startled are more in appearance than\r\nreality, if, by reading aloud to him, or by reducing the ordinary words\r\nto the modern orthography, he satisfies his proselyte that only about\r\none-tenth part of the words employed are in fact obsolete, the novice\r\nmay be easily persuaded to approach the \xe2\x80\x9cwell of English undefiled,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwith the certainty that a slender degree of patience will enable him to\r\nto enjoy both the humour and the pathos with which old Geoffrey\r\ndelighted the age of Cressy and of Poictiers.\r\n\r\nTo pursue this a little farther. If our neophyte, strong in the\r\nnew-born love of antiquity, were to undertake to imitate what he had\r\nlearnt to admire, it must be allowed he would act very injudiciously,\r\nif he were to select from the Glossary the obsolete words which it\r\ncontains, and employ those exclusively of all phrases and vocables\r\nretained in modern days. This was the error of the unfortunate\r\nChatterton. In order to give his language the appearance of antiquity,\r\nhe rejected every word that was modern, and produced a dialect entirely\r\ndifferent from any that had ever been spoken in Great Britain. He who\r\nwould imitate an ancient language with success, must attend rather to\r\nits grammatical character, turn of expression, and mode of arrangement,\r\nthan labour to collect extraordinary and antiquated terms, which, as I\r\nhave already averred, do not in ancient authors approach the number of\r\nwords still in use, though perhaps somewhat altered in sense and\r\nspelling, in the proportion of one to ten.\r\n\r\nWhat I have applied to language, is still more justly applicable to\r\nsentiments and manners. The passions, the sources from which these must\r\nspring in all their modifications, are generally the same in all ranks\r\nand conditions, all countries and ages; and it follows, as a matter of\r\ncourse, that the opinions, habits of thinking, and actions, however\r\ninfluenced by the peculiar state of society, must still, upon the\r\nwhole, bear a strong resemblance to each other. Our ancestors were not\r\nmore distinct from us, surely, than Jews are from Christians; they had\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ceyes, hands, organs, dimensions, senses, affections, passions;\xe2\x80\x9d were\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfed with the same food, hurt with the same weapons, subject to the\r\nsame diseases, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer,\xe2\x80\x9d as\r\nourselves. The tenor, therefore, of their affections and feelings, must\r\nhave borne the same general proportion to our own.\r\n\r\nIt follows, therefore, that of the materials which an author has to use\r\nin a romance, or fictitious composition, such as I have ventured to\r\nattempt, he will find that a great proportion, both of language and\r\nmanners, is as proper to the present time as to those in which he has\r\nlaid his time of action. The freedom of choice which this allows him,\r\nis therefore much greater, and the difficulty of his task much more\r\ndiminished, than at first appears. To take an illustration from a\r\nsister art, the antiquarian details may be said to represent the\r\npeculiar features of a landscape under delineation of the pencil. His\r\nfeudal tower must arise in due majesty; the figures which he introduces\r\nmust have the costume and character of their age; the piece must\r\nrepresent the peculiar features of the scene which he has chosen for\r\nhis subject, with all its appropriate elevation of rock, or precipitate\r\ndescent of cataract. His general colouring, too, must be copied from\r\nNature: The sky must be clouded or serene, according to the climate,\r\nand the general tints must be those which prevail in a natural\r\nlandscape. So far the painter is bound down by the rules of his art, to\r\na precise imitation of the features of Nature; but it is not required\r\nthat he should descend to copy all her more minute features, or\r\nrepresent with absolute exactness the very herbs, flowers, and trees,\r\nwith which the spot is decorated. These, as well as all the more minute\r\npoints of light and shadow, are attributes proper to scenery in\r\ngeneral, natural to each situation, and subject to the artist\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndisposal, as his taste or pleasure may dictate.\r\n\r\nIt is true, that this license is confined in either case within\r\nlegitimate bounds. The painter must introduce no ornament inconsistent\r\nwith the climate or country of his landscape; he must not plant cypress\r\ntrees upon Inch-Merrin, or Scottish firs among the ruins of Persepolis;\r\nand the author lies under a corresponding restraint. However far he may\r\nventure in a more full detail of passions and feelings, than is to be\r\nfound in the ancient compositions which he imitates, he must introduce\r\nnothing inconsistent with the manners of the age; his knights, squires,\r\ngrooms, and yeomen, may be more fully drawn than in the hard, dry\r\ndelineations of an ancient illuminated manuscript, but the character\r\nand costume of the age must remain inviolate; they must be the same\r\nfigures, drawn by a better pencil, or, to speak more modestly, executed\r\nin an age when the principles of art were better understood. His\r\nlanguage must not be exclusively obsolete and unintelligible; but he\r\nshould admit, if possible, no word or turn of phraseology betraying an\r\norigin directly modern. It is one thing to make use of the language and\r\nsentiments which are common to ourselves and our forefathers, and it is\r\nanother to invest them with the sentiments and dialect exclusively\r\nproper to their descendants.\r\n\r\nThis, my dear friend, I have found the most difficult part of my task;\r\nand, to speak frankly, I hardly expect to satisfy your less partial\r\njudgment, and more extensive knowledge of such subjects, since I have\r\nhardly been able to please my own.\r\n\r\nI am conscious that I shall be found still more faulty in the tone of\r\nkeeping and costume, by those who may be disposed rigidly to examine my\r\nTale, with reference to the manners of the exact period in which my\r\nactors flourished: It may be, that I have introduced little which can\r\npositively be termed modern; but, on the other hand, it is extremely\r\nprobable that I may have confused the manners of two or three\r\ncenturies, and introduced, during the reign of Richard the First,\r\ncircumstances appropriated to a period either considerably earlier, or\r\na good deal later than that era. It is my comfort, that errors of this\r\nkind will escape the general class of readers, and that I may share in\r\nthe ill-deserved applause of those architects, who, in their modern\r\nGothic, do not hesitate to introduce, without rule or method, ornaments\r\nproper to different styles and to different periods of the art. Those\r\nwhose extensive researches have given them the means of judging my\r\nbackslidings with more severity, will probably be lenient in proportion\r\nto their knowledge of the difficulty of my task. My honest and\r\nneglected friend, Ingulphus, has furnished me with many a valuable\r\nhint; but the light afforded by the Monk of Croydon, and Geoffrey de\r\nVinsauff, is dimmed by such a conglomeration of uninteresting and\r\nunintelligible matter, that we gladly fly for relief to the delightful\r\npages of the gallant Froissart, although he flourished at a period so\r\nmuch more remote from the date of my history. If, therefore, my dear\r\nfriend, you have generosity enough to pardon the presumptuous attempt,\r\nto frame for myself a minstrel coronet, partly out of the pearls of\r\npure antiquity, and partly from the Bristol stones and paste, with\r\nwhich I have endeavoured to imitate them, I am convinced your opinion\r\nof the difficulty of the task will reconcile you to the imperfect\r\nmanner of its execution.\r\n\r\nOf my materials I have but little to say. They may be chiefly found in\r\nthe singular Anglo-Norman MS., which Sir Arthur Wardour preserves with\r\nsuch jealous care in the third drawer of his oaken cabinet, scarcely\r\nallowing any one to touch it, and being himself not able to read one\r\nsyllable of its contents. I should never have got his consent, on my\r\nvisit to Scotland, to read in those precious pages for so many hours,\r\nhad I not promised to designate it by some emphatic mode of printing,\r\nas {The Wardour Manuscript}; giving it, thereby, an individuality as\r\nimportant as the Bannatyne MS., the Auchinleck MS., and any other\r\nmonument of the patience of a Gothic scrivener. I have sent, for your\r\nprivate consideration, a list of the contents of this curious piece,\r\nwhich I shall perhaps subjoin, with your approbation, to the third\r\nvolume of my Tale, in case the printer\xe2\x80\x99s devil should continue\r\nimpatient for copy, when the whole of my narrative has been imposed.\r\n\r\nAdieu, my dear friend; I have said enough to explain, if not to\r\nvindicate, the attempt which I have made, and which, in spite of your\r\ndoubts, and my own incapacity, I am still willing to believe has not\r\nbeen altogether made in vain.\r\n\r\nI hope you are now well recovered from your spring fit of the gout, and\r\nshall be happy if the advice of your learned physician should recommend\r\na tour to these parts. Several curiosities have been lately dug up near\r\nthe wall, as well as at the ancient station of Habitancum. Talking of\r\nthe latter, I suppose you have long since heard the news, that a sulky\r\nchurlish boor has destroyed the ancient statue, or rather bas-relief,\r\npopularly called Robin of Redesdale. It seems Robin\xe2\x80\x99s fame attracted\r\nmore visitants than was consistent with the growth of the heather, upon\r\na moor worth a shilling an acre. Reverend as you write yourself, be\r\nrevengeful for once, and pray with me that he may be visited with such\r\na fit of the stone, as if he had all the fragments of poor Robin in\r\nthat region of his viscera where the disease holds its seat. Tell this\r\nnot in Gath, lest the Scots rejoice that they have at length found a\r\nparallel instance among their neighbours, to that barbarous deed which\r\ndemolished Arthur\xe2\x80\x99s Oven. But there is no end to lamentation, when we\r\nbetake ourselves to such subjects. My respectful compliments attend\r\nMiss Dryasdust; I endeavoured to match the spectacles agreeable to her\r\ncommission, during my late journey to London, and hope she has received\r\nthem safe, and found them satisfactory. I send this by the blind\r\ncarrier, so that probably it may be some time upon its journey. 6\r\n\r\nThe last news which I hear from Edinburgh is, that the gentleman who\r\nfills the situation of Secretary to the Society of Antiquaries of\r\nScotland, 7 is the best amateur draftsman in that kingdom, and that\r\nmuch is expected from his skill and zeal in delineating those specimens\r\nof national antiquity, which are either mouldering under the slow touch\r\nof time, or swept away by modern taste, with the same besom of\r\ndestruction which John Knox used at the Reformation. Once more adieu;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cvale tandem, non immemor mei\xe2\x80\x9d. Believe me to be,\r\n\r\nReverend, and very dear Sir,\r\n\r\nYour most faithful humble Servant.\r\n\r\nLaurence Templeton.\r\n\r\nToppingwold, near Egremont, Cumberland, Nov. 17, 1817.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIVANHOE.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\nThus communed these; while to their lowly dome,\r\nThe full-fed swine return\xe2\x80\x99d with evening home;\r\nCompell\xe2\x80\x99d, reluctant, to the several sties,\r\nWith din obstreperous, and ungrateful cries.\r\n\r\n\r\nPOPE\xe2\x80\x99S ODYSSEY\r\n\r\n\r\nIn that pleasant district of merry England which is watered by the\r\nriver Don, there extended in ancient times a large forest, covering the\r\ngreater part of the beautiful hills and valleys which lie between\r\nSheffield and the pleasant town of Doncaster. The remains of this\r\nextensive wood are still to be seen at the noble seats of Wentworth, of\r\nWarncliffe Park, and around Rotherham. Here haunted of yore the\r\nfabulous Dragon of Wantley; here were fought many of the most desperate\r\nbattles during the Civil Wars of the Roses; and here also flourished in\r\nancient times those bands of gallant outlaws, whose deeds have been\r\nrendered so popular in English song.\r\n\r\nSuch being our chief scene, the date of our story refers to a period\r\ntowards the end of the reign of Richard I., when his return from his\r\nlong captivity had become an event rather wished than hoped for by his\r\ndespairing subjects, who were in the meantime subjected to every\r\nspecies of subordinate oppression. The nobles, whose power had become\r\nexorbitant during the reign of Stephen, and whom the prudence of Henry\r\nthe Second had scarce reduced to some degree of subjection to the\r\ncrown, had now resumed their ancient license in its utmost extent;\r\ndespising the feeble interference of the English Council of State,\r\nfortifying their castles, increasing the number of their dependants,\r\nreducing all around them to a state of vassalage, and striving by every\r\nmeans in their power, to place themselves each at the head of such\r\nforces as might enable him to make a figure in the national convulsions\r\nwhich appeared to be impending.\r\n\r\nThe situation of the inferior gentry, or Franklins, as they were\r\ncalled, who, by the law and spirit of the English constitution, were\r\nentitled to hold themselves independent of feudal tyranny, became now\r\nunusually precarious. If, as was most generally the case, they placed\r\nthemselves under the protection of any of the petty kings in their\r\nvicinity, accepted of feudal offices in his household, or bound\r\nthemselves by mutual treaties of alliance and protection, to support\r\nhim in his enterprises, they might indeed purchase temporary repose;\r\nbut it must be with the sacrifice of that independence which was so\r\ndear to every English bosom, and at the certain hazard of being\r\ninvolved as a party in whatever rash expedition the ambition of their\r\nprotector might lead him to undertake. On the other hand, such and so\r\nmultiplied were the means of vexation and oppression possessed by the\r\ngreat Barons, that they never wanted the pretext, and seldom the will,\r\nto harass and pursue, even to the very edge of destruction, any of\r\ntheir less powerful neighbours, who attempted to separate themselves\r\nfrom their authority, and to trust for their protection, during the\r\ndangers of the times, to their own inoffensive conduct, and to the laws\r\nof the land.\r\n\r\nA circumstance which greatly tended to enhance the tyranny of the\r\nnobility, and the sufferings of the inferior classes, arose from the\r\nconsequences of the Conquest by Duke William of Normandy. Four\r\ngenerations had not sufficed to blend the hostile blood of the Normans\r\nand Anglo-Saxons, or to unite, by common language and mutual interests,\r\ntwo hostile races, one of which still felt the elation of triumph,\r\nwhile the other groaned under all the consequences of defeat. The power\r\nhad been completely placed in the hands of the Norman nobility, by the\r\nevent of the battle of Hastings, and it had been used, as our histories\r\nassure us, with no moderate hand. The whole race of Saxon princes and\r\nnobles had been extirpated or disinherited, with few or no exceptions;\r\nnor were the numbers great who possessed land in the country of their\r\nfathers, even as proprietors of the second, or of yet inferior classes.\r\nThe royal policy had long been to weaken, by every means, legal or\r\nillegal, the strength of a part of the population which was justly\r\nconsidered as nourishing the most inveterate antipathy to their victor.\r\nAll the monarchs of the Norman race had shown the most marked\r\npredilection for their Norman subjects; the laws of the chase, and many\r\nothers equally unknown to the milder and more free spirit of the Saxon\r\nconstitution, had been fixed upon the necks of the subjugated\r\ninhabitants, to add weight, as it were, to the feudal chains with which\r\nthey were loaded. At court, and in the castles of the great nobles,\r\nwhere the pomp and state of a court was emulated, Norman-French was the\r\nonly language employed; in courts of law, the pleadings and judgments\r\nwere delivered in the same tongue. In short, French was the language of\r\nhonour, of chivalry, and even of justice, while the far more manly and\r\nexpressive Anglo-Saxon was abandoned to the use of rustics and hinds,\r\nwho knew no other. Still, however, the necessary intercourse between\r\nthe lords of the soil, and those oppressed inferior beings by whom that\r\nsoil was cultivated, occasioned the gradual formation of a dialect,\r\ncompounded betwixt the French and the Anglo-Saxon, in which they could\r\nrender themselves mutually intelligible to each other; and from this\r\nnecessity arose by degrees the structure of our present English\r\nlanguage, in which the speech of the victors and the vanquished have\r\nbeen so happily blended together; and which has since been so richly\r\nimproved by importations from the classical languages, and from those\r\nspoken by the southern nations of Europe.\r\n\r\nThis state of things I have thought it necessary to premise for the\r\ninformation of the general reader, who might be apt to forget, that,\r\nalthough no great historical events, such as war or insurrection, mark\r\nthe existence of the Anglo-Saxons as a separate people subsequent to\r\nthe reign of William the Second; yet the great national distinctions\r\nbetwixt them and their conquerors, the recollection of what they had\r\nformerly been, and to what they were now reduced, continued down to the\r\nreign of Edward the Third, to keep open the wounds which the Conquest\r\nhad inflicted, and to maintain a line of separation betwixt the\r\ndescendants of the victor Normans and the vanquished Saxons.\r\n\r\nThe sun was setting upon one of the rich grassy glades of that forest,\r\nwhich we have mentioned in the beginning of the chapter. Hundreds of\r\nbroad-headed, short-stemmed, wide-branched oaks, which had witnessed\r\nperhaps the stately march of the Roman soldiery, flung their gnarled\r\narms over a thick carpet of the most delicious green sward; in some\r\nplaces they were intermingled with beeches, hollies, and copsewood of\r\nvarious descriptions, so closely as totally to intercept the level\r\nbeams of the sinking sun; in others they receded from each other,\r\nforming those long sweeping vistas, in the intricacy of which the eye\r\ndelights to lose itself, while imagination considers them as the paths\r\nto yet wilder scenes of silvan solitude. Here the red rays of the sun\r\nshot a broken and discoloured light, that partially hung upon the\r\nshattered boughs and mossy trunks of the trees, and there they\r\nilluminated in brilliant patches the portions of turf to which they\r\nmade their way. A considerable open space, in the midst of this glade,\r\nseemed formerly to have been dedicated to the rites of Druidical\r\nsuperstition; for, on the summit of a hillock, so regular as to seem\r\nartificial, there still remained part of a circle of rough unhewn\r\nstones, of large dimensions. Seven stood upright; the rest had been\r\ndislodged from their places, probably by the zeal of some convert to\r\nChristianity, and lay, some prostrate near their former site, and\r\nothers on the side of the hill. One large stone only had found its way\r\nto the bottom, and in stopping the course of a small brook, which\r\nglided smoothly round the foot of the eminence, gave, by its\r\nopposition, a feeble voice of murmur to the placid and elsewhere silent\r\nstreamlet.\r\n\r\nThe human figures which completed this landscape, were in number two,\r\npartaking, in their dress and appearance, of that wild and rustic\r\ncharacter, which belonged to the woodlands of the West-Riding of\r\nYorkshire at that early period. The eldest of these men had a stern,\r\nsavage, and wild aspect. His garment was of the simplest form\r\nimaginable, being a close jacket with sleeves, composed of the tanned\r\nskin of some animal, on which the hair had been originally left, but\r\nwhich had been worn off in so many places, that it would have been\r\ndifficult to distinguish from the patches that remained, to what\r\ncreature the fur had belonged. This primeval vestment reached from the\r\nthroat to the knees, and served at once all the usual purposes of\r\nbody-clothing; there was no wider opening at the collar, than was\r\nnecessary to admit the passage of the head, from which it may be\r\ninferred, that it was put on by slipping it over the head and\r\nshoulders, in the manner of a modern shirt, or ancient hauberk.\r\nSandals, bound with thongs made of boars\xe2\x80\x99 hide, protected the feet, and\r\na roll of thin leather was twined artificially round the legs, and,\r\nascending above the calf, left the knees bare, like those of a Scottish\r\nHighlander. To make the jacket sit yet more close to the body, it was\r\ngathered at the middle by a broad leathern belt, secured by a brass\r\nbuckle; to one side of which was attached a sort of scrip, and to the\r\nother a ram\xe2\x80\x99s horn, accoutred with a mouthpiece, for the purpose of\r\nblowing. In the same belt was stuck one of those long, broad,\r\nsharp-pointed, and two-edged knives, with a buck\xe2\x80\x99s-horn handle, which\r\nwere fabricated in the neighbourhood, and bore even at this early\r\nperiod the name of a Sheffield whittle. The man had no covering upon\r\nhis head, which was only defended by his own thick hair, matted and\r\ntwisted together, and scorched by the influence of the sun into a rusty\r\ndark-red colour, forming a contrast with the overgrown beard upon his\r\ncheeks, which was rather of a yellow or amber hue. One part of his\r\ndress only remains, but it is too remarkable to be suppressed; it was a\r\nbrass ring, resembling a dog\xe2\x80\x99s collar, but without any opening, and\r\nsoldered fast round his neck, so loose as to form no impediment to his\r\nbreathing, yet so tight as to be incapable of being removed, excepting\r\nby the use of the file. On this singular gorget was engraved, in Saxon\r\ncharacters, an inscription of the following purport:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGurth, the son of\r\nBeowulph, is the born thrall of Cedric of Rotherwood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeside the swine-herd, for such was Gurth\xe2\x80\x99s occupation, was seated,\r\nupon one of the fallen Druidical monuments, a person about ten years\r\nyounger in appearance, and whose dress, though resembling his\r\ncompanion\xe2\x80\x99s in form, was of better materials, and of a more fantastic\r\nappearance. His jacket had been stained of a bright purple hue, upon\r\nwhich there had been some attempt to paint grotesque ornaments in\r\ndifferent colours. To the jacket he added a short cloak, which scarcely\r\nreached half way down his thigh; it was of crimson cloth, though a good\r\ndeal soiled, lined with bright yellow; and as he could transfer it from\r\none shoulder to the other, or at his pleasure draw it all around him,\r\nits width, contrasted with its want of longitude, formed a fantastic\r\npiece of drapery. He had thin silver bracelets upon his arms, and on\r\nhis neck a collar of the same metal bearing the inscription, \xe2\x80\x9cWamba,\r\nthe son of Witless, is the thrall of Cedric of Rotherwood.\xe2\x80\x9d This\r\npersonage had the same sort of sandals with his companion, but instead\r\nof the roll of leather thong, his legs were cased in a sort of gaiters,\r\nof which one was red and the other yellow. He was provided also with a\r\ncap, having around it more than one bell, about the size of those\r\nattached to hawks, which jingled as he turned his head to one side or\r\nother; and as he seldom remained a minute in the same posture, the\r\nsound might be considered as incessant. Around the edge of this cap was\r\na stiff bandeau of leather, cut at the top into open work, resembling a\r\ncoronet, while a prolonged bag arose from within it, and fell down on\r\none shoulder like an old-fashioned nightcap, or a jelly-bag, or the\r\nhead-gear of a modern hussar. It was to this part of the cap that the\r\nbells were attached; which circumstance, as well as the shape of his\r\nhead-dress, and his own half-crazed, half-cunning expression of\r\ncountenance, sufficiently pointed him out as belonging to the race of\r\ndomestic clowns or jesters, maintained in the houses of the wealthy, to\r\nhelp away the tedium of those lingering hours which they were obliged\r\nto spend within doors. He bore, like his companion, a scrip, attached\r\nto his belt, but had neither horn nor knife, being probably considered\r\nas belonging to a class whom it is esteemed dangerous to intrust with\r\nedge-tools. In place of these, he was equipped with a sword of lath,\r\nresembling that with which Harlequin operates his wonders upon the\r\nmodern stage.\r\n\r\nThe outward appearance of these two men formed scarce a stronger\r\ncontrast than their look and demeanour. That of the serf, or bondsman,\r\nwas sad and sullen; his aspect was bent on the ground with an\r\nappearance of deep dejection, which might be almost construed into\r\napathy, had not the fire which occasionally sparkled in his red eye\r\nmanifested that there slumbered, under the appearance of sullen\r\ndespondency, a sense of oppression, and a disposition to resistance.\r\nThe looks of Wamba, on the other hand, indicated, as usual with his\r\nclass, a sort of vacant curiosity, and fidgetty impatience of any\r\nposture of repose, together with the utmost self-satisfaction\r\nrespecting his own situation, and the appearance which he made. The\r\ndialogue which they maintained between them, was carried on in\r\nAnglo-Saxon, which, as we said before, was universally spoken by the\r\ninferior classes, excepting the Norman soldiers, and the immediate\r\npersonal dependants of the great feudal nobles. But to give their\r\nconversation in the original would convey but little information to the\r\nmodern reader, for whose benefit we beg to offer the following\r\ntranslation:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe curse of St Withold upon these infernal porkers!\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nswine-herd, after blowing his horn obstreperously, to collect together\r\nthe scattered herd of swine, which, answering his call with notes\r\nequally melodious, made, however, no haste to remove themselves from\r\nthe luxurious banquet of beech-mast and acorns on which they had\r\nfattened, or to forsake the marshy banks of the rivulet, where several\r\nof them, half plunged in mud, lay stretched at their ease, altogether\r\nregardless of the voice of their keeper. \xe2\x80\x9cThe curse of St Withold upon\r\nthem and upon me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth; \xe2\x80\x9cif the two-legged wolf snap not up some\r\nof them ere nightfall, I am no true man. Here, Fangs! Fangs!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nejaculated at the top of his voice to a ragged wolfish-looking dog, a\r\nsort of lurcher, half mastiff, half greyhound, which ran limping about\r\nas if with the purpose of seconding his master in collecting the\r\nrefractory grunters; but which, in fact, from misapprehension of the\r\nswine-herd\xe2\x80\x99s signals, ignorance of his own duty, or malice prepense,\r\nonly drove them hither and thither, and increased the evil which he\r\nseemed to design to remedy. \xe2\x80\x9cA devil draw the teeth of him,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nGurth, \xe2\x80\x9cand the mother of mischief confound the Ranger of the forest,\r\nthat cuts the foreclaws off our dogs, and makes them unfit for their\r\ntrade! 8 Wamba, up and help me an thou be\xe2\x80\x99st a man; take a turn round\r\nthe back o\xe2\x80\x99 the hill to gain the wind on them; and when thous\xe2\x80\x99t got the\r\nweather-gage, thou mayst drive them before thee as gently as so many\r\ninnocent lambs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, without stirring from the spot, \xe2\x80\x9cI have consulted\r\nmy legs upon this matter, and they are altogether of opinion, that to\r\ncarry my gay garments through these sloughs, would be an act of\r\nunfriendship to my sovereign person and royal wardrobe; wherefore,\r\nGurth, I advise thee to call off Fangs, and leave the herd to their\r\ndestiny, which, whether they meet with bands of travelling soldiers, or\r\nof outlaws, or of wandering pilgrims, can be little else than to be\r\nconverted into Normans before morning, to thy no small ease and\r\ncomfort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe swine turned Normans to my comfort!\xe2\x80\x9d quoth Gurth; \xe2\x80\x9cexpound that to\r\nme, Wamba, for my brain is too dull, and my mind too vexed, to read\r\nriddles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, how call you those grunting brutes running about on their four\r\nlegs?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Wamba.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSwine, fool, swine,\xe2\x80\x9d said the herd, \xe2\x80\x9cevery fool knows that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd swine is good Saxon,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester; \xe2\x80\x9cbut how call you the sow\r\nwhen she is flayed, and drawn, and quartered, and hung up by the heels,\r\nlike a traitor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPork,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the swine-herd.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very glad every fool knows that too,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cand pork, I\r\nthink, is good Norman-French; and so when the brute lives, and is in\r\nthe charge of a Saxon slave, she goes by her Saxon name; but becomes a\r\nNorman, and is called pork, when she is carried to the Castle-hall to\r\nfeast among the nobles; what dost thou think of this, friend Gurth,\r\nha?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is but too true doctrine, friend Wamba, however it got into thy\r\nfool\xe2\x80\x99s pate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, I can tell you more,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, in the same tone; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is old\r\nAlderman Ox continues to hold his Saxon epithet, while he is under the\r\ncharge of serfs and bondsmen such as thou, but becomes Beef, a fiery\r\nFrench gallant, when he arrives before the worshipful jaws that are\r\ndestined to consume him. Mynheer Calf, too, becomes Monsieur de Veau in\r\nthe like manner; he is Saxon when he requires tendance, and takes a\r\nNorman name when he becomes matter of enjoyment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy St Dunstan,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cthou speakest but sad truths; little\r\nis left to us but the air we breathe, and that appears to have been\r\nreserved with much hesitation, solely for the purpose of enabling us to\r\nendure the tasks they lay upon our shoulders. The finest and the\r\nfattest is for their board; the loveliest is for their couch; the best\r\nand bravest supply their foreign masters with soldiers, and whiten\r\ndistant lands with their bones, leaving few here who have either will\r\nor the power to protect the unfortunate Saxon. God\xe2\x80\x99s blessing on our\r\nmaster Cedric, he hath done the work of a man in standing in the gap;\r\nbut Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf is coming down to this country in person,\r\nand we shall soon see how little Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s trouble will avail him.\xe2\x80\x94Here,\r\nhere,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed again, raising his voice, \xe2\x80\x9cSo ho! so ho! well done,\r\nFangs! thou hast them all before thee now, and bring\xe2\x80\x99st them on\r\nbravely, lad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGurth,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cI know thou thinkest me a fool, or thou\r\nwouldst not be so rash in putting thy head into my mouth. One word to\r\nReginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, or Philip de Malvoisin, that thou hast spoken\r\ntreason against the Norman,\xe2\x80\x94and thou art but a cast-away\r\nswineherd,\xe2\x80\x94thou wouldst waver on one of these trees as a terror to all\r\nevil speakers against dignities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDog, thou wouldst not betray me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cafter having led me on\r\nto speak so much at disadvantage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetray thee!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester; \xe2\x80\x9cno, that were the trick of a wise\r\nman; a fool cannot half so well help himself\xe2\x80\x94but soft, whom have we\r\nhere?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, listening to the trampling of several horses which\r\nbecame then audible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind whom,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth, who had now got his herd before him,\r\nand, with the aid of Fangs, was driving them down one of the long dim\r\nvistas which we have endeavoured to describe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but I must see the riders,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps they are\r\ncome from Fairy-land with a message from King Oberon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA murrain take thee,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the swine-herd; \xe2\x80\x9cwilt thou talk of such\r\nthings, while a terrible storm of thunder and lightning is raging\r\nwithin a few miles of us? Hark, how the thunder rumbles! and for summer\r\nrain, I never saw such broad downright flat drops fall out of the\r\nclouds; the oaks, too, notwithstanding the calm weather, sob and creak\r\nwith their great boughs as if announcing a tempest. Thou canst play the\r\nrational if thou wilt; credit me for once, and let us home ere the\r\nstorm begins to rage, for the night will be fearful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWamba seemed to feel the force of this appeal, and accompanied his\r\ncompanion, who began his journey after catching up a long quarter-staff\r\nwhich lay upon the grass beside him. This second Eumaeus strode hastily\r\ndown the forest glade, driving before him, with the assistance of\r\nFangs, the whole herd of his inharmonious charge.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\nA Monk there was, a fayre for the maistrie,\r\nAn outrider that loved venerie;\r\nA manly man, to be an Abbot able,\r\nFull many a daintie horse had he in stable:\r\nAnd whan he rode, men might his bridle hear\r\nGingeling in a whistling wind as clear,\r\nAnd eke as loud, as doth the chapell bell,\r\nThere as this lord was keeper of the cell.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAUCER\r\n\r\n\r\nNotwithstanding the occasional exhortation and chiding of his\r\ncompanion, the noise of the horsemen\xe2\x80\x99s feet continuing to approach,\r\nWamba could not be prevented from lingering occasionally on the road,\r\nupon every pretence which occurred; now catching from the hazel a\r\ncluster of half-ripe nuts, and now turning his head to leer after a\r\ncottage maiden who crossed their path. The horsemen, therefore, soon\r\novertook them on the road.\r\n\r\nTheir numbers amounted to ten men, of whom the two who rode foremost\r\nseemed to be persons of considerable importance, and the others their\r\nattendants. It was not difficult to ascertain the condition and\r\ncharacter of one of these personages. He was obviously an ecclesiastic\r\nof high rank; his dress was that of a Cistercian Monk, but composed of\r\nmaterials much finer than those which the rule of that order admitted.\r\nHis mantle and hood were of the best Flanders cloth, and fell in ample,\r\nand not ungraceful folds, around a handsome, though somewhat corpulent\r\nperson. His countenance bore as little the marks of self-denial, as his\r\nhabit indicated contempt of worldly splendour. His features might have\r\nbeen called good, had there not lurked under the pent-house of his eye,\r\nthat sly epicurean twinkle which indicates the cautious voluptuary. In\r\nother respects, his profession and situation had taught him a ready\r\ncommand over his countenance, which he could contract at pleasure into\r\nsolemnity, although its natural expression was that of good-humoured\r\nsocial indulgence. In defiance of conventual rules, and the edicts of\r\npopes and councils, the sleeves of this dignitary were lined and turned\r\nup with rich furs, his mantle secured at the throat with a golden\r\nclasp, and the whole dress proper to his order as much refined upon and\r\nornamented, as that of a quaker beauty of the present day, who, while\r\nshe retains the garb and costume of her sect continues to give to its\r\nsimplicity, by the choice of materials and the mode of disposing them,\r\na certain air of coquettish attraction, savouring but too much of the\r\nvanities of the world.\r\n\r\nThis worthy churchman rode upon a well-fed ambling mule, whose\r\nfurniture was highly decorated, and whose bridle, according to the\r\nfashion of the day, was ornamented with silver bells. In his seat he\r\nhad nothing of the awkwardness of the convent, but displayed the easy\r\nand habitual grace of a well-trained horseman. Indeed, it seemed that\r\nso humble a conveyance as a mule, in however good case, and however\r\nwell broken to a pleasant and accommodating amble, was only used by the\r\ngallant monk for travelling on the road. A lay brother, one of those\r\nwho followed in the train, had, for his use on other occasions, one of\r\nthe most handsome Spanish jennets ever bred at Andalusia, which\r\nmerchants used at that time to import, with great trouble and risk, for\r\nthe use of persons of wealth and distinction. The saddle and housings\r\nof this superb palfrey were covered by a long foot-cloth, which reached\r\nnearly to the ground, and on which were richly embroidered, mitres,\r\ncrosses, and other ecclesiastical emblems. Another lay brother led a\r\nsumpter mule, loaded probably with his superior\xe2\x80\x99s baggage; and two\r\nmonks of his own order, of inferior station, rode together in the rear,\r\nlaughing and conversing with each other, without taking much notice of\r\nthe other members of the cavalcade.\r\n\r\nThe companion of the church dignitary was a man past forty, thin,\r\nstrong, tall, and muscular; an athletic figure, which long fatigue and\r\nconstant exercise seemed to have left none of the softer part of the\r\nhuman form, having reduced the whole to brawn, bones, and sinews, which\r\nhad sustained a thousand toils, and were ready to dare a thousand more.\r\nHis head was covered with a scarlet cap, faced with fur\xe2\x80\x94of that kind\r\nwhich the French call \xe2\x80\x9cmortier\xe2\x80\x9d, from its resemblance to the shape of\r\nan inverted mortar. His countenance was therefore fully displayed, and\r\nits expression was calculated to impress a degree of awe, if not of\r\nfear, upon strangers. High features, naturally strong and powerfully\r\nexpressive, had been burnt almost into Negro blackness by constant\r\nexposure to the tropical sun, and might, in their ordinary state, be\r\nsaid to slumber after the storm of passion had passed away; but the\r\nprojection of the veins of the forehead, the readiness with which the\r\nupper lip and its thick black moustaches quivered upon the slightest\r\nemotion, plainly intimated that the tempest might be again and easily\r\nawakened. His keen, piercing, dark eyes, told in every glance a history\r\nof difficulties subdued, and dangers dared, and seemed to challenge\r\nopposition to his wishes, for the pleasure of sweeping it from his road\r\nby a determined exertion of courage and of will; a deep scar on his\r\nbrow gave additional sternness to his countenance, and a sinister\r\nexpression to one of his eyes, which had been slightly injured on the\r\nsame occasion, and of which the vision, though perfect, was in a slight\r\nand partial degree distorted.\r\n\r\nThe upper dress of this personage resembled that of his companion in\r\nshape, being a long monastic mantle; but the colour, being scarlet,\r\nshowed that he did not belong to any of the four regular orders of\r\nmonks. On the right shoulder of the mantle there was cut, in white\r\ncloth, a cross of a peculiar form.
