This upper robe concealed what at\r\nfirst view seemed rather inconsistent with its form, a shirt, namely,\r\nof linked mail, with sleeves and gloves of the same, curiously plaited\r\nand interwoven, as flexible to the body as those which are now wrought\r\nin the stocking-loom, out of less obdurate materials. The fore-part of\r\nhis thighs, where the folds of his mantle permitted them to be seen,\r\nwere also covered with linked mail; the knees and feet were defended by\r\nsplints, or thin plates of steel, ingeniously jointed upon each other;\r\nand mail hose, reaching from the ankle to the knee, effectually\r\nprotected the legs, and completed the rider\xe2\x80\x99s defensive armour. In his\r\ngirdle he wore a long and double-edged dagger, which was the only\r\noffensive weapon about his person.\r\n\r\nHe rode, not a mule, like his companion, but a strong hackney for the\r\nroad, to save his gallant war-horse, which a squire led behind, fully\r\naccoutred for battle, with a chamfron or plaited head-piece upon his\r\nhead, having a short spike projecting from the front. On one side of\r\nthe saddle hung a short battle-axe, richly inlaid with Damascene\r\ncarving; on the other the rider\xe2\x80\x99s plumed head-piece and hood of mail,\r\nwith a long two-handed sword, used by the chivalry of the period. A\r\nsecond squire held aloft his master\xe2\x80\x99s lance, from the extremity of\r\nwhich fluttered a small banderole, or streamer, bearing a cross of the\r\nsame form with that embroidered upon his cloak. He also carried his\r\nsmall triangular shield, broad enough at the top to protect the breast,\r\nand from thence diminishing to a point. It was covered with a scarlet\r\ncloth, which prevented the device from being seen.\r\n\r\nThese two squires were followed by two attendants, whose dark visages,\r\nwhite turbans, and the Oriental form of their garments, showed them to\r\nbe natives of some distant Eastern country. 9\r\n\r\nThe whole appearance of this warrior and his retinue was wild and\r\noutlandish; the dress of his squires was gorgeous, and his Eastern\r\nattendants wore silver collars round their throats, and bracelets of\r\nthe same metal upon their swarthy arms and legs, of which the former\r\nwere naked from the elbow, and the latter from mid-leg to ankle. Silk\r\nand embroidery distinguished their dresses, and marked the wealth and\r\nimportance of their master; forming, at the same time, a striking\r\ncontrast with the martial simplicity of his own attire. They were armed\r\nwith crooked sabres, having the hilt and baldric inlaid with gold, and\r\nmatched with Turkish daggers of yet more costly workmanship. Each of\r\nthem bore at his saddle-bow a bundle of darts or javelins, about four\r\nfeet in length, having sharp steel heads, a weapon much in use among\r\nthe Saracens, and of which the memory is yet preserved in the martial\r\nexercise called \xe2\x80\x9cEl Jerrid\xe2\x80\x9d, still practised in the Eastern countries.\r\n\r\nThe steeds of these attendants were in appearance as foreign as their\r\nriders. They were of Saracen origin, and consequently of Arabian\r\ndescent; and their fine slender limbs, small fetlocks, thin manes, and\r\neasy springy motion, formed a marked contrast with the large-jointed,\r\nheavy horses, of which the race was cultivated in Flanders and in\r\nNormandy, for mounting the men-at-arms of the period in all the panoply\r\nof plate and mail; and which, placed by the side of those Eastern\r\ncoursers, might have passed for a personification of substance and of\r\nshadow.\r\n\r\nThe singular appearance of this cavalcade not only attracted the\r\ncuriosity of Wamba, but excited even that of his less volatile\r\ncompanion. The monk he instantly knew to be the Prior of Jorvaulx\r\nAbbey, well known for many miles around as a lover of the chase, of the\r\nbanquet, and, if fame did him not wrong, of other worldly pleasures\r\nstill more inconsistent with his monastic vows.\r\n\r\nYet so loose were the ideas of the times respecting the conduct of the\r\nclergy, whether secular or regular, that the Prior Aymer maintained a\r\nfair character in the neighbourhood of his abbey. His free and jovial\r\ntemper, and the readiness with which he granted absolution from all\r\nordinary delinquencies, rendered him a favourite among the nobility and\r\nprincipal gentry, to several of whom he was allied by birth, being of a\r\ndistinguished Norman family. The ladies, in particular, were not\r\ndisposed to scan too nicely the morals of a man who was a professed\r\nadmirer of their sex, and who possessed many means of dispelling the\r\nennui which was too apt to intrude upon the halls and bowers of an\r\nancient feudal castle. The Prior mingled in the sports of the field\r\nwith more than due eagerness, and was allowed to possess the\r\nbest-trained hawks, and the fleetest greyhounds in the North Riding;\r\ncircumstances which strongly recommended him to the youthful gentry.\r\nWith the old, he had another part to play, which, when needful, he\r\ncould sustain with great decorum. His knowledge of books, however\r\nsuperficial, was sufficient to impress upon their ignorance respect for\r\nhis supposed learning; and the gravity of his deportment and language,\r\nwith the high tone which he exerted in setting forth the authority of\r\nthe church and of the priesthood, impressed them no less with an\r\nopinion of his sanctity. Even the common people, the severest critics\r\nof the conduct of their betters, had commiseration with the follies of\r\nPrior Aymer. He was generous; and charity, as it is well known,\r\ncovereth a multitude of sins, in another sense than that in which it is\r\nsaid to do so in Scripture. The revenues of the monastery, of which a\r\nlarge part was at his disposal, while they gave him the means of\r\nsupplying his own very considerable expenses, afforded also those\r\nlargesses which he bestowed among the peasantry, and with which he\r\nfrequently relieved the distresses of the oppressed. If Prior Aymer\r\nrode hard in the chase, or remained long at the banquet,\xe2\x80\x94if Prior Aymer\r\nwas seen, at the early peep of dawn, to enter the postern of the abbey,\r\nas he glided home from some rendezvous which had occupied the hours of\r\ndarkness, men only shrugged up their shoulders, and reconciled\r\nthemselves to his irregularities, by recollecting that the same were\r\npractised by many of his brethren who had no redeeming qualities\r\nwhatsoever to atone for them. Prior Aymer, therefore, and his\r\ncharacter, were well known to our Saxon serfs, who made their rude\r\nobeisance, and received his \xe2\x80\x9cbenedicite, mes filz,\xe2\x80\x9d in return.\r\n\r\nBut the singular appearance of his companion and his attendants,\r\narrested their attention and excited their wonder, and they could\r\nscarcely attend to the Prior of Jorvaulx\xe2\x80\x99 question, when he demanded if\r\nthey knew of any place of harbourage in the vicinity; so much were they\r\nsurprised at the half monastic, half military appearance of the swarthy\r\nstranger, and at the uncouth dress and arms of his Eastern attendants.\r\nIt is probable, too, that the language in which the benediction was\r\nconferred, and the information asked, sounded ungracious, though not\r\nprobably unintelligible, in the ears of the Saxon peasants.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI asked you, my children,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, raising his voice, and\r\nusing the lingua Franca, or mixed language, in which the Norman and\r\nSaxon races conversed with each other, \xe2\x80\x9cif there be in this\r\nneighbourhood any good man, who, for the love of God, and devotion to\r\nMother Church, will give two of her humblest servants, with their\r\ntrain, a night\xe2\x80\x99s hospitality and refreshment?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis he spoke with a tone of conscious importance, which formed a\r\nstrong contrast to the modest terms which he thought it proper to\r\nemploy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo of the humblest servants of Mother Church!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Wamba to\r\nhimself,\xe2\x80\x94but, fool as he was, taking care not to make his observation\r\naudible; \xe2\x80\x9cI should like to see her seneschals, her chief butlers, and\r\nother principal domestics!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter this internal commentary on the Prior\xe2\x80\x99s speech, he raised his\r\neyes, and replied to the question which had been put.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the reverend fathers,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cloved good cheer and soft lodging,\r\nfew miles of riding would carry them to the Priory of Brinxworth, where\r\ntheir quality could not but secure them the most honourable reception;\r\nor if they preferred spending a penitential evening, they might turn\r\ndown yonder wild glade, which would bring them to the hermitage of\r\nCopmanhurst, where a pious anchoret would make them sharers for the\r\nnight of the shelter of his roof and the benefit of his prayers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Prior shook his head at both proposals.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMine honest friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cif the jangling of thy bells had not\r\ndizzied thine understanding, thou mightst know \xe2\x80\x9cClericus clericum non\r\ndecimat\xe2\x80\x9d; that is to say, we churchmen do not exhaust each other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhospitality, but rather require that of the laity, giving them thus an\r\nopportunity to serve God in honouring and relieving his appointed\r\nservants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I, being but an ass, am,\r\nnevertheless, honoured to hear the bells as well as your reverence\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmule; notwithstanding, I did conceive that the charity of Mother Church\r\nand her servants might be said, with other charity, to begin at home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA truce to thine insolence, fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the armed rider, breaking in\r\non his prattle with a high and stern voice, \xe2\x80\x9cand tell us, if thou\r\ncanst, the road to\xe2\x80\x94How call\xe2\x80\x99d you your Franklin, Prior Aymer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCedric,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Prior; \xe2\x80\x9cCedric the Saxon.\xe2\x80\x94Tell me, good fellow,\r\nare we near his dwelling, and can you show us the road?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe road will be uneasy to find,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth, who broke silence\r\nfor the first time, \xe2\x80\x9cand the family of Cedric retire early to rest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTush, tell not me, fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the military rider; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99tis easy for\r\nthem to arise and supply the wants of travellers such as we are, who\r\nwill not stoop to beg the hospitality which we have a right to\r\ncommand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, sullenly, \xe2\x80\x9cif I should show the way to my\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s house, to those who demand as a right, the shelter which most\r\nare fain to ask as a favour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you dispute with me, slave!\xe2\x80\x9d said the soldier; and, setting spurs\r\nto his horse, he caused him make a demivolte across the path, raising\r\nat the same time the riding rod which he held in his hand, with a\r\npurpose of chastising what he considered as the insolence of the\r\npeasant.\r\n\r\nGurth darted at him a savage and revengeful scowl, and with a fierce,\r\nyet hesitating motion, laid his hand on the haft of his knife; but the\r\ninterference of Prior Aymer, who pushed his mule betwixt his companion\r\nand the swineherd, prevented the meditated violence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, by St Mary, brother Brian, you must not think you are now in\r\nPalestine, predominating over heathen Turks and infidel Saracens; we\r\nislanders love not blows, save those of holy Church, who chasteneth\r\nwhom she loveth.\xe2\x80\x94Tell me, good fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Wamba, and seconded\r\nhis speech by a small piece of silver coin, \xe2\x80\x9cthe way to Cedric the\r\nSaxon\xe2\x80\x99s; you cannot be ignorant of it, and it is your duty to direct\r\nthe wanderer even when his character is less sanctified than ours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn truth, venerable father,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Saracen head of\r\nyour right reverend companion has frightened out of mine the way home\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nam not sure I shall get there to-night myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTush,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Abbot, \xe2\x80\x9cthou canst tell us if thou wilt. This reverend\r\nbrother has been all his life engaged in fighting among the Saracens\r\nfor the recovery of the Holy Sepulchre; he is of the order of Knights\r\nTemplars, whom you may have heard of; he is half a monk, half a\r\nsoldier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he is but half a monk,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9che should not be wholly\r\nunreasonable with those whom he meets upon the road, even if they\r\nshould be in no hurry to answer questions that no way concern them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI forgive thy wit,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Abbot, \xe2\x80\x9con condition thou wilt show me\r\nthe way to Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s mansion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cyour reverences must hold on this path\r\ntill you come to a sunken cross, of which scarce a cubit\xe2\x80\x99s length\r\nremains above ground; then take the path to the left, for there are\r\nfour which meet at Sunken Cross, and I trust your reverences will\r\nobtain shelter before the storm comes on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nThe Abbot thanked his sage adviser; and the cavalcade, setting spurs to\r\ntheir horses, rode on as men do who wish to reach their inn before the\r\nbursting of a night-storm. As their horses\xe2\x80\x99 hoofs died away, Gurth said\r\nto his companion, \xe2\x80\x9cIf they follow thy wise direction, the reverend\r\nfathers will hardly reach Rotherwood this night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, grinning, \xe2\x80\x9cbut they may reach Sheffield if they\r\nhave good luck, and that is as fit a place for them. I am not so bad a\r\nwoodsman as to show the dog where the deer lies, if I have no mind he\r\nshould chase him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth; \xe2\x80\x9cit were ill that Aymer saw the Lady\r\nRowena; and it were worse, it may be, for Cedric to quarrel, as is most\r\nlikely he would, with this military monk. But, like good servants let\r\nus hear and see, and say nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe return to the riders, who had soon left the bondsmen far behind\r\nthem, and who maintained the following conversation in the\r\nNorman-French language, usually employed by the superior classes, with\r\nthe exception of the few who were still inclined to boast their Saxon\r\ndescent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat mean these fellows by their capricious insolence?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nTemplar to the Benedictine, \xe2\x80\x9cand why did you prevent me from chastising\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarry, brother Brian,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9ctouching the one of them,\r\nit were hard for me to render a reason for a fool speaking according to\r\nhis folly; and the other churl is of that savage, fierce, intractable\r\nrace, some of whom, as I have often told you, are still to be found\r\namong the descendants of the conquered Saxons, and whose supreme\r\npleasure it is to testify, by all means in their power, their aversion\r\nto their conquerors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would soon have beat him into courtesy,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Brian; \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\naccustomed to deal with such spirits: Our Turkish captives are as\r\nfierce and intractable as Odin himself could have been; yet two months\r\nin my household, under the management of my master of the slaves, has\r\nmade them humble, submissive, serviceable, and observant of your will.\r\nMarry, sir, you must be aware of the poison and the dagger; for they\r\nuse either with free will when you give them the slightest\r\nopportunity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Prior Aymer, \xe2\x80\x9cevery land has its own manners and\r\nfashions; and, besides that beating this fellow could procure us no\r\ninformation respecting the road to Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s house, it would have been\r\nsure to have established a quarrel betwixt you and him had we found our\r\nway thither. Remember what I told you: this wealthy franklin is proud,\r\nfierce, jealous, and irritable, a withstander of the nobility, and even\r\nof his neighbors, Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and Philip Malvoisin, who are\r\nno babies to strive with. He stands up sternly for the privileges of\r\nhis race, and is so proud of his uninterrupted descend from Hereward, a\r\nrenowned champion of the Heptarchy, that he is universally called\r\nCedric the Saxon; and makes a boast of his belonging to a people from\r\nwhom many others endeaver to hide their descent, lest they should\r\nencounter a share of the \xe2\x80\x98vae victis,\xe2\x80\x99 or severities imposed upon the\r\nvanquished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrior Aymer,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are a man of gallantry, learned\r\nin the study of beauty, and as expert as a troubadour in all matters\r\nconcerning the \xe2\x80\x98arrets\xe2\x80\x99 of love; but I shall expect much beauty in this\r\ncelebrated Rowena to counterbalance the self-denial and forbearance\r\nwhich I must exert if I am to court the favor of such a seditious churl\r\nas you have described her father Cedric.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCedric is not her father,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cand is but of remote\r\nrelation: she is descended from higher blood than even he pretends to,\r\nand is but distantly connected with him by birth. Her guardian,\r\nhowever, he is, self-constituted as I believe; but his ward is as dear\r\nto him as if she were his own child. Of her beauty you shall soon be\r\njudge; and if the purity of her complexion, and the majestic, yet soft\r\nexpression of a mild blue eye, do not chase from your memory the\r\nblack-tressed girls of Palestine, ay, or the houris of old Mahound\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nparadise, I am an infidel, and no true son of the church.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShould your boasted beauty,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cbe weighed in the\r\nbalance and found wanting, you know our wager?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy gold collar,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cagainst ten butts of Chian\r\nwine;\xe2\x80\x94they are mine as securely as if they were already in the convent\r\nvaults, under the key of old Dennis the cellarer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am myself to be judge,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cand am only to be\r\nconvicted on my own admission, that I have seen no maiden so beautiful\r\nsince Pentecost was a twelvemonth. Ran it not so?\xe2\x80\x94Prior, your collar is\r\nin danger; I will wear it over my gorget in the lists of\r\nAshby-de-la-Zouche.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWin it fairly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cand wear it as ye will; I will trust\r\nyour giving true response, on your word as a knight and as a churchman.\r\nYet, brother, take my advice, and file your tongue to a little more\r\ncourtesy than your habits of predominating over infidel captives and\r\nEastern bondsmen have accustomed you. Cedric the Saxon, if\r\noffended,\xe2\x80\x94and he is noway slack in taking offence,\xe2\x80\x94is a man who,\r\nwithout respect to your knighthood, my high office, or the sanctity of\r\neither, would clear his house of us, and send us to lodge with the\r\nlarks, though the hour were midnight. And be careful how you look on\r\nRowena, whom he cherishes with the most jealous care; an he take the\r\nleast alarm in that quarter we are but lost men. It is said he banished\r\nhis only son from his family for lifting his eyes in the way of\r\naffection towards this beauty, who may be worshipped, it seems, at a\r\ndistance, but is not to be approached with other thoughts than such as\r\nwe bring to the shrine of the Blessed Virgin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you have said enough,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cI will for a night\r\nput on the needful restraint, and deport me as meekly as a maiden; but\r\nas for the fear of his expelling us by violence, myself and squires,\r\nwith Hamet and Abdalla, will warrant you against that disgrace. Doubt\r\nnot that we shall be strong enough to make good our quarters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must not let it come so far,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Prior; \xe2\x80\x9cbut here is the\r\nclown\xe2\x80\x99s sunken cross, and the night is so dark that we can hardly see\r\nwhich of the roads we are to follow. He bid us turn, I think to the\r\nleft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Brian, \xe2\x80\x9cto the best of my remembrance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the left, certainly, the left; I remember his pointing with his\r\nwooden sword.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but he held his sword in his left hand, and so pointed across his\r\nbody with it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar.\r\n\r\nEach maintained his opinion with sufficient obstinacy, as is usual in\r\nall such cases; the attendants were appealed to, but they had not been\r\nnear enough to hear Wamba\xe2\x80\x99s directions. At length Brian remarked, what\r\nhad at first escaped him in the twilight; \xe2\x80\x9cHere is some one either\r\nasleep, or lying dead at the foot of this cross\xe2\x80\x94Hugo, stir him with the\r\nbutt-end of thy lance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was no sooner done than the figure arose, exclaiming in good\r\nFrench, \xe2\x80\x9cWhosoever thou art, it is discourteous in you to disturb my\r\nthoughts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe did but wish to ask you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cthe road to Rotherwood,\r\nthe abode of Cedric the Saxon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI myself am bound thither,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the stranger; \xe2\x80\x9cand if I had a\r\nhorse, I would be your guide, for the way is somewhat intricate, though\r\nperfectly well known to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou shalt have both thanks and reward, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif thou wilt bring us to Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s in safety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he caused one of his attendants to mount his own led horse, and\r\ngive that upon which he had hitherto ridden to the stranger, who was to\r\nserve for a guide.\r\n\r\nTheir conductor pursued an opposite road from that which Wamba had\r\nrecommended, for the purpose of misleading them. The path soon led\r\ndeeper into the woodland, and crossed more than one brook, the approach\r\nto which was rendered perilous by the marshes through which it flowed;\r\nbut the stranger seemed to know, as if by instinct, the soundest ground\r\nand the safest points of passage; and by dint of caution and attention,\r\nbrought the party safely into a wilder avenue than any they had yet\r\nseen; and, pointing to a large low irregular building at the upper\r\nextremity, he said to the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cYonder is Rotherwood, the dwelling of\r\nCedric the Saxon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was a joyful intimation to Aymer, whose nerves were none of the\r\nstrongest, and who had suffered such agitation and alarm in the course\r\nof passing through the dangerous bogs, that he had not yet had the\r\ncuriosity to ask his guide a single question. Finding himself now at\r\nhis ease and near shelter, his curiosity began to awake, and he\r\ndemanded of the guide who and what he was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Palmer, just returned from the Holy Land,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had better have tarried there to fight for the recovery of the\r\nHoly Sepulchre,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, Reverend Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Palmer, to whom the\r\nappearance of the Templar seemed perfectly familiar; \xe2\x80\x9cbut when those\r\nwho are under oath to recover the holy city, are found travelling at\r\nsuch a distance from the scene of their duties, can you wonder that a\r\npeaceful peasant like me should decline the task which they have\r\nabandoned?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Templar would have made an angry reply, but was interrupted by the\r\nPrior, who again expressed his astonishment, that their guide, after\r\nsuch long absence, should be so perfectly acquainted with the passes of\r\nthe forest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was born a native of these parts,\xe2\x80\x9d answered their guide, and as he\r\nmade the reply they stood before the mansion of Cedric;\xe2\x80\x94a low irregular\r\nbuilding, containing several court-yards or enclosures, extending over\r\na considerable space of ground, and which, though its size argued the\r\ninhabitant to be a person of wealth, differed entirely from the tall,\r\nturretted, and castellated buildings in which the Norman nobility\r\nresided, and which had become the universal style of architecture\r\nthroughout England.\r\n\r\nRotherwood was not, however, without defences; no habitation, in that\r\ndisturbed period, could have been so, without the risk of being\r\nplundered and burnt before the next morning. A deep fosse, or ditch,\r\nwas drawn round the whole building, and filled with water from a\r\nneighbouring stream. A double stockade, or palisade, composed of\r\npointed beams, which the adjacent forest supplied, defended the outer\r\nand inner bank of the trench. There was an entrance from the west\r\nthrough the outer stockade, which communicated by a drawbridge, with a\r\nsimilar opening in the interior defences. Some precautions had been\r\ntaken to place those entrances under the protection of projecting\r\nangles, by which they might be flanked in case of need by archers or\r\nslingers.\r\n\r\nBefore this entrance the Templar wound his horn loudly; for the rain,\r\nwhich had long threatened, began now to descend with great violence.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\nThen (sad relief!) from the bleak coast that hears\r\nThe German Ocean roar, deep-blooming, strong,\r\nAnd yellow hair\xe2\x80\x99d, the blue-eyed Saxon came.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHOMSON\xe2\x80\x99S LIBERTY\r\n\r\n\r\nIn a hall, the height of which was greatly disproportioned to its\r\nextreme length and width, a long oaken table, formed of planks\r\nrough-hewn from the forest, and which had scarcely received any polish,\r\nstood ready prepared for the evening meal of Cedric the Saxon. The\r\nroof, composed of beams and rafters, had nothing to divide the\r\napartment from the sky excepting the planking and thatch; there was a\r\nhuge fireplace at either end of the hall, but as the chimneys were\r\nconstructed in a very clumsy manner, at least as much of the smoke\r\nfound its way into the apartment as escaped by the proper vent. The\r\nconstant vapour which this occasioned, had polished the rafters and\r\nbeams of the low-browed hall, by encrusting them with a black varnish\r\nof soot. On the sides of the apartment hung implements of war and of\r\nthe chase, and there were at each corner folding doors, which gave\r\naccess to other parts of the extensive building.\r\n\r\nThe other appointments of the mansion partook of the rude simplicity of\r\nthe Saxon period, which Cedric piqued himself upon maintaining. The\r\nfloor was composed of earth mixed with lime, trodden into a hard\r\nsubstance, such as is often employed in flooring our modern barns. For\r\nabout one quarter of the length of the apartment, the floor was raised\r\nby a step, and this space, which was called the dais, was occupied only\r\nby the principal members of the family, and visitors of distinction.\r\nFor this purpose, a table richly covered with scarlet cloth was placed\r\ntransversely across the platform, from the middle of which ran the\r\nlonger and lower board, at which the domestics and inferior persons\r\nfed, down towards the bottom of the hall. The whole resembled the form\r\nof the letter T, or some of those ancient dinner-tables, which,\r\narranged on the same principles, may be still seen in the antique\r\nColleges of Oxford or Cambridge. Massive chairs and settles of carved\r\noak were placed upon the dais, and over these seats and the more\r\nelevated table was fastened a canopy of cloth, which served in some\r\ndegree to protect the dignitaries who occupied that distinguished\r\nstation from the weather, and especially from the rain, which in some\r\nplaces found its way through the ill-constructed roof.\r\n\r\nThe walls of this upper end of the hall, as far as the dais extended,\r\nwere covered with hangings or curtains, and upon the floor there was a\r\ncarpet, both of which were adorned with some attempts at tapestry, or\r\nembroidery, executed with brilliant or rather gaudy colouring. Over the\r\nlower range of table, the roof, as we have noticed, had no covering;\r\nthe rough plastered walls were left bare, and the rude earthen floor\r\nwas uncarpeted; the board was uncovered by a cloth, and rude massive\r\nbenches supplied the place of chairs.\r\n\r\nIn the centre of the upper table, were placed two chairs more elevated\r\nthan the rest, for the master and mistress of the family, who presided\r\nover the scene of hospitality, and from doing so derived their Saxon\r\ntitle of honour, which signifies \xe2\x80\x9cthe Dividers of Bread.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo each of these chairs was added a footstool, curiously carved and\r\ninlaid with ivory, which mark of distinction was peculiar to them. One\r\nof these seats was at present occupied by Cedric the Saxon, who, though\r\nbut in rank a thane, or, as the Normans called him, a Franklin, felt,\r\nat the delay of his evening meal, an irritable impatience, which might\r\nhave become an alderman, whether of ancient or of modern times.\r\n\r\nIt appeared, indeed, from the countenance of this proprietor, that he\r\nwas of a frank, but hasty and choleric temper. He was not above the\r\nmiddle stature, but broad-shouldered, long-armed, and powerfully made,\r\nlike one accustomed to endure the fatigue of war or of the chase; his\r\nface was broad, with large blue eyes, open and frank features, fine\r\nteeth, and a well formed head, altogether expressive of that sort of\r\ngood-humour which often lodges with a sudden and hasty temper. Pride\r\nand jealousy there was in his eye, for his life had been spent in\r\nasserting rights which were constantly liable to invasion; and the\r\nprompt, fiery, and resolute disposition of the man, had been kept\r\nconstantly upon the alert by the circumstances of his situation. His\r\nlong yellow hair was equally divided on the top of his head and upon\r\nhis brow, and combed down on each side to the length of his shoulders;\r\nit had but little tendency to grey, although Cedric was approaching to\r\nhis sixtieth year.\r\n\r\nHis dress was a tunic of forest green, furred at the throat and cuffs\r\nwith what was called minever; a kind of fur inferior in quality to\r\nermine, and formed, it is believed, of the skin of the grey squirrel.\r\nThis doublet hung unbuttoned over a close dress of scarlet which sat\r\ntight to his body; he had breeches of the same, but they did not reach\r\nbelow the lower part of the thigh, leaving the knee exposed. His feet\r\nhad sandals of the same fashion with the peasants, but of finer\r\nmaterials, and secured in the front with golden clasps. He had\r\nbracelets of gold upon his arms, and a broad collar of the same\r\nprecious metal around his neck. About his waist he wore a\r\nrichly-studded belt, in which was stuck a short straight two-edged\r\nsword, with a sharp point, so disposed as to hang almost\r\nperpendicularly by his side. Behind his seat was hung a scarlet cloth\r\ncloak lined with fur, and a cap of the same materials richly\r\nembroidered, which completed the dress of the opulent landholder when\r\nhe chose to go forth. A short boar-spear, with a broad and bright steel\r\nhead, also reclined against the back of his chair, which served him,\r\nwhen he walked abroad, for the purposes of a staff or of a weapon, as\r\nchance might require.\r\n\r\nSeveral domestics, whose dress held various proportions betwixt the\r\nrichness of their master\xe2\x80\x99s, and the coarse and simple attire of Gurth\r\nthe swine-herd, watched the looks and waited the commands of the Saxon\r\ndignitary. Two or three servants of a superior order stood behind their\r\nmaster upon the dais; the rest occupied the lower part of the hall.\r\nOther attendants there were of a different description; two or three\r\nlarge and shaggy greyhounds, such as were then employed in hunting the\r\nstag and wolf; as many slow-hounds of a large bony breed, with thick\r\nnecks, large heads, and long ears; and one or two of the smaller dogs,\r\nnow called terriers, which waited with impatience the arrival of the\r\nsupper; but, with the sagacious knowledge of physiognomy peculiar to\r\ntheir race, forbore to intrude upon the moody silence of their master,\r\napprehensive probably of a small white truncheon which lay by Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntrencher, for the purpose of repelling the advances of his four-legged\r\ndependants. One grisly old wolf-dog alone, with the liberty of an\r\nindulged favourite, had planted himself close by the chair of state,\r\nand occasionally ventured to solicit notice by putting his large hairy\r\nhead upon his master\xe2\x80\x99s knee, or pushing his nose into his hand. Even he\r\nwas repelled by the stern command, \xe2\x80\x9cDown, Balder, down! I am not in the\r\nhumour for foolery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, Cedric, as we have observed, was in no very placid state of\r\nmind. The Lady Rowena, who had been absent to attend an evening mass at\r\na distant church, had but just returned, and was changing her garments,\r\nwhich had been wetted by the storm. There were as yet no tidings of\r\nGurth and his charge, which should long since have been driven home\r\nfrom the forest and such was the insecurity of the period, as to render\r\nit probable that the delay might be explained by some depreciation of\r\nthe outlaws, with whom the adjacent forest abounded, or by the violence\r\nof some neighbouring baron, whose consciousness of strength made him\r\nequally negligent of the laws of property. The matter was of\r\nconsequence, for great part of the domestic wealth of the Saxon\r\nproprietors consisted in numerous herds of swine, especially in\r\nforest-land, where those animals easily found their food.\r\n\r\nBesides these subjects of anxiety, the Saxon thane was impatient for\r\nthe presence of his favourite clown Wamba, whose jests, such as they\r\nwere, served for a sort of seasoning to his evening meal, and to the\r\ndeep draughts of ale and wine with which he was in the habit of\r\naccompanying it. Add to all this, Cedric had fasted since noon, and his\r\nusual supper hour was long past, a cause of irritation common to\r\ncountry squires, both in ancient and modern times. His displeasure was\r\nexpressed in broken sentences, partly muttered to himself, partly\r\naddressed to the domestics who stood around; and particularly to his\r\ncupbearer, who offered him from time to time, as a sedative, a silver\r\ngoblet filled with wine\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhy tarries the Lady Rowena?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is but changing her head-gear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied a female attendant, with\r\nas much confidence as the favourite lady\xe2\x80\x99s-maid usually answers the\r\nmaster of a modern family; \xe2\x80\x9cyou would not wish her to sit down to the\r\nbanquet in her hood and kirtle? and no lady within the shire can be\r\nquicker in arraying herself than my mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis undeniable argument produced a sort of acquiescent umph! on the\r\npart of the Saxon, with the addition, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish her devotion may choose\r\nfair weather for the next visit to St John\xe2\x80\x99s Kirk;\xe2\x80\x94but what, in the\r\nname of ten devils,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, turning to the cupbearer, and\r\nraising his voice as if happy to have found a channel into which he\r\nmight divert his indignation without fear or control\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwhat, in the name\r\nof ten devils, keeps Gurth so long afield? I suppose we shall have an\r\nevil account of the herd; he was wont to be a faithful and cautious\r\ndrudge, and I had destined him for something better; perchance I might\r\neven have made him one of my warders.\xe2\x80\x9d 11\r\n\r\nOswald the cupbearer modestly suggested, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it was scarce an hour\r\nsince the tolling of the curfew;\xe2\x80\x9d an ill-chosen apology, since it\r\nturned upon a topic so harsh to Saxon ears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe foul fiend,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9ctake the curfew-bell, and the\r\ntyrannical bastard by whom it was devised, and the heartless slave who\r\nnames it with a Saxon tongue to a Saxon ear! The curfew!\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\r\npausing, \xe2\x80\x9cay, the curfew; which compels true men to extinguish their\r\nlights, that thieves and robbers may work their deeds in darkness!\xe2\x80\x94Ay,\r\nthe curfew;\xe2\x80\x94Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and Philip de Malvoisin know the use\r\nof the curfew as well as William the Bastard himself, or e\xe2\x80\x99er a Norman\r\nadventurer that fought at Hastings. I shall hear, I guess, that my\r\nproperty has been swept off to save from starving the hungry banditti,\r\nwhom they cannot support but by theft and robbery. My faithful slave is\r\nmurdered, and my goods are taken for a prey\xe2\x80\x94and Wamba\xe2\x80\x94where is Wamba?\r\nSaid not some one he had gone forth with Gurth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOswald replied in the affirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy? why this is better and better! he is carried off too, the Saxon\r\nfool, to serve the Norman lord. Fools are we all indeed that serve\r\nthem, and fitter subjects for their scorn and laughter, than if we were\r\nborn with but half our wits. But I will be avenged,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, starting\r\nfrom his chair in impatience at the supposed injury, and catching hold\r\nof his boar-spear; \xe2\x80\x9cI will go with my complaint to the great council; I\r\nhave friends, I have followers\xe2\x80\x94man to man will I appeal the Norman to\r\nthe lists; let him come in his plate and his mail, and all that can\r\nrender cowardice bold; I have sent such a javelin as this through a\r\nstronger fence than three of their war shields!\xe2\x80\x94Haply they think me\r\nold; but they shall find, alone and childless as I am, the blood of\r\nHereward is in the veins of Cedric.\xe2\x80\x94Ah, Wilfred, Wilfred!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed\r\nin a lower tone, \xe2\x80\x9ccouldst thou have ruled thine unreasonable passion,\r\nthy father had not been left in his age like the solitary oak that\r\nthrows out its shattered and unprotected branches against the full\r\nsweep of the tempest!\xe2\x80\x9d The reflection seemed to conjure into sadness\r\nhis irritated feelings. Replacing his javelin, he resumed his seat,\r\nbent his looks downward, and appeared to be absorbed in melancholy\r\nreflection.\r\n\r\nFrom his musing, Cedric was suddenly awakened by the blast of a horn,\r\nwhich was replied to by the clamorous yells and barking of all the dogs\r\nin the hall, and some twenty or thirty which were quartered in other\r\nparts of the building. It cost some exercise of the white truncheon,\r\nwell seconded by the exertions of the domestics, to silence this canine\r\nclamour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the gate, knaves!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Saxon, hastily, as soon as the tumult\r\nwas so much appeased that the dependants could hear his voice. \xe2\x80\x9cSee\r\nwhat tidings that horn tells us of\xe2\x80\x94to announce, I ween, some hership 12\r\nand robbery which has been done upon my lands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nReturning in less than three minutes, a warder announced \xe2\x80\x9cthat the\r\nPrior Aymer of Jorvaulx, and the good knight Brian de Bois-Guilbert,\r\ncommander of the valiant and venerable order of Knights Templars, with\r\na small retinue, requested hospitality and lodging for the night, being\r\non their way to a tournament which was to be held not far from\r\nAshby-de-la-Zouche, on the second day from the present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAymer, the Prior Aymer? Brian de Bois-Guilbert?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94muttered Cedric;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNormans both;\xe2\x80\x94but Norman or Saxon, the hospitality of Rotherwood must\r\nnot be impeached; they are welcome, since they have chosen to halt\xe2\x80\x94more\r\nwelcome would they have been to have ridden further on their way\xe2\x80\x94But it\r\nwere unworthy to murmur for a night\xe2\x80\x99s lodging and a night\xe2\x80\x99s food; in\r\nthe quality of guests, at least, even Normans must suppress their\r\ninsolence.\xe2\x80\x94Go, Hundebert,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, to a sort of major-domo who stood\r\nbehind him with a white wand; \xe2\x80\x9ctake six of the attendants, and\r\nintroduce the strangers to the guests\xe2\x80\x99 lodging. Look after their horses\r\nand mules, and see their train lack nothing. Let them have change of\r\nvestments if they require it, and fire, and water to wash, and wine and\r\nale; and bid the cooks add what they hastily can to our evening meal;\r\nand let it be put on the board when those strangers are ready to share\r\nit. Say to them, Hundebert, that Cedric would himself bid them welcome,\r\nbut he is under a vow never to step more than three steps from the dais\r\nof his own hall to meet any who shares not the blood of Saxon royalty.\r\nBegone! see them carefully tended; let them not say in their pride, the\r\nSaxon churl has shown at once his poverty and his avarice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe major-domo departed with several attendants, to execute his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s commands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Prior Aymer!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Cedric, looking to Oswald, \xe2\x80\x9cthe brother, if\r\nI mistake not, of Giles de Mauleverer, now lord of Middleham?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOswald made a respectful sign of assent. \xe2\x80\x9cHis brother sits in the seat,\r\nand usurps the patrimony, of a better race, the race of Ulfgar of\r\nMiddleham; but what Norman lord doth not the same? This Prior is, they\r\nsay, a free and jovial priest, who loves the wine-cup and the\r\nbugle-horn better than bell and book: Good; let him come, he shall be\r\nwelcome. How named ye the Templar?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrian de Bois-Guilbert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBois-Guilbert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, still in the musing, half-arguing tone,\r\nwhich the habit of living among dependants had accustomed him to\r\nemploy, and which resembled a man who talks to himself rather than to\r\nthose around him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBois-Guilbert? that name has been spread wide both\r\nfor good and evil. They say he is valiant as the bravest of his order;\r\nbut stained with their usual vices, pride, arrogance, cruelty, and\r\nvoluptuousness; a hard-hearted man, who knows neither fear of earth,\r\nnor awe of heaven. So say the few warriors who have returned from\r\nPalestine.\xe2\x80\x94Well; it is but for one night; he shall be welcome\r\ntoo.\xe2\x80\x94Oswald, broach the oldest wine-cask; place the best mead, the\r\nmightiest ale, the richest morat, the most sparkling cider, the most\r\nodoriferous pigments, upon the board; fill the largest horns 13\r\n\xe2\x80\x94Templars and Abbots love good wines and good measure.\xe2\x80\x94Elgitha, let thy\r\nLady Rowena, know we shall not this night expect her in the hall,\r\nunless such be her especial pleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it will be her especial pleasure,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Elgitha, with great\r\nreadiness, \xe2\x80\x9cfor she is ever desirous to hear the latest news from\r\nPalestine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCedric darted at the forward damsel a glance of hasty resentment; but\r\nRowena, and whatever belonged to her, were privileged and secure from\r\nhis anger. He only replied, \xe2\x80\x9cSilence, maiden; thy tongue outruns thy\r\ndiscretion. Say my message to thy mistress, and let her do her\r\npleasure. Here, at least, the descendant of Alfred still reigns a\r\nprincess.\xe2\x80\x9d Elgitha left the apartment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPalestine!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the Saxon; \xe2\x80\x9cPalestine! how many ears are turned\r\nto the tales which dissolute crusaders, or hypocritical pilgrims, bring\r\nfrom that fatal land! I too might ask\xe2\x80\x94I too might enquire\xe2\x80\x94I too might\r\nlisten with a beating heart to fables which the wily strollers devise\r\nto cheat us into hospitality\xe2\x80\x94but no\xe2\x80\x94The son who has disobeyed me is no\r\nlonger mine; nor will I concern myself more for his fate than for that\r\nof the most worthless among the millions that ever shaped the cross on\r\ntheir shoulder, rushed into excess and blood-guiltiness, and called it\r\nan accomplishment of the will of God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe knit his brows, and fixed his eyes for an instant on the ground; as\r\nhe raised them, the folding doors at the bottom of the hall were cast\r\nwide, and, preceded by the major-domo with his wand, and four domestics\r\nbearing blazing torches, the guests of the evening entered the\r\napartment.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nWith sheep and shaggy goats the porkers bled,\r\nAnd the proud steer was on the marble spread;\r\nWith fire prepared, they deal the morsels round,\r\nWine rosy bright the brimming goblets crown\xe2\x80\x99d.\r\n\r\nDisposed apart, Ulysses shares the treat;\r\nA trivet table and ignobler seat,\r\nThe Prince assigns\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\r\nODYSSEY, _Book_ XXI.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Prior Aymer had taken the opportunity afforded him, of changing his\r\nriding robe for one of yet more costly materials, over which he wore a\r\ncope curiously embroidered. Besides the massive golden signet ring,\r\nwhich marked his ecclesiastical dignity, his fingers, though contrary\r\nto the canon, were loaded with precious gems; his sandals were of the\r\nfinest leather which was imported from Spain; his beard trimmed to as\r\nsmall dimensions as his order would possibly permit, and his shaven\r\ncrown concealed by a scarlet cap richly embroidered.\r\n\r\nThe appearance of the Knight Templar was also changed; and, though less\r\nstudiously bedecked with ornament, his dress was as rich, and his\r\nappearance far more commanding, than that of his companion. He had\r\nexchanged his shirt of mail for an under tunic of dark purple silk,\r\ngarnished with furs, over which flowed his long robe of spotless white,\r\nin ample folds. The eight-pointed cross of his order was cut on the\r\nshoulder of his mantle in black velvet. The high cap no longer invested\r\nhis brows, which were only shaded by short and thick curled hair of a\r\nraven blackness, corresponding to his unusually swart complexion.\r\nNothing could be more gracefully majestic than his step and manner, had\r\nthey not been marked by a predominant air of haughtiness, easily\r\nacquired by the exercise of unresisted authority.\r\n\r\nThese two dignified persons were followed by their respective\r\nattendants, and at a more humble distance by their guide, whose figure\r\nhad nothing more remarkable than it derived from the usual weeds of a\r\npilgrim. A cloak or mantle of coarse black serge, enveloped his whole\r\nbody. It was in shape something like the cloak of a modern hussar,\r\nhaving similar flaps for covering the arms, and was called a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSclaveyn\xe2\x80\x9d, or \xe2\x80\x9cSclavonian\xe2\x80\x9d. Coarse sandals, bound with thongs, on his\r\nbare feet; a broad and shadowy hat, with cockle-shells stitched on its\r\nbrim, and a long staff shod with iron, to the upper end of which was\r\nattached a branch of palm, completed the palmer\xe2\x80\x99s attire. He followed\r\nmodestly the last of the train which entered the hall, and, observing\r\nthat the lower table scarce afforded room sufficient for the domestics\r\nof Cedric and the retinue of his guests, he withdrew to a settle placed\r\nbeside and almost under one of the large chimneys, and seemed to employ\r\nhimself in drying his garments, until the retreat of some one should\r\nmake room at the board, or the hospitality of the steward should supply\r\nhim with refreshments in the place he had chosen apart.\r\n\r\nCedric rose to receive his guests with an air of dignified hospitality,\r\nand, descending from the dais, or elevated part of his hall, made three\r\nsteps towards them, and then awaited their approach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI grieve,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9creverend Prior, that my vow binds me to advance\r\nno farther upon this floor of my fathers, even to receive such guests\r\nas you, and this valiant Knight of the Holy Temple. But my steward has\r\nexpounded to you the cause of my seeming discourtesy. Let me also pray,\r\nthat you will excuse my speaking to you in my native language, and that\r\nyou will reply in the same if your knowledge of it permits; if not, I\r\nsufficiently understand Norman to follow your meaning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVows,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Abbot, \xe2\x80\x9cmust be unloosed, worthy Franklin, or permit\r\nme rather to say, worthy Thane, though the title is antiquated. Vows\r\nare the knots which tie us to Heaven\xe2\x80\x94they are the cords which bind the\r\nsacrifice to the horns of the altar,\xe2\x80\x94and are therefore,\xe2\x80\x94as I said\r\nbefore,\xe2\x80\x94to be unloosened and discharged, unless our holy Mother Church\r\nshall pronounce the contrary. And respecting language, I willingly hold\r\ncommunication in that spoken by my respected grandmother, Hilda of\r\nMiddleham, who died in odour of sanctity, little short, if we may\r\npresume to say so, of her glorious namesake, the blessed Saint Hilda of\r\nWhitby, God be gracious to her soul!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen the Prior had ceased what he meant as a conciliatory harangue, his\r\ncompanion said briefly and emphatically, \xe2\x80\x9cI speak ever French, the\r\nlanguage of King Richard and his nobles; but I understand English\r\nsufficiently to communicate with the natives of the country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCedric darted at the speaker one of those hasty and impatient glances,\r\nwhich comparisons between the two rival nations seldom failed to call\r\nforth; but, recollecting the duties of hospitality, he suppressed\r\nfurther show of resentment, and, motioning with his hand, caused his\r\nguests to assume two seats a little lower than his own, but placed\r\nclose beside him, and gave a signal that the evening meal should be\r\nplaced upon the board.\r\n\r\nWhile the attendants hastened to obey Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s commands, his eye\r\ndistinguished Gurth the swineherd, who, with his companion Wamba, had\r\njust entered the hall. \xe2\x80\x9cSend these loitering knaves up hither,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe Saxon, impatiently. And when the culprits came before the\r\ndais,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHow comes it, villains! that you have loitered abroad so late as\r\nthis? Hast thou brought home thy charge, sirrah Gurth, or hast thou\r\nleft them to robbers and marauders?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe herd is safe, so please ye,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it does not please me, thou knave,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I should be\r\nmade to suppose otherwise for two hours, and sit here devising\r\nvengeance against my neighbours for wrongs they have not done me. I\r\ntell thee, shackles and the prison-house shall punish the next offence\r\nof this kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGurth, knowing his master\xe2\x80\x99s irritable temper, attempted no exculpation;\r\nbut the Jester, who could presume upon Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s tolerance, by virtue of\r\nhis privileges as a fool, replied for them both; \xe2\x80\x9cIn troth, uncle\r\nCedric, you are neither wise nor reasonable to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98How, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d said his master; \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall to the porter\xe2\x80\x99s lodge, and\r\ntaste of the discipline there, if you give your foolery such license.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFirst let your wisdom tell me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cis it just and reasonable\r\nto punish one person for the fault of another?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not, fool,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why should you shackle poor Gurth, uncle, for the fault of his\r\ndog Fangs? for I dare be sworn we lost not a minute by the way, when we\r\nhad got our herd together, which Fangs did not manage until we heard\r\nthe vesper-bell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen hang up Fangs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, turning hastily towards the\r\nswineherd, \xe2\x80\x9cif the fault is his, and get thee another dog.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnder favour, uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cthat were still somewhat on\r\nthe bow-hand of fair justice; for it was no fault of Fangs that he was\r\nlame and could not gather the herd, but the fault of those that struck\r\noff two of his fore-claws, an operation for which, if the poor fellow\r\nhad been consulted, he would scarce have given his voice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who dared to lame an animal which belonged to my bondsman?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe Saxon, kindling in wrath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarry, that did old Hubert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cSir Philip de Malvoisin\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nkeeper of the chase. He caught Fangs strolling in the forest, and said\r\nhe chased the deer contrary to his master\xe2\x80\x99s right, as warden of the\r\nwalk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe foul fiend take Malvoisin,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Saxon, \xe2\x80\x9cand his keeper\r\nboth! I will teach them that the wood was disforested in terms of the\r\ngreat Forest Charter. But enough of this. Go to, knave, go to thy\r\nplace\xe2\x80\x94and thou, Gurth, get thee another dog, and should the keeper dare\r\nto touch it, I will mar his archery; the curse of a coward on my head,\r\nif I strike not off the forefinger of his right hand!\xe2\x80\x94he shall draw\r\nbowstring no more.\xe2\x80\x94I crave your pardon, my worthy guests. I am beset\r\nhere with neighbours that match your infidels, Sir Knight, in Holy\r\nLand. But your homely fare is before you; feed, and let welcome make\r\namends for hard fare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe feast, however, which was spread upon the board, needed no\r\napologies from the lord of the mansion. Swine\xe2\x80\x99s flesh, dressed in\r\nseveral modes, appeared on the lower part of the board, as also that of\r\nfowls, deer, goats, and hares, and various kinds of fish, together with\r\nhuge loaves and cakes of bread, and sundry confections made of fruits\r\nand honey. The smaller sorts of wild-fowl, of which there was\r\nabundance, were not served up in platters, but brought in upon small\r\nwooden spits or broaches, and offered by the pages and domestics who\r\nbore them, to each guest in succession, who cut from them such a\r\nportion as he pleased. Beside each person of rank was placed a goblet\r\nof silver; the lower board was accommodated with large drinking horns.\r\n\r\nWhen the repast was about to commence, the major-domo, or steward,\r\nsuddenly raising his wand, said aloud,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cForbear!\xe2\x80\x94Place for the Lady\r\nRowena.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA side-door at the upper end of the hall now opened behind the banquet\r\ntable, and Rowena, followed by four female attendants, entered the\r\napartment. Cedric, though surprised, and perhaps not altogether\r\nagreeably so, at his ward appearing in public on this occasion,\r\nhastened to meet her, and to conduct her, with respectful ceremony, to\r\nthe elevated seat at his own right hand, appropriated to the lady of\r\nthe mansion. All stood up to receive her; and, replying to their\r\ncourtesy by a mute gesture of salutation, she moved gracefully forward\r\nto assume her place at the board. Ere she had time to do so, the\r\nTemplar whispered to the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall wear no collar of gold of\r\nyours at the tournament. The Chian wine is your own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaid I not so?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Prior; \xe2\x80\x9cbut check your raptures, the\r\nFranklin observes you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUnheeding this remonstrance, and accustomed only to act upon the\r\nimmediate impulse of his own wishes, Brian de Bois-Guilbert kept his\r\neyes riveted on the Saxon beauty, more striking perhaps to his\r\nimagination, because differing widely from those of the Eastern\r\nsultanas.\r\n\r\nFormed in the best proportions of her sex, Rowena was tall in stature,\r\nyet not so much so as to attract observation on account of superior\r\nheight. Her complexion was exquisitely fair, but the noble cast of her\r\nhead and features prevented the insipidity which sometimes attaches to\r\nfair beauties. Her clear blue eye, which sat enshrined beneath a\r\ngraceful eyebrow of brown sufficiently marked to give expression to the\r\nforehead, seemed capable to kindle as well as melt, to command as well\r\nas to beseech. If mildness were the more natural expression of such a\r\ncombination of features, it was plain, that in the present instance,\r\nthe exercise of habitual superiority, and the reception of general\r\nhomage, had given to the Saxon lady a loftier character, which mingled\r\nwith and qualified that bestowed by nature. Her profuse hair, of a\r\ncolour betwixt brown and flaxen, was arranged in a fanciful and\r\ngraceful manner in numerous ringlets, to form which art had probably\r\naided nature. These locks were braided with gems, and, being worn at\r\nfull length, intimated the noble birth and free-born condition of the\r\nmaiden. A golden chain, to which was attached a small reliquary of the\r\nsame metal, hung round her neck. She wore bracelets on her arms, which\r\nwere bare. Her dress was an under-gown and kirtle of pale sea-green\r\nsilk, over which hung a long loose robe, which reached to the ground,\r\nhaving very wide sleeves, which came down, however, very little below\r\nthe elbow. This robe was crimson, and manufactured out of the very\r\nfinest wool. A veil of silk, interwoven with gold, was attached to the\r\nupper part of it, which could be, at the wearer\xe2\x80\x99s pleasure, either\r\ndrawn over the face and bosom after the Spanish fashion, or disposed as\r\na sort of drapery round the shoulders.\r\n\r\nWhen Rowena perceived the Knight Templar\xe2\x80\x99s eyes bent on her with an\r\nardour, that, compared with the dark caverns under which they moved,\r\ngave them the effect of lighted charcoal, she drew with dignity the\r\nveil around her face, as an intimation that the determined freedom of\r\nhis glance was disagreeable. Cedric saw the motion and its cause. \xe2\x80\x9cSir\r\nTemplar,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe cheeks of our Saxon maidens have seen too\r\nlittle of the sun to enable them to bear the fixed glance of a\r\ncrusader.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I have offended,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Sir Brian, \xe2\x80\x9cI crave your pardon,\xe2\x80\x94that is,\r\nI crave the Lady Rowena\xe2\x80\x99s pardon,\xe2\x80\x94for my humility will carry me no\r\nlower.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lady Rowena,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9chas punished us all, in chastising\r\nthe boldness of my friend. Let me hope she will be less cruel to the\r\nsplendid train which are to meet at the tournament.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur going thither,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cis uncertain. I love not these\r\nvanities, which were unknown to my fathers when England was free.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us hope, nevertheless,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cour company may determine\r\nyou to travel thitherward; when the roads are so unsafe, the escort of\r\nSir Brian de Bois-Guilbert is not to be despised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Prior,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Saxon, \xe2\x80\x9cwheresoever I have travelled in this\r\nland, I have hitherto found myself, with the assistance of my good\r\nsword and faithful followers, in no respect needful of other aid. At\r\npresent, if we indeed journey to Ashby-de-la-Zouche, we do so with my\r\nnoble neighbour and countryman Athelstane of Coningsburgh, and with\r\nsuch a train as would set outlaws and feudal enemies at defiance.\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ndrink to you, Sir Prior, in this cup of wine, which I trust your taste\r\nwill approve, and I thank you for your courtesy. Should you be so rigid\r\nin adhering to monastic rule,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cas to prefer your acid\r\npreparation of milk, I hope you will not strain courtesy to do me\r\nreason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Priest, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cit is only in our abbey that we\r\nconfine ourselves to the \xe2\x80\x98lac dulce\xe2\x80\x99 or the \xe2\x80\x98lac acidum\xe2\x80\x99 either.\r\nConversing with, the world, we use the world\xe2\x80\x99s fashions, and therefore\r\nI answer your pledge in this honest wine, and leave the weaker liquor\r\nto my lay-brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, filling his goblet, \xe2\x80\x9cdrink wassail to the\r\nfair Rowena; for since her namesake introduced the word into England,\r\nhas never been one more worthy of such a tribute. By my faith, I could\r\npardon the unhappy Vortigern, had he half the cause that we now\r\nwitness, for making shipwreck of his honour and his kingdom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will spare your courtesy, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena with dignity, and\r\nwithout unveiling herself; \xe2\x80\x9cor rather I will tax it so far as to\r\nrequire of you the latest news from Palestine, a theme more agreeable\r\nto our English ears than the compliments which your French breeding\r\nteaches.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have little of importance to say, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Sir Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cexcepting the confirmed tidings of a truce with\r\nSaladin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was interrupted by Wamba, who had taken his appropriated seat upon a\r\nchair, the back of which was decorated with two ass\xe2\x80\x99s ears, and which\r\nwas placed about two steps behind that of his master, who, from time to\r\ntime, supplied him with victuals from his own trencher; a favour,\r\nhowever, which the Jester shared with the favourite dogs, of whom, as\r\nwe have already noticed, there were several in attendance. Here sat\r\nWamba, with a small table before him, his heels tucked up against the\r\nbar of the chair, his cheeks sucked up so as to make his jaws resemble\r\na pair of nut-crackers, and his eyes half-shut, yet watching with\r\nalertness every opportunity to exercise his licensed foolery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese truces with the infidels,\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, without caring how\r\nsuddenly he interrupted the stately Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cmake an old man of me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to, knave, how so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, his features prepared to receive\r\nfavourably the expected jest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cI remember three of them in my day, each of\r\nwhich was to endure for the course of fifty years; so that, by\r\ncomputation, I must be at least a hundred and fifty years old.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will warrant you against dying of old age, however,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nTemplar, who now recognised his friend of the forest; \xe2\x80\x9cI will assure\r\nyou from all deaths but a violent one, if you give such directions to\r\nwayfarers, as you did this night to the Prior and me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, sirrah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cmisdirect travellers? We must have you\r\nwhipt; you are at least as much rogue as fool.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pray thee, uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9clet my folly, for once,\r\nprotect my roguery. I did but make a mistake between my right hand and\r\nmy left; and he might have pardoned a greater, who took a fool for his\r\ncounsellor and guide.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nConversation was here interrupted by the entrance of the porter\xe2\x80\x99s page,\r\nwho announced that there was a stranger at the gate, imploring\r\nadmittance and hospitality.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdmit him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cbe he who or what he may;\xe2\x80\x94a night like that\r\nwhich roars without, compels even wild animals to herd with tame, and\r\nto seek the protection of man, their mortal foe, rather than perish by\r\nthe elements. Let his wants be ministered to with all care\xe2\x80\x94look to it,\r\nOswald.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the steward left the banqueting hall to see the commands of his\r\npatron obeyed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nHath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands, organs, dimensions, senses,\r\naffections, passions? Fed with the same food, hurt with the same\r\nweapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed\r\nand cooled by the same winter and summer, as a Christian is?\r\n\r\n\r\nMERCHANT OF VENICE\r\n\r\n\r\nOswald, returning, whispered into the ear of his master, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a Jew,\r\nwho calls himself Isaac of York; is it fit I should marshall him into\r\nthe hall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet Gurth do thine office, Oswald,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba with his usual\r\neffrontery; \xe2\x80\x9cthe swineherd will be a fit usher to the Jew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt Mary,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Abbot, crossing himself, \xe2\x80\x9can unbelieving Jew, and\r\nadmitted into this presence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA dog Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d echoed the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cto approach a defender of the Holy\r\nSepulchre?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cit would seem the Templars love the Jews\xe2\x80\x99\r\ninheritance better than they do their company.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace, my worthy guests,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cmy hospitality must not be\r\nbounded by your dislikes. If Heaven bore with the whole nation of\r\nstiff-necked unbelievers for more years than a layman can number, we\r\nmay endure the presence of one Jew for a few hours. But I constrain no\r\nman to converse or to feed with him.\xe2\x80\x94Let him have a board and a morsel\r\napart,\xe2\x80\x94unless,\xe2\x80\x9d he said smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cthese turban\xe2\x80\x99d strangers will admit\r\nhis society.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Franklin,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cmy Saracen slaves are true\r\nMoslems, and scorn as much as any Christian to hold intercourse with a\r\nJew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, in faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot see that the worshippers of\r\nMahound and Termagaunt have so greatly the advantage over the people\r\nonce chosen of Heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe shall sit with thee, Wamba,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cthe fool and the knave\r\nwill be well met.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fool,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Wamba, raising the relics of a gammon of bacon,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwill take care to erect a bulwark against the knave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cfor here he comes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIntroduced with little ceremony, and advancing with fear and\r\nhesitation, and many a bow of deep humility, a tall thin old man, who,\r\nhowever, had lost by the habit of stooping much of his actual height,\r\napproached the lower end of the board. His features, keen and regular,\r\nwith an aquiline nose, and piercing black eyes; his high and wrinkled\r\nforehead, and long grey hair and beard, would have been considered as\r\nhandsome, had they not been the marks of a physiognomy peculiar to a\r\nrace, which, during those dark ages, was alike detested by the\r\ncredulous and prejudiced vulgar, and persecuted by the greedy and\r\nrapacious nobility, and who, perhaps, owing to that very hatred and\r\npersecution, had adopted a national character, in which there was much,\r\nto say the least, mean and unamiable.\r\n\r\nThe Jew\xe2\x80\x99s dress, which appeared to have suffered considerably from the\r\nstorm, was a plain russet cloak of many folds, covering a dark purple\r\ntunic. He had large boots lined with fur, and a belt around his waist,\r\nwhich sustained a small knife, together with a case for writing\r\nmaterials, but no weapon. He wore a high square yellow cap of a\r\npeculiar fashion, assigned to his nation to distinguish them from\r\nChristians, and which he doffed with great humility at the door of the\r\nhall.\r\n\r\nThe reception of this person in the hall of Cedric the Saxon, was such\r\nas might have satisfied the most prejudiced enemy of the tribes of\r\nIsrael. Cedric himself coldly nodded in answer to the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s repeated\r\nsalutations, and signed to him to take place at the lower end of the\r\ntable, where, however, no one offered to make room for him. On the\r\ncontrary, as he passed along the file, casting a timid supplicating\r\nglance, and turning towards each of those who occupied the lower end of\r\nthe board, the Saxon domestics squared their shoulders, and continued\r\nto devour their supper with great perseverance, paying not the least\r\nattention to the wants of the new guest. The attendants of the Abbot\r\ncrossed themselves, with looks of pious horror, and the very heathen\r\nSaracens, as Isaac drew near them, curled up their whiskers with\r\nindignation, and laid their hands on their poniards, as if ready to rid\r\nthemselves by the most desperate means from the apprehended\r\ncontamination of his nearer approach.\r\n\r\nProbably the same motives which induced Cedric to open his hall to this\r\nson of a rejected people, would have made him insist on his attendants\r\nreceiving Isaac with more courtesy. But the Abbot had, at this moment,\r\nengaged him in a most interesting discussion on the breed and character\r\nof his favourite hounds, which he would not have interrupted for\r\nmatters of much greater importance than that of a Jew going to bed\r\nsupperless. While Isaac thus stood an outcast in the present society,\r\nlike his people among the nations, looking in vain for welcome or\r\nresting place, the pilgrim who sat by the chimney took compassion upon\r\nhim, and resigned his seat, saying briefly, \xe2\x80\x9cOld man, my garments are\r\ndried, my hunger is appeased, thou art both wet and fasting.\xe2\x80\x9d So\r\nsaying, he gathered together, and brought to a flame, the decaying\r\nbrands which lay scattered on the ample hearth; took from the larger\r\nboard a mess of pottage and seethed kid, placed it upon the small table\r\nat which he had himself supped, and, without waiting the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s thanks,\r\nwent to the other side of the hall;\xe2\x80\x94whether from unwillingness to hold\r\nmore close communication with the object of his benevolence, or from a\r\nwish to draw near to the upper end of the table, seemed uncertain.\r\n\r\nHad there been painters in those days capable to execute such a\r\nsubject, the Jew, as he bent his withered form, and expanded his\r\nchilled and trembling hands over the fire, would have formed no bad\r\nemblematical personification of the Winter season. Having dispelled the\r\ncold, he turned eagerly to the smoking mess which was placed before\r\nhim, and ate with a haste and an apparent relish, that seemed to\r\nbetoken long abstinence from food.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile the Abbot and Cedric continued their discourse upon hunting;\r\nthe Lady Rowena seemed engaged in conversation with one of her\r\nattendant females; and the haughty Templar, whose eye wandered from the\r\nJew to the Saxon beauty, revolved in his mind thoughts which appeared\r\ndeeply to interest him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI marvel, worthy Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Abbot, as their discourse\r\nproceeded, \xe2\x80\x9cthat, great as your predilection is for your own manly\r\nlanguage, you do not receive the Norman-French into your favour, so far\r\nat least as the mystery of wood-craft and hunting is concerned. Surely\r\nno tongue is so rich in the various phrases which the field-sports\r\ndemand, or furnishes means to the experienced woodman so well to\r\nexpress his jovial art.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Father Aymer,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Saxon, \xe2\x80\x9cbe it known to you, I care not\r\nfor those over-sea refinements, without which I can well enough take my\r\npleasure in the woods. I can wind my horn, though I call not the blast\r\neither a \xe2\x80\x98recheate\xe2\x80\x99 or a \xe2\x80\x98morte\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94I can cheer my dogs on the prey, and I\r\ncan flay and quarter the animal when it is brought down, without using\r\nthe newfangled jargon of \xe2\x80\x98curee, arbor, nombles\xe2\x80\x99, and all the babble of\r\nthe fabulous Sir Tristrem.\xe2\x80\x9d 14\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe French,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, raising his voice with the presumptuous\r\nand authoritative tone which he used upon all occasions, \xe2\x80\x9cis not only\r\nthe natural language of the chase, but that of love and of war, in\r\nwhich ladies should be won and enemies defied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPledge me in a cup of wine, Sir Templar,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cand fill\r\nanother to the Abbot, while I look back some thirty years to tell you\r\nanother tale. As Cedric the Saxon then was, his plain English tale\r\nneeded no garnish from French troubadours, when it was told in the ear\r\nof beauty; and the field of Northallerton, upon the day of the Holy\r\nStandard, could tell whether the Saxon war-cry was not heard as far\r\nwithin the ranks of the Scottish host as the \xe2\x80\x98cri de guerre\xe2\x80\x99 of the\r\nboldest Norman baron. To the memory of the brave who fought\r\nthere!\xe2\x80\x94Pledge me, my guests.\xe2\x80\x9d He drank deep, and went on with\r\nincreasing warmth. \xe2\x80\x9cAy, that was a day of cleaving of shields, when a\r\nhundred banners were bent forwards over the heads of the valiant, and\r\nblood flowed round like water, and death was held better than flight. A\r\nSaxon bard had called it a feast of the swords\xe2\x80\x94a gathering of the\r\neagles to the prey\xe2\x80\x94the clashing of bills upon shield and helmet, the\r\nshouting of battle more joyful than the clamour of a bridal. But our\r\nbards are no more,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cour deeds are lost in those of another\r\nrace\xe2\x80\x94our language\xe2\x80\x94our very name\xe2\x80\x94is hastening to decay, and none mourns\r\nfor it save one solitary old man\xe2\x80\x94Cupbearer! knave, fill the goblets\xe2\x80\x94To\r\nthe strong in arms, Sir Templar, be their race or language what it\r\nwill, who now bear them best in Palestine among the champions of the\r\nCross!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt becomes not one wearing this badge to answer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert; \xe2\x80\x9cyet to whom, besides the sworn Champions of the Holy\r\nSepulchre, can the palm be assigned among the champions of the Cross?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the Knights Hospitallers,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Abbot; \xe2\x80\x9cI have a brother of\r\ntheir order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI impeach not their fame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cnevertheless\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think, friend Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, interfering, \xe2\x80\x9cthat had Richard of\r\nthe Lion\xe2\x80\x99s Heart been wise enough to have taken a fool\xe2\x80\x99s advice, he\r\nmight have staid at home with his merry Englishmen, and left the\r\nrecovery of Jerusalem to those same Knights who had most to do with the\r\nloss of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere there, then, none in the English army,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Lady Rowena,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhose names are worthy to be mentioned with the Knights of the Temple,\r\nand of St John?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bois-Guilbert; \xe2\x80\x9cthe English monarch did,\r\nindeed, bring to Palestine a host of gallant warriors, second only to\r\nthose whose breasts have been the unceasing bulwark of that blessed\r\nland.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSecond to NONE,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim, who had stood near enough to hear,\r\nand had listened to this conversation with marked impatience. All\r\nturned toward the spot from whence this unexpected asseveration was\r\nheard.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the Pilgrim in a firm and strong voice, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the\r\nEnglish chivalry were second to NONE who ever drew sword in defence of\r\nthe Holy Land. I say besides, for I saw it, that King Richard himself,\r\nand five of his knights, held a tournament after the taking of St\r\nJohn-de-Acre, as challengers against all comers. I say that, on that\r\nday, each knight ran three courses, and cast to the ground three\r\nantagonists. I add, that seven of these assailants were Knights of the\r\nTemple\xe2\x80\x94and Sir Brian de Bois-Guilbert well knows the truth of what I\r\ntell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt is impossible for language to describe the bitter scowl of rage\r\nwhich rendered yet darker the swarthy countenance of the Templar. In\r\nthe extremity of his resentment and confusion, his quivering fingers\r\ngriped towards the handle of his sword, and perhaps only withdrew, from\r\nthe consciousness that no act of violence could be safely executed in\r\nthat place and presence. Cedric, whose feelings were all of a right\r\nonward and simple kind, and were seldom occupied by more than one\r\nobject at once, omitted, in the joyous glee with which he heard of the\r\nglory of his countrymen, to remark the angry confusion of his guest; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwould give thee this golden bracelet, Pilgrim,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9ccouldst thou\r\ntell me the names of those knights who upheld so gallantly the renown\r\nof merry England.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will I do blithely,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Pilgrim, \xe2\x80\x9cand without guerdon;\r\nmy oath, for a time, prohibits me from touching gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will wear the bracelet for you, if you will, friend Palmer,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nWamba.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first in honour as in arms, in renown as in place,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nPilgrim, \xe2\x80\x9cwas the brave Richard, King of England.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI forgive him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric;
