\xe2\x80\x9cI forgive him his descent from the\r\ntyrant Duke William.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Earl of Leicester was the second,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the Pilgrim; \xe2\x80\x9cSir\r\nThomas Multon of Gilsland was the third.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf Saxon descent, he at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, with exultation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Foulk Doilly the fourth,\xe2\x80\x9d proceeded the Pilgrim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaxon also, at least by the mother\xe2\x80\x99s side,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Cedric, who\r\nlistened with the utmost eagerness, and forgot, in part at least, his\r\nhatred to the Normans, in the common triumph of the King of England and\r\nhis islanders. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd who was the fifth?\xe2\x80\x9d he demanded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fifth was Sir Edwin Turneham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGenuine Saxon, by the soul of Hengist!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Cedric\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the\r\nsixth?\xe2\x80\x9d he continued with eagerness\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9chow name you the sixth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sixth,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, after a pause, in which he seemed to\r\nrecollect himself, \xe2\x80\x9cwas a young knight of lesser renown and lower rank,\r\nassumed into that honourable company, less to aid their enterprise than\r\nto make up their number\xe2\x80\x94his name dwells not in my memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Palmer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir Brian de Bois-Guilbert scornfully, \xe2\x80\x9cthis assumed\r\nforgetfulness, after so much has been remembered, comes too late to\r\nserve your purpose. I will myself tell the name of the knight before\r\nwhose lance fortune and my horse\xe2\x80\x99s fault occasioned my falling\xe2\x80\x94it was\r\nthe Knight of Ivanhoe; nor was there one of the six that, for his\r\nyears, had more renown in arms.\xe2\x80\x94Yet this will I say, and loudly\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nwere he in England, and durst repeat, in this week\xe2\x80\x99s tournament, the\r\nchallenge of St John-de-Acre, I, mounted and armed as I now am, would\r\ngive him every advantage of weapons, and abide the result.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour challenge would soon be answered,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Palmer, \xe2\x80\x9cwere your\r\nantagonist near you. As the matter is, disturb not the peaceful hall\r\nwith vaunts of the issue of the conflict, which you well know cannot\r\ntake place. If Ivanhoe ever returns from Palestine, I will be his\r\nsurety that he meets you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA goodly security!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cand what do you proffer\r\nas a pledge?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis reliquary,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, taking a small ivory box from his\r\nbosom, and crossing himself, \xe2\x80\x9ccontaining a portion of the true cross,\r\nbrought from the Monastery of Mount Carmel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Prior of Jorvaulx crossed himself and repeated a pater noster, in\r\nwhich all devoutly joined, excepting the Jew, the Mahomedans, and the\r\nTemplar; the latter of whom, without vailing his bonnet, or testifying\r\nany reverence for the alleged sanctity of the relic, took from his neck\r\na gold chain, which he flung on the board, saying\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLet Prior Aymer hold\r\nmy pledge and that of this nameless vagrant, in token that when the\r\nKnight of Ivanhoe comes within the four seas of Britain, he underlies\r\nthe challenge of Brian de Bois-Guilbert, which, if he answer not, I\r\nwill proclaim him as a coward on the walls of every Temple Court in\r\nEurope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will not need,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Lady Rowena, breaking silence; \xe2\x80\x9cMy voice\r\nshall be heard, if no other in this hall is raised in behalf of the\r\nabsent Ivanhoe. I affirm he will meet fairly every honourable\r\nchallenge. Could my weak warrant add security to the inestimable pledge\r\nof this holy pilgrim, I would pledge name and fame that Ivanhoe gives\r\nthis proud knight the meeting he desires.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA crowd of conflicting emotions seemed to have occupied Cedric, and\r\nkept him silent during this discussion. Gratified pride, resentment,\r\nembarrassment, chased each other over his broad and open brow, like the\r\nshadow of clouds drifting over a harvest-field; while his attendants,\r\non whom the name of the sixth knight seemed to produce an effect almost\r\nelectrical, hung in suspense upon their master\xe2\x80\x99s looks. But when Rowena\r\nspoke, the sound of her voice seemed to startle him from his silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLady,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cthis beseems not; were further pledge necessary,\r\nI myself, offended, and justly offended, as I am, would yet gage my\r\nhonour for the honour of Ivanhoe. But the wager of battle is complete,\r\neven according to the fantastic fashions of Norman chivalry\xe2\x80\x94Is it not,\r\nFather Aymer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Prior; \xe2\x80\x9cand the blessed relic and rich chain will\r\nI bestow safely in the treasury of our convent, until the decision of\r\nthis warlike challenge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving thus spoken, he crossed himself again and again, and after many\r\ngenuflections and muttered prayers, he delivered the reliquary to\r\nBrother Ambrose, his attendant monk, while he himself swept up with\r\nless ceremony, but perhaps with no less internal satisfaction, the\r\ngolden chain, and bestowed it in a pouch lined with perfumed leather,\r\nwhich opened under his arm. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, Sir Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmy ears\r\nare chiming vespers with the strength of your good wine\xe2\x80\x94permit us\r\nanother pledge to the welfare of the Lady Rowena, and indulge us with\r\nliberty to pass to our repose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the rood of Bromholme,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Saxon, \xe2\x80\x9cyou do but small credit to\r\nyour fame, Sir Prior! Report speaks you a bonny monk, that would hear\r\nthe matin chime ere he quitted his bowl; and, old as I am, I feared to\r\nhave shame in encountering you. But, by my faith, a Saxon boy of\r\ntwelve, in my time, would not so soon have relinquished his goblet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Prior had his own reasons, however, for persevering in the course\r\nof temperance which he had adopted. He was not only a professional\r\npeacemaker, but from practice a hater of all feuds and brawls. It was\r\nnot altogether from a love to his neighbour, or to himself, or from a\r\nmixture of both. On the present occasion, he had an instinctive\r\napprehension of the fiery temper of the Saxon, and saw the danger that\r\nthe reckless and presumptuous spirit, of which his companion had\r\nalready given so many proofs, might at length produce some disagreeable\r\nexplosion. He therefore gently insinuated the incapacity of the native\r\nof any other country to engage in the genial conflict of the bowl with\r\nthe hardy and strong-headed Saxons; something he mentioned, but\r\nslightly, about his own holy character, and ended by pressing his\r\nproposal to depart to repose.\r\n\r\nThe grace-cup was accordingly served round, and the guests, after\r\nmaking deep obeisance to their landlord and to the Lady Rowena, arose\r\nand mingled in the hall, while the heads of the family, by separate\r\ndoors, retired with their attendants.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnbelieving dog,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar to Isaac the Jew, as he passed him\r\nin the throng, \xe2\x80\x9cdost thou bend thy course to the tournament?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do so propose,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Isaac, bowing in all humility, \xe2\x80\x9cif it please\r\nyour reverend valour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cto gnaw the bowels of our nobles with usury,\r\nand to gull women and boys with gauds and toys\xe2\x80\x94I warrant thee store of\r\nshekels in thy Jewish scrip.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a shekel, not a silver penny, not a halfling\xe2\x80\x94so help me the God of\r\nAbraham!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, clasping his hands; \xe2\x80\x9cI go but to seek the\r\nassistance of some brethren of my tribe to aid me to pay the fine which\r\nthe Exchequer of the Jews have imposed upon me\xe2\x80\x94Father Jacob be my\r\nspeed! I am an impoverished wretch\xe2\x80\x94the very gaberdine I wear is\r\nborrowed from Reuben of Tadcaster.\xe2\x80\x9d 15\r\n\r\nThe Templar smiled sourly as he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cBeshrew thee for a\r\nfalse-hearted liar!\xe2\x80\x9d and passing onward, as if disdaining farther\r\nconference, he communed with his Moslem slaves in a language unknown to\r\nthe bystanders. The poor Israelite seemed so staggered by the address\r\nof the military monk, that the Templar had passed on to the extremity\r\nof the hall ere he raised his head from the humble posture which he had\r\nassumed, so far as to be sensible of his departure. And when he did\r\nlook around, it was with the astonished air of one at whose feet a\r\nthunderbolt has just burst, and who hears still the astounding report\r\nringing in his ears.\r\n\r\nThe Templar and Prior were shortly after marshalled to their sleeping\r\napartments by the steward and the cupbearer, each attended by two\r\ntorchbearers and two servants carrying refreshments, while servants of\r\ninferior condition indicated to their retinue and to the other guests\r\ntheir respective places of repose.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\n\r\n\r\nTo buy his favour I extend this friendship:\r\nIf he will take it, so; if not, adieu;\r\nAnd, for my love, I pray you wrong me not.\r\n\r\n\r\nMERCHANT OF VENICE\r\n\r\n\r\nAs the Palmer, lighted by a domestic with a torch, passed through the\r\nintricate combination of apartments of this large and irregular\r\nmansion, the cupbearer coming behind him whispered in his ear, that if\r\nhe had no objection to a cup of good mead in his apartment, there were\r\nmany domestics in that family who would gladly hear the news he had\r\nbrought from the Holy Land, and particularly that which concerned the\r\nKnight of Ivanhoe. Wamba presently appeared to urge the same request,\r\nobserving that a cup after midnight was worth three after curfew.\r\nWithout disputing a maxim urged by such grave authority, the Palmer\r\nthanked them for their courtesy, but observed that he had included in\r\nhis religious vow, an obligation never to speak in the kitchen on\r\nmatters which were prohibited in the hall. \xe2\x80\x9cThat vow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba to\r\nthe cupbearer, \xe2\x80\x9cwould scarce suit a serving-man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cupbearer shrugged up his shoulders in displeasure. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought to\r\nhave lodged him in the solere chamber,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbut since he is so\r\nunsocial to Christians, e\xe2\x80\x99en let him take the next stall to Isaac the\r\nJew\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x94Anwold,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the torchbearer, \xe2\x80\x9ccarry the Pilgrim to the\r\nsouthern cell.\xe2\x80\x94I give you good-night,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cSir Palmer, with\r\nsmall thanks for short courtesy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-night, and Our Lady\xe2\x80\x99s benison,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, with composure;\r\nand his guide moved forward.\r\n\r\nIn a small antechamber, into which several doors opened, and which was\r\nlighted by a small iron lamp, they met a second interruption from the\r\nwaiting-maid of Rowena, who, saying in a tone of authority, that her\r\nmistress desired to speak with the Palmer, took the torch from the hand\r\nof Anwold, and, bidding him await her return, made a sign to the Palmer\r\nto follow. Apparently he did not think it proper to decline this\r\ninvitation as he had done the former; for, though his gesture indicated\r\nsome surprise at the summons, he obeyed it without answer or\r\nremonstrance.\r\n\r\nA short passage, and an ascent of seven steps, each of which was\r\ncomposed of a solid beam of oak, led him to the apartment of the Lady\r\nRowena, the rude magnificence of which corresponded to the respect\r\nwhich was paid to her by the lord of the mansion. The walls were\r\ncovered with embroidered hangings, on which different-coloured silks,\r\ninterwoven with gold and silver threads, had been employed with all the\r\nart of which the age was capable, to represent the sports of hunting\r\nand hawking. The bed was adorned with the same rich tapestry, and\r\nsurrounded with curtains dyed with purple. The seats had also their\r\nstained coverings, and one, which was higher than the rest, was\r\naccommodated with a footstool of ivory, curiously carved.\r\n\r\nNo fewer than four silver candelabras, holding great waxen torches,\r\nserved to illuminate this apartment. Yet let not modern beauty envy the\r\nmagnificence of a Saxon princess. The walls of the apartment were so\r\nill finished and so full of crevices, that the rich hangings shook in\r\nthe night blast, and, in despite of a sort of screen intended to\r\nprotect them from the wind, the flame of the torches streamed sideways\r\ninto the air, like the unfurled pennon of a chieftain. Magnificence\r\nthere was, with some rude attempt at taste; but of comfort there was\r\nlittle, and, being unknown, it was unmissed.\r\n\r\nThe Lady Rowena, with three of her attendants standing at her back, and\r\narranging her hair ere she lay down to rest, was seated in the sort of\r\nthrone already mentioned, and looked as if born to exact general\r\nhomage. The Pilgrim acknowledged her claim to it by a low genuflection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRise, Palmer,\xe2\x80\x9d said she graciously. \xe2\x80\x9cThe defender of the absent has a\r\nright to favourable reception from all who value truth, and honour\r\nmanhood.\xe2\x80\x9d She then said to her train, \xe2\x80\x9cRetire, excepting only Elgitha;\r\nI would speak with this holy Pilgrim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe maidens, without leaving the apartment, retired to its further\r\nextremity, and sat down on a small bench against the wall, where they\r\nremained mute as statues, though at such a distance that their whispers\r\ncould not have interrupted the conversation of their mistress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPilgrim,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause, during which she\r\nseemed uncertain how to address him, \xe2\x80\x9cyou this night mentioned a name\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nmean,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, with a degree of effort, \xe2\x80\x9cthe name of Ivanhoe, in the\r\nhalls where by nature and kindred it should have sounded most\r\nacceptably; and yet, such is the perverse course of fate, that of many\r\nwhose hearts must have throbbed at the sound, I, only, dare ask you\r\nwhere, and in what condition, you left him of whom you spoke?\xe2\x80\x94We heard,\r\nthat, having remained in Palestine, on account of his impaired health,\r\nafter the departure of the English army, he had experienced the\r\npersecution of the French faction, to whom the Templars are known to be\r\nattached.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know little of the Knight of Ivanhoe,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Palmer, with a\r\ntroubled voice. \xe2\x80\x9cI would I knew him better, since you, lady, are\r\ninterested in his fate. He hath, I believe, surmounted the persecution\r\nof his enemies in Palestine, and is on the eve of returning to England,\r\nwhere you, lady, must know better than I, what is his chance of\r\nhappiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Lady Rowena sighed deeply, and asked more particularly when the\r\nKnight of Ivanhoe might be expected in his native country, and whether\r\nhe would not be exposed to great dangers by the road. On the first\r\npoint, the Palmer professed ignorance; on the second, he said that the\r\nvoyage might be safely made by the way of Venice and Genoa, and from\r\nthence through France to England. \xe2\x80\x9cIvanhoe,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwas so well\r\nacquainted with the language and manners of the French, that there was\r\nno fear of his incurring any hazard during that part of his travels.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould to God,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Lady Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9che were here safely arrived, and\r\nable to bear arms in the approaching tourney, in which the chivalry of\r\nthis land are expected to display their address and valour. Should\r\nAthelstane of Coningsburgh obtain the prize, Ivanhoe is like to hear\r\nevil tidings when he reaches England.\xe2\x80\x94How looked he, stranger, when you\r\nlast saw him? Had disease laid her hand heavy upon his strength and\r\ncomeliness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was darker,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, \xe2\x80\x9cand thinner, than when he came from\r\nCyprus in the train of C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion, and care seemed to sit heavy on\r\nhis brow; but I approached not his presence, because he is unknown to\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady, \xe2\x80\x9cI fear, find little in his native land to\r\nclear those clouds from his countenance. Thanks, good Pilgrim, for your\r\ninformation concerning the companion of my childhood.\xe2\x80\x94Maidens,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cdraw near\xe2\x80\x94offer the sleeping cup to this holy man, whom I will\r\nno longer detain from repose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne of the maidens presented a silver cup, containing a rich mixture of\r\nwine and spice, which Rowena barely put to her lips. It was then\r\noffered to the Palmer, who, after a low obeisance, tasted a few drops.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAccept this alms, friend,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the lady, offering a piece of\r\ngold, \xe2\x80\x9cin acknowledgment of thy painful travail, and of the shrines\r\nthou hast visited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Palmer received the boon with another low reverence, and followed\r\nEdwina out of the apartment.\r\n\r\nIn the anteroom he found his attendant Anwold, who, taking the torch\r\nfrom the hand of the waiting-maid, conducted him with more haste than\r\nceremony to an exterior and ignoble part of the building, where a\r\nnumber of small apartments, or rather cells, served for sleeping places\r\nto the lower order of domestics, and to strangers of mean degree.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn which of these sleeps the Jew?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe unbelieving dog,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Anwold, \xe2\x80\x9ckennels in the cell next your\r\nholiness.\xe2\x80\x94St Dunstan, how it must be scraped and cleansed ere it be\r\nagain fit for a Christian!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where sleeps Gurth the swineherd?\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGurth,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the bondsman, \xe2\x80\x9csleeps in the cell on your right, as\r\nthe Jew on that to your left; you serve to keep the child of\r\ncircumcision separate from the abomination of his tribe. You might have\r\noccupied a more honourable place had you accepted of Oswald\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ninvitation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is as well as it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer; \xe2\x80\x9cthe company, even of a Jew,\r\ncan hardly spread contamination through an oaken partition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he entered the cabin allotted to him, and taking the torch\r\nfrom the domestic\xe2\x80\x99s hand, thanked him, and wished him good-night.\r\nHaving shut the door of his cell, he placed the torch in a candlestick\r\nmade of wood, and looked around his sleeping apartment, the furniture\r\nof which was of the most simple kind. It consisted of a rude wooden\r\nstool, and still ruder hutch or bed-frame, stuffed with clean straw,\r\nand accommodated with two or three sheepskins by way of bed-clothes.\r\n\r\nThe Palmer, having extinguished his torch, threw himself, without\r\ntaking off any part of his clothes, on this rude couch, and slept, or\r\nat least retained his recumbent posture, till the earliest sunbeams\r\nfound their way through the little grated window, which served at once\r\nto admit both air and light to his uncomfortable cell. He then started\r\nup, and after repeating his matins, and adjusting his dress, he left\r\nit, and entered that of Isaac the Jew, lifting the latch as gently as\r\nhe could.\r\n\r\nThe inmate was lying in troubled slumber upon a couch similar to that\r\non which the Palmer himself had passed the night. Such parts of his\r\ndress as the Jew had laid aside on the preceding evening, were disposed\r\ncarefully around his person, as if to prevent the hazard of their being\r\ncarried off during his slumbers. There was a trouble on his brow\r\namounting almost to agony. His hands and arms moved convulsively, as if\r\nstruggling with the nightmare; and besides several ejaculations in\r\nHebrew, the following were distinctly heard in the Norman-English, or\r\nmixed language of the country: \xe2\x80\x9cFor the sake of the God of Abraham,\r\nspare an unhappy old man! I am poor, I am penniless\xe2\x80\x94should your irons\r\nwrench my limbs asunder, I could not gratify you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Palmer awaited not the end of the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s vision, but stirred him\r\nwith his pilgrim\xe2\x80\x99s staff. The touch probably associated, as is usual,\r\nwith some of the apprehensions excited by his dream; for the old man\r\nstarted up, his grey hair standing almost erect upon his head, and\r\nhuddling some part of his garments about him, while he held the\r\ndetached pieces with the tenacious grasp of a falcon, he fixed upon the\r\nPalmer his keen black eyes, expressive of wild surprise and of bodily\r\napprehension.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear nothing from me, Isaac,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, \xe2\x80\x9cI come as your\r\nfriend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe God of Israel requite you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, greatly relieved; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ndreamed\xe2\x80\x94But Father Abraham be praised, it was but a dream.\xe2\x80\x9d Then,\r\ncollecting himself, he added in his usual tone, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what may it be\r\nyour pleasure to want at so early an hour with the poor Jew?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is to tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if you leave not this\r\nmansion instantly, and travel not with some haste, your journey may\r\nprove a dangerous one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly father!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cwhom could it interest to endanger so\r\npoor a wretch as I am?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe purpose you can best guess,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim; \xe2\x80\x9cbut rely on this,\r\nthat when the Templar crossed the hall yesternight, he spoke to his\r\nMussulman slaves in the Saracen language, which I well understand, and\r\ncharged them this morning to watch the journey of the Jew, to seize\r\nupon him when at a convenient distance from the mansion, and to conduct\r\nhim to the castle of Philip de Malvoisin, or to that of Reginald\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt is impossible to describe the extremity of terror which seized upon\r\nthe Jew at this information, and seemed at once to overpower his whole\r\nfaculties. His arms fell down to his sides, and his head drooped on his\r\nbreast, his knees bent under his weight, every nerve and muscle of his\r\nframe seemed to collapse and lose its energy, and he sunk at the foot\r\nof the Palmer, not in the fashion of one who intentionally stoops,\r\nkneels, or prostrates himself to excite compassion, but like a man\r\nborne down on all sides by the pressure of some invisible force, which\r\ncrushes him to the earth without the power of resistance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly God of Abraham!\xe2\x80\x9d was his first exclamation, folding and elevating\r\nhis wrinkled hands, but without raising his grey head from the\r\npavement; \xe2\x80\x9cOh, holy Moses! O, blessed Aaron! the dream is not dreamed\r\nfor nought, and the vision cometh not in vain! I feel their irons\r\nalready tear my sinews! I feel the rack pass over my body like the\r\nsaws, and harrows, and axes of iron over the men of Rabbah, and of the\r\ncities of the children of Ammon!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand up, Isaac, and hearken to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, who viewed the\r\nextremity of his distress with a compassion in which contempt was\r\nlargely mingled; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have cause for your terror, considering how your\r\nbrethren have been used, in order to extort from them their hoards,\r\nboth by princes and nobles; but stand up, I say, and I will point out\r\nto you the means of escape. Leave this mansion instantly, while its\r\ninmates sleep sound after the last night\xe2\x80\x99s revel. I will guide you by\r\nthe secret paths of the forest, known as well to me as to any forester\r\nthat ranges it, and I will not leave you till you are under safe\r\nconduct of some chief or baron going to the tournament, whose good-will\r\nyou have probably the means of securing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the ears of Isaac received the hopes of escape which this speech\r\nintimated, he began gradually, and inch by inch, as it were, to raise\r\nhimself up from the ground, until he fairly rested upon his knees,\r\nthrowing back his long grey hair and beard, and fixing his keen black\r\neyes upon the Palmer\xe2\x80\x99s face, with a look expressive at once of hope and\r\nfear, not unmingled with suspicion. But when he heard the concluding\r\npart of the sentence, his original terror appeared to revive in full\r\nforce, and he dropt once more on his face, exclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9c_I_ possess the\r\nmeans of securing good-will! alas! there is but one road to the favour\r\nof a Christian, and how can the poor Jew find it, whom extortions have\r\nalready reduced to the misery of Lazarus?\xe2\x80\x9d Then, as if suspicion had\r\noverpowered his other feelings, he suddenly exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cFor the love of\r\nGod, young man, betray me not\xe2\x80\x94for the sake of the Great Father who made\r\nus all, Jew as well as Gentile, Israelite and Ishmaelite\xe2\x80\x94do me no\r\ntreason! I have not means to secure the good-will of a Christian\r\nbeggar, were he rating it at a single penny.\xe2\x80\x9d As he spoke these last\r\nwords, he raised himself, and grasped the Palmer\xe2\x80\x99s mantle with a look\r\nof the most earnest entreaty. The pilgrim extricated himself, as if\r\nthere were contamination in the touch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWert thou loaded with all the wealth of thy tribe,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\r\ninterest have I to injure thee?\xe2\x80\x94In this dress I am vowed to poverty,\r\nnor do I change it for aught save a horse and a coat of mail. Yet think\r\nnot that I care for thy company, or propose myself advantage by it;\r\nremain here if thou wilt\xe2\x80\x94Cedric the Saxon may protect thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9che will not let me travel in his train\xe2\x80\x94Saxon or\r\nNorman will be equally ashamed of the poor Israelite; and to travel by\r\nmyself through the domains of Philip de Malvoisin and Reginald\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x94Good youth, I will go with you!\xe2\x80\x94Let us haste\xe2\x80\x94let us gird\r\nup our loins\xe2\x80\x94let us flee!\xe2\x80\x94Here is thy staff, why wilt thou tarry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tarry not,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim, giving way to the urgency of his\r\ncompanion; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I must secure the means of leaving this place\xe2\x80\x94follow\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe led the way to the adjoining cell, which, as the reader is apprised,\r\nwas occupied by Gurth the swineherd.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cArise, Gurth,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9carise quickly. Undo the postern gate, and let out the Jew and me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGurth, whose occupation, though now held so mean, gave him as much\r\nconsequence in Saxon England as that of Eumaeus in Ithaca, was offended\r\nat the familiar and commanding tone assumed by the Palmer. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Jew\r\nleaving Rotherwood,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, raising himself on his elbow, and looking\r\nsuperciliously at him without quitting his pallet, \xe2\x80\x9cand travelling in\r\ncompany with the Palmer to boot\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should as soon have dreamt,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, who entered the apartment\r\nat the instant, \xe2\x80\x9cof his stealing away with a gammon of bacon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, again laying down his head on the wooden\r\nlog which served him for a pillow, \xe2\x80\x9cboth Jew and Gentile must be\r\ncontent to abide the opening of the great gate\xe2\x80\x94we suffer no visitors to\r\ndepart by stealth at these unseasonable hours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim, in a commanding tone, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will not,\r\nI think, refuse me that favour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he stooped over the bed of the recumbent swineherd, and\r\nwhispered something in his ear in Saxon. Gurth started up as if\r\nelectrified. The Pilgrim, raising his finger in an attitude as if to\r\nexpress caution, added, \xe2\x80\x9cGurth, beware\xe2\x80\x94thou are wont to be prudent. I\r\nsay, undo the postern\xe2\x80\x94thou shalt know more anon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith hasty alacrity Gurth obeyed him, while Wamba and the Jew followed,\r\nboth wondering at the sudden change in the swineherd\xe2\x80\x99s demeanour. \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\nmule, my mule!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, as soon as they stood without the\r\npostern.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFetch him his mule,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim; \xe2\x80\x9cand, hearest thou,\xe2\x80\x94let me have\r\nanother, that I may bear him company till he is beyond these parts\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nwill return it safely to some of Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s train at Ashby. And do\r\nthou\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he whispered the rest in Gurth\xe2\x80\x99s ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly, most willingly shall it be done,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, and instantly\r\ndeparted to execute the commission.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I knew,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, when his comrade\xe2\x80\x99s back was turned, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\r\nyou Palmers learn in the Holy Land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo say our orisons, fool,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Pilgrim, \xe2\x80\x9cto repent our sins,\r\nand to mortify ourselves with fastings, vigils, and long prayers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething more potent than that,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester; \xe2\x80\x9cfor when would\r\nrepentance or prayer make Gurth do a courtesy, or fasting or vigil\r\npersuade him to lend you a mule?\xe2\x80\x94I trow you might as well have told his\r\nfavourite black boar of thy vigils and penance, and wouldst have gotten\r\nas civil an answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim, \xe2\x80\x9cthou art but a Saxon fool.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou sayst well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester; \xe2\x80\x9chad I been born a Norman, as I\r\nthink thou art, I would have had luck on my side, and been next door to\r\na wise man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment Gurth appeared on the opposite side of the moat with the\r\nmules. The travellers crossed the ditch upon a drawbridge of only two\r\nplanks breadth, the narrowness of which was matched with the straitness\r\nof the postern, and with a little wicket in the exterior palisade,\r\nwhich gave access to the forest. No sooner had they reached the mules,\r\nthan the Jew, with hasty and trembling hands, secured behind the saddle\r\na small bag of blue buckram, which he took from under his cloak,\r\ncontaining, as he muttered, \xe2\x80\x9ca change of raiment\xe2\x80\x94only a change of\r\nraiment.\xe2\x80\x9d Then getting upon the animal with more alacrity and haste\r\nthan could have been anticipated from his years, he lost no time in so\r\ndisposing of the skirts of his gabardine as to conceal completely from\r\nobservation the burden which he had thus deposited \xe2\x80\x9cen croupe\xe2\x80\x9d.\r\n\r\nThe Pilgrim mounted with more deliberation, reaching, as he departed,\r\nhis hand to Gurth, who kissed it with the utmost possible veneration.\r\nThe swineherd stood gazing after the travellers until they were lost\r\nunder the boughs of the forest path, when he was disturbed from his\r\nreverie by the voice of Wamba.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnowest thou,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cmy good friend Gurth, that thou art\r\nstrangely courteous and most unwontedly pious on this summer morning? I\r\nwould I were a black Prior or a barefoot Palmer, to avail myself of thy\r\nunwonted zeal and courtesy\xe2\x80\x94certes, I would make more out of it than a\r\nkiss of the hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art no fool thus far, Wamba,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cthough thou\r\narguest from appearances, and the wisest of us can do no more\xe2\x80\x94But it is\r\ntime to look after my charge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he turned back to the mansion, attended by the Jester.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile the travellers continued to press on their journey with a\r\ndispatch which argued the extremity of the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s fears, since persons\r\nat his age are seldom fond of rapid motion. The Palmer, to whom every\r\npath and outlet in the wood appeared to be familiar, led the way\r\nthrough the most devious paths, and more than once excited anew the\r\nsuspicion of the Israelite, that he intended to betray him into some\r\nambuscade of his enemies.\r\n\r\nHis doubts might have been indeed pardoned; for, except perhaps the\r\nflying fish, there was no race existing on the earth, in the air, or\r\nthe waters, who were the object of such an unintermitting, general, and\r\nrelentless persecution as the Jews of this period. Upon the slightest\r\nand most unreasonable pretences, as well as upon accusations the most\r\nabsurd and groundless, their persons and property were exposed to every\r\nturn of popular fury; for Norman, Saxon, Dane, and Briton, however\r\nadverse these races were to each other, contended which should look\r\nwith greatest detestation upon a people, whom it was accounted a point\r\nof religion to hate, to revile, to despise, to plunder, and to\r\npersecute. The kings of the Norman race, and the independent nobles,\r\nwho followed their example in all acts of tyranny, maintained against\r\nthis devoted people a persecution of a more regular, calculated, and\r\nself-interested kind. It is a well-known story of King John, that he\r\nconfined a wealthy Jew in one of the royal castles, and daily caused\r\none of his teeth to be torn out, until, when the jaw of the unhappy\r\nIsraelite was half disfurnished, he consented to pay a large sum, which\r\nit was the tyrant\xe2\x80\x99s object to extort from him. The little ready money\r\nwhich was in the country was chiefly in possession of this persecuted\r\npeople, and the nobility hesitated not to follow the example of their\r\nsovereign, in wringing it from them by every species of oppression, and\r\neven personal torture. Yet the passive courage inspired by the love of\r\ngain, induced the Jews to dare the various evils to which they were\r\nsubjected, in consideration of the immense profits which they were\r\nenabled to realize in a country naturally so wealthy as England. In\r\nspite of every kind of discouragement, and even of the special court of\r\ntaxations already mentioned, called the Jews\xe2\x80\x99 Exchequer, erected for\r\nthe very purpose of despoiling and distressing them, the Jews\r\nincreased, multiplied, and accumulated huge sums, which they\r\ntransferred from one hand to another by means of bills of exchange\xe2\x80\x94an\r\ninvention for which commerce is said to be indebted to them, and which\r\nenabled them to transfer their wealth from land to land, that when\r\nthreatened with oppression in one country, their treasure might be\r\nsecured in another.\r\n\r\nThe obstinacy and avarice of the Jews being thus in a measure placed in\r\nopposition to the fanaticism that tyranny of those under whom they\r\nlived, seemed to increase in proportion to the persecution with which\r\nthey were visited; and the immense wealth they usually acquired in\r\ncommerce, while it frequently placed them in danger, was at other times\r\nused to extend their influence, and to secure to them a certain degree\r\nof protection. On these terms they lived; and their character,\r\ninfluenced accordingly, was watchful, suspicious, and timid\xe2\x80\x94yet\r\nobstinate, uncomplying, and skilful in evading the dangers to which\r\nthey were exposed.\r\n\r\nWhen the travellers had pushed on at a rapid rate through many devious\r\npaths, the Palmer at length broke silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat large decayed oak,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmarks the boundaries over which\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf claims authority\xe2\x80\x94we are long since far from those of\r\nMalvoisin. There is now no fear of pursuit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the wheels of their chariots be taken off,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9clike\r\nthose of the host of Pharaoh, that they may drive heavily!\xe2\x80\x94But leave me\r\nnot, good Pilgrim\xe2\x80\x94Think but of that fierce and savage Templar, with his\r\nSaracen slaves\xe2\x80\x94they will regard neither territory, nor manor, nor\r\nlordship.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur road,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, \xe2\x80\x9cshould here separate; for it beseems not\r\nmen of my character and thine to travel together longer than needs must\r\nbe. Besides, what succour couldst thou have from me, a peaceful\r\nPilgrim, against two armed heathens?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO good youth,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cthou canst defend me, and I know\r\nthou wouldst. Poor as I am, I will requite it\xe2\x80\x94not with money, for\r\nmoney, so help me my Father Abraham, I have none\xe2\x80\x94but\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoney and recompense,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, interrupting him, \xe2\x80\x9cI have\r\nalready said I require not of thee. Guide thee I can; and, it may be,\r\neven in some sort defend thee; since to protect a Jew against a\r\nSaracen, can scarce be accounted unworthy of a Christian. Therefore,\r\nJew, I will see thee safe under some fitting escort. We are now not far\r\nfrom the town of Sheffield, where thou mayest easily find many of thy\r\ntribe with whom to take refuge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe blessing of Jacob be upon thee, good youth!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew; \xe2\x80\x9cin\r\nSheffield I can harbour with my kinsman Zareth, and find some means of\r\ntravelling forth with safety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer; \xe2\x80\x9cat Sheffield then we part, and\r\nhalf-an-hour\xe2\x80\x99s riding will bring us in sight of that town.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe half hour was spent in perfect silence on both parts; the Pilgrim\r\nperhaps disdaining to address the Jew, except in case of absolute\r\nnecessity, and the Jew not presuming to force a conversation with a\r\nperson whose journey to the Holy Sepulchre gave a sort of sanctity to\r\nhis character. They paused on the top of a gently rising bank, and the\r\nPilgrim, pointing to the town of Sheffield, which lay beneath them,\r\nrepeated the words, \xe2\x80\x9cHere, then, we part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot till you have had the poor Jew\xe2\x80\x99s thanks,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I\r\npresume not to ask you to go with me to my kinsman Zareth\xe2\x80\x99s, who might\r\naid me with some means of repaying your good offices.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have already said,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Pilgrim, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I desire no\r\nrecompense. If among the huge list of thy debtors, thou wilt, for my\r\nsake, spare the gyves and the dungeon to some unhappy Christian who\r\nstands in thy danger, I shall hold this morning\xe2\x80\x99s service to thee well\r\nbestowed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay, stay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, laying hold of his garment; \xe2\x80\x9csomething\r\nwould I do more than this, something for thyself.\xe2\x80\x94God knows the Jew is\r\npoor\xe2\x80\x94yes, Isaac is the beggar of his tribe\xe2\x80\x94but forgive me should I\r\nguess what thou most lackest at this moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou wert to guess truly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, \xe2\x80\x9cit is what thou canst\r\nnot supply, wert thou as wealthy as thou sayst thou art poor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I say?\xe2\x80\x9d echoed the Jew; \xe2\x80\x9cO! believe it, I say but the truth; I am a\r\nplundered, indebted, distressed man. Hard hands have wrung from me my\r\ngoods, my money, my ships, and all that I possessed\xe2\x80\x94Yet I can tell thee\r\nwhat thou lackest, and, it may be, supply it too. Thy wish even now is\r\nfor a horse and armour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Palmer started, and turned suddenly towards the Jew:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhat fiend\r\nprompted that guess?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, hastily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cso that it be a true one\xe2\x80\x94and, as I\r\ncan guess thy want, so I can supply it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut consider,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, \xe2\x80\x9cmy character, my dress, my vow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you Christians,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cand that the noblest of you\r\nwill take the staff and sandal in superstitious penance, and walk afoot\r\nto visit the graves of dead men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlaspheme not, Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim, sternly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew; \xe2\x80\x9cI spoke rashly. But there dropt words from\r\nyou last night and this morning, that, like sparks from flint, showed\r\nthe metal within; and in the bosom of that Palmer\xe2\x80\x99s gown, is hidden a\r\nknight\xe2\x80\x99s chain and spurs of gold. They glanced as you stooped over my\r\nbed in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Pilgrim could not forbear smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cWere thy garments searched by\r\nas curious an eye, Isaac,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat discoveries might not be\r\nmade?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, changing colour; and drawing forth his\r\nwriting materials in haste, as if to stop the conversation, he began to\r\nwrite upon a piece of paper which he supported on the top of his yellow\r\ncap, without dismounting from his mule. When he had finished, he\r\ndelivered the scroll, which was in the Hebrew character, to the\r\nPilgrim, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cIn the town of Leicester all men know the rich Jew,\r\nKirjath Jairam of Lombardy; give him this scroll\xe2\x80\x94he hath on sale six\r\nMilan harnesses, the worst would suit a crowned head\xe2\x80\x94ten goodly steeds,\r\nthe worst might mount a king, were he to do battle for his throne. Of\r\nthese he will give thee thy choice, with every thing else that can\r\nfurnish thee forth for the tournament: when it is over, thou wilt\r\nreturn them safely\xe2\x80\x94unless thou shouldst have wherewith to pay their\r\nvalue to the owner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Isaac,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Pilgrim, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cdost thou know that in these\r\nsports, the arms and steed of the knight who is unhorsed are forfeit to\r\nhis victor? Now I may be unfortunate, and so lose what I cannot replace\r\nor repay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew looked somewhat astounded at this possibility; but collecting\r\nhis courage, he replied hastily. \xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94no\xe2\x80\x94no\xe2\x80\x94It is impossible\xe2\x80\x94I will not\r\nthink so. The blessing of Our Father will be upon thee. Thy lance will\r\nbe powerful as the rod of Moses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he was turning his mule\xe2\x80\x99s head away, when the Palmer, in his\r\nturn, took hold of his gaberdine. \xe2\x80\x9cNay, but Isaac, thou knowest not all\r\nthe risk. The steed may be slain, the armour injured\xe2\x80\x94for I will spare\r\nneither horse nor man. Besides, those of thy tribe give nothing for\r\nnothing; something there must be paid for their use.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew twisted himself in the saddle, like a man in a fit of the\r\ncolic; but his better feelings predominated over those which were most\r\nfamiliar to him. \xe2\x80\x9cI care not,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI care not\xe2\x80\x94let me go. If there\r\nis damage, it will cost you nothing\xe2\x80\x94if there is usage money, Kirjath\r\nJairam will forgive it for the sake of his kinsman Isaac. Fare thee\r\nwell!\xe2\x80\x94Yet hark thee, good youth,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning about, \xe2\x80\x9cthrust\r\nthyself not too forward into this vain hurly-burly\xe2\x80\x94I speak not for\r\nendangering the steed, and coat of armour, but for the sake of thine\r\nown life and limbs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGramercy for thy caution,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Palmer, again smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cI will use\r\nthy courtesy frankly, and it will go hard with me but I will requite\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey parted, and took different roads for the town of Sheffield.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII\r\n\r\n\r\nKnights, with a long retinue of their squires,\r\nIn gaudy liveries march and quaint attires;\r\nOne laced the helm, another held the lance,\r\nA third the shining buckler did advance.\r\nThe courser paw\xe2\x80\x99d the ground with restless feet,\r\nAnd snorting foam\xe2\x80\x99d and champ\xe2\x80\x99d the golden bit.\r\nThe smiths and armourers on palfreys ride,\r\nFiles in their hands, and hammers at their side;\r\nAnd nails for loosen\xe2\x80\x99d spears, and thongs for shields provide.\r\nThe yeomen guard the streets in seemly bands;\r\nAnd clowns come crowding on, with cudgels in their hands.\r\n\r\n\r\nPALAMON AND ARCITE\r\n\r\n\r\nThe condition of the English nation was at this time sufficiently\r\nmiserable. King Richard was absent a prisoner, and in the power of the\r\nperfidious and cruel Duke of Austria. Even the very place of his\r\ncaptivity was uncertain, and his fate but very imperfectly known to the\r\ngenerality of his subjects, who were, in the meantime, a prey to every\r\nspecies of subaltern oppression.\r\n\r\nPrince John, in league with Philip of France, C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion\xe2\x80\x99s mortal\r\nenemy, was using every species of influence with the Duke of Austria,\r\nto prolong the captivity of his brother Richard, to whom he stood\r\nindebted for so many favours. In the meantime, he was strengthening his\r\nown faction in the kingdom, of which he proposed to dispute the\r\nsuccession, in case of the King\xe2\x80\x99s death, with the legitimate heir,\r\nArthur Duke of Brittany, son of Geoffrey Plantagenet, the elder brother\r\nof John. This usurpation, it is well known, he afterwards effected. His\r\nown character being light, profligate, and perfidious, John easily\r\nattached to his person and faction, not only all who had reason to\r\ndread the resentment of Richard for criminal proceedings during his\r\nabsence, but also the numerous class of \xe2\x80\x9clawless resolutes,\xe2\x80\x9d whom the\r\ncrusades had turned back on their country, accomplished in the vices of\r\nthe East, impoverished in substance, and hardened in character, and who\r\nplaced their hopes of harvest in civil commotion. To these causes of\r\npublic distress and apprehension, must be added, the multitude of\r\noutlaws, who, driven to despair by the oppression of the feudal\r\nnobility, and the severe exercise of the forest laws, banded together\r\nin large gangs, and, keeping possession of the forests and the wastes,\r\nset at defiance the justice and magistracy of the country. The nobles\r\nthemselves, each fortified within his own castle, and playing the petty\r\nsovereign over his own dominions, were the leaders of bands scarce less\r\nlawless and oppressive than those of the avowed depredators. To\r\nmaintain these retainers, and to support the extravagance and\r\nmagnificence which their pride induced them to affect, the nobility\r\nborrowed sums of money from the Jews at the most usurious interest,\r\nwhich gnawed into their estates like consuming cankers, scarce to be\r\ncured unless when circumstances gave them an opportunity of getting\r\nfree, by exercising upon their creditors some act of unprincipled\r\nviolence.\r\n\r\nUnder the various burdens imposed by this unhappy state of affairs, the\r\npeople of England suffered deeply for the present, and had yet more\r\ndreadful cause to fear for the future. To augment their misery, a\r\ncontagious disorder of a dangerous nature spread through the land; and,\r\nrendered more virulent by the uncleanness, the indifferent food, and\r\nthe wretched lodging of the lower classes, swept off many whose fate\r\nthe survivors were tempted to envy, as exempting them from the evils\r\nwhich were to come.\r\n\r\nYet amid these accumulated distresses, the poor as well as the rich,\r\nthe vulgar as well as the noble, in the event of a tournament, which\r\nwas the grand spectacle of that age, felt as much interested as the\r\nhalf-starved citizen of Madrid, who has not a real left to buy\r\nprovisions for his family, feels in the issue of a bull-feast. Neither\r\nduty nor infirmity could keep youth or age from such exhibitions. The\r\nPassage of Arms, as it was called, which was to take place at Ashby, in\r\nthe county of Leicester, as champions of the first renown were to take\r\nthe field in the presence of Prince John himself, who was expected to\r\ngrace the lists, had attracted universal attention, and an immense\r\nconfluence of persons of all ranks hastened upon the appointed morning\r\nto the place of combat.\r\n\r\nThe scene was singularly romantic. On the verge of a wood, which\r\napproached to within a mile of the town of Ashby, was an extensive\r\nmeadow, of the finest and most beautiful green turf, surrounded on one\r\nside by the forest, and fringed on the other by straggling oak-trees,\r\nsome of which had grown to an immense size. The ground, as if fashioned\r\non purpose for the martial display which was intended, sloped gradually\r\ndown on all sides to a level bottom, which was enclosed for the lists\r\nwith strong palisades, forming a space of a quarter of a mile in\r\nlength, and about half as broad. The form of the enclosure was an\r\noblong square, save that the corners were considerably rounded off, in\r\norder to afford more convenience for the spectators. The openings for\r\nthe entry of the combatants were at the northern and southern\r\nextremities of the lists, accessible by strong wooden gates, each wide\r\nenough to admit two horsemen riding abreast. At each of these portals\r\nwere stationed two heralds, attended by six trumpets, as many\r\npursuivants, and a strong body of men-at-arms for maintaining order,\r\nand ascertaining the quality of the knights who proposed to engage in\r\nthis martial game.\r\n\r\nOn a platform beyond the southern entrance, formed by a natural\r\nelevation of the ground, were pitched five magnificent pavilions,\r\nadorned with pennons of russet and black, the chosen colours of the\r\nfive knights challengers. The cords of the tents were of the same\r\ncolour. Before each pavilion was suspended the shield of the knight by\r\nwhom it was occupied, and beside it stood his squire, quaintly\r\ndisguised as a salvage or silvan man, or in some other fantastic dress,\r\naccording to the taste of his master, and the character he was pleased\r\nto assume during the game. 16\r\n\r\nThe central pavilion, as the place of honour, had been assigned to\r\nBrian be Bois-Guilbert, whose renown in all games of chivalry, no less\r\nthan his connexions with the knights who had undertaken this Passage of\r\nArms, had occasioned him to be eagerly received into the company of the\r\nchallengers, and even adopted as their chief and leader, though he had\r\nso recently joined them. On one side of his tent were pitched those of\r\nReginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and Richard de Malvoisin, and on the other was\r\nthe pavilion of Hugh de Grantmesnil, a noble baron in the vicinity,\r\nwhose ancestor had been Lord High Steward of England in the time of the\r\nConqueror, and his son William Rufus. Ralph de Vipont, a knight of St\r\nJohn of Jerusalem, who had some ancient possessions at a place called\r\nHeather, near Ashby-de-la-Zouche, occupied the fifth pavilion. From the\r\nentrance into the lists, a gently sloping passage, ten yards in\r\nbreadth, led up to the platform on which the tents were pitched. It was\r\nstrongly secured by a palisade on each side, as was the esplanade in\r\nfront of the pavilions, and the whole was guarded by men-at-arms.\r\n\r\nThe northern access to the lists terminated in a similar entrance of\r\nthirty feet in breadth, at the extremity of which was a large enclosed\r\nspace for such knights as might be disposed to enter the lists with the\r\nchallengers, behind which were placed tents containing refreshments of\r\nevery kind for their accommodation, with armourers, tarriers, and other\r\nattendants, in readiness to give their services wherever they might be\r\nnecessary.\r\n\r\nThe exterior of the lists was in part occupied by temporary galleries,\r\nspread with tapestry and carpets, and accommodated with cushions for\r\nthe convenience of those ladies and nobles who were expected to attend\r\nthe tournament. A narrow space, betwixt these galleries and the lists,\r\ngave accommodation for yeomanry and spectators of a better degree than\r\nthe mere vulgar, and might be compared to the pit of a theatre. The\r\npromiscuous multitude arranged themselves upon large banks of turf\r\nprepared for the purpose, which, aided by the natural elevation of the\r\nground, enabled them to overlook the galleries, and obtain a fair view\r\ninto the lists. Besides the accommodation which these stations\r\nafforded, many hundreds had perched themselves on the branches of the\r\ntrees which surrounded the meadow; and even the steeple of a country\r\nchurch, at some distance, was crowded with spectators.\r\n\r\nIt only remains to notice respecting the general arrangement, that one\r\ngallery in the very centre of the eastern side of the lists, and\r\nconsequently exactly opposite to the spot where the shock of the combat\r\nwas to take place, was raised higher than the others, more richly\r\ndecorated, and graced by a sort of throne and canopy, on which the\r\nroyal arms were emblazoned. Squires, pages, and yeomen in rich\r\nliveries, waited around this place of honour, which was designed for\r\nPrince John and his attendants. Opposite to this royal gallery was\r\nanother, elevated to the same height, on the western side of the lists;\r\nand more gaily, if less sumptuously decorated, than that destined for\r\nthe Prince himself. A train of pages and of young maidens, the most\r\nbeautiful who could be selected, gaily dressed in fancy habits of green\r\nand pink, surrounded a throne decorated in the same colours. Among\r\npennons and flags bearing wounded hearts, burning hearts, bleeding\r\nhearts, bows and quivers, and all the commonplace emblems of the\r\ntriumphs of Cupid, a blazoned inscription informed the spectators, that\r\nthis seat of honour was designed for \xe2\x80\x9cLa Royne de las Beaulte et des\r\nAmours\xe2\x80\x9d. But who was to represent the Queen of Beauty and of Love on\r\nthe present occasion no one was prepared to guess.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, spectators of every description thronged forward to occupy\r\ntheir respective stations, and not without many quarrels concerning\r\nthose which they were entitled to hold. Some of these were settled by\r\nthe men-at-arms with brief ceremony; the shafts of their battle-axes,\r\nand pummels of their swords, being readily employed as arguments to\r\nconvince the more refractory. Others, which involved the rival claims\r\nof more elevated persons, were determined by the heralds, or by the two\r\nmarshals of the field, William de Wyvil, and Stephen de Martival, who,\r\narmed at all points, rode up and down the lists to enforce and preserve\r\ngood order among the spectators.\r\n\r\nGradually the galleries became filled with knights and nobles, in their\r\nrobes of peace, whose long and rich-tinted mantles were contrasted with\r\nthe gayer and more splendid habits of the ladies, who, in a greater\r\nproportion than even the men themselves, thronged to witness a sport,\r\nwhich one would have thought too bloody and dangerous to afford their\r\nsex much pleasure. The lower and interior space was soon filled by\r\nsubstantial yeomen and burghers, and such of the lesser gentry, as,\r\nfrom modesty, poverty, or dubious title, durst not assume any higher\r\nplace. It was of course amongst these that the most frequent disputes\r\nfor precedence occurred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDog of an unbeliever,\xe2\x80\x9d said an old man, whose threadbare tunic bore\r\nwitness to his poverty, as his sword, and dagger, and golden chain\r\nintimated his pretensions to rank,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwhelp of a she-wolf! darest thou\r\npress upon a Christian, and a Norman gentleman of the blood of\r\nMontdidier?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis rough expostulation was addressed to no other than our\r\nacquaintance Isaac, who, richly and even magnificently dressed in a\r\ngaberdine ornamented with lace and lined with fur, was endeavouring to\r\nmake place in the foremost row beneath the gallery for his daughter,\r\nthe beautiful Rebecca, who had joined him at Ashby, and who was now\r\nhanging on her father\xe2\x80\x99s arm, not a little terrified by the popular\r\ndispleasure which seemed generally excited by her parent\xe2\x80\x99s presumption.\r\nBut Isaac, though we have seen him sufficiently timid on other\r\noccasions, knew well that at present he had nothing to fear. It was not\r\nin places of general resort, or where their equals were assembled, that\r\nany avaricious or malevolent noble durst offer him injury. At such\r\nmeetings the Jews were under the protection of the general law; and if\r\nthat proved a weak assurance, it usually happened that there were among\r\nthe persons assembled some barons, who, for their own interested\r\nmotives, were ready to act as their protectors. On the present\r\noccasion, Isaac felt more than usually confident, being aware that\r\nPrince John was even then in the very act of negotiating a large loan\r\nfrom the Jews of York, to be secured upon certain jewels and lands.\r\nIsaac\xe2\x80\x99s own share in this transaction was considerable, and he well\r\nknew that the Prince\xe2\x80\x99s eager desire to bring it to a conclusion would\r\nensure him his protection in the dilemma in which he stood.\r\n\r\nEmboldened by these considerations, the Jew pursued his point, and\r\njostled the Norman Christian, without respect either to his descent,\r\nquality, or religion. The complaints of the old man, however, excited\r\nthe indignation of the bystanders. One of these, a stout well-set\r\nyeoman, arrayed in Lincoln green, having twelve arrows stuck in his\r\nbelt, with a baldric and badge of silver, and a bow of six feet length\r\nin his hand, turned short round, and while his countenance, which his\r\nconstant exposure to weather had rendered brown as a hazel nut, grew\r\ndarker with anger, he advised the Jew to remember that all the wealth\r\nhe had acquired by sucking the blood of his miserable victims had but\r\nswelled him like a bloated spider, which might be overlooked while he\r\nkept in a corner, but would be crushed if it ventured into the light.\r\nThis intimation, delivered in Norman-English with a firm voice and a\r\nstern aspect, made the Jew shrink back; and he would have probably\r\nwithdrawn himself altogether from a vicinity so dangerous, had not the\r\nattention of every one been called to the sudden entrance of Prince\r\nJohn, who at that moment entered the lists, attended by a numerous and\r\ngay train, consisting partly of laymen, partly of churchmen, as light\r\nin their dress, and as gay in their demeanour, as their companions.\r\nAmong the latter was the Prior of Jorvaulx, in the most gallant trim\r\nwhich a dignitary of the church could venture to exhibit. Fur and gold\r\nwere not spared in his garments; and the points of his boots,\r\nout-heroding the preposterous fashion of the time, turned up so very\r\nfar, as to be attached, not to his knees merely, but to his very\r\ngirdle, and effectually prevented him from putting his foot into the\r\nstirrup. This, however, was a slight inconvenience to the gallant\r\nAbbot, who, perhaps, even rejoicing in the opportunity to display his\r\naccomplished horsemanship before so many spectators, especially of the\r\nfair sex, dispensed with the use of these supports to a timid rider.\r\nThe rest of Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s retinue consisted of the favourite leaders of\r\nhis mercenary troops, some marauding barons and profligate attendants\r\nupon the court, with several Knights Templars and Knights of St John.\r\n\r\nIt may be here remarked, that the knights of these two orders were\r\naccounted hostile to King Richard, having adopted the side of Philip of\r\nFrance in the long train of disputes which took place in Palestine\r\nbetwixt that monarch and the lion-hearted King of England. It was the\r\nwell-known consequence of this discord that Richard\xe2\x80\x99s repeated\r\nvictories had been rendered fruitless, his romantic attempts to besiege\r\nJerusalem disappointed, and the fruit of all the glory which he had\r\nacquired had dwindled into an uncertain truce with the Sultan Saladin.\r\nWith the same policy which had dictated the conduct of their brethren\r\nin the Holy Land, the Templars and Hospitallers in England and Normandy\r\nattached themselves to the faction of Prince John, having little reason\r\nto desire the return of Richard to England, or the succession of\r\nArthur, his legitimate heir. For the opposite reason, Prince John hated\r\nand contemned the few Saxon families of consequence which subsisted in\r\nEngland, and omitted no opportunity of mortifying and affronting them;\r\nbeing conscious that his person and pretensions were disliked by them,\r\nas well as by the greater part of the English commons, who feared\r\nfarther innovation upon their rights and liberties, from a sovereign of\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s licentious and tyrannical disposition.\r\n\r\nAttended by this gallant equipage, himself well mounted, and splendidly\r\ndressed in crimson and in gold, bearing upon his hand a falcon, and\r\nhaving his head covered by a rich fur bonnet, adorned with a circle of\r\nprecious stones, from which his long curled hair escaped and overspread\r\nhis shoulders, Prince John, upon a grey and high-mettled palfrey,\r\ncaracoled within the lists at the head of his jovial party, laughing\r\nloud with his train, and eyeing with all the boldness of royal\r\ncriticism the beauties who adorned the lofty galleries.\r\n\r\nThose who remarked in the physiognomy of the Prince a dissolute\r\naudacity, mingled with extreme haughtiness and indifference to the\r\nfeelings of others could not yet deny to his countenance that sort of\r\ncomeliness which belongs to an open set of features, well formed by\r\nnature, modelled by art to the usual rules of courtesy, yet so far\r\nfrank and honest, that they seemed as if they disclaimed to conceal the\r\nnatural workings of the soul. Such an expression is often mistaken for\r\nmanly frankness, when in truth it arises from the reckless indifference\r\nof a libertine disposition, conscious of superiority of birth, of\r\nwealth, or of some other adventitious advantage, totally unconnected\r\nwith personal merit. To those who did not think so deeply, and they\r\nwere the greater number by a hundred to one, the splendour of Prince\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9crheno\xe2\x80\x9d, (i.e. fur tippet,) the richness of his cloak, lined\r\nwith the most costly sables, his maroquin boots and golden spurs,\r\ntogether with the grace with which he managed his palfrey, were\r\nsufficient to merit clamorous applause.\r\n\r\nIn his joyous caracole round the lists, the attention of the Prince was\r\ncalled by the commotion, not yet subsided, which had attended the\r\nambitious movement of Isaac towards the higher places of the assembly.\r\nThe quick eye of Prince John instantly recognised the Jew, but was much\r\nmore agreeably attracted by the beautiful daughter of Zion, who,\r\nterrified by the tumult, clung close to the arm of her aged father.\r\n\r\nThe figure of Rebecca might indeed have compared with the proudest\r\nbeauties of England, even though it had been judged by as shrewd a\r\nconnoisseur as Prince John. Her form was exquisitely symmetrical, and\r\nwas shown to advantage by a sort of Eastern dress, which she wore\r\naccording to the fashion of the females of her nation. Her turban of\r\nyellow silk suited well with the darkness of her complexion. The\r\nbrilliancy of her eyes, the superb arch of her eyebrows, her\r\nwell-formed aquiline nose, her teeth as white as pearl, and the\r\nprofusion of her sable tresses, which, each arranged in its own little\r\nspiral of twisted curls, fell down upon as much of a lovely neck and\r\nbosom as a simarre of the richest Persian silk, exhibiting flowers in\r\ntheir natural colours embossed upon a purple ground, permitted to be\r\nvisible\xe2\x80\x94all these constituted a combination of loveliness, which\r\nyielded not to the most beautiful of the maidens who surrounded her. It\r\nis true, that of the golden and pearl-studded clasps, which closed her\r\nvest from the throat to the waist, the three uppermost were left\r\nunfastened on account of the heat, which somewhat enlarged the prospect\r\nto which we allude. A diamond necklace, with pendants of inestimable\r\nvalue, were by this means also made more conspicuous. The feather of an\r\nostrich, fastened in her turban by an agraffe set with brilliants, was\r\nanother distinction of the beautiful Jewess, scoffed and sneered at by\r\nthe proud dames who sat above her, but secretly envied by those who\r\naffected to deride them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the bald scalp of Abraham,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cyonder Jewess must\r\nbe the very model of that perfection, whose charms drove frantic the\r\nwisest king that ever lived! What sayest thou, Prior Aymer?\xe2\x80\x94By the\r\nTemple of that wise king, which our wiser brother Richard proved unable\r\nto recover, she is the very Bride of the Canticles!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Rose of Sharon and the Lily of the Valley,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94answered the Prior, in\r\na sort of snuffling tone; \xe2\x80\x9cbut your Grace must remember she is still\r\nbut a Jewess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy!\xe2\x80\x9d added Prince John, without heeding him, \xe2\x80\x9cand there is my Mammon\r\nof unrighteousness too\xe2\x80\x94the Marquis of Marks, the Baron of Byzants,\r\ncontesting for place with penniless dogs, whose threadbare cloaks have\r\nnot a single cross in their pouches to keep the devil from dancing\r\nthere. By the body of St Mark, my prince of supplies, with his lovely\r\nJewess, shall have a place in the gallery!\xe2\x80\x94What is she, Isaac? Thy wife\r\nor thy daughter, that Eastern houri that thou lockest under thy arm as\r\nthou wouldst thy treasure-casket?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter Rebecca, so please your Grace,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Isaac, with a low\r\ncongee, nothing embarrassed by the Prince\xe2\x80\x99s salutation, in which,\r\nhowever, there was at least as much mockery as courtesy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe wiser man thou,\xe2\x80\x9d said John, with a peal of laughter, in which his\r\ngay followers obsequiously joined. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, daughter or wife, she should\r\nbe preferred according to her beauty and thy merits.\xe2\x80\x94Who sits above\r\nthere?\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, bending his eye on the gallery. \xe2\x80\x9cSaxon churls,\r\nlolling at their lazy length!\xe2\x80\x94out upon them!\xe2\x80\x94let them sit close, and\r\nmake room for my prince of usurers and his lovely daughter. I\xe2\x80\x99ll make\r\nthe hinds know they must share the high places of the synagogue with\r\nthose whom the synagogue properly belongs to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThose who occupied the gallery to whom this injurious and unpolite\r\nspeech was addressed, were the family of Cedric the Saxon, with that of\r\nhis ally and kinsman, Athelstane of Coningsburgh, a personage, who, on\r\naccount of his descent from the last Saxon monarchs of England, was\r\nheld in the highest respect by all the Saxon natives of the north of\r\nEngland. But with the blood of this ancient royal race, many of their\r\ninfirmities had descended to Athelstane. He was comely in countenance,\r\nbulky and strong in person, and in the flower of his age\xe2\x80\x94yet inanimate\r\nin expression, dull-eyed, heavy-browed, inactive and sluggish in all\r\nhis motions, and so slow in resolution, that the soubriquet of one of\r\nhis ancestors was conferred upon him, and he was very generally called\r\nAthelstane the Unready. His friends, and he had many, who, as well as\r\nCedric, were passionately attached to him, contended that this sluggish\r\ntemper arose not from want of courage, but from mere want of decision;\r\nothers alleged that his hereditary vice of drunkenness had obscured his\r\nfaculties, never of a very acute order, and that the passive courage\r\nand meek good-nature which remained behind, were merely the dregs of a\r\ncharacter that might have been deserving of praise, but of which all\r\nthe valuable parts had flown off in the progress of a long course of\r\nbrutal debauchery.\r\n\r\nIt was to this person, such as we have described him, that the Prince\r\naddressed his imperious command to make place for Isaac and Rebecca.\r\nAthelstane, utterly confounded at an order which the manners and\r\nfeelings of the times rendered so injuriously insulting, unwilling to\r\nobey, yet undetermined how to resist, opposed only the \xe2\x80\x9cvis inertiae\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nto the will of John; and, without stirring or making any motion\r\nwhatever of obedience, opened his large grey eyes, and stared at the\r\nPrince with an astonishment which had in it something extremely\r\nludicrous. But the impatient John regarded it in no such light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Saxon porker,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cis either asleep or minds me not\xe2\x80\x94Prick\r\nhim with your lance, De Bracy,\xe2\x80\x9d speaking to a knight who rode near him,\r\nthe leader of a band of Free Companions, or Condottieri; that is, of\r\nmercenaries belonging to no particular nation, but attached for the\r\ntime to any prince by whom they were paid. There was a murmur even\r\namong the attendants of Prince John; but De Bracy, whose profession\r\nfreed him from all scruples, extended his long lance over the space\r\nwhich separated the gallery from the lists, and would have executed the\r\ncommands of the Prince before Athelstane the Unready had recovered\r\npresence of mind sufficient even to draw back his person from the\r\nweapon, had not Cedric, as prompt as his companion was tardy,\r\nunsheathed, with the speed of lightning, the short sword which he wore,\r\nand at a single blow severed the point of the lance from the handle.\r\nThe blood rushed into the countenance of Prince John. He swore one of\r\nhis deepest oaths, and was about to utter some threat corresponding in\r\nviolence, when he was diverted from his purpose, partly by his own\r\nattendants, who gathered around him conjuring him to be patient, partly\r\nby a general exclamation of the crowd, uttered in loud applause of the\r\nspirited conduct of Cedric. The Prince rolled his eyes in indignation,\r\nas if to collect some safe and easy victim; and chancing to encounter\r\nthe firm glance of the same archer whom we have already noticed, and\r\nwho seemed to persist in his gesture of applause, in spite of the\r\nfrowning aspect which the Prince bent upon him, he demanded his reason\r\nfor clamouring thus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI always add my hollo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen I see a good shot, or a\r\ngallant blow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSayst thou?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Prince; \xe2\x80\x9cthen thou canst hit the white\r\nthyself, I\xe2\x80\x99ll warrant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA woodsman\xe2\x80\x99s mark, and at woodsman\xe2\x80\x99s distance, I can hit,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nthe yeoman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Wat Tyrrel\xe2\x80\x99s mark, at a hundred yards,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice from behind,\r\nbut by whom uttered could not be discerned.\r\n\r\nThis allusion to the fate of William Rufus, his Relative, at once\r\nincensed and alarmed Prince John. He satisfied himself, however, with\r\ncommanding the men-at-arms, who surrounded the lists, to keep an eye on\r\nthe braggart, pointing to the yeoman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy St Grizzel,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will try his own skill, who is so ready\r\nto give his voice to the feats of others!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall not fly the trial,\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman, with the composure which\r\nmarked his whole deportment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMeanwhile, stand up, ye Saxon churls,\xe2\x80\x9d said the fiery Prince; \xe2\x80\x9cfor, by\r\nthe light of Heaven, since I have said it, the Jew shall have his seat\r\namongst ye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means, an it please your Grace!\xe2\x80\x94it is not fit for such as we to\r\nsit with the rulers of the land,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew; whose ambition for\r\nprecedence though it had led him to dispute Place with the extenuated\r\nand impoverished descendant of the line of Montdidier, by no means\r\nstimulated him to an intrusion upon the privileges of the wealthy\r\nSaxons.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUp, infidel dog when I command you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cor I will have\r\nthy swarthy hide stript off, and tanned for horse-furniture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus urged, the Jew began to ascend the steep and narrow steps which\r\nled up to the gallery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me see,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prince, \xe2\x80\x9cwho dare stop him,\xe2\x80\x9d fixing his eye on\r\nCedric, whose attitude intimated his intention to hurl the Jew down\r\nheadlong.\r\n\r\nThe catastrophe was prevented by the clown Wamba, who, springing\r\nbetwixt his master and Isaac, and exclaiming, in answer to the Prince\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndefiance, \xe2\x80\x9cMarry, that will I!\xe2\x80\x9d opposed to the beard of the Jew a\r\nshield of brawn, which he plucked from beneath his cloak, and with\r\nwhich, doubtless, he had furnished himself, lest the tournament should\r\nhave proved longer than his appetite could endure abstinence. Finding\r\nthe abomination of his tribe opposed to his very nose, while the\r\nJester, at the same time, flourished his wooden sword above his head,\r\nthe Jew recoiled, missed his footing, and rolled down the steps,\xe2\x80\x94an\r\nexcellent jest to the spectators, who set up a loud laughter, in which\r\nPrince John and his attendants heartily joined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeal me the prize, cousin Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cI have vanquished my\r\nfoe in fair fight with sword and shield,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, brandishing the\r\nbrawn in one hand and the wooden sword in the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho, and what art thou, noble champion?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, still\r\nlaughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fool by right of descent,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester; \xe2\x80\x9cI am Wamba, the son\r\nof Witless, who was the son of Weatherbrain, who was the son of an\r\nAlderman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake room for the Jew in front of the lower ring,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John,\r\nnot unwilling perhaps to seize an apology to desist from his original\r\npurpose; \xe2\x80\x9cto place the vanquished beside the victor were false\r\nheraldry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnave upon fool were worse,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cand Jew upon bacon\r\nworst of all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGramercy! good fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cthou pleasest me\xe2\x80\x94Here,\r\nIsaac, lend me a handful of byzants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the Jew, stunned by the request, afraid to refuse, and unwilling to\r\ncomply, fumbled in the furred bag which hung by his girdle, and was\r\nperhaps endeavouring to ascertain how few coins might pass for a\r\nhandful, the Prince stooped from his jennet and settled Isaac\xe2\x80\x99s doubts\r\nby snatching the pouch itself from his side; and flinging to Wamba a\r\ncouple of the gold pieces which it contained, he pursued his career\r\nround the lists, leaving the Jew to the derision of those around him,\r\nand himself receiving as much applause from the spectators as if he had\r\ndone some honest and honourable action.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VIII\r\n\r\n\r\nAt this the challenger with fierce defy\r\nHis trumpet sounds; the challenged makes reply:\r\nWith clangour rings the field, resounds the vaulted sky.\r\nTheir visors closed, their lances in the rest,\r\nOr at the helmet pointed or the crest,\r\nThey vanish from the barrier, speed the race,\r\nAnd spurring see decrease the middle space.\r\n\r\n\r\nPALAMON AND ARCITE\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the midst of Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s cavalcade, he suddenly stopt, and\r\nappealing to the Prior of Jorvaulx, declared the principal business of\r\nthe day had been forgotten.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my halidom,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have forgotten, Sir Prior, to name the\r\nfair Sovereign of Love and of Beauty, by whose white hand the palm is\r\nto be distributed. For my part, I am liberal in my ideas, and I care\r\nnot if I give my vote for the black-eyed Rebecca.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly Virgin,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Prior, turning up his eyes in horror, \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nJewess!\xe2\x80\x94We should deserve to be stoned out of the lists; and I am not\r\nyet old enough to be a martyr. Besides, I swear by my patron saint,\r\nthat she is far inferior to the lovely Saxon, Rowena.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaxon or Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Prince, \xe2\x80\x9cSaxon or Jew, dog or hog, what\r\nmatters it? I say, name Rebecca, were it only to mortify the Saxon\r\nchurls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA murmur arose even among his own immediate attendants.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis passes a jest, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cno knight here will lay\r\nlance in rest if such an insult is attempted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the mere wantonness of insult,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the oldest and most\r\nimportant of Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s followers, Waldemar Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cand if your\r\nGrace attempt it, cannot but prove ruinous to your projects.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI entertained you, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said John, reining up his palfrey haughtily,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfor my follower, but not for my counsellor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose who follow your Grace in the paths which you tread,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nWaldemar, but speaking in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cacquire the right of\r\ncounsellors; for your interest and safety are not more deeply gaged\r\nthan their own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom the tone in which this was spoken, John saw the necessity of\r\nacquiescence. \xe2\x80\x9cI did but jest,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cand you turn upon me like so\r\nmany adders!
