Name whom you will, in the fiend\xe2\x80\x99s name, and please\r\nyourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, nay,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9clet the fair sovereign\xe2\x80\x99s throne remain\r\nunoccupied, until the conqueror shall be named, and then let him choose\r\nthe lady by whom it shall be filled. It will add another grace to his\r\ntriumph, and teach fair ladies to prize the love of valiant knights,\r\nwho can exalt them to such distinction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Brian de Bois-Guilbert gain the prize,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cI will\r\ngage my rosary that I name the Sovereign of Love and Beauty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBois-Guilbert,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cis a good lance; but there are\r\nothers around these lists, Sir Prior, who will not fear to encounter\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence, sirs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar, \xe2\x80\x9cand let the Prince assume his seat.\r\nThe knights and spectators are alike impatient, the time advances, and\r\nhighly fit it is that the sports should commence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPrince John, though not yet a monarch, had in Waldemar Fitzurse all the\r\ninconveniences of a favourite minister, who, in serving his sovereign,\r\nmust always do so in his own way. The Prince acquiesced, however,\r\nalthough his disposition was precisely of that kind which is apt to be\r\nobstinate upon trifles, and, assuming his throne, and being surrounded\r\nby his followers, gave signal to the heralds to proclaim the laws of\r\nthe tournament, which were briefly as follows:\r\n\r\nFirst, the five challengers were to undertake all comers.\r\n\r\nSecondly, any knight proposing to combat, might, if he pleased, select\r\na special antagonist from among the challengers, by touching his\r\nshield. If he did so with the reverse of his lance, the trial of skill\r\nwas made with what were called the arms of courtesy, that is, with\r\nlances at whose extremity a piece of round flat board was fixed, so\r\nthat no danger was encountered, save from the shock of the horses and\r\nriders. But if the shield was touched with the sharp end of the lance,\r\nthe combat was understood to be at \xe2\x80\x9coutrance\xe2\x80\x9d, that is, the knights\r\nwere to fight with sharp weapons, as in actual battle.\r\n\r\nThirdly, when the knights present had accomplished their vow, by each\r\nof them breaking five lances, the Prince was to declare the victor in\r\nthe first day\xe2\x80\x99s tourney, who should receive as prize a warhorse of\r\nexquisite beauty and matchless strength; and in addition to this reward\r\nof valour, it was now declared, he should have the peculiar honour of\r\nnaming the Queen of Love and Beauty, by whom the prize should be given\r\non the ensuing day.\r\n\r\nFourthly, it was announced, that, on the second day, there should be a\r\ngeneral tournament, in which all the knights present, who were desirous\r\nto win praise, might take part; and being divided into two bands of\r\nequal numbers, might fight it out manfully, until the signal was given\r\nby Prince John to cease the combat. The elected Queen of Love and\r\nBeauty was then to crown the knight whom the Prince should adjudge to\r\nhave borne himself best in this second day, with a coronet composed of\r\nthin gold plate, cut into the shape of a laurel crown. On this second\r\nday the knightly games ceased. But on that which was to follow, feats\r\nof archery, of bull-baiting, and other popular amusements, were to be\r\npractised, for the more immediate amusement of the populace. In this\r\nmanner did Prince John endeavour to lay the foundation of a popularity,\r\nwhich he was perpetually throwing down by some inconsiderate act of\r\nwanton aggression upon the feelings and prejudices of the people.\r\n\r\nThe lists now presented a most splendid spectacle. The sloping\r\ngalleries were crowded with all that was noble, great, wealthy, and\r\nbeautiful in the northern and midland parts of England; and the\r\ncontrast of the various dresses of these dignified spectators, rendered\r\nthe view as gay as it was rich, while the interior and lower space,\r\nfilled with the substantial burgesses and yeomen of merry England,\r\nformed, in their more plain attire, a dark fringe, or border, around\r\nthis circle of brilliant embroidery, relieving, and, at the same time,\r\nsetting off its splendour.\r\n\r\nThe heralds finished their proclamation with their usual cry of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLargesse, largesse, gallant knights!\xe2\x80\x9d and gold and silver pieces were\r\nshowered on them from the galleries, it being a high point of chivalry\r\nto exhibit liberality towards those whom the age accounted at once the\r\nsecretaries and the historians of honour. The bounty of the spectators\r\nwas acknowledged by the customary shouts of \xe2\x80\x9cLove of Ladies\xe2\x80\x94Death of\r\nChampions\xe2\x80\x94Honour to the Generous\xe2\x80\x94Glory to the Brave!\xe2\x80\x9d To which the more\r\nhumble spectators added their acclamations, and a numerous band of\r\ntrumpeters the flourish of their martial instruments. When these sounds\r\nhad ceased, the heralds withdrew from the lists in gay and glittering\r\nprocession, and none remained within them save the marshals of the\r\nfield, who, armed cap-a-pie, sat on horseback, motionless as statues,\r\nat the opposite ends of the lists. Meantime, the enclosed space at the\r\nnorthern extremity of the lists, large as it was, was now completely\r\ncrowded with knights desirous to prove their skill against the\r\nchallengers, and, when viewed from the galleries, presented the\r\nappearance of a sea of waving plumage, intermixed with glistening\r\nhelmets, and tall lances, to the extremities of which were, in many\r\ncases, attached small pennons of about a span\xe2\x80\x99s breadth, which,\r\nfluttering in the air as the breeze caught them, joined with the\r\nrestless motion of the feathers to add liveliness to the scene.\r\n\r\nAt length the barriers were opened, and five knights, chosen by lot,\r\nadvanced slowly into the area; a single champion riding in front, and\r\nthe other four following in pairs. All were splendidly armed, and my\r\nSaxon authority (in the Wardour Manuscript) records at great length\r\ntheir devices, their colours, and the embroidery of their horse\r\ntrappings. It is unnecessary to be particular on these subjects. To\r\nborrow lines from a contemporary poet, who has written but too little:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe knights are dust,\r\nAnd their good swords are rust,\r\nTheir souls are with the saints, we trust.\xe2\x80\x9d 17\r\n\r\n\r\nTheir escutcheons have long mouldered from the walls of their castles.\r\nTheir castles themselves are but green mounds and shattered ruins\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nplace that once knew them, knows them no more\xe2\x80\x94nay, many a race since\r\ntheirs has died out and been forgotten in the very land which they\r\noccupied, with all the authority of feudal proprietors and feudal\r\nlords. What, then, would it avail the reader to know their names, or\r\nthe evanescent symbols of their martial rank!\r\n\r\nNow, however, no whit anticipating the oblivion which awaited their\r\nnames and feats, the champions advanced through the lists, restraining\r\ntheir fiery steeds, and compelling them to move slowly, while, at the\r\nsame time, they exhibited their paces, together with the grace and\r\ndexterity of the riders. As the procession entered the lists, the sound\r\nof a wild Barbaric music was heard from behind the tents of the\r\nchallengers, where the performers were concealed. It was of Eastern\r\norigin, having been brought from the Holy Land; and the mixture of the\r\ncymbals and bells seemed to bid welcome at once, and defiance, to the\r\nknights as they advanced. With the eyes of an immense concourse of\r\nspectators fixed upon them, the five knights advanced up the platform\r\nupon which the tents of the challengers stood, and there separating\r\nthemselves, each touched slightly, and with the reverse of his lance,\r\nthe shield of the antagonist to whom he wished to oppose himself. The\r\nlower orders of spectators in general\xe2\x80\x94nay, many of the higher class,\r\nand it is even said several of the ladies, were rather disappointed at\r\nthe champions choosing the arms of courtesy. For the same sort of\r\npersons, who, in the present day, applaud most highly the deepest\r\ntragedies, were then interested in a tournament exactly in proportion\r\nto the danger incurred by the champions engaged.\r\n\r\nHaving intimated their more pacific purpose, the champions retreated to\r\nthe extremity of the lists, where they remained drawn up in a line;\r\nwhile the challengers, sallying each from his pavilion, mounted their\r\nhorses, and, headed by Brian de Bois-Guilbert, descended from the\r\nplatform, and opposed themselves individually to the knights who had\r\ntouched their respective shields.\r\n\r\nAt the flourish of clarions and trumpets, they started out against each\r\nother at full gallop; and such was the superior dexterity or good\r\nfortune of the challengers, that those opposed to Bois-Guilbert,\r\nMalvoisin, and Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, rolled on the ground. The antagonist of\r\nGrantmesnil, instead of bearing his lance-point fair against the crest\r\nor the shield of his enemy, swerved so much from the direct line as to\r\nbreak the weapon athwart the person of his opponent\xe2\x80\x94a circumstance\r\nwhich was accounted more disgraceful than that of being actually\r\nunhorsed; because the latter might happen from accident, whereas the\r\nformer evinced awkwardness and want of management of the weapon and of\r\nthe horse. The fifth knight alone maintained the honour of his party,\r\nand parted fairly with the Knight of St John, both splintering their\r\nlances without advantage on either side.\r\n\r\nThe shouts of the multitude, together with the acclamations of the\r\nheralds, and the clangour of the trumpets, announced the triumph of the\r\nvictors and the defeat of the vanquished. The former retreated to their\r\npavilions, and the latter, gathering themselves up as they could,\r\nwithdrew from the lists in disgrace and dejection, to agree with their\r\nvictors concerning the redemption of their arms and their horses,\r\nwhich, according to the laws of the tournament, they had forfeited. The\r\nfifth of their number alone tarried in the lists long enough to be\r\ngreeted by the applauses of the spectators, amongst whom he retreated,\r\nto the aggravation, doubtless, of his companions\xe2\x80\x99 mortification.\r\n\r\nA second and a third party of knights took the field; and although they\r\nhad various success, yet, upon the whole, the advantage decidedly\r\nremained with the challengers, not one of whom lost his seat or swerved\r\nfrom his charge\xe2\x80\x94misfortunes which befell one or two of their\r\nantagonists in each encounter. The spirits, therefore, of those opposed\r\nto them, seemed to be considerably damped by their continued success.\r\nThree knights only appeared on the fourth entry, who, avoiding the\r\nshields of Bois-Guilbert and Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, contented themselves with\r\ntouching those of the three other knights, who had not altogether\r\nmanifested the same strength and dexterity. This politic selection did\r\nnot alter the fortune of the field, the challengers were still\r\nsuccessful: one of their antagonists was overthrown, and both the\r\nothers failed in the \xe2\x80\x9cattaint\xe2\x80\x9d, 18 that is, in striking the helmet and\r\nshield of their antagonist firmly and strongly, with the lance held in\r\na direct line, so that the weapon might break unless the champion was\r\noverthrown.\r\n\r\nAfter this fourth encounter, there was a considerable pause; nor did it\r\nappear that any one was very desirous of renewing the contest. The\r\nspectators murmured among themselves; for, among the challengers,\r\nMalvoisin and Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf were unpopular from their characters, and\r\nthe others, except Grantmesnil, were disliked as strangers and\r\nforeigners.\r\n\r\nBut none shared the general feeling of dissatisfaction so keenly as\r\nCedric the Saxon, who saw, in each advantage gained by the Norman\r\nchallengers, a repeated triumph over the honour of England. His own\r\neducation had taught him no skill in the games of chivalry, although,\r\nwith the arms of his Saxon ancestors, he had manifested himself, on\r\nmany occasions, a brave and determined soldier. He looked anxiously to\r\nAthelstane, who had learned the accomplishments of the age, as if\r\ndesiring that he should make some personal effort to recover the\r\nvictory which was passing into the hands of the Templar and his\r\nassociates. But, though both stout of heart, and strong of person,\r\nAthelstane had a disposition too inert and unambitious to make the\r\nexertions which Cedric seemed to expect from him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe day is against England, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, in a marked tone;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9care you not tempted to take the lance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall tilt to-morrow\xe2\x80\x9d answered Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cin the \xe2\x80\x98melee\xe2\x80\x99; it is\r\nnot worth while for me to arm myself to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTwo things displeased Cedric in this speech. It contained the Norman\r\nword \xe2\x80\x9cmelee\xe2\x80\x9d, (to express the general conflict,) and it evinced some\r\nindifference to the honour of the country; but it was spoken by\r\nAthelstane, whom he held in such profound respect, that he would not\r\ntrust himself to canvass his motives or his foibles. Moreover, he had\r\nno time to make any remark, for Wamba thrust in his word, observing,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was better, though scarce easier, to be the best man among a\r\nhundred, than the best man of two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthelstane took the observation as a serious compliment; but Cedric,\r\nwho better understood the Jester\xe2\x80\x99s meaning, darted at him a severe and\r\nmenacing look; and lucky it was for Wamba, perhaps, that the time and\r\nplace prevented his receiving, notwithstanding his place and service,\r\nmore sensible marks of his master\xe2\x80\x99s resentment.\r\n\r\nThe pause in the tournament was still uninterrupted, excepting by the\r\nvoices of the heralds exclaiming\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLove of ladies, splintering of\r\nlances! stand forth gallant knights, fair eyes look upon your deeds!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe music also of the challengers breathed from time to time wild\r\nbursts expressive of triumph or defiance, while the clowns grudged a\r\nholiday which seemed to pass away in inactivity; and old knights and\r\nnobles lamented in whispers the decay of martial spirit, spoke of the\r\ntriumphs of their younger days, but agreed that the land did not now\r\nsupply dames of such transcendent beauty as had animated the jousts of\r\nformer times. Prince John began to talk to his attendants about making\r\nready the banquet, and the necessity of adjudging the prize to Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, who had, with a single spear, overthrown two knights,\r\nand foiled a third.\r\n\r\nAt length, as the Saracenic music of the challengers concluded one of\r\nthose long and high flourishes with which they had broken the silence\r\nof the lists, it was answered by a solitary trumpet, which breathed a\r\nnote of defiance from the northern extremity. All eyes were turned to\r\nsee the new champion which these sounds announced, and no sooner were\r\nthe barriers opened than he paced into the lists. As far as could be\r\njudged of a man sheathed in armour, the new adventurer did not greatly\r\nexceed the middle size, and seemed to be rather slender than strongly\r\nmade. His suit of armour was formed of steel, richly inlaid with gold,\r\nand the device on his shield was a young oak-tree pulled up by the\r\nroots, with the Spanish word Desdichado, signifying Disinherited. He\r\nwas mounted on a gallant black horse, and as he passed through the\r\nlists he gracefully saluted the Prince and the ladies by lowering his\r\nlance. The dexterity with which he managed his steed, and something of\r\nyouthful grace which he displayed in his manner, won him the favour of\r\nthe multitude, which some of the lower classes expressed by calling\r\nout, \xe2\x80\x9cTouch Ralph de Vipont\xe2\x80\x99s shield\xe2\x80\x94touch the Hospitallers shield; he\r\nhas the least sure seat, he is your cheapest bargain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe champion, moving onward amid these well-meant hints, ascended the\r\nplatform by the sloping alley which led to it from the lists, and, to\r\nthe astonishment of all present, riding straight up to the central\r\npavilion, struck with the sharp end of his spear the shield of Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert until it rung again. All stood astonished at his\r\npresumption, but none more than the redoubted Knight whom he had thus\r\ndefied to mortal combat, and who, little expecting so rude a challenge,\r\nwas standing carelessly at the door of the pavilion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you confessed yourself, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cand have you\r\nheard mass this morning, that you peril your life so frankly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am fitter to meet death than thou art\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Disinherited\r\nKnight; for by this name the stranger had recorded himself in the books\r\nof the tourney.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen take your place in the lists,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cand look your\r\nlast upon the sun; for this night thou shalt sleep in paradise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGramercy for thy courtesy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Disinherited Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cand to\r\nrequite it, I advise thee to take a fresh horse and a new lance, for by\r\nmy honour you will need both.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving expressed himself thus confidently, he reined his horse backward\r\ndown the slope which he had ascended, and compelled him in the same\r\nmanner to move backward through the lists, till he reached the northern\r\nextremity, where he remained stationary, in expectation of his\r\nantagonist. This feat of horsemanship again attracted the applause of\r\nthe multitude.\r\n\r\nHowever incensed at his adversary for the precautions which he\r\nrecommended, Brian de Bois-Guilbert did not neglect his advice; for his\r\nhonour was too nearly concerned, to permit his neglecting any means\r\nwhich might ensure victory over his presumptuous opponent. He changed\r\nhis horse for a proved and fresh one of great strength and spirit. He\r\nchose a new and a tough spear, lest the wood of the former might have\r\nbeen strained in the previous encounters he had sustained. Lastly, he\r\nlaid aside his shield, which had received some little damage, and\r\nreceived another from his squires. His first had only borne the general\r\ndevice of his rider, representing two knights riding upon one horse, an\r\nemblem expressive of the original humility and poverty of the Templars,\r\nqualities which they had since exchanged for the arrogance and wealth\r\nthat finally occasioned their suppression. Bois-Guilbert\xe2\x80\x99s new shield\r\nbore a raven in full flight, holding in its claws a skull, and bearing\r\nthe motto, \xe2\x80\x9cGare le Corbeau\xe2\x80\x9d.\r\n\r\nWhen the two champions stood opposed to each other at the two\r\nextremities of the lists, the public expectation was strained to the\r\nhighest pitch. Few augured the possibility that the encounter could\r\nterminate well for the Disinherited Knight, yet his courage and\r\ngallantry secured the general good wishes of the spectators.\r\n\r\nThe trumpets had no sooner given the signal, than the champions\r\nvanished from their posts with the speed of lightning, and closed in\r\nthe centre of the lists with the shock of a thunderbolt. The lances\r\nburst into shivers up to the very grasp, and it seemed at the moment\r\nthat both knights had fallen, for the shock had made each horse recoil\r\nbackwards upon its haunches. The address of the riders recovered their\r\nsteeds by use of the bridle and spur; and having glared on each other\r\nfor an instant with eyes which seemed to flash fire through the bars of\r\ntheir visors, each made a demi-volte, and, retiring to the extremity of\r\nthe lists, received a fresh lance from the attendants.\r\n\r\nA loud shout from the spectators, waving of scarfs and handkerchiefs,\r\nand general acclamations, attested the interest taken by the spectators\r\nin this encounter; the most equal, as well as the best performed, which\r\nhad graced the day. But no sooner had the knights resumed their\r\nstation, than the clamour of applause was hushed into a silence, so\r\ndeep and so dead, that it seemed the multitude were afraid even to\r\nbreathe.\r\n\r\nA few minutes pause having been allowed, that the combatants and their\r\nhorses might recover breath, Prince John with his truncheon signed to\r\nthe trumpets to sound the onset. The champions a second time sprung\r\nfrom their stations, and closed in the centre of the lists, with the\r\nsame speed, the same dexterity, the same violence, but not the same\r\nequal fortune as before.\r\n\r\nIn this second encounter, the Templar aimed at the centre of his\r\nantagonist\xe2\x80\x99s shield, and struck it so fair and forcibly, that his spear\r\nwent to shivers, and the Disinherited Knight reeled in his saddle. On\r\nthe other hand, that champion had, in the beginning of his career,\r\ndirected the point of his lance towards Bois-Guilbert\xe2\x80\x99s shield, but,\r\nchanging his aim almost in the moment of encounter, he addressed it to\r\nthe helmet, a mark more difficult to hit, but which, if attained,\r\nrendered the shock more irresistible. Fair and true he hit the Norman\r\non the visor, where his lance\xe2\x80\x99s point kept hold of the bars. Yet, even\r\nat this disadvantage, the Templar sustained his high reputation; and\r\nhad not the girths of his saddle burst, he might not have been\r\nunhorsed. As it chanced, however, saddle, horse, and man, rolled on the\r\nground under a cloud of dust.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nTo extricate himself from the stirrups and fallen steed, was to the\r\nTemplar scarce the work of a moment; and, stung with madness, both at\r\nhis disgrace and at the acclamations with which it was hailed by the\r\nspectators, he drew his sword and waved it in defiance of his\r\nconqueror. The Disinherited Knight sprung from his steed, and also\r\nunsheathed his sword. The marshals of the field, however, spurred their\r\nhorses between them, and reminded them, that the laws of the tournament\r\ndid not, on the present occasion, permit this species of encounter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall meet again, I trust,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, casting a resentful\r\nglance at his antagonist; \xe2\x80\x9cand where there are none to separate us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf we do not,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Disinherited Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthe fault shall not be\r\nmine. On foot or horseback, with spear, with axe, or with sword, I am\r\nalike ready to encounter thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMore and angrier words would have been exchanged, but the marshals,\r\ncrossing their lances betwixt them, compelled them to separate. The\r\nDisinherited Knight returned to his first station, and Bois-Guilbert to\r\nhis tent, where he remained for the rest of the day in an agony of\r\ndespair.\r\n\r\nWithout alighting from his horse, the conqueror called for a bowl of\r\nwine, and opening the beaver, or lower part of his helmet, announced\r\nthat he quaffed it, \xe2\x80\x9cTo all true English hearts, and to the confusion\r\nof foreign tyrants.\xe2\x80\x9d He then commanded his trumpet to sound a defiance\r\nto the challengers, and desired a herald to announce to them, that he\r\nshould make no election, but was willing to encounter them in the order\r\nin which they pleased to advance against him.\r\n\r\nThe gigantic Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, armed in sable armour, was the first who\r\ntook the field. He bore on a white shield a black bull\xe2\x80\x99s head, half\r\ndefaced by the numerous encounters which he had undergone, and bearing\r\nthe arrogant motto, \xe2\x80\x9cCave, Adsum\xe2\x80\x9d. Over this champion the Disinherited\r\nKnight obtained a slight but decisive advantage. Both Knights broke\r\ntheir lances fairly, but Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, who lost a stirrup in the\r\nencounter, was adjudged to have the disadvantage.\r\n\r\nIn the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s third encounter with Sir Philip Malvoisin, he was\r\nequally successful; striking that baron so forcibly on the casque, that\r\nthe laces of the helmet broke, and Malvoisin, only saved from falling\r\nby being unhelmeted, was declared vanquished like his companions.\r\n\r\nIn his fourth combat with De Grantmesnil, the Disinherited Knight\r\nshowed as much courtesy as he had hitherto evinced courage and\r\ndexterity. De Grantmesnil\xe2\x80\x99s horse, which was young and violent, reared\r\nand plunged in the course of the career so as to disturb the rider\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naim, and the stranger, declining to take the advantage which this\r\naccident afforded him, raised his lance, and passing his antagonist\r\nwithout touching him, wheeled his horse and rode back again to his own\r\nend of the lists, offering his antagonist, by a herald, the chance of a\r\nsecond encounter. This De Grantmesnil declined, avowing himself\r\nvanquished as much by the courtesy as by the address of his opponent.\r\n\r\nRalph de Vipont summed up the list of the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s triumphs, being\r\nhurled to the ground with such force, that the blood gushed from his\r\nnose and his mouth, and he was borne senseless from the lists.\r\n\r\nThe acclamations of thousands applauded the unanimous award of the\r\nPrince and marshals, announcing that day\xe2\x80\x99s honours to the Disinherited\r\nKnight.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IX\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94In the midst was seen\r\nA lady of a more majestic mien,\r\nBy stature and by beauty mark\xe2\x80\x99d their sovereign Queen.\r\n\r\nAnd as in beauty she surpass\xe2\x80\x99d the choir,\r\nSo nobler than the rest was her attire;\r\nA crown of ruddy gold enclosed her brow,\r\nPlain without pomp, and rich without a show;\r\nA branch of Agnus Castus in her hand,\r\nShe bore aloft her symbol of command.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE FLOWER AND THE LEAF\r\n\r\n\r\nWilliam de Wyvil and Stephen de Martival, the marshals of the field,\r\nwere the first to offer their congratulations to the victor, praying\r\nhim, at the same time, to suffer his helmet to be unlaced, or, at\r\nleast, that he would raise his visor ere they conducted him to receive\r\nthe prize of the day\xe2\x80\x99s tourney from the hands of Prince John. The\r\nDisinherited Knight, with all knightly courtesy, declined their\r\nrequest, alleging, that he could not at this time suffer his face to be\r\nseen, for reasons which he had assigned to the heralds when he entered\r\nthe lists. The marshals were perfectly satisfied by this reply; for\r\namidst the frequent and capricious vows by which knights were\r\naccustomed to bind themselves in the days of chivalry, there were none\r\nmore common than those by which they engaged to remain incognito for a\r\ncertain space, or until some particular adventure was achieved. The\r\nmarshals, therefore, pressed no farther into the mystery of the\r\nDisinherited Knight, but, announcing to Prince John the conqueror\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndesire to remain unknown, they requested permission to bring him before\r\nhis Grace, in order that he might receive the reward of his valour.\r\n\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s curiosity was excited by the mystery observed by the stranger;\r\nand, being already displeased with the issue of the tournament, in\r\nwhich the challengers whom he favoured had been successively defeated\r\nby one knight, he answered haughtily to the marshals, \xe2\x80\x9cBy the light of\r\nOur Lady\xe2\x80\x99s brow, this same knight hath been disinherited as well of his\r\ncourtesy as of his lands, since he desires to appear before us without\r\nuncovering his face.\xe2\x80\x94Wot ye, my lords,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning round to his\r\ntrain, \xe2\x80\x9cwho this gallant can be, that bears himself thus proudly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot guess,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cnor did I think there had been\r\nwithin the four seas that girth Britain a champion that could bear down\r\nthese five knights in one day\xe2\x80\x99s jousting. By my faith, I shall never\r\nforget the force with which he shocked De Vipont. The poor Hospitaller\r\nwas hurled from his saddle like a stone from a sling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoast not of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said a Knight of St John, who was present; \xe2\x80\x9cyour\r\nTemple champion had no better luck. I saw your brave lance,\r\nBois-Guilbert, roll thrice over, grasping his hands full of sand at\r\nevery turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDe Bracy, being attached to the Templars, would have replied, but was\r\nprevented by Prince John. \xe2\x80\x9cSilence, sirs!\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat unprofitable\r\ndebate have we here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe victor,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Wyvil, \xe2\x80\x9cstill waits the pleasure of your\r\nhighness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is our pleasure,\xe2\x80\x9d answered John, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he do so wait until we learn\r\nwhether there is not some one who can at least guess at his name and\r\nquality. Should he remain there till night-fall, he has had work enough\r\nto keep him warm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Grace,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cwill do less than due honour to\r\nthe victor, if you compel him to wait till we tell your highness that\r\nwhich we cannot know; at least I can form no guess\xe2\x80\x94unless he be one of\r\nthe good lances who accompanied King Richard to Palestine, and who are\r\nnow straggling homeward from the Holy Land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be the Earl of Salisbury,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9che is about the same\r\npitch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Thomas de Multon, the Knight of Gilsland, rather,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSalisbury is bigger in the bones.\xe2\x80\x9d A whisper arose among the train,\r\nbut by whom first suggested could not be ascertained. \xe2\x80\x9cIt might be the\r\nKing\xe2\x80\x94it might be Richard C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion himself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOver God\xe2\x80\x99s forbode!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, involuntarily turning at the\r\nsame time as pale as death, and shrinking as if blighted by a flash of\r\nlightning; \xe2\x80\x9cWaldemar!\xe2\x80\x94De Bracy! brave knights and gentlemen, remember\r\nyour promises, and stand truly by me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is no danger impending,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar Fitzurse; \xe2\x80\x9care you so\r\nlittle acquainted with the gigantic limbs of your father\xe2\x80\x99s son, as to\r\nthink they can be held within the circumference of yonder suit of\r\narmour?\xe2\x80\x94De Wyvil and Martival, you will best serve the Prince by\r\nbringing forward the victor to the throne, and ending an error that has\r\nconjured all the blood from his cheeks.\xe2\x80\x94Look at him more closely,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ncontinued, \xe2\x80\x9cyour highness will see that he wants three inches of King\r\nRichard\xe2\x80\x99s height, and twice as much of his shoulder-breadth. The very\r\nhorse he backs, could not have carried the ponderous weight of King\r\nRichard through a single course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile he was yet speaking, the marshals brought forward the\r\nDisinherited Knight to the foot of a wooden flight of steps, which\r\nformed the ascent from the lists to Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s throne. Still\r\ndiscomposed with the idea that his brother, so much injured, and to\r\nwhom he was so much indebted, had suddenly arrived in his native\r\nkingdom, even the distinctions pointed out by Fitzurse did not\r\naltogether remove the Prince\xe2\x80\x99s apprehensions; and while, with a short\r\nand embarrassed eulogy upon his valour, he caused to be delivered to\r\nhim the war-horse assigned as the prize, he trembled lest from the\r\nbarred visor of the mailed form before him, an answer might be\r\nreturned, in the deep and awful accents of Richard the Lion-hearted.\r\n\r\nBut the Disinherited Knight spoke not a word in reply to the compliment\r\nof the Prince, which he only acknowledged with a profound obeisance.\r\n\r\nThe horse was led into the lists by two grooms richly dressed, the\r\nanimal itself being fully accoutred with the richest war-furniture;\r\nwhich, however, scarcely added to the value of the noble creature in\r\nthe eyes of those who were judges. Laying one hand upon the pommel of\r\nthe saddle, the Disinherited Knight vaulted at once upon the back of\r\nthe steed without making use of the stirrup, and, brandishing aloft his\r\nlance, rode twice around the lists, exhibiting the points and paces of\r\nthe horse with the skill of a perfect horseman.\r\n\r\nThe appearance of vanity, which might otherwise have been attributed to\r\nthis display, was removed by the propriety shown in exhibiting to the\r\nbest advantage the princely reward with which he had been just\r\nhonoured, and the Knight was again greeted by the acclamations of all\r\npresent.\r\n\r\nIn the meanwhile, the bustling Prior of Jorvaulx had reminded Prince\r\nJohn, in a whisper, that the victor must now display his good judgment,\r\ninstead of his valour, by selecting from among the beauties who graced\r\nthe galleries a lady, who should fill the throne of the Queen of Beauty\r\nand of Love, and deliver the prize of the tourney upon the ensuing day.\r\nThe Prince accordingly made a sign with his truncheon, as the Knight\r\npassed him in his second career around the lists. The Knight turned\r\ntowards the throne, and, sinking his lance, until the point was within\r\na foot of the ground, remained motionless, as if expecting John\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncommands; while all admired the sudden dexterity with which he\r\ninstantly reduced his fiery steed from a state of violent emotion and\r\nhigh excitation to the stillness of an equestrian statue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Disinherited Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9csince that is the only\r\ntitle by which we can address you, it is now your duty, as well as\r\nprivilege, to name the fair lady, who, as Queen of Honour and of Love,\r\nis to preside over next day\xe2\x80\x99s festival. If, as a stranger in our land,\r\nyou should require the aid of other judgment to guide your own, we can\r\nonly say that Alicia, the daughter of our gallant knight Waldemar\r\nFitzurse, has at our court been long held the first in beauty as in\r\nplace. Nevertheless, it is your undoubted prerogative to confer on whom\r\nyou please this crown, by the delivery of which to the lady of your\r\nchoice, the election of to-morrow\xe2\x80\x99s Queen will be formal and\r\ncomplete.\xe2\x80\x94Raise your lance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Knight obeyed; and Prince John placed upon its point a coronet of\r\ngreen satin, having around its edge a circlet of gold, the upper edge\r\nof which was relieved by arrow-points and hearts placed\r\ninterchangeably, like the strawberry leaves and balls upon a ducal\r\ncrown.\r\n\r\nIn the broad hint which he dropped respecting the daughter of Waldemar\r\nFitzurse, John had more than one motive, each the offspring of a mind,\r\nwhich was a strange mixture of carelessness and presumption with low\r\nartifice and cunning. He wished to banish from the minds of the\r\nchivalry around him his own indecent and unacceptable jest respecting\r\nthe Jewess Rebecca; he was desirous of conciliating Alicia\xe2\x80\x99s father\r\nWaldemar, of whom he stood in awe, and who had more than once shown\r\nhimself dissatisfied during the course of the day\xe2\x80\x99s proceedings. He had\r\nalso a wish to establish himself in the good graces of the lady; for\r\nJohn was at least as licentious in his pleasures as profligate in his\r\nambition. But besides all these reasons, he was desirous to raise up\r\nagainst the Disinherited Knight (towards whom he already entertained a\r\nstrong dislike) a powerful enemy in the person of Waldemar Fitzurse,\r\nwho was likely, he thought, highly to resent the injury done to his\r\ndaughter, in case, as was not unlikely, the victor should make another\r\nchoice.\r\n\r\nAnd so indeed it proved. For the Disinherited Knight passed the gallery\r\nclose to that of the Prince, in which the Lady Alicia was seated in the\r\nfull pride of triumphant beauty, and, pacing forwards as slowly as he\r\nhad hitherto rode swiftly around the lists, he seemed to exercise his\r\nright of examining the numerous fair faces which adorned that splendid\r\ncircle.\r\n\r\nIt was worth while to see the different conduct of the beauties who\r\nunderwent this examination, during the time it was proceeding. Some\r\nblushed, some assumed an air of pride and dignity, some looked straight\r\nforward, and essayed to seem utterly unconscious of what was going on,\r\nsome drew back in alarm, which was perhaps affected, some endeavoured\r\nto forbear smiling, and there were two or three who laughed outright.\r\nThere were also some who dropped their veils over their charms; but, as\r\nthe Wardour Manuscript says these were fair ones of ten years standing,\r\nit may be supposed that, having had their full share of such vanities,\r\nthey were willing to withdraw their claim, in order to give a fair\r\nchance to the rising beauties of the age.\r\n\r\nAt length the champion paused beneath the balcony in which the Lady\r\nRowena was placed, and the expectation of the spectators was excited to\r\nthe utmost.\r\n\r\nIt must be owned, that if an interest displayed in his success could\r\nhave bribed the Disinherited Knight, the part of the lists before which\r\nhe paused had merited his predilection. Cedric the Saxon, overjoyed at\r\nthe discomfiture of the Templar, and still more so at the miscarriage\r\nof his two malevolent neighbours, Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and Malvoisin, had,\r\nwith his body half stretched over the balcony, accompanied the victor\r\nin each course, not with his eyes only, but with his whole heart and\r\nsoul. The Lady Rowena had watched the progress of the day with equal\r\nattention, though without openly betraying the same intense interest.\r\nEven the unmoved Athelstane had shown symptoms of shaking off his\r\napathy, when, calling for a huge goblet of muscadine, he quaffed it to\r\nthe health of the Disinherited Knight. Another group, stationed under\r\nthe gallery occupied by the Saxons, had shown no less interest in the\r\nfate of the day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather Abraham!\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac of York, when the first course was run\r\nbetwixt the Templar and the Disinherited Knight, \xe2\x80\x9chow fiercely that\r\nGentile rides! Ah, the good horse that was brought all the long way\r\nfrom Barbary, he takes no more care of him than if he were a wild ass\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncolt\xe2\x80\x94and the noble armour, that was worth so many zecchins to Joseph\r\nPareira, the armourer of Milan, besides seventy in the hundred of\r\nprofits, he cares for it as little as if he had found it in the\r\nhighways!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he risks his own person and limbs, father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cin doing\r\nsuch a dreadful battle, he can scarce be expected to spare his horse\r\nand armour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChild!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Isaac, somewhat heated, \xe2\x80\x9cthou knowest not what thou\r\nspeakest\xe2\x80\x94His neck and limbs are his own, but his horse and armour\r\nbelong to\xe2\x80\x94Holy Jacob! what was I about to say!\xe2\x80\x94Nevertheless, it is a\r\ngood youth\xe2\x80\x94See, Rebecca! see, he is again about to go up to battle\r\nagainst the Philistine\xe2\x80\x94Pray, child\xe2\x80\x94pray for the safety of the good\r\nyouth,\xe2\x80\x94and of the speedy horse, and the rich armour.\xe2\x80\x94God of my\r\nfathers!\xe2\x80\x9d he again exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9che hath conquered, and the uncircumcised\r\nPhilistine hath fallen before his lance,\xe2\x80\x94even as Og the King of Bashan,\r\nand Sihon, King of the Amorites, fell before the sword of our\r\nfathers!\xe2\x80\x94Surely he shall take their gold and their silver, and their\r\nwar-horses, and their armour of brass and of steel, for a prey and for\r\na spoil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe same anxiety did the worthy Jew display during every course that\r\nwas run, seldom failing to hazard a hasty calculation concerning the\r\nvalue of the horse and armour which was forfeited to the champion upon\r\neach new success. There had been therefore no small interest taken in\r\nthe success of the Disinherited Knight, by those who occupied the part\r\nof the lists before which he now paused.\r\n\r\nWhether from indecision, or some other motive of hesitation, the\r\nchampion of the day remained stationary for more than a minute, while\r\nthe eyes of the silent audience were riveted upon his motions; and\r\nthen, gradually and gracefully sinking the point of his lance, he\r\ndeposited the coronet which it supported at the feet of the fair\r\nRowena. The trumpets instantly sounded, while the heralds proclaimed\r\nthe Lady Rowena the Queen of Beauty and of Love for the ensuing day,\r\nmenacing with suitable penalties those who should be disobedient to her\r\nauthority. They then repeated their cry of Largesse, to which Cedric,\r\nin the height of his joy, replied by an ample donative, and to which\r\nAthelstane, though less promptly, added one equally large.\r\n\r\nThere was some murmuring among the damsels of Norman descent, who were\r\nas much unused to see the preference given to a Saxon beauty, as the\r\nNorman nobles were to sustain defeat in the games of chivalry which\r\nthey themselves had introduced. But these sounds of disaffection were\r\ndrowned by the popular shout of \xe2\x80\x9cLong live the Lady Rowena, the chosen\r\nand lawful Queen of Love and of Beauty!\xe2\x80\x9d To which many in the lower\r\narea added, \xe2\x80\x9cLong live the Saxon Princess! long live the race of the\r\nimmortal Alfred!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHowever unacceptable these sounds might be to Prince John, and to those\r\naround him, he saw himself nevertheless obliged to confirm the\r\nnomination of the victor, and accordingly calling to horse, he left his\r\nthrone; and mounting his jennet, accompanied by his train, he again\r\nentered the lists. The Prince paused a moment beneath the gallery of\r\nthe Lady Alicia, to whom he paid his compliments, observing, at the\r\nsame time, to those around him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBy my halidome, sirs! if the Knight\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfeats in arms have shown that he hath limbs and sinews, his choice hath\r\nno less proved that his eyes are none of the clearest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was on this occasion, as during his whole life, John\xe2\x80\x99s misfortune,\r\nnot perfectly to understand the characters of those whom he wished to\r\nconciliate. Waldemar Fitzurse was rather offended than pleased at the\r\nPrince stating thus broadly an opinion, that his daughter had been\r\nslighted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know no right of chivalry,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmore precious or inalienable\r\nthan that of each free knight to choose his lady-love by his own\r\njudgment. My daughter courts distinction from no one; and in her own\r\ncharacter, and in her own sphere, will never fail to receive the full\r\nproportion of that which is her due.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPrince John replied not; but, spurring his horse, as if to give vent to\r\nhis vexation, he made the animal bound forward to the gallery where\r\nRowena was seated, with the crown still at her feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAssume,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cfair lady, the mark of your sovereignty, to which\r\nnone vows homage more sincerely than ourself, John of Anjou; and if it\r\nplease you to-day, with your noble sire and friends, to grace our\r\nbanquet in the Castle of Ashby, we shall learn to know the empress to\r\nwhose service we devote to-morrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRowena remained silent, and Cedric answered for her in his native\r\nSaxon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lady Rowena,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cpossesses not the language in which to\r\nreply to your courtesy, or to sustain her part in your festival. I\r\nalso, and the noble Athelstane of Coningsburgh, speak only the\r\nlanguage, and practise only the manners, of our fathers. We therefore\r\ndecline with thanks your Highness\xe2\x80\x99s courteous invitation to the\r\nbanquet. To-morrow, the Lady Rowena will take upon her the state to\r\nwhich she has been called by the free election of the victor Knight,\r\nconfirmed by the acclamations of the people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he lifted the coronet, and placed it upon Rowena\xe2\x80\x99s head, in\r\ntoken of her acceptance of the temporary authority assigned to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat says he?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, affecting not to understand the Saxon\r\nlanguage, in which, however, he was well skilled. The purport of\r\nCedric\xe2\x80\x99s speech was repeated to him in French. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is well,\xe2\x80\x9d he said;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cto-morrow we will ourself conduct this mute sovereign to her seat of\r\ndignity.\xe2\x80\x94You, at least, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, turning to the victor,\r\nwho had remained near the gallery, \xe2\x80\x9cwill this day share our banquet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Knight, speaking for the first time, in a low and hurried voice,\r\nexcused himself by pleading fatigue, and the necessity of preparing for\r\nto-morrow\xe2\x80\x99s encounter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, haughtily; \xe2\x80\x9calthough unused to such\r\nrefusals, we will endeavour to digest our banquet as we may, though\r\nungraced by the most successful in arms, and his elected Queen of\r\nBeauty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he prepared to leave the lists with his glittering train,\r\nand his turning his steed for that purpose, was the signal for the\r\nbreaking up and dispersion of the spectators.\r\n\r\nYet, with the vindictive memory proper to offended pride, especially\r\nwhen combined with conscious want of desert, John had hardly proceeded\r\nthree paces, ere again, turning around, he fixed an eye of stern\r\nresentment upon the yeoman who had displeased him in the early part of\r\nthe day, and issued his commands to the men-at-arms who stood near\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cOn\r\nyour life, suffer not that fellow to escape.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe yeoman stood the angry glance of the Prince with the same unvaried\r\nsteadiness which had marked his former deportment, saying, with a\r\nsmile, \xe2\x80\x9cI have no intention to leave Ashby until the day after\r\nto-morrow\xe2\x80\x94I must see how Staffordshire and Leicestershire can draw\r\ntheir bows\xe2\x80\x94the forests of Needwood and Charnwood must rear good\r\narchers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John to his attendants, but not in direct reply,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwill see how he can draw his own; and woe betide him unless his skill\r\nshould prove some apology for his insolence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is full time,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the \xe2\x80\x98outrecuidance\xe2\x80\x99 19 of these\r\npeasants should be restrained by some striking example.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWaldemar Fitzurse, who probably thought his patron was not taking the\r\nreadiest road to popularity, shrugged up his shoulders and was silent.\r\nPrince John resumed his retreat from the lists, and the dispersion of\r\nthe multitude became general.\r\n\r\nIn various routes, according to the different quarters from which they\r\ncame, and in groups of various numbers, the spectators were seen\r\nretiring over the plain. By far the most numerous part streamed towards\r\nthe town of Ashby, where many of the distinguished persons were lodged\r\nin the castle, and where others found accommodation in the town itself.\r\nAmong these were most of the knights who had already appeared in the\r\ntournament, or who proposed to fight there the ensuing day, and who, as\r\nthey rode slowly along, talking over the events of the day, were\r\ngreeted with loud shouts by the populace. The same acclamations were\r\nbestowed upon Prince John, although he was indebted for them rather to\r\nthe splendour of his appearance and train, than to the popularity of\r\nhis character.\r\n\r\nA more sincere and more general, as well as a better-merited\r\nacclamation, attended the victor of the day, until, anxious to withdraw\r\nhimself from popular notice, he accepted the accommodation of one of\r\nthose pavilions pitched at the extremities of the lists, the use of\r\nwhich was courteously tendered him by the marshals of the field. On his\r\nretiring to his tent, many who had lingered in the lists, to look upon\r\nand form conjectures concerning him, also dispersed.\r\n\r\nThe signs and sounds of a tumultuous concourse of men lately crowded\r\ntogether in one place, and agitated by the same passing events, were\r\nnow exchanged for the distant hum of voices of different groups\r\nretreating in all directions, and these speedily died away in silence.\r\nNo other sounds were heard save the voices of the menials who stripped\r\nthe galleries of their cushions and tapestry, in order to put them in\r\nsafety for the night, and wrangled among themselves for the half-used\r\nbottles of wine and relics of the refreshment which had been served\r\nround to the spectators.\r\n\r\nBeyond the precincts of the lists more than one forge was erected; and\r\nthese now began to glimmer through the twilight, announcing the toil of\r\nthe armourers, which was to continue through the whole night, in order\r\nto repair or alter the suits of armour to be used again on the morrow.\r\n\r\nA strong guard of men-at-arms, renewed at intervals, from two hours to\r\ntwo hours, surrounded the lists, and kept watch during the night.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER X\r\n\r\n\r\nThus, like the sad presaging raven, that tolls\r\nThe sick man\xe2\x80\x99s passport in her hollow beak,\r\nAnd in the shadow of the silent night\r\nDoth shake contagion from her sable wings;\r\nVex\xe2\x80\x99d and tormented, runs poor Barrabas,\r\nWith fatal curses towards these Christians.\r\n\r\n\r\nJEW OF MALTA\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Disinherited Knight had no sooner reached his pavilion, than\r\nsquires and pages in abundance tendered their services to disarm him,\r\nto bring fresh attire, and to offer him the refreshment of the bath.\r\nTheir zeal on this occasion was perhaps sharpened by curiosity, since\r\nevery one desired to know who the knight was that had gained so many\r\nlaurels, yet had refused, even at the command of Prince John, to lift\r\nhis visor or to name his name. But their officious inquisitiveness was\r\nnot gratified. The Disinherited Knight refused all other assistance\r\nsave that of his own squire, or rather yeoman\xe2\x80\x94a clownish-looking man,\r\nwho, wrapt in a cloak of dark-coloured felt, and having his head and\r\nface half-buried in a Norman bonnet made of black fur, seemed to affect\r\nthe incognito as much as his master. All others being excluded from the\r\ntent, this attendant relieved his master from the more burdensome parts\r\nof his armour, and placed food and wine before him, which the exertions\r\nof the day rendered very acceptable.\r\n\r\nThe Knight had scarcely finished a hasty meal, ere his menial announced\r\nto him that five men, each leading a barbed steed, desired to speak\r\nwith him. The Disinherited Knight had exchanged his armour for the long\r\nrobe usually worn by those of his condition, which, being furnished\r\nwith a hood, concealed the features, when such was the pleasure of the\r\nwearer, almost as completely as the visor of the helmet itself, but the\r\ntwilight, which was now fast darkening, would of itself have rendered a\r\ndisguise unnecessary, unless to persons to whom the face of an\r\nindividual chanced to be particularly well known.\r\n\r\nThe Disinherited Knight, therefore, stept boldly forth to the front of\r\nhis tent, and found in attendance the squires of the challengers, whom\r\nhe easily knew by their russet and black dresses, each of whom led his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s charger, loaded with the armour in which he had that day\r\nfought.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAccording to the laws of chivalry,\xe2\x80\x9d said the foremost of these men,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, Baldwin de Oyley, squire to the redoubted Knight Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, make offer to you, styling yourself, for the present,\r\nthe Disinherited Knight, of the horse and armour used by the said Brian\r\nde Bois-Guilbert in this day\xe2\x80\x99s Passage of Arms, leaving it with your\r\nnobleness to retain or to ransom the same, according to your pleasure;\r\nfor such is the law of arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe other squires repeated nearly the same formula, and then stood to\r\nawait the decision of the Disinherited Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo you four, sirs,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Knight, addressing those who had last\r\nspoken, \xe2\x80\x9cand to your honourable and valiant masters, I have one common\r\nreply. Commend me to the noble knights, your masters, and say, I should\r\ndo ill to deprive them of steeds and arms which can never be used by\r\nbraver cavaliers.\xe2\x80\x94I would I could here end my message to these gallant\r\nknights; but being, as I term myself, in truth and earnest, the\r\nDisinherited, I must be thus far bound to your masters, that they will,\r\nof their courtesy, be pleased to ransom their steeds and armour, since\r\nthat which I wear I can hardly term mine own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe stand commissioned, each of us,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the squire of Reginald\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cto offer a hundred zecchins in ransom of these horses\r\nand suits of armour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is sufficient,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Disinherited Knight. \xe2\x80\x9cHalf the sum my\r\npresent necessities compel me to accept; of the remaining half,\r\ndistribute one moiety among yourselves, sir squires, and divide the\r\nother half betwixt the heralds and the pursuivants, and minstrels, and\r\nattendants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe squires, with cap in hand, and low reverences, expressed their deep\r\nsense of a courtesy and generosity not often practised, at least upon a\r\nscale so extensive. The Disinherited Knight then addressed his\r\ndiscourse to Baldwin, the squire of Brian de Bois-Guilbert. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom your\r\nmaster,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI will accept neither arms nor ransom. Say to him in\r\nmy name, that our strife is not ended\xe2\x80\x94no, not till we have fought as\r\nwell with swords as with lances\xe2\x80\x94as well on foot as on horseback. To\r\nthis mortal quarrel he has himself defied me, and I shall not forget\r\nthe challenge.\xe2\x80\x94Meantime, let him be assured, that I hold him not as one\r\nof his companions, with whom I can with pleasure exchange courtesies;\r\nbut rather as one with whom I stand upon terms of mortal defiance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy master,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Baldwin, \xe2\x80\x9cknows how to requite scorn with scorn,\r\nand blows with blows, as well as courtesy with courtesy. Since you\r\ndisdain to accept from him any share of the ransom at which you have\r\nrated the arms of the other knights, I must leave his armour and his\r\nhorse here, being well assured that he will never deign to mount the\r\none nor wear the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have spoken well, good squire,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Disinherited Knight,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwell and boldly, as it beseemeth him to speak who answers for an\r\nabsent master. Leave not, however, the horse and armour here. Restore\r\nthem to thy master; or, if he scorns to accept them, retain them, good\r\nfriend, for thine own use. So far as they are mine, I bestow them upon\r\nyou freely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBaldwin made a deep obeisance, and retired with his companions; and the\r\nDisinherited Knight entered the pavilion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThus far, Gurth,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, addressing his attendant, \xe2\x80\x9cthe reputation\r\nof English chivalry hath not suffered in my hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cfor a Saxon swineherd, have not ill played the\r\npersonage of a Norman squire-at-arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYea, but,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Disinherited Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast ever kept me\r\nin anxiety lest thy clownish bearing should discover thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTush!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cI fear discovery from none, saving my playfellow,\r\nWamba the Jester, of whom I could never discover whether he were most\r\nknave or fool. Yet I could scarce choose but laugh, when my old master\r\npassed so near to me, dreaming all the while that Gurth was keeping his\r\nporkers many a mile off, in the thickets and swamps of Rotherwood. If I\r\nam discovered\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Disinherited Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthou knowest my promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, for that matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cI will never fail my friend for\r\nfear of my skin-cutting. I have a tough hide, that will bear knife or\r\nscourge as well as any boar\xe2\x80\x99s hide in my herd.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust me, I will requite the risk you run for my love, Gurth,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe Knight. \xe2\x80\x9cMeanwhile, I pray you to accept these ten pieces of gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am richer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, putting them into his pouch, \xe2\x80\x9cthan ever was\r\nswineherd or bondsman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake this bag of gold to Ashby,\xe2\x80\x9d continued his master, \xe2\x80\x9cand find out\r\nIsaac the Jew of York, and let him pay himself for the horse and arms\r\nwith which his credit supplied me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, by St Dunstan,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I will not do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, knave,\xe2\x80\x9d replied his master, \xe2\x80\x9cwilt thou not obey my commands?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo they be honest, reasonable, and Christian commands,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gurth;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut this is none of these. To suffer the Jew to pay himself would be\r\ndishonest, for it would be cheating my master; and unreasonable, for it\r\nwere the part of a fool; and unchristian, since it would be plundering\r\na believer to enrich an infidel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee him contented, however, thou stubborn varlet,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nDisinherited Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, taking the bag under his cloak, and leaving\r\nthe apartment; \xe2\x80\x9cand it will go hard,\xe2\x80\x9d he muttered, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I content him\r\nwith one-half of his own asking.\xe2\x80\x9d So saying, he departed, and left the\r\nDisinherited Knight to his own perplexed ruminations; which, upon more\r\naccounts than it is now possible to communicate to the reader, were of\r\na nature peculiarly agitating and painful.\r\n\r\nWe must now change the scene to the village of Ashby, or rather to a\r\ncountry house in its vicinity belonging to a wealthy Israelite, with\r\nwhom Isaac, his daughter, and retinue, had taken up their quarters; the\r\nJews, it is well known, being as liberal in exercising the duties of\r\nhospitality and charity among their own people, as they were alleged to\r\nbe reluctant and churlish in extending them to those whom they termed\r\nGentiles, and whose treatment of them certainly merited little\r\nhospitality at their hand.\r\n\r\nIn an apartment, small indeed, but richly furnished with decorations of\r\nan Oriental taste, Rebecca was seated on a heap of embroidered\r\ncushions, which, piled along a low platform that surrounded the\r\nchamber, served, like the estrada of the Spaniards, instead of chairs\r\nand stools. She was watching the motions of her father with a look of\r\nanxious and filial affection, while he paced the apartment with a\r\ndejected mien and disordered step; sometimes clasping his hands\r\ntogether\xe2\x80\x94sometimes casting his eyes to the roof of the apartment, as\r\none who laboured under great mental tribulation. \xe2\x80\x9cO, Jacob!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nexclaimed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cO, all ye twelve Holy Fathers of our tribe! what a losing\r\nventure is this for one who hath duly kept every jot and tittle of the\r\nlaw of Moses\xe2\x80\x94Fifty zecchins wrenched from me at one clutch, and by the\r\ntalons of a tyrant!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cyou seemed to give the gold to Prince\r\nJohn willingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly? the blotch of Egypt upon him!\xe2\x80\x94Willingly, saidst thou?\xe2\x80\x94Ay,\r\nas willingly as when, in the Gulf of Lyons, I flung over my merchandise\r\nto lighten the ship, while she laboured in the tempest\xe2\x80\x94robed the\r\nseething billows in my choice silks\xe2\x80\x94perfumed their briny foam with\r\nmyrrh and aloes\xe2\x80\x94enriched their caverns with gold and silver work! And\r\nwas not that an hour of unutterable misery, though my own hands made\r\nthe sacrifice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it was a sacrifice which Heaven exacted to save our lives,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nanswered Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cand the God of our fathers has since blessed your\r\nstore and your gettings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cbut if the tyrant lays hold on them as he did\r\nto-day, and compels me to smile while he is robbing me?\xe2\x80\x94O, daughter,\r\ndisinherited and wandering as we are, the worst evil which befalls our\r\nrace is, that when we are wronged and plundered, all the world laughs\r\naround, and we are compelled to suppress our sense of injury, and to\r\nsmile tamely, when we would revenge bravely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink not thus of it, my father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cwe also have\r\nadvantages. These Gentiles, cruel and oppressive as they are, are in\r\nsome sort dependent on the dispersed children of Zion, whom they\r\ndespise and persecute. Without the aid of our wealth, they could\r\nneither furnish forth their hosts in war, nor their triumphs in peace,\r\nand the gold which we lend them returns with increase to our coffers.\r\nWe are like the herb which flourisheth most when it is most trampled\r\non. Even this day\xe2\x80\x99s pageant had not proceeded without the consent of\r\nthe despised Jew, who furnished the means.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDaughter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast harped upon another string of\r\nsorrow. The goodly steed and the rich armour, equal to the full profit\r\nof my adventure with our Kirjath Jairam of Leicester\xe2\x80\x94there is a dead\r\nloss too\xe2\x80\x94ay, a loss which swallows up the gains of a week; ay, of the\r\nspace between two Sabbaths\xe2\x80\x94and yet it may end better than I now think,\r\nfor \xe2\x80\x99tis a good youth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAssuredly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall not repent you of requiting the\r\ngood deed received of the stranger knight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI trust so, daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cand I trust too in the rebuilding\r\nof Zion; but as well do I hope with my own bodily eyes to see the walls\r\nand battlements of the new Temple, as to see a Christian, yea, the very\r\nbest of Christians, repay a debt to a Jew, unless under the awe of the\r\njudge and jailor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he resumed his discontented walk through the apartment; and\r\nRebecca, perceiving that her attempts at consolation only served to\r\nawaken new subjects of complaint, wisely desisted from her unavailing\r\nefforts\xe2\x80\x94a prudential line of conduct, and we recommend to all who set\r\nup for comforters and advisers, to follow it in the like circumstances.\r\n\r\nThe evening was now becoming dark, when a Jewish servant entered the\r\napartment, and placed upon the table two silver lamps, fed with\r\nperfumed oil; the richest wines, and the most delicate refreshments,\r\nwere at the same time displayed by another Israelitish domestic on a\r\nsmall ebony table, inlaid with silver; for, in the interior of their\r\nhouses, the Jews refused themselves no expensive indulgences. At the\r\nsame time the servant informed Isaac, that a Nazarene (so they termed\r\nChristians, while conversing among themselves) desired to speak with\r\nhim. He that would live by traffic, must hold himself at the disposal\r\nof every one claiming business with him. Isaac at once replaced on the\r\ntable the untasted glass of Greek wine which he had just raised to his\r\nlips, and saying hastily to his daughter, \xe2\x80\x9cRebecca, veil thyself,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncommanded the stranger to be admitted.\r\n\r\nJust as Rebecca had dropped over her fine features a screen of silver\r\ngauze which reached to her feet, the door opened, and Gurth entered,\r\nwrapt in the ample folds of his Norman mantle. His appearance was\r\nrather suspicious than prepossessing, especially as, instead of doffing\r\nhis bonnet, he pulled it still deeper over his rugged brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou Isaac the Jew of York?\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, in Saxon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Isaac, in the same language, (for his traffic had\r\nrendered every tongue spoken in Britain familiar to him)\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand who art\r\nthou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not to the purpose,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs much as my name is to thee,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Isaac; \xe2\x80\x9cfor without knowing\r\nthine, how can I hold intercourse with thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEasily,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth; \xe2\x80\x9cI, being to pay money, must know that I\r\ndeliver it to the right person; thou, who are to receive it, will not,\r\nI think, care very greatly by whose hands it is delivered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are come to pay moneys?\xe2\x80\x94Holy Father Abraham!\r\nthat altereth our relation to each other. And from whom dost thou bring\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the Disinherited Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cvictor in this day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntournament. It is the price of the armour supplied to him by Kirjath\r\nJairam of Leicester, on thy recommendation. The steed is restored to\r\nthy stable. I desire to know the amount of the sum which I am to pay\r\nfor the armour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said he was a good youth!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Isaac with joyful exultation.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA cup of wine will do thee no harm,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, filling and handing to\r\nthe swineherd a richer drought than Gurth had ever before tasted. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nhow much money,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9chas thou brought with thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly Virgin!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, setting down the cup, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat nectar these\r\nunbelieving dogs drink, while true Christians are fain to quaff ale as\r\nmuddy and thick as the draff we give to hogs!\xe2\x80\x94What money have I brought\r\nwith me?\xe2\x80\x9d continued the Saxon, when he had finished this uncivil\r\nejaculation, \xe2\x80\x9ceven but a small sum; something in hand the whilst. What,\r\nIsaac! thou must bear a conscience, though it be a Jewish one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cthy master has won goodly steeds and rich\r\narmours with the strength of his lance, and of his right hand\xe2\x80\x94but \xe2\x80\x99tis\r\na good youth\xe2\x80\x94the Jew will take these in present payment, and render him\r\nback the surplus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy master has disposed of them already,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! that was wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cthat was the part of a fool. No\r\nChristians here could buy so many horses and armour\xe2\x80\x94no Jew except\r\nmyself would give him half the values. But thou hast a hundred zecchins\r\nwith thee in that bag,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, prying under Gurth\xe2\x80\x99s cloak, \xe2\x80\x9cit is\r\na heavy one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heads for cross-bow bolts in it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, readily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said Isaac, panting and hesitating between habitual love\r\nof gain and a new-born desire to be liberal in the present instance,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif I should say that I would take eighty zecchins for the good steed\r\nand the rich armour, which leaves me not a guilder\xe2\x80\x99s profit, have you\r\nmoney to pay me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBarely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, though the sum demanded was more reasonable than\r\nhe expected, \xe2\x80\x9cand it will leave my master nigh penniless. Nevertheless,\r\nif such be your least offer, I must be content.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFill thyself another goblet of wine,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew. \xe2\x80\x9cAh! eighty\r\nzecchins is too little. It leaveth no profit for the usages of the\r\nmoneys; and, besides, the good horse may have suffered wrong in this\r\nday\xe2\x80\x99s encounter. O, it was a hard and a dangerous meeting! man and\r\nsteed rushing on each other like wild bulls of Bashan! The horse cannot\r\nbut have had wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9che is sound, wind and limb; and you may\r\nsee him now, in your stable. And I say, over and above, that seventy\r\nzecchins is enough for the armour, and I hope a Christian\xe2\x80\x99s word is as\r\ngood as a Jew\xe2\x80\x99s. If you will not take seventy, I will carry this bag\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(and he shook it till the contents jingled) \xe2\x80\x9cback to my master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, nay!\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac; \xe2\x80\x9clay down the talents\xe2\x80\x94the shekels\xe2\x80\x94the eighty\r\nzecchins, and thou shalt see I will consider thee liberally.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGurth at length complied; and telling out eighty zecchins upon the\r\ntable, the Jew delivered out to him an acquittance for the horse and\r\nsuit of armour. The Jew\xe2\x80\x99s hand trembled for joy as he wrapped up the\r\nfirst seventy pieces of gold. The last ten he told over with much\r\ndeliberation, pausing, and saying something as he took each piece from\r\nthe table, and dropt it into his purse. It seemed as if his avarice\r\nwere struggling with his better nature, and compelling him to pouch\r\nzecchin after zecchin while his generosity urged him to restore some\r\npart at least to his benefactor, or as a donation to his agent. His\r\nwhole speech ran nearly thus:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeventy-one\xe2\x80\x94seventy-two; thy master is a good youth\xe2\x80\x94seventy-three, an\r\nexcellent youth\xe2\x80\x94seventy-four\xe2\x80\x94that piece hath been clipt within the\r\nring\xe2\x80\x94seventy-five\xe2\x80\x94and that looketh light of weight\xe2\x80\x94seventy-six\xe2\x80\x94when thy\r\nmaster wants money, let him come to Isaac of York\xe2\x80\x94seventy-seven\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nis, with reasonable security.\xe2\x80\x9d Here he made a considerable pause, and\r\nGurth had good hope that the last three pieces might escape the fate of\r\ntheir comrades; but the enumeration proceeded.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSeventy-eight\xe2\x80\x94thou art\r\na good fellow\xe2\x80\x94seventy-nine\xe2\x80\x94and deservest something for thyself\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere the Jew paused again, and looked at the last zecchin, intending,\r\ndoubtless, to bestow it upon Gurth. He weighed it upon the tip of his\r\nfinger, and made it ring by dropping it upon the table. Had it rung too\r\nflat, or had it felt a hair\xe2\x80\x99s breadth too light, generosity had carried\r\nthe day; but, unhappily for Gurth, the chime was full and true, the\r\nzecchin plump, newly coined, and a grain above weight. Isaac could not\r\nfind in his heart to part with it, so dropt it into his purse as if in\r\nabsence of mind, with the words, \xe2\x80\x9cEighty completes the tale, and I\r\ntrust thy master will reward thee handsomely.\xe2\x80\x94Surely,\xe2\x80\x9d he added,\r\nlooking earnestly at the bag, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast more coins in that pouch?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGurth grinned, which was his nearest approach to a laugh, as he\r\nreplied, \xe2\x80\x9cAbout the same quantity which thou hast just told over so\r\ncarefully.\xe2\x80\x9d He then folded the quittance, and put it under his cap,\r\nadding,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cPeril of thy beard, Jew, see that this be full and ample!\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nfilled himself unbidden, a third goblet of wine, and left the apartment\r\nwithout ceremony.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Ishmaelite hath gone somewhat beyond me.\r\nNevertheless his master is a good youth\xe2\x80\x94ay, and I am well pleased that\r\nhe hath gained shekels of gold and shekels of silver, even by the speed\r\nof his horse and by the strength of his lance, which, like that of\r\nGoliath the Philistine, might vie with a weaver\xe2\x80\x99s beam.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he turned to receive Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s answer, he observed, that during his\r\nchattering with Gurth, she had left the apartment unperceived.\r\n\r\nIn the meanwhile, Gurth had descended the stair, and, having reached\r\nthe dark antechamber or hall, was puzzling about to discover the\r\nentrance, when a figure in white, shown by a small silver lamp which\r\nshe held in her hand, beckoned him into a side apartment. Gurth had\r\nsome reluctance to obey the summons. Rough and impetuous as a wild\r\nboar, where only earthly force was to be apprehended, he had all the\r\ncharacteristic terrors of a Saxon respecting fawns, forest-fiends,\r\nwhite women, and the whole of the superstitions which his ancestors had\r\nbrought with them from the wilds of Germany. He remembered, moreover,\r\nthat he was in the house of a Jew, a people who, besides the other\r\nunamiable qualities which popular report ascribed to them, were\r\nsupposed to be profound necromancers and cabalists. Nevertheless, after\r\na moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause, he obeyed the beckoning summons of the apparition,\r\nand followed her into the apartment which she indicated, where he found\r\nto his joyful surprise that his fair guide was the beautiful Jewess\r\nwhom he had seen at the tournament, and a short time in her father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\napartment.\r\n\r\nShe asked him the particulars of his transaction with Isaac, which he\r\ndetailed accurately.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father did but jest with thee, good fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9che owes\r\nthy master deeper kindness than these arms and steed could pay, were\r\ntheir value tenfold. What sum didst thou pay my father even now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEighty zecchins,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, surprised at the question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn this purse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cthou wilt find a hundred. Restore to\r\nthy master that which is his due, and enrich thyself with the\r\nremainder. Haste\xe2\x80\x94begone\xe2\x80\x94stay not to render thanks! and beware how you\r\npass through this crowded town, where thou mayst easily lose both thy\r\nburden and thy life.\xe2\x80\x94Reuben,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, clapping her hands together,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clight forth this stranger, and fail not to draw lock and bar behind\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d Reuben, a dark-brow\xe2\x80\x99d and black-bearded Israelite, obeyed her\r\nsummons, with a torch in his hand; undid the outward door of the house,\r\nand conducting Gurth across a paved court, let him out through a wicket\r\nin the entrance-gate, which he closed behind him with such bolts and\r\nchains as would well have become that of a prison.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy St Dunstan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, as he stumbled up the dark avenue, \xe2\x80\x9cthis\r\nis no Jewess, but an angel from heaven! Ten zecchins from my brave\r\nyoung master\xe2\x80\x94twenty from this pearl of Zion\xe2\x80\x94Oh, happy day!\xe2\x80\x94Such\r\nanother, Gurth, will redeem thy bondage, and make thee a brother as\r\nfree of thy guild as the best. And then do I lay down my swineherd\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhorn and staff, and take the freeman\xe2\x80\x99s sword and buckler, and follow my\r\nyoung master to the death, without hiding either my face or my name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XI\r\n\r\n\r\n1st Outlaw: Stand, sir, and throw us that you have about you;\r\nIf not, we\xe2\x80\x99ll make you sit, and rifle you.\r\nSpeed: Sir, we are undone! these are the villains\r\nThat all the travellers do fear so much.\r\nVal: My friends,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n1st Out: That\xe2\x80\x99s not so, sir, we are your enemies.\r\n2d Out: Peace! we\xe2\x80\x99ll hear him.\r\n3d Out: Ay, by my beard, will we;\r\nFor he\xe2\x80\x99s a proper man.\r\n\r\n\r\nTWO GENTLEMEN OF VERONA\r\n\r\n\r\nThe nocturnal adventures of Gurth were not yet concluded; indeed he\r\nhimself became partly of that mind, when, after passing one or two\r\nstraggling houses which stood in the outskirts of the village, he found\r\nhimself in a deep lane, running between two banks overgrown with hazel\r\nand holly, while here and there a dwarf oak flung its arms altogether\r\nacross the path. The lane was moreover much rutted and broken up by the\r\ncarriages which had recently transported articles of various kinds to\r\nthe tournament; and it was dark, for the banks and bushes intercepted\r\nthe light of the harvest moon.\r\n\r\nFrom the village were heard the distant sounds of revelry, mixed\r\noccasionally with loud laughter, sometimes broken by screams, and\r\nsometimes by wild strains of distant music. All these sounds,\r\nintimating the disorderly state of the town, crowded with military\r\nnobles and their dissolute attendants, gave Gurth some uneasiness. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nJewess was right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cBy heaven and St Dunstan, I\r\nwould I were safe at my journey\xe2\x80\x99s end with all this treasure! Here are\r\nsuch numbers, I will not say of arrant thieves, but of errant knights\r\nand errant squires, errant monks and errant minstrels, errant jugglers\r\nand errant jesters, that a man with a single merk would be in danger,\r\nmuch more a poor swineherd with a whole bagful of zecchins. Would I\r\nwere out of the shade of these infernal bushes, that I might at least\r\nsee any of St Nicholas\xe2\x80\x99s clerks before they spring on my shoulders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGurth accordingly hastened his pace, in order to gain the open common\r\nto which the lane led, but was not so fortunate as to accomplish his\r\nobject.
