Just as he had attained the upper end of the lane, where the\r\nunderwood was thickest, four men sprung upon him, even as his fears\r\nanticipated, two from each side of the road, and seized him so fast,\r\nthat resistance, if at first practicable, would have been now too\r\nlate.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSurrender your charge,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of them; \xe2\x80\x9cwe are the deliverers\r\nof the commonwealth, who ease every man of his burden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should not ease me of mine so lightly,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Gurth, whose\r\nsurly honesty could not be tamed even by the pressure of immediate\r\nviolence,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9chad I it but in my power to give three strokes in its\r\ndefence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see that presently,\xe2\x80\x9d said the robber; and, speaking to his\r\ncompanions, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cbring along the knave. I see he would have his\r\nhead broken, as well as his purse cut, and so be let blood in two veins\r\nat once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGurth was hurried along agreeably to this mandate, and having been\r\ndragged somewhat roughly over the bank, on the left-hand side of the\r\nlane, found himself in a straggling thicket, which lay betwixt it and\r\nthe open common. He was compelled to follow his rough conductors into\r\nthe very depth of this cover, where they stopt unexpectedly in an\r\nirregular open space, free in a great measure from trees, and on which,\r\ntherefore, the beams of the moon fell without much interruption from\r\nboughs and leaves. Here his captors were joined by two other persons,\r\napparently belonging to the gang. They had short swords by their sides,\r\nand quarter-staves in their hands, and Gurth could now observe that all\r\nsix wore visors, which rendered their occupation a matter of no\r\nquestion, even had their former proceedings left it in doubt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat money hast thou, churl?\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the thieves.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThirty zecchins of my own property,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth, doggedly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA forfeit\xe2\x80\x94a forfeit,\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the robbers; \xe2\x80\x9ca Saxon hath thirty\r\nzecchins, and returns sober from a village! An undeniable and\r\nunredeemable forfeit of all he hath about him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hoarded it to purchase my freedom,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art an ass,\xe2\x80\x9d replied one of the thieves \xe2\x80\x9cthree quarts of double\r\nale had rendered thee as free as thy master, ay, and freer too, if he\r\nbe a Saxon like thyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA sad truth,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gurth; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if these same thirty zecchins will\r\nbuy my freedom from you, unloose my hands, and I will pay them to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold,\xe2\x80\x9d said one who seemed to exercise some authority over the others;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthis bag which thou bearest, as I can feel through thy cloak, contains\r\nmore coin than thou hast told us of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the good knight my master\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cof which,\r\nassuredly, I would not have spoken a word, had you been satisfied with\r\nworking your will upon mine own property.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art an honest fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the robber, \xe2\x80\x9cI warrant thee; and\r\nwe worship not St Nicholas so devoutly but what thy thirty zecchins may\r\nyet escape, if thou deal uprightly with us. Meantime render up thy\r\ntrust for a time.\xe2\x80\x9d So saying, he took from Gurth\xe2\x80\x99s breast the large\r\nleathern pouch, in which the purse given him by Rebecca was enclosed,\r\nas well as the rest of the zecchins, and then continued his\r\ninterrogation.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWho is thy master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Disinherited Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhose good lance,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the robber, \xe2\x80\x9cwon the prize in to-day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntourney? What is his name and lineage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is his pleasure,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cthat they be concealed; and from\r\nme, assuredly, you will learn nought of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is thine own name and lineage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo tell that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cmight reveal my master\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art a saucy groom,\xe2\x80\x9d said the robber, \xe2\x80\x9cbut of that anon. How comes\r\nthy master by this gold? is it of his inheritance, or by what means\r\nhath it accrued to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy his good lance,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThese bags contain the ransom of\r\nfour good horses, and four good suits of armour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much is there?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the robber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo hundred zecchins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly two hundred zecchins!\xe2\x80\x9d said the bandit; \xe2\x80\x9cyour master hath dealt\r\nliberally by the vanquished, and put them to a cheap ransom. Name those\r\nwho paid the gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGurth did so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe armour and horse of the Templar Brian de Bois-Guilbert, at what\r\nransom were they held?\xe2\x80\x94Thou seest thou canst not deceive me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy master,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cwill take nought from the Templar save his\r\nlife\xe2\x80\x99s-blood. They are on terms of mortal defiance, and cannot hold\r\ncourteous intercourse together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94repeated the robber, and paused after he had said the word.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what wert thou now doing at Ashby with such a charge in thy\r\ncustody?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI went thither to render to Isaac the Jew of York,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gurth,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe price of a suit of armour with which he fitted my master for this\r\ntournament.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how much didst thou pay to Isaac?\xe2\x80\x94Methinks, to judge by weight,\r\nthere is still two hundred zecchins in this pouch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI paid to Isaac,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Saxon, \xe2\x80\x9ceighty zecchins, and he restored me\r\na hundred in lieu thereof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow! what!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed all the robbers at once; \xe2\x80\x9cdarest thou trifle\r\nwith us, that thou tellest such improbable lies?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cis as true as the moon is in heaven.\r\nYou will find the just sum in a silken purse within the leathern pouch,\r\nand separate from the rest of the gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBethink thee, man,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cthou speakest of a Jew\xe2\x80\x94of an\r\nIsraelite,\xe2\x80\x94as unapt to restore gold, as the dry sand of his deserts to\r\nreturn the cup of water which the pilgrim spills upon them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no more mercy in them,\xe2\x80\x9d said another of the banditti, \xe2\x80\x9cthan\r\nin an unbribed sheriffs officer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, however, as I say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrike a light instantly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain; \xe2\x80\x9cI will examine this said\r\npurse; and if it be as this fellow says, the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s bounty is little\r\nless miraculous than the stream which relieved his fathers in the\r\nwilderness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA light was procured accordingly, and the robber proceeded to examine\r\nthe purse. The others crowded around him, and even two who had hold of\r\nGurth relaxed their grasp while they stretched their necks to see the\r\nissue of the search. Availing himself of their negligence, by a sudden\r\nexertion of strength and activity, Gurth shook himself free of their\r\nhold, and might have escaped, could he have resolved to leave his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s property behind him. But such was no part of his intention. He\r\nwrenched a quarter-staff from one of the fellows, struck down the\r\nCaptain, who was altogether unaware of his purpose, and had well-nigh\r\nrepossessed himself of the pouch and treasure. The thieves, however,\r\nwere too nimble for him, and again secured both the bag and the trusty\r\nGurth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKnave!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, getting up, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast broken my head; and\r\nwith other men of our sort thou wouldst fare the worse for thy\r\ninsolence. But thou shalt know thy fate instantly. First let us speak\r\nof thy master; the knight\xe2\x80\x99s matters must go before the squire\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\naccording to the due order of chivalry. Stand thou fast in the\r\nmeantime\xe2\x80\x94if thou stir again, thou shalt have that will make thee quiet\r\nfor thy life\xe2\x80\x94Comrades!\xe2\x80\x9d he then said, addressing his gang, \xe2\x80\x9cthis purse\r\nis embroidered with Hebrew characters, and I well believe the yeoman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntale is true. The errant knight, his master, must needs pass us\r\ntoll-free. He is too like ourselves for us to make booty of him, since\r\ndogs should not worry dogs where wolves and foxes are to be found in\r\nabundance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike us?\xe2\x80\x9d answered one of the gang; \xe2\x80\x9cI should like to hear how that is\r\nmade good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, thou fool,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cis he not poor and\r\ndisinherited as we are?\xe2\x80\x94Doth he not win his substance at the sword\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npoint as we do?\xe2\x80\x94Hath he not beaten Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and Malvoisin, even as\r\nwe would beat them if we could? Is he not the enemy to life and death\r\nof Brian de Bois-Guilbert, whom we have so much reason to fear? And\r\nwere all this otherwise, wouldst thou have us show a worse conscience\r\nthan an unbeliever, a Hebrew Jew?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, that were a shame,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the other fellow; \xe2\x80\x9cand yet, when I\r\nserved in the band of stout old Gandelyn, we had no such scruples of\r\nconscience. And this insolent peasant,\xe2\x80\x94he too, I warrant me, is to be\r\ndismissed scatheless?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot if THOU canst scathe him,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Captain.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHere, fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued he, addressing Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9ccanst thou use the staff, that thou\r\nstarts to it so readily?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cthou shouldst be best able to reply to that\r\nquestion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, by my troth, thou gavest me a round knock,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Captain;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdo as much for this fellow, and thou shalt pass scot-free; and if thou\r\ndost not\xe2\x80\x94why, by my faith, as thou art such a sturdy knave, I think I\r\nmust pay thy ransom myself.\xe2\x80\x94Take thy staff, Miller,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nkeep thy head; and do you others let the fellow go, and give him a\r\nstaff\xe2\x80\x94there is light enough to lay on load by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two champions being alike armed with quarter-staves, stepped\r\nforward into the centre of the open space, in order to have the full\r\nbenefit of the moonlight; the thieves in the meantime laughing, and\r\ncrying to their comrade, \xe2\x80\x9cMiller! beware thy toll-dish.\xe2\x80\x9d The Miller, on\r\nthe other hand, holding his quarter-staff by the middle, and making it\r\nflourish round his head after the fashion which the French call \xe2\x80\x9cfaire\r\nle moulinet\xe2\x80\x9d, exclaimed boastfully, \xe2\x80\x9cCome on, churl, an thou darest:\r\nthou shalt feel the strength of a miller\xe2\x80\x99s thumb!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou be\xe2\x80\x99st a miller,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Gurth, undauntedly, making his\r\nweapon play around his head with equal dexterity, \xe2\x80\x9cthou art doubly a\r\nthief, and I, as a true man, bid thee defiance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, the two champions closed together, and for a few minutes\r\nthey displayed great equality in strength, courage, and skill,\r\nintercepting and returning the blows of their adversary with the most\r\nrapid dexterity, while, from the continued clatter of their weapons, a\r\nperson at a distance might have supposed that there were at least six\r\npersons engaged on each side. Less obstinate, and even less dangerous\r\ncombats, have been described in good heroic verse; but that of Gurth\r\nand the Miller must remain unsung, for want of a sacred poet to do\r\njustice to its eventful progress. Yet, though quarter-staff play be out\r\nof date, what we can in prose we will do for these bold champions.\r\n\r\nLong they fought equally, until the Miller began to lose temper at\r\nfinding himself so stoutly opposed, and at hearing the laughter of his\r\ncompanions, who, as usual in such cases, enjoyed his vexation. This was\r\nnot a state of mind favourable to the noble game of quarter-staff, in\r\nwhich, as in ordinary cudgel-playing, the utmost coolness is requisite;\r\nand it gave Gurth, whose temper was steady, though surly, the\r\nopportunity of acquiring a decided advantage, in availing himself of\r\nwhich he displayed great mastery.\r\n\r\nThe Miller pressed furiously forward, dealing blows with either end of\r\nhis weapon alternately, and striving to come to half-staff distance,\r\nwhile Gurth defended himself against the attack, keeping his hands\r\nabout a yard asunder, and covering himself by shifting his weapon with\r\ngreat celerity, so as to protect his head and body. Thus did he\r\nmaintain the defensive, making his eye, foot, and hand keep true time,\r\nuntil, observing his antagonist to lose wind, he darted the staff at\r\nhis face with his left hand; and, as the Miller endeavoured to parry\r\nthe thrust, he slid his right hand down to his left, and with the full\r\nswing of the weapon struck his opponent on the left side of the head,\r\nwho instantly measured his length upon the green sward.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell and yeomanly done!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the robbers; \xe2\x80\x9cfair play and Old\r\nEngland for ever! The Saxon hath saved both his purse and his hide, and\r\nthe Miller has met his match.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou mayst go thy ways, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, addressing\r\nGurth, in special confirmation of the general voice, \xe2\x80\x9cand I will cause\r\ntwo of my comrades to guide thee by the best way to thy master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npavilion, and to guard thee from night-walkers that might have less\r\ntender consciences than ours; for there is many one of them upon the\r\namble in such a night as this. Take heed, however,\xe2\x80\x9d he added sternly;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cremember thou hast refused to tell thy name\xe2\x80\x94ask not after ours, nor\r\nendeavour to discover who or what we are; for, if thou makest such an\r\nattempt, thou wilt come by worse fortune than has yet befallen thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGurth thanked the Captain for his courtesy, and promised to attend to\r\nhis recommendation. Two of the outlaws, taking up their quarter-staves,\r\nand desiring Gurth to follow close in the rear, walked roundly forward\r\nalong a by-path, which traversed the thicket and the broken ground\r\nadjacent to it. On the very verge of the thicket two men spoke to his\r\nconductors, and receiving an answer in a whisper, withdrew into the\r\nwood, and suffered them to pass unmolested. This circumstance induced\r\nGurth to believe both that the gang was strong in numbers, and that\r\nthey kept regular guards around their place of rendezvous.\r\n\r\nWhen they arrived on the open heath, where Gurth might have had some\r\ntrouble in finding his road, the thieves guided him straight forward to\r\nthe top of a little eminence, whence he could see, spread beneath him\r\nin the moonlight, the palisades of the lists, the glimmering pavilions\r\npitched at either end, with the pennons which adorned them fluttering\r\nin the moonbeams, and from which could be heard the hum of the song\r\nwith which the sentinels were beguiling their night-watch.\r\n\r\nHere the thieves stopt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe go with you no farther,\xe2\x80\x9d said they; \xe2\x80\x9cit were not safe that we\r\nshould do so.\xe2\x80\x94Remember the warning you have received\xe2\x80\x94keep secret what\r\nhas this night befallen you, and you will have no room to repent\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94neglect what is now told you, and the Tower of London shall not\r\nprotect you against our revenge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood night to you, kind sirs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall remember your\r\norders, and trust that there is no offence in wishing you a safer and\r\nan honester trade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus they parted, the outlaws returning in the direction from whence\r\nthey had come, and Gurth proceeding to the tent of his master, to whom,\r\nnotwithstanding the injunction he had received, he communicated the\r\nwhole adventures of the evening.\r\n\r\nThe Disinherited Knight was filled with astonishment, no less at the\r\ngenerosity of Rebecca, by which, however, he resolved he would not\r\nprofit, than that of the robbers, to whose profession such a quality\r\nseemed totally foreign. His course of reflections upon these singular\r\ncircumstances was, however, interrupted by the necessity for taking\r\nrepose, which the fatigue of the preceding day, and the propriety of\r\nrefreshing himself for the morrow\xe2\x80\x99s encounter, rendered alike\r\nindispensable.\r\n\r\nThe knight, therefore, stretched himself for repose upon a rich couch\r\nwith which the tent was provided; and the faithful Gurth, extending his\r\nhardy limbs upon a bear-skin which formed a sort of carpet to the\r\npavilion, laid himself across the opening of the tent, so that no one\r\ncould enter without awakening him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XII\r\n\r\n\r\nThe heralds left their pricking up and down,\r\nNow ringen trumpets loud and clarion.\r\nThere is no more to say, but east and west,\r\nIn go the speares sadly in the rest,\r\nIn goth the sharp spur into the side,\r\nThere see men who can just and who can ride;\r\nThere shiver shaftes upon shieldes thick,\r\nHe feeleth through the heart-spone the prick;\r\nUp springen speares, twenty feet in height,\r\nOut go the swordes to the silver bright;\r\nThe helms they to-hewn and to-shred;\r\nOut burst the blood with stern streames red.\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAUCER\r\n\r\n\r\nMorning arose in unclouded splendour, and ere the sun was much above\r\nthe horizon, the idlest or the most eager of the spectators appeared on\r\nthe common, moving to the lists as to a general centre, in order to\r\nsecure a favourable situation for viewing the continuation of the\r\nexpected games.\r\n\r\nThe marshals and their attendants appeared next on the field, together\r\nwith the heralds, for the purpose of receiving the names of the knights\r\nwho intended to joust, with the side which each chose to espouse. This\r\nwas a necessary precaution, in order to secure equality betwixt the two\r\nbodies who should be opposed to each other.\r\n\r\nAccording to due formality, the Disinherited Knight was to be\r\nconsidered as leader of the one body, while Brian de Bois-Guilbert, who\r\nhad been rated as having done second-best in the preceding day, was\r\nnamed first champion of the other band. Those who had concurred in the\r\nchallenge adhered to his party of course, excepting only Ralph de\r\nVipont, whom his fall had rendered unfit so soon to put on his armour.\r\nThere was no want of distinguished and noble candidates to fill up the\r\nranks on either side.\r\n\r\nIn fact, although the general tournament, in which all knights fought\r\nat once, was more dangerous than single encounters, they were,\r\nnevertheless, more frequented and practised by the chivalry of the age.\r\nMany knights, who had not sufficient confidence in their own skill to\r\ndefy a single adversary of high reputation, were, nevertheless,\r\ndesirous of displaying their valour in the general combat, where they\r\nmight meet others with whom they were more upon an equality. On the\r\npresent occasion, about fifty knights were inscribed as desirous of\r\ncombating upon each side, when the marshals declared that no more could\r\nbe admitted, to the disappointment of several who were too late in\r\npreferring their claim to be included.\r\n\r\nAbout the hour of ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the whole plain was crowded with\r\nhorsemen, horsewomen, and foot-passengers, hastening to the tournament;\r\nand shortly after, a grand flourish of trumpets announced Prince John\r\nand his retinue, attended by many of those knights who meant to take\r\nshare in the game, as well as others who had no such intention.\r\n\r\nAbout the same time arrived Cedric the Saxon, with the Lady Rowena,\r\nunattended, however, by Athelstane. This Saxon lord had arrayed his\r\ntall and strong person in armour, in order to take his place among the\r\ncombatants; and, considerably to the surprise of Cedric, had chosen to\r\nenlist himself on the part of the Knight Templar. The Saxon, indeed,\r\nhad remonstrated strongly with his friend upon the injudicious choice\r\nhe had made of his party; but he had only received that sort of answer\r\nusually given by those who are more obstinate in following their own\r\ncourse, than strong in justifying it.\r\n\r\nHis best, if not his only reason, for adhering to the party of Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, Athelstane had the prudence to keep to himself. Though\r\nhis apathy of disposition prevented his taking any means to recommend\r\nhimself to the Lady Rowena, he was, nevertheless, by no means\r\ninsensible to her charms, and considered his union with her as a matter\r\nalready fixed beyond doubt, by the assent of Cedric and her other\r\nfriends. It had therefore been with smothered displeasure that the\r\nproud though indolent Lord of Coningsburgh beheld the victor of the\r\npreceding day select Rowena as the object of that honour which it\r\nbecame his privilege to confer. In order to punish him for a preference\r\nwhich seemed to interfere with his own suit, Athelstane, confident of\r\nhis strength, and to whom his flatterers, at least, ascribed great\r\nskill in arms, had determined not only to deprive the Disinherited\r\nKnight of his powerful succour, but, if an opportunity should occur, to\r\nmake him feel the weight of his battle-axe.\r\n\r\nDe Bracy, and other knights attached to Prince John, in obedience to a\r\nhint from him, had joined the party of the challengers, John being\r\ndesirous to secure, if possible, the victory to that side. On the other\r\nhand, many other knights, both English and Norman, natives and\r\nstrangers, took part against the challengers, the more readily that the\r\nopposite band was to be led by so distinguished a champion as the\r\nDisinherited Knight had approved himself.\r\n\r\nAs soon as Prince John observed that the destined Queen of the day had\r\narrived upon the field, assuming that air of courtesy which sat well\r\nupon him when he was pleased to exhibit it, he rode forward to meet\r\nher, doffed his bonnet, and, alighting from his horse, assisted the\r\nLady Rowena from her saddle, while his followers uncovered at the same\r\ntime, and one of the most distinguished dismounted to hold her palfrey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is thus,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we set the dutiful example of\r\nloyalty to the Queen of Love and Beauty, and are ourselves her guide to\r\nthe throne which she must this day occupy.\xe2\x80\x94Ladies,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cattend\r\nyour Queen, as you wish in your turn to be distinguished by like\r\nhonours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, the Prince marshalled Rowena to the seat of honour opposite\r\nhis own, while the fairest and most distinguished ladies present\r\ncrowded after her to obtain places as near as possible to their\r\ntemporary sovereign.\r\n\r\nNo sooner was Rowena seated, than a burst of music, half-drowned by the\r\nshouts of the multitude, greeted her new dignity. Meantime, the sun\r\nshone fierce and bright upon the polished arms of the knights of either\r\nside, who crowded the opposite extremities of the lists, and held eager\r\nconference together concerning the best mode of arranging their line of\r\nbattle, and supporting the conflict.\r\n\r\nThe heralds then proclaimed silence until the laws of the tourney\r\nshould be rehearsed. These were calculated in some degree to abate the\r\ndangers of the day; a precaution the more necessary, as the conflict\r\nwas to be maintained with sharp swords and pointed lances.\r\n\r\nThe champions were therefore prohibited to thrust with the sword, and\r\nwere confined to striking. A knight, it was announced, might use a mace\r\nor battle-axe at pleasure, but the dagger was a prohibited weapon. A\r\nknight unhorsed might renew the fight on foot with any other on the\r\nopposite side in the same predicament; but mounted horsemen were in\r\nthat case forbidden to assail him. When any knight could force his\r\nantagonist to the extremity of the lists, so as to touch the palisade\r\nwith his person or arms, such opponent was obliged to yield himself\r\nvanquished, and his armour and horse were placed at the disposal of the\r\nconqueror. A knight thus overcome was not permitted to take farther\r\nshare in the combat. If any combatant was struck down, and unable to\r\nrecover his feet, his squire or page might enter the lists, and drag\r\nhis master out of the press; but in that case the knight was adjudged\r\nvanquished, and his arms and horse declared forfeited. The combat was\r\nto cease as soon as Prince John should throw down his leading staff, or\r\ntruncheon; another precaution usually taken to prevent the unnecessary\r\neffusion of blood by the too long endurance of a sport so desperate.\r\nAny knight breaking the rules of the tournament, or otherwise\r\ntransgressing the rules of honourable chivalry, was liable to be stript\r\nof his arms, and, having his shield reversed to be placed in that\r\nposture astride upon the bars of the palisade, and exposed to public\r\nderision, in punishment of his unknightly conduct. Having announced\r\nthese precautions, the heralds concluded with an exhortation to each\r\ngood knight to do his duty, and to merit favour from the Queen of\r\nBeauty and of Love.\r\n\r\nThis proclamation having been made, the heralds withdrew to their\r\nstations. The knights, entering at either end of the lists in long\r\nprocession, arranged themselves in a double file, precisely opposite to\r\neach other, the leader of each party being in the centre of the\r\nforemost rank, a post which he did not occupy until each had carefully\r\nmarshalled the ranks of his party, and stationed every one in his\r\nplace.\r\n\r\nIt was a goodly, and at the same time an anxious, sight, to behold so\r\nmany gallant champions, mounted bravely, and armed richly, stand ready\r\nprepared for an encounter so formidable, seated on their war-saddles\r\nlike so many pillars of iron, and awaiting the signal of encounter with\r\nthe same ardour as their generous steeds, which, by neighing and pawing\r\nthe ground, gave signal of their impatience.\r\n\r\nAs yet the knights held their long lances upright, their bright points\r\nglancing to the sun, and the streamers with which they were decorated\r\nfluttering over the plumage of the helmets. Thus they remained while\r\nthe marshals of the field surveyed their ranks with the utmost\r\nexactness, lest either party had more or fewer than the appointed\r\nnumber. The tale was found exactly complete. The marshals then withdrew\r\nfrom the lists, and William de Wyvil, with a voice of thunder,\r\npronounced the signal words\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLaissez aller!\xe2\x80\x9d The trumpets sounded as he\r\nspoke\xe2\x80\x94the spears of the champions were at once lowered and placed in\r\nthe rests\xe2\x80\x94the spurs were dashed into the flanks of the horses, and the\r\ntwo foremost ranks of either party rushed upon each other in full\r\ngallop, and met in the middle of the lists with a shock, the sound of\r\nwhich was heard at a mile\xe2\x80\x99s distance. The rear rank of each party\r\nadvanced at a slower pace to sustain the defeated, and follow up the\r\nsuccess of the victors of their party.\r\n\r\nThe consequences of the encounter were not instantly seen, for the dust\r\nraised by the trampling of so many steeds darkened the air, and it was\r\na minute ere the anxious spectator could see the fate of the encounter.\r\nWhen the fight became visible, half the knights on each side were\r\ndismounted, some by the dexterity of their adversary\xe2\x80\x99s lance,\xe2\x80\x94some by\r\nthe superior weight and strength of opponents, which had borne down\r\nboth horse and man,\xe2\x80\x94some lay stretched on earth as if never more to\r\nrise,\xe2\x80\x94some had already gained their feet, and were closing hand to hand\r\nwith those of their antagonists who were in the same predicament,\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nseveral on both sides, who had received wounds by which they were\r\ndisabled, were stopping their blood by their scarfs, and endeavouring\r\nto extricate themselves from the tumult. The mounted knights, whose\r\nlances had been almost all broken by the fury of the encounter, were\r\nnow closely engaged with their swords, shouting their war-cries, and\r\nexchanging buffets, as if honour and life depended on the issue of the\r\ncombat.\r\n\r\nThe tumult was presently increased by the advance of the second rank on\r\neither side, which, acting as a reserve, now rushed on to aid their\r\ncompanions. The followers of Brian de Bois-Guilbert shouted\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHa!\r\nBeau-seant! Beau-seant! 20\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x94For the Temple\xe2\x80\x94For the Temple!\xe2\x80\x9d The opposite party shouted in\r\nanswer\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDesdichado! Desdichado!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94which watch-word they took from the\r\nmotto upon their leader\xe2\x80\x99s shield.\r\n\r\nThe champions thus encountering each other with the utmost fury, and\r\nwith alternate success, the tide of battle seemed to flow now toward\r\nthe southern, now toward the northern extremity of the lists, as the\r\none or the other party prevailed. Meantime the clang of the blows, and\r\nthe shouts of the combatants, mixed fearfully with the sound of the\r\ntrumpets, and drowned the groans of those who fell, and lay rolling\r\ndefenceless beneath the feet of the horses. The splendid armour of the\r\ncombatants was now defaced with dust and blood, and gave way at every\r\nstroke of the sword and battle-axe. The gay plumage, shorn from the\r\ncrests, drifted upon the breeze like snow-flakes. All that was\r\nbeautiful and graceful in the martial array had disappeared, and what\r\nwas now visible was only calculated to awake terror or compassion.\r\n\r\nYet such is the force of habit, that not only the vulgar spectators,\r\nwho are naturally attracted by sights of horror, but even the ladies of\r\ndistinction who crowded the galleries, saw the conflict with a\r\nthrilling interest certainly, but without a wish to withdraw their eyes\r\nfrom a sight so terrible. Here and there, indeed, a fair cheek might\r\nturn pale, or a faint scream might be heard, as a lover, a brother, or\r\na husband, was struck from his horse. But, in general, the ladies\r\naround encouraged the combatants, not only by clapping their hands and\r\nwaving their veils and kerchiefs, but even by exclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cBrave lance!\r\nGood sword!\xe2\x80\x9d when any successful thrust or blow took place under their\r\nobservation.\r\n\r\nSuch being the interest taken by the fair sex in this bloody game, that\r\nof the men is the more easily understood. It showed itself in loud\r\nacclamations upon every change of fortune, while all eyes were so\r\nriveted on the lists, that the spectators seemed as if they themselves\r\nhad dealt and received the blows which were there so freely bestowed.\r\nAnd between every pause was heard the voice of the heralds, exclaiming,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFight on, brave knights! Man dies, but glory lives!\xe2\x80\x94Fight on\xe2\x80\x94death is\r\nbetter than defeat!\xe2\x80\x94Fight on, brave knights!\xe2\x80\x94for bright eyes behold\r\nyour deeds!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmid the varied fortunes of the combat, the eyes of all endeavoured to\r\ndiscover the leaders of each band, who, mingling in the thick of the\r\nfight, encouraged their companions both by voice and example. Both\r\ndisplayed great feats of gallantry, nor did either Bois-Guilbert or the\r\nDisinherited Knight find in the ranks opposed to them a champion who\r\ncould be termed their unquestioned match. They repeatedly endeavoured\r\nto single out each other, spurred by mutual animosity, and aware that\r\nthe fall of either leader might be considered as decisive of victory.\r\nSuch, however, was the crowd and confusion, that, during the earlier\r\npart of the conflict, their efforts to meet were unavailing, and they\r\nwere repeatedly separated by the eagerness of their followers, each of\r\nwhom was anxious to win honour, by measuring his strength against the\r\nleader of the opposite party.\r\n\r\nBut when the field became thin by the numbers on either side who had\r\nyielded themselves vanquished, had been compelled to the extremity of\r\nthe lists, or been otherwise rendered incapable of continuing the\r\nstrife, the Templar and the Disinherited Knight at length encountered\r\nhand to hand, with all the fury that mortal animosity, joined to\r\nrivalry of honour, could inspire. Such was the address of each in\r\nparrying and striking, that the spectators broke forth into a unanimous\r\nand involuntary shout, expressive of their delight and admiration.\r\n\r\nBut at this moment the party of the Disinherited Knight had the worst;\r\nthe gigantic arm of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf on the one flank, and the ponderous\r\nstrength of Athelstane on the other, bearing down and dispersing those\r\nimmediately exposed to them. Finding themselves freed from their\r\nimmediate antagonists, it seems to have occurred to both these knights\r\nat the same instant, that they would render the most decisive advantage\r\nto their party, by aiding the Templar in his contest with his rival.\r\nTurning their horses, therefore, at the same moment, the Norman spurred\r\nagainst the Disinherited Knight on the one side, and the Saxon on the\r\nother. It was utterly impossible that the object of this unequal and\r\nunexpected assault could have sustained it, had he not been warned by a\r\ngeneral cry from the spectators, who could not but take interest in one\r\nexposed to such disadvantage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeware! beware! Sir Disinherited!\xe2\x80\x9d was shouted so universally, that\r\nthe knight became aware of his danger; and, striking a full blow at the\r\nTemplar, he reined back his steed in the same moment, so as to escape\r\nthe charge of Athelstane and Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf. These knights, therefore,\r\ntheir aim being thus eluded, rushed from opposite sides betwixt the\r\nobject of their attack and the Templar, almost running their horses\r\nagainst each other ere they could stop their career. Recovering their\r\nhorses however, and wheeling them round, the whole three pursued their\r\nunited purpose of bearing to the earth the Disinherited Knight.\r\n\r\nNothing could have saved him, except the remarkable strength and\r\nactivity of the noble horse which he had won on the preceding day.\r\n\r\nThis stood him in the more stead, as the horse of Bois-Guilbert was\r\nwounded, and those of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and Athelstane were both tired with\r\nthe weight of their gigantic masters, clad in complete armour, and with\r\nthe preceding exertions of the day. The masterly horsemanship of the\r\nDisinherited Knight, and the activity of the noble animal which he\r\nmounted, enabled him for a few minutes to keep at sword\xe2\x80\x99s point his\r\nthree antagonists, turning and wheeling with the agility of a hawk upon\r\nthe wing, keeping his enemies as far separate as he could, and rushing\r\nnow against the one, now against the other, dealing sweeping blows with\r\nhis sword, without waiting to receive those which were aimed at him in\r\nreturn.\r\n\r\nBut although the lists rang with the applauses of his dexterity, it was\r\nevident that he must at last be overpowered; and the nobles around\r\nPrince John implored him with one voice to throw down his warder, and\r\nto save so brave a knight from the disgrace of being overcome by odds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I, by the light of Heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Prince John; \xe2\x80\x9cthis same\r\nspringald, who conceals his name, and despises our proffered\r\nhospitality, hath already gained one prize, and may now afford to let\r\nothers have their turn.\xe2\x80\x9d As he spoke thus, an unexpected incident\r\nchanged the fortune of the day.\r\n\r\nThere was among the ranks of the Disinherited Knight a champion in\r\nblack armour, mounted on a black horse, large of size, tall, and to all\r\nappearance powerful and strong, like the rider by whom he was mounted.\r\nThis knight, who bore on his shield no device of any kind, had hitherto\r\nevinced very little interest in the event of the fight, beating off\r\nwith seeming ease those combatants who attacked him, but neither\r\npursuing his advantages, nor himself assailing any one. In short, he\r\nhad hitherto acted the part rather of a spectator than of a party in\r\nthe tournament, a circumstance which procured him among the spectators\r\nthe name of \xe2\x80\x9cLe Noir Faineant\xe2\x80\x9d, or the Black Sluggard.\r\n\r\nAt once this knight seemed to throw aside his apathy, when he\r\ndiscovered the leader of his party so hard bestead; for, setting spurs\r\nto his horse, which was quite fresh, he came to his assistance like a\r\nthunderbolt, exclaiming, in a voice like a trumpet-call, \xe2\x80\x9cDesdichado,\r\nto the rescue!\xe2\x80\x9d It was high time; for, while the Disinherited Knight\r\nwas pressing upon the Templar, Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf had got nigh to him with\r\nhis uplifted sword; but ere the blow could descend, the Sable Knight\r\ndealt a stroke on his head, which, glancing from the polished helmet,\r\nlighted with violence scarcely abated on the \xe2\x80\x9cchamfron\xe2\x80\x9d of the steed,\r\nand Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf rolled on the ground, both horse and man equally\r\nstunned by the fury of the blow. \xe2\x80\x9cLe Noir Faineant\xe2\x80\x9d then turned his\r\nhorse upon Athelstane of Coningsburgh; and his own sword having been\r\nbroken in his encounter with Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, he wrenched from the hand\r\nof the bulky Saxon the battle-axe which he wielded, and, like one\r\nfamiliar with the use of the weapon, bestowed him such a blow upon the\r\ncrest, that Athelstane also lay senseless on the field. Having achieved\r\nthis double feat, for which he was the more highly applauded that it\r\nwas totally unexpected from him, the knight seemed to resume the\r\nsluggishness of his character, returning calmly to the northern\r\nextremity of the lists, leaving his leader to cope as he best could\r\nwith Brian de Bois-Guilbert. This was no longer matter of so much\r\ndifficulty as formerly. The Templars horse had bled much, and gave way\r\nunder the shock of the Disinherited Knight\xe2\x80\x99s charge. Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert rolled on the field, encumbered with the stirrup, from\r\nwhich he was unable to draw his foot. His antagonist sprung from\r\nhorseback, waved his fatal sword over the head of his adversary, and\r\ncommanded him to yield himself; when Prince John, more moved by the\r\nTemplars dangerous situation than he had been by that of his rival,\r\nsaved him the mortification of confessing himself vanquished, by\r\ncasting down his warder, and putting an end to the conflict.\r\n\r\nIt was, indeed, only the relics and embers of the fight which continued\r\nto burn; for of the few knights who still continued in the lists, the\r\ngreater part had, by tacit consent, forborne the conflict for some\r\ntime, leaving it to be determined by the strife of the leaders.\r\n\r\nThe squires, who had found it a matter of danger and difficulty to\r\nattend their masters during the engagement, now thronged into the lists\r\nto pay their dutiful attendance to the wounded, who were removed with\r\nthe utmost care and attention to the neighbouring pavilions, or to the\r\nquarters prepared for them in the adjoining village.\r\n\r\nThus ended the memorable field of Ashby-de-la-Zouche, one of the most\r\ngallantly contested tournaments of that age; for although only four\r\nknights, including one who was smothered by the heat of his armour, had\r\ndied upon the field, yet upwards of thirty were desperately wounded,\r\nfour or five of whom never recovered. Several more were disabled for\r\nlife; and those who escaped best carried the marks of the conflict to\r\nthe grave with them. Hence it is always mentioned in the old records,\r\nas the Gentle and Joyous Passage of Arms of Ashby.\r\n\r\nIt being now the duty of Prince John to name the knight who had done\r\nbest, he determined that the honour of the day remained with the knight\r\nwhom the popular voice had termed \xe2\x80\x9cLe Noir Faineant.\xe2\x80\x9d It was pointed\r\nout to the Prince, in impeachment of this decree, that the victory had\r\nbeen in fact won by the Disinherited Knight, who, in the course of the\r\nday, had overcome six champions with his own hand, and who had finally\r\nunhorsed and struck down the leader of the opposite party. But Prince\r\nJohn adhered to his own opinion, on the ground that the Disinherited\r\nKnight and his party had lost the day, but for the powerful assistance\r\nof the Knight of the Black Armour, to whom, therefore, he persisted in\r\nawarding the prize.\r\n\r\nTo the surprise of all present, however, the knight thus preferred was\r\nnowhere to be found. He had left the lists immediately when the\r\nconflict ceased, and had been observed by some spectators to move down\r\none of the forest glades with the same slow pace and listless and\r\nindifferent manner which had procured him the epithet of the Black\r\nSluggard. After he had been summoned twice by sound of trumpet, and\r\nproclamation of the heralds, it became necessary to name another to\r\nreceive the honours which had been assigned to him. Prince John had now\r\nno further excuse for resisting the claim of the Disinherited Knight,\r\nwhom, therefore, he named the champion of the day.\r\n\r\nThrough a field slippery with blood, and encumbered with broken armour\r\nand the bodies of slain and wounded horses, the marshals of the lists\r\nagain conducted the victor to the foot of Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s throne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDisinherited Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9csince by that title only you\r\nwill consent to be known to us, we a second time award to you the\r\nhonours of this tournament, and announce to you your right to claim and\r\nreceive from the hands of the Queen of Love and Beauty, the Chaplet of\r\nHonour which your valour has justly deserved.\xe2\x80\x9d The Knight bowed low and\r\ngracefully, but returned no answer.\r\n\r\nWhile the trumpets sounded, while the heralds strained their voices in\r\nproclaiming honour to the brave and glory to the victor\xe2\x80\x94while ladies\r\nwaved their silken kerchiefs and embroidered veils, and while all ranks\r\njoined in a clamorous shout of exultation, the marshals conducted the\r\nDisinherited Knight across the lists to the foot of that throne of\r\nhonour which was occupied by the Lady Rowena.\r\n\r\nOn the lower step of this throne the champion was made to kneel down.\r\nIndeed his whole action since the fight had ended, seemed rather to\r\nhave been upon the impulse of those around him than from his own free\r\nwill; and it was observed that he tottered as they guided him the\r\nsecond time across the lists. Rowena, descending from her station with\r\na graceful and dignified step, was about to place the chaplet which she\r\nheld in her hand upon the helmet of the champion, when the marshals\r\nexclaimed with one voice, \xe2\x80\x9cIt must not be thus\xe2\x80\x94his head must be bare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThe knight muttered faintly a few words, which were lost in the hollow\r\nof his helmet, but their purport seemed to be a desire that his casque\r\nmight not be removed.\r\n\r\nWhether from love of form, or from curiosity, the marshals paid no\r\nattention to his expressions of reluctance, but unhelmed him by cutting\r\nthe laces of his casque, and undoing the fastening of his gorget. When\r\nthe helmet was removed, the well-formed, yet sun-burnt features of a\r\nyoung man of twenty-five were seen, amidst a profusion of short fair\r\nhair. His countenance was as pale as death, and marked in one or two\r\nplaces with streaks of blood.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nRowena had no sooner beheld him than she uttered a faint shriek; but at\r\nonce summoning up the energy of her disposition, and compelling\r\nherself, as it were, to proceed, while her frame yet trembled with the\r\nviolence of sudden emotion, she placed upon the drooping head of the\r\nvictor the splendid chaplet which was the destined reward of the day,\r\nand pronounced, in a clear and distinct tone, these words: \xe2\x80\x9cI bestow on\r\nthee this chaplet, Sir Knight, as the meed of valour assigned to this\r\nday\xe2\x80\x99s victor:\xe2\x80\x9d Here she paused a moment, and then firmly added, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd\r\nupon brows more worthy could a wreath of chivalry never be placed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe knight stooped his head, and kissed the hand of the lovely\r\nSovereign by whom his valour had been rewarded; and then, sinking yet\r\nfarther forward, lay prostrate at her feet.\r\n\r\nThere was a general consternation. Cedric, who had been struck mute by\r\nthe sudden appearance of his banished son, now rushed forward, as if to\r\nseparate him from Rowena. But this had been already accomplished by the\r\nmarshals of the field, who, guessing the cause of Ivanhoe\xe2\x80\x99s swoon, had\r\nhastened to undo his armour, and found that the head of a lance had\r\npenetrated his breastplate, and inflicted a wound in his side.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIII\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeroes, approach!\xe2\x80\x9d Atrides thus aloud,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand forth distinguish\xe2\x80\x99d from the circling crowd,\r\nYe who by skill or manly force may claim,\r\nYour rivals to surpass and merit fame.\r\nThis cow, worth twenty oxen, is decreed,\r\nFor him who farthest sends the winged reed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nILIAD\r\n\r\n\r\nThe name of Ivanhoe was no sooner pronounced than it flew from mouth to\r\nmouth, with all the celerity with which eagerness could convey and\r\ncuriosity receive it. It was not long ere it reached the circle of the\r\nPrince, whose brow darkened as he heard the news. Looking around him,\r\nhowever, with an air of scorn, \xe2\x80\x9cMy Lords,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand especially\r\nyou, Sir Prior, what think ye of the doctrine the learned tell us,\r\nconcerning innate attractions and antipathies? Methinks that I felt the\r\npresence of my brother\xe2\x80\x99s minion, even when I least guessed whom yonder\r\nsuit of armour enclosed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf must prepare to restore his fief of Ivanhoe,\xe2\x80\x9d said De\r\nBracy, who, having discharged his part honourably in the tournament,\r\nhad laid his shield and helmet aside, and again mingled with the\r\nPrince\xe2\x80\x99s retinue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Waldemar Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cthis gallant is likely to reclaim\r\nthe castle and manor which Richard assigned to him, and which your\r\nHighness\xe2\x80\x99s generosity has since given to Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\xe2\x80\x9d replied John, \xe2\x80\x9cis a man more willing to swallow three\r\nmanors such as Ivanhoe, than to disgorge one of them. For the rest,\r\nsirs, I hope none here will deny my right to confer the fiefs of the\r\ncrown upon the faithful followers who are around me, and ready to\r\nperform the usual military service, in the room of those who have\r\nwandered to foreign Countries, and can neither render homage nor\r\nservice when called upon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe audience were too much interested in the question not to pronounce\r\nthe Prince\xe2\x80\x99s assumed right altogether indubitable. \xe2\x80\x9cA generous\r\nPrince!\xe2\x80\x94a most noble Lord, who thus takes upon himself the task of\r\nrewarding his faithful followers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSuch were the words which burst from the train, expectants all of them\r\nof similar grants at the expense of King Richard\xe2\x80\x99s followers and\r\nfavourites, if indeed they had not as yet received such. Prior Aymer\r\nalso assented to the general proposition, observing, however, \xe2\x80\x9cThat the\r\nblessed Jerusalem could not indeed be termed a foreign country. She was\r\n\xe2\x80\x98communis mater\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94the mother of all Christians. But he saw not,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ndeclared, \xe2\x80\x9chow the Knight of Ivanhoe could plead any advantage from\r\nthis, since he\xe2\x80\x9d (the Prior) \xe2\x80\x9cwas assured that the crusaders, under\r\nRichard, had never proceeded much farther than Askalon, which, as all\r\nthe world knew, was a town of the Philistines, and entitled to none of\r\nthe privileges of the Holy City.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWaldemar, whose curiosity had led him towards the place where Ivanhoe\r\nhad fallen to the ground, now returned. \xe2\x80\x9cThe gallant,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cis\r\nlikely to give your Highness little disturbance, and to leave\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf in the quiet possession of his gains\xe2\x80\x94he is severely\r\nwounded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhatever becomes of him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9che is victor of the day;\r\nand were he tenfold our enemy, or the devoted friend of our brother,\r\nwhich is perhaps the same, his wounds must be looked to\xe2\x80\x94our own\r\nphysician shall attend him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA stern smile curled the Prince\xe2\x80\x99s lip as he spoke. Waldemar Fitzurse\r\nhastened to reply, that Ivanhoe was already removed from the lists, and\r\nin the custody of his friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was somewhat afflicted,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cto see the grief of the Queen of\r\nLove and Beauty, whose sovereignty of a day this event has changed into\r\nmourning. I am not a man to be moved by a woman\xe2\x80\x99s lament for her lover,\r\nbut this same Lady Rowena suppressed her sorrow with such dignity of\r\nmanner, that it could only be discovered by her folded hands, and her\r\ntearless eye, which trembled as it remained fixed on the lifeless form\r\nbefore her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is this Lady Rowena,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cof whom we have heard so\r\nmuch?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Saxon heiress of large possessions,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Prior Aymer; \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nrose of loveliness, and a jewel of wealth; the fairest among a\r\nthousand, a bundle of myrrh, and a cluster of camphire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall cheer her sorrows,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cand amend her blood,\r\nby wedding her to a Norman. She seems a minor, and must therefore be at\r\nour royal disposal in marriage.\xe2\x80\x94How sayst thou, De Bracy? What thinkst\r\nthou of gaining fair lands and livings, by wedding a Saxon, after the\r\nfashion of the followers of the Conqueror?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the lands are to my liking, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cit will\r\nbe hard to displease me with a bride; and deeply will I hold myself\r\nbound to your highness for a good deed, which will fulfil all promises\r\nmade in favour of your servant and vassal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will not forget it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John; \xe2\x80\x9cand that we may instantly\r\ngo to work, command our seneschal presently to order the attendance of\r\nthe Lady Rowena and her company\xe2\x80\x94that is, the rude churl her guardian,\r\nand the Saxon ox whom the Black Knight struck down in the tournament,\r\nupon this evening\xe2\x80\x99s banquet.\xe2\x80\x94De Bigot,\xe2\x80\x9d he added to his seneschal,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthou wilt word this our second summons so courteously, as to gratify\r\nthe pride of these Saxons, and make it impossible for them again to\r\nrefuse; although, by the bones of Becket, courtesy to them is casting\r\npearls before swine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPrince John had proceeded thus far, and was about to give the signal\r\nfor retiring from the lists, when a small billet was put into his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom whence?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, looking at the person by whom it was\r\ndelivered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom foreign parts, my lord, but from whence I know not\xe2\x80\x9d replied his\r\nattendant. \xe2\x80\x9cA Frenchman brought it hither, who said, he had ridden\r\nnight and day to put it into the hands of your highness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Prince looked narrowly at the superscription, and then at the seal,\r\nplaced so as to secure the flex-silk with which the billet was\r\nsurrounded, and which bore the impression of three fleurs-de-lis. John\r\nthen opened the billet with apparent agitation, which visibly and\r\ngreatly increased when he had perused the contents, which were\r\nexpressed in these words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Take heed to yourself for the Devil is unchained!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Prince turned as pale as death, looked first on the earth, and then\r\nup to heaven, like a man who has received news that sentence of\r\nexecution has been passed upon him. Recovering from the first effects\r\nof his surprise, he took Waldemar Fitzurse and De Bracy aside, and put\r\nthe billet into their hands successively. \xe2\x80\x9cIt means,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, in a\r\nfaltering voice, \xe2\x80\x9cthat my brother Richard has obtained his freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis may be a false alarm, or a forged letter,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is France\xe2\x80\x99s own hand and seal,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince John.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is time, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cto draw our party to a head, either\r\nat York, or some other centrical place. A few days later, and it will\r\nbe indeed too late. Your highness must break short this present\r\nmummery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe yeomen and commons,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cmust not be dismissed\r\ndiscontented, for lack of their share in the sports.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe day,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar, \xe2\x80\x9cis not yet very far spent\xe2\x80\x94let the archers\r\nshoot a few rounds at the target, and the prize be adjudged. This will\r\nbe an abundant fulfilment of the Prince\xe2\x80\x99s promises, so far as this herd\r\nof Saxon serfs is concerned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank thee, Waldemar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prince; \xe2\x80\x9cthou remindest me, too,\r\nthat I have a debt to pay to that insolent peasant who yesterday\r\ninsulted our person. Our banquet also shall go forward to-night as we\r\nproposed. Were this my last hour of power, it should be an hour sacred\r\nto revenge and to pleasure\xe2\x80\x94let new cares come with to-morrow\xe2\x80\x99s new\r\nday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe sound of the trumpets soon recalled those spectators who had\r\nalready begun to leave the field; and proclamation was made that Prince\r\nJohn, suddenly called by high and peremptory public duties, held\r\nhimself obliged to discontinue the entertainments of to-morrow\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfestival: Nevertheless, that, unwilling so many good yeoman should\r\ndepart without a trial of skill, he was pleased to appoint them, before\r\nleaving the ground, presently to execute the competition of archery\r\nintended for the morrow. To the best archer a prize was to be awarded,\r\nbeing a bugle-horn, mounted with silver, and a silken baldric richly\r\nornamented with a medallion of St Hubert, the patron of silvan sport.\r\n\r\nMore than thirty yeomen at first presented themselves as competitors,\r\nseveral of whom were rangers and under-keepers in the royal forests of\r\nNeedwood and Charnwood. When, however, the archers understood with whom\r\nthey were to be matched, upwards of twenty withdrew themselves from the\r\ncontest, unwilling to encounter the dishonour of almost certain defeat.\r\nFor in those days the skill of each celebrated marksman was as well\r\nknown for many miles round him, as the qualities of a horse trained at\r\nNewmarket are familiar to those who frequent that well-known meeting.\r\n\r\nThe diminished list of competitors for silvan fame still amounted to\r\neight. Prince John stepped from his royal seat to view more nearly the\r\npersons of these chosen yeomen, several of whom wore the royal livery.\r\nHaving satisfied his curiosity by this investigation, he looked for the\r\nobject of his resentment, whom he observed standing on the same spot,\r\nand with the same composed countenance which he had exhibited upon the\r\npreceding day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cI guessed by thy insolent babble that thou\r\nwert no true lover of the longbow, and I see thou darest not adventure\r\nthy skill among such merry-men as stand yonder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnder favour, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9cI have another reason for\r\nrefraining to shoot, besides the fearing discomfiture and disgrace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is thy other reason?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, who, for some cause\r\nwhich perhaps he could not himself have explained, felt a painful\r\ncuriosity respecting this individual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the woodsman, \xe2\x80\x9cI know not if these yeomen and I are\r\nused to shoot at the same marks; and because, moreover, I know not how\r\nyour Grace might relish the winning of a third prize by one who has\r\nunwittingly fallen under your displeasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPrince John coloured as he put the question, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is thy name,\r\nyeoman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLocksley,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the yeoman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, Locksley,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt shoot in thy turn, when\r\nthese yeomen have displayed their skill. If thou carriest the prize, I\r\nwill add to it twenty nobles; but if thou losest it, thou shalt be\r\nstript of thy Lincoln green, and scourged out of the lists with\r\nbowstrings, for a wordy and insolent braggart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how if I refuse to shoot on such a wager?\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYour\r\nGrace\xe2\x80\x99s power, supported, as it is, by so many men-at-arms, may indeed\r\neasily strip and scourge me, but cannot compel me to bend or to draw my\r\nbow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou refusest my fair proffer,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prince, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Provost of\r\nthe lists shall cut thy bowstring, break thy bow and arrows, and expel\r\nthee from the presence as a faint-hearted craven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is no fair chance you put on me, proud Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cto compel me to peril myself against the best archers of Leicester and\r\nStaffordshire, under the penalty of infamy if they should overshoot me.\r\nNevertheless, I will obey your pleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook to him close, men-at-arms,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9chis heart is\r\nsinking; I am jealous lest he attempt to escape the trial.\xe2\x80\x94And do you,\r\ngood fellows, shoot boldly round; a buck and a butt of wine are ready\r\nfor your refreshment in yonder tent, when the prize is won.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA target was placed at the upper end of the southern avenue which led\r\nto the lists. The contending archers took their station in turn, at the\r\nbottom of the southern access, the distance between that station and\r\nthe mark allowing full distance for what was called a shot at rovers.\r\nThe archers, having previously determined by lot their order of\r\nprecedence, were to shoot each three shafts in succession. The sports\r\nwere regulated by an officer of inferior rank, termed the Provost of\r\nthe Games; for the high rank of the marshals of the lists would have\r\nbeen held degraded, had they condescended to superintend the sports of\r\nthe yeomanry.\r\n\r\nOne by one the archers, stepping forward, delivered their shafts\r\nyeomanlike and bravely. Of twenty-four arrows, shot in succession, ten\r\nwere fixed in the target, and the others ranged so near it, that,\r\nconsidering the distance of the mark, it was accounted good archery. Of\r\nthe ten shafts which hit the target, two within the inner ring were\r\nshot by Hubert, a forester in the service of Malvoisin, who was\r\naccordingly pronounced victorious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Locksley,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John to the bold yeoman, with a bitter\r\nsmile, \xe2\x80\x9cwilt thou try conclusions with Hubert, or wilt thou yield up\r\nbow, baldric, and quiver, to the Provost of the sports?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSith it be no better,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9cI am content to try my fortune;\r\non condition that when I have shot two shafts at yonder mark of\r\nHubert\xe2\x80\x99s, he shall be bound to shoot one at that which I shall\r\npropose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is but fair,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cand it shall not be refused\r\nthee.\xe2\x80\x94If thou dost beat this braggart, Hubert, I will fill the bugle\r\nwith silver-pennies for thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man can do but his best,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Hubert; \xe2\x80\x9cbut my grandsire drew a\r\ngood long bow at Hastings, and I trust not to dishonour his memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe former target was now removed, and a fresh one of the same size\r\nplaced in its room. Hubert, who, as victor in the first trial of skill,\r\nhad the right to shoot first, took his aim with great deliberation,\r\nlong measuring the distance with his eye, while he held in his hand his\r\nbended bow, with the arrow placed on the string. At length he made a\r\nstep forward, and raising the bow at the full stretch of his left arm,\r\ntill the centre or grasping-place was nigh level with his face, he drew\r\nhis bowstring to his ear. The arrow whistled through the air, and\r\nlighted within the inner ring of the target, but not exactly in the\r\ncentre.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have not allowed for the wind, Hubert,\xe2\x80\x9d said his antagonist,\r\nbending his bow, \xe2\x80\x9cor that had been a better shot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, and without showing the least anxiety to pause upon his aim,\r\nLocksley stept to the appointed station, and shot his arrow as\r\ncarelessly in appearance as if he had not even looked at the mark. He\r\nwas speaking almost at the instant that the shaft left the bowstring,\r\nyet it alighted in the target two inches nearer to the white spot which\r\nmarked the centre than that of Hubert.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the light of heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John to Hubert, \xe2\x80\x9can thou suffer\r\nthat runagate knave to overcome thee, thou art worthy of the gallows!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHubert had but one set speech for all occasions. \xe2\x80\x9cAn your highness were\r\nto hang me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9ca man can but do his best. Nevertheless, my\r\ngrandsire drew a good bow\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe foul fiend on thy grandsire and all his generation!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted\r\nJohn, \xe2\x80\x9cshoot, knave, and shoot thy best, or it shall be the worse for\r\nthee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus exhorted, Hubert resumed his place, and not neglecting the caution\r\nwhich he had received from his adversary, he made the necessary\r\nallowance for a very light air of wind, which had just arisen, and shot\r\nso successfully that his arrow alighted in the very centre of the\r\ntarget.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Hubert! a Hubert!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the populace, more interested in a known\r\nperson than in a stranger. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the clout!\xe2\x80\x94in the clout!\xe2\x80\x94a Hubert for\r\never!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou canst not mend that shot, Locksley,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prince, with an\r\ninsulting smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will notch his shaft for him, however,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Locksley.\r\n\r\nAnd letting fly his arrow with a little more precaution than before, it\r\nlighted right upon that of his competitor, which it split to shivers.\r\nThe people who stood around were so astonished at his wonderful\r\ndexterity, that they could not even give vent to their surprise in\r\ntheir usual clamour. \xe2\x80\x9cThis must be the devil, and no man of flesh and\r\nblood,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the yeomen to each other; \xe2\x80\x9csuch archery was never\r\nseen since a bow was first bent in Britain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9cI will crave your Grace\xe2\x80\x99s permission to\r\nplant such a mark as is used in the North Country; and welcome every\r\nbrave yeoman who shall try a shot at it to win a smile from the bonny\r\nlass he loves best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then turned to leave the lists. \xe2\x80\x9cLet your guards attend me,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cif you please\xe2\x80\x94I go but to cut a rod from the next willow-bush.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPrince John made a signal that some attendants should follow him in\r\ncase of his escape: but the cry of \xe2\x80\x9cShame! shame!\xe2\x80\x9d which burst from the\r\nmultitude, induced him to alter his ungenerous purpose.\r\n\r\nLocksley returned almost instantly with a willow wand about six feet in\r\nlength, perfectly straight, and rather thicker than a man\xe2\x80\x99s thumb. He\r\nbegan to peel this with great composure, observing at the same time,\r\nthat to ask a good woodsman to shoot at a target so broad as had\r\nhitherto been used, was to put shame upon his skill. \xe2\x80\x9cFor his own\r\npart,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand in the land where he was bred, men would as soon\r\ntake for their mark King Arthur\xe2\x80\x99s round-table, which held sixty knights\r\naround it. A child of seven years old,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmight hit yonder\r\ntarget with a headless shaft; but,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, walking deliberately to\r\nthe other end of the lists, and sticking the willow wand upright in the\r\nground, \xe2\x80\x9che that hits that rod at five-score yards, I call him an\r\narcher fit to bear both bow and quiver before a king, an it were the\r\nstout King Richard himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy grandsire,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hubert, \xe2\x80\x9cdrew a good bow at the battle of\r\nHastings, and never shot at such a mark in his life\xe2\x80\x94and neither will I.\r\nIf this yeoman can cleave that rod, I give him the bucklers\xe2\x80\x94or rather,\r\nI yield to the devil that is in his jerkin, and not to any human skill;\r\na man can but do his best, and I will not shoot where I am sure to\r\nmiss. I might as well shoot at the edge of our parson\xe2\x80\x99s whittle, or at\r\na wheat straw, or at a sunbeam, as at a twinkling white streak which I\r\ncan hardly see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCowardly dog!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSirrah Locksley, do thou shoot; but,\r\nif thou hittest such a mark, I will say thou art the first man ever did\r\nso. However it be, thou shalt not crow over us with a mere show of\r\nsuperior skill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do my best, as Hubert says,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cno man can do\r\nmore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he again bent his bow, but on the present occasion looked\r\nwith attention to his weapon, and changed the string, which he thought\r\nwas no longer truly round, having been a little frayed by the two\r\nformer shots. He then took his aim with some deliberation, and the\r\nmultitude awaited the event in breathless silence. The archer\r\nvindicated their opinion of his skill: his arrow split the willow rod\r\nagainst which it was aimed. A jubilee of acclamations followed; and\r\neven Prince John, in admiration of Locksley\xe2\x80\x99s skill, lost for an\r\ninstant his dislike to his person. \xe2\x80\x9cThese twenty nobles,\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhich, with the bugle, thou hast fairly won, are thine own; we will\r\nmake them fifty, if thou wilt take livery and service with us as a\r\nyeoman of our body guard, and be near to our person. For never did so\r\nstrong a hand bend a bow, or so true an eye direct a shaft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, noble Prince,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I have vowed, that if\r\never I take service, it should be with your royal brother King Richard.\r\nThese twenty nobles I leave to Hubert, who has this day drawn as brave\r\na bow as his grandsire did at Hastings. Had his modesty not refused the\r\ntrial, he would have hit the wand as well I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHubert shook his head as he received with reluctance the bounty of the\r\nstranger, and Locksley, anxious to escape further observation, mixed\r\nwith the crowd, and was seen no more.\r\n\r\nThe victorious archer would not perhaps have escaped John\xe2\x80\x99s attention\r\nso easily, had not that Prince had other subjects of anxious and more\r\nimportant meditation pressing upon his mind at that instant. He called\r\nupon his chamberlain as he gave the signal for retiring from the lists,\r\nand commanded him instantly to gallop to Ashby, and seek out Isaac the\r\nJew. \xe2\x80\x9cTell the dog,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cto send me, before sun-down, two\r\nthousand crowns. He knows the security; but thou mayst show him this\r\nring for a token. The rest of the money must be paid at York within six\r\ndays. If he neglects, I will have the unbelieving villain\xe2\x80\x99s head. Look\r\nthat thou pass him not on the way; for the circumcised slave was\r\ndisplaying his stolen finery amongst us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, the Prince resumed his horse, and returned to Ashby, the\r\nwhole crowd breaking up and dispersing upon his retreat.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIV\r\n\r\n\r\nIn rough magnificence array\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nWhen ancient Chivalry display\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nThe pomp of her heroic games,\r\nAnd crested chiefs and tissued dames\r\nAssembled, at the clarion\xe2\x80\x99s call,\r\nIn some proud castle\xe2\x80\x99s high arch\xe2\x80\x99d hall.\r\n\r\n\r\nWARTON\r\n\r\n\r\nPrince John held his high festival in the Castle of Ashby. This was not\r\nthe same building of which the stately ruins still interest the\r\ntraveller, and which was erected at a later period by the Lord\r\nHastings, High Chamberlain of England, one of the first victims of the\r\ntyranny of Richard the Third, and yet better known as one of\r\nShakespeare\xe2\x80\x99s characters than by his historical fame. The castle and\r\ntown of Ashby, at this time, belonged to Roger de Quincy, Earl of\r\nWinchester, who, during the period of our history, was absent in the\r\nHoly Land. Prince John, in the meanwhile, occupied his castle, and\r\ndisposed of his domains without scruple; and seeking at present to\r\ndazzle men\xe2\x80\x99s eyes by his hospitality and magnificence, had given orders\r\nfor great preparations, in order to render the banquet as splendid as\r\npossible.\r\n\r\nThe purveyors of the Prince, who exercised on this and other occasions\r\nthe full authority of royalty, had swept the country of all that could\r\nbe collected which was esteemed fit for their master\xe2\x80\x99s table. Guests\r\nalso were invited in great numbers; and in the necessity in which he\r\nthen found himself of courting popularity, Prince John had extended his\r\ninvitation to a few distinguished Saxon and Danish families, as well as\r\nto the Norman nobility and gentry of the neighbourhood. However\r\ndespised and degraded on ordinary occasions, the great numbers of the\r\nAnglo-Saxons must necessarily render them formidable in the civil\r\ncommotions which seemed approaching, and it was an obvious point of\r\npolicy to secure popularity with their leaders.\r\n\r\nIt was accordingly the Prince\xe2\x80\x99s intention, which he for some time\r\nmaintained, to treat these unwonted guests with a courtesy to which\r\nthey had been little accustomed. But although no man with less scruple\r\nmade his ordinary habits and feelings bend to his interest, it was the\r\nmisfortune of this Prince, that his levity and petulance were\r\nperpetually breaking out, and undoing all that had been gained by his\r\nprevious dissimulation.\r\n\r\nOf this fickle temper he gave a memorable example in Ireland, when sent\r\nthither by his father, Henry the Second, with the purpose of buying\r\ngolden opinions of the inhabitants of that new and important\r\nacquisition to the English crown. Upon this occasion the Irish\r\nchieftains contended which should first offer to the young Prince their\r\nloyal homage and the kiss of peace. But, instead of receiving their\r\nsalutations with courtesy, John and his petulant attendants could not\r\nresist the temptation of pulling the long beards of the Irish\r\nchieftains; a conduct which, as might have been expected, was highly\r\nresented by these insulted dignitaries, and produced fatal consequences\r\nto the English domination in Ireland. It is necessary to keep these\r\ninconsistencies of John\xe2\x80\x99s character in view, that the reader may\r\nunderstand his conduct during the present evening.\r\n\r\nIn execution of the resolution which he had formed during his cooler\r\nmoments, Prince John received Cedric and Athelstane with distinguished\r\ncourtesy, and expressed his disappointment, without resentment, when\r\nthe indisposition of Rowena was alleged by the former as a reason for\r\nher not attending upon his gracious summons. Cedric and Athelstane were\r\nboth dressed in the ancient Saxon garb, which, although not unhandsome\r\nin itself, and in the present instance composed of costly materials,\r\nwas so remote in shape and appearance from that of the other guests,\r\nthat Prince John took great credit to himself with Waldemar Fitzurse\r\nfor refraining from laughter at a sight which the fashion of the day\r\nrendered ridiculous. Yet, in the eye of sober judgment, the short close\r\ntunic and long mantle of the Saxons was a more graceful, as well as a\r\nmore convenient dress, than the garb of the Normans, whose under\r\ngarment was a long doublet, so loose as to resemble a shirt or\r\nwaggoner\xe2\x80\x99s frock, covered by a cloak of scanty dimensions, neither fit\r\nto defend the wearer from cold or from rain, and the only purpose of\r\nwhich appeared to be to display as much fur, embroidery, and jewellery\r\nwork, as the ingenuity of the tailor could contrive to lay upon it. The\r\nEmperor Charlemagne, in whose reign they were first introduced, seems\r\nto have been very sensible of the inconveniences arising from the\r\nfashion of this garment. \xe2\x80\x9cIn Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s name,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cto what purpose\r\nserve these abridged cloaks? If we are in bed they are no cover, on\r\nhorseback they are no protection from the wind and rain, and when\r\nseated, they do not guard our legs from the damp or the frost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNevertheless, spite of this imperial objurgation, the short cloaks\r\ncontinued in fashion down to the time of which we treat, and\r\nparticularly among the princes of the House of Anjou. They were\r\ntherefore in universal use among Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s courtiers; and the long\r\nmantle, which formed the upper garment of the Saxons, was held in\r\nproportional derision.\r\n\r\nThe guests were seated at a table which groaned under the quantity of\r\ngood cheer. The numerous cooks who attended on the Prince\xe2\x80\x99s progress,\r\nhaving exerted all their art in varying the forms in which the ordinary\r\nprovisions were served up, had succeeded almost as well as the modern\r\nprofessors of the culinary art in rendering them perfectly unlike their\r\nnatural appearance. Besides these dishes of domestic origin, there were\r\nvarious delicacies brought from foreign parts, and a quantity of rich\r\npastry, as well as of the simnel-bread and wastle cakes, which were\r\nonly used at the tables of the highest nobility. The banquet was\r\ncrowned with the richest wines, both foreign and domestic.\r\n\r\nBut, though luxurious, the Norman nobles were not generally speaking an\r\nintemperate race. While indulging themselves in the pleasures of the\r\ntable, they aimed at delicacy, but avoided excess, and were apt to\r\nattribute gluttony and drunkenness to the vanquished Saxons, as vices\r\npeculiar to their inferior station. Prince John, indeed, and those who\r\ncourted his pleasure by imitating his foibles, were apt to indulge to\r\nexcess in the pleasures of the trencher and the goblet; and indeed it\r\nis well known that his death was occasioned by a surfeit upon peaches\r\nand new ale. His conduct, however, was an exception to the general\r\nmanners of his countrymen.\r\n\r\nWith sly gravity, interrupted only by private signs to each other, the\r\nNorman knights and nobles beheld the ruder demeanour of Athelstane and\r\nCedric at a banquet, to the form and fashion of which they were\r\nunaccustomed. And while their manners were thus the subject of\r\nsarcastic observation, the untaught Saxons unwittingly transgressed\r\nseveral of the arbitrary rules established for the regulation of\r\nsociety. Now, it is well known, that a man may with more impunity be\r\nguilty of an actual breach either of real good breeding or of good\r\nmorals, than appear ignorant of the most minute point of fashionable\r\netiquette. Thus Cedric, who dried his hands with a towel, instead of\r\nsuffering the moisture to exhale by waving them gracefully in the air,\r\nincurred more ridicule than his companion Athelstane, when he swallowed\r\nto his own single share the whole of a large pasty composed of the most\r\nexquisite foreign delicacies, and termed at that time a \xe2\x80\x9cKarum-Pie\xe2\x80\x9d.\r\nWhen, however, it was discovered, by a serious cross-examination, that\r\nthe Thane of Coningsburgh (or Franklin, as the Normans termed him) had\r\nno idea what he had been devouring, and that he had taken the contents\r\nof the Karum-pie for larks and pigeons, whereas they were in fact\r\nbeccaficoes and nightingales, his ignorance brought him in for an ample\r\nshare of the ridicule which would have been more justly bestowed on his\r\ngluttony.\r\n\r\nThe long feast had at length its end; and, while the goblet circulated\r\nfreely, men talked of the feats of the preceding tournament,\xe2\x80\x94of the\r\nunknown victor in the archery games, of the Black Knight, whose\r\nself-denial had induced him to withdraw from the honours he had\r\nwon,\xe2\x80\x94and of the gallant Ivanhoe, who had so dearly bought the honours\r\nof the day.
