The topics were treated with military frankness, and the\r\njest and laugh went round the hall. The brow of Prince John alone was\r\noverclouded during these discussions; some overpowering care seemed\r\nagitating his mind, and it was only when he received occasional hints\r\nfrom his attendants, that he seemed to take interest in what was\r\npassing around him. On such occasions he would start up, quaff a cup of\r\nwine as if to raise his spirits, and then mingle in the conversation by\r\nsome observation made abruptly or at random.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe drink this beaker,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cto the health of Wilfred of Ivanhoe,\r\nchampion of this Passage of Arms, and grieve that his wound renders him\r\nabsent from our board\xe2\x80\x94Let all fill to the pledge, and especially Cedric\r\nof Rotherwood, the worthy father of a son so promising.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cedric, standing up, and placing on the table\r\nhis untasted cup, \xe2\x80\x9cI yield not the name of son to the disobedient\r\nyouth, who at once despises my commands, and relinquishes the manners\r\nand customs of his fathers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Prince John, with well-feigned astonishment,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat so gallant a knight should be an unworthy or disobedient son!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cso it is with this Wilfred. He left\r\nmy homely dwelling to mingle with the gay nobility of your brother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncourt, where he learned to do those tricks of horsemanship which you\r\nprize so highly. He left it contrary to my wish and command; and in the\r\ndays of Alfred that would have been termed disobedience\xe2\x80\x94ay, and a crime\r\nseverely punishable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Prince John, with a deep sigh of affected sympathy,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csince your son was a follower of my unhappy brother, it need not be\r\nenquired where or from whom he learned the lesson of filial\r\ndisobedience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus spake Prince John, wilfully forgetting, that of all the sons of\r\nHenry the Second, though no one was free from the charge, he himself\r\nhad been most distinguished for rebellion and ingratitude to his\r\nfather.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause, \xe2\x80\x9cthat my brother proposed\r\nto confer upon his favourite the rich manor of Ivanhoe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did endow him with it,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cnor is it my least\r\nquarrel with my son, that he stooped to hold, as a feudal vassal, the\r\nvery domains which his fathers possessed in free and independent\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall then have your willing sanction, good Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince\r\nJohn, \xe2\x80\x9cto confer this fief upon a person whose dignity will not be\r\ndiminished by holding land of the British crown.\xe2\x80\x94Sir Reginald\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, turning towards that Baron, \xe2\x80\x9cI trust you will\r\nso keep the goodly Barony of Ivanhoe, that Sir Wilfred shall not incur\r\nhis father\xe2\x80\x99s farther displeasure by again entering upon that fief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy St Anthony!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the black-brow\xe2\x80\x99d giant, \xe2\x80\x9cI will consent that\r\nyour highness shall hold me a Saxon, if either Cedric or Wilfred, or\r\nthe best that ever bore English blood, shall wrench from me the gift\r\nwith which your highness has graced me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhoever shall call thee Saxon, Sir Baron,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cedric, offended at\r\na mode of expression by which the Normans frequently expressed their\r\nhabitual contempt of the English, \xe2\x80\x9cwill do thee an honour as great as\r\nit is undeserved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf would have replied, but Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s petulance and\r\nlevity got the start.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAssuredly,\xe2\x80\x9d said be, \xe2\x80\x9cmy lords, the noble Cedric speaks truth; and his\r\nrace may claim precedence over us as much in the length of their\r\npedigrees as in the longitude of their cloaks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey go before us indeed in the field\xe2\x80\x94as deer before dogs,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nMalvoisin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd with good right may they go before us\xe2\x80\x94forget not,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior\r\nAymer, \xe2\x80\x9cthe superior decency and decorum of their manners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTheir singular abstemiousness and temperance,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy,\r\nforgetting the plan which promised him a Saxon bride.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTogether with the courage and conduct,\xe2\x80\x9d said Brian de Bois-Guilbert,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cby which they distinguished themselves at Hastings and elsewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile, with smooth and smiling cheek, the courtiers, each in turn,\r\nfollowed their Prince\xe2\x80\x99s example, and aimed a shaft of ridicule at\r\nCedric, the face of the Saxon became inflamed with passion, and he\r\nglanced his eyes fiercely from one to another, as if the quick\r\nsuccession of so many injuries had prevented his replying to them in\r\nturn; or, like a baited bull, who, surrounded by his tormentors, is at\r\na loss to choose from among them the immediate object of his revenge.\r\nAt length he spoke, in a voice half choked with passion; and,\r\naddressing himself to Prince John as the head and front of the offence\r\nwhich he had received, \xe2\x80\x9cWhatever,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9chave been the follies and\r\nvices of our race, a Saxon would have been held \xe2\x80\x98nidering\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d 21 (the\r\nmost emphatic term for abject worthlessness,) \xe2\x80\x9cwho should in his own\r\nhall, and while his own wine-cup passed, have treated, or suffered to\r\nbe treated, an unoffending guest as your highness has this day beheld\r\nme used; and whatever was the misfortune of our fathers on the field of\r\nHastings, those may at least be silent,\xe2\x80\x9d here he looked at\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf and the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cwho have within these few hours once\r\nand again lost saddle and stirrup before the lance of a Saxon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my faith, a biting jest!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John. \xe2\x80\x9cHow like you it,\r\nsirs?\xe2\x80\x94Our Saxon subjects rise in spirit and courage; become shrewd in\r\nwit, and bold in bearing, in these unsettled times\xe2\x80\x94What say ye, my\r\nlords?\xe2\x80\x94By this good light, I hold it best to take our galleys, and\r\nreturn to Normandy in time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor fear of the Saxons?\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, laughing; \xe2\x80\x9cwe should need no\r\nweapon but our hunting spears to bring these boars to bay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA truce with your raillery, Sir Knights,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand it were\r\nwell,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, addressing the Prince, \xe2\x80\x9cthat your highness should\r\nassure the worthy Cedric there is no insult intended him by jests,\r\nwhich must sound but harshly in the ear of a stranger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInsult?\xe2\x80\x9d answered Prince John, resuming his courtesy of demeanour; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ntrust it will not be thought that I could mean, or permit any, to be\r\noffered in my presence. Here! I fill my cup to Cedric himself, since he\r\nrefuses to pledge his son\xe2\x80\x99s health.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cup went round amid the well-dissembled applause of the courtiers,\r\nwhich, however, failed to make the impression on the mind of the Saxon\r\nthat had been designed. He was not naturally acute of perception, but\r\nthose too much undervalued his understanding who deemed that this\r\nflattering compliment would obliterate the sense of the prior insult.\r\nHe was silent, however, when the royal pledge again passed round, \xe2\x80\x9cTo\r\nSir Athelstane of Coningsburgh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe knight made his obeisance, and showed his sense of the honour by\r\ndraining a huge goblet in answer to it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, sirs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, who began to be warmed with the wine\r\nwhich he had drank, \xe2\x80\x9chaving done justice to our Saxon guests, we will\r\npray of them some requital to our courtesy.\xe2\x80\x94Worthy Thane,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\ncontinued, addressing Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cmay we pray you to name to us some\r\nNorman whose mention may least sully your mouth, and to wash down with\r\na goblet of wine all bitterness which the sound may leave behind it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFitzurse arose while Prince John spoke, and gliding behind the seat of\r\nthe Saxon, whispered to him not to omit the opportunity of putting an\r\nend to unkindness betwixt the two races, by naming Prince John. The\r\nSaxon replied not to this politic insinuation, but, rising up, and\r\nfilling his cup to the brim, he addressed Prince John in these words:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour highness has required that I should name a Norman deserving to be\r\nremembered at our banquet. This, perchance, is a hard task, since it\r\ncalls on the slave to sing the praises of the master\xe2\x80\x94upon the\r\nvanquished, while pressed by all the evils of conquest, to sing the\r\npraises of the conqueror. Yet I will name a Norman\xe2\x80\x94the first in arms\r\nand in place\xe2\x80\x94the best and the noblest of his race. And the lips that\r\nshall refuse to pledge me to his well-earned fame, I term false and\r\ndishonoured, and will so maintain them with my life.\xe2\x80\x94I quaff this\r\ngoblet to the health of Richard the Lion-hearted!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPrince John, who had expected that his own name would have closed the\r\nSaxon\xe2\x80\x99s speech, started when that of his injured brother was so\r\nunexpectedly introduced. He raised mechanically the wine-cup to his\r\nlips, then instantly set it down, to view the demeanour of the company\r\nat this unexpected proposal, which many of them felt it as unsafe to\r\noppose as to comply with. Some of them, ancient and experienced\r\ncourtiers, closely imitated the example of the Prince himself, raising\r\nthe goblet to their lips, and again replacing it before them. There\r\nwere many who, with a more generous feeling, exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cLong live King\r\nRichard! and may he be speedily restored to us!\xe2\x80\x9d And some few, among\r\nwhom were Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and the Templar, in sullen disdain suffered\r\ntheir goblets to stand untasted before them. But no man ventured\r\ndirectly to gainsay a pledge filled to the health of the reigning\r\nmonarch.\r\n\r\nHaving enjoyed his triumph for about a minute, Cedric said to his\r\ncompanion, \xe2\x80\x9cUp, noble Athelstane! we have remained here long enough,\r\nsince we have requited the hospitable courtesy of Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbanquet. Those who wish to know further of our rude Saxon manners must\r\nhenceforth seek us in the homes of our fathers, since we have seen\r\nenough of royal banquets, and enough of Norman courtesy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he arose and left the banqueting room, followed by\r\nAthelstane, and by several other guests, who, partaking of the Saxon\r\nlineage, held themselves insulted by the sarcasms of Prince John and\r\nhis courtiers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the bones of St Thomas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, as they retreated, \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nSaxon churls have borne off the best of the day, and have retreated\r\nwith triumph!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Conclamatum est, poculatum est\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prior Aymer; \xe2\x80\x9cwe have drunk\r\nand we have shouted,\xe2\x80\x94it were time we left our wine flagons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe monk hath some fair penitent to shrive to-night, that he is in\r\nsuch a hurry to depart,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Abbot; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I must move several miles\r\nforward this evening upon my homeward journey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are breaking up,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prince in a whisper to Fitzurse;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctheir fears anticipate the event, and this coward Prior is the first\r\nto shrink from me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear not, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar; \xe2\x80\x9cI will show him such reasons as\r\nshall induce him to join us when we hold our meeting at York.\xe2\x80\x94Sir\r\nPrior,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI must speak with you in private, before you mount\r\nyour palfrey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe other guests were now fast dispersing, with the exception of those\r\nimmediately attached to Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s faction, and his retinue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis, then, is the result of your advice,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prince, turning an\r\nangry countenance upon Fitzurse; \xe2\x80\x9cthat I should be bearded at my own\r\nboard by a drunken Saxon churl, and that, on the mere sound of my\r\nbrother\xe2\x80\x99s name, men should fall off from me as if I had the leprosy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave patience, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied his counsellor; \xe2\x80\x9cI might retort your\r\naccusation, and blame the inconsiderate levity which foiled my design,\r\nand misled your own better judgment. But this is no time for\r\nrecrimination. De Bracy and I will instantly go among these shuffling\r\ncowards, and convince them they have gone too far to recede.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be in vain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, pacing the apartment with\r\ndisordered steps, and expressing himself with an agitation to which the\r\nwine he had drank partly contributed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be in vain\xe2\x80\x94they have seen\r\nthe handwriting on the wall\xe2\x80\x94they have marked the paw of the lion in the\r\nsand\xe2\x80\x94they have heard his approaching roar shake the wood\xe2\x80\x94nothing will\r\nreanimate their courage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould to God,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse to De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cthat aught could reanimate\r\nhis own! His brother\xe2\x80\x99s very name is an ague to him. Unhappy are the\r\ncounsellors of a Prince, who wants fortitude and perseverance alike in\r\ngood and in evil!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XV\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd yet he thinks,\xe2\x80\x94ha, ha, ha, ha,\xe2\x80\x94he thinks\r\nI am the tool and servant of his will.\r\nWell, let it be; through all the maze of trouble\r\nHis plots and base oppression must create,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll shape myself a way to higher things,\r\nAnd who will say \xe2\x80\x99tis wrong?\r\n\r\n\r\nBASIL, A TRAGEDY\r\n\r\n\r\nNo spider ever took more pains to repair the shattered meshes of his\r\nweb, than did Waldemar Fitzurse to reunite and combine the scattered\r\nmembers of Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s cabal. Few of these were attached to him from\r\ninclination, and none from personal regard. It was therefore necessary,\r\nthat Fitzurse should open to them new prospects of advantage, and\r\nremind them of those which they at present enjoyed. To the young and\r\nwild nobles, he held out the prospect of unpunished license and\r\nuncontrolled revelry; to the ambitious, that of power, and to the\r\ncovetous, that of increased wealth and extended domains. The leaders of\r\nthe mercenaries received a donation in gold; an argument the most\r\npersuasive to their minds, and without which all others would have\r\nproved in vain. Promises were still more liberally distributed than\r\nmoney by this active agent; and, in fine, nothing was left undone that\r\ncould determine the wavering, or animate the disheartened. The return\r\nof King Richard he spoke of as an event altogether beyond the reach of\r\nprobability; yet, when he observed, from the doubtful looks and\r\nuncertain answers which he received, that this was the apprehension by\r\nwhich the minds of his accomplices were most haunted, he boldly treated\r\nthat event, should it really take place, as one which ought not to\r\nalter their political calculations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Richard returns,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9che returns to enrich his needy\r\nand impoverished crusaders at the expense of those who did not follow\r\nhim to the Holy Land. He returns to call to a fearful reckoning, those\r\nwho, during his absence, have done aught that can be construed offence\r\nor encroachment upon either the laws of the land or the privileges of\r\nthe crown. He returns to avenge upon the Orders of the Temple and the\r\nHospital, the preference which they showed to Philip of France during\r\nthe wars in the Holy Land. He returns, in fine, to punish as a rebel\r\nevery adherent of his brother Prince John. Are ye afraid of his power?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued the artful confident of that Prince, \xe2\x80\x9cwe acknowledge him a\r\nstrong and valiant knight; but these are not the days of King Arthur,\r\nwhen a champion could encounter an army. If Richard indeed comes back,\r\nit must be alone,\xe2\x80\x94unfollowed\xe2\x80\x94unfriended. The bones of his gallant army\r\nhave whitened the sands of Palestine. The few of his followers who have\r\nreturned have straggled hither like this Wilfred of Ivanhoe, beggared\r\nand broken men.\xe2\x80\x94And what talk ye of Richard\xe2\x80\x99s right of birth?\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nproceeded, in answer to those who objected scruples on that head. \xe2\x80\x9cIs\r\nRichard\xe2\x80\x99s title of primogeniture more decidedly certain than that of\r\nDuke Robert of Normandy, the Conqueror\xe2\x80\x99s eldest son? And yet William\r\nthe Red, and Henry, his second and third brothers, were successively\r\npreferred to him by the voice of the nation, Robert had every merit\r\nwhich can be pleaded for Richard; he was a bold knight, a good leader,\r\ngenerous to his friends and to the church, and, to crown the whole, a\r\ncrusader and a conqueror of the Holy Sepulchre; and yet he died a blind\r\nand miserable prisoner in the Castle of Cardiff, because he opposed\r\nhimself to the will of the people, who chose that he should not rule\r\nover them. It is our right,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cto choose from the blood royal\r\nthe prince who is best qualified to hold the supreme power\xe2\x80\x94that is,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid he, correcting himself, \xe2\x80\x9chim whose election will best promote the\r\ninterests of the nobility. In personal qualifications,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nwas possible that Prince John might be inferior to his brother Richard;\r\nbut when it was considered that the latter returned with the sword of\r\nvengeance in his hand, while the former held out rewards, immunities,\r\nprivileges, wealth, and honours, it could not be doubted which was the\r\nking whom in wisdom the nobility were called on to support.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese, and many more arguments, some adapted to the peculiar\r\ncircumstances of those whom he addressed, had the expected weight with\r\nthe nobles of Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s faction. Most of them consented to attend\r\nthe proposed meeting at York, for the purpose of making general\r\narrangements for placing the crown upon the head of Prince John.\r\n\r\nIt was late at night, when, worn out and exhausted with his various\r\nexertions, however gratified with the result, Fitzurse, returning to\r\nthe Castle of Ashby, met with De Bracy, who had exchanged his\r\nbanqueting garments for a short green kirtle, with hose of the same\r\ncloth and colour, a leathern cap or head-piece, a short sword, a horn\r\nslung over his shoulder, a long bow in his hand, and a bundle of arrows\r\nstuck in his belt. Had Fitzurse met this figure in an outer apartment,\r\nhe would have passed him without notice, as one of the yeomen of the\r\nguard; but finding him in the inner hall, he looked at him with more\r\nattention, and recognised the Norman knight in the dress of an English\r\nyeoman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat mummery is this, De Bracy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, somewhat angrily; \xe2\x80\x9cis\r\nthis a time for Christmas gambols and quaint maskings, when the fate of\r\nour master, Prince John, is on the very verge of decision? Why hast\r\nthou not been, like me, among these heartless cravens, whom the very\r\nname of King Richard terrifies, as it is said to do the children of the\r\nSaracens?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been attending to mine own business,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy calmly,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cas you, Fitzurse, have been minding yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI minding mine own business!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Waldemar; \xe2\x80\x9cI have been engaged in\r\nthat of Prince John, our joint patron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs if thou hadst any other reason for that, Waldemar,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthan the promotion of thine own individual interest? Come, Fitzurse,\r\nwe know each other\xe2\x80\x94ambition is thy pursuit, pleasure is mine, and they\r\nbecome our different ages. Of Prince John thou thinkest as I do; that\r\nhe is too weak to be a determined monarch, too tyrannical to be an easy\r\nmonarch, too insolent and presumptuous to be a popular monarch, and too\r\nfickle and timid to be long a monarch of any kind. But he is a monarch\r\nby whom Fitzurse and De Bracy hope to rise and thrive; and therefore\r\nyou aid him with your policy, and I with the lances of my Free\r\nCompanions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hopeful auxiliary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse impatiently; \xe2\x80\x9cplaying the fool in\r\nthe very moment of utter necessity.\xe2\x80\x94What on earth dost thou purpose by\r\nthis absurd disguise at a moment so urgent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo get me a wife,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy coolly, \xe2\x80\x9cafter the manner of the\r\ntribe of Benjamin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe tribe of Benjamin?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse; \xe2\x80\x9cI comprehend thee not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWert thou not in presence yester-even,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen we heard\r\nthe Prior Aymer tell us a tale in reply to the romance which was sung\r\nby the Minstrel?\xe2\x80\x94He told how, long since in Palestine, a deadly feud\r\narose between the tribe of Benjamin and the rest of the Israelitish\r\nnation; and how they cut to pieces well-nigh all the chivalry of that\r\ntribe; and how they swore by our blessed Lady, that they would not\r\npermit those who remained to marry in their lineage; and how they\r\nbecame grieved for their vow, and sent to consult his holiness the Pope\r\nhow they might be absolved from it; and how, by the advice of the Holy\r\nFather, the youth of the tribe of Benjamin carried off from a superb\r\ntournament all the ladies who were there present, and thus won them\r\nwives without the consent either of their brides or their brides\xe2\x80\x99\r\nfamilies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard the story,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cthough either the Prior or\r\nthou has made some singular alterations in date and circumstances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell thee,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I mean to purvey me a wife after\r\nthe fashion of the tribe of Benjamin; which is as much as to say, that\r\nin this same equipment I will fall upon that herd of Saxon bullocks,\r\nwho have this night left the castle, and carry off from them the lovely\r\nRowena.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou mad, De Bracy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse. \xe2\x80\x9cBethink thee that, though the\r\nmen be Saxons, they are rich and powerful, and regarded with the more\r\nrespect by their countrymen, that wealth and honour are but the lot of\r\nfew of Saxon descent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd should belong to none,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cthe work of the Conquest\r\nshould be completed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is no time for it at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse \xe2\x80\x9cthe approaching\r\ncrisis renders the favour of the multitude indispensable, and Prince\r\nJohn cannot refuse justice to any one who injures their favourites.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him grant it, if he dare,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9che will soon see the\r\ndifference betwixt the support of such a lusty lot of spears as mine,\r\nand that of a heartless mob of Saxon churls. Yet I mean no immediate\r\ndiscovery of myself. Seem I not in this garb as bold a forester as ever\r\nblew horn? The blame of the violence shall rest with the outlaws of the\r\nYorkshire forests. I have sure spies on the Saxon\xe2\x80\x99s motions\xe2\x80\x94To-night\r\nthey sleep in the convent of Saint Wittol, or Withold, or whatever they\r\ncall that churl of a Saxon Saint at Burton-on-Trent. Next day\xe2\x80\x99s march\r\nbrings them within our reach, and, falcon-ways, we swoop on them at\r\nonce. Presently after I will appear in mine own shape, play the\r\ncourteous knight, rescue the unfortunate and afflicted fair one from\r\nthe hands of the rude ravishers, conduct her to Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s Castle,\r\nor to Normandy, if it should be necessary, and produce her not again to\r\nher kindred until she be the bride and dame of Maurice de Bracy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA marvellously sage plan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cand, as I think, not\r\nentirely of thine own device.\xe2\x80\x94Come, be frank, De Bracy, who aided thee\r\nin the invention? and who is to assist in the execution? for, as I\r\nthink, thine own band lies as far off as York.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarry, if thou must needs know,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cit was the Templar\r\nBrian de Bois-Guilbert that shaped out the enterprise, which the\r\nadventure of the men of Benjamin suggested to me. He is to aid me in\r\nthe onslaught, and he and his followers will personate the outlaws,\r\nfrom whom my valorous arm is, after changing my garb, to rescue the\r\nlady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my halidome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cthe plan was worthy of your united\r\nwisdom! and thy prudence, De Bracy, is most especially manifested in\r\nthe project of leaving the lady in the hands of thy worthy confederate.\r\nThou mayst, I think, succeed in taking her from her Saxon friends, but\r\nhow thou wilt rescue her afterwards from the clutches of Bois-Guilbert\r\nseems considerably more doubtful\xe2\x80\x94He is a falcon well accustomed to\r\npounce on a partridge, and to hold his prey fast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a Templar,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cand cannot therefore rival me in my\r\nplan of wedding this heiress;\xe2\x80\x94and to attempt aught dishonourable\r\nagainst the intended bride of De Bracy\xe2\x80\x94By Heaven! were he a whole\r\nChapter of his Order in his single person, he dared not do me such an\r\ninjury!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen since nought that I can say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cwill put this folly\r\nfrom thy imagination, (for well I know the obstinacy of thy\r\ndisposition,) at least waste as little time as possible\xe2\x80\x94let not thy\r\nfolly be lasting as well as untimely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell thee,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it will be the work of a few\r\nhours, and I shall be at York\xe2\x80\x94at the head of my daring and valorous\r\nfellows, as ready to support any bold design as thy policy can be to\r\nform one.\xe2\x80\x94But I hear my comrades assembling, and the steeds stamping\r\nand neighing in the outer court.\xe2\x80\x94Farewell.\xe2\x80\x94I go, like a true knight, to\r\nwin the smiles of beauty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike a true knight?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Fitzurse, looking after him; \xe2\x80\x9clike a\r\nfool, I should say, or like a child, who will leave the most serious\r\nand needful occupation, to chase the down of the thistle that drives\r\npast him.\xe2\x80\x94But it is with such tools that I must work;\xe2\x80\x94and for whose\r\nadvantage?\xe2\x80\x94For that of a Prince as unwise as he is profligate, and as\r\nlikely to be an ungrateful master as he has already proved a rebellious\r\nson and an unnatural brother.\xe2\x80\x94But he\xe2\x80\x94he, too, is but one of the tools\r\nwith which I labour; and, proud as he is, should he presume to separate\r\nhis interest from mine, this is a secret which he shall soon learn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe meditations of the statesman were here interrupted by the voice of\r\nthe Prince from an interior apartment, calling out, \xe2\x80\x9cNoble Waldemar\r\nFitzurse!\xe2\x80\x9d and, with bonnet doffed, the future Chancellor (for to such\r\nhigh preferment did the wily Norman aspire) hastened to receive the\r\norders of the future sovereign.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVI\r\n\r\n\r\nFar in a wild, unknown to public view,\r\nFrom youth to age a reverend hermit grew;\r\nThe moss his bed, the cave his humble cell,\r\nHis food the fruits, his drink the crystal well\r\nRemote from man, with God he pass\xe2\x80\x99d his days,\r\nPrayer all his business\xe2\x80\x94all his pleasure praise.\r\n\r\n\r\nPARNELL\r\n\r\n\r\nThe reader cannot have forgotten that the event of the tournament was\r\ndecided by the exertions of an unknown knight, whom, on account of the\r\npassive and indifferent conduct which he had manifested on the former\r\npart of the day, the spectators had entitled, \xe2\x80\x9cLe Noir Faineant\xe2\x80\x9d. This\r\nknight had left the field abruptly when the victory was achieved; and\r\nwhen he was called upon to receive the reward of his valour, he was\r\nnowhere to be found. In the meantime, while summoned by heralds and by\r\ntrumpets, the knight was holding his course northward, avoiding all\r\nfrequented paths, and taking the shortest road through the woodlands.\r\nHe paused for the night at a small hostelry lying out of the ordinary\r\nroute, where, however, he obtained from a wandering minstrel news of\r\nthe event of the tourney.\r\n\r\nOn the next morning the knight departed early, with the intention of\r\nmaking a long journey; the condition of his horse, which he had\r\ncarefully spared during the preceding morning, being such as enabled\r\nhim to travel far without the necessity of much repose. Yet his purpose\r\nwas baffled by the devious paths through which he rode, so that when\r\nevening closed upon him, he only found himself on the frontiers of the\r\nWest Riding of Yorkshire. By this time both horse and man required\r\nrefreshment, and it became necessary, moreover, to look out for some\r\nplace in which they might spend the night, which was now fast\r\napproaching.\r\n\r\nThe place where the traveller found himself seemed unpropitious for\r\nobtaining either shelter or refreshment, and he was likely to be\r\nreduced to the usual expedient of knights-errant, who, on such\r\noccasions, turned their horses to graze, and laid themselves down to\r\nmeditate on their lady-mistress, with an oak-tree for a canopy. But the\r\nBlack Knight either had no mistress to meditate upon, or, being as\r\nindifferent in love as he seemed to be in war, was not sufficiently\r\noccupied by passionate reflections upon her beauty and cruelty, to be\r\nable to parry the effects of fatigue and hunger, and suffer love to act\r\nas a substitute for the solid comforts of a bed and supper. He felt\r\ndissatisfied, therefore, when, looking around, he found himself deeply\r\ninvolved in woods, through which indeed there were many open glades,\r\nand some paths, but such as seemed only formed by the numerous herds of\r\ncattle which grazed in the forest, or by the animals of chase, and the\r\nhunters who made prey of them.\r\n\r\nThe sun, by which the knight had chiefly directed his course, had now\r\nsunk behind the Derbyshire hills on his left, and every effort which he\r\nmight make to pursue his journey was as likely to lead him out of his\r\nroad as to advance him on his route. After having in vain endeavoured\r\nto select the most beaten path, in hopes it might lead to the cottage\r\nof some herdsman, or the silvan lodge of a forester, and having\r\nrepeatedly found himself totally unable to determine on a choice, the\r\nknight resolved to trust to the sagacity of his horse; experience\r\nhaving, on former occasions, made him acquainted with the wonderful\r\ntalent possessed by these animals for extricating themselves and their\r\nriders on such emergencies.\r\n\r\nThe good steed, grievously fatigued with so long a day\xe2\x80\x99s journey under\r\na rider cased in mail, had no sooner found, by the slackened reins,\r\nthat he was abandoned to his own guidance, than he seemed to assume new\r\nstrength and spirit; and whereas, formerly he had scarce replied to the\r\nspur, otherwise than by a groan, he now, as if proud of the confidence\r\nreposed in him, pricked up his ears, and assumed, of his own accord, a\r\nmore lively motion. The path which the animal adopted rather turned off\r\nfrom the course pursued by the knight during the day; but as the horse\r\nseemed confident in his choice, the rider abandoned himself to his\r\ndiscretion.\r\n\r\nHe was justified by the event; for the footpath soon after appeared a\r\nlittle wider and more worn, and the tinkle of a small bell gave the\r\nknight to understand that he was in the vicinity of some chapel or\r\nhermitage.\r\n\r\nAccordingly, he soon reached an open plat of turf, on the opposite side\r\nof which, a rock, rising abruptly from a gently sloping plain, offered\r\nits grey and weatherbeaten front to the traveller. Ivy mantled its\r\nsides in some places, and in others oaks and holly bushes, whose roots\r\nfound nourishment in the cliffs of the crag, waved over the precipices\r\nbelow, like the plumage of the warrior over his steel helmet, giving\r\ngrace to that whose chief expression was terror. At the bottom of the\r\nrock, and leaning, as it were, against it, was constructed a rude hut,\r\nbuilt chiefly of the trunks of trees felled in the neighbouring forest,\r\nand secured against the weather by having its crevices stuffed with\r\nmoss mingled with clay. The stem of a young fir-tree lopped of its\r\nbranches, with a piece of wood tied across near the top, was planted\r\nupright by the door, as a rude emblem of the holy cross. At a little\r\ndistance on the right hand, a fountain of the purest water trickled out\r\nof the rock, and was received in a hollow stone, which labour had\r\nformed into a rustic basin. Escaping from thence, the stream murmured\r\ndown the descent by a channel which its course had long worn, and so\r\nwandered through the little plain to lose itself in the neighbouring\r\nwood.\r\n\r\nBeside this fountain were the ruins of a very small chapel, of which\r\nthe roof had partly fallen in. The building, when entire, had never\r\nbeen above sixteen feet long by twelve feet in breadth, and the roof,\r\nlow in proportion, rested upon four concentric arches which sprung from\r\nthe four corners of the building, each supported upon a short and heavy\r\npillar. The ribs of two of these arches remained, though the roof had\r\nfallen down betwixt them; over the others it remained entire. The\r\nentrance to this ancient place of devotion was under a very low round\r\narch, ornamented by several courses of that zig-zag moulding,\r\nresembling shark\xe2\x80\x99s teeth, which appears so often in the more ancient\r\nSaxon architecture. A belfry rose above the porch on four small\r\npillars, within which hung the green and weatherbeaten bell, the feeble\r\nsounds of which had been some time before heard by the Black Knight.\r\n\r\nThe whole peaceful and quiet scene lay glimmering in twilight before\r\nthe eyes of the traveller, giving him good assurance of lodging for the\r\nnight; since it was a special duty of those hermits who dwelt in the\r\nwoods, to exercise hospitality towards benighted or bewildered\r\npassengers.\r\n\r\nAccordingly, the knight took no time to consider minutely the\r\nparticulars which we have detailed, but thanking Saint Julian (the\r\npatron of travellers) who had sent him good harbourage, he leaped from\r\nhis horse and assailed the door of the hermitage with the butt of his\r\nlance, in order to arouse attention and gain admittance.\r\n\r\nIt was some time before he obtained any answer, and the reply, when\r\nmade, was unpropitious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPass on, whosoever thou art,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer given by a deep hoarse\r\nvoice from within the hut, \xe2\x80\x9cand disturb not the servant of God and St\r\nDunstan in his evening devotions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWorthy father,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the knight, \xe2\x80\x9chere is a poor wanderer\r\nbewildered in these woods, who gives thee the opportunity of exercising\r\nthy charity and hospitality.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood brother,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the inhabitant of the hermitage, \xe2\x80\x9cit has\r\npleased Our Lady and St Dunstan to destine me for the object of those\r\nvirtues, instead of the exercise thereof. I have no provisions here\r\nwhich even a dog would share with me, and a horse of any tenderness of\r\nnurture would despise my couch\xe2\x80\x94pass therefore on thy way, and God speed\r\nthee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cis it possible for me to find my way\r\nthrough such a wood as this, when darkness is coming on? I pray you,\r\nreverend father as you are a Christian, to undo your door, and at least\r\npoint out to me my road.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I pray you, good Christian brother,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the anchorite, \xe2\x80\x9cto\r\ndisturb me no more. You have already interrupted one \xe2\x80\x98pater\xe2\x80\x99, two\r\n\xe2\x80\x98aves\xe2\x80\x99, and a \xe2\x80\x98credo\xe2\x80\x99, which I, miserable sinner that I am, should,\r\naccording to my vow, have said before moonrise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe road\xe2\x80\x94the road!\xe2\x80\x9d vociferated the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cgive me directions for\r\nthe road, if I am to expect no more from thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe road,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cis easy to hit. The path from the wood\r\nleads to a morass, and from thence to a ford, which, as the rains have\r\nabated, may now be passable. When thou hast crossed the ford, thou wilt\r\ntake care of thy footing up the left bank, as it is somewhat\r\nprecipitous; and the path, which hangs over the river, has lately, as I\r\nlearn, (for I seldom leave the duties of my chapel,) given way in\r\nsundry places. Thou wilt then keep straight forward\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA broken path\xe2\x80\x94a precipice\xe2\x80\x94a ford, and a morass!\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight\r\ninterrupting him,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSir Hermit, if you were the holiest that ever wore\r\nbeard or told bead, you shall scarce prevail on me to hold this road\r\nto-night. I tell thee, that thou, who livest by the charity of the\r\ncountry\xe2\x80\x94ill deserved, as I doubt it is\xe2\x80\x94hast no right to refuse shelter\r\nto the wayfarer when in distress. Either open the door quickly, or, by\r\nthe rood, I will beat it down and make entry for myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend wayfarer,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cbe not importunate; if thou\r\nputtest me to use the carnal weapon in mine own defence, it will be\r\ne\xe2\x80\x99en the worse for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment a distant noise of barking and growling, which the\r\ntraveller had for some time heard, became extremely loud and furious,\r\nand made the knight suppose that the hermit, alarmed by his threat of\r\nmaking forcible entry, had called the dogs who made this clamour to aid\r\nhim in his defence, out of some inner recess in which they had been\r\nkennelled. Incensed at this preparation on the hermit\xe2\x80\x99s part for making\r\ngood his inhospitable purpose, the knight struck the door so furiously\r\nwith his foot, that posts as well as staples shook with violence.\r\n\r\nThe anchorite, not caring again to expose his door to a similar shock,\r\nnow called out aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cPatience, patience\xe2\x80\x94spare thy strength, good\r\ntraveller, and I will presently undo the door, though, it may be, my\r\ndoing so will be little to thy pleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe door accordingly was opened; and the hermit, a large, strong-built\r\nman, in his sackcloth gown and hood, girt with a rope of rushes, stood\r\nbefore the knight. He had in one hand a lighted torch, or link, and in\r\nthe other a baton of crab-tree, so thick and heavy, that it might well\r\nbe termed a club. Two large shaggy dogs, half greyhound half mastiff,\r\nstood ready to rush upon the traveller as soon as the door should be\r\nopened. But when the torch glanced upon the lofty crest and golden\r\nspurs of the knight, who stood without, the hermit, altering probably\r\nhis original intentions, repressed the rage of his auxiliaries, and,\r\nchanging his tone to a sort of churlish courtesy, invited the knight to\r\nenter his hut, making excuse for his unwillingness to open his lodge\r\nafter sunset, by alleging the multitude of robbers and outlaws who were\r\nabroad, and who gave no honour to Our Lady or St Dunstan, nor to those\r\nholy men who spent life in their service.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe poverty of your cell, good father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, looking\r\naround him, and seeing nothing but a bed of leaves, a crucifix rudely\r\ncarved in oak, a missal, with a rough-hewn table and two stools, and\r\none or two clumsy articles of furniture\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe poverty of your cell\r\nshould seem a sufficient defence against any risk of thieves, not to\r\nmention the aid of two trusty dogs, large and strong enough, I think,\r\nto pull down a stag, and of course, to match with most men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe good keeper of the forest,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9chath allowed me the\r\nuse of these animals, to protect my solitude until the times shall\r\nmend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving said this, he fixed his torch in a twisted branch of iron which\r\nserved for a candlestick; and, placing the oaken trivet before the\r\nembers of the fire, which he refreshed with some dry wood, he placed a\r\nstool upon one side of the table, and beckoned to the knight to do the\r\nsame upon the other.\r\n\r\nThey sat down, and gazed with great gravity at each other, each\r\nthinking in his heart that he had seldom seen a stronger or more\r\nathletic figure than was placed opposite to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReverend hermit,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, after looking long and fixedly at\r\nhis host, \xe2\x80\x9cwere it not to interrupt your devout meditations, I would\r\npray to know three things of your holiness; first, where I am to put my\r\nhorse?\xe2\x80\x94secondly, what I can have for supper?\xe2\x80\x94thirdly, where I am to\r\ntake up my couch for the night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will reply to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cwith my finger, it being\r\nagainst my rule to speak by words where signs can answer the purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSo saying, he pointed successively to two corners of the hut. \xe2\x80\x9cYour\r\nstable,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cis there\xe2\x80\x94your bed there; and,\xe2\x80\x9d reaching down a\r\nplatter with two handfuls of parched pease upon it from the\r\nneighbouring shelf, and placing it upon the table, he added, \xe2\x80\x9cyour\r\nsupper is here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe knight shrugged his shoulders, and leaving the hut, brought in his\r\nhorse, (which in the interim he had fastened to a tree,) unsaddled him\r\nwith much attention, and spread upon the steed\xe2\x80\x99s weary back his own\r\nmantle.\r\n\r\nThe hermit was apparently somewhat moved to compassion by the anxiety\r\nas well as address which the stranger displayed in tending his horse;\r\nfor, muttering something about provender left for the keeper\xe2\x80\x99s palfrey,\r\nhe dragged out of a recess a bundle of forage, which he spread before\r\nthe knight\xe2\x80\x99s charger, and immediately afterwards shook down a quantity\r\nof dried fern in the corner which he had assigned for the rider\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncouch. The knight returned him thanks for his courtesy; and, this duty\r\ndone, both resumed their seats by the table, whereon stood the trencher\r\nof pease placed between them. The hermit, after a long grace, which had\r\nonce been Latin, but of which original language few traces remained,\r\nexcepting here and there the long rolling termination of some word or\r\nphrase, set example to his guest, by modestly putting into a very large\r\nmouth, furnished with teeth which might have ranked with those of a\r\nboar both in sharpness and whiteness, some three or four dried pease, a\r\nmiserable grist as it seemed for so large and able a mill.\r\n\r\nThe knight, in order to follow so laudable an example, laid aside his\r\nhelmet, his corslet, and the greater part of his armour, and showed to\r\nthe hermit a head thick-curled with yellow hair, high features, blue\r\neyes, remarkably bright and sparkling, a mouth well formed, having an\r\nupper lip clothed with mustachoes darker than his hair, and bearing\r\naltogether the look of a bold, daring, and enterprising man, with which\r\nhis strong form well corresponded.\r\n\r\nThe hermit, as if wishing to answer to the confidence of his guest,\r\nthrew back his cowl, and showed a round bullet head belonging to a man\r\nin the prime of life. His close-shaven crown, surrounded by a circle of\r\nstiff curled black hair, had something the appearance of a parish\r\npinfold begirt by its high hedge. The features expressed nothing of\r\nmonastic austerity, or of ascetic privations; on the contrary, it was a\r\nbold bluff countenance, with broad black eyebrows, a well-turned\r\nforehead, and cheeks as round and vermilion as those of a trumpeter,\r\nfrom which descended a long and curly black beard. Such a visage,\r\njoined to the brawny form of the holy man, spoke rather of sirloins and\r\nhaunches, than of pease and pulse. This incongruity did not escape the\r\nguest. After he had with great difficulty accomplished the mastication\r\nof a mouthful of the dried pease, he found it absolutely necessary to\r\nrequest his pious entertainer to furnish him with some liquor; who\r\nreplied to his request by placing before him a large can of the purest\r\nwater from the fountain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is from the well of St Dunstan,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cin which, betwixt sun\r\nand sun, he baptized five hundred heathen Danes and Britons\xe2\x80\x94blessed be\r\nhis name!\xe2\x80\x9d And applying his black beard to the pitcher, he took a\r\ndraught much more moderate in quantity than his encomium seemed to\r\nwarrant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me, reverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the small\r\nmorsels which you eat, together with this holy, but somewhat thin\r\nbeverage, have thriven with you marvellously. You appear a man more fit\r\nto win the ram at a wrestling match, or the ring at a bout at\r\nquarter-staff, or the bucklers at a sword-play, than to linger out your\r\ntime in this desolate wilderness, saying masses, and living upon\r\nparched pease and cold water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cyour thoughts, like those of the\r\nignorant laity, are according to the flesh. It has pleased Our Lady and\r\nmy patron saint to bless the pittance to which I restrain myself, even\r\nas the pulse and water was blessed to the children Shadrach, Meshech,\r\nand Abednego, who drank the same rather than defile themselves with the\r\nwine and meats which were appointed them by the King of the Saracens.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cupon whose countenance it hath pleased\r\nHeaven to work such a miracle, permit a sinful layman to crave thy\r\nname?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou mayst call me,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Clerk of Copmanhurst,\r\nfor so I am termed in these parts\xe2\x80\x94They add, it is true, the epithet\r\nholy, but I stand not upon that, as being unworthy of such\r\naddition.\xe2\x80\x94And now, valiant knight, may I pray ye for the name of my\r\nhonourable guest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cHoly Clerk of Copmanhurst, men call me in\r\nthese parts the Black Knight,\xe2\x80\x94many, sir, add to it the epithet of\r\nSluggard, whereby I am no way ambitious to be distinguished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hermit could scarcely forbear from smiling at his guest\xe2\x80\x99s reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cSir Sluggish Knight, that thou art a man of prudence\r\nand of counsel; and moreover, I see that my poor monastic fare likes\r\nthee not, accustomed, perhaps, as thou hast been, to the license of\r\ncourts and of camps, and the luxuries of cities; and now I bethink me,\r\nSir Sluggard, that when the charitable keeper of this forest-walk left\r\nthose dogs for my protection, and also those bundles of forage, he left\r\nme also some food, which, being unfit for my use, the very recollection\r\nof it had escaped me amid my more weighty meditations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI dare be sworn he did so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight; \xe2\x80\x9cI was convinced that\r\nthere was better food in the cell, Holy Clerk, since you first doffed\r\nyour cowl.\xe2\x80\x94Your keeper is ever a jovial fellow; and none who beheld thy\r\ngrinders contending with these pease, and thy throat flooded with this\r\nungenial element, could see thee doomed to such horse-provender and\r\nhorse-beverage,\xe2\x80\x9d (pointing to the provisions upon the table,) \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nrefrain from mending thy cheer. Let us see the keeper\xe2\x80\x99s bounty,\r\ntherefore, without delay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hermit cast a wistful look upon the knight, in which there was a\r\nsort of comic expression of hesitation, as if uncertain how far he\r\nshould act prudently in trusting his guest. There was, however, as much\r\nof bold frankness in the knight\xe2\x80\x99s countenance as was possible to be\r\nexpressed by features. His smile, too, had something in it irresistibly\r\ncomic, and gave an assurance of faith and loyalty, with which his host\r\ncould not refrain from sympathizing.\r\n\r\nAfter exchanging a mute glance or two, the hermit went to the further\r\nside of the hut, and opened a hutch, which was concealed with great\r\ncare and some ingenuity. Out of the recesses of a dark closet, into\r\nwhich this aperture gave admittance, he brought a large pasty, baked in\r\na pewter platter of unusual dimensions. This mighty dish he placed\r\nbefore his guest, who, using his poniard to cut it open, lost no time\r\nin making himself acquainted with its contents.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long is it since the good keeper has been here?\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight\r\nto his host, after having swallowed several hasty morsels of this\r\nreinforcement to the hermit\xe2\x80\x99s good cheer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout two months,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the father hastily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the true Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cevery thing in your hermitage\r\nis miraculous, Holy Clerk! for I would have been sworn that the fat\r\nbuck which furnished this venison had been running on foot within the\r\nweek.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hermit was somewhat discountenanced by this observation; and,\r\nmoreover, he made but a poor figure while gazing on the diminution of\r\nthe pasty, on which his guest was making desperate inroads; a warfare\r\nin which his previous profession of abstinence left him no pretext for\r\njoining.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been in Palestine, Sir Clerk,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, stopping short\r\nof a sudden, \xe2\x80\x9cand I bethink me it is a custom there that every host who\r\nentertains a guest shall assure him of the wholesomeness of his food,\r\nby partaking of it along with him. Far be it from me to suspect so holy\r\na man of aught inhospitable; nevertheless I will be highly bound to you\r\nwould you comply with this Eastern custom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo ease your unnecessary scruples, Sir Knight, I will for once depart\r\nfrom my rule,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the hermit. And as there were no forks in those\r\ndays, his clutches were instantly in the bowels of the pasty.\r\n\r\nThe ice of ceremony being once broken, it seemed matter of rivalry\r\nbetween the guest and the entertainer which should display the best\r\nappetite; and although the former had probably fasted longest, yet the\r\nhermit fairly surpassed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly Clerk,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, when his hunger was appeased, \xe2\x80\x9cI would\r\ngage my good horse yonder against a zecchin, that that same honest\r\nkeeper to whom we are obliged for the venison has left thee a stoup of\r\nwine, or a runlet of canary, or some such trifle, by way of ally to\r\nthis noble pasty. This would be a circumstance, doubtless, totally\r\nunworthy to dwell in the memory of so rigid an anchorite; yet, I think,\r\nwere you to search yonder crypt once more, you would find that I am\r\nright in my conjecture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hermit only replied by a grin; and returning to the hutch, he\r\nproduced a leathern bottle, which might contain about four quarts. He\r\nalso brought forth two large drinking cups, made out of the horn of the\r\nurus, and hooped with silver. Having made this goodly provision for\r\nwashing down the supper, he seemed to think no farther ceremonious\r\nscruple necessary on his part; but filling both cups, and saying, in\r\nthe Saxon fashion, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Waes hael\xe2\x80\x99, Sir Sluggish Knight!\xe2\x80\x9d he emptied his\r\nown at a draught.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Drink hael\xe2\x80\x99, Holy Clerk of Copmanhurst!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the warrior, and\r\ndid his host reason in a similar brimmer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly Clerk,\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger, after the first cup was thus\r\nswallowed, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot but marvel that a man possessed of such thews and\r\nsinews as thine, and who therewithal shows the talent of so goodly a\r\ntrencher-man, should think of abiding by himself in this wilderness. In\r\nmy judgment, you are fitter to keep a castle or a fort, eating of the\r\nfat and drinking of the strong, than to live here upon pulse and water,\r\nor even upon the charity of the keeper. At least, were I as thou, I\r\nshould find myself both disport and plenty out of the king\xe2\x80\x99s deer.\r\nThere is many a goodly herd in these forests, and a buck will never be\r\nmissed that goes to the use of Saint Dunstan\xe2\x80\x99s chaplain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Sluggish Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Clerk, \xe2\x80\x9cthese are dangerous words,\r\nand I pray you to forbear them. I am true hermit to the king and law,\r\nand were I to spoil my liege\xe2\x80\x99s game, I should be sure of the prison,\r\nand, an my gown saved me not, were in some peril of hanging.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless, were I as thou,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cI would take my walk\r\nby moonlight, when foresters and keepers were warm in bed, and ever and\r\nanon,\xe2\x80\x94as I pattered my prayers,\xe2\x80\x94I would let fly a shaft among the herds\r\nof dun deer that feed in the glades\xe2\x80\x94Resolve me, Holy Clerk, hast thou\r\nnever practised such a pastime?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend Sluggard,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast seen all that can\r\nconcern thee of my housekeeping, and something more than he deserves\r\nwho takes up his quarters by violence. Credit me, it is better to enjoy\r\nthe good which God sends thee, than to be impertinently curious how it\r\ncomes. Fill thy cup, and welcome; and do not, I pray thee, by further\r\nimpertinent enquiries, put me to show that thou couldst hardly have\r\nmade good thy lodging had I been earnest to oppose thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthou makest me more curious than ever!\r\nThou art the most mysterious hermit I ever met; and I will know more of\r\nthee ere we part. As for thy threats, know, holy man, thou speakest to\r\none whose trade it is to find out danger wherever it is to be met\r\nwith.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Sluggish Knight, I drink to thee,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit; \xe2\x80\x9crespecting\r\nthy valour much, but deeming wondrous slightly of thy discretion. If\r\nthou wilt take equal arms with me, I will give thee, in all friendship\r\nand brotherly love, such sufficing penance and complete absolution,\r\nthat thou shalt not for the next twelve months sin the sin of excess of\r\ncuriosity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe knight pledged him, and desired him to name his weapons.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is none,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom the scissors of Delilah, and\r\nthe tenpenny nail of Jael, to the scimitar of Goliath, at which I am\r\nnot a match for thee\xe2\x80\x94But, if I am to make the election, what sayst\r\nthou, good friend, to these trinkets?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus speaking, he opened another hutch, and took out from it a couple\r\nof broadswords and bucklers, such as were used by the yeomanry of the\r\nperiod. The knight, who watched his motions, observed that this second\r\nplace of concealment was furnished with two or three good long-bows, a\r\ncross-bow, a bundle of bolts for the latter, and half-a-dozen sheaves\r\nof arrows for the former. A harp, and other matters of a very\r\nuncanonical appearance, were also visible when this dark recess was\r\nopened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise thee, brother Clerk,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI will ask thee no more\r\noffensive questions. The contents of that cupboard are an answer to all\r\nmy enquiries; and I see a weapon there\xe2\x80\x9d (here he stooped and took out\r\nthe harp) \xe2\x80\x9con which I would more gladly prove my skill with thee, than\r\nat the sword and buckler.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast given no good reason\r\nfor thy surname of the Sluggard. I do promise thee I suspect thee\r\ngrievously. Nevertheless, thou art my guest, and I will not put thy\r\nmanhood to the proof without thine own free will. Sit thee down, then,\r\nand fill thy cup; let us drink, sing, and be merry. If thou knowest\r\never a good lay, thou shalt be welcome to a nook of pasty at\r\nCopmanhurst so long as I serve the chapel of St Dunstan, which, please\r\nGod, shall be till I change my grey covering for one of green turf. But\r\ncome, fill a flagon, for it will crave some time to tune the harp; and\r\nnought pitches the voice and sharpens the ear like a cup of wine. For\r\nmy part, I love to feel the grape at my very finger-ends before they\r\nmake the harp-strings tinkle.\xe2\x80\x9d 22\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVII\r\n\r\n\r\nAt eve, within yon studious nook,\r\nI ope my brass-embossed book,\r\nPortray\xe2\x80\x99d with many a holy deed\r\nOf martyrs crown\xe2\x80\x99d with heavenly meed;\r\nThen, as my taper waxes dim,\r\nChant, ere I sleep, my measured hymn.\r\n\r\nWho but would cast his pomp away,\r\nTo take my staff and amice grey,\r\nAnd to the world\xe2\x80\x99s tumultuous stage,\r\nPrefer the peaceful Hermitage?\r\n\r\n\r\nWARTON\r\n\r\n\r\nNotwithstanding the prescription of the genial hermit, with which his\r\nguest willingly complied, he found it no easy matter to bring the harp\r\nto harmony.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMethinks, holy father,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe instrument wants one string, and\r\nthe rest have been somewhat misused.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, mark\xe2\x80\x99st thou that?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the hermit; \xe2\x80\x9cthat shows thee a master\r\nof the craft. Wine and wassail,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, gravely casting up his\r\neyes\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9call the fault of wine and wassail!\xe2\x80\x94I told Allan-a-Dale, the\r\nnorthern minstrel, that he would damage the harp if he touched it after\r\nthe seventh cup, but he would not be controlled\xe2\x80\x94Friend, I drink to thy\r\nsuccessful performance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he took off his cup with much gravity, at the same time\r\nshaking his head at the intemperance of the Scottish harper.\r\n\r\nThe knight in the meantime, had brought the strings into some order,\r\nand after a short prelude, asked his host whether he would choose a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csirvente\xe2\x80\x9d in the language of \xe2\x80\x9coc\xe2\x80\x9d, or a \xe2\x80\x9clai\xe2\x80\x9d in the language of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9coui\xe2\x80\x9d, or a \xe2\x80\x9cvirelai\xe2\x80\x9d, or a ballad in the vulgar English. 23\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA ballad, a ballad,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cagainst all the \xe2\x80\x98ocs\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\n\xe2\x80\x98ouis\xe2\x80\x99 of France. Downright English am I, Sir Knight, and downright\r\nEnglish was my patron St Dunstan, and scorned \xe2\x80\x98oc\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98oui\xe2\x80\x99, as he\r\nwould have scorned the parings of the devil\xe2\x80\x99s hoof\xe2\x80\x94downright English\r\nalone shall be sung in this cell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will assay, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9ca ballad composed by a Saxon\r\nglee-man, whom I knew in Holy Land.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt speedily appeared, that if the knight was not a complete master of\r\nthe minstrel art, his taste for it had at least been cultivated under\r\nthe best instructors. Art had taught him to soften the faults of a\r\nvoice which had little compass, and was naturally rough rather than\r\nmellow, and, in short, had done all that culture can do in supplying\r\nnatural deficiencies. His performance, therefore, might have been\r\ntermed very respectable by abler judges than the hermit, especially as\r\nthe knight threw into the notes now a degree of spirit, and now of\r\nplaintive enthusiasm, which gave force and energy to the verses which\r\nhe sung.\r\n\r\nTHE CRUSADER\xe2\x80\x99S RETURN.\r\n\r\n1.\r\n\r\nHigh deeds achieved of knightly fame,\r\nFrom Palestine the champion came;\r\nThe cross upon his shoulders borne,\r\nBattle and blast had dimm\xe2\x80\x99d and torn.\r\nEach dint upon his batter\xe2\x80\x99d shield\r\nWas token of a foughten field;\r\nAnd thus, beneath his lady\xe2\x80\x99s bower,\r\nHe sung as fell the twilight hour:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n2.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJoy to the fair!\xe2\x80\x94thy knight behold,\r\nReturn\xe2\x80\x99d from yonder land of gold;\r\nNo wealth he brings, nor wealth can need,\r\nSave his good arms and battle-steed\r\nHis spurs, to dash against a foe,\r\nHis lance and sword to lay him low;\r\nSuch all the trophies of his toil,\r\nSuch\xe2\x80\x94and the hope of Tekla\xe2\x80\x99s smile!\r\n\r\n3.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJoy to the fair! whose constant knight\r\nHer favour fired to feats of might;\r\nUnnoted shall she not remain,\r\nWhere meet the bright and noble train;\r\nMinstrel shall sing and herald tell\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Mark yonder maid of beauty well,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Tis she for whose bright eyes were won\r\nThe listed field at Askalon!\r\n\r\n4.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Note well her smile!\xe2\x80\x94it edged the blade\r\nWhich fifty wives to widows made,\r\nWhen, vain his strength and Mahound\xe2\x80\x99s spell,\r\nIconium\xe2\x80\x99s turban\xe2\x80\x99d Soldan fell.\r\nSeest thou her locks, whose sunny glow\r\nHalf shows, half shades, her neck of snow?\r\nTwines not of them one golden thread,\r\nBut for its sake a Paynim bled.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n5.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJoy to the fair!\xe2\x80\x94my name unknown,\r\nEach deed, and all its praise thine own\r\nThen, oh! unbar this churlish gate,\r\nThe night dew falls, the hour is late.\r\nInured to Syria\xe2\x80\x99s glowing breath,\r\nI feel the north breeze chill as death;\r\nLet grateful love quell maiden shame,\r\nAnd grant him bliss who brings thee fame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring this performance, the hermit demeaned himself much like a\r\nfirst-rate critic of the present day at a new opera. He reclined back\r\nupon his seat, with his eyes half shut; now, folding his hands and\r\ntwisting his thumbs, he seemed absorbed in attention, and anon,\r\nbalancing his expanded palms, he gently flourished them in time to the\r\nmusic. At one or two favourite cadences, he threw in a little\r\nassistance of his own, where the knight\xe2\x80\x99s voice seemed unable to carry\r\nthe air so high as his worshipful taste approved. When the song was\r\nended, the anchorite emphatically declared it a good one, and well\r\nsung.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI think my Saxon countrymen had herded long enough\r\nwith the Normans, to fall into the tone of their melancholy ditties.\r\nWhat took the honest knight from home? or what could he expect but to\r\nfind his mistress agreeably engaged with a rival on his return, and his\r\nserenade, as they call it, as little regarded as the caterwauling of a\r\ncat in the gutter? Nevertheless, Sir Knight, I drink this cup to thee,\r\nto the success of all true lovers\xe2\x80\x94I fear you are none,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, on\r\nobserving that the knight (whose brain began to be heated with these\r\nrepeated draughts) qualified his flagon from the water pitcher.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you not tell me that this water was from\r\nthe well of your blessed patron, St Dunstan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, truly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cand many a hundred of pagans did he\r\nbaptize there, but I never heard that he drank any of it. Every thing\r\nshould be put to its proper use in this world. St Dunstan knew, as well\r\nas any one, the prerogatives of a jovial friar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd so saying, he reached the harp, and entertained his guest with the\r\nfollowing characteristic song, to a sort of derry-down chorus,\r\nappropriate to an old English ditty. 24\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nTHE BAREFOOTED FRIAR.\r\n\r\n1.\r\n\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll give thee, good fellow, a twelvemonth or twain,\r\nTo search Europe through, from Byzantium to Spain;\r\nBut ne\xe2\x80\x99er shall you find, should you search till you tire,\r\nSo happy a man as the Barefooted Friar.\r\n\r\n2.\r\n\r\nYour knight for his lady pricks forth in career,\r\nAnd is brought home at even-song prick\xe2\x80\x99d through with a spear;\r\nI confess him in haste\xe2\x80\x94for his lady desires\r\nNo comfort on earth save the Barefooted Friar\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n3.\r\n\r\nYour monarch?\xe2\x80\x94Pshaw! many a prince has been known\r\nTo barter his robes for our cowl and our gown,\r\nBut which of us e\xe2\x80\x99er felt the idle desire\r\nTo exchange for a crown the grey hood of a Friar!\r\n\r\n4.\r\n\r\nThe Friar has walk\xe2\x80\x99d out, and where\xe2\x80\x99er he has gone,\r\nThe land and its fatness is mark\xe2\x80\x99d for his own;\r\nHe can roam where he lists, he can stop when he tires,\r\nFor every man\xe2\x80\x99s house is the Barefooted Friar\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n5.\r\n\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99s expected at noon, and no wight till he comes\r\nMay profane the great chair, or the porridge of plums\r\nFor the best of the cheer, and the seat by the fire,\r\nIs the undenied right of the Barefooted Friar.\r\n\r\n6.\r\n\r\nHe\xe2\x80\x99s expected at night, and the pasty\xe2\x80\x99s made hot,\r\nThey broach the brown ale, and they fill the black pot,\r\nAnd the goodwife would wish the goodman in the mire,\r\nEre he lack\xe2\x80\x99d a soft pillow, the Barefooted Friar.\r\n\r\n7.\r\n\r\nLong flourish the sandal, the cord, and the cope,\r\nThe dread of the devil and trust of the Pope;\r\nFor to gather life\xe2\x80\x99s roses, unscathed by the briar,\r\nIs granted alone to the Barefooted Friar.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my troth,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast sung well and lustily, and\r\nin high praise of thine order. And, talking of the devil, Holy Clerk,\r\nare you not afraid that he may pay you a visit during some of your\r\nuncanonical pastimes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI uncanonical!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the hermit; \xe2\x80\x9cI scorn the charge\xe2\x80\x94I scorn it\r\nwith my heels!\xe2\x80\x94I serve the duty of my chapel duly and truly\xe2\x80\x94Two masses\r\ndaily, morning and evening, primes, noons, and vespers, \xe2\x80\x98aves, credos,\r\npaters\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcepting moonlight nights, when the venison is in season,\xe2\x80\x9d said his\r\nguest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Exceptis excipiendis\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d replied the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cas our old abbot taught\r\nme to say, when impertinent laymen should ask me if I kept every\r\npunctilio of mine order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, holy father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight; \xe2\x80\x9cbut the devil is apt to keep an\r\neye on such exceptions; he goes about, thou knowest, like a roaring\r\nlion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him roar here if he dares,\xe2\x80\x9d said the friar; \xe2\x80\x9ca touch of my cord\r\nwill make him roar as loud as the tongs of St Dunstan himself did. I\r\nnever feared man, and I as little fear the devil and his imps. Saint\r\nDunstan, Saint Dubric, Saint Winibald, Saint Winifred, Saint Swibert,\r\nSaint Willick, not forgetting Saint Thomas a Kent, and my own poor\r\nmerits to speed, I defy every devil of them, come cut and long\r\ntail.\xe2\x80\x94But to let you into a secret, I never speak upon such subjects,\r\nmy friend, until after morning vespers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe changed the conversation; fast and furious grew the mirth of the\r\nparties, and many a song was exchanged betwixt them, when their revels\r\nwere interrupted by a loud knocking at the door of the hermitage.\r\n\r\nThe occasion of this interruption we can only explain by resuming the\r\nadventures of another set of our characters; for, like old Ariosto, we\r\ndo not pique ourselves upon continuing uniformly to keep company with\r\nany one personage of our drama.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVIII\r\n\r\n\r\nAway! our journey lies through dell and dingle,\r\nWhere the blithe fawn trips by its timid mother,\r\nWhere the broad oak, with intercepting boughs,\r\nChequers the sunbeam in the green-sward alley\xe2\x80\x94\r\nUp and away!\xe2\x80\x94for lovely paths are these\r\nTo tread, when the glad Sun is on his throne\r\nLess pleasant, and less safe, when Cynthia\xe2\x80\x99s lamp\r\nWith doubtful glimmer lights the dreary forest.\r\n\r\n\r\nETTRICK FOREST\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Cedric the Saxon saw his son drop down senseless in the lists at\r\nAshby, his first impulse was to order him into the custody and care of\r\nhis own attendants, but the words choked in his throat. He could not\r\nbring himself to acknowledge, in presence of such an assembly, the son\r\nwhom he had renounced and disinherited. He ordered, however, Oswald to\r\nkeep an eye upon him; and directed that officer, with two of his serfs,\r\nto convey Ivanhoe to Ashby as soon as the crowd had dispersed. Oswald,\r\nhowever, was anticipated in this good office. The crowd dispersed,\r\nindeed, but the knight was nowhere to be seen.\r\n\r\nIt was in vain that Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s cupbearer looked around for his young\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x94he saw the bloody spot on which he had lately sunk down, but\r\nhimself he saw no longer; it seemed as if the fairies had conveyed him\r\nfrom the spot. Perhaps Oswald (for the Saxons were very superstitious)\r\nmight have adopted some such hypothesis, to account for Ivanhoe\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndisappearance, had he not suddenly cast his eye upon a person attired\r\nlike a squire, in whom he recognised the features of his fellow-servant\r\nGurth. Anxious concerning his master\xe2\x80\x99s fate, and in despair at his\r\nsudden disappearance, the translated swineherd was searching for him\r\neverywhere, and had neglected, in doing so, the concealment on which\r\nhis own safety depended. Oswald deemed it his duty to secure Gurth, as\r\na fugitive of whose fate his master was to judge.\r\n\r\nRenewing his enquiries concerning the fate of Ivanhoe, the only\r\ninformation which the cupbearer could collect from the bystanders was,\r\nthat the knight had been raised with care by certain well-attired\r\ngrooms, and placed in a litter belonging to a lady among the\r\nspectators, which had immediately transported him out of the press.\r\nOswald, on receiving this intelligence, resolved to return to his\r\nmaster for farther instructions, carrying along with him Gurth, whom he\r\nconsidered in some sort as a deserter from the service of Cedric.\r\n\r\nThe Saxon had been under very intense and agonizing apprehensions\r\nconcerning his son; for Nature had asserted her rights, in spite of the\r\npatriotic stoicism which laboured to disown her. But no sooner was he\r\ninformed that Ivanhoe was in careful, and probably in friendly hands,\r\nthan the paternal anxiety which had been excited by the dubiety of his\r\nfate, gave way anew to the feeling of injured pride and resentment, at\r\nwhat he termed Wilfred\xe2\x80\x99s filial disobedience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him wander his way,\xe2\x80\x9d said he\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9clet those leech his wounds for whose\r\nsake he encountered them. He is fitter to do the juggling tricks of the\r\nNorman chivalry than to maintain the fame and honour of his English\r\nancestry with the glaive and brown-bill, the good old weapons of his\r\ncountry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf to maintain the honour of ancestry,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, who was present,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cit is sufficient to be wise in council and brave in execution\xe2\x80\x94to be\r\nboldest among the bold, and gentlest among the gentle, I know no voice,\r\nsave his father\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe silent, Lady Rowena!\xe2\x80\x94on this subject only I hear you not. Prepare\r\nyourself for the Prince\xe2\x80\x99s festival: we have been summoned thither with\r\nunwonted circumstance of honour and of courtesy, such as the haughty\r\nNormans have rarely used to our race since the fatal day of Hastings.\r\nThither will I go, were it only to show these proud Normans how little\r\nthe fate of a son, who could defeat their bravest, can affect a Saxon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThither,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9cdo I NOT go; and I pray you to beware, lest\r\nwhat you mean for courage and constancy, shall be accounted hardness of\r\nheart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemain at home, then, ungrateful lady,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cthine is the\r\nhard heart, which can sacrifice the weal of an oppressed people to an\r\nidle and unauthorized attachment. I seek the noble Athelstane, and with\r\nhim attend the banquet of John of Anjou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe went accordingly to the banquet, of which we have already mentioned\r\nthe principal events. Immediately upon retiring from the castle, the\r\nSaxon thanes, with their attendants, took horse; and it was during the\r\nbustle which attended their doing so, that Cedric, for the first time,\r\ncast his eyes upon the deserter Gurth. The noble Saxon had returned\r\nfrom the banquet, as we have seen, in no very placid humour, and wanted\r\nbut a pretext for wreaking his anger upon some one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe gyves!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe gyves!\xe2\x80\x94Oswald\xe2\x80\x94Hundibert!\xe2\x80\x94Dogs and\r\nvillains!\xe2\x80\x94why leave ye the knave unfettered?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout daring to remonstrate, the companions of Gurth bound him with a\r\nhalter, as the readiest cord which occurred. He submitted to the\r\noperation without remonstrance, except that, darting a reproachful look\r\nat his master, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cThis comes of loving your flesh and blood\r\nbetter than mine own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo horse, and forward!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is indeed full time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the noble Athelstane; \xe2\x80\x9cfor, if we ride\r\nnot the faster, the worthy Abbot Waltheoff\xe2\x80\x99s preparations for a\r\nrere-supper 25 will be altogether spoiled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe travellers, however, used such speed as to reach the convent of St\r\nWithold\xe2\x80\x99s before the apprehended evil took place. The Abbot, himself of\r\nancient Saxon descent, received the noble Saxons with the profuse and\r\nexuberant hospitality of their nation, wherein they indulged to a late,\r\nor rather an early hour; nor did they take leave of their reverend host\r\nthe next morning until they had shared with him a sumptuous refection.\r\n\r\nAs the cavalcade left the court of the monastery, an incident happened\r\nsomewhat alarming to the Saxons, who, of all people of Europe, were\r\nmost addicted to a superstitious observance of omens, and to whose\r\nopinions can be traced most of those notions upon such subjects, still\r\nto be found among our popular antiquities. For the Normans being a\r\nmixed race, and better informed according to the information of the\r\ntimes, had lost most of the superstitious prejudices which their\r\nancestors had brought from Scandinavia, and piqued themselves upon\r\nthinking freely on such topics.\r\n\r\nIn the present instance, the apprehension of impending evil was\r\ninspired by no less respectable a prophet than a large lean black dog,\r\nwhich, sitting upright, howled most piteously as the foremost riders\r\nleft the gate, and presently afterwards, barking wildly, and jumping to\r\nand fro, seemed bent upon attaching itself to the party.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like not that music, father Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane; for by this\r\ntitle of respect he was accustomed to address him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor I either, uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cI greatly fear we shall have to pay\r\nthe piper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn my mind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, upon whose memory the Abbot\xe2\x80\x99s good ale\r\n(for Burton was already famous for that genial liquor) had made a\r\nfavourable impression,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cin my mind we had better turn back, and abide\r\nwith the Abbot until the afternoon. It is unlucky to travel where your\r\npath is crossed by a monk, a hare, or a howling dog, until you have\r\neaten your next meal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAway!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, impatiently; \xe2\x80\x9cthe day is already too short for our\r\njourney. For the dog, I know it to be the cur of the runaway slave\r\nGurth, a useless fugitive like its master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, and rising at the same time in his stirrups, impatient at\r\nthe interruption of his journey, he launched his javelin at poor\r\nFangs\xe2\x80\x94for Fangs it was, who, having traced his master thus far upon his\r\nstolen expedition, had here lost him, and was now, in his uncouth way,\r\nrejoicing at his reappearance. The javelin inflicted a wound upon the\r\nanimal\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder, and narrowly missed pinning him to the earth; and\r\nFangs fled howling from the presence of the enraged thane. Gurth\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nheart swelled within him; for he felt this meditated slaughter of his\r\nfaithful adherent in a degree much deeper than the harsh treatment he\r\nhad himself received.
