Having in vain attempted to raise his hand to his\r\neyes, he said to Wamba, who, seeing his master\xe2\x80\x99s ill humour had\r\nprudently retreated to the rear, \xe2\x80\x9cI pray thee, do me the kindness to\r\nwipe my eyes with the skirt of thy mantle; the dust offends me, and\r\nthese bonds will not let me help myself one way or another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWamba did him the service he required, and they rode side by side for\r\nsome time, during which Gurth maintained a moody silence. At length he\r\ncould repress his feelings no longer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend Wamba,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cof all those who are fools enough to serve\r\nCedric, thou alone hast dexterity enough to make thy folly acceptable\r\nto him. Go to him, therefore, and tell him that neither for love nor\r\nfear will Gurth serve him longer. He may strike the head from me\xe2\x80\x94he may\r\nscourge me\xe2\x80\x94he may load me with irons\xe2\x80\x94but henceforth he shall never\r\ncompel me either to love or to obey him. Go to him, then, and tell him\r\nthat Gurth the son of Beowulph renounces his service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAssuredly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cfool as I am, I shall not do your fool\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nerrand. Cedric hath another javelin stuck into his girdle, and thou\r\nknowest he does not always miss his mark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI care not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9chow soon he makes a mark of me. Yesterday\r\nhe left Wilfred, my young master, in his blood. To-day he has striven\r\nto kill before my face the only other living creature that ever showed\r\nme kindness. By St Edmund, St Dunstan, St Withold, St Edward the\r\nConfessor, and every other Saxon saint in the calendar,\xe2\x80\x9d (for Cedric\r\nnever swore by any that was not of Saxon lineage, and all his household\r\nhad the same limited devotion,) \xe2\x80\x9cI will never forgive him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo my thinking now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, who was frequently wont to act\r\nas peace-maker in the family, \xe2\x80\x9cour master did not propose to hurt\r\nFangs, but only to affright him. For, if you observed, he rose in his\r\nstirrups, as thereby meaning to overcast the mark; and so he would have\r\ndone, but Fangs happening to bound up at the very moment, received a\r\nscratch, which I will be bound to heal with a penny\xe2\x80\x99s breadth of tar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I thought so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cif I could but think so\xe2\x80\x94but no\xe2\x80\x94I saw the\r\njavelin was well aimed\xe2\x80\x94I heard it whizz through the air with all the\r\nwrathful malevolence of him who cast it, and it quivered after it had\r\npitched in the ground, as if with regret for having missed its mark. By\r\nthe hog dear to St Anthony, I renounce him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the indignant swineherd resumed his sullen silence, which no\r\nefforts of the Jester could again induce him to break.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile Cedric and Athelstane, the leaders of the troop, conversed\r\ntogether on the state of the land, on the dissensions of the royal\r\nfamily, on the feuds and quarrels among the Norman nobles, and on the\r\nchance which there was that the oppressed Saxons might be able to free\r\nthemselves from the yoke of the Normans, or at least to elevate\r\nthemselves into national consequence and independence, during the civil\r\nconvulsions which were likely to ensue. On this subject Cedric was all\r\nanimation. The restoration of the independence of his race was the idol\r\nof his heart, to which he had willingly sacrificed domestic happiness\r\nand the interests of his own son. But, in order to achieve this great\r\nrevolution in favour of the native English, it was necessary that they\r\nshould be united among themselves, and act under an acknowledged head.\r\nThe necessity of choosing their chief from the Saxon blood-royal was\r\nnot only evident in itself, but had been made a solemn condition by\r\nthose whom Cedric had intrusted with his secret plans and hopes.\r\nAthelstane had this quality at least; and though he had few mental\r\naccomplishments or talents to recommend him as a leader, he had still a\r\ngoodly person, was no coward, had been accustomed to martial exercises,\r\nand seemed willing to defer to the advice of counsellors more wise than\r\nhimself. Above all, he was known to be liberal and hospitable, and\r\nbelieved to be good-natured. But whatever pretensions Athelstane had to\r\nbe considered as head of the Saxon confederacy, many of that nation\r\nwere disposed to prefer to the title of the Lady Rowena, who drew her\r\ndescent from Alfred, and whose father having been a chief renowned for\r\nwisdom, courage, and generosity, his memory was highly honoured by his\r\noppressed countrymen.\r\n\r\nIt would have been no difficult thing for Cedric, had he been so\r\ndisposed, to have placed himself at the head of a third party, as\r\nformidable at least as any of the others. To counterbalance their royal\r\ndescent, he had courage, activity, energy, and, above all, that devoted\r\nattachment to the cause which had procured him the epithet of The\r\nSaxon, and his birth was inferior to none, excepting only that of\r\nAthelstane and his ward. These qualities, however, were unalloyed by\r\nthe slightest shade of selfishness; and, instead of dividing yet\r\nfarther his weakened nation by forming a faction of his own, it was a\r\nleading part of Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s plan to extinguish that which already existed,\r\nby promoting a marriage betwixt Rowena and Athelstane. An obstacle\r\noccurred to this his favourite project, in the mutual attachment of his\r\nward and his son and hence the original cause of the banishment of\r\nWilfred from the house of his father.\r\n\r\nThis stern measure Cedric had adopted, in hopes that, during Wilfred\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nabsence, Rowena might relinquish her preference, but in this hope he\r\nwas disappointed; a disappointment which might be attributed in part to\r\nthe mode in which his ward had been educated. Cedric, to whom the name\r\nof Alfred was as that of a deity, had treated the sole remaining scion\r\nof that great monarch with a degree of observance, such as, perhaps,\r\nwas in those days scarce paid to an acknowledged princess. Rowena\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwill had been in almost all cases a law to his household; and Cedric\r\nhimself, as if determined that her sovereignty should be fully\r\nacknowledged within that little circle at least, seemed to take a pride\r\nin acting as the first of her subjects. Thus trained in the exercise\r\nnot only of free will, but despotic authority, Rowena was, by her\r\nprevious education, disposed both to resist and to resent any attempt\r\nto control her affections, or dispose of her hand contrary to her\r\ninclinations, and to assert her independence in a case in which even\r\nthose females who have been trained up to obedience and subjection, are\r\nnot infrequently apt to dispute the authority of guardians and parents.\r\nThe opinions which she felt strongly, she avowed boldly; and Cedric,\r\nwho could not free himself from his habitual deference to her opinions,\r\nfelt totally at a loss how to enforce his authority of guardian.\r\n\r\nIt was in vain that he attempted to dazzle her with the prospect of a\r\nvisionary throne. Rowena, who possessed strong sense, neither\r\nconsidered his plan as practicable, nor as desirable, so far as she was\r\nconcerned, could it have been achieved. Without attempting to conceal\r\nher avowed preference of Wilfred of Ivanhoe, she declared that, were\r\nthat favoured knight out of question, she would rather take refuge in a\r\nconvent, than share a throne with Athelstane, whom, having always\r\ndespised, she now began, on account of the trouble she received on his\r\naccount, thoroughly to detest.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, Cedric, whose opinions of women\xe2\x80\x99s constancy was far from\r\nstrong, persisted in using every means in his power to bring about the\r\nproposed match, in which he conceived he was rendering an important\r\nservice to the Saxon cause. The sudden and romantic appearance of his\r\nson in the lists at Ashby, he had justly regarded as almost a death\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nblow to his hopes. His paternal affection, it is true, had for an\r\ninstant gained the victory over pride and patriotism; but both had\r\nreturned in full force, and under their joint operation, he was now\r\nbent upon making a determined effort for the union of Athelstane and\r\nRowena, together with expediting those other measures which seemed\r\nnecessary to forward the restoration of Saxon independence.\r\n\r\nOn this last subject, he was now labouring with Athelstane, not without\r\nhaving reason, every now and then, to lament, like Hotspur, that he\r\nshould have moved such a dish of skimmed milk to so honourable an\r\naction. Athelstane, it is true, was vain enough, and loved to have his\r\nears tickled with tales of his high descent, and of his right by\r\ninheritance to homage and sovereignty. But his petty vanity was\r\nsufficiently gratified by receiving this homage at the hands of his\r\nimmediate attendants, and of the Saxons who approached him. If he had\r\nthe courage to encounter danger, he at least hated the trouble of going\r\nto seek it; and while he agreed in the general principles laid down by\r\nCedric concerning the claim of the Saxons to independence, and was\r\nstill more easily convinced of his own title to reign over them when\r\nthat independence should be attained, yet when the means of asserting\r\nthese rights came to be discussed, he was still \xe2\x80\x9cAthelstane the\r\nUnready,\xe2\x80\x9d slow, irresolute, procrastinating, and unenterprising. The\r\nwarm and impassioned exhortations of Cedric had as little effect upon\r\nhis impassive temper, as red-hot balls alighting in the water, which\r\nproduce a little sound and smoke, and are instantly extinguished.\r\n\r\nIf, leaving this task, which might be compared to spurring a tired\r\njade, or to hammering upon cold iron, Cedric fell back to his ward\r\nRowena, he received little more satisfaction from conferring with her.\r\nFor, as his presence interrupted the discourse between the lady and her\r\nfavourite attendant upon the gallantry and fate of Wilfred, Elgitha\r\nfailed not to revenge both her mistress and herself, by recurring to\r\nthe overthrow of Athelstane in the lists, the most disagreeable subject\r\nwhich could greet the ears of Cedric. To this sturdy Saxon, therefore,\r\nthe day\xe2\x80\x99s journey was fraught with all manner of displeasure and\r\ndiscomfort; so that he more than once internally cursed the tournament,\r\nand him who had proclaimed it, together with his own folly in ever\r\nthinking of going thither.\r\n\r\nAt noon, upon the motion of Athelstane, the travellers paused in a\r\nwoodland shade by a fountain, to repose their horses and partake of\r\nsome provisions, with which the hospitable Abbot had loaded a sumpter\r\nmule. Their repast was a pretty long one; and these several\r\ninterruptions rendered it impossible for them to hope to reach\r\nRotherwood without travelling all night, a conviction which induced\r\nthem to proceed on their way at a more hasty pace than they had\r\nhitherto used.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIX\r\n\r\n\r\nA train of armed men, some noble dame\r\nEscorting, (so their scatter\xe2\x80\x99d words discover\xe2\x80\x99d,\r\nAs unperceived I hung upon their rear,)\r\nAre close at hand, and mean to pass the night\r\nWithin the castle.\r\n\r\n\r\nORRA, A TRAGEDY\r\n\r\n\r\nThe travellers had now reached the verge of the wooded country, and\r\nwere about to plunge into its recesses, held dangerous at that time\r\nfrom the number of outlaws whom oppression and poverty had driven to\r\ndespair, and who occupied the forests in such large bands as could\r\neasily bid defiance to the feeble police of the period. From these\r\nrovers, however, notwithstanding the lateness of the hour Cedric and\r\nAthelstane accounted themselves secure, as they had in attendance ten\r\nservants, besides Wamba and Gurth, whose aid could not be counted upon,\r\nthe one being a jester and the other a captive. It may be added, that\r\nin travelling thus late through the forest, Cedric and Athelstane\r\nrelied on their descent and character, as well as their courage. The\r\noutlaws, whom the severity of the forest laws had reduced to this\r\nroving and desperate mode of life, were chiefly peasants and yeomen of\r\nSaxon descent, and were generally supposed to respect the persons and\r\nproperty of their countrymen.\r\n\r\nAs the travellers journeyed on their way, they were alarmed by repeated\r\ncries for assistance; and when they rode up to the place from whence\r\nthey came, they were surprised to find a horse-litter placed upon the\r\nground, beside which sat a young woman, richly dressed in the Jewish\r\nfashion, while an old man, whose yellow cap proclaimed him to belong to\r\nthe same nation, walked up and down with gestures expressive of the\r\ndeepest despair, and wrung his hands, as if affected by some strange\r\ndisaster.\r\n\r\nTo the enquiries of Athelstane and Cedric, the old Jew could for some\r\ntime only answer by invoking the protection of all the patriarchs of\r\nthe Old Testament successively against the sons of Ishmael, who were\r\ncoming to smite them, hip and thigh, with the edge of the sword. When\r\nhe began to come to himself out of this agony of terror, Isaac of York\r\n(for it was our old friend) was at length able to explain, that he had\r\nhired a body-guard of six men at Ashby, together with mules for\r\ncarrying the litter of a sick friend. This party had undertaken to\r\nescort him as far as Doncaster. They had come thus far in safety; but\r\nhaving received information from a wood-cutter that there was a strong\r\nband of outlaws lying in wait in the woods before them, Isaac\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmercenaries had not only taken flight, but had carried off with them\r\nthe horses which bore the litter and left the Jew and his daughter\r\nwithout the means either of defence or of retreat, to be plundered, and\r\nprobably murdered, by the banditti, who they expected every moment\r\nwould bring down upon them. \xe2\x80\x9cWould it but please your valours,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\nIsaac, in a tone of deep humiliation, \xe2\x80\x9cto permit the poor Jews to\r\ntravel under your safeguard, I swear by the tables of our law, that\r\nnever has favour been conferred upon a child of Israel since the days\r\nof our captivity, which shall be more gratefully acknowledged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDog of a Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, whose memory was of that petty kind\r\nwhich stores up trifles of all kinds, but particularly trifling\r\noffences, \xe2\x80\x9cdost not remember how thou didst beard us in the gallery at\r\nthe tilt-yard? Fight or flee, or compound with the outlaws as thou dost\r\nlist, ask neither aid nor company from us; and if they rob only such as\r\nthee, who rob all the world, I, for mine own share, shall hold them\r\nright honest folk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCedric did not assent to the severe proposal of his companion. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\r\nshall do better,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cto leave them two of our attendants and two\r\nhorses to convey them back to the next village. It will diminish our\r\nstrength but little; and with your good sword, noble Athelstane, and\r\nthe aid of those who remain, it will be light work for us to face\r\ntwenty of those runagates.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRowena, somewhat alarmed by the mention of outlaws in force, and so\r\nnear them, strongly seconded the proposal of her guardian. But Rebecca\r\nsuddenly quitting her dejected posture, and making her way through the\r\nattendants to the palfrey of the Saxon lady, knelt down, and, after the\r\nOriental fashion in addressing superiors, kissed the hem of Rowena\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngarment. Then rising, and throwing back her veil, she implored her in\r\nthe great name of the God whom they both worshipped, and by that\r\nrevelation of the Law upon Mount Sinai, in which they both believed,\r\nthat she would have compassion upon them, and suffer them to go forward\r\nunder their safeguard. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not for myself that I pray this favour,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cnor is it even for that poor old man. I know that to\r\nwrong and to spoil our nation is a light fault, if not a merit, with\r\nthe Christians; and what is it to us whether it be done in the city, in\r\nthe desert, or in the field? But it is in the name of one dear to many,\r\nand dear even to you, that I beseech you to let this sick person be\r\ntransported with care and tenderness under your protection. For, if\r\nevil chance him, the last moment of your life would be embittered with\r\nregret for denying that which I ask of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe noble and solemn air with which Rebecca made this appeal, gave it\r\ndouble weight with the fair Saxon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man is old and feeble,\xe2\x80\x9d she said to her guardian, \xe2\x80\x9cthe maiden\r\nyoung and beautiful, their friend sick and in peril of his life\xe2\x80\x94Jews\r\nthough they be, we cannot as Christians leave them in this extremity.\r\nLet them unload two of the sumpter-mules, and put the baggage behind\r\ntwo of the serfs. The mules may transport the litter, and we have led\r\nhorses for the old man and his daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCedric readily assented to what she proposed, and Athelstane only added\r\nthe condition, \xe2\x80\x9cthat they should travel in the rear of the whole party,\r\nwhere Wamba,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmight attend them with his shield of boar\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbrawn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have left my shield in the tilt-yard,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cas has\r\nbeen the fate of many a better knight than myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthelstane coloured deeply, for such had been his own fate on the last\r\nday of the tournament; while Rowena, who was pleased in the same\r\nproportion, as if to make amends for the brutal jest of her unfeeling\r\nsuitor, requested Rebecca to ride by her side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt were not fit I should do so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, with proud\r\nhumility, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere my society might be held a disgrace to my\r\nprotectress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy this time the change of baggage was hastily achieved; for the single\r\nword \xe2\x80\x9coutlaws\xe2\x80\x9d rendered every one sufficiently alert, and the approach\r\nof twilight made the sound yet more impressive. Amid the bustle, Gurth\r\nwas taken from horseback, in the course of which removal he prevailed\r\nupon the Jester to slack the cord with which his arms were bound. It\r\nwas so negligently refastened, perhaps intentionally, on the part of\r\nWamba, that Gurth found no difficulty in freeing his arms altogether\r\nfrom bondage, and then, gliding into the thicket, he made his escape\r\nfrom the party.\r\n\r\nThe bustle had been considerable, and it was some time before Gurth was\r\nmissed; for, as he was to be placed for the rest of the journey behind\r\na servant, every one supposed that some other of his companions had him\r\nunder his custody, and when it began to be whispered among them that\r\nGurth had actually disappeared, they were under such immediate\r\nexpectation of an attack from the outlaws, that it was not held\r\nconvenient to pay much attention to the circumstance.\r\n\r\nThe path upon which the party travelled was now so narrow, as not to\r\nadmit, with any sort of convenience, above two riders abreast, and\r\nbegan to descend into a dingle, traversed by a brook whose banks were\r\nbroken, swampy, and overgrown with dwarf willows. Cedric and\r\nAthelstane, who were at the head of their retinue, saw the risk of\r\nbeing attacked at this pass; but neither of them having had much\r\npractice in war, no better mode of preventing the danger occurred to\r\nthem than that they should hasten through the defile as fast as\r\npossible. Advancing, therefore, without much order, they had just\r\ncrossed the brook with a part of their followers, when they were\r\nassailed in front, flank, and rear at once, with an impetuosity to\r\nwhich, in their confused and ill-prepared condition, it was impossible\r\nto offer effectual resistance. The shout of \xe2\x80\x9cA white dragon!\xe2\x80\x94a white\r\ndragon!\xe2\x80\x94Saint George for merry England!\xe2\x80\x9d war-cries adopted by the\r\nassailants, as belonging to their assumed character of Saxon outlaws,\r\nwas heard on every side, and on every side enemies appeared with a\r\nrapidity of advance and attack which seemed to multiply their numbers.\r\n\r\nBoth the Saxon chiefs were made prisoners at the same moment, and each\r\nunder circumstances expressive of his character. Cedric, the instant\r\nthat an enemy appeared, launched at him his remaining javelin, which,\r\ntaking better effect than that which he had hurled at Fangs, nailed the\r\nman against an oak-tree that happened to be close behind him. Thus far\r\nsuccessful, Cedric spurred his horse against a second, drawing his\r\nsword at the same time, and striking with such inconsiderate fury, that\r\nhis weapon encountered a thick branch which hung over him, and he was\r\ndisarmed by the violence of his own blow. He was instantly made\r\nprisoner, and pulled from his horse by two or three of the banditti who\r\ncrowded around him. Athelstane shared his captivity, his bridle having\r\nbeen seized, and he himself forcibly dismounted, long before he could\r\ndraw his weapon, or assume any posture of effectual defence.\r\n\r\nThe attendants, embarrassed with baggage, surprised and terrified at\r\nthe fate of their masters, fell an easy prey to the assailants; while\r\nthe Lady Rowena, in the centre of the cavalcade, and the Jew and his\r\ndaughter in the rear, experienced the same misfortune.\r\n\r\nOf all the train none escaped except Wamba, who showed upon the\r\noccasion much more courage than those who pretended to greater sense.\r\nHe possessed himself of a sword belonging to one of the domestics, who\r\nwas just drawing it with a tardy and irresolute hand, laid it about him\r\nlike a lion, drove back several who approached him, and made a brave\r\nthough ineffectual attempt to succour his master. Finding himself\r\noverpowered, the Jester at length threw himself from his horse, plunged\r\ninto the thicket, and, favoured by the general confusion, escaped from\r\nthe scene of action. Yet the valiant Jester, as soon as he found\r\nhimself safe, hesitated more than once whether he should not turn back\r\nand share the captivity of a master to whom he was sincerely attached.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard men talk of the blessings of freedom,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to\r\nhimself, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I wish any wise man would teach me what use to make of it\r\nnow that I have it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he pronounced these words aloud, a voice very near him called out in\r\na low and cautious tone, \xe2\x80\x9cWamba!\xe2\x80\x9d and, at the same time, a dog, which\r\nhe recognised to be Fangs, jumped up and fawned upon him. \xe2\x80\x9cGurth!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nanswered Wamba, with the same caution, and the swineherd immediately\r\nstood before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d said he eagerly; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat mean these cries, and that\r\nclashing of swords?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly a trick of the times,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cthey are all prisoners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are prisoners?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Gurth, impatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy lord, and my lady, and Athelstane, and Hundibert, and Oswald.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9chow came they prisoners?\xe2\x80\x94and to\r\nwhom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur master was too ready to fight,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester; \xe2\x80\x9cand Athelstane\r\nwas not ready enough, and no other person was ready at all. And they\r\nare prisoners to green cassocks, and black visors. And they lie all\r\ntumbled about on the green, like the crab-apples that you shake down to\r\nyour swine. And I would laugh at it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the honest Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cif I\r\ncould for weeping.\xe2\x80\x9d And he shed tears of unfeigned sorrow.\r\n\r\nGurth\xe2\x80\x99s countenance kindled\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWamba,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast a weapon, and\r\nthy heart was ever stronger than thy brain,\xe2\x80\x94we are only two\xe2\x80\x94but a\r\nsudden attack from men of resolution will do much\xe2\x80\x94follow me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither?\xe2\x80\x94and for what purpose?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo rescue Cedric.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have renounced his service but now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cwas but while he was fortunate\xe2\x80\x94follow me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs the Jester was about to obey, a third person suddenly made his\r\nappearance, and commanded them both to halt. From his dress and arms,\r\nWamba would have conjectured him to be one of those outlaws who had\r\njust assailed his master; but, besides that he wore no mask, the\r\nglittering baldric across his shoulder, with the rich bugle-horn which\r\nit supported, as well as the calm and commanding expression of his\r\nvoice and manner, made him, notwithstanding the twilight, recognise\r\nLocksley the yeoman, who had been victorious, under such\r\ndisadvantageous circumstances, in the contest for the prize of archery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the meaning of all this,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cor who is it that rifle,\r\nand ransom, and make prisoners, in these forests?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may look at their cassocks close by,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cand see whether\r\nthey be thy children\xe2\x80\x99s coats or no\xe2\x80\x94for they are as like thine own, as\r\none green pea-cod is to another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will learn that presently,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cand I charge ye, on\r\nperil of your lives, not to stir from the place where ye stand, until I\r\nhave returned. Obey me, and it shall be the better for you and your\r\nmasters.\xe2\x80\x94Yet stay, I must render myself as like these men as possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying he unbuckled his baldric with the bugle, took a feather from\r\nhis cap, and gave them to Wamba; then drew a vizard from his pouch,\r\nand, repeating his charges to them to stand fast, went to execute his\r\npurposes of reconnoitring.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we stand fast, Gurth?\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cor shall we e\xe2\x80\x99en give him\r\nleg-bail? In my foolish mind, he had all the equipage of a thief too\r\nmuch in readiness, to be himself a true man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him be the devil,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9can he will. We can be no worse of\r\nwaiting his return. If he belong to that party, he must already have\r\ngiven them the alarm, and it will avail nothing either to fight or fly.\r\nBesides, I have late experience, that errant thieves are not the worst\r\nmen in the world to have to deal with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe yeoman returned in the course of a few minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend Gurth,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI have mingled among yon men, and have learnt\r\nto whom they belong, and whither they are bound. There is, I think, no\r\nchance that they will proceed to any actual violence against their\r\nprisoners. For three men to attempt them at this moment, were little\r\nelse than madness; for they are good men of war, and have, as such,\r\nplaced sentinels to give the alarm when any one approaches. But I trust\r\nsoon to gather such a force, as may act in defiance of all their\r\nprecautions; you are both servants, and, as I think, faithful servants,\r\nof Cedric the Saxon, the friend of the rights of Englishmen. He shall\r\nnot want English hands to help him in this extremity. Come then with\r\nme, until I gather more aid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he walked through the wood at a great pace, followed by the\r\njester and the swineherd. It was not consistent with Wamba\xe2\x80\x99s humour to\r\ntravel long in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, looking at the baldric and bugle which he still\r\ncarried, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I saw the arrow shot which won this gay prize, and that\r\nnot so long since as Christmas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9ccould take it on my halidome, that I have heard\r\nthe voice of the good yeoman who won it, by night as well as by day,\r\nand that the moon is not three days older since I did so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMine honest friends,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9cwho, or what I am, is\r\nlittle to the present purpose; should I free your master, you will have\r\nreason to think me the best friend you have ever had in your lives. And\r\nwhether I am known by one name or another\xe2\x80\x94or whether I can draw a bow\r\nas well or better than a cow-keeper, or whether it is my pleasure to\r\nwalk in sunshine or by moonlight, are matters, which, as they do not\r\nconcern you, so neither need ye busy yourselves respecting them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur heads are in the lion\xe2\x80\x99s mouth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, in a whisper to Gurth,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cget them out how we can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush\xe2\x80\x94be silent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth. \xe2\x80\x9cOffend him not by thy folly, and I trust\r\nsincerely that all will go well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XX\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen autumn nights were long and drear,\r\n    And forest walks were dark and dim,\r\nHow sweetly on the pilgrim\xe2\x80\x99s ear\r\n    Was wont to steal the hermit\xe2\x80\x99s hymn\r\n\r\nDevotion borrows Music\xe2\x80\x99s tone,\r\n    And Music took Devotion\xe2\x80\x99s wing;\r\nAnd, like the bird that hails the sun,\r\n    They soar to heaven, and soaring sing.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE HERMIT OF ST CLEMENT\xe2\x80\x99S WELL\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was after three hours\xe2\x80\x99 good walking that the servants of Cedric,\r\nwith their mysterious guide, arrived at a small opening in the forest,\r\nin the centre of which grew an oak-tree of enormous magnitude, throwing\r\nits twisted branches in every direction. Beneath this tree four or five\r\nyeomen lay stretched on the ground, while another, as sentinel, walked\r\nto and fro in the moonlight shade.\r\n\r\nUpon hearing the sound of feet approaching, the watch instantly gave\r\nthe alarm, and the sleepers as suddenly started up and bent their bows.\r\nSix arrows placed on the string were pointed towards the quarter from\r\nwhich the travellers approached, when their guide, being recognised,\r\nwas welcomed with every token of respect and attachment, and all signs\r\nand fears of a rough reception at once subsided.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the Miller?\xe2\x80\x9d was his first question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the road towards Rotherham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith how many?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the leader, for such he seemed to be.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith six men, and good hope of booty, if it please St Nicholas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDevoutly spoken,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cand where is Allan-a-Dale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWalked up towards the Watling-street, to watch for the Prior of\r\nJorvaulx.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is well thought on also,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Captain;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand where is the\r\nFriar?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn his cell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThither will I go,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley. \xe2\x80\x9cDisperse and seek your companions.\r\nCollect what force you can, for there\xe2\x80\x99s game afoot that must be hunted\r\nhard, and will turn to bay. Meet me here by daybreak.\xe2\x80\x94And stay,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nadded, \xe2\x80\x9cI have forgotten what is most necessary of the whole\xe2\x80\x94Two of you\r\ntake the road quickly towards Torquilstone, the Castle of\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf. A set of gallants, who have been masquerading in such\r\nguise as our own, are carrying a band of prisoners thither\xe2\x80\x94Watch them\r\nclosely, for even if they reach the castle before we collect our force,\r\nour honour is concerned to punish them, and we will find means to do\r\nso. Keep a close watch on them therefore; and dispatch one of your\r\ncomrades, the lightest of foot, to bring the news of the yeomen\r\nthereabout.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey promised implicit obedience, and departed with alacrity on their\r\ndifferent errands. In the meanwhile, their leader and his two\r\ncompanions, who now looked upon him with great respect, as well as some\r\nfear, pursued their way to the Chapel of Copmanhurst.\r\n\r\nWhen they had reached the little moonlight glade, having in front the\r\nreverend, though ruinous chapel, and the rude hermitage, so well suited\r\nto ascetic devotion, Wamba whispered to Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cIf this be the\r\nhabitation of a thief, it makes good the old proverb, The nearer the\r\nchurch the farther from God.\xe2\x80\x94And by my coxcomb,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cI think it\r\nbe even so\xe2\x80\x94Hearken but to the black sanctus which they are singing in\r\nthe hermitage!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact the anchorite and his guest were performing, at the full extent\r\nof their very powerful lungs, an old drinking song, of which this was\r\nthe burden:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, trowl the brown bowl to me,\r\n    Bully boy, bully boy,\r\nCome, trowl the brown bowl to me:\r\n    Ho! jolly Jenkin, I spy a knave in drinking,\r\nCome, trowl the brown bowl to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, that is not ill sung,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, who had thrown in a few of his\r\nown flourishes to help out the chorus. \xe2\x80\x9cBut who, in the saint\xe2\x80\x99s name,\r\never expected to have heard such a jolly chant come from out a hermit\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncell at midnight!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarry, that should I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the jolly Clerk of Copmanhurst\r\nis a known man, and kills half the deer that are stolen in this walk.\r\nMen say that the keeper has complained to his official, and that he\r\nwill be stripped of his cowl and cope altogether, if he keeps not\r\nbetter order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile they were thus speaking, Locksley\xe2\x80\x99s loud and repeated knocks had\r\nat length disturbed the anchorite and his guest. \xe2\x80\x9cBy my beads,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe hermit, stopping short in a grand flourish, \xe2\x80\x9chere come more\r\nbenighted guests. I would not for my cowl that they found us in this\r\ngoodly exercise. All men have their enemies, good Sir Sluggard; and\r\nthere be those malignant enough to construe the hospitable refreshment\r\nwhich I have been offering to you, a weary traveller, for the matter of\r\nthree short hours, into sheer drunkenness and debauchery, vices alike\r\nalien to my profession and my disposition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBase calumniators!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the knight; \xe2\x80\x9cI would I had the chastising\r\nof them. Nevertheless, Holy Clerk, it is true that all have their\r\nenemies; and there be those in this very land whom I would rather speak\r\nto through the bars of my helmet than barefaced.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGet thine iron pot on thy head then, friend Sluggard, as quickly as\r\nthy nature will permit,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cwhile I remove these pewter\r\nflagons, whose late contents run strangely in mine own pate; and to\r\ndrown the clatter\xe2\x80\x94for, in faith, I feel somewhat unsteady\xe2\x80\x94strike into\r\nthe tune which thou hearest me sing; it is no matter for the words\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nscarce know them myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he struck up a thundering \xe2\x80\x9cDe profundis clamavi\xe2\x80\x9d, under\r\ncover of which he removed the apparatus of their banquet: while the\r\nknight, laughing heartily, and arming himself all the while, assisted\r\nhis host with his voice from time to time as his mirth permitted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat devil\xe2\x80\x99s matins are you after at this hour?\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice from\r\nwithout.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeaven forgive you, Sir Traveller!\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit, whose own noise,\r\nand perhaps his nocturnal potations, prevented from recognising accents\r\nwhich were tolerably familiar to him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWend on your way, in the name of\r\nGod and Saint Dunstan, and disturb not the devotions of me and my holy\r\nbrother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMad priest,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the voice from without, \xe2\x80\x9copen to Locksley!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll\xe2\x80\x99s safe\xe2\x80\x94all\xe2\x80\x99s right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit to his companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who is he?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight; \xe2\x80\x9cit imports me much to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the hermit; \xe2\x80\x9cI tell thee he is a friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what friend?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the knight; \xe2\x80\x9cfor he may be friend to thee\r\nand none of mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat friend?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the hermit; \xe2\x80\x9cthat, now, is one of the questions\r\nthat is more easily asked than answered. What friend?\xe2\x80\x94why, he is, now\r\nthat I bethink me a little, the very same honest keeper I told thee of\r\na while since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, as honest a keeper as thou art a pious hermit,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\nknight, \xe2\x80\x9cI doubt it not. But undo the door to him before he beat it\r\nfrom its hinges.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe dogs, in the meantime, which had made a dreadful baying at the\r\ncommencement of the disturbance, seemed now to recognise the voice of\r\nhim who stood without; for, totally changing their manner, they\r\nscratched and whined at the door, as if interceding for his admission.\r\nThe hermit speedily unbolted his portal, and admitted Locksley, with\r\nhis two companions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, hermit,\xe2\x80\x9d was the yeoman\xe2\x80\x99s first question as soon as he beheld the\r\nknight, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat boon companion hast thou here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA brother of our order,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the friar, shaking his head; \xe2\x80\x9cwe have\r\nbeen at our orisons all night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a monk of the church militant, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nthere be more of them abroad. I tell thee, friar, thou must lay down\r\nthe rosary and take up the quarter-staff; we shall need every one of\r\nour merry men, whether clerk or layman.\xe2\x80\x94But,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, taking him a\r\nstep aside, \xe2\x80\x9cart thou mad? to give admittance to a knight thou dost not\r\nknow? Hast thou forgot our articles?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot know him!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the friar, boldly, \xe2\x80\x9cI know him as well as the\r\nbeggar knows his dish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is his name, then?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Locksley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis name,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9chis name is Sir Anthony of Scrabelstone\xe2\x80\x94as\r\nif I would drink with a man, and did not know his name!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast been drinking more than enough, friar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woodsman,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand, I fear, prating more than enough too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood yeoman,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, coming forward, \xe2\x80\x9cbe not wroth with my\r\nmerry host. He did but afford me the hospitality which I would have\r\ncompelled from him if he had refused it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou compel!\xe2\x80\x9d said the friar; \xe2\x80\x9cwait but till have changed this grey\r\ngown for a green cassock, and if I make not a quarter-staff ring twelve\r\nupon thy pate, I am neither true clerk nor good woodsman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile he spoke thus, he stript off his gown, and appeared in a close\r\nblack buckram doublet and drawers, over which he speedily did on a\r\ncassock of green, and hose of the same colour. \xe2\x80\x9cI pray thee truss my\r\npoints,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cand thou shalt have a cup of sack for thy\r\nlabour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGramercy for thy sack,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cbut think\xe2\x80\x99st thou it is lawful\r\nfor me to aid you to transmew thyself from a holy hermit into a sinful\r\nforester?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever fear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hermit; \xe2\x80\x9cI will but confess the sins of my green\r\ncloak to my greyfriar\xe2\x80\x99s frock, and all shall be well again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester; \xe2\x80\x9ca broadcloth penitent should have a\r\nsackcloth confessor, and your frock may absolve my motley doublet into\r\nthe bargain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he accommodated the friar with his assistance in tying the\r\nendless number of points, as the laces which attached the hose to the\r\ndoublet were then termed.\r\n\r\nWhile they were thus employed, Locksley led the knight a little apart,\r\nand addressed him thus:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDeny it not, Sir Knight\xe2\x80\x94you are he who decided\r\nthe victory to the advantage of the English against the strangers on\r\nthe second day of the tournament at Ashby.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what follows if you guess truly, good yeoman?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should in that case hold you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9ca friend to the\r\nweaker party.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch is the duty of a true knight at least,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Black\r\nChampion; \xe2\x80\x9cand I would not willingly that there were reason to think\r\notherwise of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut for my purpose,\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9cthou shouldst be as well a good\r\nEnglishman as a good knight; for that, which I have to speak of,\r\nconcerns, indeed, the duty of every honest man, but is more especially\r\nthat of a true-born native of England.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can speak to no one,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cto whom England, and\r\nthe life of every Englishman, can be dearer than to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would willingly believe so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woodsman, \xe2\x80\x9cfor never had this\r\ncountry such need to be supported by those who love her. Hear me, and I\r\nwill tell thee of an enterprise, in which, if thou be\xe2\x80\x99st really that\r\nwhich thou seemest, thou mayst take an honourable part. A band of\r\nvillains, in the disguise of better men than themselves, have made\r\nthemselves master of the person of a noble Englishman, called Cedric\r\nthe Saxon, together with his ward, and his friend Athelstane of\r\nConingsburgh, and have transported them to a castle in this forest,\r\ncalled Torquilstone. I ask of thee, as a good knight and a good\r\nEnglishman, wilt thou aid in their rescue?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am bound by my vow to do so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the knight; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I would\r\nwillingly know who you are, who request my assistance in their behalf?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am,\xe2\x80\x9d said the forester, \xe2\x80\x9ca nameless man; but I am the friend of my\r\ncountry, and of my country\xe2\x80\x99s friends\xe2\x80\x94With this account of me you must\r\nfor the present remain satisfied, the more especially since you\r\nyourself desire to continue unknown. Believe, however, that my word,\r\nwhen pledged, is as inviolate as if I wore golden spurs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI willingly believe it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight; \xe2\x80\x9cI have been accustomed to\r\nstudy men\xe2\x80\x99s countenances, and I can read in thine honesty and\r\nresolution. I will, therefore, ask thee no further questions, but aid\r\nthee in setting at freedom these oppressed captives; which done, I\r\ntrust we shall part better acquainted, and well satisfied with each\r\nother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba to Gurth,\xe2\x80\x94for the friar being now fully equipped, the\r\nJester, having approached to the other side of the hut, had heard the\r\nconclusion of the conversation,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSo we have got a new ally?\xe2\x80\x94I trust the\r\nvalour of the knight will be truer metal than the religion of the\r\nhermit, or the honesty of the yeoman; for this Locksley looks like a\r\nborn deer-stealer, and the priest like a lusty hypocrite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold thy peace, Wamba,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth; \xe2\x80\x9cit may all be as thou dost guess;\r\nbut were the horned devil to rise and proffer me his assistance to set\r\nat liberty Cedric and the Lady Rowena, I fear I should hardly have\r\nreligion enough to refuse the foul fiend\xe2\x80\x99s offer, and bid him get\r\nbehind me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe friar was now completely accoutred as a yeoman, with sword and\r\nbuckler, bow, and quiver, and a strong partisan over his shoulder. He\r\nleft his cell at the head of the party, and, having carefully locked\r\nthe door, deposited the key under the threshold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou in condition to do good service, friar,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9cor\r\ndoes the brown bowl still run in thy head?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot more than a drought of St Dunstan\xe2\x80\x99s fountain will allay,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nthe priest; \xe2\x80\x9csomething there is of a whizzing in my brain, and of\r\ninstability in my legs, but you shall presently see both pass away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he stepped to the stone basin, in which the waters of the\r\nfountain as they fell formed bubbles which danced in the white\r\nmoonlight, and took so long a drought as if he had meant to exhaust the\r\nspring.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen didst thou drink as deep a drought of water before, Holy Clerk of\r\nCopmanhurst?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever since my wine-butt leaked, and let out its liquor by an illegal\r\nvent,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the friar, \xe2\x80\x9cand so left me nothing to drink but my\r\npatron\xe2\x80\x99s bounty here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen plunging his hands and head into the fountain, he washed from them\r\nall marks of the midnight revel.\r\n\r\nThus refreshed and sobered, the jolly priest twirled his heavy partisan\r\nround his head with three fingers, as if he had been balancing a reed,\r\nexclaiming at the same time, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere be those false ravishers, who carry\r\noff wenches against their will? May the foul fiend fly off with me, if\r\nI am not man enough for a dozen of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSwearest thou, Holy Clerk?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cClerk me no Clerks,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the transformed priest; \xe2\x80\x9cby Saint George\r\nand the Dragon, I am no longer a shaveling than while my frock is on my\r\nback\xe2\x80\x94When I am cased in my green cassock, I will drink, swear, and woo\r\na lass, with any blithe forester in the West Riding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on, Jack Priest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9cand be silent; thou art as\r\nnoisy as a whole convent on a holy eve, when the Father Abbot has gone\r\nto bed.\xe2\x80\x94Come on you, too, my masters, tarry not to talk of it\xe2\x80\x94I say,\r\ncome on, we must collect all our forces, and few enough we shall have,\r\nif we are to storm the Castle of Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! is it Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cwho has stopt on\r\nthe king\xe2\x80\x99s highway the king\xe2\x80\x99s liege subjects?\xe2\x80\x94Is he turned thief and\r\noppressor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOppressor he ever was,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd for thief,\xe2\x80\x9d said the priest, \xe2\x80\x9cI doubt if ever he were even half so\r\nhonest a man as many a thief of my acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMove on, priest, and be silent,\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman; \xe2\x80\x9cit were better you\r\nled the way to the place of rendezvous, than say what should be left\r\nunsaid, both in decency and prudence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXI\r\n\r\n\r\nAlas, how many hours and years have past,\r\nSince human forms have round this table sate,\r\nOr lamp, or taper, on its surface gleam\xe2\x80\x99d!\r\nMethinks, I hear the sound of time long pass\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nStill murmuring o\xe2\x80\x99er us, in the lofty void\r\nOf these dark arches, like the ling\xe2\x80\x99ring voices\r\nOf those who long within their graves have slept.\r\n\r\n\r\nORRA, A TRAGEDY\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile these measures were taking in behalf of Cedric and his\r\ncompanions, the armed men by whom the latter had been seized, hurried\r\ntheir captives along towards the place of security, where they intended\r\nto imprison them. But darkness came on fast, and the paths of the wood\r\nseemed but imperfectly known to the marauders. They were compelled to\r\nmake several long halts, and once or twice to return on their road to\r\nresume the direction which they wished to pursue. The summer morn had\r\ndawned upon them ere they could travel in full assurance that they held\r\nthe right path. But confidence returned with light, and the cavalcade\r\nnow moved rapidly forward. Meanwhile, the following dialogue took place\r\nbetween the two leaders of the banditti.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is time thou shouldst leave us, Sir Maurice,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar to\r\nDe Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cin order to prepare the second part of thy mystery. Thou art\r\nnext, thou knowest, to act the Knight Deliverer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have thought better of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cI will not leave thee\r\ntill the prize is fairly deposited in Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s castle. There\r\nwill I appear before the Lady Rowena in mine own shape, and trust that\r\nshe will set down to the vehemence of my passion the violence of which\r\nI have been guilty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what has made thee change thy plan, De Bracy?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Knight\r\nTemplar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat concerns thee nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d answered his companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would hope, however, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this\r\nalteration of measures arises from no suspicion of my honourable\r\nmeaning, such as Fitzurse endeavoured to instil into thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy thoughts are my own,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cthe fiend laughs, they\r\nsay, when one thief robs another; and we know, that were he to spit\r\nfire and brimstone instead, it would never prevent a Templar from\r\nfollowing his bent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr the leader of a Free Company,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom dreading\r\nat the hands of a comrade and friend, the injustice he does to all\r\nmankind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is unprofitable and perilous recrimination,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csuffice it to say, I know the morals of the Temple-Order, and I will\r\nnot give thee the power of cheating me out of the fair prey for which I\r\nhave run such risks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPsha,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat hast thou to fear?\xe2\x80\x94Thou knowest the\r\nvows of our order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight well,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cand also how they are kept. Come, Sir\r\nTemplar, the laws of gallantry have a liberal interpretation in\r\nPalestine, and this is a case in which I will trust nothing to your\r\nconscience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear the truth, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cI care not for your\r\nblue-eyed beauty. There is in that train one who will make me a better\r\nmate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! wouldst thou stoop to the waiting damsel?\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, haughtily. \xe2\x80\x9cTo the waiting-woman\r\nwill I not stoop. I have a prize among the captives as lovely as thine\r\nown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the mass, thou meanest the fair Jewess!\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cwho shall gainsay me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one that I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cunless it be your vow of\r\ncelibacy, or a check of conscience for an intrigue with a Jewess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor my vow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cour Grand Master hath granted me a\r\ndispensation. And for my conscience, a man that has slain three hundred\r\nSaracens, need not reckon up every little failing, like a village girl\r\nat her first confession upon Good Friday eve.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou knowest best thine own privileges,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy. \xe2\x80\x9cYet, I would\r\nhave sworn thy thought had been more on the old usurer\xe2\x80\x99s money bags,\r\nthan on the black eyes of the daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can admire both,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, the old Jew is but\r\nhalf-prize. I must share his spoils with Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, who will not\r\nlend us the use of his castle for nothing. I must have something that I\r\ncan term exclusively my own by this foray of ours, and I have fixed on\r\nthe lovely Jewess as my peculiar prize. But, now thou knowest my drift,\r\nthou wilt resume thine own original plan, wilt thou not?\xe2\x80\x94Thou hast\r\nnothing, thou seest, to fear from my interference.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cI will remain beside my prize. What thou sayst\r\nis passing true, but I like not the privileges acquired by the\r\ndispensation of the Grand Master, and the merit acquired by the\r\nslaughter of three hundred Saracens. You have too good a right to a\r\nfree pardon, to render you very scrupulous about peccadilloes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile this dialogue was proceeding, Cedric was endeavouring to wring\r\nout of those who guarded him an avowal of their character and purpose.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should be Englishmen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cand yet, sacred Heaven! you prey\r\nupon your countrymen as if you were very Normans. You should be my\r\nneighbours, and, if so, my friends; for which of my English neighbours\r\nhave reason to be otherwise? I tell ye, yeomen, that even those among\r\nye who have been branded with outlawry have had from me protection; for\r\nI have pitied their miseries, and curst the oppression of their\r\ntyrannic nobles. What, then, would you have of me? or in what can this\r\nviolence serve ye?\xe2\x80\x94Ye are worse than brute beasts in your actions, and\r\nwill you imitate them in their very dumbness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was in vain that Cedric expostulated with his guards, who had too\r\nmany good reasons for their silence to be induced to break it either by\r\nhis wrath or his expostulations. They continued to hurry him along,\r\ntravelling at a very rapid rate, until, at the end of an avenue of huge\r\ntrees, arose Torquilstone, now the hoary and ancient castle of Reginald\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf. It was a fortress of no great size, consisting of a\r\ndonjon, or large and high square tower, surrounded by buildings of\r\ninferior height, which were encircled by an inner court-yard. Around\r\nthe exterior wall was a deep moat, supplied with water from a\r\nneighbouring rivulet. Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, whose character placed him often\r\nat feud with his enemies, had made considerable additions to the\r\nstrength of his castle, by building towers upon the outward wall, so as\r\nto flank it at every angle. The access, as usual in castles of the\r\nperiod, lay through an arched barbican, or outwork, which was\r\nterminated and defended by a small turret at each corner.\r\n\r\nCedric no sooner saw the turrets of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s castle raise their\r\ngrey and moss-grown battlements, glimmering in the morning sun above\r\nthe wood by which they were surrounded, than he instantly augured more\r\ntruly concerning the cause of his misfortune.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did injustice,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cto the thieves and outlaws of these woods,\r\nwhen I supposed such banditti to belong to their bands; I might as\r\njustly have confounded the foxes of these brakes with the ravening\r\nwolves of France. Tell me, dogs\xe2\x80\x94is it my life or my wealth that your\r\nmaster aims at? Is it too much that two Saxons, myself and the noble\r\nAthelstane, should hold land in the country which was once the\r\npatrimony of our race?\xe2\x80\x94Put us then to death, and complete your tyranny\r\nby taking our lives, as you began with our liberties. If the Saxon\r\nCedric cannot rescue England, he is willing to die for her. Tell your\r\ntyrannical master, I do only beseech him to dismiss the Lady Rowena in\r\nhonour and safety. She is a woman, and he need not dread her; and with\r\nus will die all who dare fight in her cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe attendants remained as mute to this address as to the former, and\r\nthey now stood before the gate of the castle. De Bracy winded his horn\r\nthree times, and the archers and cross-bow men, who had manned the wall\r\nupon seeing their approach, hastened to lower the drawbridge, and admit\r\nthem. The prisoners were compelled by their guards to alight, and were\r\nconducted to an apartment where a hasty repast was offered them, of\r\nwhich none but Athelstane felt any inclination to partake. Neither had\r\nthe descendant of the Confessor much time to do justice to the good\r\ncheer placed before them, for their guards gave him and Cedric to\r\nunderstand that they were to be imprisoned in a chamber apart from\r\nRowena. Resistance was vain; and they were compelled to follow to a\r\nlarge room, which, rising on clumsy Saxon pillars, resembled those\r\nrefectories and chapter-houses which may be still seen in the most\r\nancient parts of our most ancient monasteries.\r\n\r\nThe Lady Rowena was next separated from her train, and conducted, with\r\ncourtesy, indeed, but still without consulting her inclination, to a\r\ndistant apartment. The same alarming distinction was conferred on\r\nRebecca, in spite of her father\xe2\x80\x99s entreaties, who offered even money,\r\nin this extremity of distress, that she might be permitted to abide\r\nwith him. \xe2\x80\x9cBase unbeliever,\xe2\x80\x9d answered one of his guards, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen thou\r\nhast seen thy lair, thou wilt not wish thy daughter to partake it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd, without farther discussion, the old Jew was forcibly dragged off\r\nin a different direction from the other prisoners. The domestics, after\r\nbeing carefully searched and disarmed, were confined in another part of\r\nthe castle; and Rowena was refused even the comfort she might have\r\nderived from the attendance of her handmaiden Elgitha.\r\n\r\nThe apartment in which the Saxon chiefs were confined, for to them we\r\nturn our first attention, although at present used as a sort of\r\nguard-room, had formerly been the great hall of the castle. It was now\r\nabandoned to meaner purposes, because the present lord, among other\r\nadditions to the convenience, security, and beauty of his baronial\r\nresidence, had erected a new and noble hall, whose vaulted roof was\r\nsupported by lighter and more elegant pillars, and fitted up with that\r\nhigher degree of ornament, which the Normans had already introduced\r\ninto architecture.\r\n\r\nCedric paced the apartment, filled with indignant reflections on the\r\npast and on the present, while the apathy of his companion served,\r\ninstead of patience and philosophy, to defend him against every thing\r\nsave the inconvenience of the present moment; and so little did he feel\r\neven this last, that he was only from time to time roused to a reply by\r\nCedric\xe2\x80\x99s animated and impassioned appeal to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, half speaking to himself, and half addressing\r\nhimself to Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cit was in this very hall that my father feasted\r\nwith Torquil Wolfganger, when he entertained the valiant and\r\nunfortunate Harold, then advancing against the Norwegians, who had\r\nunited themselves to the rebel Tosti. It was in this hall that Harold\r\nreturned the magnanimous answer to the ambassador of his rebel brother.\r\nOft have I heard my father kindle as he told the tale. The envoy of\r\nTosti was admitted, when this ample room could scarce contain the crowd\r\nof noble Saxon leaders, who were quaffing the blood-red wine around\r\ntheir monarch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, somewhat moved by this part of his friend\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndiscourse, \xe2\x80\x9cthey will not forget to send us some wine and refactions at\r\nnoon\xe2\x80\x94we had scarce a breathing-space allowed to break our fast, and I\r\nnever have the benefit of my food when I eat immediately after\r\ndismounting from horseback, though the leeches recommend that\r\npractice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCedric went on with his story without noticing this interjectional\r\nobservation of his friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe envoy of Tosti,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmoved up the hall, undismayed by the\r\nfrowning countenances of all around him, until he made his obeisance\r\nbefore the throne of King Harold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98What terms,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98Lord King, hath thy brother Tosti to hope, if\r\nhe should lay down his arms, and crave peace at thy hands?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98A brother\xe2\x80\x99s love,\xe2\x80\x99 cried the generous Harold, \xe2\x80\x98and the fair earldom\r\nof Northumberland.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98But should Tosti accept these terms,\xe2\x80\x99 continued the envoy, \xe2\x80\x98what\r\nlands shall be assigned to his faithful ally, Hardrada, King of\r\nNorway?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Seven feet of English ground,\xe2\x80\x99 answered Harold, fiercely, \xe2\x80\x98or, as\r\nHardrada is said to be a giant, perhaps we may allow him twelve inches\r\nmore.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe hall rung with acclamations, and cup and horn was filled to the\r\nNorwegian, who should be speedily in possession of his English\r\nterritory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could have pledged him with all my soul,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cfor my\r\ntongue cleaves to my palate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe baffled envoy,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Cedric, pursuing with animation his\r\ntale, though it interested not the listener, \xe2\x80\x9cretreated, to carry to\r\nTosti and his ally the ominous answer of his injured brother. It was\r\nthen that the distant towers of York, and the bloody streams of the\r\nDerwent, 26 beheld that direful conflict, in which, after displaying\r\nthe most undaunted valour, the King of Norway, and Tosti, both fell,\r\nwith ten thousand of their bravest followers. Who would have thought\r\nthat upon the proud day when this battle was won, the very gale which\r\nwaved the Saxon banners in triumph, was filling the Norman sails, and\r\nimpelling them to the fatal shores of Sussex?\xe2\x80\x94Who would have thought\r\nthat Harold, within a few brief days, would himself possess no more of\r\nhis kingdom, than the share which he allotted in his wrath to the\r\nNorwegian invader?\xe2\x80\x94Who would have thought that you, noble\r\nAthelstane\xe2\x80\x94that you, descended of Harold\xe2\x80\x99s blood, and that I, whose\r\nfather was not the worst defender of the Saxon crown, should be\r\nprisoners to a vile Norman, in the very hall in which our ancestors\r\nheld such high festival?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is sad enough,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athelstane; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I trust they will hold us\r\nto a moderate ransom\xe2\x80\x94At any rate it cannot be their purpose to starve\r\nus outright; and yet, although it is high noon, I see no preparations\r\nfor serving dinner. Look up at the window, noble Cedric, and judge by\r\nthe sunbeams if it is not on the verge of noon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I cannot look on that stained\r\nlattice without its awakening other reflections than those which\r\nconcern the passing moment, or its privations. When that window was\r\nwrought, my noble friend, our hardy fathers knew not the art of making\r\nglass, or of staining it\xe2\x80\x94The pride of Wolfganger\xe2\x80\x99s father brought an\r\nartist from Normandy to adorn his hall with this new species of\r\nemblazonment, that breaks the golden light of God\xe2\x80\x99s blessed day into so\r\nmany fantastic hues. The foreigner came here poor, beggarly, cringing,\r\nand subservient, ready to doff his cap to the meanest native of the\r\nhousehold. He returned pampered and proud, to tell his rapacious\r\ncountrymen of the wealth and the simplicity of the Saxon nobles\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nfolly, oh, Athelstane, foreboded of old, as well as foreseen, by those\r\ndescendants of Hengist and his hardy tribes, who retained the\r\nsimplicity of their manners. We made these strangers our bosom friends,\r\nour confidential servants; we borrowed their artists and their arts,\r\nand despised the honest simplicity and hardihood with which our brave\r\nancestors supported themselves, and we became enervated by Norman arts\r\nlong ere we fell under Norman arms. Far better was our homely diet,\r\neaten in peace and liberty, than the luxurious dainties, the love of\r\nwhich hath delivered us as bondsmen to the foreign conqueror!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9chold very humble diet a luxury at\r\npresent; and it astonishes me, noble Cedric, that you can bear so truly\r\nin mind the memory of past deeds, when it appeareth you forget the very\r\nhour of dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is time lost,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered Cedric apart and impatiently, \xe2\x80\x9cto speak to\r\nhim of aught else but that which concerns his appetite! The soul of\r\nHardicanute hath taken possession of him, and he hath no pleasure save\r\nto fill, to swill, and to call for more.\xe2\x80\x94Alas!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, looking at\r\nAthelstane with compassion, \xe2\x80\x9cthat so dull a spirit should be lodged in\r\nso goodly a form! Alas! that such an enterprise as the regeneration of\r\nEngland should turn on a hinge so imperfect! Wedded to Rowena, indeed,\r\nher nobler and more generous soul may yet awake the better nature which\r\nis torpid within him. Yet how should this be, while Rowena, Athelstane,\r\nand I myself, remain the prisoners of this brutal marauder and have\r\nbeen made so perhaps from a sense of the dangers which our liberty\r\nmight bring to the usurped power of his nation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile the Saxon was plunged in these painful reflections, the door of\r\ntheir prison opened, and gave entrance to a sewer, holding his white\r\nrod of office. This important person advanced into the chamber with a\r\ngrave pace, followed by four attendants, bearing in a table covered\r\nwith dishes, the sight and smell of which seemed to be an instant\r\ncompensation to Athelstane for all the inconvenience he had undergone.\r\nThe persons who attended on the feast were masked and cloaked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat mummery is this?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cthink you that we are ignorant\r\nwhose prisoners we are, when we are in the castle of your master? Tell\r\nhim,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, willing to use this opportunity to open a\r\nnegotiation for his freedom,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cTell your master, Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\r\nthat we know no reason he can have for withholding our liberty,\r\nexcepting his unlawful desire to enrich himself at our expense. Tell\r\nhim that we yield to his rapacity, as in similar circumstances we\r\nshould do to that of a literal robber. Let him name the ransom at which\r\nhe rates our liberty, and it shall be paid, providing the exaction is\r\nsuited to our means.\xe2\x80\x9d The sewer made no answer, but bowed his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd tell Sir Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I send\r\nhim my mortal defiance, and challenge him to combat with me, on foot or\r\nhorseback, at any secure place, within eight days after our liberation;\r\nwhich, if he be a true knight, he will not, under these circumstances,\r\nventure to refuse or to delay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall deliver to the knight your defiance,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sewer;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmeanwhile I leave you to your food.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe challenge of Athelstane was delivered with no good grace; for a\r\nlarge mouthful, which required the exercise of both jaws at once, added\r\nto a natural hesitation, considerably damped the effect of the bold\r\ndefiance it contained. Still, however, his speech was hailed by Cedric\r\nas an incontestible token of reviving spirit in his companion, whose\r\nprevious indifference had begun, notwithstanding his respect for\r\nAthelstane\xe2\x80\x99s descent, to wear out his patience. But he now cordially\r\nshook hands with him in token of his approbation, and was somewhat\r\ngrieved when Athelstane observed, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he would fight a dozen such men\r\nas Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, if, by so doing, he could hasten his departure from a\r\ndungeon where they put so much garlic into their pottage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nNotwithstanding this intimation of a relapse into the apathy of\r\nsensuality, Cedric placed himself opposite to Athelstane, and soon\r\nshowed, that if the distresses of his country could banish the\r\nrecollection of food while the table was uncovered, yet no sooner were\r\nthe victuals put there, than he proved that the appetite of his Saxon\r\nancestors had descended to him along with their other qualities.\r\n\r\nThe captives had not long enjoyed their refreshment, however, ere their\r\nattention was disturbed even from this most serious occupation by the\r\nblast of a horn winded before the gate. It was repeated three times,\r\nwith as much violence as if it had been blown before an enchanted\r\ncastle by the destined knight, at whose summons halls and towers,\r\nbarbican and battlement, were to roll off like a morning vapour. The\r\nSaxons started from the table, and hastened to the window. But their\r\ncuriosity was disappointed; for these outlets only looked upon the\r\ncourt of the castle, and the sound came from beyond its precincts. The\r\nsummons, however, seemed of importance, for a considerable degree of\r\nbustle instantly took place in the castle.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXII\r\n\r\n\r\nMy daughter\xe2\x80\x94O my ducats\xe2\x80\x94O my daughter!\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94O my Christian ducats!\r\nJustice\xe2\x80\x94the Law\xe2\x80\x94my ducats, and my daughter!\r\n\r\n\r\nMERCHANT OF VENICE\r\n\r\n\r\nLeaving the Saxon chiefs to return to their banquet as soon as their\r\nungratified curiosity should permit them to attend to the calls of\r\ntheir half-satiated appetite, we have to look in upon the yet more\r\nsevere imprisonment of Isaac of York. The poor Jew had been hastily\r\nthrust into a dungeon-vault of the castle, the floor of which was deep\r\nbeneath the level of the ground, and very damp, being lower than even\r\nthe moat itself. The only light was received through one or two\r\nloop-holes far above the reach of the captive\xe2\x80\x99s hand. These apertures\r\nadmitted, even at mid-day, only a dim and uncertain light, which was\r\nchanged for utter darkness long before the rest of the castle had lost\r\nthe blessing of day. Chains and shackles, which had been the portion of\r\nformer captives, from whom active exertions to escape had been\r\napprehended, hung rusted and empty on the walls of the prison, and in\r\nthe rings of one of those sets of fetters there remained two mouldering\r\nbones, which seemed to have been once those of the human leg, as if\r\nsome prisoner had been left not only to perish there, but to be\r\nconsumed to a skeleton.\r\n\r\nAt one end of this ghastly apartment was a large fire-grate, over the\r\ntop of which were stretched some transverse iron bars, half devoured\r\nwith rust.\r\n\r\nThe whole appearance of the dungeon might have appalled a stouter heart\r\nthan that of Isaac, who, nevertheless, was more composed under the\r\nimminent pressure of danger, than he had seemed to be while affected by\r\nterrors, of which the cause was as yet remote and contingent. The\r\nlovers of the chase say that the hare feels more agony during the\r\npursuit of the greyhounds, than when she is struggling in their fangs.\r\n27\r\n\r\nAnd thus it is probable, that the Jews, by the very frequency of their\r\nfear on all occasions, had their minds in some degree prepared for\r\nevery effort of tyranny which could be practised upon them; so that no\r\naggression, when it had taken place, could bring with it that surprise\r\nwhich is the most disabling quality of terror. Neither was it the first\r\ntime that Isaac had been placed in circumstances so dangerous. He had\r\ntherefore experience to guide him, as well as hope, that he might\r\nagain, as formerly, be delivered as a prey from the fowler. Above all,\r\nhe had upon his side the unyielding obstinacy of his nation, and that\r\nunbending resolution, with which Israelites have been frequently known\r\nto submit to the uttermost evils which power and violence can inflict\r\nupon them, rather than gratify their oppressors by granting their\r\ndemands.\r\n\r\nIn this humour of passive resistance, and with his garment collected\r\nbeneath him to keep his limbs from the wet pavement, Isaac sat in a\r\ncorner of his dungeon, where his folded hands, his dishevelled hair and\r\nbeard, his furred cloak and high cap, seen by the wiry and broken\r\nlight, would have afforded a study for Rembrandt, had that celebrated\r\npainter existed at the period. The Jew remained, without altering his\r\nposition, for nearly three hours, at the expiry of which steps were\r\nheard on the dungeon stair. The bolts screamed as they were\r\nwithdrawn\xe2\x80\x94the hinges creaked as the wicket opened, and Reginald\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf, followed by the two Saracen slaves of the Templar,\r\nentered the prison.\r\n\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf, a tall and strong man, whose life had been spent in\r\npublic war or in private feuds and broils, and who had hesitated at no\r\nmeans of extending his feudal power, had features corresponding to his\r\ncharacter, and which strongly expressed the fiercer and more malignant\r\npassions of the mind. The scars with which his visage was seamed,\r\nwould, on features of a different cast, have excited the sympathy and\r\nveneration due to the marks of honourable valour; but, in the peculiar\r\ncase of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, they only added to the ferocity of his\r\ncountenance, and to the dread which his presence inspired. This\r\nformidable baron was clad in a leathern doublet, fitted close to his\r\nbody, which was frayed and soiled with the stains of his armour. He had\r\nno weapon, excepting a poniard at his belt, which served to\r\ncounterbalance the weight of the bunch of rusty keys that hung at his\r\nright side.\r\n\r\nThe black slaves who attended Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf were stripped of their\r\ngorgeous apparel, and attired in jerkins and trowsers of coarse linen,\r\ntheir sleeves being tucked up above the elbow, like those of butchers\r\nwhen about to exercise their function in the slaughter-house. Each had\r\nin his hand a small pannier; and, when they entered the dungeon, they\r\nstopt at the door until Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf himself carefully locked and\r\ndouble-locked it. Having taken this precaution, he advanced slowly up\r\nthe apartment towards the Jew, upon whom he kept his eye fixed, as if\r\nhe wished to paralyze him with his glance, as some animals are said to\r\nfascinate their prey. It seemed indeed as if the sullen and malignant\r\neye of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf possessed some portion of that supposed power over\r\nhis unfortunate prisoner. The Jew sat with his mouth agape, and his\r\neyes fixed on the savage baron with such earnestness of terror, that\r\nhis frame seemed literally to shrink together, and to diminish in size\r\nwhile encountering the fierce Norman\xe2\x80\x99s fixed and baleful gaze. The\r\nunhappy Isaac was deprived not only of the power of rising to make the\r\nobeisance which his terror dictated, but he could not even doff his\r\ncap, or utter any word of supplication; so strongly was he agitated by\r\nthe conviction that tortures and death were impending over him.\r\n\r\nOn the other hand, the stately form of the Norman appeared to dilate in\r\nmagnitude, like that of the eagle, which ruffles up its plumage when\r\nabout to pounce on its defenceless prey. He paused within three steps\r\nof the corner in which the unfortunate Jew had now, as it were, coiled\r\nhimself up into the smallest possible space, and made a sign for one of\r\nthe slaves to approach. The black satellite came forward accordingly,\r\nand, producing from his basket a large pair of scales and several\r\nweights, he laid them at the feet of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, and again retired\r\nto the respectful distance, at which his companion had already taken\r\nhis station.\r\n\r\nThe motions of these men were slow and solemn, as if there impended\r\nover their souls some preconception of horror and of cruelty.\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf himself opened the scene by thus addressing his ill-fated\r\ncaptive.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost accursed dog of an accursed race,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, awaking with his deep\r\nand sullen voice the sullen echoes of his dungeon vault, \xe2\x80\x9cseest thou\r\nthese scales?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe unhappy Jew returned a feeble affirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn these very scales shalt thou weigh me out,\xe2\x80\x9d said the relentless\r\nBaron, \xe2\x80\x9ca thousand silver pounds, after the just measure and weight of\r\nthe Tower of London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly Abraham!\xe2\x80\x9d returned the Jew, finding voice through the very\r\nextremity of his danger, \xe2\x80\x9cheard man ever such a demand?\xe2\x80\x94Who ever heard,\r\neven in a minstrel\xe2\x80\x99s tale, of such a sum as a thousand pounds of\r\nsilver?\xe2\x80\x94What human sight was ever blessed with the vision of such a\r\nmass of treasure?\xe2\x80\x94Not within the walls of York, ransack my house and\r\nthat of all my tribe, wilt thou find the tithe of that huge sum of\r\nsilver that thou speakest of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am reasonable,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cand if silver be scant, I\r\nrefuse not gold.
