At the rate of a mark of gold for each six pounds of\r\nsilver, thou shalt free thy unbelieving carcass from such punishment as\r\nthy heart has never even conceived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave mercy on me, noble knight!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Isaac; \xe2\x80\x9cI am old, and poor,\r\nand helpless. It were unworthy to triumph over me\xe2\x80\x94It is a poor deed to\r\ncrush a worm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOld thou mayst be,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the knight; \xe2\x80\x9cmore shame to their folly who\r\nhave suffered thee to grow grey in usury and knavery\xe2\x80\x94Feeble thou mayst\r\nbe, for when had a Jew either heart or hand\xe2\x80\x94But rich it is well known\r\nthou art.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI swear to you, noble knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew \xe2\x80\x9cby all which I believe,\r\nand by all which we believe in common\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerjure not thyself,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Norman, interrupting him, \xe2\x80\x9cand let not\r\nthine obstinacy seal thy doom, until thou hast seen and well considered\r\nthe fate that awaits thee. Think not I speak to thee only to excite thy\r\nterror, and practise on the base cowardice thou hast derived from thy\r\ntribe. I swear to thee by that which thou dost NOT believe, by the\r\ngospel which our church teaches, and by the keys which are given her to\r\nbind and to loose, that my purpose is deep and peremptory. This dungeon\r\nis no place for trifling. Prisoners ten thousand times more\r\ndistinguished than thou have died within these walls, and their fate\r\nhath never been known! But for thee is reserved a long and lingering\r\ndeath, to which theirs were luxury.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe again made a signal for the slaves to approach, and spoke to them\r\napart, in their own language; for he also had been in Palestine, where\r\nperhaps, he had learnt his lesson of cruelty. The Saracens produced\r\nfrom their baskets a quantity of charcoal, a pair of bellows, and a\r\nflask of oil. While the one struck a light with a flint and steel, the\r\nother disposed the charcoal in the large rusty grate which we have\r\nalready mentioned, and exercised the bellows until the fuel came to a\r\nred glow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeest thou, Isaac,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cthe range of iron bars above\r\nthe glowing charcoal?\xe2\x80\x94 28 on that warm couch thou shalt lie, stripped\r\nof thy clothes as if thou wert to rest on a bed of down. One of these\r\nslaves shall maintain the fire beneath thee, while the other shall\r\nanoint thy wretched limbs with oil, lest the roast should burn.\xe2\x80\x94Now,\r\nchoose betwixt such a scorching bed and the payment of a thousand\r\npounds of silver; for, by the head of my father, thou hast no other\r\noption.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the miserable Jew\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit is impossible that\r\nyour purpose can be real! The good God of nature never made a heart\r\ncapable of exercising such cruelty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust not to that, Isaac,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cit were a fatal error.\r\nDost thou think that I, who have seen a town sacked, in which thousands\r\nof my Christian countrymen perished by sword, by flood, and by fire,\r\nwill blench from my purpose for the outcries or screams of one single\r\nwretched Jew?\xe2\x80\x94or thinkest thou that these swarthy slaves, who have\r\nneither law, country, nor conscience, but their master\xe2\x80\x99s will\xe2\x80\x94who use\r\nthe poison, or the stake, or the poniard, or the cord, at his slightest\r\nwink\xe2\x80\x94thinkest thou that THEY will have mercy, who do not even\r\nunderstand the language in which it is asked?\xe2\x80\x94Be wise, old man;\r\ndischarge thyself of a portion of thy superfluous wealth; repay to the\r\nhands of a Christian a part of what thou hast acquired by the usury\r\nthou hast practised on those of his religion. Thy cunning may soon\r\nswell out once more thy shrivelled purse, but neither leech nor\r\nmedicine can restore thy scorched hide and flesh wert thou once\r\nstretched on these bars. Tell down thy ransom, I say, and rejoice that\r\nat such rate thou canst redeem thee from a dungeon, the secrets of\r\nwhich few have returned to tell. I waste no more words with thee\xe2\x80\x94choose\r\nbetween thy dross and thy flesh and blood, and as thou choosest, so\r\nshall it be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo may Abraham, Jacob, and all the fathers of our people assist me,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot make the choice, because I have not the means of\r\nsatisfying your exorbitant demand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeize him and strip him, slaves,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cand let the\r\nfathers of his race assist him if they can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe assistants, taking their directions more from the Baron\xe2\x80\x99s eye and\r\nhis hand than his tongue, once more stepped forward, laid hands on the\r\nunfortunate Isaac, plucked him up from the ground, and, holding him\r\nbetween them, waited the hard-hearted Baron\xe2\x80\x99s farther signal. The\r\nunhappy Jew eyed their countenances and that of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, in hope\r\nof discovering some symptoms of relenting; but that of the Baron\r\nexhibited the same cold, half-sullen, half-sarcastic smile which had\r\nbeen the prelude to his cruelty; and the savage eyes of the Saracens,\r\nrolling gloomily under their dark brows, acquiring a yet more sinister\r\nexpression by the whiteness of the circle which surrounds the pupil,\r\nevinced rather the secret pleasure which they expected from the\r\napproaching scene, than any reluctance to be its directors or agents.\r\nThe Jew then looked at the glowing furnace, over which he was presently\r\nto be stretched, and seeing no chance of his tormentor\xe2\x80\x99s relenting, his\r\nresolution gave way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will pay,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe thousand pounds of silver\xe2\x80\x94That is,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nadded, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause, \xe2\x80\x9cI will pay it with the help of my\r\nbrethren; for I must beg as a mendicant at the door of our synagogue\r\nere I make up so unheard-of a sum.\xe2\x80\x94When and where must it be\r\ndelivered?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9chere it must be delivered\xe2\x80\x94weighed it\r\nmust be\xe2\x80\x94weighed and told down on this very dungeon floor.\xe2\x80\x94Thinkest thou\r\nI will part with thee until thy ransom is secure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is to be my surety,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I shall be at\r\nliberty after this ransom is paid?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe word of a Norman noble, thou pawn-broking slave,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cthe faith of a Norman nobleman, more pure than the gold\r\nand silver of thee and all thy tribe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI crave pardon, noble lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac timidly, \xe2\x80\x9cbut wherefore should\r\nI rely wholly on the word of one who will trust nothing to mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause thou canst not help it, Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, sternly. \xe2\x80\x9cWert\r\nthou now in thy treasure-chamber at York, and were I craving a loan of\r\nthy shekels, it would be thine to dictate the time of payment, and the\r\npledge of security. This is MY treasure-chamber. Here I have thee at\r\nadvantage, nor will I again deign to repeat the terms on which I grant\r\nthee liberty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew groaned deeply.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGrant me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cat least with my own\r\nliberty, that of the companions with whom I travel. They scorned me as\r\na Jew, yet they pitied my desolation, and because they tarried to aid\r\nme by the way, a share of my evil hath come upon them; moreover, they\r\nmay contribute in some sort to my ransom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou meanest yonder Saxon churls,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9ctheir\r\nransom will depend upon other terms than thine. Mind thine own\r\nconcerns, Jew, I warn thee, and meddle not with those of others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9conly to be set at liberty, together with\r\nmine wounded friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I twice recommend it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cto a son of Israel,\r\nto meddle with his own concerns, and leave those of others alone?\xe2\x80\x94Since\r\nthou hast made thy choice, it remains but that thou payest down thy\r\nransom, and that at a short day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet hear me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cfor the sake of that very wealth which\r\nthou wouldst obtain at the expense of thy\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d Here he stopt short,\r\nafraid of irritating the savage Norman. But Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf only laughed,\r\nand himself filled up the blank at which the Jew had hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the expense of my conscience, thou wouldst say, Isaac; speak it\r\nout\xe2\x80\x94I tell thee, I am reasonable. I can bear the reproaches of a loser,\r\neven when that loser is a Jew. Thou wert not so patient, Isaac, when\r\nthou didst invoke justice against Jacques Fitzdotterel, for calling\r\nthee a usurious blood-sucker, when thy exactions had devoured his\r\npatrimony.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI swear by the Talmud,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cthat your valour has been\r\nmisled in that matter. Fitzdotterel drew his poniard upon me in mine\r\nown chamber, because I craved him for mine own silver. The term of\r\npayment was due at the Passover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI care not what he did,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cthe question is, when\r\nshall I have mine own?\xe2\x80\x94when shall I have the shekels, Isaac?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet my daughter Rebecca go forth to York,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cwith your\r\nsafe conduct, noble knight, and so soon as man and horse can return,\r\nthe treasure\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d Here he groaned deeply, but added, after the pause of a\r\nfew seconds,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe treasure shall be told down on this very floor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy daughter!\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, as if surprised,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBy heavens,\r\nIsaac, I would I had known of this. I deemed that yonder black-browed\r\ngirl had been thy concubine, and I gave her to be a handmaiden to Sir\r\nBrian de Bois-Guilbert, after the fashion of patriarchs and heroes of\r\nthe days of old, who set us in these matters a wholesome example.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe yell which Isaac raised at this unfeeling communication made the\r\nvery vault to ring, and astounded the two Saracens so much that they\r\nlet go their hold of the Jew. He availed himself of his enlargement to\r\nthrow himself on the pavement, and clasp the knees of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake all that you have asked,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cSir Knight\xe2\x80\x94take ten times\r\nmore\xe2\x80\x94reduce me to ruin and to beggary, if thou wilt,\xe2\x80\x94nay, pierce me\r\nwith thy poniard, broil me on that furnace, but spare my daughter,\r\ndeliver her in safety and honour!\xe2\x80\x94As thou art born of woman, spare the\r\nhonour of a helpless maiden\xe2\x80\x94She is the image of my deceased Rachel, she\r\nis the last of six pledges of her love\xe2\x80\x94Will you deprive a widowed\r\nhusband of his sole remaining comfort?\xe2\x80\x94Will you reduce a father to wish\r\nthat his only living child were laid beside her dead mother, in the\r\ntomb of our fathers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Norman, somewhat relenting, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I had known of\r\nthis before. I thought your race had loved nothing save their\r\nmoneybags.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink not so vilely of us, Jews though we be,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, eager to\r\nimprove the moment of apparent sympathy; \xe2\x80\x9cthe hunted fox, the tortured\r\nwildcat loves its young\xe2\x80\x94the despised and persecuted race of Abraham\r\nlove their children!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cI will believe it in future, Isaac,\r\nfor thy very sake\xe2\x80\x94but it aids us not now, I cannot help what has\r\nhappened, or what is to follow; my word is passed to my comrade in\r\narms, nor would I break it for ten Jews and Jewesses to boot. Besides,\r\nwhy shouldst thou think evil is to come to the girl, even if she became\r\nBois-Guilbert\xe2\x80\x99s booty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere will, there must!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Isaac, wringing his hands in agony;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhen did Templars breathe aught but cruelty to men, and dishonour to\r\nwomen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDog of an infidel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, with sparkling eyes, and not\r\nsorry, perhaps, to seize a pretext for working himself into a passion,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cblaspheme not the Holy Order of the Temple of Zion, but take thought\r\ninstead to pay me the ransom thou hast promised, or woe betide thy\r\nJewish throat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRobber and villain!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, retorting the insults of his\r\noppressor with passion, which, however impotent, he now found it\r\nimpossible to bridle, \xe2\x80\x9cI will pay thee nothing\xe2\x80\x94not one silver penny\r\nwill I pay thee, unless my daughter is delivered to me in safety and\r\nhonour!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou in thy senses, Israelite?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Norman, sternly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9chas thy\r\nflesh and blood a charm against heated iron and scalding oil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI care not!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, rendered desperate by paternal affection;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdo thy worst. My daughter is my flesh and blood, dearer to me a\r\nthousand times than those limbs which thy cruelty threatens. No silver\r\nwill I give thee, unless I were to pour it molten down thy avaricious\r\nthroat\xe2\x80\x94no, not a silver penny will I give thee, Nazarene, were it to\r\nsave thee from the deep damnation thy whole life has merited! Take my\r\nlife if thou wilt, and say, the Jew, amidst his tortures, knew how to\r\ndisappoint the Christian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cfor by the blessed rood,\r\nwhich is the abomination of thy accursed tribe, thou shalt feel the\r\nextremities of fire and steel!\xe2\x80\x94Strip him, slaves, and chain him down\r\nupon the bars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn spite of the feeble struggles of the old man, the Saracens had\r\nalready torn from him his upper garment, and were proceeding totally to\r\ndisrobe him, when the sound of a bugle, twice winded without the\r\ncastle, penetrated even to the recesses of the dungeon, and immediately\r\nafter loud voices were heard calling for Sir Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf.\r\nUnwilling to be found engaged in his hellish occupation, the savage\r\nBaron gave the slaves a signal to restore Isaac\xe2\x80\x99s garment, and,\r\nquitting the dungeon with his attendants, he left the Jew to thank God\r\nfor his own deliverance, or to lament over his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s captivity,\r\nand probable fate, as his personal or parental feelings might prove\r\nstrongest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIII\r\n\r\n\r\nNay, if the gentle spirit of moving words\r\nCan no way change you to a milder form,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll woo you, like a soldier, at arms\xe2\x80\x99 end,\r\nAnd love you \xe2\x80\x99gainst the nature of love, force you.\r\n\r\n\r\nTWO GENTLEMEN OF VERONA\r\n\r\n\r\nThe apartment to which the Lady Rowena had been introduced was fitted\r\nup with some rude attempts at ornament and magnificence, and her being\r\nplaced there might be considered as a peculiar mark of respect not\r\noffered to the other prisoners. But the wife of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, for whom\r\nit had been originally furnished, was long dead, and decay and neglect\r\nhad impaired the few ornaments with which her taste had adorned it. The\r\ntapestry hung down from the walls in many places, and in others was\r\ntarnished and faded under the effects of the sun, or tattered and\r\ndecayed by age. Desolate, however, as it was, this was the apartment of\r\nthe castle which had been judged most fitting for the accommodation of\r\nthe Saxon heiress; and here she was left to meditate upon her fate,\r\nuntil the actors in this nefarious drama had arranged the several parts\r\nwhich each of them was to perform. This had been settled in a council\r\nheld by Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, De Bracy, and the Templar, in which, after a\r\nlong and warm debate concerning the several advantages which each\r\ninsisted upon deriving from his peculiar share in this audacious\r\nenterprise, they had at length determined the fate of their unhappy\r\nprisoners.\r\n\r\nIt was about the hour of noon, therefore, when De Bracy, for whose\r\nadvantage the expedition had been first planned, appeared to prosecute\r\nhis views upon the hand and possessions of the Lady Rowena.\r\n\r\nThe interval had not entirely been bestowed in holding council with his\r\nconfederates, for De Bracy had found leisure to decorate his person\r\nwith all the foppery of the times. His green cassock and vizard were\r\nnow flung aside. His long luxuriant hair was trained to flow in quaint\r\ntresses down his richly furred cloak. His beard was closely shaved, his\r\ndoublet reached to the middle of his leg, and the girdle which secured\r\nit, and at the same time supported his ponderous sword, was embroidered\r\nand embossed with gold work. We have already noticed the extravagant\r\nfashion of the shoes at this period, and the points of Maurice de\r\nBracy\xe2\x80\x99s might have challenged the prize of extravagance with the\r\ngayest, being turned up and twisted like the horns of a ram. Such was\r\nthe dress of a gallant of the period; and, in the present instance,\r\nthat effect was aided by the handsome person and good demeanour of the\r\nwearer, whose manners partook alike of the grace of a courtier, and the\r\nfrankness of a soldier.\r\n\r\nHe saluted Rowena by doffing his velvet bonnet, garnished with a golden\r\nbroach, representing St Michael trampling down the Prince of Evil. With\r\nthis, he gently motioned the lady to a seat; and, as she still retained\r\nher standing posture, the knight ungloved his right hand, and motioned\r\nto conduct her thither. But Rowena declined, by her gesture, the\r\nproffered compliment, and replied, \xe2\x80\x9cIf I be in the presence of my\r\njailor, Sir Knight\xe2\x80\x94nor will circumstances allow me to think\r\notherwise\xe2\x80\x94it best becomes his prisoner to remain standing till she\r\nlearns her doom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas! fair Rowena,\xe2\x80\x9d returned De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are in presence of your\r\ncaptive, not your jailor; and it is from your fair eyes that De Bracy\r\nmust receive that doom which you fondly expect from him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you not, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lady, drawing herself up with all the\r\npride of offended rank and beauty; \xe2\x80\x9cI know you not\xe2\x80\x94and the insolent\r\nfamiliarity with which you apply to me the jargon of a troubadour,\r\nforms no apology for the violence of a robber.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo thyself, fair maid,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy, in his former tone\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cto\r\nthine own charms be ascribed whate\xe2\x80\x99er I have done which passed the\r\nrespect due to her, whom I have chosen queen of my heart, and lodestar\r\nof my eyes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI repeat to you, Sir Knight, that I know you not, and that no man\r\nwearing chain and spurs ought thus to intrude himself upon the presence\r\nof an unprotected lady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I am unknown to you,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cis indeed my misfortune;\r\nyet let me hope that De Bracy\xe2\x80\x99s name has not been always unspoken, when\r\nminstrels or heralds have praised deeds of chivalry, whether in the\r\nlists or in the battle-field.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo heralds and to minstrels, then, leave thy praise, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9cmore suiting for their mouths than for thine own; and\r\ntell me which of them shall record in song, or in book of tourney, the\r\nmemorable conquest of this night, a conquest obtained over an old man,\r\nfollowed by a few timid hinds; and its booty, an unfortunate maiden,\r\ntransported against her will to the castle of a robber?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are unjust, Lady Rowena,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, biting his lips in some\r\nconfusion, and speaking in a tone more natural to him than that of\r\naffected gallantry, which he had at first adopted; \xe2\x80\x9cyourself free from\r\npassion, you can allow no excuse for the frenzy of another, although\r\ncaused by your own beauty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pray you, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9cto cease a language so commonly\r\nused by strolling minstrels, that it becomes not the mouth of knights\r\nor nobles. Certes, you constrain me to sit down, since you enter upon\r\nsuch commonplace terms, of which each vile crowder hath a stock that\r\nmight last from hence to Christmas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProud damsel,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, incensed at finding his gallant style\r\nprocured him nothing but contempt\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cproud damsel, thou shalt be as\r\nproudly encountered. Know then, that I have supported my pretensions to\r\nyour hand in the way that best suited thy character. It is meeter for\r\nthy humour to be wooed with bow and bill, than in set terms, and in\r\ncourtly language.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCourtesy of tongue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen it is used to veil\r\nchurlishness of deed, is but a knight\xe2\x80\x99s girdle around the breast of a\r\nbase clown. I wonder not that the restraint appears to gall you\xe2\x80\x94more it\r\nwere for your honour to have retained the dress and language of an\r\noutlaw, than to veil the deeds of one under an affectation of gentle\r\nlanguage and demeanour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou counsel well, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Norman; \xe2\x80\x9cand in the bold language\r\nwhich best justifies bold action I tell thee, thou shalt never leave\r\nthis castle, or thou shalt leave it as Maurice de Bracy\xe2\x80\x99s wife. I am\r\nnot wont to be baffled in my enterprises, nor needs a Norman noble\r\nscrupulously to vindicate his conduct to the Saxon maiden whom he\r\ndistinguishes by the offer of his hand. Thou art proud, Rowena, and\r\nthou art the fitter to be my wife. By what other means couldst thou be\r\nraised to high honour and to princely place, saving by my alliance? How\r\nelse wouldst thou escape from the mean precincts of a country grange,\r\nwhere Saxons herd with the swine which form their wealth, to take thy\r\nseat, honoured as thou shouldst be, and shalt be, amid all in England\r\nthat is distinguished by beauty, or dignified by power?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9cthe grange which you contemn hath been\r\nmy shelter from infancy; and, trust me, when I leave it\xe2\x80\x94should that day\r\never arrive\xe2\x80\x94it shall be with one who has not learnt to despise the\r\ndwelling and manners in which I have been brought up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI guess your meaning, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cthough you may think it\r\nlies too obscure for my apprehension. But dream not, that Richard C\xc5\x93ur\r\nde Lion will ever resume his throne, far less that Wilfred of Ivanhoe,\r\nhis minion, will ever lead thee to his footstool, to be there welcomed\r\nas the bride of a favourite. Another suitor might feel jealousy while\r\nhe touched this string; but my firm purpose cannot be changed by a\r\npassion so childish and so hopeless. Know, lady, that this rival is in\r\nmy power, and that it rests but with me to betray the secret of his\r\nbeing within the castle to Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, whose jealousy will be more\r\nfatal than mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWilfred here?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, in disdain; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is as true as that\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf is his rival.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDe Bracy looked at her steadily for an instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWert thou really ignorant of this?\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cdidst thou not know that\r\nWilfred of Ivanhoe travelled in the litter of the Jew?\xe2\x80\x94a meet\r\nconveyance for the crusader, whose doughty arm was to reconquer the\r\nHoly Sepulchre!\xe2\x80\x9d And he laughed scornfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if he is here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, compelling herself to a tone of\r\nindifference, though trembling with an agony of apprehension which she\r\ncould not suppress, \xe2\x80\x9cin what is he the rival of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf? or what\r\nhas he to fear beyond a short imprisonment, and an honourable ransom,\r\naccording to the use of chivalry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRowena,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cart thou, too, deceived by the common error\r\nof thy sex, who think there can be no rivalry but that respecting their\r\nown charms? Knowest thou not there is a jealousy of ambition and of\r\nwealth, as well as of love; and that this our host, Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, will\r\npush from his road him who opposes his claim to the fair barony of\r\nIvanhoe, as readily, eagerly, and unscrupulously, as if he were\r\npreferred to him by some blue-eyed damsel? But smile on my suit, lady,\r\nand the wounded champion shall have nothing to fear from Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\r\nwhom else thou mayst mourn for, as in the hands of one who has never\r\nshown compassion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSave him, for the love of Heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, her firmness giving\r\nway under terror for her lover\xe2\x80\x99s impending fate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x94I will\xe2\x80\x94it is my purpose,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cfor, when Rowena\r\nconsents to be the bride of De Bracy, who is it shall dare to put forth\r\na violent hand upon her kinsman\xe2\x80\x94the son of her guardian\xe2\x80\x94the companion\r\nof her youth? But it is thy love must buy his protection. I am not\r\nromantic fool enough to further the fortune, or avert the fate, of one\r\nwho is likely to be a successful obstacle between me and my wishes. Use\r\nthine influence with me in his behalf, and he is safe,\xe2\x80\x94refuse to employ\r\nit, Wilfred dies, and thou thyself art not the nearer to freedom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy language,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9chath in its indifferent bluntness\r\nsomething which cannot be reconciled with the horrors it seems to\r\nexpress. I believe not that thy purpose is so wicked, or thy power so\r\ngreat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFlatter thyself, then, with that belief,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cuntil time\r\nshall prove it false. Thy lover lies wounded in this castle\xe2\x80\x94thy\r\npreferred lover. He is a bar betwixt Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and that which\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf loves better than either ambition or beauty. What will it\r\ncost beyond the blow of a poniard, or the thrust of a javelin, to\r\nsilence his opposition for ever? Nay, were Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf afraid to\r\njustify a deed so open, let the leech but give his patient a wrong\r\ndraught\xe2\x80\x94let the chamberlain, or the nurse who tends him, but pluck the\r\npillow from his head, and Wilfred in his present condition, is sped\r\nwithout the effusion of blood. Cedric also\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Cedric also,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, repeating his words; \xe2\x80\x9cmy noble\xe2\x80\x94my\r\ngenerous guardian! I deserved the evil I have encountered, for\r\nforgetting his fate even in that of his son!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCedric\xe2\x80\x99s fate also depends upon thy determination,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand I leave thee to form it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHitherto, Rowena had sustained her part in this trying scene with\r\nundismayed courage, but it was because she had not considered the\r\ndanger as serious and imminent. Her disposition was naturally that\r\nwhich physiognomists consider as proper to fair complexions, mild,\r\ntimid, and gentle; but it had been tempered, and, as it were, hardened,\r\nby the circumstances of her education. Accustomed to see the will of\r\nall, even of Cedric himself, (sufficiently arbitrary with others,) give\r\nway before her wishes, she had acquired that sort of courage and\r\nself-confidence which arises from the habitual and constant deference\r\nof the circle in which we move. She could scarce conceive the\r\npossibility of her will being opposed, far less that of its being\r\ntreated with total disregard.\r\n\r\nHer haughtiness and habit of domination was, therefore, a fictitious\r\ncharacter, induced over that which was natural to her, and it deserted\r\nher when her eyes were opened to the extent of her own danger, as well\r\nas that of her lover and her guardian; and when she found her will, the\r\nslightest expression of which was wont to command respect and\r\nattention, now placed in opposition to that of a man of a strong,\r\nfierce, and determined mind, who possessed the advantage over her, and\r\nwas resolved to use it, she quailed before him.\r\n\r\nAfter casting her eyes around, as if to look for the aid which was\r\nnowhere to be found, and after a few broken interjections, she raised\r\nher hands to heaven, and burst into a passion of uncontrolled vexation\r\nand sorrow. It was impossible to see so beautiful a creature in such\r\nextremity without feeling for her, and De Bracy was not unmoved, though\r\nhe was yet more embarrassed than touched. He had, in truth, gone too\r\nfar to recede; and yet, in Rowena\xe2\x80\x99s present condition, she could not be\r\nacted on either by argument or threats. He paced the apartment to and\r\nfro, now vainly exhorting the terrified maiden to compose herself, now\r\nhesitating concerning his own line of conduct.\r\n\r\nIf, thought he, I should be moved by the tears and sorrow of this\r\ndisconsolate damsel, what should I reap but the loss of these fair\r\nhopes for which I have encountered so much risk, and the ridicule of\r\nPrince John and his jovial comrades? \xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nfeel myself ill framed for the part which I am playing. I cannot look\r\non so fair a face while it is disturbed with agony, or on those eyes\r\nwhen they are drowned in tears. I would she had retained her original\r\nhaughtiness of disposition, or that I had a larger share of\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s thrice-tempered hardness of heart!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgitated by these thoughts, he could only bid the unfortunate Rowena be\r\ncomforted, and assure her, that as yet she had no reason for the excess\r\nof despair to which she was now giving way. But in this task of\r\nconsolation De Bracy was interrupted by the horn, \xe2\x80\x9choarse-winded\r\nblowing far and keen,\xe2\x80\x9d which had at the same time alarmed the other\r\ninmates of the castle, and interrupted their several plans of avarice\r\nand of license. Of them all, perhaps, De Bracy least regretted the\r\ninterruption; for his conference with the Lady Rowena had arrived at a\r\npoint, where he found it equally difficult to prosecute or to resign\r\nhis enterprise.\r\n\r\nAnd here we cannot but think it necessary to offer some better proof\r\nthan the incidents of an idle tale, to vindicate the melancholy\r\nrepresentation of manners which has been just laid before the reader.\r\nIt is grievous to think that those valiant barons, to whose stand\r\nagainst the crown the liberties of England were indebted for their\r\nexistence, should themselves have been such dreadful oppressors, and\r\ncapable of excesses contrary not only to the laws of England, but to\r\nthose of nature and humanity. But, alas! we have only to extract from\r\nthe industrious Henry one of those numerous passages which he has\r\ncollected from contemporary historians, to prove that fiction itself\r\ncan hardly reach the dark reality of the horrors of the period.\r\n\r\nThe description given by the author of the Saxon Chronicle of the\r\ncruelties exercised in the reign of King Stephen by the great barons\r\nand lords of castles, who were all Normans, affords a strong proof of\r\nthe excesses of which they were capable when their passions were\r\ninflamed. \xe2\x80\x9cThey grievously oppressed the poor people by building\r\ncastles; and when they were built, they filled them with wicked men, or\r\nrather devils, who seized both men and women who they imagined had any\r\nmoney, threw them into prison, and put them to more cruel tortures than\r\nthe martyrs ever endured. They suffocated some in mud, and suspended\r\nothers by the feet, or the head, or the thumbs, kindling fires below\r\nthem. They squeezed the heads of some with knotted cords till they\r\npierced their brains, while they threw others into dungeons swarming\r\nwith serpents, snakes, and toads.\xe2\x80\x9d But it would be cruel to put the\r\nreader to the pain of perusing the remainder of this description. 29\r\n\r\nAs another instance of these bitter fruits of conquest, and perhaps the\r\nstrongest that can be quoted, we may mention, that the Princess\r\nMatilda, though a daughter of the King of Scotland, and afterwards both\r\nQueen of England, niece to Edgar Atheling, and mother to the Empress of\r\nGermany, the daughter, the wife, and the mother of monarchs, was\r\nobliged, during her early residence for education in England, to assume\r\nthe veil of a nun, as the only means of escaping the licentious pursuit\r\nof the Norman nobles. This excuse she stated before a great council of\r\nthe clergy of England, as the sole reason for her having taken the\r\nreligious habit. The assembled clergy admitted the validity of the\r\nplea, and the notoriety of the circumstances upon which it was founded;\r\ngiving thus an indubitable and most remarkable testimony to the\r\nexistence of that disgraceful license by which that age was stained. It\r\nwas a matter of public knowledge, they said, that after the conquest of\r\nKing William, his Norman followers, elated by so great a victory,\r\nacknowledged no law but their own wicked pleasure, and not only\r\ndespoiled the conquered Saxons of their lands and their goods, but\r\ninvaded the honour of their wives and of their daughters with the most\r\nunbridled license; and hence it was then common for matrons and maidens\r\nof noble families to assume the veil, and take shelter in convents, not\r\nas called thither by the vocation of God, but solely to preserve their\r\nhonour from the unbridled wickedness of man.\r\n\r\nSuch and so licentious were the times, as announced by the public\r\ndeclaration of the assembled clergy, recorded by Eadmer; and we need\r\nadd nothing more to vindicate the probability of the scenes which we\r\nhave detailed, and are about to detail, upon the more apocryphal\r\nauthority of the Wardour MS.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIV\r\n\r\n\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll woo her as the lion woos his bride.\r\n\r\n\r\nDOUGLAS\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile the scenes we have described were passing in other parts of the\r\ncastle, the Jewess Rebecca awaited her fate in a distant and\r\nsequestered turret. Hither she had been led by two of her disguised\r\nravishers, and on being thrust into the little cell, she found herself\r\nin the presence of an old sibyl, who kept murmuring to herself a Saxon\r\nrhyme, as if to beat time to the revolving dance which her spindle was\r\nperforming upon the floor. The hag raised her head as Rebecca entered,\r\nand scowled at the fair Jewess with the malignant envy with which old\r\nage and ugliness, when united with evil conditions, are apt to look\r\nupon youth and beauty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou must up and away, old house-cricket,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the men; \xe2\x80\x9cour\r\nnoble master commands it\xe2\x80\x94Thou must e\xe2\x80\x99en leave this chamber to a fairer\r\nguest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d grumbled the hag, \xe2\x80\x9ceven thus is service requited. I have known\r\nwhen my bare word would have cast the best man-at-arms among ye out of\r\nsaddle and out of service; and now must I up and away at the command of\r\nevery groom such as thou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Dame Urfried,\xe2\x80\x9d said the other man, \xe2\x80\x9cstand not to reason on it,\r\nbut up and away. Lords\xe2\x80\x99 hests must be listened to with a quick ear.\r\nThou hast had thy day, old dame, but thy sun has long been set. Thou\r\nart now the very emblem of an old war-horse turned out on the barren\r\nheath\xe2\x80\x94thou hast had thy paces in thy time, but now a broken amble is\r\nthe best of them\xe2\x80\x94Come, amble off with thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIll omens dog ye both!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old woman; \xe2\x80\x9cand a kennel be your\r\nburying-place! May the evil demon Zernebock tear me limb from limb, if\r\nI leave my own cell ere I have spun out the hemp on my distaff!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnswer it to our lord, then, old housefiend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the man, and\r\nretired; leaving Rebecca in company with the old woman, upon whose\r\npresence she had been thus unwillingly forced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat devil\xe2\x80\x99s deed have they now in the wind?\xe2\x80\x9d said the old hag,\r\nmurmuring to herself, yet from time to time casting a sidelong and\r\nmalignant glance at Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is easy to guess\xe2\x80\x94Bright eyes,\r\nblack locks, and a skin like paper, ere the priest stains it with his\r\nblack unguent\xe2\x80\x94Ay, it is easy to guess why they send her to this lone\r\nturret, whence a shriek could no more be heard than at the depth of\r\nfive hundred fathoms beneath the earth.\xe2\x80\x94Thou wilt have owls for thy\r\nneighbours, fair one; and their screams will be heard as far, and as\r\nmuch regarded, as thine own. Outlandish, too,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, marking the\r\ndress and turban of Rebecca\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhat country art thou of?\xe2\x80\x94a Saracen? or an\r\nEgyptian?\xe2\x80\x94Why dost not answer?\xe2\x80\x94thou canst weep, canst thou not speak?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe not angry, good mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou needst say no more,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Urfried \xe2\x80\x9cmen know a fox by the\r\ntrain, and a Jewess by her tongue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the sake of mercy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9ctell me what I am to expect as\r\nthe conclusion of the violence which hath dragged me hither! Is it my\r\nlife they seek, to atone for my religion? I will lay it down\r\ncheerfully.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy life, minion?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the sibyl; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat would taking thy life\r\npleasure them?\xe2\x80\x94Trust me, thy life is in no peril. Such usage shalt thou\r\nhave as was once thought good enough for a noble Saxon maiden. And\r\nshall a Jewess, like thee, repine because she hath no better? Look at\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94I was as young and twice as fair as thou, when Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, father\r\nof this Reginald, and his Normans, stormed this castle. My father and\r\nhis seven sons defended their inheritance from story to story, from\r\nchamber to chamber\xe2\x80\x94There was not a room, not a step of the stair, that\r\nwas not slippery with their blood. They died\xe2\x80\x94they died every man; and\r\nere their bodies were cold, and ere their blood was dried, I had become\r\nthe prey and the scorn of the conqueror!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there no help?\xe2\x80\x94Are there no means of escape?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cRichly,\r\nrichly would I requite thine aid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink not of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hag; \xe2\x80\x9cfrom hence there is no escape but\r\nthrough the gates of death; and it is late, late,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, shaking\r\nher grey head, \xe2\x80\x9cere these open to us\xe2\x80\x94Yet it is comfort to think that we\r\nleave behind us on earth those who shall be wretched as ourselves. Fare\r\nthee well, Jewess!\xe2\x80\x94Jew or Gentile, thy fate would be the same; for thou\r\nhast to do with them that have neither scruple nor pity. Fare thee\r\nwell, I say. My thread is spun out\xe2\x80\x94thy task is yet to begin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay! stay! for Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cstay, though it be to\r\ncurse and to revile me\xe2\x80\x94thy presence is yet some protection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe presence of the mother of God were no protection,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\r\nold woman. \xe2\x80\x9cThere she stands,\xe2\x80\x9d pointing to a rude image of the Virgin\r\nMary, \xe2\x80\x9csee if she can avert the fate that awaits thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe left the room as she spoke, her features writhed into a sort of\r\nsneering laugh, which made them seem even more hideous than their\r\nhabitual frown. She locked the door behind her, and Rebecca might hear\r\nher curse every step for its steepness, as slowly and with difficulty\r\nshe descended the turret-stair.\r\n\r\nRebecca was now to expect a fate even more dreadful than that of\r\nRowena; for what probability was there that either softness or ceremony\r\nwould be used towards one of her oppressed race, whatever shadow of\r\nthese might be preserved towards a Saxon heiress? Yet had the Jewess\r\nthis advantage, that she was better prepared by habits of thought, and\r\nby natural strength of mind, to encounter the dangers to which she was\r\nexposed. Of a strong and observing character, even from her earliest\r\nyears, the pomp and wealth which her father displayed within his walls,\r\nor which she witnessed in the houses of other wealthy Hebrews, had not\r\nbeen able to blind her to the precarious circumstances under which they\r\nwere enjoyed. Like Damocles at his celebrated banquet, Rebecca\r\nperpetually beheld, amid that gorgeous display, the sword which was\r\nsuspended over the heads of her people by a single hair. These\r\nreflections had tamed and brought down to a pitch of sounder judgment a\r\ntemper, which, under other circumstances, might have waxed haughty,\r\nsupercilious, and obstinate.\r\n\r\nFrom her father\xe2\x80\x99s example and injunctions, Rebecca had learnt to bear\r\nherself courteously towards all who approached her. She could not\r\nindeed imitate his excess of subservience, because she was a stranger\r\nto the meanness of mind, and to the constant state of timid\r\napprehension, by which it was dictated; but she bore herself with a\r\nproud humility, as if submitting to the evil circumstances in which she\r\nwas placed as the daughter of a despised race, while she felt in her\r\nmind the consciousness that she was entitled to hold a higher rank from\r\nher merit, than the arbitrary despotism of religious prejudice\r\npermitted her to aspire to.\r\n\r\nThus prepared to expect adverse circumstances, she had acquired the\r\nfirmness necessary for acting under them. Her present situation\r\nrequired all her presence of mind, and she summoned it up accordingly.\r\n\r\nHer first care was to inspect the apartment; but it afforded few hopes\r\neither of escape or protection. It contained neither secret passage nor\r\ntrap-door, and unless where the door by which she had entered joined\r\nthe main building, seemed to be circumscribed by the round exterior\r\nwall of the turret. The door had no inside bolt or bar. The single\r\nwindow opened upon an embattled space surmounting the turret, which\r\ngave Rebecca, at first sight, some hopes of escaping; but she soon\r\nfound it had no communication with any other part of the battlements,\r\nbeing an isolated bartisan, or balcony, secured, as usual, by a\r\nparapet, with embrasures, at which a few archers might be stationed for\r\ndefending the turret, and flanking with their shot the wall of the\r\ncastle on that side.\r\n\r\nThere was therefore no hope but in passive fortitude, and in that\r\nstrong reliance on Heaven natural to great and generous characters.\r\nRebecca, however erroneously taught to interpret the promises of\r\nScripture to the chosen people of Heaven, did not err in supposing the\r\npresent to be their hour of trial, or in trusting that the children of\r\nZion would be one day called in with the fulness of the Gentiles. In\r\nthe meanwhile, all around her showed that their present state was that\r\nof punishment and probation, and that it was their especial duty to\r\nsuffer without sinning. Thus prepared to consider herself as the victim\r\nof misfortune, Rebecca had early reflected upon her own state, and\r\nschooled her mind to meet the dangers which she had probably to\r\nencounter.\r\n\r\nThe prisoner trembled, however, and changed colour, when a step was\r\nheard on the stair, and the door of the turret-chamber slowly opened,\r\nand a tall man, dressed as one of those banditti to whom they owed\r\ntheir misfortune, slowly entered, and shut the door behind him; his\r\ncap, pulled down upon his brows, concealed the upper part of his face,\r\nand he held his mantle in such a manner as to muffle the rest. In this\r\nguise, as if prepared for the execution of some deed, at the thought of\r\nwhich he was himself ashamed, he stood before the affrighted prisoner;\r\nyet, ruffian as his dress bespoke him, he seemed at a loss to express\r\nwhat purpose had brought him thither, so that Rebecca, making an effort\r\nupon herself, had time to anticipate his explanation. She had already\r\nunclasped two costly bracelets and a collar, which she hastened to\r\nproffer to the supposed outlaw, concluding naturally that to gratify\r\nhis avarice was to bespeak his favour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake these,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cgood friend, and for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake be merciful to\r\nme and my aged father! These ornaments are of value, yet are they\r\ntrifling to what he would bestow to obtain our dismissal from this\r\ncastle, free and uninjured.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFair flower of Palestine,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the outlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cthese pearls are\r\norient, but they yield in whiteness to your teeth; the diamonds are\r\nbrilliant, but they cannot match your eyes; and ever since I have taken\r\nup this wild trade, I have made a vow to prefer beauty to wealth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not do yourself such wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9ctake ransom, and have\r\nmercy!\xe2\x80\x94Gold will purchase you pleasure,\xe2\x80\x94to misuse us, could only bring\r\nthee remorse. My father will willingly satiate thy utmost wishes; and\r\nif thou wilt act wisely, thou mayst purchase with our spoils thy\r\nrestoration to civil society\xe2\x80\x94mayst obtain pardon for past errors, and\r\nbe placed beyond the necessity of committing more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well spoken,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the outlaw in French, finding it difficult\r\nprobably to sustain, in Saxon, a conversation which Rebecca had opened\r\nin that language; \xe2\x80\x9cbut know, bright lily of the vale of Baca! that thy\r\nfather is already in the hands of a powerful alchemist, who knows how\r\nto convert into gold and silver even the rusty bars of a dungeon grate.\r\nThe venerable Isaac is subjected to an alembic, which will distil from\r\nhim all he holds dear, without any assistance from my requests or thy\r\nentreaty. The ransom must be paid by love and beauty, and in no other\r\ncoin will I accept it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art no outlaw,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, in the same language in which he\r\naddressed her; \xe2\x80\x9cno outlaw had refused such offers. No outlaw in this\r\nland uses the dialect in which thou hast spoken. Thou art no outlaw,\r\nbut a Norman\xe2\x80\x94a Norman, noble perhaps in birth\xe2\x80\x94O, be so in thy actions,\r\nand cast off this fearful mask of outrage and violence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou, who canst guess so truly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Brian de Bois-Guilbert,\r\ndropping the mantle from his face, \xe2\x80\x9cart no true daughter of Israel, but\r\nin all, save youth and beauty, a very witch of Endor. I am not an\r\noutlaw, then, fair rose of Sharon. And I am one who will be more prompt\r\nto hang thy neck and arms with pearls and diamonds, which so well\r\nbecome them, than to deprive thee of these ornaments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat wouldst thou have of me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cif not my wealth?\xe2\x80\x94We can\r\nhave nought in common between us\xe2\x80\x94you are a Christian\xe2\x80\x94I am a Jewess.\xe2\x80\x94Our\r\nunion were contrary to the laws, alike of the church and the\r\nsynagogue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt were so, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Templar, laughing; \xe2\x80\x9cwed with a\r\nJewess? \xe2\x80\x98Despardieux!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Not if she were the Queen of Sheba! And know,\r\nbesides, sweet daughter of Zion, that were the most Christian king to\r\noffer me his most Christian daughter, with Languedoc for a dowery, I\r\ncould not wed her. It is against my vow to love any maiden, otherwise\r\nthan \xe2\x80\x98par amours\xe2\x80\x99, as I will love thee. I am a Templar. Behold the\r\ncross of my Holy Order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDarest thou appeal to it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9con an occasion like the\r\npresent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I do so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cit concerns not thee, who art no\r\nbeliever in the blessed sign of our salvation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe as my fathers taught,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cand may God forgive my\r\nbelief if erroneous! But you, Sir Knight, what is yours, when you\r\nappeal without scruple to that which you deem most holy, even while you\r\nare about to transgress the most solemn of your vows as a knight, and\r\nas a man of religion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is gravely and well preached, O daughter of Sirach!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\r\nTemplar; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, gentle Ecclesiastics, thy narrow Jewish prejudices make\r\nthee blind to our high privilege. Marriage were an enduring crime on\r\nthe part of a Templar; but what lesser folly I may practise, I shall\r\nspeedily be absolved from at the next Preceptory of our Order. Not the\r\nwisest of monarchs, not his father, whose examples you must needs allow\r\nare weighty, claimed wider privileges than we poor soldiers of the\r\nTemple of Zion have won by our zeal in its defence. The protectors of\r\nSolomon\xe2\x80\x99s Temple may claim license by the example of Solomon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou readest the Scripture,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jewess, \xe2\x80\x9cand the lives of the\r\nsaints, only to justify thine own license and profligacy, thy crime is\r\nlike that of him who extracts poison from the most healthful and\r\nnecessary herbs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe eyes of the Templar flashed fire at this reproof\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHearken,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cRebecca; I have hitherto spoken mildly to thee, but now my\r\nlanguage shall be that of a conqueror. Thou art the captive of my bow\r\nand spear\xe2\x80\x94subject to my will by the laws of all nations; nor will I\r\nabate an inch of my right, or abstain from taking by violence what thou\r\nrefusest to entreaty or necessity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand back,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cstand back, and hear me ere thou offerest\r\nto commit a sin so deadly! My strength thou mayst indeed overpower for\r\nGod made women weak, and trusted their defence to man\xe2\x80\x99s generosity. But\r\nI will proclaim thy villainy, Templar, from one end of Europe to the\r\nother. I will owe to the superstition of thy brethren what their\r\ncompassion might refuse me, Each Preceptory\xe2\x80\x94each Chapter of thy Order,\r\nshall learn, that, like a heretic, thou hast sinned with a Jewess.\r\nThose who tremble not at thy crime, will hold thee accursed for having\r\nso far dishonoured the cross thou wearest, as to follow a daughter of\r\nmy people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art keen-witted, Jewess,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Templar, well aware of the\r\ntruth of what she spoke, and that the rules of his Order condemned in\r\nthe most positive manner, and under high penalties, such intrigues as\r\nhe now prosecuted, and that, in some instances, even degradation had\r\nfollowed upon it\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthou art sharp-witted,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cbut loud must be\r\nthy voice of complaint, if it is heard beyond the iron walls of this\r\ncastle; within these, murmurs, laments, appeals to justice, and screams\r\nfor help, die alike silent away. One thing only can save thee, Rebecca.\r\nSubmit to thy fate\xe2\x80\x94embrace our religion, and thou shalt go forth in\r\nsuch state, that many a Norman lady shall yield as well in pomp as in\r\nbeauty to the favourite of the best lance among the defenders of the\r\nTemple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSubmit to my fate!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand, sacred Heaven! to what\r\nfate?\xe2\x80\x94embrace thy religion! and what religion can it be that harbours\r\nsuch a villain?\xe2\x80\x94THOU the best lance of the Templars!\xe2\x80\x94Craven\r\nknight!\xe2\x80\x94forsworn priest! I spit at thee, and I defy thee.\xe2\x80\x94The God of\r\nAbraham\xe2\x80\x99s promise hath opened an escape to his daughter\xe2\x80\x94even from this\r\nabyss of infamy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs she spoke, she threw open the latticed window which led to the\r\nbartisan, and in an instant after, stood on the very verge of the\r\nparapet, with not the slightest screen between her and the tremendous\r\ndepth below. Unprepared for such a desperate effort, for she had\r\nhitherto stood perfectly motionless, Bois-Guilbert had neither time to\r\nintercept nor to stop her. As he offered to advance, she exclaimed,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemain where thou art, proud Templar, or at thy choice advance!\xe2\x80\x94one\r\nfoot nearer, and I plunge myself from the precipice; my body shall be\r\ncrushed out of the very form of humanity upon the stones of that\r\ncourt-yard, ere it become the victim of thy brutality!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs she spoke this, she clasped her hands and extended them towards\r\nheaven, as if imploring mercy on her soul before she made the final\r\nplunge. The Templar hesitated, and a resolution which had never yielded\r\nto pity or distress, gave way to his admiration of her fortitude. \xe2\x80\x9cCome\r\ndown,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9crash girl!\xe2\x80\x94I swear by earth, and sea, and sky, I will\r\noffer thee no offence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not trust thee, Templar,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast taught me\r\nbetter how to estimate the virtues of thine Order. The next Preceptory\r\nwould grant thee absolution for an oath, the keeping of which concerned\r\nnought but the honour or the dishonour of a miserable Jewish maiden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do me injustice,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Templar fervently; \xe2\x80\x9cI swear to you\r\nby the name which I bear\xe2\x80\x94by the cross on my bosom\xe2\x80\x94by the sword on my\r\nside\xe2\x80\x94by the ancient crest of my fathers do I swear, I will do thee no\r\ninjury whatsoever! If not for thyself, yet for thy father\xe2\x80\x99s sake\r\nforbear! I will be his friend, and in this castle he will need a\r\npowerful one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cI know it but too well\xe2\x80\x94dare I trust thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay my arms be reversed, and my name dishonoured,\xe2\x80\x9d said Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cif thou shalt have reason to complain of me! Many a\r\nlaw, many a commandment have I broken, but my word never.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will then trust thee,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cthus far;\xe2\x80\x9d and she descended\r\nfrom the verge of the battlement, but remained standing close by one of\r\nthe embrasures, or \xe2\x80\x9cmachicolles\xe2\x80\x9d, as they were then called.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cI take my stand. Remain where thou art, and if thou shalt\r\nattempt to diminish by one step the distance now between us, thou shalt\r\nsee that the Jewish maiden will rather trust her soul with God, than\r\nher honour to the Templar!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile Rebecca spoke thus, her high and firm resolve, which corresponded\r\nso well with the expressive beauty of her countenance, gave to her\r\nlooks, air, and manner, a dignity that seemed more than mortal. Her\r\nglance quailed not, her cheek blanched not, for the fear of a fate so\r\ninstant and so horrible; on the contrary, the thought that she had her\r\nfate at her command, and could escape at will from infamy to death,\r\ngave a yet deeper colour of carnation to her complexion, and a yet more\r\nbrilliant fire to her eye. Bois-Guilbert, proud himself and\r\nhigh-spirited, thought he had never beheld beauty so animated and so\r\ncommanding.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet there be peace between us, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace, if thou wilt,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cPeace\xe2\x80\x94but with this space\r\nbetween.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou needst no longer fear me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear thee not,\xe2\x80\x9d replied she; \xe2\x80\x9cthanks to him that reared this dizzy\r\ntower so high, that nought could fall from it and live\xe2\x80\x94thanks to him,\r\nand to the God of Israel!\xe2\x80\x94I fear thee not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou dost me injustice,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cby earth, sea, and sky,\r\nthou dost me injustice! I am not naturally that which you have seen me,\r\nhard, selfish, and relentless. It was woman that taught me cruelty, and\r\non woman therefore I have exercised it; but not upon such as thou. Hear\r\nme, Rebecca\xe2\x80\x94Never did knight take lance in his hand with a heart more\r\ndevoted to the lady of his love than Brian de Bois-Guilbert. She, the\r\ndaughter of a petty baron, who boasted for all his domains but a\r\nruinous tower, and an unproductive vineyard, and some few leagues of\r\nthe barren Landes of Bourdeaux, her name was known wherever deeds of\r\narms were done, known wider than that of many a lady\xe2\x80\x99s that had a\r\ncounty for a dowery.\xe2\x80\x94Yes,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, pacing up and down the little\r\nplatform, with an animation in which he seemed to lose all\r\nconsciousness of Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s presence\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my deeds, my danger, my\r\nblood, made the name of Adelaide de Montemare known from the court of\r\nCastile to that of Byzantium. And how was I requited?\xe2\x80\x94When I returned\r\nwith my dear-bought honours, purchased by toil and blood, I found her\r\nwedded to a Gascon squire, whose name was never heard beyond the limits\r\nof his own paltry domain! Truly did I love her, and bitterly did I\r\nrevenge me of her broken faith! But my vengeance has recoiled on\r\nmyself. Since that day I have separated myself from life and its\r\nties\xe2\x80\x94My manhood must know no domestic home\xe2\x80\x94must be soothed by no\r\naffectionate wife\xe2\x80\x94My age must know no kindly hearth\xe2\x80\x94My grave must be\r\nsolitary, and no offspring must outlive me, to bear the ancient name of\r\nBois-Guilbert. At the feet of my Superior I have laid down the right of\r\nself-action\xe2\x80\x94the privilege of independence. The Templar, a serf in all\r\nbut the name, can possess neither lands nor goods, and lives, moves,\r\nand breathes, but at the will and pleasure of another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat advantages could compensate for such an\r\nabsolute sacrifice?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe power of vengeance, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cand the\r\nprospects of ambition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn evil recompense,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the surrender of the rights\r\nwhich are dearest to humanity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay not so, maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9crevenge is a feast for the\r\ngods! And if they have reserved it, as priests tell us, to themselves,\r\nit is because they hold it an enjoyment too precious for the possession\r\nof mere mortals.\xe2\x80\x94And ambition? it is a temptation which could disturb\r\neven the bliss of heaven itself.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94He paused a moment, and then added,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca! she who could prefer death to dishonour, must have a proud\r\nand a powerful soul. Mine thou must be!\xe2\x80\x94Nay, start not,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nmust be with thine own consent, and on thine own terms. Thou must\r\nconsent to share with me hopes more extended than can be viewed from\r\nthe throne of a monarch!\xe2\x80\x94Hear me ere you answer and judge ere you\r\nrefuse.\xe2\x80\x94The Templar loses, as thou hast said, his social rights, his\r\npower of free agency, but he becomes a member and a limb of a mighty\r\nbody, before which thrones already tremble,\xe2\x80\x94even as the single drop of\r\nrain which mixes with the sea becomes an individual part of that\r\nresistless ocean, which undermines rocks and ingulfs royal armadas.\r\nSuch a swelling flood is that powerful league. Of this mighty Order I\r\nam no mean member, but already one of the Chief Commanders, and may\r\nwell aspire one day to hold the batoon of Grand Master. The poor\r\nsoldiers of the Temple will not alone place their foot upon the necks\r\nof kings\xe2\x80\x94a hemp-sandall\xe2\x80\x99d monk can do that. Our mailed step shall\r\nascend their throne\xe2\x80\x94our gauntlet shall wrench the sceptre from their\r\ngripe. Not the reign of your vainly-expected Messiah offers such power\r\nto your dispersed tribes as my ambition may aim at. I have sought but a\r\nkindred spirit to share it, and I have found such in thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSayest thou this to one of my people?\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca. \xe2\x80\x9cBethink\r\nthee\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnswer me not,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cby urging the difference of our\r\ncreeds; within our secret conclaves we hold these nursery tales in\r\nderision. Think not we long remained blind to the idiotical folly of\r\nour founders, who forswore every delight of life for the pleasure of\r\ndying martyrs by hunger, by thirst, and by pestilence, and by the\r\nswords of savages, while they vainly strove to defend a barren desert,\r\nvaluable only in the eyes of superstition. Our Order soon adopted\r\nbolder and wider views, and found out a better indemnification for our\r\nsacrifices. Our immense possessions in every kingdom of Europe, our\r\nhigh military fame, which brings within our circle the flower of\r\nchivalry from every Christian clime\xe2\x80\x94these are dedicated to ends of\r\nwhich our pious founders little dreamed, and which are equally\r\nconcealed from such weak spirits as embrace our Order on the ancient\r\nprinciples, and whose superstition makes them our passive tools. But I\r\nwill not further withdraw the veil of our mysteries. That bugle-sound\r\nannounces something which may require my presence. Think on what I have\r\nsaid.\xe2\x80\x94Farewell!\xe2\x80\x94I do not say forgive me the violence I have threatened,\r\nfor it was necessary to the display of thy character. Gold can be only\r\nknown by the application of the touchstone. I will soon return, and\r\nhold further conference with thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe re-entered the turret-chamber, and descended the stair, leaving\r\nRebecca scarcely more terrified at the prospect of the death to which\r\nshe had been so lately exposed, than at the furious ambition of the\r\nbold bad man in whose power she found herself so unhappily placed. When\r\nshe entered the turret-chamber, her first duty was to return thanks to\r\nthe God of Jacob for the protection which he had afforded her, and to\r\nimplore its continuance for her and for her father. Another name glided\r\ninto her petition\xe2\x80\x94it was that of the wounded Christian, whom fate had\r\nplaced in the hands of bloodthirsty men, his avowed enemies. Her heart\r\nindeed checked her, as if, even in communing with the Deity in prayer,\r\nshe mingled in her devotions the recollection of one with whose fate\r\nhers could have no alliance\xe2\x80\x94a Nazarene, and an enemy to her faith. But\r\nthe petition was already breathed, nor could all the narrow prejudices\r\nof her sect induce Rebecca to wish it recalled.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXV\r\n\r\n\r\nA damn\xe2\x80\x99d cramp piece of penmanship as ever I saw in my life!\r\n\r\n\r\nSHE STOOPS TO CONQUER\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the Templar reached the hall of the castle, he found De Bracy\r\nalready there. \xe2\x80\x9cYour love-suit,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9chath, I suppose, been\r\ndisturbed, like mine, by this obstreperous summons. But you have come\r\nlater and more reluctantly, and therefore I presume your interview has\r\nproved more agreeable than mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas your suit, then, been unsuccessfully paid to the Saxon heiress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the Templar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the bones of Thomas a Becket,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Lady Rowena\r\nmust have heard that I cannot endure the sight of women\xe2\x80\x99s tears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAway!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cthou a leader of a Free Company, and regard\r\na woman\xe2\x80\x99s tears! A few drops sprinkled on the torch of love, make the\r\nflame blaze the brighter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGramercy for the few drops of thy sprinkling,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nthis damsel hath wept enough to extinguish a beacon-light. Never was\r\nsuch wringing of hands and such overflowing of eyes, since the days of\r\nSt Niobe, of whom Prior Aymer told us. 30 A water-fiend hath possessed\r\nthe fair Saxon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA legion of fiends have occupied the bosom of the Jewess,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\nTemplar; \xe2\x80\x9cfor, I think no single one, not even Apollyon himself, could\r\nhave inspired such indomitable pride and resolution.\xe2\x80\x94But where is\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf? That horn is sounded more and more clamorously.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is negotiating with the Jew, I suppose,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy, coolly;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cprobably the howls of Isaac have drowned the blast of the bugle. Thou\r\nmayst know, by experience, Sir Brian, that a Jew parting with his\r\ntreasures on such terms as our friend Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf is like to offer,\r\nwill raise a clamour loud enough to be heard over twenty horns and\r\ntrumpets to boot. But we will make the vassals call him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey were soon after joined by Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, who had been disturbed in\r\nhis tyrannic cruelty in the manner with which the reader is acquainted,\r\nand had only tarried to give some necessary directions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us see the cause of this cursed clamour,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9chere\r\nis a letter, and, if I mistake not, it is in Saxon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked at it, turning it round and round as if he had had really\r\nsome hopes of coming at the meaning by inverting the position of the\r\npaper, and then handed it to De Bracy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be magic spells for aught I know,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, who possessed\r\nhis full proportion of the ignorance which characterised the chivalry\r\nof the period. \xe2\x80\x9cOur chaplain attempted to teach me to write,\xe2\x80\x9d he said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut all my letters were formed like spear-heads and sword-blades, and\r\nso the old shaveling gave up the task.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive it me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have that of the priestly\r\ncharacter, that we have some knowledge to enlighten our valour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us profit by your most reverend knowledge, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhat says the scroll?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a formal letter of defiance,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, by our\r\nLady of Bethlehem, if it be not a foolish jest, it is the most\r\nextraordinary cartel that ever was sent across the drawbridge of a\r\nbaronial castle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJest!\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cI would gladly know who dares jest with me\r\nin such a matter!\xe2\x80\x94Read it, Sir Brian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Templar accordingly read it as follows:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI, Wamba, the son of\r\nWitless, Jester to a noble and free-born man, Cedric of Rotherwood,\r\ncalled the Saxon,\xe2\x80\x94And I, Gurth, the son of Beowulph, the swineherd\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art mad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, interrupting the reader.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy St Luke, it is so set down,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar. Then resuming\r\nhis task, he went on,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI, Gurth, the son of Beowulph, swineherd unto\r\nthe said Cedric, with the assistance of our allies and confederates,\r\nwho make common cause with us in this our feud, namely, the good\r\nknight, called for the present \xe2\x80\x98Le Noir Faineant\xe2\x80\x99, and the stout\r\nyeoman, Robert Locksley, called Cleave-the-Wand. Do you, Reginald Front\r\nde-B\xc5\x93uf, and your allies and accomplices whomsoever, to wit, that\r\nwhereas you have, without cause given or feud declared, wrongfully and\r\nby mastery seized upon the person of our lord and master the said\r\nCedric; also upon the person of a noble and freeborn damsel, the Lady\r\nRowena of Hargottstandstede; also upon the person of a noble and\r\nfreeborn man, Athelstane of Coningsburgh; also upon the persons of\r\ncertain freeborn men, their \xe2\x80\x98cnichts\xe2\x80\x99; also upon certain serfs, their\r\nborn bondsmen; also upon a certain Jew, named Isaac of York, together\r\nwith his daughter, a Jewess, and certain horses and mules: Which noble\r\npersons, with their \xe2\x80\x98cnichts\xe2\x80\x99 and slaves, and also with the horses and\r\nmules, Jew and Jewess beforesaid, were all in peace with his majesty,\r\nand travelling as liege subjects upon the king\xe2\x80\x99s highway; therefore we\r\nrequire and demand that the said noble persons, namely, Cedric of\r\nRotherwood, Rowena of Hargottstandstede, Athelstane of Coningsburgh,\r\nwith their servants, \xe2\x80\x98cnichts\xe2\x80\x99, and followers, also the horses and\r\nmules, Jew and Jewess aforesaid, together with all goods and chattels\r\nto them pertaining, be, within an hour after the delivery hereof,\r\ndelivered to us, or to those whom we shall appoint to receive the same,\r\nand that untouched and unharmed in body and goods. Failing of which, we\r\ndo pronounce to you, that we hold ye as robbers and traitors, and will\r\nwager our bodies against ye in battle, siege, or otherwise, and do our\r\nutmost to your annoyance and destruction. Wherefore may God have you in\r\nhis keeping.\xe2\x80\x94Signed by us upon the eve of St Withold\xe2\x80\x99s day, under the\r\ngreat trysting oak in the Hart-hill Walk, the above being written by a\r\nholy man, Clerk to God, our Lady, and St Dunstan, in the Chapel of\r\nCopmanhurst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the bottom of this document was scrawled, in the first place, a rude\r\nsketch of a cock\xe2\x80\x99s head and comb, with a legend expressing this\r\nhieroglyphic to be the sign-manual of Wamba, son of Witless. Under this\r\nrespectable emblem stood a cross, stated to be the mark of Gurth, the\r\nson of Beowulph. Then was written, in rough bold characters, the words,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLe Noir Faineant\xe2\x80\x9d. And, to conclude the whole, an arrow, neatly enough\r\ndrawn, was described as the mark of the yeoman Locksley.\r\n\r\nThe knights heard this uncommon document read from end to end, and then\r\ngazed upon each other in silent amazement, as being utterly at a loss\r\nto know what it could portend. De Bracy was the first to break silence\r\nby an uncontrollable fit of laughter, wherein he was joined, though\r\nwith more moderation, by the Templar. Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, on the contrary,\r\nseemed impatient of their ill-timed jocularity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI give you plain warning,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cfair sirs, that you had better\r\nconsult how to bear yourselves under these circumstances, than give way\r\nto such misplaced merriment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf has not recovered his temper since his late overthrow,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid De Bracy to the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9che is cowed at the very idea of a\r\ncartel, though it come but from a fool and a swineherd.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy St Michael,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cI would thou couldst stand\r\nthe whole brunt of this adventure thyself, De Bracy. These fellows\r\ndared not have acted with such inconceivable impudence, had they not\r\nbeen supported by some strong bands. There are enough of outlaws in\r\nthis forest to resent my protecting the deer. I did but tie one fellow,\r\nwho was taken redhanded and in the fact, to the horns of a wild stag,\r\nwhich gored him to death in five minutes, and I had as many arrows shot\r\nat me as there were launched against yonder target at Ashby.\xe2\x80\x94Here,\r\nfellow,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, to one of his attendants, \xe2\x80\x9chast thou sent out to see\r\nby what force this precious challenge is to be supported?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are at least two hundred men assembled in the woods,\xe2\x80\x9d answered a\r\nsquire who was in attendance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is a proper matter!\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cthis comes of lending\r\nyou the use of my castle, that cannot manage your undertaking quietly,\r\nbut you must bring this nest of hornets about my ears!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf hornets?\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cof stingless drones rather; a band of\r\nlazy knaves, who take to the wood, and destroy the venison rather than\r\nlabour for their maintenance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStingless!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cfork-headed shafts of a cloth-yard\r\nin length, and these shot within the breadth of a French crown, are\r\nsting enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor shame, Sir Knight!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us summon our people,\r\nand sally forth upon them. One knight\xe2\x80\x94ay, one man-at-arms, were enough\r\nfor twenty such peasants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough, and too much,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cI should only be ashamed to\r\ncouch lance against them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cwere they black Turks or Moors, Sir\r\nTemplar, or the craven peasants of France, most valiant De Bracy; but\r\nthese are English yeomen, over whom we shall have no advantage, save\r\nwhat we may derive from our arms and horses, which will avail us little\r\nin the glades of the forest. Sally, saidst thou? we have scarce men\r\nenough to defend the castle. The best of mine are at York; so is all\r\nyour band, De Bracy; and we have scarcely twenty, besides the handful\r\nthat were engaged in this mad business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou dost not fear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cthat they can assemble in\r\nforce sufficient to attempt the castle?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so, Sir Brian,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf. \xe2\x80\x9cThese outlaws have indeed\r\na daring captain; but without machines, scaling ladders, and\r\nexperienced leaders, my castle may defy them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSend to thy neighbours,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9clet them assemble their\r\npeople, and come to the rescue of three knights, besieged by a jester\r\nand a swineherd in the baronial castle of Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou jest, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the baron; \xe2\x80\x9cbut to whom should I\r\nsend?\xe2\x80\x94Malvoisin is by this time at York with his retainers, and so are\r\nmy other allies; and so should I have been, but for this infernal\r\nenterprise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen send to York, and recall our people,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy. \xe2\x80\x9cIf they\r\nabide the shaking of my standard, or the sight of my Free Companions, I\r\nwill give them credit for the boldest outlaws ever bent bow in\r\ngreen-wood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who shall bear such a message?\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cthey will\r\nbeset every path, and rip the errand out of his bosom.\xe2\x80\x94I have it,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nadded, after pausing for a moment\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSir Templar, thou canst write as\r\nwell as read, and if we can but find the writing materials of my\r\nchaplain, who died a twelvemonth since in the midst of his Christmas\r\ncarousals\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo please ye,\xe2\x80\x9d said the squire, who was still in attendance, \xe2\x80\x9cI think\r\nold Urfried has them somewhere in keeping, for love of the confessor.\r\nHe was the last man, I have heard her tell, who ever said aught to her,\r\nwhich man ought in courtesy to address to maid or matron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, search them out, Engelred,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cand then, Sir\r\nTemplar, thou shalt return an answer to this bold challenge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather do it at the sword\xe2\x80\x99s point than at that of the pen,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Bois-Guilbert; \xe2\x80\x9cbut be it as you will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe sat down accordingly, and indited, in the French language, an\r\nepistle of the following tenor:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSir Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, with his\r\nnoble and knightly allies and confederates, receive no defiances at the\r\nhands of slaves, bondsmen, or fugitives.
