If the person calling himself\r\nthe Black Knight have indeed a claim to the honours of chivalry, he\r\nought to know that he stands degraded by his present association, and\r\nhas no right to ask reckoning at the hands of good men of noble blood.\r\nTouching the prisoners we have made, we do in Christian charity require\r\nyou to send a man of religion, to receive their confession, and\r\nreconcile them with God; since it is our fixed intention to execute\r\nthem this morning before noon, so that their heads being placed on the\r\nbattlements, shall show to all men how lightly we esteem those who have\r\nbestirred themselves in their rescue. Wherefore, as above, we require\r\nyou to send a priest to reconcile them to God, in doing which you shall\r\nrender them the last earthly service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis letter being folded, was delivered to the squire, and by him to\r\nthe messenger who waited without, as the answer to that which he had\r\nbrought.\r\n\r\nThe yeoman having thus accomplished his mission, returned to the\r\nhead-quarters of the allies, which were for the present established\r\nunder a venerable oak-tree, about three arrow-flights distant from the\r\ncastle. Here Wamba and Gurth, with their allies the Black Knight and\r\nLocksley, and the jovial hermit, awaited with impatience an answer to\r\ntheir summons. Around, and at a distance from them, were seen many a\r\nbold yeoman, whose silvan dress and weatherbeaten countenances showed\r\nthe ordinary nature of their occupation. More than two hundred had\r\nalready assembled, and others were fast coming in. Those whom they\r\nobeyed as leaders were only distinguished from the others by a feather\r\nin the cap, their dress, arms, and equipments being in all other\r\nrespects the same.\r\n\r\nBesides these bands, a less orderly and a worse armed force, consisting\r\nof the Saxon inhabitants of the neighbouring township, as well as many\r\nbondsmen and servants from Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s extensive estate, had already\r\narrived, for the purpose of assisting in his rescue. Few of these were\r\narmed otherwise than with such rustic weapons as necessity sometimes\r\nconverts to military purposes. Boar-spears, scythes, flails, and the\r\nlike, were their chief arms; for the Normans, with the usual policy of\r\nconquerors, were jealous of permitting to the vanquished Saxons the\r\npossession or the use of swords and spears. These circumstances\r\nrendered the assistance of the Saxons far from being so formidable to\r\nthe besieged, as the strength of the men themselves, their superior\r\nnumbers, and the animation inspired by a just cause, might otherwise\r\nwell have made them. It was to the leaders of this motley army that the\r\nletter of the Templar was now delivered.\r\n\r\nReference was at first made to the chaplain for an exposition of its\r\ncontents.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the crook of St Dunstan,\xe2\x80\x9d said that worthy ecclesiastic, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich\r\nhath brought more sheep within the sheepfold than the crook of e\xe2\x80\x99er\r\nanother saint in Paradise, I swear that I cannot expound unto you this\r\njargon, which, whether it be French or Arabic, is beyond my guess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then gave the letter to Gurth, who shook his head gruffly, and\r\npassed it to Wamba. The Jester looked at each of the four corners of\r\nthe paper with such a grin of affected intelligence as a monkey is apt\r\nto assume upon similar occasions, then cut a caper, and gave the letter\r\nto Locksley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the long letters were bows, and the short letters broad arrows, I\r\nmight know something of the matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the brave yeoman; \xe2\x80\x9cbut as the\r\nmatter stands, the meaning is as safe, for me, as the stag that\xe2\x80\x99s at\r\ntwelve miles distance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must be clerk, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight; and taking the letter\r\nfrom Locksley, he first read it over to himself, and then explained the\r\nmeaning in Saxon to his confederates.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExecute the noble Cedric!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cby the rood, thou must be\r\nmistaken, Sir Knight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I, my worthy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cI have explained the\r\nwords as they are here set down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, by St Thomas of Canterbury,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Gurth, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will have the\r\ncastle, should we tear it down with our hands!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have nothing else to tear it with,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cbut mine are\r\nscarce fit to make mammocks of freestone and mortar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis but a contrivance to gain time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cthey dare not do\r\na deed for which I could exact a fearful penalty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthere were some one among us who\r\ncould obtain admission into the castle, and discover how the case\r\nstands with the besieged. Methinks, as they require a confessor to be\r\nsent, this holy hermit might at once exercise his pious vocation, and\r\nprocure us the information we desire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA plague on thee, and thy advice!\xe2\x80\x9d said the pious hermit; \xe2\x80\x9cI tell\r\nthee, Sir Slothful Knight, that when I doff my friar\xe2\x80\x99s frock, my\r\npriesthood, my sanctity, my very Latin, are put off along with it; and\r\nwhen in my green jerkin, I can better kill twenty deer than confess one\r\nChristian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cI fear greatly, there is no one here\r\nthat is qualified to take upon him, for the nonce, this same character\r\nof father confessor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll looked on each other, and were silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, after a short pause, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the fool must be still\r\nthe fool, and put his neck in the venture which wise men shrink from.\r\nYou must know, my dear cousins and countrymen, that I wore russet\r\nbefore I wore motley, and was bred to be a friar, until a brain-fever\r\ncame upon me and left me just wit enough to be a fool. I trust, with\r\nthe assistance of the good hermit\xe2\x80\x99s frock, together with the\r\npriesthood, sanctity, and learning which are stitched into the cowl of\r\nit, I shall be found qualified to administer both worldly and ghostly\r\ncomfort to our worthy master Cedric, and his companions in adversity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHath he sense enough, thinkst thou?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, addressing\r\nGurth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gurth; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if he hath not, it will be the first\r\ntime he hath wanted wit to turn his folly to account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn with the frock, then, good fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d quoth the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cand let thy\r\nmaster send us an account of their situation within the castle. Their\r\nnumbers must be few, and it is five to one they may be accessible by a\r\nsudden and bold attack. Time wears\xe2\x80\x94away with thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, in the meantime,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will beset the place so\r\nclosely, that not so much as a fly shall carry news from thence. So\r\nthat, my good friend,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, addressing Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cthou mayst\r\nassure these tyrants, that whatever violence they exercise on the\r\npersons of their prisoners, shall be most severely repaid upon their\r\nown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPax vobiscum,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, who was now muffled in his religious\r\ndisguise.\r\n\r\nAnd so saying he imitated the solemn and stately deportment of a friar,\r\nand departed to execute his mission.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVI\r\n\r\n\r\nThe hottest horse will oft be cool,\r\nThe dullest will show fire;\r\nThe friar will often play the fool,\r\nThe fool will play the friar.\r\n\r\n\r\nOLD SONG\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the Jester, arrayed in the cowl and frock of the hermit, and\r\nhaving his knotted cord twisted round his middle, stood before the\r\nportal of the castle of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, the warder demanded of him his\r\nname and errand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPax vobiscum,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a poor brother of the Order\r\nof St Francis, who come hither to do my office to certain unhappy\r\nprisoners now secured within this castle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art a bold friar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the warder, \xe2\x80\x9cto come hither, where,\r\nsaving our own drunken confessor, a cock of thy feather hath not crowed\r\nthese twenty years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet I pray thee, do mine errand to the lord of the castle,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nthe pretended friar; \xe2\x80\x9ctrust me it will find good acceptance with him,\r\nand the cock shall crow, that the whole castle shall hear him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGramercy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the warder; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if I come to shame for leaving my\r\npost upon thine errand, I will try whether a friar\xe2\x80\x99s grey gown be proof\r\nagainst a grey-goose shaft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith this threat he left his turret, and carried to the hall of the\r\ncastle his unwonted intelligence, that a holy friar stood before the\r\ngate and demanded instant admission. With no small wonder he received\r\nhis master\xe2\x80\x99s commands to admit the holy man immediately; and, having\r\npreviously manned the entrance to guard against surprise, he obeyed,\r\nwithout further scruple, the commands which he had received. The\r\nharebrained self-conceit which had emboldened Wamba to undertake this\r\ndangerous office, was scarce sufficient to support him when he found\r\nhimself in the presence of a man so dreadful, and so much dreaded, as\r\nReginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, and he brought out his \xe2\x80\x9cpax vobiscum\xe2\x80\x9d, to which\r\nhe, in a good measure, trusted for supporting his character, with more\r\nanxiety and hesitation than had hitherto accompanied it. But\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf was accustomed to see men of all ranks tremble in his\r\npresence, so that the timidity of the supposed father did not give him\r\nany cause of suspicion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho and whence art thou, priest?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Pax vobiscum\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d reiterated the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a poor servant of St\r\nFrancis, who, travelling through this wilderness, have fallen among\r\nthieves, (as Scripture hath it,) \xe2\x80\x98quidam viator incidit in latrones\xe2\x80\x99,\r\nwhich thieves have sent me unto this castle in order to do my ghostly\r\noffice on two persons condemned by your honourable justice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, right,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cand canst thou tell me, holy\r\nfather, the number of those banditti?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGallant sir,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98nomen illis legio\xe2\x80\x99, their name is\r\nlegion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me in plain terms what numbers there are, or, priest, thy cloak\r\nand cord will ill protect thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said the supposed friar, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98cor meum eructavit\xe2\x80\x99, that is to say,\r\nI was like to burst with fear! but I conceive they may be\xe2\x80\x94what of\r\nyeomen\xe2\x80\x94what of commons, at least five hundred men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, who came into the hall that moment, \xe2\x80\x9cmuster\r\nthe wasps so thick here? it is time to stifle such a mischievous\r\nbrood.\xe2\x80\x9d Then taking Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf aside \xe2\x80\x9cKnowest thou the priest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a stranger from a distant convent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cI know\r\nhim not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen trust him not with thy purpose in words,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him carry a written order to De Bracy\xe2\x80\x99s company of Free\r\nCompanions, to repair instantly to their master\xe2\x80\x99s aid. In the meantime,\r\nand that the shaveling may suspect nothing, permit him to go freely\r\nabout his task of preparing these Saxon hogs for the slaughter-house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt shall be so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf. And he forthwith appointed a\r\ndomestic to conduct Wamba to the apartment where Cedric and Athelstane\r\nwere confined.\r\n\r\nThe impatience of Cedric had been rather enhanced than diminished by\r\nhis confinement. He walked from one end of the hall to the other, with\r\nthe attitude of one who advances to charge an enemy, or to storm the\r\nbreach of a beleaguered place, sometimes ejaculating to himself,\r\nsometimes addressing Athelstane, who stoutly and stoically awaited the\r\nissue of the adventure, digesting, in the meantime, with great\r\ncomposure, the liberal meal which he had made at noon, and not greatly\r\ninteresting himself about the duration of his captivity, which he\r\nconcluded, would, like all earthly evils, find an end in Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s good\r\ntime.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Pax vobiscum\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, entering the apartment; \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nblessing of St Dunstan, St Dennis, St Duthoc, and all other saints\r\nwhatsoever, be upon ye and about ye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnter freely,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric to the supposed friar; \xe2\x80\x9cwith what\r\nintent art thou come hither?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo bid you prepare yourselves for death,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jester.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cedric, starting. \xe2\x80\x9cFearless and wicked as\r\nthey are, they dare not attempt such open and gratuitous cruelty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cto restrain them by their sense of humanity,\r\nis the same as to stop a runaway horse with a bridle of silk thread.\r\nBethink thee, therefore, noble Cedric, and you also, gallant\r\nAthelstane, what crimes you have committed in the flesh; for this very\r\nday will ye be called to answer at a higher tribunal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHearest thou this, Athelstane?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cwe must rouse up our\r\nhearts to this last action, since better it is we should die like men,\r\nthan live like slaves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ready,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cto stand the worst of their malice,\r\nand shall walk to my death with as much composure as ever I did to my\r\ndinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us then unto our holy gear, father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait yet a moment, good uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, in his natural tone;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbetter look long before you leap in the dark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cI should know that voice!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is that of your trusty slave and jester,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Wamba, throwing\r\nback his cowl. \xe2\x80\x9cHad you taken a fool\xe2\x80\x99s advice formerly, you would not\r\nhave been here at all. Take a fool\xe2\x80\x99s advice now, and you will not be\r\nhere long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow mean\xe2\x80\x99st thou, knave?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Saxon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEven thus,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9ctake thou this frock and cord, which are\r\nall the orders I ever had, and march quietly out of the castle, leaving\r\nme your cloak and girdle to take the long leap in thy stead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave thee in my stead!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, astonished at the proposal;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhy, they would hang thee, my poor knave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cE\xe2\x80\x99en let them do as they are permitted,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cI trust\xe2\x80\x94no\r\ndisparagement to your birth\xe2\x80\x94that the son of Witless may hang in a chain\r\nwith as much gravity as the chain hung upon his ancestor the alderman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Wamba,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cfor one thing will I grant thy\r\nrequest. And that is, if thou wilt make the exchange of garments with\r\nLord Athelstane instead of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, by St Dunstan,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cthere were little reason in that.\r\nGood right there is, that the son of Witless should suffer to save the\r\nson of Hereward; but little wisdom there were in his dying for the\r\nbenefit of one whose fathers were strangers to his.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVillain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cthe fathers of Athelstane were monarchs of\r\nEngland!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey might be whomsoever they pleased,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cbut my neck\r\nstands too straight upon my shoulders to have it twisted for their\r\nsake. Wherefore, good my master, either take my proffer yourself, or\r\nsuffer me to leave this dungeon as free as I entered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet the old tree wither,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cso the stately hope of\r\nthe forest be preserved. Save the noble Athelstane, my trusty Wamba! it\r\nis the duty of each who has Saxon blood in his veins. Thou and I will\r\nabide together the utmost rage of our injurious oppressors, while he,\r\nfree and safe, shall arouse the awakened spirits of our countrymen to\r\navenge us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so, father Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, grasping his hand,\xe2\x80\x94for, when\r\nroused to think or act, his deeds and sentiments were not unbecoming\r\nhis high race\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cNot so,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued; \xe2\x80\x9cI would rather remain in this\r\nhall a week without food save the prisoner\xe2\x80\x99s stinted loaf, or drink\r\nsave the prisoner\xe2\x80\x99s measure of water, than embrace the opportunity to\r\nescape which the slave\xe2\x80\x99s untaught kindness has purveyed for his\r\nmaster.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are called wise men, sirs,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cand I a crazed fool;\r\nbut, uncle Cedric, and cousin Athelstane, the fool shall decide this\r\ncontroversy for ye, and save ye the trouble of straining courtesies any\r\nfarther. I am like John-a-Duck\xe2\x80\x99s mare, that will let no man mount her\r\nbut John-a-Duck. I came to save my master, and if he will not\r\nconsent\xe2\x80\x94basta\xe2\x80\x94I can but go away home again. Kind service cannot be\r\nchucked from hand to hand like a shuttlecock or stool-ball. I\xe2\x80\x99ll hang\r\nfor no man but my own born master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, then, noble Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cneglect not this\r\nopportunity. Your presence without may encourage friends to our\r\nrescue\xe2\x80\x94your remaining here would ruin us all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is there any prospect, then, of rescue from without?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric,\r\nlooking to the Jester.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProspect, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9clet me tell you, when you fill my\r\ncloak, you are wrapped in a general\xe2\x80\x99s cassock. Five hundred men are\r\nthere without, and I was this morning one of the chief leaders. My\r\nfool\xe2\x80\x99s cap was a casque, and my bauble a truncheon. Well, we shall see\r\nwhat good they will make by exchanging a fool for a wise man. Truly, I\r\nfear they will lose in valour what they may gain in discretion. And so\r\nfarewell, master, and be kind to poor Gurth and his dog Fangs; and let\r\nmy cockscomb hang in the hall at Rotherwood, in memory that I flung\r\naway my life for my master, like a faithful\xe2\x80\x94-fool.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe last word came out with a sort of double expression, betwixt jest\r\nand earnest. The tears stood in Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy memory shall be preserved,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwhile fidelity and affection\r\nhave honour upon earth! But that I trust I shall find the means of\r\nsaving Rowena, and thee, Athelstane, and thee, also, my poor Wamba,\r\nthou shouldst not overbear me in this matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe exchange of dress was now accomplished, when a sudden doubt struck\r\nCedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know no language,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cbut my own, and a few words of their\r\nmincing Norman. How shall I bear myself like a reverend brother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe spell lies in two words,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Wamba\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Pax vobiscum\xe2\x80\x99 will\r\nanswer all queries. If you go or come, eat or drink, bless or ban, \xe2\x80\x98Pax\r\nvobiscum\xe2\x80\x99 carries you through it all. It is as useful to a friar as a\r\nbroomstick to a witch, or a wand to a conjurer. Speak it but thus, in a\r\ndeep grave tone,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Pax vobiscum!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94it is irresistible\xe2\x80\x94Watch and ward,\r\nknight and squire, foot and horse, it acts as a charm upon them all. I\r\nthink, if they bring me out to be hanged to-morrow, as is much to be\r\ndoubted they may, I will try its weight upon the finisher of the\r\nsentence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf such prove the case,\xe2\x80\x9d said the master, \xe2\x80\x9cmy religious orders are\r\nsoon taken\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Pax vobiscum\xe2\x80\x99. I trust I shall remember the\r\npass-word.\xe2\x80\x94Noble Athelstane, farewell; and farewell, my poor boy, whose\r\nheart might make amends for a weaker head\xe2\x80\x94I will save you, or return\r\nand die with you. The royal blood of our Saxon kings shall not be spilt\r\nwhile mine beats in my veins; nor shall one hair fall from the head of\r\nthe kind knave who risked himself for his master, if Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s peril can\r\nprevent it.\xe2\x80\x94Farewell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, noble Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane; \xe2\x80\x9cremember it is the true\r\npart of a friar to accept refreshment, if you are offered any.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, uncle,\xe2\x80\x9d added Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cand remember \xe2\x80\x98Pax vobiscum\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus exhorted, Cedric sallied forth upon his expedition; and it was not\r\nlong ere he had occasion to try the force of that spell which his\r\nJester had recommended as omnipotent. In a low-arched and dusky\r\npassage, by which he endeavoured to work his way to the hall of the\r\ncastle, he was interrupted by a female form.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Pax vobiscum!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d said the pseudo friar, and was endeavouring to hurry\r\npast, when a soft voice replied, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Et vobis\xe2\x80\x94quaso, domine\r\nreverendissime, pro misericordia vestra\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am somewhat deaf,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cedric, in good Saxon, and at the same\r\ntime muttered to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cA curse on the fool and his \xe2\x80\x98Pax vobiscum!\xe2\x80\x99\r\nI have lost my javelin at the first cast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was, however, no unusual thing for a priest of those days to be deaf\r\nof his Latin ear, and this the person who now addressed Cedric knew\r\nfull well.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pray you of dear love, reverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied in his own\r\nlanguage, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you will deign to visit with your ghostly comfort a\r\nwounded prisoner of this castle, and have such compassion upon him and\r\nus as thy holy office teaches\xe2\x80\x94Never shall good deed so highly advantage\r\nthy convent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDaughter,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric, much embarrassed, \xe2\x80\x9cmy time in this castle\r\nwill not permit me to exercise the duties of mine office\xe2\x80\x94I must\r\npresently forth\xe2\x80\x94there is life and death upon my speed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet, father, let me entreat you by the vow you have taken on you,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied the suppliant, \xe2\x80\x9cnot to leave the oppressed and endangered\r\nwithout counsel or succour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the fiend fly away with me, and leave me in Ifrin with the souls\r\nof Odin and of Thor!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric impatiently, and would probably\r\nhave proceeded in the same tone of total departure from his spiritual\r\ncharacter, when the colloquy was interrupted by the harsh voice of\r\nUrfried, the old crone of the turret.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, minion,\xe2\x80\x9d said she to the female speaker, \xe2\x80\x9cis this the manner in\r\nwhich you requite the kindness which permitted thee to leave thy\r\nprison-cell yonder?\xe2\x80\x94Puttest thou the reverend man to use ungracious\r\nlanguage to free himself from the importunities of a Jewess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Jewess!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, availing himself of the information to get\r\nclear of their interruption,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLet me pass, woman! stop me not at your\r\nperil. I am fresh from my holy office, and would avoid pollution.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome this way, father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old hag, \xe2\x80\x9cthou art a stranger in this\r\ncastle, and canst not leave it without a guide. Come hither, for I\r\nwould speak with thee.\xe2\x80\x94And you, daughter of an accursed race, go to the\r\nsick man\xe2\x80\x99s chamber, and tend him until my return; and woe betide you if\r\nyou again quit it without my permission!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRebecca retreated. Her importunities had prevailed upon Urfried to\r\nsuffer her to quit the turret, and Urfried had employed her services\r\nwhere she herself would most gladly have paid them, by the bedside of\r\nthe wounded Ivanhoe. With an understanding awake to their dangerous\r\nsituation, and prompt to avail herself of each means of safety which\r\noccurred, Rebecca had hoped something from the presence of a man of\r\nreligion, who, she learned from Urfried, had penetrated into this\r\ngodless castle. She watched the return of the supposed ecclesiastic,\r\nwith the purpose of addressing him, and interesting him in favour of\r\nthe prisoners; with what imperfect success the reader has been just\r\nacquainted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVII\r\n\r\n\r\nFond wretch! and what canst thou relate,\r\nBut deeds of sorrow, shame, and sin?\r\nThy deeds are proved\xe2\x80\x94thou know\xe2\x80\x99st thy fate;\r\nBut come, thy tale\xe2\x80\x94begin\xe2\x80\x94begin.\r\n\r\nBut I have griefs of other kind,\r\nTroubles and sorrows more severe;\r\nGive me to ease my tortured mind,\r\nLend to my woes a patient ear;\r\nAnd let me, if I may not find\r\nA friend to help\xe2\x80\x94find one to hear.\r\n\r\n\r\nCRABBE\xe2\x80\x99S HALL OF JUSTICE\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Urfried had with clamours and menaces driven Rebecca back to the\r\napartment from which she had sallied, she proceeded to conduct the\r\nunwilling Cedric into a small apartment, the door of which she\r\nheedfully secured. Then fetching from a cupboard a stoup of wine and\r\ntwo flagons, she placed them on the table, and said in a tone rather\r\nasserting a fact than asking a question, \xe2\x80\x9cThou art Saxon, father\xe2\x80\x94Deny\r\nit not,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, observing that Cedric hastened not to reply;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe sounds of my native language are sweet to mine ears, though seldom\r\nheard save from the tongues of the wretched and degraded serfs on whom\r\nthe proud Normans impose the meanest drudgery of this dwelling. Thou\r\nart a Saxon, father\xe2\x80\x94a Saxon, and, save as thou art a servant of God, a\r\nfreeman.\xe2\x80\x94Thine accents are sweet in mine ear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not Saxon priests visit this castle, then?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nwere, methinks, their duty to comfort the outcast and oppressed\r\nchildren of the soil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey come not\xe2\x80\x94or if they come, they better love to revel at the boards\r\nof their conquerors,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Urfried, \xe2\x80\x9cthan to hear the groans of\r\ntheir countrymen\xe2\x80\x94so, at least, report speaks of them\xe2\x80\x94of myself I can\r\nsay little. This castle, for ten years, has opened to no priest save\r\nthe debauched Norman chaplain who partook the nightly revels of\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf, and he has been long gone to render an account of his\r\nstewardship.\xe2\x80\x94But thou art a Saxon\xe2\x80\x94a Saxon priest, and I have one\r\nquestion to ask of thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a Saxon,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cbut unworthy, surely, of the name of\r\npriest. Let me begone on my way\xe2\x80\x94I swear I will return, or send one of\r\nour fathers more worthy to hear your confession.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay yet a while,\xe2\x80\x9d said Urfried; \xe2\x80\x9cthe accents of the voice which thou\r\nhearest now will soon be choked with the cold earth, and I would not\r\ndescend to it like the beast I have lived. But wine must give me\r\nstrength to tell the horrors of my tale.\xe2\x80\x9d She poured out a cup, and\r\ndrank it with a frightful avidity, which seemed desirous of draining\r\nthe last drop in the goblet. \xe2\x80\x9cIt stupifies,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, looking upwards\r\nas she finished her drought, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it cannot cheer\xe2\x80\x94Partake it, father,\r\nif you would hear my tale without sinking down upon the pavement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nCedric would have avoided pledging her in this ominous conviviality,\r\nbut the sign which she made to him expressed impatience and despair. He\r\ncomplied with her request, and answered her challenge in a large\r\nwine-cup; she then proceeded with her story, as if appeased by his\r\ncomplaisance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was not born,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cfather, the wretch that thou now seest me.\r\nI was free, was happy, was honoured, loved, and was beloved. I am now a\r\nslave, miserable and degraded\xe2\x80\x94the sport of my masters\xe2\x80\x99 passions while I\r\nhad yet beauty\xe2\x80\x94the object of their contempt, scorn, and hatred, since\r\nit has passed away. Dost thou wonder, father, that I should hate\r\nmankind, and, above all, the race that has wrought this change in me?\r\nCan the wrinkled decrepit hag before thee, whose wrath must vent itself\r\nin impotent curses, forget she was once the daughter of the noble Thane\r\nof Torquilstone, before whose frown a thousand vassals trembled?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou the daughter of Torquil Wolfganger!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, receding as he\r\nspoke; \xe2\x80\x9cthou\xe2\x80\x94thou\xe2\x80\x94the daughter of that noble Saxon, my father\xe2\x80\x99s friend\r\nand companion in arms!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy father\xe2\x80\x99s friend!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Urfried; \xe2\x80\x9cthen Cedric called the Saxon\r\nstands before me, for the noble Hereward of Rotherwood had but one son,\r\nwhose name is well known among his countrymen. But if thou art Cedric\r\nof Rotherwood, why this religious dress?\xe2\x80\x94hast thou too despaired of\r\nsaving thy country, and sought refuge from oppression in the shade of\r\nthe convent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt matters not who I am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cproceed, unhappy woman, with\r\nthy tale of horror and guilt!\xe2\x80\x94Guilt there must be\xe2\x80\x94there is guilt even\r\nin thy living to tell it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is\xe2\x80\x94there is,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the wretched woman, \xe2\x80\x9cdeep, black, damning\r\nguilt,\xe2\x80\x94guilt, that lies like a load at my breast\xe2\x80\x94guilt, that all the\r\npenitential fires of hereafter cannot cleanse.\xe2\x80\x94Yes, in these halls,\r\nstained with the noble and pure blood of my father and my brethren\xe2\x80\x94in\r\nthese very halls, to have lived the paramour of their murderer, the\r\nslave at once and the partaker of his pleasures, was to render every\r\nbreath which I drew of vital air, a crime and a curse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWretched woman!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Cedric. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd while the friends of thy\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x94while each true Saxon heart, as it breathed a requiem for his\r\nsoul, and those of his valiant sons, forgot not in their prayers the\r\nmurdered Ulrica\xe2\x80\x94while all mourned and honoured the dead, thou hast\r\nlived to merit our hate and execration\xe2\x80\x94lived to unite thyself with the\r\nvile tyrant who murdered thy nearest and dearest\xe2\x80\x94who shed the blood of\r\ninfancy, rather than a male of the noble house of Torquil Wolfganger\r\nshould survive\xe2\x80\x94with him hast thou lived to unite thyself, and in the\r\nhands of lawless love!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn lawless hands, indeed, but not in those of love!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the hag;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clove will sooner visit the regions of eternal doom, than those\r\nunhallowed vaults.\xe2\x80\x94No, with that at least I cannot reproach\r\nmyself\xe2\x80\x94hatred to Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and his race governed my soul most\r\ndeeply, even in the hour of his guilty endearments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou hated him, and yet you lived,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cwretch! was there\r\nno poniard\xe2\x80\x94no knife\xe2\x80\x94no bodkin!\xe2\x80\x94Well was it for thee, since thou didst\r\nprize such an existence, that the secrets of a Norman castle are like\r\nthose of the grave. For had I but dreamed of the daughter of Torquil\r\nliving in foul communion with the murderer of her father, the sword of\r\na true Saxon had found thee out even in the arms of thy paramour!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWouldst thou indeed have done this justice to the name of Torquil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Ulrica, for we may now lay aside her assumed name of Urfried;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthou art then the true Saxon report speaks thee! for even within these\r\naccursed walls, where, as thou well sayest, guilt shrouds itself in\r\ninscrutable mystery, even there has the name of Cedric been sounded\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nI, wretched and degraded, have rejoiced to think that there yet\r\nbreathed an avenger of our unhappy nation.\xe2\x80\x94I also have had my hours of\r\nvengeance\xe2\x80\x94I have fomented the quarrels of our foes, and heated drunken\r\nrevelry into murderous broil\xe2\x80\x94I have seen their blood flow\xe2\x80\x94I have heard\r\ntheir dying groans!\xe2\x80\x94Look on me, Cedric\xe2\x80\x94are there not still left on this\r\nfoul and faded face some traces of the features of Torquil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk me not of them, Ulrica,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Cedric, in a tone of grief mixed\r\nwith abhorrence; \xe2\x80\x9cthese traces form such a resemblance as arises from\r\nthe graves of the dead, when a fiend has animated the lifeless corpse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ulrica; \xe2\x80\x9cyet wore these fiendish features the mask\r\nof a spirit of light when they were able to set at variance the elder\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf and his son Reginald! The darkness of hell should hide\r\nwhat followed, but revenge must lift the veil, and darkly intimate what\r\nit would raise the dead to speak aloud. Long had the smouldering fire\r\nof discord glowed between the tyrant father and his savage son\xe2\x80\x94long had\r\nI nursed, in secret, the unnatural hatred\xe2\x80\x94it blazed forth in an hour of\r\ndrunken wassail, and at his own board fell my oppressor by the hand of\r\nhis own son\xe2\x80\x94such are the secrets these vaults conceal!\xe2\x80\x94Rend asunder, ye\r\naccursed arches,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, looking up towards the roof, \xe2\x80\x9cand bury in\r\nyour fall all who are conscious of the hideous mystery!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou, creature of guilt and misery,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat became thy\r\nlot on the death of thy ravisher?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGuess it, but ask it not.\xe2\x80\x94Here\xe2\x80\x94here I dwelt, till age, premature age,\r\nhas stamped its ghastly features on my countenance\xe2\x80\x94scorned and insulted\r\nwhere I was once obeyed, and compelled to bound the revenge which had\r\nonce such ample scope, to the efforts of petty malice of a discontented\r\nmenial, or the vain or unheeded curses of an impotent hag\xe2\x80\x94condemned to\r\nhear from my lonely turret the sounds of revelry in which I once\r\npartook, or the shrieks and groans of new victims of oppression.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUlrica,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cwith a heart which still, I fear, regrets the\r\nlost reward of thy crimes, as much as the deeds by which thou didst\r\nacquire that meed, how didst thou dare to address thee to one who wears\r\nthis robe? Consider, unhappy woman, what could the sainted Edward\r\nhimself do for thee, were he here in bodily presence? The royal\r\nConfessor was endowed by heaven with power to cleanse the ulcers of the\r\nbody, but only God himself can cure the leprosy of the soul.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet, turn not from me, stern prophet of wrath,\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\ntell me, if thou canst, in what shall terminate these new and awful\r\nfeelings that burst on my solitude\xe2\x80\x94Why do deeds, long since done, rise\r\nbefore me in new and irresistible horrors? What fate is prepared beyond\r\nthe grave for her, to whom God has assigned on earth a lot of such\r\nunspeakable wretchedness? Better had I turn to Woden, Hertha, and\r\nZernebock\xe2\x80\x94to Mista, and to Skogula, the gods of our yet unbaptized\r\nancestors, than endure the dreadful anticipations which have of late\r\nhaunted my waking and my sleeping hours!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am no priest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, turning with disgust from this miserable\r\npicture of guilt, wretchedness, and despair; \xe2\x80\x9cI am no priest, though I\r\nwear a priest\xe2\x80\x99s garment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPriest or layman,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ulrica, \xe2\x80\x9cthou art the first I have seen\r\nfor twenty years, by whom God was feared or man regarded; and dost thou\r\nbid me despair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI bid thee repent,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric. \xe2\x80\x9cSeek to prayer and penance, and\r\nmayest thou find acceptance! But I cannot, I will not, longer abide\r\nwith thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay yet a moment!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ulrica; \xe2\x80\x9cleave me not now, son of my father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfriend, lest the demon who has governed my life should tempt me to\r\navenge myself of thy hard-hearted scorn\xe2\x80\x94Thinkest thou, if Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\r\nfound Cedric the Saxon in his castle, in such a disguise, that thy life\r\nwould be a long one?\xe2\x80\x94Already his eye has been upon thee like a falcon\r\non his prey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd be it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cand let him tear me with beak and talons,\r\nere my tongue say one word which my heart doth not warrant. I will die\r\na Saxon\xe2\x80\x94true in word, open in deed\xe2\x80\x94I bid thee avaunt!\xe2\x80\x94touch me not,\r\nstay me not!\xe2\x80\x94The sight of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf himself is less odious to me\r\nthan thou, degraded and degenerate as thou art.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ulrica, no longer interrupting him; \xe2\x80\x9cgo thy way, and\r\nforget, in the insolence of thy superority, that the wretch before thee\r\nis the daughter of thy father\xe2\x80\x99s friend.\xe2\x80\x94Go thy way\xe2\x80\x94if I am separated\r\nfrom mankind by my sufferings\xe2\x80\x94separated from those whose aid I might\r\nmost justly expect\xe2\x80\x94not less will I be separated from them in my\r\nrevenge!\xe2\x80\x94No man shall aid me, but the ears of all men shall tingle to\r\nhear of the deed which I shall dare to do!\xe2\x80\x94Farewell!\xe2\x80\x94thy scorn has\r\nburst the last tie which seemed yet to unite me to my kind\xe2\x80\x94a thought\r\nthat my woes might claim the compassion of my people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUlrica,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, softened by this appeal, \xe2\x80\x9chast thou borne up and\r\nendured to live through so much guilt and so much misery, and wilt thou\r\nnow yield to despair when thine eyes are opened to thy crimes, and when\r\nrepentance were thy fitter occupation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCedric,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ulrica, \xe2\x80\x9cthou little knowest the human heart. To act\r\nas I have acted, to think as I have thought, requires the maddening\r\nlove of pleasure, mingled with the keen appetite of revenge, the proud\r\nconsciousness of power; droughts too intoxicating for the human heart\r\nto bear, and yet retain the power to prevent. Their force has long\r\npassed away\xe2\x80\x94Age has no pleasures, wrinkles have no influence, revenge\r\nitself dies away in impotent curses. Then comes remorse, with all its\r\nvipers, mixed with vain regrets for the past, and despair for the\r\nfuture!\xe2\x80\x94Then, when all other strong impulses have ceased, we become\r\nlike the fiends in hell, who may feel remorse, but never\r\nrepentance.\xe2\x80\x94But thy words have awakened a new soul within me\xe2\x80\x94Well hast\r\nthou said, all is possible for those who dare to die!\xe2\x80\x94Thou hast shown\r\nme the means of revenge, and be assured I will embrace them. It has\r\nhitherto shared this wasted bosom with other and with rival\r\npassions\xe2\x80\x94henceforward it shall possess me wholly, and thou thyself\r\nshalt say, that, whatever was the life of Ulrica, her death well became\r\nthe daughter of the noble Torquil. There is a force without\r\nbeleaguering this accursed castle\xe2\x80\x94hasten to lead them to the attack,\r\nand when thou shalt see a red flag wave from the turret on the eastern\r\nangle of the donjon, press the Normans hard\xe2\x80\x94they will then have enough\r\nto do within, and you may win the wall in spite both of bow and\r\nmangonel.\xe2\x80\x94Begone, I pray thee\xe2\x80\x94follow thine own fate, and leave me to\r\nmine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCedric would have enquired farther into the purpose which she thus\r\ndarkly announced, but the stern voice of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf was heard,\r\nexclaiming, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere tarries this loitering priest? By the scallop-shell\r\nof Compostella, I will make a martyr of him, if he loiters here to\r\nhatch treason among my domestics!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a true prophet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ulrica, \xe2\x80\x9cis an evil conscience! But heed\r\nhim not\xe2\x80\x94out and to thy people\xe2\x80\x94Cry your Saxon onslaught, and let them\r\nsing their war-song of Rollo, if they will; vengeance shall bear a\r\nburden to it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs she thus spoke, she vanished through a private door, and Reginald\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf entered the apartment. Cedric, with some difficulty,\r\ncompelled himself to make obeisance to the haughty Baron, who returned\r\nhis courtesy with a slight inclination of the head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy penitents, father, have made a long shrift\xe2\x80\x94it is the better for\r\nthem, since it is the last they shall ever make. Hast thou prepared\r\nthem for death?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI found them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, in such French as he could command,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cexpecting the worst, from the moment they knew into whose power they\r\nhad fallen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow now, Sir Friar,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cthy speech, methinks,\r\nsmacks of a Saxon tongue?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was bred in the convent of St Withold of Burton,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Baron; \xe2\x80\x9cit had been better for thee to have been a\r\nNorman, and better for my purpose too; but need has no choice of\r\nmessengers. That St Withold\xe2\x80\x99s of Burton is an owlet\xe2\x80\x99s nest worth the\r\nharrying. The day will soon come that the frock shall protect the Saxon\r\nas little as the mail-coat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x99s will be done,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, in a voice tremulous with passion,\r\nwhich Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf imputed to fear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthou dreamest already that our men-at-arms are in\r\nthy refectory and thy ale-vaults. But do me one cast of thy holy\r\noffice, and, come what list of others, thou shalt sleep as safe in thy\r\ncell as a snail within his shell of proof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak your commands,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, with suppressed emotion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFollow me through this passage, then, that I may dismiss thee by the\r\npostern.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd as he strode on his way before the supposed friar, Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\r\nthus schooled him in the part which he desired he should act.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou seest, Sir Friar, yon herd of Saxon swine, who have dared to\r\nenviron this castle of Torquilstone\xe2\x80\x94Tell them whatever thou hast a mind\r\nof the weakness of this fortalice, or aught else that can detain them\r\nbefore it for twenty-four hours. Meantime bear thou this scroll\xe2\x80\x94But\r\nsoft\xe2\x80\x94canst read, Sir Priest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a jot I,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9csave on my breviary; and then I know\r\nthe characters, because I have the holy service by heart, praised be\r\nOur Lady and St Withold!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fitter messenger for my purpose.\xe2\x80\x94Carry thou this scroll to the\r\ncastle of Philip de Malvoisin; say it cometh from me, and is written by\r\nthe Templar Brian de Bois-Guilbert, and that I pray him to send it to\r\nYork with all the speed man and horse can make. Meanwhile, tell him to\r\ndoubt nothing, he shall find us whole and sound behind our\r\nbattlement\xe2\x80\x94Shame on it, that we should be compelled to hide thus by a\r\npack of runagates, who are wont to fly even at the flash of our pennons\r\nand the tramp of our horses! I say to thee, priest, contrive some cast\r\nof thine art to keep the knaves where they are, until our friends bring\r\nup their lances. My vengeance is awake, and she is a falcon that\r\nslumbers not till she has been gorged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my patron saint,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, with deeper energy than became his\r\ncharacter, \xe2\x80\x9cand by every saint who has lived and died in England, your\r\ncommands shall be obeyed! Not a Saxon shall stir from before these\r\nwalls, if I have art and influence to detain them there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa!\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cthou changest thy tone, Sir Priest, and\r\nspeakest brief and bold, as if thy heart were in the slaughter of the\r\nSaxon herd; and yet thou art thyself of kindred to the swine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCedric was no ready practiser of the art of dissimulation, and would at\r\nthis moment have been much the better of a hint from Wamba\xe2\x80\x99s more\r\nfertile brain. But necessity, according to the ancient proverb,\r\nsharpens invention, and he muttered something under his cowl concerning\r\nthe men in question being excommunicated outlaws both to church and to\r\nkingdom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Despardieux\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast spoken the very\r\ntruth\xe2\x80\x94I forgot that the knaves can strip a fat abbot, as well as if\r\nthey had been born south of yonder salt channel. Was it not he of St\r\nIves whom they tied to an oak-tree, and compelled to sing a mass while\r\nthey were rifling his mails and his wallets?\xe2\x80\x94No, by our Lady\xe2\x80\x94that jest\r\nwas played by Gualtier of Middleton, one of our own companions-at-arms.\r\nBut they were Saxons who robbed the chapel at St Bees of cup,\r\ncandlestick and chalice, were they not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey were godless men,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, and they drank out all the good wine and ale that lay in store for\r\nmany a secret carousal, when ye pretend ye are but busied with vigils\r\nand primes!\xe2\x80\x94Priest, thou art bound to revenge such sacrilege.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am indeed bound to vengeance,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cSaint Withold knows\r\nmy heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf, in the meanwhile, led the way to a postern, where,\r\npassing the moat on a single plank, they reached a small barbican, or\r\nexterior defence, which communicated with the open field by a\r\nwell-fortified sallyport.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBegone, then; and if thou wilt do mine errand, and if thou return\r\nhither when it is done, thou shalt see Saxon flesh cheap as ever was\r\nhog\xe2\x80\x99s in the shambles of Sheffield. And, hark thee, thou seemest to be\r\na jolly confessor\xe2\x80\x94come hither after the onslaught, and thou shalt have\r\nas much Malvoisie as would drench thy whole convent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAssuredly we shall meet again,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething in hand the whilst,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the Norman; and, as they\r\nparted at the postern door, he thrust into Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s reluctant hand a\r\ngold byzant, adding, \xe2\x80\x9cRemember, I will fly off both cowl and skin, if\r\nthou failest in thy purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd full leave will I give thee to do both,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric, leaving\r\nthe postern, and striding forth over the free field with a joyful step,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif, when we meet next, I deserve not better at thine hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Turning\r\nthen back towards the castle, he threw the piece of gold towards the\r\ndonor, exclaiming at the same time, \xe2\x80\x9cFalse Norman, thy money perish\r\nwith thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf heard the words imperfectly, but the action was\r\nsuspicious\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cArchers,\xe2\x80\x9d he called to the warders on the outward\r\nbattlements, \xe2\x80\x9csend me an arrow through yon monk\xe2\x80\x99s frock!\xe2\x80\x94yet stay,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, as his retainers were bending their bows, \xe2\x80\x9cit avails not\xe2\x80\x94we must\r\nthus far trust him since we have no better shift. I think he dares not\r\nbetray me\xe2\x80\x94at the worst I can but treat with these Saxon dogs whom I\r\nhave safe in kennel.\xe2\x80\x94Ho! Giles jailor, let them bring Cedric of\r\nRotherwood before me, and the other churl, his companion\xe2\x80\x94him I mean of\r\nConingsburgh\xe2\x80\x94Athelstane there, or what call they him? Their very names\r\nare an encumbrance to a Norman knight\xe2\x80\x99s mouth, and have, as it were, a\r\nflavour of bacon\xe2\x80\x94Give me a stoup of wine, as jolly Prince John said,\r\nthat I may wash away the relish\xe2\x80\x94place it in the armoury, and thither\r\nlead the prisoners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis commands were obeyed; and, upon entering that Gothic apartment,\r\nhung with many spoils won by his own valour and that of his father, he\r\nfound a flagon of wine on the massive oaken table, and the two Saxon\r\ncaptives under the guard of four of his dependants. Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf took\r\na long drought of wine, and then addressed his prisoners;\xe2\x80\x94for the\r\nmanner in which Wamba drew the cap over his face, the change of dress,\r\nthe gloomy and broken light, and the Baron\xe2\x80\x99s imperfect acquaintance\r\nwith the features of Cedric, (who avoided his Norman neighbours, and\r\nseldom stirred beyond his own domains,) prevented him from discovering\r\nthat the most important of his captives had made his escape.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGallants of England,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9chow relish ye your\r\nentertainment at Torquilstone?\xe2\x80\x94Are ye yet aware what your \xe2\x80\x98surquedy\xe2\x80\x99\r\nand \xe2\x80\x98outrecuidance\xe2\x80\x99 31 merit, for scoffing at the entertainment of a\r\nprince of the House of Anjou?\xe2\x80\x94Have ye forgotten how ye requited the\r\nunmerited hospitality of the royal John? By God and St Dennis, an ye\r\npay not the richer ransom, I will hang ye up by the feet from the iron\r\nbars of these windows, till the kites and hooded crows have made\r\nskeletons of you!\xe2\x80\x94Speak out, ye Saxon dogs\xe2\x80\x94what bid ye for your\r\nworthless lives?\xe2\x80\x94How say you, you of Rotherwood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a doit I,\xe2\x80\x9d answered poor Wamba\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand for hanging up by the feet, my\r\nbrain has been topsy-turvy, they say, ever since the biggin was bound\r\nfirst round my head; so turning me upside down may peradventure restore\r\nit again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaint Genevieve!\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat have we got here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd with the back of his hand he struck Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s cap from the head of\r\nthe Jester, and throwing open his collar, discovered the fatal badge of\r\nservitude, the silver collar round his neck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGiles\xe2\x80\x94Clement\xe2\x80\x94dogs and varlets!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the furious Norman, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\r\nhave you brought me here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I can tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, who just entered the\r\napartment. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s clown, who fought so manful a skirmish\r\nwith Isaac of York about a question of precedence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall settle it for them both,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cthey shall\r\nhang on the same gallows, unless his master and this boar of\r\nConingsburgh will pay well for their lives. Their wealth is the least\r\nthey can surrender; they must also carry off with them the swarms that\r\nare besetting the castle, subscribe a surrender of their pretended\r\nimmunities, and live under us as serfs and vassals; too happy if, in\r\nthe new world that is about to begin, we leave them the breath of their\r\nnostrils.\xe2\x80\x94Go,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to two of his attendants, \xe2\x80\x9cfetch me the right\r\nCedric hither, and I pardon your error for once; the rather that you\r\nbut mistook a fool for a Saxon franklin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cyour chivalrous excellency will find there are\r\nmore fools than franklins among us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat means the knave?\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, looking towards his\r\nfollowers, who, lingering and loath, faltered forth their belief, that\r\nif this were not Cedric who was there in presence, they knew not what\r\nwas become of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaints of Heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9che must have escaped in the\r\nmonk\xe2\x80\x99s garments!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFiends of hell!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cit was then the boar of\r\nRotherwood whom I ushered to the postern, and dismissed with my own\r\nhands!\xe2\x80\x94And thou,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cwhose folly could overreach the\r\nwisdom of idiots yet more gross than thyself\xe2\x80\x94I will give thee holy\r\norders\xe2\x80\x94I will shave thy crown for thee!\xe2\x80\x94Here, let them tear the scalp\r\nfrom his head, and then pitch him headlong from the battlements\xe2\x80\x94Thy\r\ntrade is to jest, canst thou jest now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou deal with me better than your word, noble knight,\xe2\x80\x9d whimpered forth\r\npoor Wamba, whose habits of buffoonery were not to be overcome even by\r\nthe immediate prospect of death; \xe2\x80\x9cif you give me the red cap you\r\npropose, out of a simple monk you will make a cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe poor wretch,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cis resolved to die in his\r\nvocation.\xe2\x80\x94Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, you shall not slay him. Give him to me to make\r\nsport for my Free Companions.\xe2\x80\x94How sayst thou, knave? Wilt thou take\r\nheart of grace, and go to the wars with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, with my master\xe2\x80\x99s leave,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cfor, look you, I must not\r\nslip collar\xe2\x80\x9d (and he touched that which he wore) \xe2\x80\x9cwithout his\r\npermission.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, a Norman saw will soon cut a Saxon collar.\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, noble sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cand thence goes the proverb\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Norman saw on English oak,\r\nOn English neck a Norman yoke;\r\nNorman spoon in English dish,\r\nAnd England ruled as Normans wish;\r\nBlithe world to England never will be more,\r\nTill England\xe2\x80\x99s rid of all the four.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou dost well, De Bracy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cto stand there\r\nlistening to a fool\xe2\x80\x99s jargon, when destruction is gaping for us! Seest\r\nthou not we are overreached, and that our proposed mode of\r\ncommunicating with our friends without has been disconcerted by this\r\nsame motley gentleman thou art so fond to brother? What views have we\r\nto expect but instant storm?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the battlements then,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cwhen didst thou ever see me\r\nthe graver for the thoughts of battle? Call the Templar yonder, and let\r\nhim fight but half so well for his life as he has done for his\r\nOrder\xe2\x80\x94Make thou to the walls thyself with thy huge body\xe2\x80\x94Let me do my\r\npoor endeavour in my own way, and I tell thee the Saxon outlaws may as\r\nwell attempt to scale the clouds, as the castle of Torquilstone; or, if\r\nyou will treat with the banditti, why not employ the mediation of this\r\nworthy franklin, who seems in such deep contemplation of the\r\nwine-flagon?\xe2\x80\x94Here, Saxon,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, addressing Athelstane, and\r\nhanding the cup to him, \xe2\x80\x9crinse thy throat with that noble liquor, and\r\nrouse up thy soul to say what thou wilt do for thy liberty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a man of mould may,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cproviding it be what a\r\nman of manhood ought.\xe2\x80\x94Dismiss me free, with my companions, and I will\r\npay a ransom of a thousand marks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd wilt moreover assure us the retreat of that scum of mankind who\r\nare swarming around the castle, contrary to God\xe2\x80\x99s peace and the\r\nking\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn so far as I can,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cI will withdraw them; and I\r\nfear not but that my father Cedric will do his best to assist me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are agreed then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthou and they are to be set\r\nat freedom, and peace is to be on both sides, for payment of a thousand\r\nmarks. It is a trifling ransom, Saxon, and thou wilt owe gratitude to\r\nthe moderation which accepts of it in exchange of your persons. But\r\nmark, this extends not to the Jew Isaac.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor to the Jew Isaac\xe2\x80\x99s daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, who had now joined\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeither,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cbelong to this Saxon\xe2\x80\x99s company.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI were unworthy to be called Christian, if they did,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nAthelstane: \xe2\x80\x9cdeal with the unbelievers as ye list.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeither does the ransom include the Lady Rowena,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\nshall never be said I was scared out of a fair prize without striking a\r\nblow for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeither,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cdoes our treaty refer to this wretched\r\nJester, whom I retain, that I may make him an example to every knave\r\nwho turns jest into earnest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lady Rowena,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Athelstane, with the most steady\r\ncountenance, \xe2\x80\x9cis my affianced bride. I will be drawn by wild horses\r\nbefore I consent to part with her. The slave Wamba has this day saved\r\nthe life of my father Cedric\xe2\x80\x94I will lose mine ere a hair of his head be\r\ninjured.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy affianced bride?\xe2\x80\x94The Lady Rowena the affianced bride of a vassal\r\nlike thee?\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cSaxon, thou dreamest that the days of thy\r\nseven kingdoms are returned again. I tell thee, the Princes of the\r\nHouse of Anjou confer not their wards on men of such lineage as thine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy lineage, proud Norman,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cis drawn from a source\r\nmore pure and ancient than that of a beggarly Frenchman, whose living\r\nis won by selling the blood of the thieves whom he assembles under his\r\npaltry standard. Kings were my ancestors, strong in war and wise in\r\ncouncil, who every day feasted in their hall more hundreds than thou\r\ncanst number individual followers; whose names have been sung by\r\nminstrels, and their laws recorded by Wittenagemotes; whose bones were\r\ninterred amid the prayers of saints, and over whose tombs minsters have\r\nbeen builded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast it, De Bracy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, well pleased with the\r\nrebuff which his companion had received; \xe2\x80\x9cthe Saxon hath hit thee\r\nfairly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs fairly as a captive can strike,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, with apparent\r\ncarelessness; \xe2\x80\x9cfor he whose hands are tied should have his tongue at\r\nfreedom.\xe2\x80\x94But thy glibness of reply, comrade,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined he, speaking to\r\nAthelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cwill not win the freedom of the Lady Rowena.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo this Athelstane, who had already made a longer speech than was his\r\ncustom to do on any topic, however interesting, returned no answer. The\r\nconversation was interrupted by the arrival of a menial, who announced\r\nthat a monk demanded admittance at the postern gate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of Saint Bennet, the prince of these bull-beggars,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9chave we a real monk this time, or another impostor?\r\nSearch him, slaves\xe2\x80\x94for an ye suffer a second impostor to be palmed upon\r\nyou, I will have your eyes torn out, and hot coals put into the\r\nsockets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me endure the extremity of your anger, my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said Giles, \xe2\x80\x9cif\r\nthis be not a real shaveling. Your squire Jocelyn knows him well, and\r\nwill vouch him to be brother Ambrose, a monk in attendance upon the\r\nPrior of Jorvaulx.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdmit him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cmost likely he brings us news from\r\nhis jovial master. Surely the devil keeps holiday, and the priests are\r\nrelieved from duty, that they are strolling thus wildly through the\r\ncountry. Remove these prisoners; and, Saxon, think on what thou hast\r\nheard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI claim,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9can honourable imprisonment, with due care\r\nof my board and of my couch, as becomes my rank, and as is due to one\r\nwho is in treaty for ransom. Moreover, I hold him that deems himself\r\nthe best of you, bound to answer to me with his body for this\r\naggression on my freedom. This defiance hath already been sent to thee\r\nby thy sewer; thou underliest it, and art bound to answer me\xe2\x80\x94There lies\r\nmy glove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI answer not the challenge of my prisoner,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cnor\r\nshalt thou, Maurice de Bracy.\xe2\x80\x94Giles,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9chang the\r\nfranklin\xe2\x80\x99s glove upon the tine of yonder branched antlers: there shall\r\nit remain until he is a free man. Should he then presume to demand it,\r\nor to affirm he was unlawfully made my prisoner, by the belt of Saint\r\nChristopher, he will speak to one who hath never refused to meet a foe\r\non foot or on horseback, alone or with his vassals at his back!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Saxon prisoners were accordingly removed, just as they introduced\r\nthe monk Ambrose, who appeared to be in great perturbation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the real \xe2\x80\x98Deus vobiscum\xe2\x80\x99,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, as he passed the\r\nreverend brother; \xe2\x80\x9cthe others were but counterfeits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly Mother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the monk, as he addressed the assembled knights, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nam at last safe and in Christian keeping!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSafe thou art,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cand for Christianity, here is the\r\nstout Baron Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, whose utter abomination is a Jew;\r\nand the good Knight Templar, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, whose trade is to\r\nslay Saracens\xe2\x80\x94If these are not good marks of Christianity, I know no\r\nother which they bear about them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe are friends and allies of our reverend father in God, Aymer, Prior\r\nof Jorvaulx,\xe2\x80\x9d said the monk, without noticing the tone of De Bracy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreply; \xe2\x80\x9cye owe him aid both by knightly faith and holy charity; for\r\nwhat saith the blessed Saint Augustin, in his treatise \xe2\x80\x98De Civitate\r\nDei\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat saith the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cor rather what dost\r\nthou say, Sir Priest? We have little time to hear texts from the holy\r\nfathers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Sancta Maria!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated Father Ambrose, \xe2\x80\x9chow prompt to ire are\r\nthese unhallowed laymen!\xe2\x80\x94But be it known to you, brave knights, that\r\ncertain murderous caitiffs, casting behind them fear of God, and\r\nreverence of his church, and not regarding the bull of the holy see,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Si quis, suadende Diabolo\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother priest,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9call this we know or guess at\xe2\x80\x94tell\r\nus plainly, is thy master, the Prior, made prisoner, and to whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ambrose, \xe2\x80\x9che is in the hands of the men of Belial,\r\ninfesters of these woods, and contemners of the holy text, \xe2\x80\x98Touch not\r\nmine anointed, and do my prophets naught of evil.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is a new argument for our swords, sirs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\r\nturning to his companions; \xe2\x80\x9cand so, instead of reaching us any\r\nassistance, the Prior of Jorvaulx requests aid at our hands? a man is\r\nwell helped of these lazy churchmen when he hath most to do!\xe2\x80\x94But speak\r\nout, priest, and say at once, what doth thy master expect from us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo please you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ambrose, \xe2\x80\x9cviolent hands having been imposed on my\r\nreverend superior, contrary to the holy ordinance which I did already\r\nquote, and the men of Belial having rifled his mails and budgets, and\r\nstripped him of two hundred marks of pure refined gold, they do yet\r\ndemand of him a large sum beside, ere they will suffer him to depart\r\nfrom their uncircumcised hands. Wherefore the reverend father in God\r\nprays you, as his dear friends, to rescue him, either by paying down\r\nthe ransom at which they hold him, or by force of arms, at your best\r\ndiscretion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe foul fiend quell the Prior!\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9chis morning\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndrought has been a deep one. When did thy master hear of a Norman baron\r\nunbuckling his purse to relieve a churchman, whose bags are ten times\r\nas weighty as ours?\xe2\x80\x94And how can we do aught by valour to free him, that\r\nare cooped up here by ten times our number, and expect an assault every\r\nmoment?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that was what I was about to tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the monk, \xe2\x80\x9chad your\r\nhastiness allowed me time. But, God help me, I am old, and these foul\r\nonslaughts distract an aged man\xe2\x80\x99s brain. Nevertheless, it is of verity\r\nthat they assemble a camp, and raise a bank against the walls of this\r\ncastle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the battlements!\xe2\x80\x9d cried De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cand let us mark what these\r\nknaves do without;\xe2\x80\x9d and so saying, he opened a latticed window which\r\nled to a sort of bartisan or projecting balcony, and immediately called\r\nfrom thence to those in the apartment\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSaint Dennis, but the old monk\r\nhath brought true tidings!\xe2\x80\x94They bring forward mantelets and pavisses,\r\n32 and the archers muster on the skirts of the wood like a dark cloud\r\nbefore a hailstorm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nReginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf also looked out upon the field, and immediately\r\nsnatched his bugle; and, after winding a long and loud blast, commanded\r\nhis men to their posts on the walls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDe Bracy, look to the eastern side, where the walls are lowest\xe2\x80\x94Noble\r\nBois-Guilbert, thy trade hath well taught thee how to attack and\r\ndefend, look thou to the western side\xe2\x80\x94I myself will take post at the\r\nbarbican. Yet, do not confine your exertions to any one spot, noble\r\nfriends!\xe2\x80\x94we must this day be everywhere, and multiply ourselves, were\r\nit possible, so as to carry by our presence succour and relief wherever\r\nthe attack is hottest. Our numbers are few, but activity and courage\r\nmay supply that defect, since we have only to do with rascal clowns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, noble knights,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Father Ambrose, amidst the bustle and\r\nconfusion occasioned by the preparations for defence, \xe2\x80\x9cwill none of ye\r\nhear the message of the reverend father in God Aymer, Prior of\r\nJorvaulx?\xe2\x80\x94I beseech thee to hear me, noble Sir Reginald!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo patter thy petitions to heaven,\xe2\x80\x9d said the fierce Norman, \xe2\x80\x9cfor we on\r\nearth have no time to listen to them.\xe2\x80\x94Ho! there, Anselm I see that\r\nseething pitch and oil are ready to pour on the heads of these\r\naudacious traitors\xe2\x80\x94Look that the cross-bowmen lack not bolts. 33\xe2\x80\x94Fling\r\nabroad my banner with the old bull\xe2\x80\x99s head\xe2\x80\x94the knaves shall soon find\r\nwith whom they have to do this day!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, noble sir,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the monk, persevering in his endeavours to\r\ndraw attention, \xe2\x80\x9cconsider my vow of obedience, and let me discharge\r\nmyself of my Superior\xe2\x80\x99s errand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAway with this prating dotard,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9clock him up in\r\nthe chapel, to tell his beads till the broil be over. It will be a new\r\nthing to the saints in Torquilstone to hear aves and paters; they have\r\nnot been so honoured, I trow, since they were cut out of stone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlaspheme not the holy saints, Sir Reginald,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall\r\nhave need of their aid to-day before yon rascal rout disband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI expect little aid from their hand,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cunless we\r\nwere to hurl them from the battlements on the heads of the villains.\r\nThere is a huge lumbering Saint Christopher yonder, sufficient to bear\r\na whole company to the earth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Templar had in the meantime been looking out on the proceedings of\r\nthe besiegers, with rather more attention than the brutal Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\r\nor his giddy companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the faith of mine order,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthese men approach with more\r\ntouch of discipline than could have been judged, however they come by\r\nit. See ye how dexterously they avail themselves of every cover which a\r\ntree or bush affords, and shun exposing themselves to the shot of our\r\ncross-bows? I spy neither banner nor pennon among them, and yet will I\r\ngage my golden chain, that they are led on by some noble knight or\r\ngentleman, skilful in the practice of wars.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI espy him,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cI see the waving of a knight\xe2\x80\x99s crest, and\r\nthe gleam of his armour. See yon tall man in the black mail, who is\r\nbusied marshalling the farther troop of the rascaille yeomen\xe2\x80\x94by Saint\r\nDennis, I hold him to be the same whom we called \xe2\x80\x98Le Noir Faineant\xe2\x80\x99,\r\nwho overthrew thee, Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, in the lists at Ashby.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better,\xe2\x80\x9d said Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he comes here to give\r\nme my revenge. Some hilding fellow he must be, who dared not stay to\r\nassert his claim to the tourney prize which chance had assigned him. I\r\nshould in vain have sought for him where knights and nobles seek their\r\nfoes, and right glad am I he hath here shown himself among yon villain\r\nyeomanry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe demonstrations of the enemy\xe2\x80\x99s immediate approach cut off all\r\nfarther discourse. Each knight repaired to his post, and at the head of\r\nthe few followers whom they were able to muster, and who were in\r\nnumbers inadequate to defend the whole extent of the walls, they\r\nawaited with calm determination the threatened assault.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVIII\r\n\r\n\r\nThis wandering race, sever\xe2\x80\x99d from other men,\r\nBoast yet their intercourse with human arts;\r\nThe seas, the woods, the deserts, which they haunt,\r\nFind them acquainted with their secret treasures:\r\nAnd unregarded herbs, and flowers, and blossoms,\r\nDisplay undreamt-of powers when gather\xe2\x80\x99d by them.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE JEW\r\n\r\n\r\nOur history must needs retrograde for the space of a few pages, to\r\ninform the reader of certain passages material to his understanding the\r\nrest of this important narrative. His own intelligence may indeed have\r\neasily anticipated that, when Ivanhoe sunk down, and seemed abandoned\r\nby all the world, it was the importunity of Rebecca which prevailed on\r\nher father to have the gallant young warrior transported from the lists\r\nto the house which for the time the Jews inhabited in the suburbs of\r\nAshby.\r\n\r\nIt would not have been difficult to have persuaded Isaac to this step\r\nin any other circumstances, for his disposition was kind and grateful.\r\nBut he had also the prejudices and scrupulous timidity of his\r\npersecuted people, and those were to be conquered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly Abraham!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9che is a good youth, and my heart bleeds\r\nto see the gore trickle down his rich embroidered hacqueton, and his\r\ncorslet of goodly price\xe2\x80\x94but to carry him to our house!\xe2\x80\x94damsel, hast\r\nthou well considered?\xe2\x80\x94he is a Christian, and by our law we may not deal\r\nwith the stranger and Gentile, save for the advantage of our commerce.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak not so, my dear father,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cwe may not indeed mix\r\nwith them in banquet and in jollity; but in wounds and in misery, the\r\nGentile becometh the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would I knew what the Rabbi Jacob Ben Tudela would opine on it,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied Isaac;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cnevertheless, the good youth must not bleed to death.\r\nLet Seth and Reuben bear him to Ashby.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, let them place him in my litter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cI will mount one\r\nof the palfreys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat were to expose thee to the gaze of those dogs of Ishmael and of\r\nEdom,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Isaac, with a suspicious glance towards the crowd of\r\nknights and squires. But Rebecca was already busied in carrying her\r\ncharitable purpose into effect, and listed not what he said, until\r\nIsaac, seizing the sleeve of her mantle, again exclaimed, in a hurried\r\nvoice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBeard of Aaron!\xe2\x80\x94what if the youth perish!\xe2\x80\x94if he die in our\r\ncustody, shall we not be held guilty of his blood, and be torn to\r\npieces by the multitude?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will not die, my father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, gently extricating herself\r\nfrom the grasp of Isaac \xe2\x80\x9che will not die unless we abandon him; and if\r\nso, we are indeed answerable for his blood to God and to man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, releasing his hold, \xe2\x80\x9cit grieveth me as much to see\r\nthe drops of his blood, as if they were so many golden byzants from\r\nmine own purse; and I well know, that the lessons of Miriam, daughter\r\nof the Rabbi Manasses of Byzantium whose soul is in Paradise, have made\r\nthee skilful in the art of healing, and that thou knowest the craft of\r\nherbs, and the force of elixirs. Therefore, do as thy mind giveth\r\nthee\xe2\x80\x94thou art a good damsel, a blessing, and a crown, and a song of\r\nrejoicing unto me and unto my house, and unto the people of my\r\nfathers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe apprehensions of Isaac, however, were not ill founded; and the\r\ngenerous and grateful benevolence of his daughter exposed her, on her\r\nreturn to Ashby, to the unhallowed gaze of Brian de Bois-Guilbert. The\r\nTemplar twice passed and repassed them on the road, fixing his bold and\r\nardent look on the beautiful Jewess; and we have already seen the\r\nconsequences of the admiration which her charms excited when accident\r\nthrew her into the power of that unprincipled voluptuary.\r\n\r\nRebecca lost no time in causing the patient to be transported to their\r\ntemporary dwelling, and proceeded with her own hands to examine and to\r\nbind up his wounds. The youngest reader of romances and romantic\r\nballads, must recollect how often the females, during the dark ages, as\r\nthey are called, were initiated into the mysteries of surgery, and how\r\nfrequently the gallant knight submitted the wounds of his person to her\r\ncure, whose eyes had yet more deeply penetrated his heart.\r\n\r\nBut the Jews, both male and female, possessed and practised the medical\r\nscience in all its branches, and the monarchs and powerful barons of\r\nthe time frequently committed themselves to the charge of some\r\nexperienced sage among this despised people, when wounded or in\r\nsickness. The aid of the Jewish physicians was not the less eagerly\r\nsought after, though a general belief prevailed among the Christians,\r\nthat the Jewish Rabbins were deeply acquainted with the occult\r\nsciences, and particularly with the cabalistical art, which had its\r\nname and origin in the studies of the sages of Israel.
