Neither did the\r\nRabbins disown such acquaintance with supernatural arts, which added\r\nnothing (for what could add aught?) to the hatred with which their\r\nnation was regarded, while it diminished the contempt with which that\r\nmalevolence was mingled. A Jewish magician might be the subject of\r\nequal abhorrence with a Jewish usurer, but he could not be equally\r\ndespised. It is besides probable, considering the wonderful cures they\r\nare said to have performed, that the Jews possessed some secrets of the\r\nhealing art peculiar to themselves, and which, with the exclusive\r\nspirit arising out of their condition, they took great care to conceal\r\nfrom the Christians amongst whom they dwelt.\r\n\r\nThe beautiful Rebecca had been heedfully brought up in all the\r\nknowledge proper to her nation, which her apt and powerful mind had\r\nretained, arranged, and enlarged, in the course of a progress beyond\r\nher years, her sex, and even the age in which she lived. Her knowledge\r\nof medicine and of the healing art had been acquired under an aged\r\nJewess, the daughter of one of their most celebrated doctors, who loved\r\nRebecca as her own child, and was believed to have communicated to her\r\nsecrets, which had been left to herself by her sage father at the same\r\ntime, and under the same circumstances. The fate of Miriam had indeed\r\nbeen to fall a sacrifice to the fanaticism of the times; but her\r\nsecrets had survived in her apt pupil.\r\n\r\nRebecca, thus endowed with knowledge as with beauty, was universally\r\nrevered and admired by her own tribe, who almost regarded her as one of\r\nthose gifted women mentioned in the sacred history. Her father himself,\r\nout of reverence for her talents, which involuntarily mingled itself\r\nwith his unbounded affection, permitted the maiden a greater liberty\r\nthan was usually indulged to those of her sex by the habits of her\r\npeople, and was, as we have just seen, frequently guided by her\r\nopinion, even in preference to his own.\r\n\r\nWhen Ivanhoe reached the habitation of Isaac, he was still in a state\r\nof unconsciousness, owing to the profuse loss of blood which had taken\r\nplace during his exertions in the lists. Rebecca examined the wound,\r\nand having applied to it such vulnerary remedies as her art prescribed,\r\ninformed her father that if fever could be averted, of which the great\r\nbleeding rendered her little apprehensive, and if the healing balsam of\r\nMiriam retained its virtue, there was nothing to fear for his guest\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlife, and that he might with safety travel to York with them on the\r\nensuing day. Isaac looked a little blank at this annunciation. His\r\ncharity would willingly have stopped short at Ashby, or at most would\r\nhave left the wounded Christian to be tended in the house where he was\r\nresiding at present, with an assurance to the Hebrew to whom it\r\nbelonged, that all expenses should be duly discharged. To this,\r\nhowever, Rebecca opposed many reasons, of which we shall only mention\r\ntwo that had peculiar weight with Isaac. The one was, that she would on\r\nno account put the phial of precious balsam into the hands of another\r\nphysician even of her own tribe, lest that valuable mystery should be\r\ndiscovered; the other, that this wounded knight, Wilfred of Ivanhoe,\r\nwas an intimate favourite of Richard C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion, and that, in case\r\nthe monarch should return, Isaac, who had supplied his brother John\r\nwith treasure to prosecute his rebellious purposes, would stand in no\r\nsmall need of a powerful protector who enjoyed Richard\xe2\x80\x99s favour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art speaking but sooth, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, giving way to these\r\nweighty arguments\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit were an offending of Heaven to betray the secrets\r\nof the blessed Miriam; for the good which Heaven giveth, is not rashly\r\nto be squandered upon others, whether it be talents of gold and shekels\r\nof silver, or whether it be the secret mysteries of a wise\r\nphysician\xe2\x80\x94assuredly they should be preserved to those to whom\r\nProvidence hath vouchsafed them. And him whom the Nazarenes of England\r\ncall the Lion\xe2\x80\x99s Heart, assuredly it were better for me to fall into the\r\nhands of a strong lion of Idumea than into his, if he shall have got\r\nassurance of my dealing with his brother. Wherefore I will lend ear to\r\nthy counsel, and this youth shall journey with us unto York, and our\r\nhouse shall be as a home to him until his wounds shall be healed. And\r\nif he of the Lion Heart shall return to the land, as is now noised\r\nabroad, then shall this Wilfred of Ivanhoe be unto me as a wall of\r\ndefence, when the king\xe2\x80\x99s displeasure shall burn high against thy\r\nfather. And if he doth not return, this Wilfred may natheless repay us\r\nour charges when he shall gain treasure by the strength of his spear\r\nand of his sword, even as he did yesterday and this day also. For the\r\nyouth is a good youth, and keepeth the day which he appointeth, and\r\nrestoreth that which he borroweth, and succoureth the Israelite, even\r\nthe child of my father\xe2\x80\x99s house, when he is encompassed by strong\r\nthieves and sons of Belial.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was not until evening was nearly closed that Ivanhoe was restored to\r\nconsciousness of his situation. He awoke from a broken slumber, under\r\nthe confused impressions which are naturally attendant on the recovery\r\nfrom a state of insensibility. He was unable for some time to recall\r\nexactly to memory the circumstances which had preceded his fall in the\r\nlists, or to make out any connected chain of the events in which he had\r\nbeen engaged upon the yesterday. A sense of wounds and injury, joined\r\nto great weakness and exhaustion, was mingled with the recollection of\r\nblows dealt and received, of steeds rushing upon each other,\r\noverthrowing and overthrown\xe2\x80\x94of shouts and clashing of arms, and all the\r\nheady tumult of a confused fight. An effort to draw aside the curtain\r\nof his couch was in some degree successful, although rendered difficult\r\nby the pain of his wound.\r\n\r\nTo his great surprise he found himself in a room magnificently\r\nfurnished, but having cushions instead of chairs to rest upon, and in\r\nother respects partaking so much of Oriental costume, that he began to\r\ndoubt whether he had not, during his sleep, been transported back again\r\nto the land of Palestine. The impression was increased, when, the\r\ntapestry being drawn aside, a female form, dressed in a rich habit,\r\nwhich partook more of the Eastern taste than that of Europe, glided\r\nthrough the door which it concealed, and was followed by a swarthy\r\ndomestic.\r\n\r\nAs the wounded knight was about to address this fair apparition, she\r\nimposed silence by placing her slender finger upon her ruby lips, while\r\nthe attendant, approaching him, proceeded to uncover Ivanhoe\xe2\x80\x99s side,\r\nand the lovely Jewess satisfied herself that the bandage was in its\r\nplace, and the wound doing well. She performed her task with a graceful\r\nand dignified simplicity and modesty, which might, even in more\r\ncivilized days, have served to redeem it from whatever might seem\r\nrepugnant to female delicacy. The idea of so young and beautiful a\r\nperson engaged in attendance on a sick-bed, or in dressing the wound of\r\none of a different sex, was melted away and lost in that of a\r\nbeneficent being contributing her effectual aid to relieve pain, and to\r\navert the stroke of death. Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s few and brief directions were\r\ngiven in the Hebrew language to the old domestic; and he, who had been\r\nfrequently her assistant in similar cases, obeyed them without reply.\r\n\r\nThe accents of an unknown tongue, however harsh they might have sounded\r\nwhen uttered by another, had, coming from the beautiful Rebecca, the\r\nromantic and pleasing effect which fancy ascribes to the charms\r\npronounced by some beneficent fairy, unintelligible, indeed, to the\r\near, but, from the sweetness of utterance, and benignity of aspect,\r\nwhich accompanied them, touching and affecting to the heart. Without\r\nmaking an attempt at further question, Ivanhoe suffered them in silence\r\nto take the measures they thought most proper for his recovery; and it\r\nwas not until those were completed, and this kind physician about to\r\nretire, that his curiosity could no longer be suppressed.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGentle\r\nmaiden,\xe2\x80\x9d he began in the Arabian tongue, with which his Eastern travels\r\nhad rendered him familiar, and which he thought most likely to be\r\nunderstood by the turban\xe2\x80\x99d and caftan\xe2\x80\x99d damsel who stood before him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\r\npray you, gentle maiden, of your courtesy\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut here he was interrupted by his fair physician, a smile which she\r\ncould scarce suppress dimpling for an instant a face, whose general\r\nexpression was that of contemplative melancholy. \xe2\x80\x9cI am of England, Sir\r\nKnight, and speak the English tongue, although my dress and my lineage\r\nbelong to another climate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNoble damsel,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94again the Knight of Ivanhoe began; and again Rebecca\r\nhastened to interrupt him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBestow not on me, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe epithet of noble. It is\r\nwell you should speedily know that your handmaiden is a poor Jewess,\r\nthe daughter of that Isaac of York, to whom you were so lately a good\r\nand kind lord. It well becomes him, and those of his household, to\r\nrender to you such careful tendance as your present state necessarily\r\ndemands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI know not whether the fair Rowena would have been altogether satisfied\r\nwith the species of emotion with which her devoted knight had hitherto\r\ngazed on the beautiful features, and fair form, and lustrous eyes, of\r\nthe lovely Rebecca; eyes whose brilliancy was shaded, and, as it were,\r\nmellowed, by the fringe of her long silken eyelashes, and which a\r\nminstrel would have compared to the evening star darting its rays\r\nthrough a bower of jessamine. But Ivanhoe was too good a Catholic to\r\nretain the same class of feelings towards a Jewess. This Rebecca had\r\nforeseen, and for this very purpose she had hastened to mention her\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s name and lineage; yet\xe2\x80\x94for the fair and wise daughter of Isaac\r\nwas not without a touch of female weakness\xe2\x80\x94she could not but sigh\r\ninternally when the glance of respectful admiration, not altogether\r\nunmixed with tenderness, with which Ivanhoe had hitherto regarded his\r\nunknown benefactress, was exchanged at once for a manner cold,\r\ncomposed, and collected, and fraught with no deeper feeling than that\r\nwhich expressed a grateful sense of courtesy received from an\r\nunexpected quarter, and from one of an inferior race. It was not that\r\nIvanhoe\xe2\x80\x99s former carriage expressed more than that general devotional\r\nhomage which youth always pays to beauty; yet it was mortifying that\r\none word should operate as a spell to remove poor Rebecca, who could\r\nnot be supposed altogether ignorant of her title to such homage, into a\r\ndegraded class, to whom it could not be honourably rendered.\r\n\r\nBut the gentleness and candour of Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s nature imputed no fault to\r\nIvanhoe for sharing in the universal prejudices of his age and\r\nreligion. On the contrary the fair Jewess, though sensible her patient\r\nnow regarded her as one of a race of reprobation, with whom it was\r\ndisgraceful to hold any beyond the most necessary intercourse, ceased\r\nnot to pay the same patient and devoted attention to his safety and\r\nconvalescence. She informed him of the necessity they were under of\r\nremoving to York, and of her father\xe2\x80\x99s resolution to transport him\r\nthither, and tend him in his own house until his health should be\r\nrestored. Ivanhoe expressed great repugnance to this plan, which he\r\ngrounded on unwillingness to give farther trouble to his benefactors.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas there not,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cin Ashby, or near it, some Saxon franklin,\r\nor even some wealthy peasant, who would endure the burden of a wounded\r\ncountryman\xe2\x80\x99s residence with him until he should be again able to bear\r\nhis armour?\xe2\x80\x94Was there no convent of Saxon endowment, where he could be\r\nreceived?\xe2\x80\x94Or could he not be transported as far as Burton, where he was\r\nsure to find hospitality with Waltheoff, the Abbot of St Withold\xe2\x80\x99s, to\r\nwhom he was related?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny, the worst of these harbourages,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, with a melancholy\r\nsmile, \xe2\x80\x9cwould unquestionably be more fitting for your residence than\r\nthe abode of a despised Jew; yet, Sir Knight, unless you would dismiss\r\nyour physician, you cannot change your lodging. Our nation, as you well\r\nknow, can cure wounds, though we deal not in inflicting them; and in\r\nour own family, in particular, are secrets which have been handed down\r\nsince the days of Solomon, and of which you have already experienced\r\nthe advantages. No Nazarene\xe2\x80\x94I crave your forgiveness, Sir Knight\xe2\x80\x94no\r\nChristian leech, within the four seas of Britain, could enable you to\r\nbear your corslet within a month.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how soon wilt THOU enable me to brook it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe,\r\nimpatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithin eight days, if thou wilt be patient and conformable to my\r\ndirections,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rebecca.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Our Blessed Lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wilfred, \xe2\x80\x9cif it be not a sin to name her\r\nhere, it is no time for me or any true knight to be bedridden; and if\r\nthou accomplish thy promise, maiden, I will pay thee with my casque\r\nfull of crowns, come by them as I may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will accomplish my promise,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cand thou shalt bear\r\nthine armour on the eighth day from hence, if thou will grant me but\r\none boon in the stead of the silver thou dost promise me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it be within my power, and such as a true Christian knight may\r\nyield to one of thy people,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cI will grant thy boon\r\nblithely and thankfully.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cI will but pray of thee to believe\r\nhenceforward that a Jew may do good service to a Christian, without\r\ndesiring other guerdon than the blessing of the Great Father who made\r\nboth Jew and Gentile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt were sin to doubt it, maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cand I repose\r\nmyself on thy skill without further scruple or question, well trusting\r\nyou will enable me to bear my corslet on the eighth day. And now, my\r\nkind leech, let me enquire of the news abroad. What of the noble Saxon\r\nCedric and his household?\xe2\x80\x94what of the lovely Lady\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d He stopt, as if\r\nunwilling to speak Rowena\xe2\x80\x99s name in the house of a Jew\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cOf her, I mean,\r\nwho was named Queen of the tournament?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who was selected by you, Sir Knight, to hold that dignity, with\r\njudgment which was admired as much as your valour,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rebecca.\r\n\r\nThe blood which Ivanhoe had lost did not prevent a flush from crossing\r\nhis cheek, feeling that he had incautiously betrayed a deep interest in\r\nRowena by the awkward attempt he had made to conceal it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was less of her I would speak,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthan of Prince John; and\r\nI would fain know somewhat of a faithful squire, and why he now attends\r\nme not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me use my authority as a leech,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cand enjoin you\r\nto keep silence, and avoid agitating reflections, whilst I apprize you\r\nof what you desire to know. Prince John hath broken off the tournament,\r\nand set forward in all haste towards York, with the nobles, knights,\r\nand churchmen of his party, after collecting such sums as they could\r\nwring, by fair means or foul, from those who are esteemed the wealthy\r\nof the land. It is said he designs to assume his brother\xe2\x80\x99s crown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot without a blow struck in its defence,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, raising\r\nhimself upon the couch, \xe2\x80\x9cif there were but one true subject in England\r\nI will fight for Richard\xe2\x80\x99s title with the best of them\xe2\x80\x94ay, one or two,\r\nin his just quarrel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that you may be able to do so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca touching his shoulder\r\nwith her hand, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must now observe my directions, and remain quiet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cas quiet as these disquieted times will\r\npermit\xe2\x80\x94And of Cedric and his household?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis steward came but brief while since,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jewess, \xe2\x80\x9cpanting\r\nwith haste, to ask my father for certain monies, the price of wool the\r\ngrowth of Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s flocks, and from him I learned that Cedric and\r\nAthelstane of Coningsburgh had left Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s lodging in high\r\ndispleasure, and were about to set forth on their return homeward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWent any lady with them to the banquet?\xe2\x80\x9d said Wilfred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lady Rowena,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, answering the question with more\r\nprecision than it had been asked\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lady Rowena went not to the\r\nPrince\xe2\x80\x99s feast, and, as the steward reported to us, she is now on her\r\njourney back to Rotherwood, with her guardian Cedric. And touching your\r\nfaithful squire Gurth\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cknowest thou his name?\xe2\x80\x94But thou dost,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nimmediately added, \xe2\x80\x9cand well thou mayst, for it was from thy hand, and,\r\nas I am now convinced, from thine own generosity of spirit, that he\r\nreceived but yesterday a hundred zecchins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak not of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, blushing deeply; \xe2\x80\x9cI see how easy it\r\nis for the tongue to betray what the heart would gladly conceal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this sum of gold,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cmy honour is concerned\r\nin repaying it to your father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet it be as thou wilt,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen eight days have passed\r\naway; but think not, and speak not now, of aught that may retard thy\r\nrecovery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so, kind maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cI were most ungrateful to\r\ndispute thy commands. But one word of the fate of poor Gurth, and I\r\nhave done with questioning thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI grieve to tell thee, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jewess, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he is\r\nin custody by the order of Cedric.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94And then observing the distress\r\nwhich her communication gave to Wilfred, she instantly added, \xe2\x80\x9cBut the\r\nsteward Oswald said, that if nothing occurred to renew his master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndispleasure against him, he was sure that Cedric would pardon Gurth, a\r\nfaithful serf, and one who stood high in favour, and who had but\r\ncommitted this error out of the love which he bore to Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s son. And\r\nhe said, moreover, that he and his comrades, and especially Wamba the\r\nJester, were resolved to warn Gurth to make his escape by the way, in\r\ncase Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s ire against him could not be mitigated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould to God they may keep their purpose!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it seems\r\nas if I were destined to bring ruin on whomsoever hath shown kindness\r\nto me. My king, by whom I was honoured and distinguished, thou seest\r\nthat the brother most indebted to him is raising his arms to grasp his\r\ncrown;\xe2\x80\x94my regard hath brought restraint and trouble on the fairest of\r\nher sex;\xe2\x80\x94and now my father in his mood may slay this poor bondsman but\r\nfor his love and loyal service to me!\xe2\x80\x94Thou seest, maiden, what an\r\nill-fated wretch thou dost labour to assist; be wise, and let me go,\r\nere the misfortunes which track my footsteps like slot-hounds, shall\r\ninvolve thee also in their pursuit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cthy weakness and thy grief, Sir Knight, make thee\r\nmiscalculate the purposes of Heaven. Thou hast been restored to thy\r\ncountry when it most needed the assistance of a strong hand and a true\r\nheart, and thou hast humbled the pride of thine enemies and those of\r\nthy king, when their horn was most highly exalted, and for the evil\r\nwhich thou hast sustained, seest thou not that Heaven has raised thee a\r\nhelper and a physician, even among the most despised of the\r\nland?\xe2\x80\x94Therefore, be of good courage, and trust that thou art preserved\r\nfor some marvel which thine arm shall work before this people.\r\nAdieu\xe2\x80\x94and having taken the medicine which I shall send thee by the hand\r\nof Reuben, compose thyself again to rest, that thou mayest be the more\r\nable to endure the journey on the succeeding day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvanhoe was convinced by the reasoning, and obeyed the directions, of\r\nRebecca. The drought which Reuben administered was of a sedative and\r\nnarcotic quality, and secured the patient sound and undisturbed\r\nslumbers. In the morning his kind physician found him entirely free\r\nfrom feverish symptoms, and fit to undergo the fatigue of a journey.\r\n\r\nHe was deposited in the horse-litter which had brought him from the\r\nlists, and every precaution taken for his travelling with ease. In one\r\ncircumstance only even the entreaties of Rebecca were unable to secure\r\nsufficient attention to the accommodation of the wounded knight. Isaac,\r\nlike the enriched traveller of Juvenal\xe2\x80\x99s tenth satire, had ever the\r\nfear of robbery before his eyes, conscious that he would be alike\r\naccounted fair game by the marauding Norman noble, and by the Saxon\r\noutlaw. He therefore journeyed at a great rate, and made short halts,\r\nand shorter repasts, so that he passed by Cedric and Athelstane who had\r\nseveral hours the start of him, but who had been delayed by their\r\nprotracted feasting at the convent of Saint Withold\xe2\x80\x99s. Yet such was the\r\nvirtue of Miriam\xe2\x80\x99s balsam, or such the strength of Ivanhoe\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconstitution, that he did not sustain from the hurried journey that\r\ninconvenience which his kind physician had apprehended.\r\n\r\nIn another point of view, however, the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s haste proved somewhat more\r\nthan good speed. The rapidity with which he insisted on travelling,\r\nbred several disputes between him and the party whom he had hired to\r\nattend him as a guard. These men were Saxons, and not free by any means\r\nfrom the national love of ease and good living which the Normans\r\nstigmatized as laziness and gluttony. Reversing Shylock\xe2\x80\x99s position,\r\nthey had accepted the employment in hopes of feeding upon the wealthy\r\nJew, and were very much displeased when they found themselves\r\ndisappointed, by the rapidity with which he insisted on their\r\nproceeding. They remonstrated also upon the risk of damage to their\r\nhorses by these forced marches. Finally, there arose betwixt Isaac and\r\nhis satellites a deadly feud, concerning the quantity of wine and ale\r\nto be allowed for consumption at each meal. And thus it happened, that\r\nwhen the alarm of danger approached, and that which Isaac feared was\r\nlikely to come upon him, he was deserted by the discontented\r\nmercenaries on whose protection he had relied, without using the means\r\nnecessary to secure their attachment.\r\n\r\nIn this deplorable condition the Jew, with his daughter and her wounded\r\npatient, were found by Cedric, as has already been noticed, and soon\r\nafterwards fell into the power of De Bracy and his confederates. Little\r\nnotice was at first taken of the horse-litter, and it might have\r\nremained behind but for the curiosity of De Bracy, who looked into it\r\nunder the impression that it might contain the object of his\r\nenterprise, for Rowena had not unveiled herself. But De Bracy\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nastonishment was considerable, when he discovered that the litter\r\ncontained a wounded man, who, conceiving himself to have fallen into\r\nthe power of Saxon outlaws, with whom his name might be a protection\r\nfor himself and his friends, frankly avowed himself to be Wilfred of\r\nIvanhoe.\r\n\r\nThe ideas of chivalrous honour, which, amidst his wildness and levity,\r\nnever utterly abandoned De Bracy, prohibited him from doing the knight\r\nany injury in his defenceless condition, and equally interdicted his\r\nbetraying him to Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, who would have had no scruples to put\r\nto death, under any circumstances, the rival claimant of the fief of\r\nIvanhoe. On the other hand, to liberate a suitor preferred by the Lady\r\nRowena, as the events of the tournament, and indeed Wilfred\xe2\x80\x99s previous\r\nbanishment from his father\xe2\x80\x99s house, had made matter of notoriety, was a\r\npitch far above the flight of De Bracy\xe2\x80\x99s generosity. A middle course\r\nbetwixt good and evil was all which he found himself capable of\r\nadopting, and he commanded two of his own squires to keep close by the\r\nlitter, and to suffer no one to approach it. If questioned, they were\r\ndirected by their master to say, that the empty litter of the Lady\r\nRowena was employed to transport one of their comrades who had been\r\nwounded in the scuffle. On arriving at Torquilstone, while the Knight\r\nTemplar and the lord of that castle were each intent upon their own\r\nschemes, the one on the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s treasure, and the other on his daughter,\r\nDe Bracy\xe2\x80\x99s squires conveyed Ivanhoe, still under the name of a wounded\r\ncomrade, to a distant apartment. This explanation was accordingly\r\nreturned by these men to Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, when he questioned them why\r\nthey did not make for the battlements upon the alarm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA wounded companion!\xe2\x80\x9d he replied in great wrath and astonishment. \xe2\x80\x9cNo\r\nwonder that churls and yeomen wax so presumptuous as even to lay\r\nleaguer before castles, and that clowns and swineherds send defiances\r\nto nobles, since men-at-arms have turned sick men\xe2\x80\x99s nurses, and Free\r\nCompanions are grown keepers of dying folk\xe2\x80\x99s curtains, when the castle\r\nis about to be assailed.\xe2\x80\x94To the battlements, ye loitering villains!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nexclaimed, raising his stentorian voice till the arches around rung\r\nagain, \xe2\x80\x9cto the battlements, or I will splinter your bones with this\r\ntruncheon!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe men sulkily replied, \xe2\x80\x9cthat they desired nothing better than to go\r\nto the battlements, providing Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf would bear them out with\r\ntheir master, who had commanded them to tend the dying man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe dying man, knaves!\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the Baron; \xe2\x80\x9cI promise thee we shall\r\nall be dying men an we stand not to it the more stoutly. But I will\r\nrelieve the guard upon this caitiff companion of yours.\xe2\x80\x94Here,\r\nUrfried\xe2\x80\x94hag\xe2\x80\x94fiend of a Saxon witch\xe2\x80\x94hearest me not?\xe2\x80\x94tend me this\r\nbedridden fellow since he must needs be tended, whilst these knaves use\r\ntheir weapons.\xe2\x80\x94Here be two arblasts, comrades, with windlaces and\r\nquarrells 34\xe2\x80\x94to the barbican with you, and see you drive each bolt\r\nthrough a Saxon brain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe men, who, like most of their description, were fond of enterprise\r\nand detested inaction, went joyfully to the scene of danger as they\r\nwere commanded, and thus the charge of Ivanhoe was transferred to\r\nUrfried, or Ulrica. But she, whose brain was burning with remembrance\r\nof injuries and with hopes of vengeance, was readily induced to devolve\r\nupon Rebecca the care of her patient.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIX\r\n\r\n\r\nAscend the watch-tower yonder, valiant soldier,\r\nLook on the field, and say how goes the battle.\r\n\r\n\r\nSCHILLER\xe2\x80\x99S MAID OF ORLEANS\r\n\r\n\r\nA moment of peril is often also a moment of open-hearted kindness and\r\naffection. We are thrown off our guard by the general agitation of our\r\nfeelings, and betray the intensity of those, which, at more tranquil\r\nperiods, our prudence at least conceals, if it cannot altogether\r\nsuppress them. In finding herself once more by the side of Ivanhoe,\r\nRebecca was astonished at the keen sensation of pleasure which she\r\nexperienced, even at a time when all around them both was danger, if\r\nnot despair. As she felt his pulse, and enquired after his health,\r\nthere was a softness in her touch and in her accents implying a kinder\r\ninterest than she would herself have been pleased to have voluntarily\r\nexpressed. Her voice faltered and her hand trembled, and it was only\r\nthe cold question of Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cIs it you, gentle maiden?\xe2\x80\x9d which\r\nrecalled her to herself, and reminded her the sensations which she felt\r\nwere not and could not be mutual. A sigh escaped, but it was scarce\r\naudible; and the questions which she asked the knight concerning his\r\nstate of health were put in the tone of calm friendship. Ivanhoe\r\nanswered her hastily that he was, in point of health, as well, and\r\nbetter than he could have expected\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThanks,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cdear Rebecca, to\r\nthy helpful skill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe calls me DEAR Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said the maiden to herself, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is in\r\nthe cold and careless tone which ill suits the word. His war-horse\xe2\x80\x94his\r\nhunting hound, are dearer to him than the despised Jewess!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mind, gentle maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cis more disturbed by\r\nanxiety, than my body with pain. From the speeches of those men who\r\nwere my warders just now, I learn that I am a prisoner, and, if I judge\r\naright of the loud hoarse voice which even now dispatched them hence on\r\nsome military duty, I am in the castle of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x94If so, how will\r\nthis end, or how can I protect Rowena and my father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe names not the Jew or Jewess,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca internally; \xe2\x80\x9cyet what is\r\nour portion in him, and how justly am I punished by Heaven for letting\r\nmy thoughts dwell upon him!\xe2\x80\x9d She hastened after this brief\r\nself-accusation to give Ivanhoe what information she could; but it\r\namounted only to this, that the Templar Bois-Guilbert, and the Baron\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf, were commanders within the castle; that it was\r\nbeleaguered from without, but by whom she knew not. She added, that\r\nthere was a Christian priest within the castle who might be possessed\r\nof more information.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Christian priest!\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, joyfully; \xe2\x80\x9cfetch him hither,\r\nRebecca, if thou canst\xe2\x80\x94say a sick man desires his ghostly counsel\xe2\x80\x94say\r\nwhat thou wilt, but bring him\xe2\x80\x94something I must do or attempt, but how\r\ncan I determine until I know how matters stand without?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRebecca in compliance with the wishes of Ivanhoe, made that attempt to\r\nbring Cedric into the wounded Knight\xe2\x80\x99s chamber, which was defeated as\r\nwe have already seen by the interference of Urfried, who had also been\r\non the watch to intercept the supposed monk. Rebecca retired to\r\ncommunicate to Ivanhoe the result of her errand.\r\n\r\nThey had not much leisure to regret the failure of this source of\r\nintelligence, or to contrive by what means it might be supplied; for\r\nthe noise within the castle, occasioned by the defensive preparations\r\nwhich had been considerable for some time, now increased into tenfold\r\nbustle and clamour. The heavy, yet hasty step of the men-at-arms,\r\ntraversed the battlements or resounded on the narrow and winding\r\npassages and stairs which led to the various bartisans and points of\r\ndefence. The voices of the knights were heard, animating their\r\nfollowers, or directing means of defence, while their commands were\r\noften drowned in the clashing of armour, or the clamorous shouts of\r\nthose whom they addressed. Tremendous as these sounds were, and yet\r\nmore terrible from the awful event which they presaged, there was a\r\nsublimity mixed with them, which Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s high-toned mind could feel\r\neven in that moment of terror. Her eye kindled, although the blood fled\r\nfrom her cheeks; and there was a strong mixture of fear, and of a\r\nthrilling sense of the sublime, as she repeated, half whispering to\r\nherself, half speaking to her companion, the sacred text,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe quiver\r\nrattleth\xe2\x80\x94the glittering spear and the shield\xe2\x80\x94the noise of the captains\r\nand the shouting!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Ivanhoe was like the war-horse of that sublime passage, glowing\r\nwith impatience at his inactivity, and with his ardent desire to mingle\r\nin the affray of which these sounds were the introduction. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I could\r\nbut drag myself,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cto yonder window, that I might see how this\r\nbrave game is like to go\xe2\x80\x94If I had but bow to shoot a shaft, or\r\nbattle-axe to strike were it but a single blow for our deliverance!\xe2\x80\x94It\r\nis in vain\xe2\x80\x94it is in vain\xe2\x80\x94I am alike nerveless and weaponless!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFret not thyself, noble knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cthe sounds have\r\nceased of a sudden\xe2\x80\x94it may be they join not battle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou knowest nought of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wilfred, impatiently; \xe2\x80\x9cthis dead\r\npause only shows that the men are at their posts on the walls, and\r\nexpecting an instant attack; what we have heard was but the instant\r\nmuttering of the storm\xe2\x80\x94it will burst anon in all its fury.\xe2\x80\x94Could I but\r\nreach yonder window!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou wilt but injure thyself by the attempt, noble knight,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nhis attendant. Observing his extreme solicitude, she firmly added, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nmyself will stand at the lattice, and describe to you as I can what\r\npasses without.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must not\xe2\x80\x94you shall not!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9ceach lattice, each\r\naperture, will be soon a mark for the archers; some random shaft\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt shall be welcome!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Rebecca, as with firm pace she ascended\r\ntwo or three steps, which led to the window of which they spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca, dear Rebecca!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is no maiden\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npastime\xe2\x80\x94do not expose thyself to wounds and death, and render me for\r\never miserable for having given the occasion; at least, cover thyself\r\nwith yonder ancient buckler, and show as little of your person at the\r\nlattice as may be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFollowing with wonderful promptitude the directions of Ivanhoe, and\r\navailing herself of the protection of the large ancient shield, which\r\nshe placed against the lower part of the window, Rebecca, with\r\ntolerable security to herself, could witness part of what was passing\r\nwithout the castle, and report to Ivanhoe the preparations which the\r\nassailants were making for the storm. Indeed the situation which she\r\nthus obtained was peculiarly favourable for this purpose, because,\r\nbeing placed on an angle of the main building, Rebecca could not only\r\nsee what passed beyond the precincts of the castle, but also commanded\r\na view of the outwork likely to be the first object of the meditated\r\nassault. It was an exterior fortification of no great height or\r\nstrength, intended to protect the postern-gate, through which Cedric\r\nhad been recently dismissed by Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf. The castle moat divided\r\nthis species of barbican from the rest of the fortress, so that, in\r\ncase of its being taken, it was easy to cut off the communication with\r\nthe main building, by withdrawing the temporary bridge. In the outwork\r\nwas a sallyport corresponding to the postern of the castle, and the\r\nwhole was surrounded by a strong palisade. Rebecca could observe, from\r\nthe number of men placed for the defence of this post, that the\r\nbesieged entertained apprehensions for its safety; and from the\r\nmustering of the assailants in a direction nearly opposite to the\r\noutwork, it seemed no less plain that it had been selected as a\r\nvulnerable point of attack.\r\n\r\nThese appearances she hastily communicated to Ivanhoe, and added, \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\nskirts of the wood seem lined with archers, although only a few are\r\nadvanced from its dark shadow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnder what banner?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Ivanhoe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnder no ensign of war which I can observe,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA singular novelty,\xe2\x80\x9d muttered the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cto advance to storm such a\r\ncastle without pennon or banner displayed!\xe2\x80\x94Seest thou who they be that\r\nact as leaders?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA knight, clad in sable armour, is the most conspicuous,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nJewess; \xe2\x80\x9che alone is armed from head to heel, and seems to assume the\r\ndirection of all around him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat device does he bear on his shield?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ivanhoe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething resembling a bar of iron, and a padlock painted blue on the\r\nblack shield.\xe2\x80\x9d 35\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fetterlock and shacklebolt azure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cI know not who may\r\nbear the device, but well I ween it might now be mine own. Canst thou\r\nnot see the motto?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cScarce the device itself at this distance,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cbut when\r\nthe sun glances fair upon his shield, it shows as I tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeem there no other leaders?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the anxious enquirer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone of mark and distinction that I can behold from this station,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, doubtless, the other side of the castle is also\r\nassailed. They appear even now preparing to advance\xe2\x80\x94God of Zion,\r\nprotect us!\xe2\x80\x94What a dreadful sight!\xe2\x80\x94Those who advance first bear huge\r\nshields and defences made of plank; the others follow, bending their\r\nbows as they come on.\xe2\x80\x94They raise their bows!\xe2\x80\x94God of Moses, forgive the\r\ncreatures thou hast made!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHer description was here suddenly interrupted by the signal for\r\nassault, which was given by the blast of a shrill bugle, and at once\r\nanswered by a flourish of the Norman trumpets from the battlements,\r\nwhich, mingled with the deep and hollow clang of the nakers, (a species\r\nof kettle-drum,) retorted in notes of defiance the challenge of the\r\nenemy. The shouts of both parties augmented the fearful din, the\r\nassailants crying, \xe2\x80\x9cSaint George for merry England!\xe2\x80\x9d and the Normans\r\nanswering them with loud cries of \xe2\x80\x9cEn avant De Bracy!\xe2\x80\x94Beau-seant!\r\nBeau-seant!\xe2\x80\x94Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf a la rescousse!\xe2\x80\x9d according to the war-cries\r\nof their different commanders.\r\n\r\nIt was not, however, by clamour that the contest was to be decided, and\r\nthe desperate efforts of the assailants were met by an equally vigorous\r\ndefence on the part of the besieged. The archers, trained by their\r\nwoodland pastimes to the most effective use of the long-bow, shot, to\r\nuse the appropriate phrase of the time, so \xe2\x80\x9cwholly together,\xe2\x80\x9d that no\r\npoint at which a defender could show the least part of his person,\r\nescaped their cloth-yard shafts. By this heavy discharge, which\r\ncontinued as thick and sharp as hail, while, notwithstanding, every\r\narrow had its individual aim, and flew by scores together against each\r\nembrasure and opening in the parapets, as well as at every window where\r\na defender either occasionally had post, or might be suspected to be\r\nstationed,\xe2\x80\x94by this sustained discharge, two or three of the garrison\r\nwere slain, and several others wounded. But, confident in their armour\r\nof proof, and in the cover which their situation afforded, the\r\nfollowers of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, and his allies, showed an obstinacy in\r\ndefence proportioned to the fury of the attack and replied with the\r\ndischarge of their large cross-bows, as well as with their long-bows,\r\nslings, and other missile weapons, to the close and continued shower of\r\narrows; and, as the assailants were necessarily but indifferently\r\nprotected, did considerably more damage than they received at their\r\nhand. The whizzing of shafts and of missiles, on both sides, was only\r\ninterrupted by the shouts which arose when either side inflicted or\r\nsustained some notable loss.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I must lie here like a bedridden monk,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cwhile\r\nthe game that gives me freedom or death is played out by the hand of\r\nothers!\xe2\x80\x94Look from the window once again, kind maiden, but beware that\r\nyou are not marked by the archers beneath\xe2\x80\x94Look out once more, and tell\r\nme if they yet advance to the storm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith patient courage, strengthened by the interval which she had\r\nemployed in mental devotion, Rebecca again took post at the lattice,\r\nsheltering herself, however, so as not to be visible from beneath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat dost thou see, Rebecca?\xe2\x80\x9d again demanded the wounded knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing but the cloud of arrows flying so thick as to dazzle mine\r\neyes, and to hide the bowmen who shoot them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat cannot endure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cif they press not right on to\r\ncarry the castle by pure force of arms, the archery may avail but\r\nlittle against stone walls and bulwarks. Look for the Knight of the\r\nFetterlock, fair Rebecca, and see how he bears himself; for as the\r\nleader is, so will his followers be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see him not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFoul craven!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cdoes he blench from the helm when\r\nthe wind blows highest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe blenches not! he blenches not!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cI see him now; he\r\nleads a body of men close under the outer barrier of the barbican. 36\r\n\xe2\x80\x94They pull down the piles and palisades; they hew down the barriers\r\nwith axes.\xe2\x80\x94His high black plume floats abroad over the throng, like a\r\nraven over the field of the slain.\xe2\x80\x94They have made a breach in the\r\nbarriers\xe2\x80\x94they rush in\xe2\x80\x94they are thrust back!\xe2\x80\x94Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf heads the\r\ndefenders; I see his gigantic form above the press. They throng again\r\nto the breach, and the pass is disputed hand to hand, and man to man.\r\nGod of Jacob! it is the meeting of two fierce tides\xe2\x80\x94the conflict of two\r\noceans moved by adverse winds!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe turned her head from the lattice, as if unable longer to endure a\r\nsight so terrible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook forth again, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, mistaking the cause of her\r\nretiring; \xe2\x80\x9cthe archery must in some degree have ceased, since they are\r\nnow fighting hand to hand.\xe2\x80\x94Look again, there is now less danger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRebecca again looked forth, and almost immediately exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cHoly\r\nprophets of the law! Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf and the Black Knight fight hand to\r\nhand on the breach, amid the roar of their followers, who watch the\r\nprogress of the strife\xe2\x80\x94Heaven strike with the cause of the oppressed\r\nand of the captive!\xe2\x80\x9d She then uttered a loud shriek, and exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\r\nis down!\xe2\x80\x94he is down!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is down?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cfor our dear Lady\xe2\x80\x99s sake, tell me which\r\nhas fallen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Black Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, faintly; then instantly again\r\nshouted with joyful eagerness\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBut no\xe2\x80\x94but no!\xe2\x80\x94the name of the Lord of\r\nHosts be blessed!\xe2\x80\x94he is on foot again, and fights as if there were\r\ntwenty men\xe2\x80\x99s strength in his single arm\xe2\x80\x94His sword is broken\xe2\x80\x94he snatches\r\nan axe from a yeoman\xe2\x80\x94he presses Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf with blow on blow\xe2\x80\x94The\r\ngiant stoops and totters like an oak under the steel of the woodman\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nfalls\xe2\x80\x94he falls!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ivanhoe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jewess; \xe2\x80\x9chis men rush to the rescue,\r\nheaded by the haughty Templar\xe2\x80\x94their united force compels the champion\r\nto pause\xe2\x80\x94They drag Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf within the walls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe assailants have won the barriers, have they not?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have\xe2\x80\x94they have!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Rebecca\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand they press the besieged\r\nhard upon the outer wall; some plant ladders, some swarm like bees, and\r\nendeavour to ascend upon the shoulders of each other\xe2\x80\x94down go stones,\r\nbeams, and trunks of trees upon their heads, and as fast as they bear\r\nthe wounded to the rear, fresh men supply their places in the\r\nassault\xe2\x80\x94Great God! hast thou given men thine own image, that it should\r\nbe thus cruelly defaced by the hands of their brethren!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink not of that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is no time for such\r\nthoughts\xe2\x80\x94Who yield?\xe2\x80\x94who push their way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ladders are thrown down,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rebecca, shuddering; \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nsoldiers lie grovelling under them like crushed reptiles\xe2\x80\x94The besieged\r\nhave the better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaint George strike for us!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the knight; \xe2\x80\x9cdo the false\r\nyeomen give way?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cthey bear themselves right yeomanly\xe2\x80\x94the Black\r\nKnight approaches the postern with his huge axe\xe2\x80\x94the thundering blows\r\nwhich he deals, you may hear them above all the din and shouts of the\r\nbattle\xe2\x80\x94Stones and beams are hailed down on the bold champion\xe2\x80\x94he regards\r\nthem no more than if they were thistle-down or feathers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Saint John of Acre,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, raising himself joyfully on his\r\ncouch, \xe2\x80\x9cmethought there was but one man in England that might do such a\r\ndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe postern gate shakes,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cit crashes\xe2\x80\x94it is\r\nsplintered by his blows\xe2\x80\x94they rush in\xe2\x80\x94the outwork is won\xe2\x80\x94Oh, God!\xe2\x80\x94they\r\nhurl the defenders from the battlements\xe2\x80\x94they throw them into the moat\xe2\x80\x94O\r\nmen, if ye be indeed men, spare them that can resist no longer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe bridge\xe2\x80\x94the bridge which communicates with the castle\xe2\x80\x94have they won\r\nthat pass?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Ivanhoe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Templar has destroyed the plank on which\r\nthey crossed\xe2\x80\x94few of the defenders escaped with him into the castle\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nshrieks and cries which you hear tell the fate of the others\xe2\x80\x94Alas!\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nsee it is still more difficult to look upon victory than upon battle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do they now, maiden?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9clook forth yet again\xe2\x80\x94this is\r\nno time to faint at bloodshed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is over for the time,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cour friends strengthen\r\nthemselves within the outwork which they have mastered, and it affords\r\nthem so good a shelter from the foemen\xe2\x80\x99s shot, that the garrison only\r\nbestow a few bolts on it from interval to interval, as if rather to\r\ndisquiet than effectually to injure them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wilfred, \xe2\x80\x9cwill surely not abandon an enterprise so\r\ngloriously begun and so happily attained.\xe2\x80\x94O no! I will put my faith in\r\nthe good knight whose axe hath rent heart-of-oak and bars of\r\niron.\xe2\x80\x94Singular,\xe2\x80\x9d he again muttered to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cif there be two who can\r\ndo a deed of such derring-do! 37\xe2\x80\x94a fetterlock, and a shacklebolt on a\r\nfield sable\xe2\x80\x94what may that mean?\xe2\x80\x94seest thou nought else, Rebecca, by\r\nwhich the Black Knight may be distinguished?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jewess; \xe2\x80\x9call about him is black as the wing of the\r\nnight raven. Nothing can I spy that can mark him further\xe2\x80\x94but having\r\nonce seen him put forth his strength in battle, methinks I could know\r\nhim again among a thousand warriors. He rushes to the fray as if he\r\nwere summoned to a banquet. There is more than mere strength, there\r\nseems as if the whole soul and spirit of the champion were given to\r\nevery blow which he deals upon his enemies. God assoilize him of the\r\nsin of bloodshed!\xe2\x80\x94it is fearful, yet magnificent, to behold how the arm\r\nand heart of one man can triumph over hundreds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast painted a hero; surely they rest\r\nbut to refresh their force, or to provide the means of crossing the\r\nmoat\xe2\x80\x94Under such a leader as thou hast spoken this knight to be, there\r\nare no craven fears, no cold-blooded delays, no yielding up a gallant\r\nemprize; since the difficulties which render it arduous render it also\r\nglorious. I swear by the honour of my house\xe2\x80\x94I vow by the name of my\r\nbright lady-love, I would endure ten years\xe2\x80\x99 captivity to fight one day\r\nby that good knight\xe2\x80\x99s side in such a quarrel as this!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, leaving her station at the window, and\r\napproaching the couch of the wounded knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthis impatient yearning\r\nafter action\xe2\x80\x94this struggling with and repining at your present\r\nweakness, will not fail to injure your returning health\xe2\x80\x94How couldst\r\nthou hope to inflict wounds on others, ere that be healed which thou\r\nthyself hast received?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cthou knowest not how impossible it is for one\r\ntrained to actions of chivalry to remain passive as a priest, or a\r\nwoman, when they are acting deeds of honour around him. The love of\r\nbattle is the food upon which we live\xe2\x80\x94the dust of the \xe2\x80\x98melee\xe2\x80\x99 is the\r\nbreath of our nostrils! We live not\xe2\x80\x94we wish not to live\xe2\x80\x94longer than\r\nwhile we are victorious and renowned\xe2\x80\x94Such, maiden, are the laws of\r\nchivalry to which we are sworn, and to which we offer all that we hold\r\ndear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said the fair Jewess, \xe2\x80\x9cand what is it, valiant knight, save an\r\noffering of sacrifice to a demon of vain glory, and a passing through\r\nthe fire to Moloch?\xe2\x80\x94What remains to you as the prize of all the blood\r\nyou have spilled\xe2\x80\x94of all the travail and pain you have endured\xe2\x80\x94of all\r\nthe tears which your deeds have caused, when death hath broken the\r\nstrong man\xe2\x80\x99s spear, and overtaken the speed of his war-horse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat remains?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cGlory, maiden, glory! which gilds our\r\nsepulchre and embalms our name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGlory?\xe2\x80\x9d continued Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9calas, is the rusted mail which hangs as a\r\nhatchment over the champion\xe2\x80\x99s dim and mouldering tomb\xe2\x80\x94is the defaced\r\nsculpture of the inscription which the ignorant monk can hardly read to\r\nthe enquiring pilgrim\xe2\x80\x94are these sufficient rewards for the sacrifice of\r\nevery kindly affection, for a life spent miserably that ye may make\r\nothers miserable? Or is there such virtue in the rude rhymes of a\r\nwandering bard, that domestic love, kindly affection, peace and\r\nhappiness, are so wildly bartered, to become the hero of those ballads\r\nwhich vagabond minstrels sing to drunken churls over their evening\r\nale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the soul of Hereward!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the knight impatiently, \xe2\x80\x9cthou\r\nspeakest, maiden, of thou knowest not what. Thou wouldst quench the\r\npure light of chivalry, which alone distinguishes the noble from the\r\nbase, the gentle knight from the churl and the savage; which rates our\r\nlife far, far beneath the pitch of our honour; raises us victorious\r\nover pain, toil, and suffering, and teaches us to fear no evil but\r\ndisgrace. Thou art no Christian, Rebecca; and to thee are unknown those\r\nhigh feelings which swell the bosom of a noble maiden when her lover\r\nhath done some deed of emprize which sanctions his flame.\r\nChivalry!\xe2\x80\x94why, maiden, she is the nurse of pure and high affection\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nstay of the oppressed, the redresser of grievances, the curb of the\r\npower of the tyrant\xe2\x80\x94Nobility were but an empty name without her, and\r\nliberty finds the best protection in her lance and her sword.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9csprung from a race whose courage was\r\ndistinguished in the defence of their own land, but who warred not,\r\neven while yet a nation, save at the command of the Deity, or in\r\ndefending their country from oppression. The sound of the trumpet wakes\r\nJudah no longer, and her despised children are now but the unresisting\r\nvictims of hostile and military oppression. Well hast thou spoken, Sir\r\nKnight,\xe2\x80\x94until the God of Jacob shall raise up for his chosen people a\r\nsecond Gideon, or a new Maccabeus, it ill beseemeth the Jewish damsel\r\nto speak of battle or of war.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe high-minded maiden concluded the argument in a tone of sorrow,\r\nwhich deeply expressed her sense of the degradation of her people,\r\nembittered perhaps by the idea that Ivanhoe considered her as one not\r\nentitled to interfere in a case of honour, and incapable of\r\nentertaining or expressing sentiments of honour and generosity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow little he knows this bosom,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cto imagine that cowardice\r\nor meanness of soul must needs be its guests, because I have censured\r\nthe fantastic chivalry of the Nazarenes! Would to heaven that the\r\nshedding of mine own blood, drop by drop, could redeem the captivity of\r\nJudah! Nay, would to God it could avail to set free my father, and this\r\nhis benefactor, from the chains of the oppressor! The proud Christian\r\nshould then see whether the daughter of God\xe2\x80\x99s chosen people dared not\r\nto die as bravely as the vainest Nazarene maiden, that boasts her\r\ndescent from some petty chieftain of the rude and frozen north!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe then looked towards the couch of the wounded knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe sleeps,\xe2\x80\x9d she said; \xe2\x80\x9cnature exhausted by sufferance and the waste of\r\nspirits, his wearied frame embraces the first moment of temporary\r\nrelaxation to sink into slumber. Alas! is it a crime that I should look\r\nupon him, when it may be for the last time?\xe2\x80\x94When yet but a short space,\r\nand those fair features will be no longer animated by the bold and\r\nbuoyant spirit which forsakes them not even in sleep!\xe2\x80\x94When the nostril\r\nshall be distended, the mouth agape, the eyes fixed and bloodshot; and\r\nwhen the proud and noble knight may be trodden on by the lowest caitiff\r\nof this accursed castle, yet stir not when the heel is lifted up\r\nagainst him!\xe2\x80\x94And my father!\xe2\x80\x94oh, my father! evil is it with his\r\ndaughter, when his grey hairs are not remembered because of the golden\r\nlocks of youth!\xe2\x80\x94What know I but that these evils are the messengers of\r\nJehovah\xe2\x80\x99s wrath to the unnatural child, who thinks of a stranger\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncaptivity before a parent\xe2\x80\x99s? who forgets the desolation of Judah, and\r\nlooks upon the comeliness of a Gentile and a stranger?\xe2\x80\x94But I will tear\r\nthis folly from my heart, though every fibre bleed as I rend it away!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe wrapped herself closely in her veil, and sat down at a distance\r\nfrom the couch of the wounded knight, with her back turned towards it,\r\nfortifying, or endeavouring to fortify her mind, not only against the\r\nimpending evils from without, but also against those treacherous\r\nfeelings which assailed her from within.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXX\r\n\r\n\r\nApproach the chamber, look upon his bed.\r\nHis is the passing of no peaceful ghost,\r\nWhich, as the lark arises to the sky,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Mid morning\xe2\x80\x99s sweetest breeze and softest dew,\r\nIs wing\xe2\x80\x99d to heaven by good men\xe2\x80\x99s sighs and tears!\xe2\x80\x94\r\nAnselm parts otherwise.\r\n\r\n\r\nOLD PLAY\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring the interval of quiet which followed the first success of the\r\nbesiegers, while the one party was preparing to pursue their advantage,\r\nand the other to strengthen their means of defence, the Templar and De\r\nBracy held brief council together in the hall of the castle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf?\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, who had superintended the\r\ndefence of the fortress on the other side; \xe2\x80\x9cmen say he hath been\r\nslain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe lives,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, coolly, \xe2\x80\x9clives as yet; but had he worn\r\nthe bull\xe2\x80\x99s head of which he bears the name, and ten plates of iron to\r\nfence it withal, he must have gone down before yonder fatal axe. Yet a\r\nfew hours, and Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf is with his fathers\xe2\x80\x94a powerful limb lopped\r\noff Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s enterprise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a brave addition to the kingdom of Satan,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cthis\r\ncomes of reviling saints and angels, and ordering images of holy things\r\nand holy men to be flung down on the heads of these rascaille yeomen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to\xe2\x80\x94thou art a fool,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cthy superstition is upon a\r\nlevel with Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s want of faith; neither of you can render a\r\nreason for your belief or unbelief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBenedicite, Sir Templar,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cpray you to keep better\r\nrule with your tongue when I am the theme of it. By the Mother of\r\nHeaven, I am a better Christian man than thou and thy fellowship; for\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x98bruit\xe2\x80\x99 goeth shrewdly out, that the most holy Order of the Temple\r\nof Zion nurseth not a few heretics within its bosom, and that Sir Brian\r\nde Bois-Guilbert is of the number.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCare not thou for such reports,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cbut let us think\r\nof making good the castle.\xe2\x80\x94How fought these villain yeomen on thy\r\nside?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike fiends incarnate,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy. \xe2\x80\x9cThey swarmed close up to the\r\nwalls, headed, as I think, by the knave who won the prize at the\r\narchery, for I knew his horn and baldric. And this is old Fitzurse\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nboasted policy, encouraging these malapert knaves to rebel against us!\r\nHad I not been armed in proof, the villain had marked me down seven\r\ntimes with as little remorse as if I had been a buck in season. He told\r\nevery rivet on my armour with a cloth-yard shaft, that rapped against\r\nmy ribs with as little compunction as if my bones had been of iron\xe2\x80\x94But\r\nthat I wore a shirt of Spanish mail under my plate-coat, I had been\r\nfairly sped.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you maintained your post?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar. \xe2\x80\x9cWe lost the outwork\r\non our part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a shrewd loss,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cthe knaves will find cover\r\nthere to assault the castle more closely, and may, if not well watched,\r\ngain some unguarded corner of a tower, or some forgotten window, and so\r\nbreak in upon us. Our numbers are too few for the defence of every\r\npoint, and the men complain that they can nowhere show themselves, but\r\nthey are the mark for as many arrows as a parish-butt on a holyday\r\neven. Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf is dying too, so we shall receive no more aid from\r\nhis bull\xe2\x80\x99s head and brutal strength. How think you, Sir Brian, were we\r\nnot better make a virtue of necessity, and compound with the rogues by\r\ndelivering up our prisoners?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cdeliver up our prisoners, and stand an\r\nobject alike of ridicule and execration, as the doughty warriors who\r\ndared by a night-attack to possess themselves of the persons of a party\r\nof defenceless travellers, yet could not make good a strong castle\r\nagainst a vagabond troop of outlaws, led by swineherds, jesters, and\r\nthe very refuse of mankind?\xe2\x80\x94Shame on thy counsel, Maurice de Bracy!\xe2\x80\x94The\r\nruins of this castle shall bury both my body and my shame, ere I\r\nconsent to such base and dishonourable composition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us to the walls, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, carelessly; \xe2\x80\x9cthat man never\r\nbreathed, be he Turk or Templar, who held life at lighter rate than I\r\ndo. But I trust there is no dishonour in wishing I had here some two\r\nscores of my gallant troop of Free Companions?\xe2\x80\x94Oh, my brave lances! if\r\nye knew but how hard your captain were this day bested, how soon should\r\nI see my banner at the head of your clump of spears! And how short\r\nwhile would these rabble villains stand to endure your encounter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWish for whom thou wilt,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cbut let us make what\r\ndefence we can with the soldiers who remain\xe2\x80\x94They are chiefly\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s followers, hated by the English for a thousand acts of\r\ninsolence and oppression.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe better,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cthe rugged slaves will defend themselves\r\nto the last drop of their blood, ere they encounter the revenge of the\r\npeasants without. Let us up and be doing, then, Brian de Bois-Guilbert;\r\nand, live or die, thou shalt see Maurice de Bracy bear himself this day\r\nas a gentleman of blood and lineage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the walls!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar; and they both ascended the\r\nbattlements to do all that skill could dictate, and manhood accomplish,\r\nin defence of the place. They readily agreed that the point of greatest\r\ndanger was that opposite to the outwork of which the assailants had\r\npossessed themselves. The castle, indeed, was divided from that\r\nbarbican by the moat, and it was impossible that the besiegers could\r\nassail the postern-door, with which the outwork corresponded, without\r\nsurmounting that obstacle; but it was the opinion both of the Templar\r\nand De Bracy, that the besiegers, if governed by the same policy their\r\nleader had already displayed, would endeavour, by a formidable assault,\r\nto draw the chief part of the defenders\xe2\x80\x99 observation to this point, and\r\ntake measures to avail themselves of every negligence which might take\r\nplace in the defence elsewhere. To guard against such an evil, their\r\nnumbers only permitted the knights to place sentinels from space to\r\nspace along the walls in communication with each other, who might give\r\nthe alarm whenever danger was threatened. Meanwhile, they agreed that\r\nDe Bracy should command the defence at the postern, and the Templar\r\nshould keep with him a score of men or thereabouts as a body of\r\nreserve, ready to hasten to any other point which might be suddenly\r\nthreatened. The loss of the barbican had also this unfortunate effect,\r\nthat, notwithstanding the superior height of the castle walls, the\r\nbesieged could not see from them, with the same precision as before,\r\nthe operations of the enemy; for some straggling underwood approached\r\nso near the sallyport of the outwork, that the assailants might\r\nintroduce into it whatever force they thought proper, not only under\r\ncover, but even without the knowledge of the defenders. Utterly\r\nuncertain, therefore, upon what point the storm was to burst, De Bracy\r\nand his companion were under the necessity of providing against every\r\npossible contingency, and their followers, however brave, experienced\r\nthe anxious dejection of mind incident to men enclosed by enemies, who\r\npossessed the power of choosing their time and mode of attack.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, the lord of the beleaguered and endangered castle lay upon a\r\nbed of bodily pain and mental agony. He had not the usual resource of\r\nbigots in that superstitious period, most of whom were wont to atone\r\nfor the crimes they were guilty of by liberality to the church,\r\nstupefying by this means their terrors by the idea of atonement and\r\nforgiveness; and although the refuge which success thus purchased, was\r\nno more like to the peace of mind which follows on sincere repentance,\r\nthan the turbid stupefaction procured by opium resembles healthy and\r\nnatural slumbers, it was still a state of mind preferable to the\r\nagonies of awakened remorse. But among the vices of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, a\r\nhard and griping man, avarice was predominant; and he preferred setting\r\nchurch and churchmen at defiance, to purchasing from them pardon and\r\nabsolution at the price of treasure and of manors. Nor did the Templar,\r\nan infidel of another stamp, justly characterise his associate, when he\r\nsaid Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf could assign no cause for his unbelief and contempt\r\nfor the established faith; for the Baron would have alleged that the\r\nChurch sold her wares too dear, that the spiritual freedom which she\r\nput up to sale was only to be bought like that of the chief captain of\r\nJerusalem, \xe2\x80\x9cwith a great sum,\xe2\x80\x9d and Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf preferred denying the\r\nvirtue of the medicine, to paying the expense of the physician.\r\n\r\nBut the moment had now arrived when earth and all his treasures were\r\ngliding from before his eyes, and when the savage Baron\xe2\x80\x99s heart, though\r\nhard as a nether millstone, became appalled as he gazed forward into\r\nthe waste darkness of futurity. The fever of his body aided the\r\nimpatience and agony of his mind, and his death-bed exhibited a mixture\r\nof the newly awakened feelings of horror, combating with the fixed and\r\ninveterate obstinacy of his disposition;\xe2\x80\x94a fearful state of mind, only\r\nto be equalled in those tremendous regions, where there are complaints\r\nwithout hope, remorse without repentance, a dreadful sense of present\r\nagony, and a presentiment that it cannot cease or be diminished!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere be these dog-priests now,\xe2\x80\x9d growled the Baron, \xe2\x80\x9cwho set such\r\nprice on their ghostly mummery?\xe2\x80\x94where be all those unshod Carmelites,\r\nfor whom old Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf founded the convent of St Anne, robbing his\r\nheir of many a fair rood of meadow, and many a fat field and\r\nclose\xe2\x80\x94where be the greedy hounds now?\xe2\x80\x94Swilling, I warrant me, at the\r\nale, or playing their juggling tricks at the bedside of some miserly\r\nchurl.\xe2\x80\x94Me, the heir of their founder\xe2\x80\x94me, whom their foundation binds\r\nthem to pray for\xe2\x80\x94me\xe2\x80\x94ungrateful villains as they are!\xe2\x80\x94they suffer to die\r\nlike the houseless dog on yonder common, unshriven and unhouseled!\xe2\x80\x94Tell\r\nthe Templar to come hither\xe2\x80\x94he is a priest, and may do something\xe2\x80\x94But\r\nno!\xe2\x80\x94as well confess myself to the devil as to Brian de Bois-Guilbert,\r\nwho recks neither of heaven nor of hell.\xe2\x80\x94I have heard old men talk of\r\nprayer\xe2\x80\x94prayer by their own voice\xe2\x80\x94Such need not to court or to bribe the\r\nfalse priest\xe2\x80\x94But I\xe2\x80\x94I dare not!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLives Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\xe2\x80\x9d said a broken and shrill voice close by\r\nhis bedside, \xe2\x80\x9cto say there is that which he dares not!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe evil conscience and the shaken nerves of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf heard, in\r\nthis strange interruption to his soliloquy, the voice of one of those\r\ndemons, who, as the superstition of the times believed, beset the beds\r\nof dying men to distract their thoughts, and turn them from the\r\nmeditations which concerned their eternal welfare. He shuddered and\r\ndrew himself together; but, instantly summoning up his wonted\r\nresolution, he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cWho is there?\xe2\x80\x94what art thou, that darest to\r\necho my words in a tone like that of the night-raven?\xe2\x80\x94Come before my\r\ncouch that I may see thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am thine evil angel, Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me behold thee then in thy bodily shape, if thou be\xe2\x80\x99st indeed a\r\nfiend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the dying knight; \xe2\x80\x9cthink not that I will blench from\r\nthee.\xe2\x80\x94By the eternal dungeon, could I but grapple with these horrors\r\nthat hover round me, as I have done with mortal dangers, heaven or hell\r\nshould never say that I shrunk from the conflict!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink on thy sins, Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\xe2\x80\x9d said the almost unearthly\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x9con rebellion, on rapine, on murder!\xe2\x80\x94Who stirred up the\r\nlicentious John to war against his grey-headed father\xe2\x80\x94against his\r\ngenerous brother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe thou fiend, priest, or devil,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cthou liest\r\nin thy throat!\xe2\x80\x94Not I stirred John to rebellion\xe2\x80\x94not I alone\xe2\x80\x94there were\r\nfifty knights and barons, the flower of the midland counties\xe2\x80\x94better men\r\nnever laid lance in rest\xe2\x80\x94And must I answer for the fault done by\r\nfifty?\xe2\x80\x94False fiend, I defy thee! Depart, and haunt my couch no more\xe2\x80\x94let\r\nme die in peace if thou be mortal\xe2\x80\x94if thou be a demon, thy time is not\r\nyet come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn peace thou shalt NOT die,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the voice; \xe2\x80\x9ceven in death shalt\r\nthou think on thy murders\xe2\x80\x94on the groans which this castle has echoed\xe2\x80\x94on\r\nthe blood that is engrained in its floors!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou canst not shake me by thy petty malice,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\r\nwith a ghastly and constrained laugh. \xe2\x80\x9cThe infidel Jew\xe2\x80\x94it was merit\r\nwith heaven to deal with him as I did, else wherefore are men canonized\r\nwho dip their hands in the blood of Saracens?\xe2\x80\x94The Saxon porkers, whom I\r\nhave slain, they were the foes of my country, and of my lineage, and of\r\nmy liege lord.\xe2\x80\x94Ho! ho! thou seest there is no crevice in my coat of\r\nplate\xe2\x80\x94Art thou fled?\xe2\x80\x94art thou silenced?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, foul parricide!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the voice; \xe2\x80\x9cthink of thy father!\xe2\x80\x94think of\r\nhis death!\xe2\x80\x94think of his banquet-room flooded with his gore, and that\r\npoured forth by the hand of a son!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Baron, after a long pause, \xe2\x80\x9can thou knowest that,\r\nthou art indeed the author of evil, and as omniscient as the monks call\r\nthee!\xe2\x80\x94That secret I deemed locked in my own breast, and in that of one\r\nbesides\xe2\x80\x94the temptress, the partaker of my guilt.\xe2\x80\x94Go, leave me, fiend!\r\nand seek the Saxon witch Ulrica, who alone could tell thee what she and\r\nI alone witnessed.\xe2\x80\x94Go, I say, to her, who washed the wounds, and\r\nstraighted the corpse, and gave to the slain man the outward show of\r\none parted in time and in the course of nature\xe2\x80\x94Go to her, she was my\r\ntemptress, the foul provoker, the more foul rewarder, of the deed\xe2\x80\x94let\r\nher, as well as I, taste of the tortures which anticipate hell!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe already tastes them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ulrica, stepping before the couch of\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cshe hath long drunken of this cup, and its bitterness\r\nis now sweetened to see that thou dost partake it.\xe2\x80\x94Grind not thy teeth,\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x94roll not thine eyes\xe2\x80\x94clench not thine hand, nor shake it\r\nat me with that gesture of menace!\xe2\x80\x94The hand which, like that of thy\r\nrenowned ancestor who gained thy name, could have broken with one\r\nstroke the skull of a mountain-bull, is now unnerved and powerless as\r\nmine own!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVile murderous hag!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cdetestable screech-owl!\r\nit is then thou who art come to exult over the ruins thou hast assisted\r\nto lay low?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, Reginald Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf,\xe2\x80\x9d answered she, \xe2\x80\x9cit is Ulrica!\xe2\x80\x94it is the\r\ndaughter of the murdered Torquil Wolfganger!\xe2\x80\x94it is the sister of his\r\nslaughtered sons!\xe2\x80\x94it is she who demands of thee, and of thy father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouse, father and kindred, name and fame\xe2\x80\x94all that she has lost by the\r\nname of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf!\xe2\x80\x94Think of my wrongs, Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, and answer me\r\nif I speak not truth. Thou hast been my evil angel, and I will be\r\nthine\xe2\x80\x94I will dog thee till the very instant of dissolution!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDetestable fury!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, \xe2\x80\x9cthat moment shalt thou\r\nnever witness\xe2\x80\x94Ho! Giles, Clement, and Eustace! Saint Maur, and Stephen!\r\nseize this damned witch, and hurl her from the battlements headlong\xe2\x80\x94she\r\nhas betrayed us to the Saxon!\xe2\x80\x94Ho! Saint Maur! Clement! false-hearted,\r\nknaves, where tarry ye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall on them again, valiant Baron,\xe2\x80\x9d said the hag, with a smile of\r\ngrisly mockery; \xe2\x80\x9csummon thy vassals around thee, doom them that loiter\r\nto the scourge and the dungeon\xe2\x80\x94But know, mighty chief,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued,\r\nsuddenly changing her tone, \xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt have neither answer, nor aid,\r\nnor obedience at their hands.\xe2\x80\x94Listen to these horrid sounds,\xe2\x80\x9d for the\r\ndin of the recommenced assault and defence now rung fearfully loud from\r\nthe battlements of the castle; \xe2\x80\x9cin that war-cry is the downfall of thy\r\nhouse\xe2\x80\x94The blood-cemented fabric of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s power totters to the\r\nfoundation, and before the foes he most despised!\xe2\x80\x94The Saxon,\r\nReginald!\xe2\x80\x94the scorned Saxon assails thy walls!\xe2\x80\x94Why liest thou here,\r\nlike a worn-out hind, when the Saxon storms thy place of strength?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGods and fiends!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the wounded knight; \xe2\x80\x9cO, for one moment\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nstrength, to drag myself to the \xe2\x80\x98melee\xe2\x80\x99, and perish as becomes my\r\nname!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink not of it, valiant warrior!\xe2\x80\x9d replied she; \xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt die no\r\nsoldier\xe2\x80\x99s death, but perish like the fox in his den, when the peasants\r\nhave set fire to the cover around it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHateful hag! thou liest!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf; \xe2\x80\x9cmy followers bear\r\nthem bravely\xe2\x80\x94my walls are strong and high\xe2\x80\x94my comrades in arms fear not\r\na whole host of Saxons, were they headed by Hengist and Horsa!\xe2\x80\x94The\r\nwar-cry of the Templar and of the Free Companions rises high over the\r\nconflict! And by mine honour, when we kindle the blazing beacon, for\r\njoy of our defence, it shall consume thee, body and bones; and I shall\r\nlive to hear thou art gone from earthly fires to those of that hell,\r\nwhich never sent forth an incarnate fiend more utterly diabolical!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold thy belief,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Ulrica, \xe2\x80\x9ctill the proof reach thee\xe2\x80\x94But, no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe said, interrupting herself, \xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt know, even now, the doom,\r\nwhich all thy power, strength, and courage, is unable to avoid, though\r\nit is prepared for thee by this feeble band.
