Markest thou the\r\nsmouldering and suffocating vapour which already eddies in sable folds\r\nthrough the chamber?\xe2\x80\x94Didst thou think it was but the darkening of thy\r\nbursting eyes\xe2\x80\x94the difficulty of thy cumbered breathing?\xe2\x80\x94No!\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf, there is another cause\xe2\x80\x94Rememberest thou the magazine of\r\nfuel that is stored beneath these apartments?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWoman!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed with fury, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast not set fire to it?\xe2\x80\x94By\r\nheaven, thou hast, and the castle is in flames!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are fast rising at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ulrica, with frightful composure;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand a signal shall soon wave to warn the besiegers to press hard upon\r\nthose who would extinguish them.\xe2\x80\x94Farewell, Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf!\xe2\x80\x94May Mista,\r\nSkogula, and Zernebock, gods of the ancient Saxons\xe2\x80\x94fiends, as the\r\npriests now call them\xe2\x80\x94supply the place of comforters at your dying bed,\r\nwhich Ulrica now relinquishes!\xe2\x80\x94But know, if it will give thee comfort\r\nto know it, that Ulrica is bound to the same dark coast with thyself,\r\nthe companion of thy punishment as the companion of thy guilt.\xe2\x80\x94And now,\r\nparricide, farewell for ever!\xe2\x80\x94May each stone of this vaulted roof find\r\na tongue to echo that title into thine ear!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, she left the apartment; and Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf could hear the\r\ncrash of the ponderous key, as she locked and double-locked the door\r\nbehind her, thus cutting off the most slender chance of escape. In the\r\nextremity of agony he shouted upon his servants and allies\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cStephen and\r\nSaint Maur!\xe2\x80\x94Clement and Giles!\xe2\x80\x94I burn here unaided!\xe2\x80\x94To the rescue\xe2\x80\x94to\r\nthe rescue, brave Bois-Guilbert, valiant De Bracy!\xe2\x80\x94It is Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\r\nwho calls!\xe2\x80\x94It is your master, ye traitor squires!\xe2\x80\x94Your ally\xe2\x80\x94your\r\nbrother in arms, ye perjured and faithless knights!\xe2\x80\x94all the curses due\r\nto traitors upon your recreant heads, do you abandon me to perish thus\r\nmiserably!\xe2\x80\x94They hear me not\xe2\x80\x94they cannot hear me\xe2\x80\x94my voice is lost in the\r\ndin of battle.\xe2\x80\x94The smoke rolls thicker and thicker\xe2\x80\x94the fire has caught\r\nupon the floor below\xe2\x80\x94O, for one drought of the air of heaven, were it\r\nto be purchased by instant annihilation!\xe2\x80\x9d And in the mad frenzy of\r\ndespair, the wretch now shouted with the shouts of the fighters, now\r\nmuttered curses on himself, on mankind, and on Heaven itself.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe red\r\nfire flashes through the thick smoke!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed; \xe2\x80\x9cthe demon marches\r\nagainst me under the banner of his own element\xe2\x80\x94Foul spirit, avoid!\xe2\x80\x94I go\r\nnot with thee without my comrades\xe2\x80\x94all, all are thine, that garrison\r\nthese walls\xe2\x80\x94Thinkest thou Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf will be singled out to go\r\nalone?\xe2\x80\x94No\xe2\x80\x94the infidel Templar\xe2\x80\x94the licentious De Bracy\xe2\x80\x94Ulrica, the foul\r\nmurdering strumpet\xe2\x80\x94the men who aided my enterprises\xe2\x80\x94the dog Saxons and\r\naccursed Jews, who are my prisoners\xe2\x80\x94all, all shall attend me\xe2\x80\x94a goodly\r\nfellowship as ever took the downward road\xe2\x80\x94Ha, ha, ha!\xe2\x80\x9d and he laughed\r\nin his frenzy till the vaulted roof rang again. \xe2\x80\x9cWho laughed there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nexclaimed Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, in altered mood, for the noise of the conflict\r\ndid not prevent the echoes of his own mad laughter from returning upon\r\nhis ear\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwho laughed there?\xe2\x80\x94Ulrica, was it thou?\xe2\x80\x94Speak, witch, and I\r\nforgive thee\xe2\x80\x94for, only thou or the fiend of hell himself could have\r\nlaughed at such a moment. Avaunt\xe2\x80\x94avaunt!\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut it were impious to trace any farther the picture of the blasphemer\r\nand parricide\xe2\x80\x99s deathbed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXI\r\n\r\n\r\nOnce more unto the breach, dear friends, once more,\r\nOr, close the wall up with our English dead.\r\n\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94And you, good yeomen,\r\nWhose limbs were made in England, show us here\r\nThe mettle of your pasture\xe2\x80\x94let us swear\r\nThat you are worth your breeding.\r\n\r\n\r\nKING HENRY V\r\n\r\n\r\nCedric, although not greatly confident in Ulrica\xe2\x80\x99s message, omitted not\r\nto communicate her promise to the Black Knight and Locksley. They were\r\nwell pleased to find they had a friend within the place, who might, in\r\nthe moment of need, be able to facilitate their entrance, and readily\r\nagreed with the Saxon that a storm, under whatever disadvantages, ought\r\nto be attempted, as the only means of liberating the prisoners now in\r\nthe hands of the cruel Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe royal blood of Alfred is endangered,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe honour of a noble lady is in peril,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, by the Saint Christopher at my baldric,\xe2\x80\x9d said the good yeoman,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwere there no other cause than the safety of that poor faithful knave,\r\nWamba, I would jeopard a joint ere a hair of his head were hurt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so would I,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat, sirs! I trust well that a\r\nfool\xe2\x80\x94I mean, d\xe2\x80\x99ye see me, sirs, a fool that is free of his guild and\r\nmaster of his craft, and can give as much relish and flavour to a cup\r\nof wine as ever a flitch of bacon can\xe2\x80\x94I say, brethren, such a fool\r\nshall never want a wise clerk to pray for or fight for him at a strait,\r\nwhile I can say a mass or flourish a partisan.\xe2\x80\x9d And with that he made\r\nhis heavy halberd to play around his head as a shepherd boy flourishes\r\nhis light crook.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, Holy Clerk,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, \xe2\x80\x9ctrue as if Saint Dunstan\r\nhimself had said it.\xe2\x80\x94And now, good Locksley, were it not well that\r\nnoble Cedric should assume the direction of this assault?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a jot I,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cI have never been wont to study either\r\nhow to take or how to hold out those abodes of tyrannic power, which\r\nthe Normans have erected in this groaning land. I will fight among the\r\nforemost; but my honest neighbours well know I am not a trained soldier\r\nin the discipline of wars, or the attack of strongholds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince it stands thus with noble Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9cI am most\r\nwilling to take on me the direction of the archery; and ye shall hang\r\nme up on my own Trysting-tree, an the defenders be permitted to show\r\nthemselves over the walls without being stuck with as many shafts as\r\nthere are cloves in a gammon of bacon at Christmas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell said, stout yeoman,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Black Knight; \xe2\x80\x9cand if I be\r\nthought worthy to have a charge in these matters, and can find among\r\nthese brave men as many as are willing to follow a true English knight,\r\nfor so I may surely call myself, I am ready, with such skill as my\r\nexperience has taught me, to lead them to the attack of these walls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe parts being thus distributed to the leaders, they commenced the\r\nfirst assault, of which the reader has already heard the issue.\r\n\r\nWhen the barbican was carried, the Sable Knight sent notice of the\r\nhappy event to Locksley, requesting him at the same time, to keep such\r\na strict observation on the castle as might prevent the defenders from\r\ncombining their force for a sudden sally, and recovering the outwork\r\nwhich they had lost. This the knight was chiefly desirous of avoiding,\r\nconscious that the men whom he led, being hasty and untrained\r\nvolunteers, imperfectly armed and unaccustomed to discipline, must,\r\nupon any sudden attack, fight at great disadvantage with the veteran\r\nsoldiers of the Norman knights, who were well provided with arms both\r\ndefensive and offensive; and who, to match the zeal and high spirit of\r\nthe besiegers, had all the confidence which arises from perfect\r\ndiscipline and the habitual use of weapons.\r\n\r\nThe knight employed the interval in causing to be constructed a sort of\r\nfloating bridge, or long raft, by means of which he hoped to cross the\r\nmoat in despite of the resistance of the enemy. This was a work of some\r\ntime, which the leaders the less regretted, as it gave Ulrica leisure\r\nto execute her plan of diversion in their favour, whatever that might\r\nbe.\r\n\r\nWhen the raft was completed, the Black Knight addressed the\r\nbesiegers:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt avails not waiting here longer, my friends; the sun is\r\ndescending to the west\xe2\x80\x94and I have that upon my hands which will not\r\npermit me to tarry with you another day. Besides, it will be a marvel\r\nif the horsemen come not upon us from York, unless we speedily\r\naccomplish our purpose. Wherefore, one of ye go to Locksley, and bid\r\nhim commence a discharge of arrows on the opposite side of the castle,\r\nand move forward as if about to assault it; and you, true English\r\nhearts, stand by me, and be ready to thrust the raft endlong over the\r\nmoat whenever the postern on our side is thrown open. Follow me boldly\r\nacross, and aid me to burst yon sallyport in the main wall of the\r\ncastle. As many of you as like not this service, or are but ill armed\r\nto meet it, do you man the top of the outwork, draw your bow-strings to\r\nyour ears, and mind you quell with your shot whatever shall appear to\r\nman the rampart\xe2\x80\x94Noble Cedric, wilt thou take the direction of those\r\nwhich remain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so, by the soul of Hereward!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Saxon; \xe2\x80\x9clead I cannot; but\r\nmay posterity curse me in my grave, if I follow not with the foremost\r\nwherever thou shalt point the way\xe2\x80\x94The quarrel is mine, and well it\r\nbecomes me to be in the van of the battle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet, bethink thee, noble Saxon,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast neither\r\nhauberk, nor corslet, nor aught but that light helmet, target, and\r\nsword.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe better!\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall be the lighter to climb these\r\nwalls. And,\xe2\x80\x94forgive the boast, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x94thou shalt this day see the\r\nnaked breast of a Saxon as boldly presented to the battle as ever ye\r\nbeheld the steel corslet of a Norman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of God, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cfling open the door, and\r\nlaunch the floating bridge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe portal, which led from the inner-wall of the barbican to the moat,\r\nand which corresponded with a sallyport in the main wall of the castle,\r\nwas now suddenly opened; the temporary bridge was then thrust forward,\r\nand soon flashed in the waters, extending its length between the castle\r\nand outwork, and forming a slippery and precarious passage for two men\r\nabreast to cross the moat. Well aware of the importance of taking the\r\nfoe by surprise, the Black Knight, closely followed by Cedric, threw\r\nhimself upon the bridge, and reached the opposite side. Here he began\r\nto thunder with his axe upon the gate of the castle, protected in part\r\nfrom the shot and stones cast by the defenders by the ruins of the\r\nformer drawbridge, which the Templar had demolished in his retreat from\r\nthe barbican, leaving the counterpoise still attached to the upper part\r\nof the portal. The followers of the knight had no such shelter; two\r\nwere instantly shot with cross-bow bolts, and two more fell into the\r\nmoat; the others retreated back into the barbican.\r\n\r\nThe situation of Cedric and of the Black Knight was now truly\r\ndangerous, and would have been still more so, but for the constancy of\r\nthe archers in the barbican, who ceased not to shower their arrows upon\r\nthe battlements, distracting the attention of those by whom they were\r\nmanned, and thus affording a respite to their two chiefs from the storm\r\nof missiles which must otherwise have overwhelmed them. But their\r\nsituation was eminently perilous, and was becoming more so with every\r\nmoment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShame on ye all!\xe2\x80\x9d cried De Bracy to the soldiers around him; \xe2\x80\x9cdo ye\r\ncall yourselves cross-bowmen, and let these two dogs keep their station\r\nunder the walls of the castle?\xe2\x80\x94Heave over the coping stones from the\r\nbattlements, an better may not be\xe2\x80\x94Get pick-axe and levers, and down\r\nwith that huge pinnacle!\xe2\x80\x9d pointing to a heavy piece of stone\r\ncarved-work that projected from the parapet.\r\n\r\nAt this moment the besiegers caught sight of the red flag upon the\r\nangle of the tower which Ulrica had described to Cedric. The stout\r\nyeoman Locksley was the first who was aware of it, as he was hasting to\r\nthe outwork, impatient to see the progress of the assault.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaint George!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cMerry Saint George for England!\xe2\x80\x94To the\r\ncharge, bold yeomen!\xe2\x80\x94why leave ye the good knight and noble Cedric to\r\nstorm the pass alone?\xe2\x80\x94make in, mad priest, show thou canst fight for\r\nthy rosary,\xe2\x80\x94make in, brave yeomen!\xe2\x80\x94the castle is ours, we have friends\r\nwithin\xe2\x80\x94See yonder flag, it is the appointed signal\xe2\x80\x94Torquilstone is\r\nours!\xe2\x80\x94Think of honour, think of spoil\xe2\x80\x94One effort, and the place is\r\nours!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith that he bent his good bow, and sent a shaft right through the\r\nbreast of one of the men-at-arms, who, under De Bracy\xe2\x80\x99s direction, was\r\nloosening a fragment from one of the battlements to precipitate on the\r\nheads of Cedric and the Black Knight. A second soldier caught from the\r\nhands of the dying man the iron crow, with which he heaved at and had\r\nloosened the stone pinnacle, when, receiving an arrow through his\r\nhead-piece, he dropped from the battlements into the moat a dead man.\r\nThe men-at-arms were daunted, for no armour seemed proof against the\r\nshot of this tremendous archer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you give ground, base knaves!\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Mount joye Saint\r\nDennis!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Give me the lever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd, snatching it up, he again assailed the loosened pinnacle, which\r\nwas of weight enough, if thrown down, not only to have destroyed the\r\nremnant of the drawbridge, which sheltered the two foremost assailants,\r\nbut also to have sunk the rude float of planks over which they had\r\ncrossed. All saw the danger, and the boldest, even the stout Friar\r\nhimself, avoided setting foot on the raft. Thrice did Locksley bend his\r\nshaft against De Bracy, and thrice did his arrow bound back from the\r\nknight\xe2\x80\x99s armour of proof.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCurse on thy Spanish steel-coat!\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9chad English smith\r\nforged it, these arrows had gone through, an as if it had been silk or\r\nsendal.\xe2\x80\x9d He then began to call out, \xe2\x80\x9cComrades! friends! noble Cedric!\r\nbear back, and let the ruin fall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis warning voice was unheard, for the din which the knight himself\r\noccasioned by his strokes upon the postern would have drowned twenty\r\nwar-trumpets. The faithful Gurth indeed sprung forward on the planked\r\nbridge, to warn Cedric of his impending fate, or to share it with him.\r\nBut his warning would have come too late; the massive pinnacle already\r\ntottered, and De Bracy, who still heaved at his task, would have\r\naccomplished it, had not the voice of the Templar sounded close in his\r\nears:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll is lost, De Bracy, the castle burns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art mad to say so!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is all in a light flame on the western side. I have striven in vain\r\nto extinguish it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith the stern coolness which formed the basis of his character, Brian\r\nde Bois-Guilbert communicated this hideous intelligence, which was not\r\nso calmly received by his astonished comrade.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaints of Paradise!\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is to be done? I vow to\r\nSaint Nicholas of Limoges a candlestick of pure gold\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpare thy vow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cand mark me. Lead thy men down, as\r\nif to a sally; throw the postern-gate open\xe2\x80\x94There are but two men who\r\noccupy the float, fling them into the moat, and push across for the\r\nbarbican. I will charge from the main gate, and attack the barbican on\r\nthe outside; and if we can regain that post, be assured we shall defend\r\nourselves until we are relieved, or at least till they grant us fair\r\nquarter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well thought upon,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cI will play my part\xe2\x80\x94Templar,\r\nthou wilt not fail me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHand and glove, I will not!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert. \xe2\x80\x9cBut haste thee, in\r\nthe name of God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDe Bracy hastily drew his men together, and rushed down to the\r\npostern-gate, which he caused instantly to be thrown open. But scarce\r\nwas this done ere the portentous strength of the Black Knight forced\r\nhis way inward in despite of De Bracy and his followers. Two of the\r\nforemost instantly fell, and the rest gave way notwithstanding all\r\ntheir leader\xe2\x80\x99s efforts to stop them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDogs!\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cwill ye let TWO men win our only pass for\r\nsafety?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d said a veteran man-at-arms, bearing back from the\r\nblows of their sable antagonist.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if he be the devil,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cwould you fly from him\r\ninto the mouth of hell?\xe2\x80\x94the castle burns behind us, villains!\xe2\x80\x94let\r\ndespair give you courage, or let me forward! I will cope with this\r\nchampion myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd well and chivalrous did De Bracy that day maintain the fame he had\r\nacquired in the civil wars of that dreadful period. The vaulted passage\r\nto which the postern gave entrance, and in which these two redoubted\r\nchampions were now fighting hand to hand, rung with the furious blows\r\nwhich they dealt each other, De Bracy with his sword, the Black Knight\r\nwith his ponderous axe. At length the Norman received a blow, which,\r\nthough its force was partly parried by his shield, for otherwise never\r\nmore would De Bracy have again moved limb, descended yet with such\r\nviolence on his crest, that he measured his length on the paved floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYield thee, De Bracy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Champion, stooping over him, and\r\nholding against the bars of his helmet the fatal poniard with which the\r\nknights dispatched their enemies, (and which was called the dagger of\r\nmercy,)\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyield thee, Maurice de Bracy, rescue or no rescue, or thou art\r\nbut a dead man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not yield,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy faintly, \xe2\x80\x9cto an unknown conqueror.\r\nTell me thy name, or work thy pleasure on me\xe2\x80\x94it shall never be said\r\nthat Maurice de Bracy was prisoner to a nameless churl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Black Knight whispered something into the ear of the vanquished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI yield me to be true prisoner, rescue or no rescue,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\r\nNorman, exchanging his tone of stern and determined obstinacy for one\r\nof deep though sullen submission.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to the barbican,\xe2\x80\x9d said the victor, in a tone of authority, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nthere wait my further orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet first, let me say,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat it imports thee to know.\r\nWilfred of Ivanhoe is wounded and a prisoner, and will perish in the\r\nburning castle without present help.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWilfred of Ivanhoe!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Black Knight\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cprisoner, and\r\nperish!\xe2\x80\x94The life of every man in the castle shall answer it if a hair\r\nof his head be singed\xe2\x80\x94Show me his chamber!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAscend yonder winding stair,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cit leads to his\r\napartment\xe2\x80\x94Wilt thou not accept my guidance?\xe2\x80\x9d he added, in a submissive\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. To the barbican, and there wait my orders. I trust thee not, De\r\nBracy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDuring this combat and the brief conversation which ensued, Cedric, at\r\nthe head of a body of men, among whom the Friar was conspicuous, had\r\npushed across the bridge as soon as they saw the postern open, and\r\ndrove back the dispirited and despairing followers of De Bracy, of whom\r\nsome asked quarter, some offered vain resistance, and the greater part\r\nfled towards the court-yard. De Bracy himself arose from the ground,\r\nand cast a sorrowful glance after his conqueror. \xe2\x80\x9cHe trusts me not!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nrepeated; \xe2\x80\x9cbut have I deserved his trust?\xe2\x80\x9d He then lifted his sword\r\nfrom the floor, took off his helmet in token of submission, and, going\r\nto the barbican, gave up his sword to Locksley, whom he met by the way.\r\n\r\nAs the fire augmented, symptoms of it became soon apparent in the\r\nchamber, where Ivanhoe was watched and tended by the Jewess Rebecca. He\r\nhad been awakened from his brief slumber by the noise of the battle;\r\nand his attendant, who had, at his anxious desire, again placed herself\r\nat the window to watch and report to him the fate of the attack, was\r\nfor some time prevented from observing either, by the increase of the\r\nsmouldering and stifling vapour. At length the volumes of smoke which\r\nrolled into the apartment\xe2\x80\x94the cries for water, which were heard even\r\nabove the din of the battle made them sensible of the progress of this\r\nnew danger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe castle burns,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cit burns!\xe2\x80\x94What can we do to save\r\nourselves?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFly, Rebecca, and save thine own life,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cfor no human\r\naid can avail me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not fly,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cwe will be saved or perish\r\ntogether\xe2\x80\x94And yet, great God!\xe2\x80\x94my father, my father\xe2\x80\x94what will be his\r\nfate!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment the door of the apartment flew open, and the Templar\r\npresented himself,\xe2\x80\x94a ghastly figure, for his gilded armour was broken\r\nand bloody, and the plume was partly shorn away, partly burnt from his\r\ncasque. \xe2\x80\x9cI have found thee,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt prove I\r\nwill keep my word to share weal and woe with thee\xe2\x80\x94There is but one path\r\nto safety, I have cut my way through fifty dangers to point it to\r\nthee\xe2\x80\x94up, and instantly follow me!\xe2\x80\x9d 38\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlone,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cI will not follow thee. If thou wert born\r\nof woman\xe2\x80\x94if thou hast but a touch of human charity in thee\xe2\x80\x94if thy heart\r\nbe not hard as thy breastplate\xe2\x80\x94save my aged father\xe2\x80\x94save this wounded\r\nknight!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar, with his characteristic calmness, \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nknight, Rebecca, must encounter his fate, whether it meet him in the\r\nshape of sword or flame\xe2\x80\x94and who recks how or where a Jew meets with\r\nhis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSavage warrior,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9crather will I perish in the flames\r\nthan accept safety from thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou shalt not choose, Rebecca\xe2\x80\x94once didst thou foil me, but never\r\nmortal did so twice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he seized on the terrified maiden, who filled the air with\r\nher shrieks, and bore her out of the room in his arms in spite of her\r\ncries, and without regarding the menaces and defiance which Ivanhoe\r\nthundered against him. \xe2\x80\x9cHound of the Temple\xe2\x80\x94stain to thine Order\xe2\x80\x94set\r\nfree the damsel! Traitor of Bois-Guilbert, it is Ivanhoe commands\r\nthee!\xe2\x80\x94Villain, I will have thy heart\xe2\x80\x99s blood!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had not found thee, Wilfred,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, who at that\r\ninstant entered the apartment, \xe2\x80\x9cbut for thy shouts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf thou be\xe2\x80\x99st true knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wilfred, \xe2\x80\x9cthink not of me\xe2\x80\x94pursue yon\r\nravisher\xe2\x80\x94save the Lady Rowena\xe2\x80\x94look to the noble Cedric!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn their turn,\xe2\x80\x9d answered he of the Fetterlock, \xe2\x80\x9cbut thine is first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd seizing upon Ivanhoe, he bore him off with as much ease as the\r\nTemplar had carried off Rebecca, rushed with him to the postern, and\r\nhaving there delivered his burden to the care of two yeomen, he again\r\nentered the castle to assist in the rescue of the other prisoners.\r\n\r\nOne turret was now in bright flames, which flashed out furiously from\r\nwindow and shot-hole. But in other parts, the great thickness of the\r\nwalls and the vaulted roofs of the apartments, resisted the progress of\r\nthe flames, and there the rage of man still triumphed, as the scarce\r\nmore dreadful element held mastery elsewhere; for the besiegers pursued\r\nthe defenders of the castle from chamber to chamber, and satiated in\r\ntheir blood the vengeance which had long animated them against the\r\nsoldiers of the tyrant Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf. Most of the garrison resisted to\r\nthe uttermost\xe2\x80\x94few of them asked quarter\xe2\x80\x94none received it. The air was\r\nfilled with groans and clashing of arms\xe2\x80\x94the floors were slippery with\r\nthe blood of despairing and expiring wretches.\r\n\r\nThrough this scene of confusion, Cedric rushed in quest of Rowena,\r\nwhile the faithful Gurth, following him closely through the \xe2\x80\x9cmelee\xe2\x80\x9d,\r\nneglected his own safety while he strove to avert the blows that were\r\naimed at his master. The noble Saxon was so fortunate as to reach his\r\nward\xe2\x80\x99s apartment just as she had abandoned all hope of safety, and,\r\nwith a crucifix clasped in agony to her bosom, sat in expectation of\r\ninstant death. He committed her to the charge of Gurth, to be conducted\r\nin safety to the barbican, the road to which was now cleared of the\r\nenemy, and not yet interrupted by the flames. This accomplished, the\r\nloyal Cedric hastened in quest of his friend Athelstane, determined, at\r\nevery risk to himself, to save that last scion of Saxon royalty. But\r\nere Cedric penetrated as far as the old hall in which he had himself\r\nbeen a prisoner, the inventive genius of Wamba had procured liberation\r\nfor himself and his companion in adversity.\r\n\r\nWhen the noise of the conflict announced that it was at the hottest,\r\nthe Jester began to shout, with the utmost power of his lungs, \xe2\x80\x9cSaint\r\nGeorge and the dragon!\xe2\x80\x94Bonny Saint George for merry England!\xe2\x80\x94The castle\r\nis won!\xe2\x80\x9d And these sounds he rendered yet more fearful, by banging\r\nagainst each other two or three pieces of rusty armour which lay\r\nscattered around the hall.\r\n\r\nA guard, which had been stationed in the outer, or anteroom, and whose\r\nspirits were already in a state of alarm, took fright at Wamba\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nclamour, and, leaving the door open behind them, ran to tell the\r\nTemplar that foemen had entered the old hall. Meantime the prisoners\r\nfound no difficulty in making their escape into the anteroom, and from\r\nthence into the court of the castle, which was now the last scene of\r\ncontest. Here sat the fierce Templar, mounted on horseback, surrounded\r\nby several of the garrison both on horse and foot, who had united their\r\nstrength to that of this renowned leader, in order to secure the last\r\nchance of safety and retreat which remained to them. The drawbridge had\r\nbeen lowered by his orders, but the passage was beset; for the archers,\r\nwho had hitherto only annoyed the castle on that side by their\r\nmissiles, no sooner saw the flames breaking out, and the bridge\r\nlowered, than they thronged to the entrance, as well to prevent the\r\nescape of the garrison, as to secure their own share of booty ere the\r\ncastle should be burnt down. On the other hand, a party of the\r\nbesiegers who had entered by the postern were now issuing out into the\r\ncourt-yard, and attacking with fury the remnant of the defenders who\r\nwere thus assaulted on both sides at once.\r\n\r\nAnimated, however, by despair, and supported by the example of their\r\nindomitable leader, the remaining soldiers of the castle fought with\r\nthe utmost valour; and, being well-armed, succeeded more than once in\r\ndriving back the assailants, though much inferior in numbers. Rebecca,\r\nplaced on horseback before one of the Templar\xe2\x80\x99s Saracen slaves, was in\r\nthe midst of the little party; and Bois-Guilbert, notwithstanding the\r\nconfusion of the bloody fray, showed every attention to her safety.\r\nRepeatedly he was by her side, and, neglecting his own defence, held\r\nbefore her the fence of his triangular steel-plated shield; and anon\r\nstarting from his position by her, he cried his war-cry, dashed\r\nforward, struck to earth the most forward of the assailants, and was on\r\nthe same instant once more at her bridle rein.\r\n\r\nAthelstane, who, as the reader knows, was slothful, but not cowardly,\r\nbeheld the female form whom the Templar protected thus sedulously, and\r\ndoubted not that it was Rowena whom the knight was carrying off, in\r\ndespite of all resistance which could be offered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the soul of Saint Edward,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI will rescue her from yonder\r\nover-proud knight, and he shall die by my hand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink what you do!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9chasty hand catches frog for fish\xe2\x80\x94by\r\nmy bauble, yonder is none of my Lady Rowena\xe2\x80\x94see but her long dark\r\nlocks!\xe2\x80\x94Nay, an ye will not know black from white, ye may be leader, but\r\nI will be no follower\xe2\x80\x94no bones of mine shall be broken unless I know\r\nfor whom.\xe2\x80\x94And you without armour too!\xe2\x80\x94Bethink you, silk bonnet never\r\nkept out steel blade.\xe2\x80\x94Nay, then, if wilful will to water, wilful must\r\ndrench.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Deus vobiscum\xe2\x80\x99, most doughty Athelstane!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94he concluded,\r\nloosening the hold which he had hitherto kept upon the Saxon\xe2\x80\x99s tunic.\r\n\r\nTo snatch a mace from the pavement, on which it lay beside one whose\r\ndying grasp had just relinquished it\xe2\x80\x94to rush on the Templar\xe2\x80\x99s band, and\r\nto strike in quick succession to the right and left, levelling a\r\nwarrior at each blow, was, for Athelstane\xe2\x80\x99s great strength, now\r\nanimated with unusual fury, but the work of a single moment; he was\r\nsoon within two yards of Bois-Guilbert, whom he defied in his loudest\r\ntone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTurn, false-hearted Templar! let go her whom thou art unworthy to\r\ntouch\xe2\x80\x94turn, limb of a hand of murdering and hypocritical robbers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDog!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, grinding his teeth, \xe2\x80\x9cI will teach thee to\r\nblaspheme the holy Order of the Temple of Zion;\xe2\x80\x9d and with these words,\r\nhalf-wheeling his steed, he made a demi-courbette towards the Saxon,\r\nand rising in the stirrups, so as to take full advantage of the descent\r\nof the horse, he discharged a fearful blow upon the head of Athelstane.\r\n\r\nWell said Wamba, that silken bonnet keeps out no steel blade. So\r\ntrenchant was the Templar\xe2\x80\x99s weapon, that it shore asunder, as it had\r\nbeen a willow twig, the tough and plaited handle of the mace, which the\r\nill-fated Saxon reared to parry the blow, and, descending on his head,\r\nlevelled him with the earth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Ha! Beau-seant!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Bois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthus be it to the\r\nmaligners of the Temple-knights!\xe2\x80\x9d Taking advantage of the dismay which\r\nwas spread by the fall of Athelstane, and calling aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cThose who\r\nwould save themselves, follow me!\xe2\x80\x9d he pushed across the drawbridge,\r\ndispersing the archers who would have intercepted them. He was followed\r\nby his Saracens, and some five or six men-at-arms, who had mounted\r\ntheir horses. The Templar\xe2\x80\x99s retreat was rendered perilous by the\r\nnumbers of arrows shot off at him and his party; but this did not\r\nprevent him from galloping round to the barbican, of which, according\r\nto his previous plan, he supposed it possible De Bracy might have been\r\nin possession.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDe Bracy! De Bracy!\xe2\x80\x9d he shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cart thou there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am here,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I am a prisoner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I rescue thee?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bois-Guilbert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cI have rendered me, rescue or no rescue. I\r\nwill be true prisoner. Save thyself\xe2\x80\x94there are hawks abroad\xe2\x80\x94put the seas\r\nbetwixt you and England\xe2\x80\x94I dare not say more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9can thou wilt tarry there, remember I\r\nhave redeemed word and glove. Be the hawks where they will, methinks\r\nthe walls of the Preceptory of Templestowe will be cover sufficient,\r\nand thither will I, like heron to her haunt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving thus spoken, he galloped off with his followers.\r\n\r\nThose of the castle who had not gotten to horse, still continued to\r\nfight desperately with the besiegers, after the departure of the\r\nTemplar, but rather in despair of quarter than that they entertained\r\nany hope of escape. The fire was spreading rapidly through all parts of\r\nthe castle, when Ulrica, who had first kindled it, appeared on a\r\nturret, in the guise of one of the ancient furies, yelling forth a\r\nwar-song, such as was of yore raised on the field of battle by the\r\nscalds of the yet heathen Saxons. Her long dishevelled grey hair flew\r\nback from her uncovered head; the inebriating delight of gratified\r\nvengeance contended in her eyes with the fire of insanity; and she\r\nbrandished the distaff which she held in her hand, as if she had been\r\none of the Fatal Sisters, who spin and abridge the thread of human\r\nlife. Tradition has preserved some wild strophes of the barbarous hymn\r\nwhich she chanted wildly amid that scene of fire and of slaughter:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n1.\r\nWhet the bright steel,\r\nSons of the White Dragon!\r\nKindle the torch,\r\nDaughter of Hengist!\r\nThe steel glimmers not for the carving of the banquet,\r\nIt is hard, broad, and sharply pointed;\r\nThe torch goeth not to the bridal chamber,\r\nIt steams and glitters blue with sulphur.\r\nWhet the steel, the raven croaks!\r\nLight the torch, Zernebock is yelling!\r\nWhet the steel, sons of the Dragon!\r\nKindle the torch, daughter of Hengist!\r\n\r\n2.\r\nThe black cloud is low over the thane\xe2\x80\x99s castle\r\nThe eagle screams\xe2\x80\x94he rides on its bosom.\r\nScream not, grey rider of the sable cloud,\r\nThy banquet is prepared!\r\nThe maidens of Valhalla look forth,\r\nThe race of Hengist will send them guests.\r\nShake your black tresses, maidens of Valhalla!\r\nAnd strike your loud timbrels for joy!\r\nMany a haughty step bends to your halls,\r\nMany a helmed head.\r\n\r\n3.\r\nDark sits the evening upon the thanes castle,\r\nThe black clouds gather round;\r\nSoon shall they be red as the blood of the valiant!\r\nThe destroyer of forests shall shake his red crest against\r\nthem.\r\nHe, the bright consumer of palaces,\r\nBroad waves he his blazing banner,\r\nRed, wide and dusky,\r\nOver the strife of the valiant:\r\nHis joy is in the clashing swords and broken bucklers;\r\nHe loves to lick the hissing blood as it bursts warm from the\r\nwound!\r\n\r\n4.\r\nAll must perish!\r\nThe sword cleaveth the helmet;\r\nThe strong armour is pierced by the lance;\r\nFire devoureth the dwelling of princes,\r\nEngines break down the fences of the battle.\r\nAll must perish!\r\nThe race of Hengist is gone\xe2\x80\x94\r\nThe name of Horsa is no more!\r\nShrink not then from your doom, sons of the sword!\r\nLet your blades drink blood like wine;\r\nFeast ye in the banquet of slaughter,\r\nBy the light of the blazing halls!\r\nStrong be your swords while your blood is warm,\r\nAnd spare neither for pity nor fear,\r\nFor vengeance hath but an hour;\r\nStrong hate itself shall expire\r\nI also must perish! 39\r\n\r\n\r\nThe towering flames had now surmounted every obstruction, and rose to\r\nthe evening skies one huge and burning beacon, seen far and wide\r\nthrough the adjacent country. Tower after tower crashed down, with\r\nblazing roof and rafter; and the combatants were driven from the\r\ncourt-yard. The vanquished, of whom very few remained, scattered and\r\nescaped into the neighbouring wood. The victors, assembling in large\r\nbands, gazed with wonder, not unmixed with fear, upon the flames, in\r\nwhich their own ranks and arms glanced dusky red. The maniac figure of\r\nthe Saxon Ulrica was for a long time visible on the lofty stand she had\r\nchosen, tossing her arms abroad with wild exultation, as if she reined\r\nempress of the conflagration which she had raised. At length, with a\r\nterrific crash, the whole turret gave way, and she perished in the\r\nflames which had consumed her tyrant. An awful pause of horror silenced\r\neach murmur of the armed spectators, who, for the space of several\r\nminutes, stirred not a finger, save to sign the cross. The voice of\r\nLocksley was then heard, \xe2\x80\x9cShout, yeomen!\xe2\x80\x94the den of tyrants is no more!\r\nLet each bring his spoil to our chosen place of rendezvous at the\r\nTrysting-tree in the Harthill-walk; for there at break of day will we\r\nmake just partition among our own bands, together with our worthy\r\nallies in this great deed of vengeance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXII.\r\n\r\n\r\nTrust me each state must have its policies:\r\nKingdoms have edicts, cities have their charters;\r\nEven the wild outlaw, in his forest-walk,\r\nKeeps yet some touch of civil discipline;\r\nFor not since Adam wore his verdant apron,\r\nHath man with man in social union dwelt,\r\nBut laws were made to draw that union closer.\r\n\r\n\r\nOLD PLAY\r\n\r\n\r\nThe daylight had dawned upon the glades of the oak forest. The green\r\nboughs glittered with all their pearls of dew. The hind led her fawn\r\nfrom the covert of high fern to the more open walks of the greenwood,\r\nand no huntsman was there to watch or intercept the stately hart, as he\r\npaced at the head of the antler\xe2\x80\x99d herd.\r\n\r\nThe outlaws were all assembled around the Trysting-tree in the\r\nHarthill-walk, where they had spent the night in refreshing themselves\r\nafter the fatigues of the siege, some with wine, some with slumber,\r\nmany with hearing and recounting the events of the day, and computing\r\nthe heaps of plunder which their success had placed at the disposal of\r\ntheir Chief.\r\n\r\nThe spoils were indeed very large; for, notwithstanding that much was\r\nconsumed, a great deal of plate, rich armour, and splendid clothing,\r\nhad been secured by the exertions of the dauntless outlaws, who could\r\nbe appalled by no danger when such rewards were in view. Yet so strict\r\nwere the laws of their society, that no one ventured to appropriate any\r\npart of the booty, which was brought into one common mass, to be at the\r\ndisposal of their leader.\r\n\r\nThe place of rendezvous was an aged oak; not however the same to which\r\nLocksley had conducted Gurth and Wamba in the earlier part of the\r\nstory, but one which was the centre of a silvan amphitheatre, within\r\nhalf a mile of the demolished castle of Torquilstone. Here Locksley\r\nassumed his seat\xe2\x80\x94a throne of turf erected under the twisted branches of\r\nthe huge oak, and the silvan followers were gathered around him. He\r\nassigned to the Black Knight a seat at his right hand, and to Cedric a\r\nplace upon his left.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon my freedom, noble sirs,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cbut in these glades I am\r\nmonarch\xe2\x80\x94they are my kingdom; and these my wild subjects would reck but\r\nlittle of my power, were I, within my own dominions, to yield place to\r\nmortal man.\xe2\x80\x94Now, sirs, who hath seen our chaplain? where is our curtal\r\nFriar? A mass amongst Christian men best begins a busy morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94No one\r\nhad seen the Clerk of Copmanhurst. \xe2\x80\x9cOver gods forbode!\xe2\x80\x9d said the outlaw\r\nchief, \xe2\x80\x9cI trust the jolly priest hath but abidden by the wine-pot a\r\nthought too late. Who saw him since the castle was ta\xe2\x80\x99en?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI,\xe2\x80\x9d quoth the Miller, \xe2\x80\x9cmarked him busy about the door of a cellar,\r\nswearing by each saint in the calendar he would taste the smack of\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s Gascoigne wine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, the saints, as many as there be of them,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cforefend, lest he has drunk too deep of the wine-butts, and perished\r\nby the fall of the castle!\xe2\x80\x94Away, Miller!\xe2\x80\x94take with you enow of men,\r\nseek the place where you last saw him\xe2\x80\x94throw water from the moat on the\r\nscorching ruins\xe2\x80\x94I will have them removed stone by stone ere I lose my\r\ncurtal Friar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe numbers who hastened to execute this duty, considering that an\r\ninteresting division of spoil was about to take place, showed how much\r\nthe troop had at heart the safety of their spiritual father.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMeanwhile, let us proceed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cfor when this bold deed\r\nshall be sounded abroad, the bands of De Bracy, of Malvoisin, and other\r\nallies of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, will be in motion against us, and it were well\r\nfor our safety that we retreat from the vicinity.\xe2\x80\x94Noble Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, turning to the Saxon, \xe2\x80\x9cthat spoil is divided into two portions;\r\ndo thou make choice of that which best suits thee, to recompense thy\r\npeople who were partakers with us in this adventure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood yeoman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cmy heart is oppressed with sadness. The\r\nnoble Athelstane of Coningsburgh is no more\xe2\x80\x94the last sprout of the\r\nsainted Confessor! Hopes have perished with him which can never\r\nreturn!\xe2\x80\x94A sparkle hath been quenched by his blood, which no human\r\nbreath can again rekindle! My people, save the few who are now with me,\r\ndo but tarry my presence to transport his honoured remains to their\r\nlast mansion. The Lady Rowena is desirous to return to Rotherwood, and\r\nmust be escorted by a sufficient force. I should, therefore, ere now,\r\nhave left this place; and I waited\xe2\x80\x94not to share the booty, for, so help\r\nme God and Saint Withold! as neither I nor any of mine will touch the\r\nvalue of a liard,\xe2\x80\x94I waited but to render my thanks to thee and to thy\r\nbold yeomen, for the life and honour ye have saved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but,\xe2\x80\x9d said the chief Outlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cwe did but half the work at\r\nmost\xe2\x80\x94take of the spoil what may reward your own neighbours and\r\nfollowers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am rich enough to reward them from mine own wealth,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nCedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd some,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9chave been wise enough to reward themselves;\r\nthey do not march off empty-handed altogether. We do not all wear\r\nmotley.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are welcome,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cour laws bind none but ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, thou, my poor knave,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, turning about and embracing\r\nhis Jester, \xe2\x80\x9chow shall I reward thee, who feared not to give thy body\r\nto chains and death instead of mine!\xe2\x80\x94All forsook me, when the poor fool\r\nwas faithful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA tear stood in the eye of the rough Thane as he spoke\xe2\x80\x94a mark of\r\nfeeling which even the death of Athelstane had not extracted; but there\r\nwas something in the half-instinctive attachment of his clown, that\r\nwaked his nature more keenly than even grief itself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, extricating himself from master\xe2\x80\x99s caress, \xe2\x80\x9cif\r\nyou pay my service with the water of your eye, the Jester must weep for\r\ncompany, and then what becomes of his vocation?\xe2\x80\x94But, uncle, if you\r\nwould indeed pleasure me, I pray you to pardon my playfellow Gurth, who\r\nstole a week from your service to bestow it on your son.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon him!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cI will both pardon and reward\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x94Kneel down, Gurth.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94The swineherd was in an instant at his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s feet\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cTHEOW and ESNE 40 art thou no longer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric\r\ntouching him with a wand; \xe2\x80\x9cFOLKFREE and SACLESS 41 art thou in town and\r\nfrom town, in the forest as in the field. A hide of land I give to thee\r\nin my steads of Walbrugham, from me and mine to thee and thine aye and\r\nfor ever; and God\xe2\x80\x99s malison on his head who this gainsays!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNo longer a serf, but a freeman and a landholder, Gurth sprung upon his\r\nfeet, and twice bounded aloft to almost his own height from the ground.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA smith and a file,\xe2\x80\x9d he cried, \xe2\x80\x9cto do away the collar from the neck of\r\na freeman!\xe2\x80\x94Noble master! doubled is my strength by your gift, and\r\ndoubly will I fight for you!\xe2\x80\x94There is a free spirit in my breast\xe2\x80\x94I am a\r\nman changed to myself and all around.\xe2\x80\x94Ha, Fangs!\xe2\x80\x9d he continued,\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nthat faithful cur, seeing his master thus transported, began to jump\r\nupon him, to express his sympathy,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cknowest thou thy master still?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cFangs and I still know thee, Gurth, though we must\r\nneeds abide by the collar; it is only thou art likely to forget both us\r\nand thyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall forget myself indeed ere I forget thee, true comrade,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nGurth; \xe2\x80\x9cand were freedom fit for thee, Wamba, the master would not let\r\nthee want it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cnever think I envy thee, brother Gurth; the serf\r\nsits by the hall-fire when the freeman must forth to the field of\r\nbattle\xe2\x80\x94And what saith Oldhelm of Malmsbury\xe2\x80\x94Better a fool at a feast\r\nthan a wise man at a fray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tramp of horses was now heard, and the Lady Rowena appeared,\r\nsurrounded by several riders, and a much stronger party of footmen, who\r\njoyfully shook their pikes and clashed their brown-bills for joy of her\r\nfreedom. She herself, richly attired, and mounted on a dark chestnut\r\npalfrey, had recovered all the dignity of her manner, and only an\r\nunwonted degree of paleness showed the sufferings she had undergone.\r\nHer lovely brow, though sorrowful, bore on it a cast of reviving hope\r\nfor the future, as well as of grateful thankfulness for the past\r\ndeliverance\xe2\x80\x94She knew that Ivanhoe was safe, and she knew that\r\nAthelstane was dead. The former assurance filled her with the most\r\nsincere delight; and if she did not absolutely rejoice at the latter,\r\nshe might be pardoned for feeling the full advantage of being freed\r\nfrom further persecution on the only subject in which she had ever been\r\ncontradicted by her guardian Cedric.\r\n\r\nAs Rowena bent her steed towards Locksley\xe2\x80\x99s seat, that bold yeoman,\r\nwith all his followers, rose to receive her, as if by a general\r\ninstinct of courtesy. The blood rose to her cheeks, as, courteously\r\nwaving her hand, and bending so low that her beautiful and loose\r\ntresses were for an instant mixed with the flowing mane of her palfrey,\r\nshe expressed in few but apt words her obligations and her gratitude to\r\nLocksley and her other deliverers.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you, brave men,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nconcluded, \xe2\x80\x9cGod and Our Lady bless you and requite you for gallantly\r\nperilling yourselves in the cause of the oppressed!\xe2\x80\x94If any of you\r\nshould hunger, remember Rowena has food\xe2\x80\x94if you should thirst, she has\r\nmany a butt of wine and brown ale\xe2\x80\x94and if the Normans drive ye from\r\nthese walks, Rowena has forests of her own, where her gallant\r\ndeliverers may range at full freedom, and never ranger ask whose arrow\r\nhath struck down the deer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, gentle lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cthanks from my company and\r\nmyself. But, to have saved you requites itself. We who walk the\r\ngreenwood do many a wild deed, and the Lady Rowena\xe2\x80\x99s deliverance may be\r\nreceived as an atonement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain bowing from her palfrey, Rowena turned to depart; but pausing a\r\nmoment, while Cedric, who was to attend her, was also taking his leave,\r\nshe found herself unexpectedly close by the prisoner De Bracy. He stood\r\nunder a tree in deep meditation, his arms crossed upon his breast, and\r\nRowena was in hopes she might pass him unobserved. He looked up,\r\nhowever, and, when aware of her presence, a deep flush of shame\r\nsuffused his handsome countenance. He stood a moment most irresolute;\r\nthen, stepping forward, took her palfrey by the rein, and bent his knee\r\nbefore her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill the Lady Rowena deign to cast an eye\xe2\x80\x94on a captive knight\xe2\x80\x94on a\r\ndishonoured soldier?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9cin enterprises such as yours, the real\r\ndishonour lies not in failure, but in success.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConquest, lady, should soften the heart,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9clet me\r\nbut know that the Lady Rowena forgives the violence occasioned by an\r\nill-fated passion, and she shall soon learn that De Bracy knows how to\r\nserve her in nobler ways.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI forgive you, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9cas a Christian.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat means,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cthat she does not forgive him at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I can never forgive the misery and desolation your madness has\r\noccasioned,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Rowena.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnloose your hold on the lady\xe2\x80\x99s rein,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, coming up. \xe2\x80\x9cBy the\r\nbright sun above us, but it were shame, I would pin thee to the earth\r\nwith my javelin\xe2\x80\x94but be well assured, thou shalt smart, Maurice de\r\nBracy, for thy share in this foul deed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe threatens safely who threatens a prisoner,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nwhen had a Saxon any touch of courtesy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen retiring two steps backward, he permitted the lady to move on.\r\n\r\nCedric, ere they departed, expressed his peculiar gratitude to the\r\nBlack Champion, and earnestly entreated him to accompany him to\r\nRotherwood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat ye errant knights desire to carry your\r\nfortunes on the point of your lance, and reck not of land or goods; but\r\nwar is a changeful mistress, and a home is sometimes desirable even to\r\nthe champion whose trade is wandering. Thou hast earned one in the\r\nhalls of Rotherwood, noble knight. Cedric has wealth enough to repair\r\nthe injuries of fortune, and all he has is his deliverer\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94Come,\r\ntherefore, to Rotherwood, not as a guest, but as a son or brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCedric has already made me rich,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9che has taught me\r\nthe value of Saxon virtue. To Rotherwood will I come, brave Saxon, and\r\nthat speedily; but, as now, pressing matters of moment detain me from\r\nyour halls. Peradventure when I come hither, I will ask such a boon as\r\nwill put even thy generosity to the test.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is granted ere spoken out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, striking his ready hand\r\ninto the gauntleted palm of the Black Knight,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit is granted already,\r\nwere it to affect half my fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGage not thy promise so lightly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight of the Fetterlock;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyet well I hope to gain the boon I shall ask. Meanwhile, adieu.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have but to say,\xe2\x80\x9d added the Saxon, \xe2\x80\x9cthat, during the funeral rites\r\nof the noble Athelstane, I shall be an inhabitant of the halls of his\r\ncastle of Coningsburgh\xe2\x80\x94They will be open to all who choose to partake\r\nof the funeral banqueting; and, I speak in name of the noble Edith,\r\nmother of the fallen prince, they will never be shut against him who\r\nlaboured so bravely, though unsuccessfully, to save Athelstane from\r\nNorman chains and Norman steel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, who had resumed his attendance on his master,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9crare feeding there will be\xe2\x80\x94pity that the noble Athelstane cannot\r\nbanquet at his own funeral.\xe2\x80\x94But he,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the Jester, lifting up\r\nhis eyes gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cis supping in Paradise, and doubtless does honour to\r\nthe cheer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace, and move on,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, his anger at this untimely jest\r\nbeing checked by the recollection of Wamba\xe2\x80\x99s recent services. Rowena\r\nwaved a graceful adieu to him of the Fetterlock\xe2\x80\x94the Saxon bade God\r\nspeed him, and on they moved through a wide glade of the forest.\r\n\r\nThey had scarce departed, ere a sudden procession moved from under the\r\ngreenwood branches, swept slowly round the silvan amphitheatre, and\r\ntook the same direction with Rowena and her followers. The priests of a\r\nneighbouring convent, in expectation of the ample donation, or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csoul-scat\xe2\x80\x9d, which Cedric had propined, attended upon the car in which\r\nthe body of Athelstane was laid, and sang hymns as it was sadly and\r\nslowly borne on the shoulders of his vassals to his castle of\r\nConingsburgh, to be there deposited in the grave of Hengist, from whom\r\nthe deceased derived his long descent. Many of his vassals had\r\nassembled at the news of his death, and followed the bier with all the\r\nexternal marks, at least, of dejection and sorrow. Again the outlaws\r\narose, and paid the same rude and spontaneous homage to death, which\r\nthey had so lately rendered to beauty\xe2\x80\x94the slow chant and mournful step\r\nof the priests brought back to their remembrance such of their comrades\r\nas had fallen in the yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s array. But such recollections dwell\r\nnot long with those who lead a life of danger and enterprise, and ere\r\nthe sound of the death-hymn had died on the wind, the outlaws were\r\nagain busied in the distribution of their spoil.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValiant knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley to the Black Champion, \xe2\x80\x9cwithout whose\r\ngood heart and mighty arm our enterprise must altogether have failed,\r\nwill it please you to take from that mass of spoil whatever may best\r\nserve to pleasure you, and to remind you of this my Trysting-tree?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI accept the offer,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cas frankly as it is given; and\r\nI ask permission to dispose of Sir Maurice de Bracy at my own\r\npleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is thine already,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9cand well for him! else the\r\ntyrant had graced the highest bough of this oak, with as many of his\r\nFree-Companions as we could gather, hanging thick as acorns around\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x94But he is thy prisoner, and he is safe, though he had slain my\r\nfather.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDe Bracy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthou art free\xe2\x80\x94depart. He whose prisoner\r\nthou art scorns to take mean revenge for what is past. But beware of\r\nthe future, lest a worse thing befall thee.\xe2\x80\x94Maurice de Bracy, I say\r\nBEWARE!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDe Bracy bowed low and in silence, and was about to withdraw, when the\r\nyeomen burst at once into a shout of execration and derision. The proud\r\nknight instantly stopped, turned back, folded his arms, drew up his\r\nform to its full height, and exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cPeace, ye yelping curs! who\r\nopen upon a cry which ye followed not when the stag was at bay\xe2\x80\x94De Bracy\r\nscorns your censure as he would disdain your applause. To your brakes\r\nand caves, ye outlawed thieves! and be silent when aught knightly or\r\nnoble is but spoken within a league of your fox-earths.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis ill-timed defiance might have procured for De Bracy a volley of\r\narrows, but for the hasty and imperative interference of the outlaw\r\nChief. Meanwhile the knight caught a horse by the rein, for several\r\nwhich had been taken in the stables of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf stood accoutred\r\naround, and were a valuable part of the booty. He threw himself upon\r\nthe saddle, and galloped off through the wood.\r\n\r\nWhen the bustle occasioned by this incident was somewhat composed, the\r\nchief Outlaw took from his neck the rich horn and baldric which he had\r\nrecently gained at the strife of archery near Ashby.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNoble knight.\xe2\x80\x9d he said to him of the Fetterlock, \xe2\x80\x9cif you disdain not\r\nto grace by your acceptance a bugle which an English yeoman has once\r\nworn, this I will pray you to keep as a memorial of your gallant\r\nbearing\xe2\x80\x94and if ye have aught to do, and, as happeneth oft to a gallant\r\nknight, ye chance to be hard bested in any forest between Trent and\r\nTees, wind three mots 42 upon the horn thus, \xe2\x80\x98Wa-sa-hoa!\xe2\x80\x99 and it may\r\nwell chance ye shall find helpers and rescue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then gave breath to the bugle, and winded once and again the call\r\nwhich he described, until the knight had caught the notes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGramercy for the gift, bold yeoman,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight; \xe2\x80\x9cand better help\r\nthan thine and thy rangers would I never seek, were it at my utmost\r\nneed.\xe2\x80\x9d And then in his turn he winded the call till all the greenwood\r\nrang.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell blown and clearly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman; \xe2\x80\x9cbeshrew me an thou knowest\r\nnot as much of woodcraft as of war!\xe2\x80\x94thou hast been a striker of deer in\r\nthy day, I warrant.\xe2\x80\x94Comrades, mark these three mots\xe2\x80\x94it is the call of\r\nthe Knight of the Fetterlock; and he who hears it, and hastens not to\r\nserve him at his need, I will have him scourged out of our band with\r\nhis own bowstring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLong live our leader!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the yeomen, \xe2\x80\x9cand long live the Black\r\nKnight of the Fetterlock!\xe2\x80\x94May he soon use our service, to prove how\r\nreadily it will be paid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLocksley now proceeded to the distribution of the spoil, which he\r\nperformed with the most laudable impartiality. A tenth part of the\r\nwhole was set apart for the church, and for pious uses; a portion was\r\nnext allotted to a sort of public treasury; a part was assigned to the\r\nwidows and children of those who had fallen, or to be expended in\r\nmasses for the souls of such as had left no surviving family. The rest\r\nwas divided amongst the outlaws, according to their rank and merit, and\r\nthe judgment of the Chief, on all such doubtful questions as occurred,\r\nwas delivered with great shrewdness, and received with absolute\r\nsubmission. The Black Knight was not a little surprised to find that\r\nmen, in a state so lawless, were nevertheless among themselves so\r\nregularly and equitably governed, and all that he observed added to his\r\nopinion of the justice and judgment of their leader.\r\n\r\nWhen each had taken his own proportion of the booty, and while the\r\ntreasurer, accompanied by four tall yeomen, was transporting that\r\nbelonging to the state to some place of concealment or of security, the\r\nportion devoted to the church still remained unappropriated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would,\xe2\x80\x9d said the leader, \xe2\x80\x9cwe could hear tidings of our joyous\r\nchaplain\xe2\x80\x94he was never wont to be absent when meat was to be blessed, or\r\nspoil to be parted; and it is his duty to take care of these the tithes\r\nof our successful enterprise. It may be the office has helped to cover\r\nsome of his canonical irregularities. Also, I have a holy brother of\r\nhis a prisoner at no great distance, and I would fain have the Friar to\r\nhelp me to deal with him in due sort\xe2\x80\x94I greatly misdoubt the safety of\r\nthe bluff priest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI were right sorry for that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight of the Fetterlock, \xe2\x80\x9cfor\r\nI stand indebted to him for the joyous hospitality of a merry night in\r\nhis cell. Let us to the ruins of the castle; it may be we shall there\r\nlearn some tidings of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile they thus spoke, a loud shout among the yeomen announced the\r\narrival of him for whom they feared, as they learned from the\r\nstentorian voice of the Friar himself, long before they saw his burly\r\nperson.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake room, my merry-men!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed; \xe2\x80\x9croom for your godly father\r\nand his prisoner\xe2\x80\x94Cry welcome once more.\xe2\x80\x94I come, noble leader, like an\r\neagle with my prey in my clutch.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94And making his way through the ring,\r\namidst the laughter of all around, he appeared in majestic triumph, his\r\nhuge partisan in one hand, and in the other a halter, one end of which\r\nwas fastened to the neck of the unfortunate Isaac of York, who, bent\r\ndown by sorrow and terror, was dragged on by the victorious priest, who\r\nshouted aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Allan-a-Dale, to chronicle me in a ballad, or\r\nif it were but a lay?\xe2\x80\x94By Saint Hermangild, the jingling crowder is ever\r\nout of the way where there is an apt theme for exalting valour!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCurtal Priest,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hast been at a wet mass this\r\nmorning, as early as it is. In the name of Saint Nicholas, whom hast\r\nthou got here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA captive to my sword and to my lance, noble Captain,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\nClerk of Copmanhurst; \xe2\x80\x9cto my bow and to my halberd, I should rather\r\nsay; and yet I have redeemed him by my divinity from a worse captivity.\r\nSpeak, Jew\xe2\x80\x94have I not ransomed thee from Sathanas?\xe2\x80\x94have I not taught\r\nthee thy \xe2\x80\x98credo\xe2\x80\x99, thy \xe2\x80\x98pater\xe2\x80\x99, and thine \xe2\x80\x98Ave Maria\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x94Did I not spend\r\nthe whole night in drinking to thee, and in expounding of mysteries?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the love of God!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated the poor Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cwill no one take me\r\nout of the keeping of this mad\xe2\x80\x94I mean this holy man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s this, Jew?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, with a menacing aspect; \xe2\x80\x9cdost thou\r\nrecant, Jew?\xe2\x80\x94Bethink thee, if thou dost relapse into thine infidelity,\r\nthough thou are not so tender as a suckling pig\xe2\x80\x94I would I had one to\r\nbreak my fast upon\xe2\x80\x94thou art not too tough to be roasted! Be\r\nconformable, Isaac, and repeat the words after me. \xe2\x80\x98Ave Maria\xe2\x80\x99!\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, we will have no profanation, mad Priest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9clet us\r\nrather hear where you found this prisoner of thine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Saint Dunstan,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, \xe2\x80\x9cI found him where I sought for\r\nbetter ware! I did step into the cellarage to see what might be rescued\r\nthere; for though a cup of burnt wine, with spice, be an evening\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndrought for an emperor, it were waste, methought, to let so much good\r\nliquor be mulled at once; and I had caught up one runlet of sack, and\r\nwas coming to call more aid among these lazy knaves, who are ever to\r\nseek when a good deed is to be done, when I was avised of a strong\r\ndoor\xe2\x80\x94Aha! thought I, here is the choicest juice of all in this secret\r\ncrypt; and the knave butler, being disturbed in his vocation, hath left\r\nthe key in the door\xe2\x80\x94In therefore I went, and found just nought besides\r\na commodity of rusted chains and this dog of a Jew, who presently\r\nrendered himself my prisoner, rescue or no rescue. I did but refresh\r\nmyself after the fatigue of the action, with the unbeliever, with one\r\nhumming cup of sack, and was proceeding to lead forth my captive, when,\r\ncrash after crash, as with wild thunder-dint and levin-fire, down\r\ntoppled the masonry of an outer tower, (marry beshrew their hands that\r\nbuilt it not the firmer!) and blocked up the passage. The roar of one\r\nfalling tower followed another\xe2\x80\x94I gave up thought of life; and deeming\r\nit a dishonour to one of my profession to pass out of this world in\r\ncompany with a Jew, I heaved up my halberd to beat his brains out; but\r\nI took pity on his grey hairs, and judged it better to lay down the\r\npartisan, and take up my spiritual weapon for his conversion. And\r\ntruly, by the blessing of Saint Dunstan, the seed has been sown in good\r\nsoil; only that, with speaking to him of mysteries through the whole\r\nnight, and being in a manner fasting, (for the few droughts of sack\r\nwhich I sharpened my wits with were not worth marking,) my head is\r\nwell-nigh dizzied, I trow.\xe2\x80\x94But I was clean exhausted.\xe2\x80\x94Gilbert and\r\nWibbald know in what state they found me\xe2\x80\x94quite and clean exhausted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can bear witness,\xe2\x80\x9d said Gilbert; \xe2\x80\x9cfor when we had cleared away the\r\nruin, and by Saint Dunstan\xe2\x80\x99s help lighted upon the dungeon stair, we\r\nfound the runlet of sack half empty, the Jew half dead, and the Friar\r\nmore than half\xe2\x80\x94exhausted, as he calls it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe be knaves! ye lie!\xe2\x80\x9d retorted the offended Friar; \xe2\x80\x9cit was you and\r\nyour gormandizing companions that drank up the sack, and called it your\r\nmorning draught\xe2\x80\x94I am a pagan, an I kept it not for the Captain\xe2\x80\x99s own\r\nthroat. But what recks it? The Jew is converted, and understands all I\r\nhave told him, very nearly, if not altogether, as well as myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJew,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cis this true? hast thou renounced thine\r\nunbelief?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I so find mercy in your eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cas I know not one\r\nword which the reverend prelate spake to me all this fearful night.\r\nAlas! I was so distraught with agony, and fear, and grief, that had our\r\nholy father Abraham come to preach to me, he had found but a deaf\r\nlistener.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou liest, Jew, and thou knowest thou dost.\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar; \xe2\x80\x9cI will\r\nremind thee of but one word of our conference\xe2\x80\x94thou didst promise to\r\ngive all thy substance to our holy Order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo help me the Promise, fair sirs,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, even more alarmed than\r\nbefore, \xe2\x80\x9cas no such sounds ever crossed my lips! Alas! I am an aged\r\nbeggar\xe2\x80\x99d man\xe2\x80\x94I fear me a childless\xe2\x80\x94have ruth on me, and let me go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, \xe2\x80\x9cif thou dost retract vows made in favour of\r\nholy Church, thou must do penance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAccordingly, he raised his halberd, and would have laid the staff of it\r\nlustily on the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s shoulders, had not the Black Knight stopped the\r\nblow, and thereby transferred the Holy Clerk\xe2\x80\x99s resentment to himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Saint Thomas of Kent,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9can I buckle to my gear, I will\r\nteach thee, sir lazy lover, to mell with thine own matters, maugre\r\nthine iron case there!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, be not wroth with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight; \xe2\x80\x9cthou knowest I am thy\r\nsworn friend and comrade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know no such thing,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Friar; \xe2\x80\x9cand defy thee for a\r\nmeddling coxcomb!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, who seemed to take a pleasure in provoking\r\nhis quondam host, \xe2\x80\x9chast thou forgotten how, that for my sake (for I say\r\nnothing of the temptation of the flagon and the pasty) thou didst break\r\nthy vow of fast and vigil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly, friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, clenching his huge fist, \xe2\x80\x9cI will\r\nbestow a buffet on thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI accept of no such presents,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight; \xe2\x80\x9cI am content to take\r\nthy cuff 421 as a loan, but I will repay thee with usury as deep as\r\never thy prisoner there exacted in his traffic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will prove that presently,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHola!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat art thou after, mad Friar? brawling\r\nbeneath our Trysting-tree?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo brawling,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cit is but a friendly interchange of\r\ncourtesy.\xe2\x80\x94Friar, strike an thou darest\xe2\x80\x94I will stand thy blow, if thou\r\nwilt stand mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast the advantage with that iron pot on thy head,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nchurchman; \xe2\x80\x9cbut have at thee\xe2\x80\x94Down thou goest, an thou wert Goliath of\r\nGath in his brazen helmet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Friar bared his brawny arm up to the elbow, and putting his full\r\nstrength to the blow, gave the Knight a buffet that might have felled\r\nan ox. But his adversary stood firm as a rock. A loud shout was uttered\r\nby all the yeomen around; for the Clerk\xe2\x80\x99s cuff was proverbial amongst\r\nthem, and there were few who, in jest or earnest, had not had the\r\noccasion to know its vigour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Priest,\xe2\x80\x9d said, the Knight, pulling off his gauntlet, \xe2\x80\x9cif I had\r\nvantage on my head, I will have none on my hand\xe2\x80\x94stand fast as a true\r\nman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Genam meam dedi vapulatori\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94I have given my cheek to the smiter,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the Priest; \xe2\x80\x9can thou canst stir me from the spot, fellow, I will\r\nfreely bestow on thee the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s ransom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo spoke the burly Priest, assuming, on his part, high defiance. But\r\nwho may resist his fate? The buffet of the Knight was given with such\r\nstrength and good-will, that the Friar rolled head over heels upon the\r\nplain, to the great amazement of all the spectators. But he arose\r\nneither angry nor crestfallen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthou shouldst have used thy strength\r\nwith more discretion. I had mumbled but a lame mass an thou hadst\r\nbroken my jaw, for the piper plays ill that wants the nether chops.\r\nNevertheless, there is my hand, in friendly witness, that I will\r\nexchange no more cuffs with thee, having been a loser by the barter.\r\nEnd now all unkindness. Let us put the Jew to ransom, since the leopard\r\nwill not change his spots, and a Jew he will continue to be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Priest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Clement, \xe2\x80\x9cis not half so confident of the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nconversion, since he received that buffet on the ear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to, knave, what pratest thou of conversions?\xe2\x80\x94what, is there no\r\nrespect?\xe2\x80\x94all masters and no men?\xe2\x80\x94I tell thee, fellow, I was somewhat\r\ntotty when I received the good knight\xe2\x80\x99s blow, or I had kept my ground\r\nunder it. But an thou gibest more of it, thou shalt learn I can give as\r\nwell as take.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace all!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou, Jew, think of thy ransom;\r\nthou needest not to be told that thy race are held to be accursed in\r\nall Christian communities, and trust me that we cannot endure thy\r\npresence among us. Think, therefore, of an offer, while I examine a\r\nprisoner of another cast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere many of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s men taken?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the Black Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone of note enough to be put to ransom,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Captain; \xe2\x80\x9ca set\r\nof hilding fellows there were, whom we dismissed to find them a new\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x94enough had been done for revenge and profit; the bunch of them\r\nwere not worth a cardecu. The prisoner I speak of is better booty\xe2\x80\x94a\r\njolly monk riding to visit his leman, an I may judge by his horse-gear\r\nand wearing apparel.\xe2\x80\x94Here cometh the worthy prelate, as pert as a\r\npyet.\xe2\x80\x9d And, between two yeomen, was brought before the silvan throne of\r\nthe outlaw Chief, our old friend, Prior Aymer of Jorvaulx.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIII\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94-Flower of warriors,\r\nHow is\xe2\x80\x99t with Titus Lartius?\r\nMARCIUS.\xe2\x80\x94As with a man busied about decrees,\r\nCondemning some to death and some to exile,\r\nRansoming him or pitying, threatening the other.\r\n\r\n\r\nCORIOLANUS\r\n\r\n\r\nThe captive Abbot\xe2\x80\x99s features and manners exhibited a whimsical mixture\r\nof offended pride, and deranged foppery and bodily terror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, how now, my masters?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with a voice in which all three\r\nemotions were blended. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat order is this among ye? Be ye Turks or\r\nChristians, that handle a churchman?\xe2\x80\x94Know ye what it is, \xe2\x80\x98manus\r\nimponere in servos Domini\xe2\x80\x99? Ye have plundered my mails\xe2\x80\x94torn my cope of\r\ncurious cut lace, which might have served a cardinal!\xe2\x80\x94Another in my\r\nplace would have been at his \xe2\x80\x98excommunicabo vos\xe2\x80\x99; but I am placible,\r\nand if ye order forth my palfreys, release my brethren, and restore my\r\nmails, tell down with all speed an hundred crowns to be expended in\r\nmasses at the high altar of Jorvaulx Abbey, and make your vow to eat no\r\nvenison until next Pentecost, it may be you shall hear little more of\r\nthis mad frolic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoly Father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the chief Outlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cit grieves me to think that you\r\nhave met with such usage from any of my followers, as calls for your\r\nfatherly reprehension.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUsage!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed the priest, encouraged by the mild tone of the silvan\r\nleader; \xe2\x80\x9cit were usage fit for no hound of good race\xe2\x80\x94much less for a\r\nChristian\xe2\x80\x94far less for a priest\xe2\x80\x94and least of all for the Prior of the\r\nholy community of Jorvaulx. Here is a profane and drunken minstrel,\r\ncalled Allan-a-Dale\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98nebulo quidam\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94who has menaced me with corporal\r\npunishment\xe2\x80\x94nay, with death itself, an I pay not down four hundred\r\ncrowns of ransom, to the boot of all the treasure he hath already\r\nrobbed me of\xe2\x80\x94gold chains and gymmal rings to an unknown value; besides\r\nwhat is broken and spoiled among their rude hands, such as my\r\npouncer-box and silver crisping-tongs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible that Allan-a-Dale can have thus treated a man of your\r\nreverend bearing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Captain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true as the gospel of Saint Nicodemus,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior; \xe2\x80\x9che\r\nswore, with many a cruel north-country oath, that he would hang me up\r\non the highest tree in the greenwood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he so in very deed? Nay, then, reverend father, I think you had\r\nbetter comply with his demands\xe2\x80\x94for Allan-a-Dale is the very man to\r\nabide by his word when he has so pledged it.\xe2\x80\x9d 43\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do but jest with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the astounded Prior, with a forced\r\nlaugh; \xe2\x80\x9cand I love a good jest with all my heart.
