But, ha! ha! ha! when\r\nthe mirth has lasted the livelong night, it is time to be grave in the\r\nmorning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am as grave as a father confessor,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Outlaw; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nmust pay a round ransom, Sir Prior, or your convent is likely to be\r\ncalled to a new election; for your place will know you no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre ye Christians,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cand hold this language to a\r\nchurchman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChristians! ay, marry are we, and have divinity among us to boot,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nanswered the Outlaw. \xe2\x80\x9cLet our buxom chaplain stand forth, and expound\r\nto this reverend father the texts which concern this matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Friar, half-drunk, half-sober, had huddled a friar\xe2\x80\x99s frock over his\r\ngreen cassock, and now summoning together whatever scraps of learning\r\nhe had acquired by rote in former days, \xe2\x80\x9cHoly father,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Deus\r\nfaciat salvam benignitatem vestram\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94You are welcome to the greenwood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat profane mummery is this?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior. \xe2\x80\x9cFriend, if thou be\xe2\x80\x99st\r\nindeed of the church, it were a better deed to show me how I may escape\r\nfrom these men\xe2\x80\x99s hands, than to stand ducking and grinning here like a\r\nmorris-dancer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly, reverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, \xe2\x80\x9cI know but one mode in which\r\nthou mayst escape. This is Saint Andrew\xe2\x80\x99s day with us, we are taking\r\nour tithes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not of the church, then, I trust, my good brother?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nPrior.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf church and lay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar; \xe2\x80\x9cand therefore, Sir Prior \xe2\x80\x98facite\r\nvobis amicos de Mammone iniquitatis\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94make yourselves friends of the\r\nMammon of unrighteousness, for no other friendship is like to serve\r\nyour turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love a jolly woodsman at heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, softening his tone;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccome, ye must not deal too hard with me\xe2\x80\x94I can well of woodcraft, and\r\ncan wind a horn clear and lustily, and hollo till every oak rings\r\nagain\xe2\x80\x94Come, ye must not deal too hard with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive him a horn,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw; \xe2\x80\x9cwe will prove the skill he boasts\r\nof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Prior Aymer winded a blast accordingly. The Captain shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Prior,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthou blowest a merry note, but it may not ransom\r\nthee\xe2\x80\x94we cannot afford, as the legend on a good knight\xe2\x80\x99s shield hath it,\r\nto set thee free for a blast. Moreover, I have found thee\xe2\x80\x94thou art one\r\nof those, who, with new French graces and Tra-li-ras, disturb the\r\nancient English bugle notes.\xe2\x80\x94Prior, that last flourish on the recheat\r\nhath added fifty crowns to thy ransom, for corrupting the true old\r\nmanly blasts of venerie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Abbot, peevishly, \xe2\x80\x9cthou art ill to please with\r\nthy woodcraft. I pray thee be more conformable in this matter of my\r\nransom. At a word\xe2\x80\x94since I must needs, for once, hold a candle to the\r\ndevil\xe2\x80\x94what ransom am I to pay for walking on Watling-street, without\r\nhaving fifty men at my back?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere it not well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Lieutenant of the gang apart to the\r\nCaptain, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the Prior should name the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s ransom, and the Jew name\r\nthe Prior\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art a mad knave,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cbut thy plan\r\ntranscends!\xe2\x80\x94Here, Jew, step forth\xe2\x80\x94Look at that holy Father Aymer, Prior\r\nof the rich Abbey of Jorvaulx, and tell us at what ransom we should\r\nhold him?\xe2\x80\x94Thou knowest the income of his convent, I warrant thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO, assuredly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac. \xe2\x80\x9cI have trafficked with the good fathers,\r\nand bought wheat and barley, and fruits of the earth, and also much\r\nwool. O, it is a rich abbey-stede, and they do live upon the fat, and\r\ndrink the sweet wines upon the lees, these good fathers of Jorvaulx.\r\nAh, if an outcast like me had such a home to go to, and such incomings\r\nby the year and by the month, I would pay much gold and silver to\r\nredeem my captivity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHound of a Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cno one knows better than thy\r\nown cursed self, that our holy house of God is indebted for the\r\nfinishing of our chancel\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd for the storing of your cellars in the last season with the due\r\nallowance of Gascon wine,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the Jew; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that\xe2\x80\x94that is small\r\nmatters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear the infidel dog!\xe2\x80\x9d said the churchman; \xe2\x80\x9che jangles as if our holy\r\ncommunity did come under debts for the wines we have a license to\r\ndrink, \xe2\x80\x98propter necessitatem, et ad frigus depellendum\xe2\x80\x99. The\r\ncircumcised villain blasphemeth the holy church, and Christian men\r\nlisten and rebuke him not!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll this helps nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the leader.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIsaac, pronounce what he\r\nmay pay, without flaying both hide and hair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn six hundred crowns,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cthe good Prior might well pay to\r\nyour honoured valours, and never sit less soft in his stall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSix hundred crowns,\xe2\x80\x9d said the leader, gravely; \xe2\x80\x9cI am contented\xe2\x80\x94thou\r\nhast well spoken, Isaac\xe2\x80\x94six hundred crowns.\xe2\x80\x94It is a sentence, Sir\r\nPrior.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA sentence!\xe2\x80\x94a sentence!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the band; \xe2\x80\x9cSolomon had not done it\r\nbetter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hearest thy doom, Prior,\xe2\x80\x9d said the leader.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe are mad, my masters,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior; \xe2\x80\x9cwhere am I to find such a\r\nsum? If I sell the very pyx and candlesticks on the altar at Jorvaulx,\r\nI shall scarce raise the half; and it will be necessary for that\r\npurpose that I go to Jorvaulx myself; ye may retain as borrows 44 my\r\ntwo priests.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will be but blind trust,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw; \xe2\x80\x9cwe will retain thee,\r\nPrior, and send them to fetch thy ransom. Thou shalt not want a cup of\r\nwine and a collop of venison the while; and if thou lovest woodcraft,\r\nthou shalt see such as your north country never witnessed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr, if so please you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, willing to curry favour with the\r\noutlaws, \xe2\x80\x9cI can send to York for the six hundred crowns, out of certain\r\nmonies in my hands, if so be that the most reverend Prior present will\r\ngrant me a quittance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe shall grant thee whatever thou dost list, Isaac,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand thou shalt lay down the redemption money for Prior Aymer as well\r\nas for thyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor myself! ah, courageous sirs,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a broken and\r\nimpoverished man; a beggar\xe2\x80\x99s staff must be my portion through life,\r\nsupposing I were to pay you fifty crowns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Prior shall judge of that matter,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Captain.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHow say\r\nyou, Father Aymer? Can the Jew afford a good ransom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan he afford a ransom?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Prior \xe2\x80\x9cIs he not Isaac of York,\r\nrich enough to redeem the captivity of the ten tribes of Israel, who\r\nwere led into Assyrian bondage?\xe2\x80\x94I have seen but little of him myself,\r\nbut our cellarer and treasurer have dealt largely with him, and report\r\nsays that his house at York is so full of gold and silver as is a shame\r\nin any Christian land. Marvel it is to all living Christian hearts that\r\nsuch gnawing adders should be suffered to eat into the bowels of the\r\nstate, and even of the holy church herself, with foul usuries and\r\nextortions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold, father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cmitigate and assuage your choler. I pray\r\nof your reverence to remember that I force my monies upon no one. But\r\nwhen churchman and layman, prince and prior, knight and priest, come\r\nknocking to Isaac\xe2\x80\x99s door, they borrow not his shekels with these\r\nuncivil terms. It is then, Friend Isaac, will you pleasure us in this\r\nmatter, and our day shall be truly kept, so God sa\xe2\x80\x99 me?\xe2\x80\x94and Kind Isaac,\r\nif ever you served man, show yourself a friend in this need! And when\r\nthe day comes, and I ask my own, then what hear I but Damned Jew, and\r\nThe curse of Egypt on your tribe, and all that may stir up the rude and\r\nuncivil populace against poor strangers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrior,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cJew though he be, he hath in this spoken\r\nwell. Do thou, therefore, name his ransom, as he named thine, without\r\nfarther rude terms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone but \xe2\x80\x98latro famosus\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94the interpretation whereof,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwill I give at some other time and tide\xe2\x80\x94would place a Christian\r\nprelate and an unbaptized Jew upon the same bench. But since ye require\r\nme to put a price upon this caitiff, I tell you openly that ye will\r\nwrong yourselves if you take from him a penny under a thousand crowns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA sentence!\xe2\x80\x94a sentence!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the chief Outlaw.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA sentence!\xe2\x80\x94a sentence!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted his assessors; \xe2\x80\x9cthe Christian has\r\nshown his good nurture, and dealt with us more generously than the\r\nJew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe God of my fathers help me!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew; \xe2\x80\x9cwill ye bear to the\r\nground an impoverished creature?\xe2\x80\x94I am this day childless, and will ye\r\ndeprive me of the means of livelihood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou wilt have the less to provide for, Jew, if thou art childless,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Aymer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas! my lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cyour law permits you not to know how the\r\nchild of our bosom is entwined with the strings of our heart\xe2\x80\x94O Rebecca!\r\nlaughter of my beloved Rachel! were each leaf on that tree a zecchin,\r\nand each zecchin mine own, all that mass of wealth would I give to know\r\nwhether thou art alive, and escaped the hands of the Nazarene!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas not thy daughter dark-haired?\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the outlaws; \xe2\x80\x9cand wore\r\nshe not a veil of twisted sendal, broidered with silver?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe did!\xe2\x80\x94she did!\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man, trembling with eagerness, as\r\nformerly with fear. \xe2\x80\x9cThe blessing of Jacob be upon thee! canst thou\r\ntell me aught of her safety?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was she, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9cwho was carried off by the proud\r\nTemplar, when he broke through our ranks on yester-even. I had drawn my\r\nbow to send a shaft after him, but spared him even for the sake of the\r\ndamsel, who I feared might take harm from the arrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cI would to God thou hadst shot, though the\r\narrow had pierced her bosom!\xe2\x80\x94Better the tomb of her fathers than the\r\ndishonourable couch of the licentious and savage Templar. Ichabod!\r\nIchabod! the glory hath departed from my house!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriends,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Chief, looking round, \xe2\x80\x9cthe old man is but a Jew,\r\nnatheless his grief touches me.\xe2\x80\x94Deal uprightly with us, Isaac\xe2\x80\x94will\r\npaying this ransom of a thousand crowns leave thee altogether\r\npenniless?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIsaac, recalled to think of his worldly goods, the love of which, by\r\ndint of inveterate habit, contended even with his parental affection,\r\ngrew pale, stammered, and could not deny there might be some small\r\nsurplus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell\xe2\x80\x94go to\xe2\x80\x94what though there be,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will not reckon\r\nwith thee too closely. Without treasure thou mayst as well hope to\r\nredeem thy child from the clutches of Sir Brian de Bois-Guilbert, as to\r\nshoot a stag-royal with a headless shaft.\xe2\x80\x94We will take thee at the same\r\nransom with Prior Aymer, or rather at one hundred crowns lower, which\r\nhundred crowns shall be mine own peculiar loss, and not light upon this\r\nworshipful community; and so we shall avoid the heinous offence of\r\nrating a Jew merchant as high as a Christian prelate, and thou wilt\r\nhave six hundred crowns remaining to treat for thy daughter\xe2\x80\x99s ransom.\r\nTemplars love the glitter of silver shekels as well as the sparkle of\r\nblack eyes.\xe2\x80\x94Hasten to make thy crowns chink in the ear of De\r\nBois-Guilbert, ere worse comes of it. Thou wilt find him, as our scouts\r\nhave brought notice, at the next Preceptory house of his Order.\xe2\x80\x94Said I\r\nwell, my merry mates?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe yeomen expressed their wonted acquiescence in their leader\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nopinion; and Isaac, relieved of one half of his apprehensions, by\r\nlearning that his daughter lived, and might possibly be ransomed, threw\r\nhimself at the feet of the generous Outlaw, and, rubbing his beard\r\nagainst his buskins, sought to kiss the hem of his green cassock. The\r\nCaptain drew himself back, and extricated himself from the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s grasp,\r\nnot without some marks of contempt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, beshrew thee, man, up with thee! I am English born, and love no\r\nsuch Eastern prostrations\xe2\x80\x94Kneel to God, and not to a poor sinner, like\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prior Aymer; \xe2\x80\x9ckneel to God, as represented in the\r\nservant of his altar, and who knows, with thy sincere repentance and\r\ndue gifts to the shrine of Saint Robert, what grace thou mayst acquire\r\nfor thyself and thy daughter Rebecca? I grieve for the maiden, for she\r\nis of fair and comely countenance,\xe2\x80\x94I beheld her in the lists of Ashby.\r\nAlso Brian de Bois-Guilbert is one with whom I may do much\xe2\x80\x94bethink thee\r\nhow thou mayst deserve my good word with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas! alas!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9con every hand the spoilers arise against\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94I am given as a prey unto the Assyrian, and a prey unto him of\r\nEgypt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what else should be the lot of thy accursed race?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\r\nPrior; \xe2\x80\x9cfor what saith holy writ, \xe2\x80\x98verbum Domini projecerunt, et\r\nsapientia est nulla in eis\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94they have cast forth the word of the Lord,\r\nand there is no wisdom in them; \xe2\x80\x98propterea dabo mulieres eorum\r\nexteris\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94I will give their women to strangers, that is to the Templar,\r\nas in the present matter; \xe2\x80\x98et thesauros eorum haeredibus alienis\xe2\x80\x99, and\r\ntheir treasures to others\xe2\x80\x94as in the present case to these honest\r\ngentlemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIsaac groaned deeply, and began to wring his hands, and to relapse into\r\nhis state of desolation and despair. But the leader of the yeomen led\r\nhim aside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdvise thee well, Isaac,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat thou wilt do in this\r\nmatter; my counsel to thee is to make a friend of this churchman. He is\r\nvain, Isaac, and he is covetous; at least he needs money to supply his\r\nprofusion. Thou canst easily gratify his greed; for think not that I am\r\nblinded by thy pretexts of poverty. I am intimately acquainted, Isaac,\r\nwith the very iron chest in which thou dost keep thy money-bags\xe2\x80\x94What!\r\nknow I not the great stone beneath the apple-tree, that leads into the\r\nvaulted chamber under thy garden at York?\xe2\x80\x9d The Jew grew as pale as\r\ndeath\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBut fear nothing from me,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9cfor we are of\r\nold acquainted. Dost thou not remember the sick yeoman whom thy fair\r\ndaughter Rebecca redeemed from the gyves at York, and kept him in thy\r\nhouse till his health was restored, when thou didst dismiss him\r\nrecovered, and with a piece of money?\xe2\x80\x94Usurer as thou art, thou didst\r\nnever place coin at better interest than that poor silver mark, for it\r\nhas this day saved thee five hundred crowns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou art he whom we called Diccon Bend-the-Bow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nthought ever I knew the accent of thy voice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am Bend-the-Bow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9cand Locksley, and have a good\r\nname besides all these.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut thou art mistaken, good Bend-the-Bow, concerning that same vaulted\r\napartment. So help me Heaven, as there is nought in it but some\r\nmerchandises which I will gladly part with to you\xe2\x80\x94one hundred yards of\r\nLincoln green to make doublets to thy men, and a hundred staves of\r\nSpanish yew to make bows, and a hundred silken bowstrings, tough,\r\nround, and sound\xe2\x80\x94these will I send thee for thy good-will, honest\r\nDiccon, an thou wilt keep silence about the vault, my good Diccon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilent as a dormouse,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw; \xe2\x80\x9cand never trust me but I am\r\ngrieved for thy daughter. But I may not help it\xe2\x80\x94The Templars lances are\r\ntoo strong for my archery in the open field\xe2\x80\x94they would scatter us like\r\ndust. Had I but known it was Rebecca when she was borne off, something\r\nmight have been done; but now thou must needs proceed by policy. Come,\r\nshall I treat for thee with the Prior?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn God\xe2\x80\x99s name, Diccon, an thou canst, aid me to recover the child of\r\nmy bosom!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not thou interrupt me with thine ill-timed avarice,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nOutlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cand I will deal with him in thy behalf.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then turned from the Jew, who followed him, however, as closely as\r\nhis shadow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrior Aymer,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9ccome apart with me under this tree.\r\nMen say thou dost love wine, and a lady\xe2\x80\x99s smile, better than beseems\r\nthy Order, Sir Priest; but with that I have nought to do. I have heard,\r\ntoo, thou dost love a brace of good dogs and a fleet horse, and it may\r\nwell be that, loving things which are costly to come by, thou hatest\r\nnot a purse of gold. But I have never heard that thou didst love\r\noppression or cruelty.\xe2\x80\x94Now, here is Isaac willing to give thee the\r\nmeans of pleasure and pastime in a bag containing one hundred marks of\r\nsilver, if thy intercession with thine ally the Templar shall avail to\r\nprocure the freedom of his daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn safety and honour, as when taken from me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cotherwise\r\nit is no bargain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace, Isaac,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cor I give up thine interest.\xe2\x80\x94What say\r\nyou to this my purpose, Prior Aymer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe matter,\xe2\x80\x9d quoth the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cis of a mixed condition; for, if I do a\r\ngood deal on the one hand, yet, on the other, it goeth to the vantage\r\nof a Jew, and in so much is against my conscience. Yet, if the\r\nIsraelite will advantage the Church by giving me somewhat over to the\r\nbuilding of our dortour, 45 I will take it on my conscience to aid him\r\nin the matter of his daughter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor a score of marks to the dortour,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBe still, I\r\nsay, Isaac!\xe2\x80\x94or for a brace of silver candlesticks to the altar, we will\r\nnot stand with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but, good Diccon Bend-the-Bow\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said Isaac, endeavouring to\r\ninterpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Jew\xe2\x80\x94good beast\xe2\x80\x94good earthworm!\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman, losing patience;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9can thou dost go on to put thy filthy lucre in the balance with thy\r\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x99s life and honour, by Heaven, I will strip thee of every\r\nmaravedi thou hast in the world, before three days are out!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIsaac shrunk together, and was silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what pledge am I to have for all this?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen Isaac returns successful through your mediation,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nOutlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cI swear by Saint Hubert, I will see that he pays thee the\r\nmoney in good silver, or I will reckon with him for it in such sort, he\r\nhad better have paid twenty such sums.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aymer, \xe2\x80\x9csince I must needs meddle in this\r\nmatter, let me have the use of thy writing-tablets\xe2\x80\x94though, hold\xe2\x80\x94rather\r\nthan use thy pen, I would fast for twenty-four hours, and where shall I\r\nfind one?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf your holy scruples can dispense with using the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s tablets, for\r\nthe pen I can find a remedy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman; and, bending his bow, he\r\naimed his shaft at a wild-goose which was soaring over their heads, the\r\nadvanced-guard of a phalanx of his tribe, which were winging their way\r\nto the distant and solitary fens of Holderness. The bird came\r\nfluttering down, transfixed with the arrow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, Prior,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9care quills enow to supply all the\r\nmonks of Jorvaulx for the next hundred years, an they take not to\r\nwriting chronicles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Prior sat down, and at great leisure indited an epistle to Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, and having carefully sealed up the tablets, delivered\r\nthem to the Jew, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cThis will be thy safe-conduct to the\r\nPreceptory of Templestowe, and, as I think, is most likely to\r\naccomplish the delivery of thy daughter, if it be well backed with\r\nproffers of advantage and commodity at thine own hand; for, trust me\r\nwell, the good Knight Bois-Guilbert is of their confraternity that do\r\nnought for nought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Prior,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cI will detain thee no longer here than\r\nto give the Jew a quittance for the six hundred crowns at which thy\r\nransom is fixed\xe2\x80\x94I accept of him for my pay-master; and if I hear that\r\nye boggle at allowing him in his accompts the sum so paid by him, Saint\r\nMary refuse me, an I burn not the abbey over thine head, though I hang\r\nten years the sooner!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith a much worse grace than that wherewith he had penned the letter to\r\nBois-Guilbert, the Prior wrote an acquittance, discharging Isaac of\r\nYork of six hundred crowns, advanced to him in his need for acquittal\r\nof his ransom, and faithfully promising to hold true compt with him for\r\nthat sum.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prior Aymer, \xe2\x80\x9cI will pray you of restitution of my\r\nmules and palfreys, and the freedom of the reverend brethren attending\r\nupon me, and also of the gymmal rings, jewels, and fair vestures, of\r\nwhich I have been despoiled, having now satisfied you for my ransom as\r\na true prisoner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTouching your brethren, Sir Prior,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley, \xe2\x80\x9cthey shall have\r\npresent freedom, it were unjust to detain them; touching your horses\r\nand mules, they shall also be restored, with such spending-money as may\r\nenable you to reach York, for it were cruel to deprive you of the means\r\nof journeying.\xe2\x80\x94But as concerning rings, jewels, chains, and what else,\r\nyou must understand that we are men of tender consciences, and will not\r\nyield to a venerable man like yourself, who should be dead to the\r\nvanities of this life, the strong temptation to break the rule of his\r\nfoundation, by wearing rings, chains, or other vain gauds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink what you do, my masters,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cere you put your hand\r\non the Church\xe2\x80\x99s patrimony\xe2\x80\x94These things are \xe2\x80\x98inter res sacras\xe2\x80\x99, and I\r\nwot not what judgment might ensue were they to be handled by laical\r\nhands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will take care of that, reverend Prior,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Hermit of\r\nCopmanhurst; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I will wear them myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend, or brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, in answer to this solution of his\r\ndoubts, \xe2\x80\x9cif thou hast really taken religious orders, I pray thee to\r\nlook how thou wilt answer to thine official for the share thou hast\r\ntaken in this day\xe2\x80\x99s work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend Prior,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the Hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are to know that I belong to\r\na little diocese, where I am my own diocesan, and care as little for\r\nthe Bishop of York as I do for the Abbot of Jorvaulx, the Prior, and\r\nall the convent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art utterly irregular,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior; \xe2\x80\x9cone of those disorderly\r\nmen, who, taking on them the sacred character without due cause,\r\nprofane the holy rites, and endanger the souls of those who take\r\ncounsel at their hands; \xe2\x80\x98lapides pro pane condonantes iis\xe2\x80\x99, giving them\r\nstones instead of bread as the Vulgate hath it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, \xe2\x80\x9can my brain-pan could have been broken by\r\nLatin, it had not held so long together.\xe2\x80\x94I say, that easing a world of\r\nsuch misproud priests as thou art of their jewels and their gimcracks,\r\nis a lawful spoiling of the Egyptians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou be\xe2\x80\x99st a hedge-priest,\xe2\x80\x9d 46 said the Prior, in great wrath,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98excommunicabo vos\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou be\xe2\x80\x99st thyself more like a thief and a heretic,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar,\r\nequally indignant; \xe2\x80\x9cI will pouch up no such affront before my\r\nparishioners, as thou thinkest it not shame to put upon me, although I\r\nbe a reverend brother to thee. \xe2\x80\x98Ossa ejus perfringam\xe2\x80\x99, I will break\r\nyour bones, as the Vulgate hath it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHola!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Captain, \xe2\x80\x9ccome the reverend brethren to such\r\nterms?\xe2\x80\x94Keep thine assurance of peace, Friar.\xe2\x80\x94Prior, an thou hast not\r\nmade thy peace perfect with God, provoke the Friar no further.\xe2\x80\x94Hermit,\r\nlet the reverend father depart in peace, as a ransomed man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe yeomen separated the incensed priests, who continued to raise their\r\nvoices, vituperating each other in bad Latin, which the Prior delivered\r\nthe more fluently, and the Hermit with the greater vehemence. The Prior\r\nat length recollected himself sufficiently to be aware that he was\r\ncompromising his dignity, by squabbling with such a hedge-priest as the\r\nOutlaw\xe2\x80\x99s chaplain, and being joined by his attendants, rode off with\r\nconsiderably less pomp, and in a much more apostolical condition, so\r\nfar as worldly matters were concerned, than he had exhibited before\r\nthis rencounter.\r\n\r\nIt remained that the Jew should produce some security for the ransom\r\nwhich he was to pay on the Prior\xe2\x80\x99s account, as well as upon his own. He\r\ngave, accordingly, an order sealed with his signet, to a brother of his\r\ntribe at York, requiring him to pay to the bearer the sum of a thousand\r\ncrowns, and to deliver certain merchandises specified in the note.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother Sheva,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, groaning deeply, \xe2\x80\x9chath the key of my\r\nwarehouses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd of the vaulted chamber,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Locksley.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no\xe2\x80\x94may Heaven forefend!\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac; \xe2\x80\x9cevil is the hour that let\r\nany one whomsoever into that secret!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is safe with me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cso be that this thy scroll\r\nproduce the sum therein nominated and set down.\xe2\x80\x94But what now, Isaac?\r\nart dead? art stupefied? hath the payment of a thousand crowns put thy\r\ndaughter\xe2\x80\x99s peril out of thy mind?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew started to his feet\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Diccon, no\xe2\x80\x94I will presently set\r\nforth.\xe2\x80\x94Farewell, thou whom I may not call good, and dare not and will\r\nnot call evil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nYet ere Isaac departed, the Outlaw Chief bestowed on him this parting\r\nadvice:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBe liberal of thine offers, Isaac, and spare not thy purse for\r\nthy daughter\xe2\x80\x99s safety. Credit me, that the gold thou shalt spare in her\r\ncause, will hereafter give thee as much agony as if it were poured\r\nmolten down thy throat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIsaac acquiesced with a deep groan, and set forth on his journey,\r\naccompanied by two tall foresters, who were to be his guides, and at\r\nthe same time his guards, through the wood.\r\n\r\nThe Black Knight, who had seen with no small interest these various\r\nproceedings, now took his leave of the Outlaw in turn; nor could he\r\navoid expressing his surprise at having witnessed so much of civil\r\npolicy amongst persons cast out from all the ordinary protection and\r\ninfluence of the laws.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood fruit, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9cwill sometimes grow on a\r\nsorry tree; and evil times are not always productive of evil alone and\r\nunmixed. Amongst those who are drawn into this lawless state, there\r\nare, doubtless, numbers who wish to exercise its license with some\r\nmoderation, and some who regret, it may be, that they are obliged to\r\nfollow such a trade at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to one of those,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cI am now, I presume,\r\nspeaking?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have each our secret. You are\r\nwelcome to form your judgment of me, and I may use my conjectures\r\ntouching you, though neither of our shafts may hit the mark they are\r\nshot at. But as I do not pray to be admitted into your mystery, be not\r\noffended that I preserve my own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI crave pardon, brave Outlaw,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cyour reproof is just.\r\nBut it may be we shall meet hereafter with less of concealment on\r\neither side.\xe2\x80\x94Meanwhile we part friends, do we not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is my hand upon it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Locksley; \xe2\x80\x9cand I will call it the hand\r\nof a true Englishman, though an outlaw for the present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there is mine in return,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cand I hold it honoured\r\nby being clasped with yours. For he that does good, having the\r\nunlimited power to do evil, deserves praise not only for the good which\r\nhe performs, but for the evil which he forbears. Fare thee well,\r\ngallant Outlaw!\xe2\x80\x9d Thus parted that fair fellowship; and He of the\r\nFetterlock, mounting upon his strong war-horse, rode off through the\r\nforest.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIV\r\n\r\n\r\nKING JOHN.\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell thee what, my friend,\r\nHe is a very serpent in my way;\r\nAnd wheresoe\xe2\x80\x99er this foot of mine doth tread,\r\nHe lies before me.\xe2\x80\x94Dost thou understand me?\r\n\r\n\r\nKING JOHN\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was brave feasting in the Castle of York, to which Prince John\r\nhad invited those nobles, prelates, and leaders, by whose assistance he\r\nhoped to carry through his ambitious projects upon his brother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthrone. Waldemar Fitzurse, his able and politic agent, was at secret\r\nwork among them, tempering all to that pitch of courage which was\r\nnecessary in making an open declaration of their purpose. But their\r\nenterprise was delayed by the absence of more than one main limb of the\r\nconfederacy. The stubborn and daring, though brutal courage of\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf; the buoyant spirits and bold bearing of De Bracy; the\r\nsagacity, martial experience, and renowned valour of Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, were important to the success of their conspiracy; and,\r\nwhile cursing in secret their unnecessary and unmeaning absence,\r\nneither John nor his adviser dared to proceed without them. Isaac the\r\nJew also seemed to have vanished, and with him the hope of certain sums\r\nof money, making up the subsidy for which Prince John had contracted\r\nwith that Israelite and his brethren. This deficiency was likely to\r\nprove perilous in an emergency so critical.\r\n\r\nIt was on the morning after the fall of Torquilstone, that a confused\r\nreport began to spread abroad in the city of York, that De Bracy and\r\nBois-Guilbert, with their confederate Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, had been taken or\r\nslain. Waldemar brought the rumour to Prince John, announcing, that he\r\nfeared its truth the more that they had set out with a small\r\nattendance, for the purpose of committing an assault on the Saxon\r\nCedric and his attendants. At another time the Prince would have\r\ntreated this deed of violence as a good jest; but now, that it\r\ninterfered with and impeded his own plans, he exclaimed against the\r\nperpetrators, and spoke of the broken laws, and the infringement of\r\npublic order and of private property, in a tone which might have become\r\nKing Alfred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe unprincipled marauders,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cwere I ever to become monarch of\r\nEngland, I would hang such transgressors over the drawbridges of their\r\nown castles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut to become monarch of England,\xe2\x80\x9d said his Ahithophel coolly, \xe2\x80\x9cit is\r\nnecessary not only that your Grace should endure the transgressions of\r\nthese unprincipled marauders, but that you should afford them your\r\nprotection, notwithstanding your laudable zeal for the laws they are in\r\nthe habit of infringing. We shall be finely helped, if the churl Saxons\r\nshould have realized your Grace\xe2\x80\x99s vision, of converting feudal\r\ndrawbridges into gibbets; and yonder bold-spirited Cedric seemeth one\r\nto whom such an imagination might occur. Your Grace is well aware, it\r\nwill be dangerous to stir without Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, De Bracy, and the\r\nTemplar; and yet we have gone too far to recede with safety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPrince John struck his forehead with impatience, and then began to\r\nstride up and down the apartment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe villains,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe base treacherous villains, to desert me\r\nat this pinch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, say rather the feather-pated giddy madmen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar, \xe2\x80\x9cwho\r\nmust be toying with follies when such business was in hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prince, stopping short before Waldemar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing which can be done,\xe2\x80\x9d answered his counsellor, \xe2\x80\x9csave that\r\nwhich I have already taken order for.\xe2\x80\x94I came not to bewail this evil\r\nchance with your Grace, until I had done my best to remedy it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art ever my better angel, Waldemar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prince; \xe2\x80\x9cand when I\r\nhave such a chancellor to advise withal, the reign of John will be\r\nrenowned in our annals.\xe2\x80\x94What hast thou commanded?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have ordered Louis Winkelbrand, De Bracy\xe2\x80\x99s lieutenant, to cause his\r\ntrumpet sound to horse, and to display his banner, and to set presently\r\nforth towards the castle of Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf, to do what yet may be done\r\nfor the succour of our friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPrince John\xe2\x80\x99s face flushed with the pride of a spoilt child, who has\r\nundergone what it conceives to be an insult. \xe2\x80\x9cBy the face of God!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cWaldemar Fitzurse, much hast thou taken upon thee! and over\r\nmalapert thou wert to cause trumpet to blow, or banner to be raised, in\r\na town where ourselves were in presence, without our express command.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI crave your Grace\xe2\x80\x99s pardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, internally cursing the\r\nidle vanity of his patron; \xe2\x80\x9cbut when time pressed, and even the loss of\r\nminutes might be fatal, I judged it best to take this much burden upon\r\nme, in a matter of such importance to your Grace\xe2\x80\x99s interest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art pardoned, Fitzurse,\xe2\x80\x9d said the prince, gravely; \xe2\x80\x9cthy purpose\r\nhath atoned for thy hasty rashness.\xe2\x80\x94But whom have we here?\xe2\x80\x94De Bracy\r\nhimself, by the rood!\xe2\x80\x94and in strange guise doth he come before us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was indeed De Bracy\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbloody with spurring, fiery red with speed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHis armour bore all the marks of the late obstinate fray, being broken,\r\ndefaced, and stained with blood in many places, and covered with clay\r\nand dust from the crest to the spur. Undoing his helmet, he placed it\r\non the table, and stood a moment as if to collect himself before he\r\ntold his news.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDe Bracy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat means this?\xe2\x80\x94Speak, I charge\r\nthee!\xe2\x80\x94Are the Saxons in rebellion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, De Bracy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, almost in the same moment with his\r\nmaster, \xe2\x80\x9cthou wert wont to be a man\xe2\x80\x94Where is the Templar?\xe2\x80\x94where\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Templar is fled,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf you will never see\r\nmore. He has found a red grave among the blazing rafters of his own\r\ncastle and I alone am escaped to tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCold news,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar, \xe2\x80\x9cto us, though you speak of fire and\r\nconflagration.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe worst news is not yet said,\xe2\x80\x9d answered De Bracy; and, coming up to\r\nPrince John, he uttered in a low and emphatic tone\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cRichard is in\r\nEngland\xe2\x80\x94I have seen and spoken with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPrince John turned pale, tottered, and caught at the back of an oaken\r\nbench to support himself\xe2\x80\x94much like to a man who receives an arrow in\r\nhis bosom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou ravest, De Bracy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cit cannot be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is as true as truth itself,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cI was his prisoner,\r\nand spoke with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith Richard Plantagenet, sayest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d continued Fitzurse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith Richard Plantagenet,\xe2\x80\x9d replied De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cwith Richard\r\nC\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion\xe2\x80\x94with Richard of England.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou wert his prisoner?\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar; \xe2\x80\x9che is then at the head of\r\na power?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94only a few outlawed yeomen were around him, and to these his person\r\nis unknown. I heard him say he was about to depart from them. He joined\r\nthem only to assist at the storming of Torquilstone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9csuch is indeed the fashion of Richard\xe2\x80\x94a true\r\nknight-errant he, and will wander in wild adventure, trusting the\r\nprowess of his single arm, like any Sir Guy or Sir Bevis, while the\r\nweighty affairs of his kingdom slumber, and his own safety is\r\nendangered.\xe2\x80\x94What dost thou propose to do De Bracy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x94I offered Richard the service of my Free Lances, and he refused\r\nthem\xe2\x80\x94I will lead them to Hull, seize on shipping, and embark for\r\nFlanders; thanks to the bustling times, a man of action will always\r\nfind employment. And thou, Waldemar, wilt thou take lance and shield,\r\nand lay down thy policies, and wend along with me, and share the fate\r\nwhich God sends us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am too old, Maurice, and I have a daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Waldemar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive her to me, Fitzurse, and I will maintain her as fits her rank,\r\nwith the help of lance and stirrup,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Fitzurse; \xe2\x80\x9cI will take sanctuary in this church of\r\nSaint Peter\xe2\x80\x94the Archbishop is my sworn brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDuring this discourse, Prince John had gradually awakened from the\r\nstupor into which he had been thrown by the unexpected intelligence,\r\nand had been attentive to the conversation which passed betwixt his\r\nfollowers. \xe2\x80\x9cThey fall off from me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cthey hold no\r\nmore by me than a withered leaf by the bough when a breeze blows on\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x94Hell and fiends! can I shape no means for myself when I am deserted\r\nby these cravens?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94He paused, and there was an expression of diabolical\r\npassion in the constrained laugh with which he at length broke in on\r\ntheir conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa, ha, ha! my good lords, by the light of Our Lady\xe2\x80\x99s brow, I held ye\r\nsage men, bold men, ready-witted men; yet ye throw down wealth, honour,\r\npleasure, all that our noble game promised you, at the moment it might\r\nbe won by one bold cast!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand you not,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy. \xe2\x80\x9cAs soon as Richard\xe2\x80\x99s return is\r\nblown abroad, he will be at the head of an army, and all is then over\r\nwith us. I would counsel you, my lord, either to fly to France or take\r\nthe protection of the Queen Mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI seek no safety for myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, haughtily; \xe2\x80\x9cthat I\r\ncould secure by a word spoken to my brother. But although you, De\r\nBracy, and you, Waldemar Fitzurse, are so ready to abandon me, I should\r\nnot greatly delight to see your heads blackening on Clifford\xe2\x80\x99s gate\r\nyonder. Thinkest thou, Waldemar, that the wily Archbishop will not\r\nsuffer thee to be taken from the very horns of the altar, would it make\r\nhis peace with King Richard? And forgettest thou, De Bracy, that Robert\r\nEstoteville lies betwixt thee and Hull with all his forces, and that\r\nthe Earl of Essex is gathering his followers? If we had reason to fear\r\nthese levies even before Richard\xe2\x80\x99s return, trowest thou there is any\r\ndoubt now which party their leaders will take? Trust me, Estoteville\r\nalone has strength enough to drive all thy Free Lances into the\r\nHumber.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Waldemar Fitzurse and De Bracy looked in each other\xe2\x80\x99s faces\r\nwith blank dismay.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThere is but one road to safety,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the\r\nPrince, and his brow grew black as midnight; \xe2\x80\x9cthis object of our terror\r\njourneys alone\xe2\x80\x94He must be met withal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot by me,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, hastily; \xe2\x80\x9cI was his prisoner, and he took\r\nme to mercy. I will not harm a feather in his crest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho spoke of harming him?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, with a hardened laugh;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe knave will say next that I meant he should slay him!\xe2\x80\x94No\xe2\x80\x94a prison\r\nwere better; and whether in Britain or Austria, what matters it?\xe2\x80\x94Things\r\nwill be but as they were when we commenced our enterprise\xe2\x80\x94It was\r\nfounded on the hope that Richard would remain a captive in Germany\xe2\x80\x94Our\r\nuncle Robert lived and died in the castle of Cardiffe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar, \xe2\x80\x9cyour sire Henry sate more firm in his seat\r\nthan your Grace can. I say the best prison is that which is made by the\r\nsexton\xe2\x80\x94no dungeon like a church-vault! I have said my say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrison or tomb,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cI wash my hands of the whole matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVillain!\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cthou wouldst not bewray our counsel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCounsel was never bewrayed by me,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, haughtily, \xe2\x80\x9cnor must\r\nthe name of villain be coupled with mine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace, Sir Knight!\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar; \xe2\x80\x9cand you, good my lord, forgive the\r\nscruples of valiant De Bracy; I trust I shall soon remove them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat passes your eloquence, Fitzurse,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, good Sir Maurice,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined the wily politician, \xe2\x80\x9cstart not aside\r\nlike a scared steed, without, at least, considering the object of your\r\nterror.\xe2\x80\x94This Richard\xe2\x80\x94but a day since, and it would have been thy\r\ndearest wish to have met him hand to hand in the ranks of battle\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nhundred times I have heard thee wish it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that was as thou sayest, hand to hand, and in\r\nthe ranks of battle! Thou never heardest me breathe a thought of\r\nassaulting him alone, and in a forest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art no good knight if thou dost scruple at it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it in battle that Lancelot de Lac and Sir Tristram won renown? or\r\nwas it not by encountering gigantic knights under the shade of deep and\r\nunknown forests?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but I promise you,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cthat neither Tristram nor\r\nLancelot would have been match, hand to hand, for Richard Plantagenet,\r\nand I think it was not their wont to take odds against a single man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art mad, De Bracy\xe2\x80\x94what is it we propose to thee, a hired and\r\nretained captain of Free Companions, whose swords are purchased for\r\nPrince John\xe2\x80\x99s service? Thou art apprized of our enemy, and then thou\r\nscruplest, though thy patron\xe2\x80\x99s fortunes, those of thy comrades, thine\r\nown, and the life and honour of every one amongst us, be at stake!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, sullenly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he gave me my life. True,\r\nhe sent me from his presence, and refused my homage\xe2\x80\x94so far I owe him\r\nneither favour nor allegiance\xe2\x80\x94but I will not lift hand against him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt needs not\xe2\x80\x94send Louis Winkelbrand and a score of thy lances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe have sufficient ruffians of your own,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cnot one of\r\nmine shall budge on such an errand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArt thou so obstinate, De Bracy?\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John; \xe2\x80\x9cand wilt thou\r\nforsake me, after so many protestations of zeal for my service?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean it not,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy; \xe2\x80\x9cI will abide by you in aught that\r\nbecomes a knight, whether in the lists or in the camp; but this highway\r\npractice comes not within my vow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome hither, Waldemar,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John. \xe2\x80\x9cAn unhappy prince am I. My\r\nfather, King Henry, had faithful servants\xe2\x80\x94He had but to say that he was\r\nplagued with a factious priest, and the blood of Thomas-a-Becket, saint\r\nthough he was, stained the steps of his own altar.\xe2\x80\x94Tracy, Morville,\r\nBrito 47 loyal and daring subjects, your names, your spirit, are\r\nextinct! and although Reginald Fitzurse hath left a son, he hath fallen\r\noff from his father\xe2\x80\x99s fidelity and courage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has fallen off from neither,\xe2\x80\x9d said Waldemar Fitzurse; \xe2\x80\x9cand since it\r\nmay not better be, I will take on me the conduct of this perilous\r\nenterprise. Dearly, however, did my father purchase the praise of a\r\nzealous friend; and yet did his proof of loyalty to Henry fall far\r\nshort of what I am about to afford; for rather would I assail a whole\r\ncalendar of saints, than put spear in rest against C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion.\xe2\x80\x94De\r\nBracy, to thee I must trust to keep up the spirits of the doubtful, and\r\nto guard Prince John\xe2\x80\x99s person. If you receive such news as I trust to\r\nsend you, our enterprise will no longer wear a doubtful aspect.\xe2\x80\x94Page,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, \xe2\x80\x9chie to my lodgings, and tell my armourer to be there in\r\nreadiness; and bid Stephen Wetheral, Broad Thoresby, and the Three\r\nSpears of Spyinghow, come to me instantly; and let the scout-master,\r\nHugh Bardon, attend me also.\xe2\x80\x94Adieu, my Prince, till better times.\xe2\x80\x9d Thus\r\nspeaking, he left the apartment. \xe2\x80\x9cHe goes to make my brother prisoner,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Prince John to De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cwith as little touch of compunction, as\r\nif it but concerned the liberty of a Saxon franklin. I trust he will\r\nobserve our orders, and use our dear Richard\xe2\x80\x99s person with all due\r\nrespect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDe Bracy only answered by a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the light of Our Lady\xe2\x80\x99s brow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, \xe2\x80\x9cour orders to him\r\nwere most precise\xe2\x80\x94though it may be you heard them not, as we stood\r\ntogether in the oriel window\xe2\x80\x94Most clear and positive was our charge\r\nthat Richard\xe2\x80\x99s safety should be cared for, and woe to Waldemar\xe2\x80\x99s head\r\nif he transgress it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had better pass to his lodgings,\xe2\x80\x9d said De Bracy, \xe2\x80\x9cand make him fully\r\naware of your Grace\xe2\x80\x99s pleasure; for, as it quite escaped my ear, it may\r\nnot perchance have reached that of Waldemar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, nay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John, impatiently, \xe2\x80\x9cI promise thee he heard me;\r\nand, besides, I have farther occupation for thee. Maurice, come hither;\r\nlet me lean on thy shoulder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey walked a turn through the hall in this familiar posture, and\r\nPrince John, with an air of the most confidential intimacy, proceeded\r\nto say, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat thinkest thou of this Waldemar Fitzurse, my De Bracy?\xe2\x80\x94He\r\ntrusts to be our Chancellor. Surely we will pause ere we give an office\r\nso high to one who shows evidently how little he reverences our blood,\r\nby his so readily undertaking this enterprise against Richard. Thou\r\ndost think, I warrant, that thou hast lost somewhat of our regard, by\r\nthy boldly declining this unpleasing task\xe2\x80\x94But no, Maurice! I rather\r\nhonour thee for thy virtuous constancy. There are things most necessary\r\nto be done, the perpetrator of which we neither love nor honour; and\r\nthere may be refusals to serve us, which shall rather exalt in our\r\nestimation those who deny our request. The arrest of my unfortunate\r\nbrother forms no such good title to the high office of Chancellor, as\r\nthy chivalrous and courageous denial establishes in thee to the\r\ntruncheon of High Marshal. Think of this, De Bracy, and begone to thy\r\ncharge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFickle tyrant!\xe2\x80\x9d muttered De Bracy, as he left the presence of the\r\nPrince; \xe2\x80\x9cevil luck have they who trust thee. Thy Chancellor, indeed!\xe2\x80\x94He\r\nwho hath the keeping of thy conscience shall have an easy charge, I\r\ntrow. But High Marshal of England! that,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, extending his arm,\r\nas if to grasp the baton of office, and assuming a loftier stride along\r\nthe antechamber, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is indeed a prize worth playing for!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDe Bracy had no sooner left the apartment than Prince John summoned an\r\nattendant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBid Hugh Bardon, our scout-master, come hither, as soon as he shall\r\nhave spoken with Waldemar Fitzurse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe scout-master arrived after a brief delay, during which John\r\ntraversed the apartment with, unequal and disordered steps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBardon,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat did Waldemar desire of thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo resolute men, well acquainted with these northern wilds, and\r\nskilful in tracking the tread of man and horse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thou hast fitted him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet your grace never trust me else,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the master of the spies.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne is from Hexamshire; he is wont to trace the Tynedale and\r\nTeviotdale thieves, as a bloodhound follows the slot of a hurt deer.\r\nThe other is Yorkshire bred, and has twanged his bowstring right oft in\r\nmerry Sherwood; he knows each glade and dingle, copse and high-wood,\r\nbetwixt this and Richmond.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prince.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cGoes Waldemar forth with them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstantly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bardon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith what attendance?\xe2\x80\x9d asked John, carelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBroad Thoresby goes with him, and Wetheral, whom they call, for his\r\ncruelty, Stephen Steel-heart; and three northern men-at-arms that\r\nbelonged to Ralph Middleton\xe2\x80\x99s gang\xe2\x80\x94they are called the Spears of\r\nSpyinghow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John; then added, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s pause,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBardon, it imports our service that thou keep a strict watch on\r\nMaurice De Bracy\xe2\x80\x94so that he shall not observe it, however\xe2\x80\x94And let us\r\nknow of his motions from time to time\xe2\x80\x94with whom he converses, what he\r\nproposeth. Fail not in this, as thou wilt be answerable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHugh Bardon bowed, and retired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Maurice betrays me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Prince John\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cif he betrays me, as his\r\nbearing leads me to fear, I will have his head, were Richard thundering\r\nat the gates of York.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXV\r\n\r\n\r\nArouse the tiger of Hyrcanian deserts,\r\nStrive with the half-starved lion for his prey;\r\nLesser the risk, than rouse the slumbering fire\r\nOf wild Fanaticism.\r\n\r\n\r\nANONYMUS\r\n\r\n\r\nOur tale now returns to Isaac of York.\xe2\x80\x94Mounted upon a mule, the gift of\r\nthe Outlaw, with two tall yeomen to act as his guard and guides, the\r\nJew had set out for the Preceptory of Templestowe, for the purpose of\r\nnegotiating his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s redemption. The Preceptory was but a day\xe2\x80\x99s\r\njourney from the demolished castle of Torquilstone, and the Jew had\r\nhoped to reach it before nightfall; accordingly, having dismissed his\r\nguides at the verge of the forest, and rewarded them with a piece of\r\nsilver, he began to press on with such speed as his weariness permitted\r\nhim to exert. But his strength failed him totally ere he had reached\r\nwithin four miles of the Temple-Court; racking pains shot along his\r\nback and through his limbs, and the excessive anguish which he felt at\r\nheart being now augmented by bodily suffering, he was rendered\r\naltogether incapable of proceeding farther than a small market-town,\r\nwere dwelt a Jewish Rabbi of his tribe, eminent in the medical\r\nprofession, and to whom Isaac was well known. Nathan Ben Israel\r\nreceived his suffering countryman with that kindness which the law\r\nprescribed, and which the Jews practised to each other. He insisted on\r\nhis betaking himself to repose, and used such remedies as were then in\r\nmost repute to check the progress of the fever, which terror, fatigue,\r\nill usage, and sorrow, had brought upon the poor old Jew.\r\n\r\nOn the morrow, when Isaac proposed to arise and pursue his journey,\r\nNathan remonstrated against his purpose, both as his host and as his\r\nphysician. It might cost him, he said, his life. But Isaac replied,\r\nthat more than life and death depended upon his going that morning to\r\nTemplestowe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Templestowe!\xe2\x80\x9d said his host with surprise again felt his pulse, and\r\nthen muttered to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cHis fever is abated, yet seems his mind\r\nsomewhat alienated and disturbed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why not to Templestowe?\xe2\x80\x9d answered his patient. \xe2\x80\x9cI grant thee,\r\nNathan, that it is a dwelling of those to whom the despised Children of\r\nthe Promise are a stumbling-block and an abomination; yet thou knowest\r\nthat pressing affairs of traffic sometimes carry us among these\r\nbloodthirsty Nazarene soldiers, and that we visit the Preceptories of\r\nthe Templars, as well as the Commanderies of the Knights Hospitallers,\r\nas they are called.\xe2\x80\x9d 48\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nathan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut wottest thou that Lucas de\r\nBeaumanoir, the chief of their Order, and whom they term Grand Master,\r\nis now himself at Templestowe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac; \xe2\x80\x9cour last letters from our brethren at\r\nParis advised us that he was at that city, beseeching Philip for aid\r\nagainst the Sultan Saladine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe hath since come to England, unexpected by his brethren,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben\r\nIsrael; \xe2\x80\x9cand he cometh among them with a strong and outstretched arm to\r\ncorrect and to punish. His countenance is kindled in anger against\r\nthose who have departed from the vow which they have made, and great is\r\nthe fear of those sons of Belial. Thou must have heard of his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well known unto me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac; \xe2\x80\x9cthe Gentiles deliver this\r\nLucas Beaumanoir as a man zealous to slaying for every point of the\r\nNazarene law; and our brethren have termed him a fierce destroyer of\r\nthe Saracens, and a cruel tyrant to the Children of the Promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd truly have they termed him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nathan the physician. \xe2\x80\x9cOther\r\nTemplars may be moved from the purpose of their heart by pleasure, or\r\nbribed by promise of gold and silver; but Beaumanoir is of a different\r\nstamp\xe2\x80\x94hating sensuality, despising treasure, and pressing forward to\r\nthat which they call the crown of martyrdom\xe2\x80\x94The God of Jacob speedily\r\nsend it unto him, and unto them all! Specially hath this proud man\r\nextended his glove over the children of Judah, as holy David over Edom,\r\nholding the murder of a Jew to be an offering of as sweet savour as the\r\ndeath of a Saracen. Impious and false things has he said even of the\r\nvirtues of our medicines, as if they were the devices of Satan\xe2\x80\x94The Lord\r\nrebuke him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cI must present myself at Templestowe,\r\nthough he hath made his face like unto a fiery furnace seven times\r\nheated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then explained to Nathan the pressing cause of his journey. The\r\nRabbi listened with interest, and testified his sympathy after the\r\nfashion of his people, rending his clothes, and saying, \xe2\x80\x9cAh, my\r\ndaughter!\xe2\x80\x94ah, my daughter!\xe2\x80\x94Alas! for the beauty of Zion!\xe2\x80\x94Alas! for the\r\ncaptivity of Israel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou seest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9chow it stands with me, and that I may not\r\ntarry. Peradventure, the presence of this Lucas Beaumanoir, being the\r\nchief man over them, may turn Brian de Bois-Guilbert from the ill which\r\nhe doth meditate, and that he may deliver to me my beloved daughter\r\nRebecca.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo thou,\xe2\x80\x9d said Nathan Ben Israel, \xe2\x80\x9cand be wise, for wisdom availed\r\nDaniel in the den of lions into which he was cast; and may it go well\r\nwith thee, even as thine heart wisheth. Yet, if thou canst, keep thee\r\nfrom the presence of the Grand Master, for to do foul scorn to our\r\npeople is his morning and evening delight. It may be if thou couldst\r\nspeak with Bois-Guilbert in private, thou shalt the better prevail with\r\nhim; for men say that these accursed Nazarenes are not of one mind in\r\nthe Preceptory\xe2\x80\x94May their counsels be confounded and brought to shame!\r\nBut do thou, brother, return to me as if it were to the house of thy\r\nfather, and bring me word how it has sped with thee; and well do I hope\r\nthou wilt bring with thee Rebecca, even the scholar of the wise Miriam,\r\nwhose cures the Gentiles slandered as if they had been wrought by\r\nnecromancy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIsaac accordingly bade his friend farewell, and about an hour\xe2\x80\x99s riding\r\nbrought him before the Preceptory of Templestowe.\r\n\r\nThis establishment of the Templars was seated amidst fair meadows and\r\npastures, which the devotion of the former Preceptor had bestowed upon\r\ntheir Order. It was strong and well fortified, a point never neglected\r\nby these knights, and which the disordered state of England rendered\r\npeculiarly necessary. Two halberdiers, clad in black, guarded the\r\ndrawbridge, and others, in the same sad livery, glided to and fro upon\r\nthe walls with a funereal pace, resembling spectres more than soldiers.\r\nThe inferior officers of the Order were thus dressed, ever since their\r\nuse of white garments, similar to those of the knights and esquires,\r\nhad given rise to a combination of certain false brethren in the\r\nmountains of Palestine, terming themselves Templars, and bringing great\r\ndishonour on the Order. A knight was now and then seen to cross the\r\ncourt in his long white cloak, his head depressed on his breast, and\r\nhis arms folded. They passed each other, if they chanced to meet, with\r\na slow, solemn, and mute greeting; for such was the rule of their\r\nOrder, quoting thereupon the holy texts, \xe2\x80\x9cIn many words thou shalt not\r\navoid sin,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cLife and death are in the power of the tongue.\xe2\x80\x9d In a\r\nword, the stern ascetic rigour of the Temple discipline, which had been\r\nso long exchanged for prodigal and licentious indulgence, seemed at\r\nonce to have revived at Templestowe under the severe eye of Lucas\r\nBeaumanoir.\r\n\r\nIsaac paused at the gate, to consider how he might seek entrance in the\r\nmanner most likely to bespeak favour; for he was well aware, that to\r\nhis unhappy race the reviving fanaticism of the Order was not less\r\ndangerous than their unprincipled licentiousness; and that his religion\r\nwould be the object of hate and persecution in the one case, as his\r\nwealth would have exposed him in the other to the extortions of\r\nunrelenting oppression.\r\n\r\nMeantime Lucas Beaumanoir walked in a small garden belonging to the\r\nPreceptory, included within the precincts of its exterior\r\nfortification, and held sad and confidential communication with a\r\nbrother of his Order, who had come in his company from Palestine.\r\n\r\nThe Grand Master was a man advanced in age, as was testified by his\r\nlong grey beard, and the shaggy grey eyebrows overhanging eyes, of\r\nwhich, however, years had been unable to quench the fire. A formidable\r\nwarrior, his thin and severe features retained the soldier\xe2\x80\x99s fierceness\r\nof expression; an ascetic bigot, they were no less marked by the\r\nemaciation of abstinence, and the spiritual pride of the self-satisfied\r\ndevotee. Yet with these severer traits of physiognomy, there was mixed\r\nsomewhat striking and noble, arising, doubtless, from the great part\r\nwhich his high office called upon him to act among monarchs and\r\nprinces, and from the habitual exercise of supreme authority over the\r\nvaliant and high-born knights, who were united by the rules of the\r\nOrder. His stature was tall, and his gait, undepressed by age and toil,\r\nwas erect and stately. His white mantle was shaped with severe\r\nregularity, according to the rule of Saint Bernard himself, being\r\ncomposed of what was then called Burrel cloth, exactly fitted to the\r\nsize of the wearer, and bearing on the left shoulder the octangular\r\ncross peculiar to the Order, formed of red cloth. No vair or ermine\r\ndecked this garment; but in respect of his age, the Grand Master, as\r\npermitted by the rules, wore his doublet lined and trimmed with the\r\nsoftest lambskin, dressed with the wool outwards, which was the nearest\r\napproach he could regularly make to the use of fur, then the greatest\r\nluxury of dress. In his hand he bore that singular \xe2\x80\x9cabacus\xe2\x80\x9d, or staff\r\nof office, with which Templars are usually represented, having at the\r\nupper end a round plate, on which was engraved the cross of the Order,\r\ninscribed within a circle or orle, as heralds term it. His companion,\r\nwho attended on this great personage, had nearly the same dress in all\r\nrespects, but his extreme deference towards his Superior showed that no\r\nother equality subsisted between them. The Preceptor, for such he was\r\nin rank, walked not in a line with the Grand Master, but just so far\r\nbehind that Beaumanoir could speak to him without turning round his\r\nhead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConrade,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cdear companion of my battles and my\r\ntoils, to thy faithful bosom alone I can confide my sorrows. To thee\r\nalone can I tell how oft, since I came to this kingdom, I have desired\r\nto be dissolved and to be with the just. Not one object in England hath\r\nmet mine eye which it could rest upon with pleasure, save the tombs of\r\nour brethren, beneath the massive roof of our Temple Church in yonder\r\nproud capital. O, valiant Robert de Ros! did I exclaim internally, as I\r\ngazed upon these good soldiers of the cross, where they lie sculptured\r\non their sepulchres,\xe2\x80\x94O, worthy William de Mareschal! open your marble\r\ncells, and take to your repose a weary brother, who would rather strive\r\nwith a hundred thousand pagans than witness the decay of our Holy\r\nOrder!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is but true,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Conrade Mont-Fitchet; \xe2\x80\x9cit is but too true;\r\nand the irregularities of our brethren in England are even more gross\r\nthan those in France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause they are more wealthy,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Grand Master. \xe2\x80\x9cBear with\r\nme, brother, although I should something vaunt myself. Thou knowest the\r\nlife I have led, keeping each point of my Order, striving with devils\r\nembodied and disembodied, striking down the roaring lion, who goeth\r\nabout seeking whom he may devour, like a good knight and devout priest,\r\nwheresoever I met with him\xe2\x80\x94even as blessed Saint Bernard hath\r\nprescribed to us in the forty-fifth capital of our rule, \xe2\x80\x98Ut Leo semper\r\nferiatur\xe2\x80\x99. 49\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut by the Holy Temple! the zeal which hath devoured my substance and\r\nmy life, yea, the very nerves and marrow of my bones; by that very Holy\r\nTemple I swear to thee, that save thyself and some few that still\r\nretain the ancient severity of our Order, I look upon no brethren whom\r\nI can bring my soul to embrace under that holy name. What say our\r\nstatutes, and how do our brethren observe them? They should wear no\r\nvain or worldly ornament, no crest upon their helmet, no gold upon\r\nstirrup or bridle-bit; yet who now go pranked out so proudly and so\r\ngaily as the poor soldiers of the Temple? They are forbidden by our\r\nstatutes to take one bird by means of another, to shoot beasts with bow\r\nor arblast, to halloo to a hunting-horn, or to spur the horse after\r\ngame. But now, at hunting and hawking, and each idle sport of wood and\r\nriver, who so prompt as the Templars in all these fond vanities? They\r\nare forbidden to read, save what their Superior permitted, or listen to\r\nwhat is read, save such holy things as may be recited aloud during the\r\nhours of refaction; but lo! their ears are at the command of idle\r\nminstrels, and their eyes study empty romaunts. They were commanded to\r\nextirpate magic and heresy. Lo! they are charged with studying the\r\naccursed cabalistical secrets of the Jews, and the magic of the Paynim\r\nSaracens. Simpleness of diet was prescribed to them, roots, pottage,\r\ngruels, eating flesh but thrice a-week, because the accustomed feeding\r\non flesh is a dishonourable corruption of the body; and behold, their\r\ntables groan under delicate fare! Their drink was to be water, and now,\r\nto drink like a Templar, is the boast of each jolly boon companion!\r\nThis very garden, filled as it is with curious herbs and trees sent\r\nfrom the Eastern climes, better becomes the harem of an unbelieving\r\nEmir, than the plot which Christian Monks should devote to raise their\r\nhomely pot-herbs.\xe2\x80\x94And O, Conrade! well it were that the relaxation of\r\ndiscipline stopped even here!\xe2\x80\x94Well thou knowest that we were forbidden\r\nto receive those devout women, who at the beginning were associated as\r\nsisters of our Order, because, saith the forty-sixth chapter, the\r\nAncient Enemy hath, by female society, withdrawn many from the right\r\npath to paradise. Nay, in the last capital, being, as it were, the\r\ncope-stone which our blessed founder placed on the pure and undefiled\r\ndoctrine which he had enjoined, we are prohibited from offering, even\r\nto our sisters and our mothers, the kiss of affection\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98ut omnium\r\nmulierum fugiantur oscula\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x94I shame to speak\xe2\x80\x94I shame to think\xe2\x80\x94of the\r\ncorruptions which have rushed in upon us even like a flood. The souls\r\nof our pure founders, the spirits of Hugh de Payen and Godfrey de Saint\r\nOmer, and of the blessed Seven who first joined in dedicating their\r\nlives to the service of the Temple, are disturbed even in the enjoyment\r\nof paradise itself. I have seen them, Conrade, in the visions of the\r\nnight\xe2\x80\x94their sainted eyes shed tears for the sins and follies of their\r\nbrethren, and for the foul and shameful luxury in which they wallow.\r\nBeaumanoir, they say, thou slumberest\xe2\x80\x94awake! There is a stain in the\r\nfabric of the Temple, deep and foul as that left by the streaks of\r\nleprosy on the walls of the infected houses of old. 50\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe soldiers of the Cross, who should shun the glance of a woman as\r\nthe eye of a basilisk, live in open sin, not with the females of their\r\nown race only, but with the daughters of the accursed heathen, and more\r\naccursed Jew. Beaumanoir, thou sleepest; up, and avenge our cause!\xe2\x80\x94Slay\r\nthe sinners, male and female!\xe2\x80\x94Take to thee the brand of Phineas!\xe2\x80\x94The\r\nvision fled, Conrade, but as I awaked I could still hear the clank of\r\ntheir mail, and see the waving of their white mantles.\xe2\x80\x94And I will do\r\naccording to their word, I WILL purify the fabric of the Temple! and\r\nthe unclean stones in which the plague is, I will remove and cast out\r\nof the building.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet bethink thee, reverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mont-Fitchet, \xe2\x80\x9cthe stain hath\r\nbecome engrained by time and consuetude; let thy reformation be\r\ncautious, as it is just and wise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mont-Fitchet,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the stern old man\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit must be sharp and\r\nsudden\xe2\x80\x94the Order is on the crisis of its fate. The sobriety,\r\nself-devotion, and piety of our predecessors, made us powerful\r\nfriends\xe2\x80\x94our presumption, our wealth, our luxury, have raised up against\r\nus mighty enemies.\xe2\x80\x94We must cast away these riches, which are a\r\ntemptation to princes\xe2\x80\x94we must lay down that presumption, which is an\r\noffence to them\xe2\x80\x94we must reform that license of manners, which is a\r\nscandal to the whole Christian world! Or\xe2\x80\x94mark my words\xe2\x80\x94the Order of the\r\nTemple will be utterly demolished\xe2\x80\x94and the Place thereof shall no more\r\nbe known among the nations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow may God avert such a calamity!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, with solemnity, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we must deserve his\r\naid. I tell thee, Conrade, that neither the powers in Heaven, nor the\r\npowers on earth, will longer endure the wickedness of this\r\ngeneration\xe2\x80\x94My intelligence is sure\xe2\x80\x94the ground on which our fabric is\r\nreared is already undermined, and each addition we make to the\r\nstructure of our greatness will only sink it the sooner in the abyss.\r\nWe must retrace our steps, and show ourselves the faithful Champions of\r\nthe Cross, sacrificing to our calling, not alone our blood and our\r\nlives\xe2\x80\x94not alone our lusts and our vices\xe2\x80\x94but our ease, our comforts, and\r\nour natural affections, and act as men convinced that many a pleasure\r\nwhich may be lawful to others, is forbidden to the vowed soldier of the\r\nTemple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment a squire, clothed in a threadbare vestment, (for the\r\naspirants after this holy Order wore during their noviciate the\r\ncast-off garments of the knights,) entered the garden, and, bowing\r\nprofoundly before the Grand Master, stood silent, awaiting his\r\npermission ere he presumed to tell his errand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it not more seemly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cto see this Damian,\r\nclothed in the garments of Christian humility, thus appear with\r\nreverend silence before his Superior, than but two days since, when the\r\nfond fool was decked in a painted coat, and jangling as pert and as\r\nproud as any popinjay?\xe2\x80\x94Speak, Damian, we permit thee\xe2\x80\x94What is thine\r\nerrand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Jew stands without the gate, noble and reverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nSquire, \xe2\x80\x9cwho prays to speak with brother Brian de Bois-Guilbert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou wert right to give me knowledge of it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cin our presence a Preceptor is but as a common compeer of our Order,\r\nwho may not walk according to his own will, but to that of his\r\nMaster\xe2\x80\x94even according to the text, \xe2\x80\x98In the hearing of the ear he hath\r\nobeyed me.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94It imports us especially to know of this Bois-Guilbert\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nproceedings,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, turning to his companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReport speaks him brave and valiant,\xe2\x80\x9d said Conrade.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd truly is he so spoken of,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master; \xe2\x80\x9cin our valour\r\nonly we are not degenerated from our predecessors, the heroes of the\r\nCross. But brother Brian came into our Order a moody and disappointed\r\nman, stirred, I doubt me, to take our vows and to renounce the world,\r\nnot in sincerity of soul, but as one whom some touch of light\r\ndiscontent had driven into penitence. Since then, he hath become an\r\nactive and earnest agitator, a murmurer, and a machinator, and a leader\r\namongst those who impugn our authority; not considering that the rule\r\nis given to the Master even by the symbol of the staff and the rod\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nstaff to support the infirmities of the weak\xe2\x80\x94the rod to correct the\r\nfaults of delinquents.\xe2\x80\x94Damian,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9clead the Jew to our\r\npresence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe squire departed with a profound reverence, and in a few minutes\r\nreturned, marshalling in Isaac of York. No naked slave, ushered into\r\nthe presence of some mighty prince, could approach his judgment-seat\r\nwith more profound reverence and terror than that with which the Jew\r\ndrew near to the presence of the Grand Master. When he had approached\r\nwithin the distance of three yards, Beaumanoir made a sign with his\r\nstaff that he should come no farther. The Jew kneeled down on the earth\r\nwhich he kissed in token of reverence; then rising, stood before the\r\nTemplars, his hands folded on his bosom, his head bowed on his breast,\r\nin all the submission of Oriental slavery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamian,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cretire, and have a guard ready to\r\nawait our sudden call; and suffer no one to enter the garden until we\r\nshall leave it.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94The squire bowed and retreated.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cJew,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the\r\nhaughty old man, \xe2\x80\x9cmark me. It suits not our condition to hold with thee\r\nlong communication, nor do we waste words or time upon any one.\r\nWherefore be brief in thy answers to what questions I shall ask thee,\r\nand let thy words be of truth; for if thy tongue doubles with me, I\r\nwill have it torn from thy misbelieving jaws.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew was about to reply, but the Grand Master went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace, unbeliever!\xe2\x80\x94not a word in our presence, save in answer to our\r\nquestions.\xe2\x80\x94What is thy business with our brother Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIsaac gasped with terror and uncertainty. To tell his tale might be\r\ninterpreted into scandalizing the Order; yet, unless he told it, what\r\nhope could he have of achieving his daughter\xe2\x80\x99s deliverance? Beaumanoir\r\nsaw his mortal apprehension, and condescended to give him some\r\nassurance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cfor thy wretched person, Jew, so thou dealest\r\nuprightly in this matter.
