I demand again to know from thee thy business\r\nwith Brian de Bois-Guilbert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am bearer of a letter,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered out the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cso please your\r\nreverend valour, to that good knight, from Prior Aymer of the Abbey of\r\nJorvaulx.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaid I not these were evil times, Conrade?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Master. \xe2\x80\x9cA\r\nCistertian Prior sends a letter to a soldier of the Temple, and can\r\nfind no more fitting messenger than an unbelieving Jew.\xe2\x80\x94Give me the\r\nletter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jew, with trembling hands, undid the folds of his Armenian cap, in\r\nwhich he had deposited the Prior\xe2\x80\x99s tablets for the greater security,\r\nand was about to approach, with hand extended and body crouched, to\r\nplace it within the reach of his grim interrogator.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBack, dog!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master; \xe2\x80\x9cI touch not misbelievers, save\r\nwith the sword.\xe2\x80\x94Conrade, take thou the letter from the Jew, and give it\r\nto me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeaumanoir, being thus possessed of the tablets, inspected the outside\r\ncarefully, and then proceeded to undo the packthread which secured its\r\nfolds. \xe2\x80\x9cReverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Conrade, interposing, though with much\r\ndeference, \xe2\x80\x9cwilt thou break the seal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd will I not?\xe2\x80\x9d said Beaumanoir, with a frown. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it not written in\r\nthe forty-second capital, \xe2\x80\x98De Lectione Literarum\xe2\x80\x99 that a Templar shall\r\nnot receive a letter, no not from his father, without communicating the\r\nsame to the Grand Master, and reading it in his presence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then perused the letter in haste, with an expression of surprise and\r\nhorror; read it over again more slowly; then holding it out to Conrade\r\nwith one hand, and slightly striking it with the other, exclaimed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHere\r\nis goodly stuff for one Christian man to write to another, and both\r\nmembers, and no inconsiderable members, of religious professions!\r\nWhen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he solemnly, and looking upward, \xe2\x80\x9cwilt thou come with thy\r\nfanners to purge the thrashing-floor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMont-Fitchet took the letter from his Superior, and was about to peruse\r\nit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead it aloud, Conrade,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cand do thou\xe2\x80\x9d (to\r\nIsaac) \xe2\x80\x9cattend to the purport of it, for we will question thee\r\nconcerning it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nConrade read the letter, which was in these words: \xe2\x80\x9cAymer, by divine\r\ngrace, Prior of the Cistertian house of Saint Mary\xe2\x80\x99s of Jorvaulx, to\r\nSir Brian de Bois-Guilbert, a Knight of the holy Order of the Temple,\r\nwisheth health, with the bounties of King Bacchus and of my Lady Venus.\r\nTouching our present condition, dear Brother, we are a captive in the\r\nhands of certain lawless and godless men, who have not feared to detain\r\nour person, and put us to ransom; whereby we have also learned of\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x99s misfortune, and that thou hast escaped with that fair\r\nJewish sorceress, whose black eyes have bewitched thee. We are heartily\r\nrejoiced of thy safety; nevertheless, we pray thee to be on thy guard\r\nin the matter of this second Witch of Endor; for we are privately\r\nassured that your Great Master, who careth not a bean for cherry cheeks\r\nand black eyes, comes from Normandy to diminish your mirth, and amend\r\nyour misdoings. Wherefore we pray you heartily to beware, and to be\r\nfound watching, even as the Holy Text hath it, \xe2\x80\x98Invenientur\r\nvigilantes\xe2\x80\x99. And the wealthy Jew her father, Isaac of York, having\r\nprayed of me letters in his behalf, I gave him these, earnestly\r\nadvising, and in a sort entreating, that you do hold the damsel to\r\nransom, seeing he will pay you from his bags as much as may find fifty\r\ndamsels upon safer terms, whereof I trust to have my part when we make\r\nmerry together, as true brothers, not forgetting the wine-cup. For what\r\nsaith the text, \xe2\x80\x98Vinum laetificat cor hominis\xe2\x80\x99; and again, \xe2\x80\x98Rex\r\ndelectabitur pulchritudine tua\xe2\x80\x99.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill which merry meeting, we wish you farewell. Given from this den of\r\nthieves, about the hour of matins,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAymer Pr. S. M. Jorvolciencis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Postscriptum.\xe2\x80\x99 Truly your golden chain hath not long abidden with me,\r\nand will now sustain, around the neck of an outlaw deer-stealer, the\r\nwhistle wherewith he calleth on his hounds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sayest thou to this, Conrade?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDen of\r\nthieves! and a fit residence is a den of thieves for such a Prior. No\r\nwonder that the hand of God is upon us, and that in the Holy Land we\r\nlose place by place, foot by foot, before the infidels, when we have\r\nsuch churchmen as this Aymer.\xe2\x80\x94And what meaneth he, I trow, by this\r\nsecond Witch of Endor?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to his confident, something apart.\r\nConrade was better acquainted (perhaps by practice) with the jargon of\r\ngallantry, than was his Superior; and he expounded the passage which\r\nembarrassed the Grand Master, to be a sort of language used by worldly\r\nmen towards those whom they loved \xe2\x80\x98par amours\xe2\x80\x99; but the explanation did\r\nnot satisfy the bigoted Beaumanoir.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is more in it than thou dost guess, Conrade; thy simplicity is\r\nno match for this deep abyss of wickedness. This Rebecca of York was a\r\npupil of that Miriam of whom thou hast heard. Thou shalt hear the Jew\r\nown it even now.\xe2\x80\x9d Then turning to Isaac, he said aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cThy daughter,\r\nthen, is prisoner with Brian de Bois-Guilbert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, reverend valorous sir,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered poor Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cand whatsoever\r\nransom a poor man may pay for her deliverance\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master. \xe2\x80\x9cThis thy daughter hath practised the\r\nart of healing, hath she not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, gracious sir,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jew, with more confidence; \xe2\x80\x9cand knight\r\nand yeoman, squire and vassal, may bless the goodly gift which Heaven\r\nhath assigned to her. Many a one can testify that she hath recovered\r\nthem by her art, when every other human aid hath proved vain; but the\r\nblessing of the God of Jacob was upon her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBeaumanoir turned to Mont-Fitchet with a grim smile. \xe2\x80\x9cSee, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cthe deceptions of the devouring Enemy! Behold the baits with\r\nwhich he fishes for souls, giving a poor space of earthly life in\r\nexchange for eternal happiness hereafter. Well said our blessed rule,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Semper percutiatur leo vorans\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x94Up on the lion! Down with the\r\ndestroyer!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, shaking aloft his mystic abacus, as if in defiance\r\nof the powers of darkness\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThy daughter worketh the cures, I doubt\r\nnot,\xe2\x80\x9d thus he went on to address the Jew, \xe2\x80\x9cby words and sighs, and\r\nperiapts, and other cabalistical mysteries.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, reverend and brave Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cbut in chief measure\r\nby a balsam of marvellous virtue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere had she that secret?\xe2\x80\x9d said Beaumanoir.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was delivered to her,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Isaac, reluctantly, \xe2\x80\x9cby Miriam, a\r\nsage matron of our tribe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, false Jew!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master; \xe2\x80\x9cwas it not from that same\r\nwitch Miriam, the abomination of whose enchantments have been heard of\r\nthroughout every Christian land?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Grand Master, crossing\r\nhimself. \xe2\x80\x9cHer body was burnt at a stake, and her ashes were scattered\r\nto the four winds; and so be it with me and mine Order, if I do not as\r\nmuch to her pupil, and more also! I will teach her to throw spell and\r\nincantation over the soldiers of the blessed Temple.\xe2\x80\x94There, Damian,\r\nspurn this Jew from the gate\xe2\x80\x94shoot him dead if he oppose or turn again.\r\nWith his daughter we will deal as the Christian law and our own high\r\noffice warrant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor Isaac was hurried off accordingly, and expelled from the\r\npreceptory; all his entreaties, and even his offers, unheard and\r\ndisregarded. He could do not better than return to the house of the\r\nRabbi, and endeavour, through his means, to learn how his daughter was\r\nto be disposed of. He had hitherto feared for her honour, he was now to\r\ntremble for her life. Meanwhile, the Grand Master ordered to his\r\npresence the Preceptor of Templestowe.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVI\r\n\r\n\r\nSay not my art is fraud\xe2\x80\x94all live by seeming.\r\nThe beggar begs with it, and the gay courtier\r\nGains land and title, rank and rule, by seeming;\r\nThe clergy scorn it not, and the bold soldier\r\nWill eke with it his service.\xe2\x80\x94All admit it,\r\nAll practise it; and he who is content\r\nWith showing what he is, shall have small credit\r\nIn church, or camp, or state\xe2\x80\x94So wags the world.\r\n\r\n\r\nOLD PLAY\r\n\r\n\r\nAlbert Malvoisin, President, or, in the language of the Order,\r\nPreceptor of the establishment of Templestowe, was brother to that\r\nPhilip Malvoisin who has been already occasionally mentioned in this\r\nhistory, and was, like that baron, in close league with Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert.\r\n\r\nAmongst dissolute and unprincipled men, of whom the Temple Order\r\nincluded but too many, Albert of Templestowe might be distinguished;\r\nbut with this difference from the audacious Bois-Guilbert, that he knew\r\nhow to throw over his vices and his ambition the veil of hypocrisy, and\r\nto assume in his exterior the fanaticism which he internally despised.\r\nHad not the arrival of the Grand Master been so unexpectedly sudden, he\r\nwould have seen nothing at Templestowe which might have appeared to\r\nargue any relaxation of discipline. And, even although surprised, and,\r\nto a certain extent, detected, Albert Malvoisin listened with such\r\nrespect and apparent contrition to the rebuke of his Superior, and made\r\nsuch haste to reform the particulars he censured,\xe2\x80\x94succeeded, in fine,\r\nso well in giving an air of ascetic devotion to a family which had been\r\nlately devoted to license and pleasure, that Lucas Beaumanoir began to\r\nentertain a higher opinion of the Preceptor\xe2\x80\x99s morals, than the first\r\nappearance of the establishment had inclined him to adopt.\r\n\r\nBut these favourable sentiments on the part of the Grand Master were\r\ngreatly shaken by the intelligence that Albert had received within a\r\nhouse of religion the Jewish captive, and, as was to be feared, the\r\nparamour of a brother of the Order; and when Albert appeared before\r\nhim, he was regarded with unwonted sternness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is in this mansion, dedicated to the purposes of the holy Order\r\nof the Temple,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, in a severe tone, \xe2\x80\x9ca Jewish\r\nwoman, brought hither by a brother of religion, by your connivance, Sir\r\nPreceptor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert Malvoisin was overwhelmed with confusion; for the unfortunate\r\nRebecca had been confined in a remote and secret part of the building,\r\nand every precaution used to prevent her residence there from being\r\nknown. He read in the looks of Beaumanoir ruin to Bois-Guilbert and to\r\nhimself, unless he should be able to avert the impending storm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you mute?\xe2\x80\x9d continued the Grand Master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it permitted to me to reply?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Preceptor, in a tone of\r\nthe deepest humility, although by the question he only meant to gain an\r\ninstant\xe2\x80\x99s space for arranging his ideas.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, you are permitted,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cspeak, and say,\r\nknowest thou the capital of our holy rule,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98De commilitonibus Templi in\r\nsancta civitate, qui cum miserrimis mulieribus versantur, propter\r\noblectationem carnis?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d 51\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely, most reverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Preceptor, \xe2\x80\x9cI have not\r\nrisen to this office in the Order, being ignorant of one of its most\r\nimportant prohibitions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow comes it, then, I demand of thee once more, that thou hast\r\nsuffered a brother to bring a paramour, and that paramour a Jewish\r\nsorceress, into this holy place, to the stain and pollution thereof?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Jewish sorceress!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Albert Malvoisin; \xe2\x80\x9cgood angels guard us!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, brother, a Jewish sorceress!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, sternly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nhave said it. Darest thou deny that this Rebecca, the daughter of that\r\nwretched usurer Isaac of York, and the pupil of the foul witch Miriam,\r\nis now\xe2\x80\x94shame to be thought or spoken!\xe2\x80\x94lodged within this thy\r\nPreceptory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour wisdom, reverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Preceptor, \xe2\x80\x9chath rolled\r\naway the darkness from my understanding. Much did I wonder that so good\r\na knight as Brian de Bois-Guilbert seemed so fondly besotted on the\r\ncharms of this female, whom I received into this house merely to place\r\na bar betwixt their growing intimacy, which else might have been\r\ncemented at the expense of the fall of our valiant and religious\r\nbrother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHath nothing, then, as yet passed betwixt them in breach of his vow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ndemanded the Grand Master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! under this roof?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor, crossing himself; \xe2\x80\x9cSaint\r\nMagdalene and the ten thousand virgins forbid!\xe2\x80\x94No! if I have sinned in\r\nreceiving her here, it was in the erring thought that I might thus\r\nbreak off our brother\xe2\x80\x99s besotted devotion to this Jewess, which seemed\r\nto me so wild and unnatural, that I could not but ascribe it to some\r\ntouch of insanity, more to be cured by pity than reproof. But since\r\nyour reverend wisdom hath discovered this Jewish queen to be a\r\nsorceress, perchance it may account fully for his enamoured folly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt doth!\xe2\x80\x94it doth!\xe2\x80\x9d said Beaumanoir. \xe2\x80\x9cSee, brother Conrade, the peril\r\nof yielding to the first devices and blandishments of Satan! We look\r\nupon woman only to gratify the lust of the eye, and to take pleasure in\r\nwhat men call her beauty; and the Ancient Enemy, the devouring Lion,\r\nobtains power over us, to complete, by talisman and spell, a work which\r\nwas begun by idleness and folly. It may be that our brother\r\nBois-Guilbert does in this matter deserve rather pity than severe\r\nchastisement; rather the support of the staff, than the strokes of the\r\nrod; and that our admonitions and prayers may turn him from his folly,\r\nand restore him to his brethren.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt were deep pity,\xe2\x80\x9d said Conrade Mont-Fitchet, \xe2\x80\x9cto lose to the Order\r\none of its best lances, when the Holy Community most requires the aid\r\nof its sons. Three hundred Saracens hath this Brian de Bois-Guilbert\r\nslain with his own hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe blood of these accursed dogs,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cshall be a\r\nsweet and acceptable offering to the saints and angels whom they\r\ndespise and blaspheme; and with their aid will we counteract the spells\r\nand charms with which our brother is entwined as in a net. He shall\r\nburst the bands of this Delilah, as Sampson burst the two new cords\r\nwith which the Philistines had bound him, and shall slaughter the\r\ninfidels, even heaps upon heaps. But concerning this foul witch, who\r\nhath flung her enchantments over a brother of the Holy Temple,\r\nassuredly she shall die the death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the laws of England,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said the Preceptor, who, though delighted\r\nthat the Grand Master\xe2\x80\x99s resentment, thus fortunately averted from\r\nhimself and Bois-Guilbert, had taken another direction, began now to\r\nfear he was carrying it too far.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe laws of England,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Beaumanoir, \xe2\x80\x9cpermit and enjoin each\r\njudge to execute justice within his own jurisdiction. The most petty\r\nbaron may arrest, try, and condemn a witch found within his own domain.\r\nAnd shall that power be denied to the Grand Master of the Temple within\r\na preceptory of his Order?\xe2\x80\x94No!\xe2\x80\x94we will judge and condemn. The witch\r\nshall be taken out of the land, and the wickedness thereof shall be\r\nforgiven. Prepare the Castle-hall for the trial of the sorceress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert Malvoisin bowed and retired,\xe2\x80\x94not to give directions for\r\npreparing the hall, but to seek out Brian de Bois-Guilbert, and\r\ncommunicate to him how matters were likely to terminate. It was not\r\nlong ere he found him, foaming with indignation at a repulse he had\r\nanew sustained from the fair Jewess. \xe2\x80\x9cThe unthinking,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nungrateful, to scorn him who, amidst blood and flames, would have saved\r\nher life at the risk of his own! By Heaven, Malvoisin! I abode until\r\nroof and rafters crackled and crashed around me. I was the butt of a\r\nhundred arrows; they rattled on mine armour like hailstones against a\r\nlatticed casement, and the only use I made of my shield was for her\r\nprotection. This did I endure for her; and now the self-willed girl\r\nupbraids me that I did not leave her to perish, and refuses me not only\r\nthe slightest proof of gratitude, but even the most distant hope that\r\never she will be brought to grant any. The devil, that possessed her\r\nrace with obstinacy, has concentrated its full force in her single\r\nperson!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor, \xe2\x80\x9cI think, possessed you both. How oft\r\nhave I preached to you caution, if not continence? Did I not tell you\r\nthat there were enough willing Christian damsels to be met with, who\r\nwould think it sin to refuse so brave a knight \xe2\x80\x98le don d\xe2\x80\x99amoureux\r\nmerci\xe2\x80\x99, and you must needs anchor your affection on a wilful, obstinate\r\nJewess! By the mass, I think old Lucas Beaumanoir guesses right, when\r\nhe maintains she hath cast a spell over you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLucas Beaumanoir!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said Bois-Guilbert reproachfully\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAre these your\r\nprecautions, Malvoisin? Hast thou suffered the dotard to learn that\r\nRebecca is in the Preceptory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow could I help it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor. \xe2\x80\x9cI neglected nothing that\r\ncould keep secret your mystery; but it is betrayed, and whether by the\r\ndevil or no, the devil only can tell. But I have turned the matter as I\r\ncould; you are safe if you renounce Rebecca. You are pitied\xe2\x80\x94the victim\r\nof magical delusion. She is a sorceress, and must suffer as such.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe shall not, by Heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Heaven, she must and will!\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin. \xe2\x80\x9cNeither you nor any\r\none else can save her. Lucas Beaumanoir hath settled that the death of\r\na Jewess will be a sin-offering sufficient to atone for all the amorous\r\nindulgences of the Knights Templars; and thou knowest he hath both the\r\npower and will to execute so reasonable and pious a purpose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill future ages believe that such stupid bigotry ever existed!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nBois-Guilbert, striding up and down the apartment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat they may believe, I know not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin, calmly; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\r\nknow well, that in this our day, clergy and laymen, take ninety-nine to\r\nthe hundred, will cry \xe2\x80\x98amen\xe2\x80\x99 to the Grand Master\xe2\x80\x99s sentence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert. \xe2\x80\x9cAlbert, thou art my friend. Thou must\r\nconnive at her escape, Malvoisin, and I will transport her to some\r\nplace of greater security and secrecy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot, if I would,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Preceptor; \xe2\x80\x9cthe mansion is filled\r\nwith the attendants of the Grand Master, and others who are devoted to\r\nhim. And, to be frank with you, brother, I would not embark with you in\r\nthis matter, even if I could hope to bring my bark to haven. I have\r\nrisked enough already for your sake. I have no mind to encounter a\r\nsentence of degradation, or even to lose my Preceptory, for the sake of\r\na painted piece of Jewish flesh and blood. And you, if you will be\r\nguided by my counsel, will give up this wild-goose chase, and fly your\r\nhawk at some other game. Think, Bois-Guilbert,\xe2\x80\x94thy present rank, thy\r\nfuture honours, all depend on thy place in the Order. Shouldst thou\r\nadhere perversely to thy passion for this Rebecca, thou wilt give\r\nBeaumanoir the power of expelling thee, and he will not neglect it. He\r\nis jealous of the truncheon which he holds in his trembling gripe, and\r\nhe knows thou stretchest thy bold hand towards it. Doubt not he will\r\nruin thee, if thou affordest him a pretext so fair as thy protection of\r\na Jewish sorceress. Give him his scope in this matter, for thou canst\r\nnot control him. When the staff is in thine own firm grasp, thou mayest\r\ncaress the daughters of Judah, or burn them, as may best suit thine own\r\nhumour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMalvoisin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthou art a cold-blooded\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor, hastening to fill up the blank, in which\r\nBois-Guilbert would probably have placed a worse word,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca cold-blooded\r\nfriend I am, and therefore more fit to give thee advice. I tell thee\r\nonce more, that thou canst not save Rebecca. I tell thee once more,\r\nthou canst but perish with her. Go hie thee to the Grand Master\xe2\x80\x94throw\r\nthyself at his feet and tell him\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at his feet, by Heaven! but to the dotard\xe2\x80\x99s very beard will I\r\nsay\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay to him, then, to his beard,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Malvoisin, coolly, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nyou love this captive Jewess to distraction; and the more thou dost\r\nenlarge on thy passion, the greater will be his haste to end it by the\r\ndeath of the fair enchantress; while thou, taken in flagrant delict by\r\nthe avowal of a crime contrary to thine oath, canst hope no aid of thy\r\nbrethren, and must exchange all thy brilliant visions of ambition and\r\npower, to lift perhaps a mercenary spear in some of the petty quarrels\r\nbetween Flanders and Burgundy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou speakest the truth, Malvoisin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Brian de Bois-Guilbert,\r\nafter a moment\xe2\x80\x99s reflection. \xe2\x80\x9cI will give the hoary bigot no advantage\r\nover me; and for Rebecca, she hath not merited at my hand that I should\r\nexpose rank and honour for her sake. I will cast her off\xe2\x80\x94yes, I will\r\nleave her to her fate, unless\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQualify not thy wise and necessary resolution,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin; \xe2\x80\x9cwomen\r\nare but the toys which amuse our lighter hours\xe2\x80\x94ambition is the serious\r\nbusiness of life. Perish a thousand such frail baubles as this Jewess,\r\nbefore thy manly step pause in the brilliant career that lies stretched\r\nbefore thee! For the present we part, nor must we be seen to hold close\r\nconversation\xe2\x80\x94I must order the hall for his judgment-seat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cso soon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Preceptor, \xe2\x80\x9ctrial moves rapidly on when the judge has\r\ndetermined the sentence beforehand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, when he was left alone, \xe2\x80\x9cthou art like\r\nto cost me dear\xe2\x80\x94Why cannot I abandon thee to thy fate, as this calm\r\nhypocrite recommends?\xe2\x80\x94One effort will I make to save thee\xe2\x80\x94but beware of\r\ningratitude! for if I am again repulsed, my vengeance shall equal my\r\nlove. The life and honour of Bois-Guilbert must not be hazarded, where\r\ncontempt and reproaches are his only reward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Preceptor had hardly given the necessary orders, when he was joined\r\nby Conrade Mont-Fitchet, who acquainted him with the Grand Master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nresolution to bring the Jewess to instant trial for sorcery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is surely a dream,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor; \xe2\x80\x9cwe have many Jewish\r\nphysicians, and we call them not wizards though they work wonderful\r\ncures.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Grand Master thinks otherwise,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mont-Fitchet; \xe2\x80\x9cand, Albert, I\r\nwill be upright with thee\xe2\x80\x94wizard or not, it were better that this\r\nmiserable damsel die, than that Brian de Bois-Guilbert should be lost\r\nto the Order, or the Order divided by internal dissension. Thou knowest\r\nhis high rank, his fame in arms\xe2\x80\x94thou knowest the zeal with which many\r\nof our brethren regard him\xe2\x80\x94but all this will not avail him with our\r\nGrand Master, should he consider Brian as the accomplice, not the\r\nvictim, of this Jewess. Were the souls of the twelve tribes in her\r\nsingle body, it were better she suffered alone, than that Bois-Guilbert\r\nwere partner in her destruction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been working him even now to abandon her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nstill, are there grounds enough to condemn this Rebecca for\r\nsorcery?\xe2\x80\x94Will not the Grand Master change his mind when he sees that\r\nthe proofs are so weak?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey must be strengthened, Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mont-Fitchet, \xe2\x80\x9cthey must\r\nbe strengthened. Dost thou understand me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor, \xe2\x80\x9cnor do I scruple to do aught for\r\nadvancement of the Order\xe2\x80\x94but there is little time to find engines\r\nfitting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMalvoisin, they MUST be found,\xe2\x80\x9d said Conrade; \xe2\x80\x9cwell will it advantage\r\nboth the Order and thee. This Templestowe is a poor Preceptory\xe2\x80\x94that of\r\nMaison-Dieu is worth double its value\xe2\x80\x94thou knowest my interest with our\r\nold Chief\xe2\x80\x94find those who can carry this matter through, and thou art\r\nPreceptor of Maison-Dieu in the fertile Kent\xe2\x80\x94How sayst thou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Malvoisin, \xe2\x80\x9camong those who came hither with\r\nBois-Guilbert, two fellows whom I well know; servants they were to my\r\nbrother Philip de Malvoisin, and passed from his service to that of\r\nFront-de-B\xc5\x93uf\xe2\x80\x94It may be they know something of the witcheries of this\r\nwoman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAway, seek them out instantly\xe2\x80\x94and hark thee, if a byzant or two will\r\nsharpen their memory, let them not be wanting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey would swear the mother that bore them a sorceress for a zecchin,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the Preceptor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAway, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mont-Fitchet; \xe2\x80\x9cat noon the affair will proceed. I\r\nhave not seen our senior in such earnest preparation since he condemned\r\nto the stake Hamet Alfagi, a convert who relapsed to the Moslem faith.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe ponderous castle-bell had tolled the point of noon, when Rebecca\r\nheard a trampling of feet upon the private stair which led to her place\r\nof confinement. The noise announced the arrival of several persons, and\r\nthe circumstance rather gave her joy; for she was more afraid of the\r\nsolitary visits of the fierce and passionate Bois-Guilbert than of any\r\nevil that could befall her besides. The door of the chamber was\r\nunlocked, and Conrade and the Preceptor Malvoisin entered, attended by\r\nfour warders clothed in black, and bearing halberds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDaughter of an accursed race!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor, \xe2\x80\x9carise and follow\r\nus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cand for what purpose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamsel,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Conrade, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not for thee to question, but to\r\nobey. Nevertheless, be it known to thee, that thou art to be brought\r\nbefore the tribunal of the Grand Master of our holy Order, there to\r\nanswer for thine offences.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the God of Abraham be praised!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, folding her hands\r\ndevoutly; \xe2\x80\x9cthe name of a judge, though an enemy to my people, is to me\r\nas the name of a protector. Most willingly do I follow thee\xe2\x80\x94permit me\r\nonly to wrap my veil around my head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey descended the stair with slow and solemn step, traversed a long\r\ngallery, and, by a pair of folding doors placed at the end, entered the\r\ngreat hall in which the Grand Master had for the time established his\r\ncourt of justice.\r\n\r\nThe lower part of this ample apartment was filled with squires and\r\nyeomen, who made way not without some difficulty for Rebecca, attended\r\nby the Preceptor and Mont-Fitchet, and followed by the guard of\r\nhalberdiers, to move forward to the seat appointed for her. As she\r\npassed through the crowd, her arms folded and her head depressed, a\r\nscrap of paper was thrust into her hand, which she received almost\r\nunconsciously, and continued to hold without examining its contents.\r\nThe assurance that she possessed some friend in this awful assembly\r\ngave her courage to look around, and to mark into whose presence she\r\nhad been conducted. She gazed, accordingly, upon the scene, which we\r\nshall endeavour to describe in the next chapter.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVII\r\n\r\n\r\nStern was the law which bade its vot\xe2\x80\x99ries leave\r\nAt human woes with human hearts to grieve;\r\nStern was the law, which at the winning wile\r\nOf frank and harmless mirth forbade to smile;\r\nBut sterner still, when high the iron-rod\r\nOf tyrant power she shook, and call\xe2\x80\x99d that power of God.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE MIDDLE AGES\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Tribunal, erected for the trial of the innocent and unhappy\r\nRebecca, occupied the dais or elevated part of the upper end of the\r\ngreat hall\xe2\x80\x94a platform, which we have already described as the place of\r\nhonour, destined to be occupied by the most distinguished inhabitants\r\nor guests of an ancient mansion.\r\n\r\nOn an elevated seat, directly before the accused, sat the Grand Master\r\nof the Temple, in full and ample robes of flowing white, holding in his\r\nhand the mystic staff, which bore the symbol of the Order. At his feet\r\nwas placed a table, occupied by two scribes, chaplains of the Order,\r\nwhose duty it was to reduce to formal record the proceedings of the\r\nday. The black dresses, bare scalps, and demure looks of these\r\nchurch-men, formed a strong contrast to the warlike appearance of the\r\nknights who attended, either as residing in the Preceptory, or as come\r\nthither to attend upon their Grand Master. The Preceptors, of whom\r\nthere were four present, occupied seats lower in height, and somewhat\r\ndrawn back behind that of their superior; and the knights, who enjoyed\r\nno such rank in the Order, were placed on benches still lower, and\r\npreserving the same distance from the Preceptors as these from the\r\nGrand Master. Behind them, but still upon the dais or elevated portion\r\nof the hall, stood the esquires of the Order, in white dresses of an\r\ninferior quality.\r\n\r\nThe whole assembly wore an aspect of the most profound gravity; and in\r\nthe faces of the knights might be perceived traces of military daring,\r\nunited with the solemn carriage becoming men of a religious profession,\r\nand which, in the presence of their Grand Master, failed not to sit\r\nupon every brow.\r\n\r\nThe remaining and lower part of the hall was filled with guards,\r\nholding partisans, and with other attendants whom curiosity had drawn\r\nthither, to see at once a Grand Master and a Jewish sorceress. By far\r\nthe greater part of those inferior persons were, in one rank or other,\r\nconnected with the Order, and were accordingly distinguished by their\r\nblack dresses. But peasants from the neighbouring country were not\r\nrefused admittance; for it was the pride of Beaumanoir to render the\r\nedifying spectacle of the justice which he administered as public as\r\npossible. His large blue eyes seemed to expand as he gazed around the\r\nassembly, and his countenance appeared elated by the conscious dignity,\r\nand imaginary merit, of the part which he was about to perform. A\r\npsalm, which he himself accompanied with a deep mellow voice, which age\r\nhad not deprived of its powers, commenced the proceedings of the day;\r\nand the solemn sounds, \xe2\x80\x9cVenite exultemus Domino\xe2\x80\x9d, so often sung by the\r\nTemplars before engaging with earthly adversaries, was judged by Lucas\r\nmost appropriate to introduce the approaching triumph, for such he\r\ndeemed it, over the powers of darkness. The deep prolonged notes,\r\nraised by a hundred masculine voices accustomed to combine in the\r\nchoral chant, arose to the vaulted roof of the hall, and rolled on\r\namongst its arches with the pleasing yet solemn sound of the rushing of\r\nmighty waters.\r\n\r\nWhen the sounds ceased, the Grand Master glanced his eye slowly around\r\nthe circle, and observed that the seat of one of the Preceptors was\r\nvacant. Brian de Bois-Guilbert, by whom it had been occupied, had left\r\nhis place, and was now standing near the extreme corner of one of the\r\nbenches occupied by the Knights Companions of the Temple, one hand\r\nextending his long mantle, so as in some degree to hide his face; while\r\nthe other held his cross-handled sword, with the point of which,\r\nsheathed as it was, he was slowly drawing lines upon the oaken floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnhappy man!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, after favouring him with a glance\r\nof compassion. \xe2\x80\x9cThou seest, Conrade, how this holy work distresses him.\r\nTo this can the light look of woman, aided by the Prince of the Powers\r\nof this world, bring a valiant and worthy knight!\xe2\x80\x94Seest thou he cannot\r\nlook upon us; he cannot look upon her; and who knows by what impulse\r\nfrom his tormentor his hand forms these cabalistic lines upon the\r\nfloor?\xe2\x80\x94It may be our life and safety are thus aimed at; but we spit at\r\nand defy the foul enemy. \xe2\x80\x98Semper Leo percutiatur!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was communicated apart to his confidential follower, Conrade\r\nMont-Fitchet. The Grand Master then raised his voice, and addressed the\r\nassembly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReverend and valiant men, Knights, Preceptors, and Companions of this\r\nHoly Order, my brethren and my children!\xe2\x80\x94you also, well-born and pious\r\nEsquires, who aspire to wear this holy Cross!\xe2\x80\x94and you also, Christian\r\nbrethren, of every degree!\xe2\x80\x94Be it known to you, that it is not defect of\r\npower in us which hath occasioned the assembling of this congregation;\r\nfor, however unworthy in our person, yet to us is committed, with this\r\nbatoon, full power to judge and to try all that regards the weal of\r\nthis our Holy Order. Holy Saint Bernard, in the rule of our knightly\r\nand religious profession, hath said, in the fifty-ninth capital, 53\r\nthat he would not that brethren be called together in council, save at\r\nthe will and command of the Master; leaving it free to us, as to those\r\nmore worthy fathers who have preceded us in this our office, to judge,\r\nas well of the occasion as of the time and place in which a chapter of\r\nthe whole Order, or of any part thereof, may be convoked. Also, in all\r\nsuch chapters, it is our duty to hear the advice of our brethren, and\r\nto proceed according to our own pleasure. But when the raging wolf hath\r\nmade an inroad upon the flock, and carried off one member thereof, it\r\nis the duty of the kind shepherd to call his comrades together, that\r\nwith bows and slings they may quell the invader, according to our\r\nwell-known rule, that the lion is ever to be beaten down. We have\r\ntherefore summoned to our presence a Jewish woman, by name Rebecca,\r\ndaughter of Isaac of York\xe2\x80\x94a woman infamous for sortileges and for\r\nwitcheries; whereby she hath maddened the blood, and besotted the\r\nbrain, not of a churl, but of a Knight\xe2\x80\x94not of a secular Knight, but of\r\none devoted to the service of the Holy Temple\xe2\x80\x94not of a Knight\r\nCompanion, but of a Preceptor of our Order, first in honour as in\r\nplace. Our brother, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, is well known to ourselves,\r\nand to all degrees who now hear me, as a true and zealous champion of\r\nthe Cross, by whose arm many deeds of valour have been wrought in the\r\nHoly Land, and the holy places purified from pollution by the blood of\r\nthose infidels who defiled them. Neither have our brother\xe2\x80\x99s sagacity\r\nand prudence been less in repute among his brethren than his valour and\r\ndiscipline; in so much, that knights, both in eastern and western\r\nlands, have named De Bois-Guilbert as one who may well be put in\r\nnomination as successor to this batoon, when it shall please Heaven to\r\nrelease us from the toil of bearing it. If we were told that such a\r\nman, so honoured, and so honourable, suddenly casting away regard for\r\nhis character, his vows, his brethren, and his prospects, had\r\nassociated to himself a Jewish damsel, wandered in this lewd company,\r\nthrough solitary places, defended her person in preference to his own,\r\nand, finally, was so utterly blinded and besotted by his folly, as to\r\nbring her even to one of our own Preceptories, what should we say but\r\nthat the noble knight was possessed by some evil demon, or influenced\r\nby some wicked spell?\xe2\x80\x94If we could suppose it otherwise, think not rank,\r\nvalour, high repute, or any earthly consideration, should prevent us\r\nfrom visiting him with punishment, that the evil thing might be\r\nremoved, even according to the text, \xe2\x80\x98Auferte malum ex vobis\xe2\x80\x99. For\r\nvarious and heinous are the acts of transgression against the rule of\r\nour blessed Order in this lamentable history.\xe2\x80\x941st, He hath walked\r\naccording to his proper will, contrary to capital 33, \xe2\x80\x98Quod nullus\r\njuxta propriam voluntatem incedat\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x942d, He hath held communication with\r\nan excommunicated person, capital 57, \xe2\x80\x98Ut fratres non participent cum\r\nexcommunicatis\xe2\x80\x99, and therefore hath a portion in \xe2\x80\x98Anathema\r\nMaranatha\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x943d, He hath conversed with strange women, contrary to the\r\ncapital, \xe2\x80\x98Ut fratres non conversantur cum extraneis mulieribus\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x944th,\r\nHe hath not avoided, nay, he hath, it is to be feared, solicited the\r\nkiss of woman; by which, saith the last rule of our renowned Order, \xe2\x80\x98Ut\r\nfugiantur oscula\xe2\x80\x99, the soldiers of the Cross are brought into a snare.\r\nFor which heinous and multiplied guilt, Brian de Bois-Guilbert should\r\nbe cut off and cast out from our congregation, were he the right hand\r\nand right eye thereof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused. A low murmur went through the assembly. Some of the younger\r\npart, who had been inclined to smile at the statute \xe2\x80\x98De osculis\r\nfugiendis\xe2\x80\x99, became now grave enough, and anxiously waited what the\r\nGrand Master was next to propose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cand so great should indeed be the punishment of a\r\nKnight Templar, who wilfully offended against the rules of his Order in\r\nsuch weighty points. But if, by means of charms and of spells, Satan\r\nhad obtained dominion over the Knight, perchance because he cast his\r\neyes too lightly upon a damsel\xe2\x80\x99s beauty, we are then rather to lament\r\nthan chastise his backsliding; and, imposing on him only such penance\r\nas may purify him from his iniquity, we are to turn the full edge of\r\nour indignation upon the accursed instrument, which had so well-nigh\r\noccasioned his utter falling away.\xe2\x80\x94Stand forth, therefore, and bear\r\nwitness, ye who have witnessed these unhappy doings, that we may judge\r\nof the sum and bearing thereof; and judge whether our justice may be\r\nsatisfied with the punishment of this infidel woman, or if we must go\r\non, with a bleeding heart, to the further proceeding against our\r\nbrother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSeveral witnesses were called upon to prove the risks to which\r\nBois-Guilbert exposed himself in endeavouring to save Rebecca from the\r\nblazing castle, and his neglect of his personal defence in attending to\r\nher safety. The men gave these details with the exaggerations common to\r\nvulgar minds which have been strongly excited by any remarkable event,\r\nand their natural disposition to the marvellous was greatly increased\r\nby the satisfaction which their evidence seemed to afford to the\r\neminent person for whose information it had been delivered. Thus the\r\ndangers which Bois-Guilbert surmounted, in themselves sufficiently\r\ngreat, became portentous in their narrative. The devotion of the Knight\r\nto Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s defence was exaggerated beyond the bounds, not only of\r\ndiscretion, but even of the most frantic excess of chivalrous zeal; and\r\nhis deference to what she said, even although her language was often\r\nsevere and upbraiding, was painted as carried to an excess, which, in a\r\nman of his haughty temper, seemed almost preternatural.\r\n\r\nThe Preceptor of Templestowe was then called on to describe the manner\r\nin which Bois-Guilbert and the Jewess arrived at the Preceptory. The\r\nevidence of Malvoisin was skilfully guarded. But while he apparently\r\nstudied to spare the feelings of Bois-Guilbert, he threw in, from time\r\nto time, such hints, as seemed to infer that he laboured under some\r\ntemporary alienation of mind, so deeply did he appear to be enamoured\r\nof the damsel whom he brought along with him. With sighs of penitence,\r\nthe Preceptor avowed his own contrition for having admitted Rebecca and\r\nher lover within the walls of the Preceptory\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBut my defence,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nconcluded, \xe2\x80\x9chas been made in my confession to our most reverend father\r\nthe Grand Master; he knows my motives were not evil, though my conduct\r\nmay have been irregular. Joyfully will I submit to any penance he shall\r\nassign me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast spoken well, Brother Albert,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beaumanoir; \xe2\x80\x9cthy motives\r\nwere good, since thou didst judge it right to arrest thine erring\r\nbrother in his career of precipitate folly. But thy conduct was wrong;\r\nas he that would stop a runaway steed, and seizing by the stirrup\r\ninstead of the bridle, receiveth injury himself, instead of\r\naccomplishing his purpose. Thirteen paternosters are assigned by our\r\npious founder for matins, and nine for vespers; be those services\r\ndoubled by thee. Thrice a-week are Templars permitted the use of flesh;\r\nbut do thou keep fast for all the seven days. This do for six weeks to\r\ncome, and thy penance is accomplished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith a hypocritical look of the deepest submission, the Preceptor of\r\nTemplestowe bowed to the ground before his Superior, and resumed his\r\nseat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere it not well, brethren,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we examine\r\nsomething into the former life and conversation of this woman,\r\nspecially that we may discover whether she be one likely to use magical\r\ncharms and spells, since the truths which we have heard may well\r\nincline us to suppose, that in this unhappy course our erring brother\r\nhas been acted upon by some infernal enticement and delusion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHerman of Goodalricke was the Fourth Preceptor present; the other three\r\nwere Conrade, Malvoisin, and Bois-Guilbert himself. Herman was an\r\nancient warrior, whose face was marked with scars inflicted by the\r\nsabre of the Moslemah, and had great rank and consideration among his\r\nbrethren. He arose and bowed to the Grand Master, who instantly granted\r\nhim license of speech. \xe2\x80\x9cI would crave to know, most Reverend Father, of\r\nour valiant brother, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, what he says to these\r\nwondrous accusations, and with what eye he himself now regards his\r\nunhappy intercourse with this Jewish maiden?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrian de Bois-Guilbert,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cthou hearest the\r\nquestion which our Brother of Goodalricke desirest thou shouldst\r\nanswer. I command thee to reply to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBois-Guilbert turned his head towards the Grand Master when thus\r\naddressed, and remained silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is possessed by a dumb devil,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master. \xe2\x80\x9cAvoid thee,\r\nSathanus!\xe2\x80\x94Speak, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, I conjure thee, by this symbol\r\nof our Holy Order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBois-Guilbert made an effort to suppress his rising scorn and\r\nindignation, the expression of which, he was well aware, would have\r\nlittle availed him. \xe2\x80\x9cBrian de Bois-Guilbert,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, \xe2\x80\x9creplies\r\nnot, most Reverend Father, to such wild and vague charges. If his\r\nhonour be impeached, he will defend it with his body, and with that\r\nsword which has often fought for Christendom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe forgive thee, Brother Brian,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master; \xe2\x80\x9cthough that\r\nthou hast boasted thy warlike achievements before us, is a glorifying\r\nof thine own deeds, and cometh of the Enemy, who tempteth us to exalt\r\nour own worship. But thou hast our pardon, judging thou speakest less\r\nof thine own suggestion than from the impulse of him whom by Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nleave, we will quell and drive forth from our assembly.\xe2\x80\x9d A glance of\r\ndisdain flashed from the dark fierce eyes of Bois-Guilbert, but he made\r\nno reply.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9csince our Brother of\r\nGoodalricke\xe2\x80\x99s question has been thus imperfectly answered, pursue we\r\nour quest, brethren, and with our patron\xe2\x80\x99s assistance, we will search\r\nto the bottom this mystery of iniquity.\xe2\x80\x94Let those who have aught to\r\nwitness of the life and conversation of this Jewish woman, stand forth\r\nbefore us.\xe2\x80\x9d There was a bustle in the lower part of the hall, and when\r\nthe Grand Master enquired the reason, it was replied, there was in the\r\ncrowd a bedridden man, whom the prisoner had restored to the perfect\r\nuse of his limbs, by a miraculous balsam.\r\n\r\nThe poor peasant, a Saxon by birth, was dragged forward to the bar,\r\nterrified at the penal consequences which he might have incurred by the\r\nguilt of having been cured of the palsy by a Jewish damsel. Perfectly\r\ncured he certainly was not, for he supported himself forward on\r\ncrutches to give evidence. Most unwilling was his testimony, and given\r\nwith many tears; but he admitted that two years since, when residing at\r\nYork, he was suddenly afflicted with a sore disease, while labouring\r\nfor Isaac the rich Jew, in his vocation of a joiner; that he had been\r\nunable to stir from his bed until the remedies applied by Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndirections, and especially a warming and spicy-smelling balsam, had in\r\nsome degree restored him to the use of his limbs. Moreover, he said,\r\nshe had given him a pot of that precious ointment, and furnished him\r\nwith a piece of money withal, to return to the house of his father,\r\nnear to Templestowe. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd may it please your gracious Reverence,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe man, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot think the damsel meant harm by me, though she hath\r\nthe ill hap to be a Jewess; for even when I used her remedy, I said the\r\nPater and the Creed, and it never operated a whit less kindly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace, slave,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cand begone! It well suits\r\nbrutes like thee to be tampering and trinketing with hellish cures, and\r\nto be giving your labour to the sons of mischief. I tell thee, the\r\nfiend can impose diseases for the very purpose of removing them, in\r\norder to bring into credit some diabolical fashion of cure. Hast thou\r\nthat unguent of which thou speakest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe peasant, fumbling in his bosom with a trembling hand, produced a\r\nsmall box, bearing some Hebrew characters on the lid, which was, with\r\nmost of the audience, a sure proof that the devil had stood apothecary.\r\nBeaumanoir, after crossing himself, took the box into his hand, and,\r\nlearned in most of the Eastern tongues, read with ease the motto on the\r\nlid,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe Lion of the tribe of Judah hath conquered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrange powers of Sathanas.\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich can convert Scripture\r\ninto blasphemy, mingling poison with our necessary food!\xe2\x80\x94Is there no\r\nleech here who can tell us the ingredients of this mystic unguent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTwo mediciners, as they called themselves, the one a monk, the other a\r\nbarber, appeared, and avouched they knew nothing of the materials,\r\nexcepting that they savoured of myrrh and camphire, which they took to\r\nbe Oriental herbs. But with the true professional hatred to a\r\nsuccessful practitioner of their art, they insinuated that, since the\r\nmedicine was beyond their own knowledge, it must necessarily have been\r\ncompounded from an unlawful and magical pharmacopeia; since they\r\nthemselves, though no conjurors, fully understood every branch of their\r\nart, so far as it might be exercised with the good faith of a\r\nChristian. When this medical research was ended, the Saxon peasant\r\ndesired humbly to have back the medicine which he had found so\r\nsalutary; but the Grand Master frowned severely at the request. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\r\nis thy name, fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the cripple.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigg, the son of Snell,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the peasant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen Higg, son of Snell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cI tell thee it is\r\nbetter to be bedridden, than to accept the benefit of unbelievers\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmedicine that thou mayest arise and walk; better to despoil infidels of\r\ntheir treasure by the strong hand, than to accept of them benevolent\r\ngifts, or do them service for wages. Go thou, and do as I have said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlack,\xe2\x80\x9d said the peasant, \xe2\x80\x9can it shall not displease your Reverence,\r\nthe lesson comes too late for me, for I am but a maimed man; but I will\r\ntell my two brethren, who serve the rich Rabbi Nathan Ben Samuel, that\r\nyour mastership says it is more lawful to rob him than to render him\r\nfaithful service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOut with the prating villain!\xe2\x80\x9d said Beaumanoir, who was not prepared\r\nto refute this practical application of his general maxim.\r\n\r\nHigg, the son of Snell, withdrew into the crowd, but, interested in the\r\nfate of his benefactress, lingered until he should learn her doom, even\r\nat the risk of again encountering the frown of that severe judge, the\r\nterror of which withered his very heart within him.\r\n\r\nAt this period of the trial, the Grand Master commanded Rebecca to\r\nunveil herself. Opening her lips for the first time, she replied\r\npatiently, but with dignity,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThat it was not the wont of the daughters\r\nof her people to uncover their faces when alone in an assembly of\r\nstrangers.\xe2\x80\x9d The sweet tones of her voice, and the softness of her\r\nreply, impressed on the audience a sentiment of pity and sympathy. But\r\nBeaumanoir, in whose mind the suppression of each feeling of humanity\r\nwhich could interfere with his imagined duty, was a virtue of itself,\r\nrepeated his commands that his victim should be unveiled. The guards\r\nwere about to remove her veil accordingly, when she stood up before the\r\nGrand Master and said, \xe2\x80\x9cNay, but for the love of your own\r\ndaughters\xe2\x80\x94Alas,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, recollecting herself, \xe2\x80\x9cye have no\r\ndaughters!\xe2\x80\x94yet for the remembrance of your mothers\xe2\x80\x94for the love of your\r\nsisters, and of female decency, let me not be thus handled in your\r\npresence; it suits not a maiden to be disrobed by such rude grooms. I\r\nwill obey you,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, with an expression of patient sorrow in her\r\nvoice, which had almost melted the heart of Beaumanoir himself; \xe2\x80\x9cye are\r\nelders among your people, and at your command I will show the features\r\nof an ill-fated maiden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe withdrew her veil, and looked on them with a countenance in which\r\nbashfulness contended with dignity. Her exceeding beauty excited a\r\nmurmur of surprise, and the younger knights told each other with their\r\neyes, in silent correspondence, that Brian\xe2\x80\x99s best apology was in the\r\npower of her real charms, rather than of her imaginary witchcraft. But\r\nHigg, the son of Snell, felt most deeply the effect produced by the\r\nsight of the countenance of his benefactress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me go forth,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to the warders at the door of the hall,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9clet\r\nme go forth!\xe2\x80\x94To look at her again will kill me, for I have had a share\r\nin murdering her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace, poor man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, when she heard his exclamation; \xe2\x80\x9cthou\r\nhast done me no harm by speaking the truth\xe2\x80\x94thou canst not aid me by thy\r\ncomplaints or lamentations. Peace, I pray thee\xe2\x80\x94go home and save\r\nthyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHigg was about to be thrust out by the compassion of the warders, who\r\nwere apprehensive lest his clamorous grief should draw upon them\r\nreprehension, and upon himself punishment. But he promised to be\r\nsilent, and was permitted to remain. The two men-at-arms, with whom\r\nAlbert Malvoisin had not failed to communicate upon the import of their\r\ntestimony, were now called forward. Though both were hardened and\r\ninflexible villains, the sight of the captive maiden, as well as her\r\nexcelling beauty, at first appeared to stagger them; but an expressive\r\nglance from the Preceptor of Templestowe restored them to their dogged\r\ncomposure; and they delivered, with a precision which would have seemed\r\nsuspicious to more impartial judges, circumstances either altogether\r\nfictitious or trivial, and natural in themselves, but rendered pregnant\r\nwith suspicion by the exaggerated manner in which they were told, and\r\nthe sinister commentary which the witnesses added to the facts. The\r\ncircumstances of their evidence would have been, in modern days,\r\ndivided into two classes\xe2\x80\x94those which were immaterial, and those which\r\nwere actually and physically impossible. But both were, in those\r\nignorant and superstitions times, easily credited as proofs of\r\nguilt.\xe2\x80\x94The first class set forth, that Rebecca was heard to mutter to\r\nherself in an unknown tongue\xe2\x80\x94that the songs she sung by fits were of a\r\nstrangely sweet sound, which made the ears of the hearer tingle, and\r\nhis heart throb\xe2\x80\x94that she spoke at times to herself, and seemed to look\r\nupward for a reply\xe2\x80\x94that her garments were of a strange and mystic form,\r\nunlike those of women of good repute\xe2\x80\x94that she had rings impressed with\r\ncabalistical devices, and that strange characters were broidered on her\r\nveil.\r\n\r\nAll these circumstances, so natural and so trivial, were gravely\r\nlistened to as proofs, or, at least, as affording strong suspicions\r\nthat Rebecca had unlawful correspondence with mystical powers.\r\n\r\nBut there was less equivocal testimony, which the credulity of the\r\nassembly, or of the greater part, greedily swallowed, however\r\nincredible. One of the soldiers had seen her work a cure upon a wounded\r\nman, brought with them to the castle of Torquilstone. She did, he said,\r\nmake certain signs upon the wound, and repeated certain mysterious\r\nwords, which he blessed God he understood not, when the iron head of a\r\nsquare cross-bow bolt disengaged itself from the wound, the bleeding\r\nwas stanched, the wound was closed, and the dying man was, within a\r\nquarter of an hour, walking upon the ramparts, and assisting the\r\nwitness in managing a mangonel, or machine for hurling stones. This\r\nlegend was probably founded upon the fact, that Rebecca had attended on\r\nthe wounded Ivanhoe when in the castle of Torquilstone. But it was the\r\nmore difficult to dispute the accuracy of the witness, as, in order to\r\nproduce real evidence in support of his verbal testimony, he drew from\r\nhis pouch the very bolt-head, which, according to his story, had been\r\nmiraculously extracted from the wound; and as the iron weighed a full\r\nounce, it completely confirmed the tale, however marvellous.\r\n\r\nHis comrade had been a witness from a neighbouring battlement of the\r\nscene betwixt Rebecca and Bois-Guilbert, when she was upon the point of\r\nprecipitating herself from the top of the tower. Not to be behind his\r\ncompanion, this fellow stated, that he had seen Rebecca perch herself\r\nupon the parapet of the turret, and there take the form of a milk-white\r\nswan, under which appearance she flitted three times round the castle\r\nof Torquilstone; then again settle on the turret, and once more assume\r\nthe female form.\r\n\r\nLess than one half of this weighty evidence would have been sufficient\r\nto convict any old woman, poor and ugly, even though she had not been a\r\nJewess. United with that fatal circumstance, the body of proof was too\r\nweighty for Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s youth, though combined with the most exquisite\r\nbeauty.\r\n\r\nThe Grand Master had collected the suffrages, and now in a solemn tone\r\ndemanded of Rebecca what she had to say against the sentence of\r\ncondemnation, which he was about to pronounce.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo invoke your pity,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lovely Jewess, with a voice somewhat\r\ntremulous with emotion, \xe2\x80\x9cwould, I am aware, be as useless as I should\r\nhold it mean. To state that to relieve the sick and wounded of another\r\nreligion, cannot be displeasing to the acknowledged Founder of both our\r\nfaiths, were also unavailing; to plead that many things which these men\r\n(whom may Heaven pardon!) have spoken against me are impossible, would\r\navail me but little, since you believe in their possibility; and still\r\nless would it advantage me to explain, that the peculiarities of my\r\ndress, language, and manners, are those of my people\xe2\x80\x94I had well-nigh\r\nsaid of my country, but alas! we have no country. Nor will I even\r\nvindicate myself at the expense of my oppressor, who stands there\r\nlistening to the fictions and surmises which seem to convert the tyrant\r\ninto the victim.\xe2\x80\x94God be judge between him and me! but rather would I\r\nsubmit to ten such deaths as your pleasure may denounce against me,\r\nthan listen to the suit which that man of Belial has urged upon\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94friendless, defenceless, and his prisoner. But he is of your own\r\nfaith, and his lightest affirmance would weigh down the most solemn\r\nprotestations of the distressed Jewess. I will not therefore return to\r\nhimself the charge brought against me\xe2\x80\x94but to himself\xe2\x80\x94Yes, Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, to thyself I appeal, whether these accusations are not\r\nfalse? as monstrous and calumnious as they are deadly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a pause; all eyes turned to Brain de Bois-Guilbert. He was\r\nsilent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cif thou art a man\xe2\x80\x94if thou art a Christian, speak!\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nconjure thee, by the habit which thou dost wear, by the name thou dost\r\ninherit\xe2\x80\x94by the knighthood thou dost vaunt\xe2\x80\x94by the honour of thy\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x94by the tomb and the bones of thy father\xe2\x80\x94I conjure thee to say,\r\nare these things true?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnswer her, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cif the Enemy with whom\r\nthou dost wrestle will give thee power.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, Bois-Guilbert seemed agitated by contending passions, which\r\nalmost convulsed his features, and it was with a constrained voice that\r\nat last he replied, looking to Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe scroll!\xe2\x80\x94the scroll!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beaumanoir, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is indeed testimony! The victim of her\r\nwitcheries can only name the fatal scroll, the spell inscribed on which\r\nis, doubtless, the cause of his silence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Rebecca put another interpretation on the words extorted as it were\r\nfrom Bois-Guilbert, and glancing her eye upon the slip of parchment\r\nwhich she continued to hold in her hand, she read written thereupon in\r\nthe Arabian character, \xe2\x80\x9cDemand a Champion!\xe2\x80\x9d The murmuring commentary\r\nwhich ran through the assembly at the strange reply of Bois-Guilbert,\r\ngave Rebecca leisure to examine and instantly to destroy the scroll\r\nunobserved. When the whisper had ceased, the Grand Master spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca, thou canst derive no benefit from the evidence of this\r\nunhappy knight, for whom, as we well perceive, the Enemy is yet too\r\npowerful. Hast thou aught else to say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is yet one chance of life left to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9ceven by\r\nyour own fierce laws. Life has been miserable\xe2\x80\x94miserable, at least, of\r\nlate\xe2\x80\x94but I will not cast away the gift of God, while he affords me the\r\nmeans of defending it. I deny this charge\xe2\x80\x94I maintain my innocence, and\r\nI declare the falsehood of this accusation\xe2\x80\x94I challenge the privilege of\r\ntrial by combat, and will appear by my champion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cwill lay lance in rest\r\nfor a sorceress? who will be the champion of a Jewess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod will raise me up a champion,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt cannot be that in\r\nmerry England\xe2\x80\x94the hospitable, the generous, the free, where so many are\r\nready to peril their lives for honour, there will not be found one to\r\nfight for justice. But it is enough that I challenge the trial by\r\ncombat\xe2\x80\x94there lies my gage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe took her embroidered glove from her hand, and flung it down before\r\nthe Grand Master with an air of mingled simplicity and dignity, which\r\nexcited universal surprise and admiration.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVIII\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x94There I throw my gage,\r\nTo prove it on thee to the extremest point\r\nOf martial daring.\r\n\r\n\r\nRICHARD II\r\n\r\n\r\nEven Lucas Beaumanoir himself was affected by the mien and appearance\r\nof Rebecca. He was not originally a cruel or even a severe man; but\r\nwith passions by nature cold, and with a high, though mistaken, sense\r\nof duty, his heart had been gradually hardened by the ascetic life\r\nwhich he pursued, the supreme power which he enjoyed, and the supposed\r\nnecessity of subduing infidelity and eradicating heresy, which he\r\nconceived peculiarly incumbent on him. His features relaxed in their\r\nusual severity as he gazed upon the beautiful creature before him,\r\nalone, unfriended, and defending herself with so much spirit and\r\ncourage. He crossed himself twice, as doubting whence arose the\r\nunwonted softening of a heart, which on such occasions used to resemble\r\nin hardness the steel of his sword. At length he spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamsel,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cif the pity I feel for thee arise from any practice\r\nthine evil arts have made on me, great is thy guilt. But I rather judge\r\nit the kinder feelings of nature, which grieves that so goodly a form\r\nshould be a vessel of perdition. Repent, my daughter\xe2\x80\x94confess thy\r\nwitchcrafts\xe2\x80\x94turn thee from thine evil faith\xe2\x80\x94embrace this holy emblem,\r\nand all shall yet be well with thee here and hereafter. In some\r\nsisterhood of the strictest order, shalt thou have time for prayer and\r\nfitting penance, and that repentance not to be repented of. This do and\r\nlive\xe2\x80\x94what has the law of Moses done for thee that thou shouldest die\r\nfor it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was the law of my fathers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cit was delivered in\r\nthunders and in storms upon the mountain of Sinai, in cloud and in\r\nfire. This, if ye are Christians, ye believe\xe2\x80\x94it is, you say, recalled;\r\nbut so my teachers have not taught me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet our chaplain,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beaumanoir, \xe2\x80\x9cstand forth, and tell this\r\nobstinate infidel\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForgive the interruption,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, meekly; \xe2\x80\x9cI am a maiden,\r\nunskilled to dispute for my religion, but I can die for it, if it be\r\nGod\xe2\x80\x99s will.\xe2\x80\x94Let me pray your answer to my demand of a champion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me her glove,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beaumanoir. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued,\r\nas he looked at the flimsy texture and slender fingers, \xe2\x80\x9ca slight and\r\nfrail gage for a purpose so deadly!\xe2\x80\x94Seest thou, Rebecca, as this thin\r\nand light glove of thine is to one of our heavy steel gauntlets, so is\r\nthy cause to that of the Temple, for it is our Order which thou hast\r\ndefied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCast my innocence into the scale,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cand the glove of\r\nsilk shall outweigh the glove of iron.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen thou dost persist in thy refusal to confess thy guilt, and in\r\nthat bold challenge which thou hast made?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do persist, noble sir,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo be it then, in the name of Heaven,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master; \xe2\x80\x9cand may\r\nGod show the right!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Preceptors around him, and the word was deeply\r\nechoed by the whole assembly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrethren,\xe2\x80\x9d said Beaumanoir, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are aware that we might well have\r\nrefused to this woman the benefit of the trial by combat\xe2\x80\x94but though a\r\nJewess and an unbeliever, she is also a stranger and defenceless, and\r\nGod forbid that she should ask the benefit of our mild laws, and that\r\nit should be refused to her. Moreover, we are knights and soldiers as\r\nwell as men of religion, and shame it were to us upon any pretence, to\r\nrefuse proffered combat. Thus, therefore, stands the case. Rebecca, the\r\ndaughter of Isaac of York, is, by many frequent and suspicious\r\ncircumstances, defamed of sorcery practised on the person of a noble\r\nknight of our holy Order, and hath challenged the combat in proof of\r\nher innocence. To whom, reverend brethren, is it your opinion that we\r\nshould deliver the gage of battle, naming him, at the same time, to be\r\nour champion on the field?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Brian de Bois-Guilbert, whom it chiefly concerns,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nPreceptor of Goodalricke, \xe2\x80\x9cand who, moreover, best knows how the truth\r\nstands in this matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cour brother Brian be under the\r\ninfluence of a charm or a spell\xe2\x80\x94we speak but for the sake of\r\nprecaution, for to the arm of none of our holy Order would we more\r\nwillingly confide this or a more weighty cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Preceptor of Goodalricke, \xe2\x80\x9cno spell can\r\neffect the champion who comes forward to fight for the judgment of\r\nGod.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou sayest right, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master. \xe2\x80\x9cAlbert Malvoisin,\r\ngive this gage of battle to Brian de Bois-Guilbert.\xe2\x80\x94It is our charge to\r\nthee, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, addressing himself to Bois-Guilbert,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat thou do thy battle manfully, nothing doubting that the good cause\r\nshall triumph.\xe2\x80\x94And do thou, Rebecca, attend, that we assign thee the\r\nthird day from the present to find a champion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is but brief space,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cfor a stranger, who is\r\nalso of another faith, to find one who will do battle, wagering life\r\nand honour for her cause, against a knight who is called an approved\r\nsoldier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe may not extend it,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Grand Master; \xe2\x80\x9cthe field must be\r\nfoughten in our own presence, and divers weighty causes call us on the\r\nfourth day from hence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x99s will be done!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cI put my trust in Him, to whom an\r\ninstant is as effectual to save as a whole age.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast spoken well, damsel,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master; \xe2\x80\x9cbut well know\r\nwe who can array himself like an angel of light. It remains but to name\r\na fitting place of combat, and, if it so hap, also of execution.\xe2\x80\x94Where\r\nis the Preceptor of this house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert Malvoisin, still holding Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s glove in his hand, was\r\nspeaking to Bois-Guilbert very earnestly, but in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cwill he not receive the gage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will\xe2\x80\x94he doth, most Reverend Father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin, slipping the\r\nglove under his own mantle. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd for the place of combat, I hold the\r\nfittest to be the lists of Saint George belonging to this Preceptory,\r\nand used by us for military exercise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca, in those lists shalt\r\nthou produce thy champion; and if thou failest to do so, or if thy\r\nchampion shall be discomfited by the judgment of God, thou shalt then\r\ndie the death of a sorceress, according to doom.\xe2\x80\x94Let this our judgment\r\nbe recorded, and the record read aloud, that no one may pretend\r\nignorance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOne of the chaplains, who acted as clerks to the chapter, immediately\r\nengrossed the order in a huge volume, which contained the proceedings\r\nof the Templar Knights when solemnly assembled on such occasions; and\r\nwhen he had finished writing, the other read aloud the sentence of the\r\nGrand Master, which, when translated from the Norman-French in which it\r\nwas couched, was expressed as follows.\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca, a Jewess, daughter of Isaac of York, being attainted of\r\nsorcery, seduction, and other damnable practices, practised on a Knight\r\nof the most Holy Order of the Temple of Zion, doth deny the same; and\r\nsaith, that the testimony delivered against her this day is false,\r\nwicked, and disloyal; and that by lawful \xe2\x80\x98essoine\xe2\x80\x99 54 of her body as\r\nbeing unable to combat in her own behalf, she doth offer, by a champion\r\ninstead thereof, to avouch her case, he performing his loyal \xe2\x80\x98devoir\xe2\x80\x99\r\nin all knightly sort, with such arms as to gage of battle do fully\r\nappertain, and that at her peril and cost. And therewith she proffered\r\nher gage. And the gage having been delivered to the noble Lord and\r\nKnight, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, of the Holy Order of the Temple of\r\nZion, he was appointed to do this battle, in behalf of his Order and\r\nhimself, as injured and impaired by the practices of the appellant.\r\nWherefore the most reverend Father and puissant Lord, Lucas Marquis of\r\nBeaumanoir, did allow of the said challenge, and of the said \xe2\x80\x98essoine\xe2\x80\x99\r\nof the appellant\xe2\x80\x99s body, and assigned the third day for the said\r\ncombat, the place being the enclosure called the lists of Saint George,\r\nnear to the Preceptory of Templestowe. And the Grand Master appoints\r\nthe appellant to appear there by her champion, on pain of doom, as a\r\nperson convicted of sorcery or seduction; and also the defendant so to\r\nappear, under the penalty of being held and adjudged recreant in case\r\nof default; and the noble Lord and most reverend Father aforesaid\r\nappointed the battle to be done in his own presence, and according to\r\nall that is commendable and profitable in such a case. And may God aid\r\nthe just cause!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master; and the word was echoed by all around.\r\nRebecca spoke not, but she looked up to heaven, and, folding her hands,\r\nremained for a minute without change of attitude. She then modestly\r\nreminded the Grand Master, that she ought to be permitted some\r\nopportunity of free communication with her friends, for the purpose of\r\nmaking her condition known to them, and procuring, if possible, some\r\nchampion to fight in her behalf.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is just and lawful,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master; \xe2\x80\x9cchoose what messenger\r\nthou shalt trust, and he shall have free communication with thee in thy\r\nprison-chamber.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cany one here, who, either for love of a good\r\ncause, or for ample hire, will do the errand of a distressed being?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll were silent; for none thought it safe, in the presence of the Grand\r\nMaster, to avow any interest in the calumniated prisoner, lest he\r\nshould be suspected of leaning towards Judaism. Not even the prospect\r\nof reward, far less any feelings of compassion alone, could surmount\r\nthis apprehension.\r\n\r\nRebecca stood for a few moments in indescribable anxiety, and then\r\nexclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cIs it really thus?\xe2\x80\x94And, in English land, am I to be\r\ndeprived of the poor chance of safety which remains to me, for want of\r\nan act of charity which would not be refused to the worst criminal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHigg, the son of Snell, at length replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI am but a maimed man, but\r\nthat I can at all stir or move was owing to her charitable\r\nassistance.\xe2\x80\x94I will do thine errand,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, addressing Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cas\r\nwell as a crippled object can, and happy were my limbs fleet enough to\r\nrepair the mischief done by my tongue. Alas! when I boasted of thy\r\ncharity, I little thought I was leading thee into danger!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cis the disposer of all. He can turn back the\r\ncaptivity of Judah, even by the weakest instrument. To execute his\r\nmessage the snail is as sure a messenger as the falcon. Seek out Isaac\r\nof York\xe2\x80\x94here is that will pay for horse and man\xe2\x80\x94let him have this\r\nscroll.\xe2\x80\x94I know not if it be of Heaven the spirit which inspires me, but\r\nmost truly do I judge that I am not to die this death, and that a\r\nchampion will be raised up for me. Farewell!\xe2\x80\x94Life and death are in thy\r\nhaste.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe peasant took the scroll, which contained only a few lines in\r\nHebrew. Many of the crowd would have dissuaded him from touching a\r\ndocument so suspicious; but Higg was resolute in the service of his\r\nbenefactress. She had saved his body, he said, and he was confident she\r\ndid not mean to peril his soul.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will get me,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmy neighbour Buthan\xe2\x80\x99s good capul, 55 and I\r\nwill be at York within as brief space as man and beast may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut as it fortuned, he had no occasion to go so far, for within a\r\nquarter of a mile from the gate of the Preceptory he met with two\r\nriders, whom, by their dress and their huge yellow caps, he knew to be\r\nJews; and, on approaching more nearly, discovered that one of them was\r\nhis ancient employer, Isaac of York. The other was the Rabbi Ben\r\nSamuel; and both had approached as near to the Preceptory as they\r\ndared, on hearing that the Grand Master had summoned a chapter for the\r\ntrial of a sorceress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother Ben Samuel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cmy soul is disquieted, and I wot not\r\nwhy. This charge of necromancy is right often used for cloaking evil\r\npractices on our people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe of good comfort, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the physician; \xe2\x80\x9cthou canst deal\r\nwith the Nazarenes as one possessing the mammon of unrighteousness, and\r\ncanst therefore purchase immunity at their hands\xe2\x80\x94it rules the savage\r\nminds of those ungodly men, even as the signet of the mighty Solomon\r\nwas said to command the evil genii.\xe2\x80\x94But what poor wretch comes hither\r\nupon his crutches, desiring, as I think, some speech of me?\xe2\x80\x94Friend,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued the physician, addressing Higg, the son of Snell, \xe2\x80\x9cI refuse\r\nthee not the aid of mine art, but I relieve not with one asper those\r\nwho beg for alms upon the highway.
