Out upon thee!\xe2\x80\x94Hast thou the palsy\r\nin thy legs? then let thy hands work for thy livelihood; for, albeit\r\nthou be\xe2\x80\x99st unfit for a speedy post, or for a careful shepherd, or for\r\nthe warfare, or for the service of a hasty master, yet there be\r\noccupations\xe2\x80\x94How now, brother?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, interrupting his harangue to\r\nlook towards Isaac, who had but glanced at the scroll which Higg\r\noffered, when, uttering a deep groan, he fell from his mule like a\r\ndying man, and lay for a minute insensible.\r\n\r\nThe Rabbi now dismounted in great alarm, and hastily applied the\r\nremedies which his art suggested for the recovery of his companion. He\r\nhad even taken from his pocket a cupping apparatus, and was about to\r\nproceed to phlebotomy, when the object of his anxious solicitude\r\nsuddenly revived; but it was to dash his cap from his head, and to\r\nthrow dust on his grey hairs. The physician was at first inclined to\r\nascribe this sudden and violent emotion to the effects of insanity;\r\nand, adhering to his original purpose, began once again to handle his\r\nimplements. But Isaac soon convinced him of his error.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChild of my sorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwell shouldst thou be called Benoni,\r\ninstead of Rebecca! Why should thy death bring down my grey hairs to\r\nthe grave, till, in the bitterness of my heart, I curse God and die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rabbi, in great surprise, \xe2\x80\x9cart thou a father in\r\nIsrael, and dost thou utter words like unto these?\xe2\x80\x94I trust that the\r\nchild of thy house yet liveth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe liveth,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Isaac; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is as Daniel, who was called\r\nBeltheshazzar, even when within the den of the lions. She is captive\r\nunto those men of Belial, and they will wreak their cruelty upon her,\r\nsparing neither for her youth nor her comely favour. O! she was as a\r\ncrown of green palms to my grey locks; and she must wither in a night,\r\nlike the gourd of Jonah!\xe2\x80\x94Child of my love!\xe2\x80\x94child of my old age!\xe2\x80\x94oh,\r\nRebecca, daughter of Rachel! the darkness of the shadow of death hath\r\nencompassed thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet read the scroll,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rabbi; \xe2\x80\x9cperadventure it may be that we\r\nmay yet find out a way of deliverance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo thou read, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cfor mine eyes are as a\r\nfountain of water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe physician read, but in their native language, the following words:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Isaac, the son of Adonikam, whom the Gentiles call Isaac of York,\r\npeace and the blessing of the promise be multiplied unto thee!\xe2\x80\x94My\r\nfather, I am as one doomed to die for that which my soul knoweth\r\nnot\xe2\x80\x94even for the crime of witchcraft. My father, if a strong man can be\r\nfound to do battle for my cause with sword and spear, according to the\r\ncustom of the Nazarenes, and that within the lists of Templestowe, on\r\nthe third day from this time, peradventure our fathers\xe2\x80\x99 God will give\r\nhim strength to defend the innocent, and her who hath none to help her.\r\nBut if this may not be, let the virgins of our people mourn for me as\r\nfor one cast off, and for the hart that is stricken by the hunter, and\r\nfor the flower which is cut down by the scythe of the mower. Wherefore\r\nlook now what thou doest, and whether there be any rescue. One Nazarene\r\nwarrior might indeed bear arms in my behalf, even Wilfred, son of\r\nCedric, whom the Gentiles call Ivanhoe. But he may not yet endure the\r\nweight of his armour. Nevertheless, send the tidings unto him, my\r\nfather; for he hath favour among the strong men of his people, and as\r\nhe was our companion in the house of bondage, he may find some one to\r\ndo battle for my sake. And say unto him, even unto him, even unto\r\nWilfred, the son of Cedric, that if Rebecca live, or if Rebecca die,\r\nshe liveth or dieth wholly free of the guilt she is charged withal. And\r\nif it be the will of God that thou shalt be deprived of thy daughter,\r\ndo not thou tarry, old man, in this land of bloodshed and cruelty; but\r\nbetake thyself to Cordova, where thy brother liveth in safety, under\r\nthe shadow of the throne, even of the throne of Boabdil the Saracen;\r\nfor less cruel are the cruelties of the Moors unto the race of Jacob,\r\nthan the cruelties of the Nazarenes of England.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIsaac listened with tolerable composure while Ben Samuel read the\r\nletter, and then again resumed the gestures and exclamations of\r\nOriental sorrow, tearing his garments, besprinkling his head with dust,\r\nand ejaculating, \xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter! my daughter! flesh of my flesh, and bone\r\nof my bone!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rabbi, \xe2\x80\x9ctake courage, for this grief availeth nothing.\r\nGird up thy loins, and seek out this Wilfred, the son of Cedric. It may\r\nbe he will help thee with counsel or with strength; for the youth hath\r\nfavour in the eyes of Richard, called of the Nazarenes C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion,\r\nand the tidings that he hath returned are constant in the land. It may\r\nbe that he may obtain his letter, and his signet, commanding these men\r\nof blood, who take their name from the Temple to the dishonour thereof,\r\nthat they proceed not in their purposed wickedness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will seek him out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cfor he is a good youth, and hath\r\ncompassion for the exile of Jacob. But he cannot bear his armour, and\r\nwhat other Christian shall do battle for the oppressed of Zion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Rabbi, \xe2\x80\x9cthou speakest as one that knoweth not the\r\nGentiles. With gold shalt thou buy their valour, even as with gold thou\r\nbuyest thine own safety. Be of good courage, and do thou set forward to\r\nfind out this Wilfred of Ivanhoe. I will also up and be doing, for\r\ngreat sin it were to leave thee in thy calamity. I will hie me to the\r\ncity of York, where many warriors and strong men are assembled, and\r\ndoubt not I will find among them some one who will do battle for thy\r\ndaughter; for gold is their god, and for riches will they pawn their\r\nlives as well as their lands.\xe2\x80\x94Thou wilt fulfil, my brother, such\r\npromise as I may make unto them in thy name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAssuredly, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cand Heaven be praised that raised me\r\nup a comforter in my misery. Howbeit, grant them not their full demand\r\nat once, for thou shalt find it the quality of this accursed people\r\nthat they will ask pounds, and peradventure accept of\r\nounces\xe2\x80\x94Nevertheless, be it as thou willest, for I am distracted in this\r\nthing, and what would my gold avail me if the child of my love should\r\nperish!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the physician, \xe2\x80\x9cand may it be to thee as thy heart\r\ndesireth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey embraced accordingly, and departed on their several roads. The\r\ncrippled peasant remained for some time looking after them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese dog-Jews!\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cto take no more notice of a free\r\nguild-brother, than if I were a bond slave or a Turk, or a circumcised\r\nHebrew like themselves! They might have flung me a mancus or two,\r\nhowever. I was not obliged to bring their unhallowed scrawls, and run\r\nthe risk of being bewitched, as more folks than one told me. And what\r\ncare I for the bit of gold that the wench gave me, if I am to come to\r\nharm from the priest next Easter at confession, and be obliged to give\r\nhim twice as much to make it up with him, and be called the Jew\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nflying post all my life, as it may hap, into the bargain? I think I was\r\nbewitched in earnest when I was beside that girl!\xe2\x80\x94But it was always so\r\nwith Jew or Gentile, whosoever came near her\xe2\x80\x94none could stay when she\r\nhad an errand to go\xe2\x80\x94and still, whenever I think of her, I would give\r\nshop and tools to save her life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIX\r\n\r\n\r\nO maid, unrelenting and cold as thou art,\r\nMy bosom is proud as thine own.\r\n\r\n\r\nSEWARD\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was in the twilight of the day when her trial, if it could be called\r\nsuch, had taken place, that a low knock was heard at the door of\r\nRebecca\xe2\x80\x99s prison-chamber. It disturbed not the inmate, who was then\r\nengaged in the evening prayer recommended by her religion, and which\r\nconcluded with a hymn we have ventured thus to translate into English.\r\n\r\nWhen Israel, of the Lord beloved,\r\n    Out of the land of bondage came,\r\nHer father\xe2\x80\x99s God before her moved,\r\n    An awful guide, in smoke and flame.\r\nBy day, along the astonish\xe2\x80\x99d lands\r\n    The cloudy pillar glided slow;\r\nBy night, Arabia\xe2\x80\x99s crimson\xe2\x80\x99d sands\r\n    Return\xe2\x80\x99d the fiery column\xe2\x80\x99s glow.\r\n\r\nThere rose the choral hymn of praise,\r\n    And trump and timbrel answer\xe2\x80\x99d keen,\r\nAnd Zion\xe2\x80\x99s daughters pour\xe2\x80\x99d their lays,\r\n    With priest\xe2\x80\x99s and warrior\xe2\x80\x99s voice between.\r\nNo portents now our foes amaze,\r\n    Forsaken Israel wanders lone;\r\nOur fathers would not know THY ways,\r\n    And THOU hast left them to their own.\r\n\r\nBut, present still, though now unseen;\r\n    When brightly shines the prosperous day,\r\nBe thoughts of THEE a cloudy screen\r\n    To temper the deceitful ray.\r\nAnd oh, when stoops on Judah\xe2\x80\x99s path\r\n    In shade and storm the frequent night,\r\nBe THOU, long-suffering, slow to wrath,\r\n    A burning, and a shining light!\r\n\r\nOur harps we left by Babel\xe2\x80\x99s streams,\r\n    The tyrant\xe2\x80\x99s jest, the Gentile\xe2\x80\x99s scorn;\r\nNo censer round our altar beams,\r\n    And mute our timbrel, trump, and horn.\r\nBut THOU hast said, the blood of goat,\r\n    The flesh of rams, I will not prize;\r\nA contrite heart, and humble thought,\r\n    Are mine accepted sacrifice.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the sounds of Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s devotional hymn had died away in silence,\r\nthe low knock at the door was again renewed. \xe2\x80\x9cEnter,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cif\r\nthou art a friend; and if a foe, I have not the means of refusing thy\r\nentrance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am,\xe2\x80\x9d said Brian de Bois-Guilbert, entering the apartment, \xe2\x80\x9cfriend or\r\nfoe, Rebecca, as the event of this interview shall make me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlarmed at the sight of this man, whose licentious passion she\r\nconsidered as the root of her misfortunes, Rebecca drew backward with a\r\ncautious and alarmed, yet not a timorous demeanour, into the farthest\r\ncorner of the apartment, as if determined to retreat as far as she\r\ncould, but to stand her ground when retreat became no longer possible.\r\nShe drew herself into an attitude not of defiance, but of resolution,\r\nas one that would avoid provoking assault, yet was resolute to repel\r\nit, being offered, to the utmost of her power.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have no reason to fear me, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cor if I\r\nmust so qualify my speech, you have at least NOW no reason to fear me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear you not, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rebecca, although her short-drawn\r\nbreath seemed to belie the heroism of her accents; \xe2\x80\x9cmy trust is strong,\r\nand I fear thee not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have no cause,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Bois-Guilbert, gravely; \xe2\x80\x9cmy former\r\nfrantic attempts you have not now to dread. Within your call are\r\nguards, over whom I have no authority. They are designed to conduct you\r\nto death, Rebecca, yet would not suffer you to be insulted by any one,\r\neven by me, were my frenzy\xe2\x80\x94for frenzy it is\xe2\x80\x94to urge me so far.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay Heaven be praised!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jewess; \xe2\x80\x9cdeath is the least of my\r\napprehensions in this den of evil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cthe idea of death is easily received by the\r\ncourageous mind, when the road to it is sudden and open. A thrust with\r\na lance, a stroke with a sword, were to me little\xe2\x80\x94To you, a spring from\r\na dizzy battlement, a stroke with a sharp poniard, has no terrors,\r\ncompared with what either thinks disgrace. Mark me\xe2\x80\x94I say this\xe2\x80\x94perhaps\r\nmine own sentiments of honour are not less fantastic, Rebecca, than\r\nthine are; but we know alike how to die for them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnhappy man,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jewess; \xe2\x80\x9cand art thou condemned to expose thy\r\nlife for principles, of which thy sober judgment does not acknowledge\r\nthe solidity? Surely this is a parting with your treasure for that\r\nwhich is not bread\xe2\x80\x94but deem not so of me. Thy resolution may fluctuate\r\non the wild and changeful billows of human opinion, but mine is\r\nanchored on the Rock of Ages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence, maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9csuch discourse now avails but\r\nlittle. Thou art condemned to die not a sudden and easy death, such as\r\nmisery chooses, and despair welcomes, but a slow, wretched, protracted\r\ncourse of torture, suited to what the diabolical bigotry of these men\r\ncalls thy crime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to whom\xe2\x80\x94if such my fate\xe2\x80\x94to whom do I owe this?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csurely only to him, who, for a most selfish and brutal cause, dragged\r\nme hither, and who now, for some unknown purpose of his own, strives to\r\nexaggerate the wretched fate to which he exposed me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink not,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I have so exposed thee; I would\r\nhave bucklered thee against such danger with my own bosom, as freely as\r\never I exposed it to the shafts which had otherwise reached thy life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad thy purpose been the honourable protection of the innocent,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nRebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cI had thanked thee for thy care\xe2\x80\x94as it is, thou hast claimed\r\nmerit for it so often, that I tell thee life is worth nothing to me,\r\npreserved at the price which thou wouldst exact for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruce with thine upbraidings, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cI have my\r\nown cause of grief, and brook not that thy reproaches should add to\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is thy purpose, then, Sir Knight?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jewess; \xe2\x80\x9cspeak it\r\nbriefly.\xe2\x80\x94If thou hast aught to do, save to witness the misery thou hast\r\ncaused, let me know it; and then, if so it please you, leave me to\r\nmyself\xe2\x80\x94the step between time and eternity is short but terrible, and I\r\nhave few moments to prepare for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI perceive, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthat thou dost continue to\r\nburden me with the charge of distresses, which most fain would I have\r\nprevented.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cI would avoid reproaches\xe2\x80\x94But what is more\r\ncertain than that I owe my death to thine unbridled passion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou err\xe2\x80\x94you err,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said the Templar, hastily, \xe2\x80\x9cif you impute what I\r\ncould neither foresee nor prevent to my purpose or agency.\xe2\x80\x94Could I\r\nguess the unexpected arrival of yon dotard, whom some flashes of\r\nfrantic valour, and the praises yielded by fools to the stupid\r\nself-torments of an ascetic, have raised for the present above his own\r\nmerits, above common sense, above me, and above the hundreds of our\r\nOrder, who think and feel as men free from such silly and fantastic\r\nprejudices as are the grounds of his opinions and actions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cyou sate a judge upon me, innocent\xe2\x80\x94most\r\ninnocent\xe2\x80\x94as you knew me to be\xe2\x80\x94you concurred in my condemnation, and, if\r\nI aright understood, are yourself to appear in arms to assert my guilt,\r\nand assure my punishment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy patience, maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Templar. \xe2\x80\x9cNo race knows so well as\r\nthine own tribes how to submit to the time, and so to trim their bark\r\nas to make advantage even of an adverse wind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLamented be the hour,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cthat has taught such art to the\r\nHouse of Israel! but adversity bends the heart as fire bends the\r\nstubborn steel, and those who are no longer their own governors, and\r\nthe denizens of their own free independent state, must crouch before\r\nstrangers. It is our curse, Sir Knight, deserved, doubtless, by our own\r\nmisdeeds and those of our fathers; but you\xe2\x80\x94you who boast your freedom\r\nas your birthright, how much deeper is your disgrace when you stoop to\r\nsoothe the prejudices of others, and that against your own conviction?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour words are bitter, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, pacing the\r\napartment with impatience, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I came not hither to bandy reproaches\r\nwith you.\xe2\x80\x94Know that Bois-Guilbert yields not to created man, although\r\ncircumstances may for a time induce him to alter his plan. His will is\r\nthe mountain stream, which may indeed be turned for a little space\r\naside by the rock, but fails not to find its course to the ocean. That\r\nscroll which warned thee to demand a champion, from whom couldst thou\r\nthink it came, if not from Bois-Guilbert? In whom else couldst thou\r\nhave excited such interest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA brief respite from instant death,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich will little\r\navail me\xe2\x80\x94was this all thou couldst do for one, on whose head thou hast\r\nheaped sorrow, and whom thou hast brought near even to the verge of the\r\ntomb?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cthis was NOT all that I purposed. Had\r\nit not been for the accursed interference of yon fanatical dotard, and\r\nthe fool of Goodalricke, who, being a Templar, affects to think and\r\njudge according to the ordinary rules of humanity, the office of the\r\nChampion Defender had devolved, not on a Preceptor, but on a Companion\r\nof the Order. Then I myself\xe2\x80\x94such was my purpose\xe2\x80\x94had, on the sounding of\r\nthe trumpet, appeared in the lists as thy champion, disguised indeed in\r\nthe fashion of a roving knight, who seeks adventures to prove his\r\nshield and spear; and then, let Beaumanoir have chosen not one, but two\r\nor three of the brethren here assembled, I had not doubted to cast them\r\nout of the saddle with my single lance. Thus, Rebecca, should thine\r\ninnocence have been avouched, and to thine own gratitude would I have\r\ntrusted for the reward of my victory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cis but idle boasting\xe2\x80\x94a brag of what\r\nyou would have done had you not found it convenient to do otherwise.\r\nYou received my glove, and my champion, if a creature so desolate can\r\nfind one, must encounter your lance in the lists\xe2\x80\x94yet you would assume\r\nthe air of my friend and protector!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy friend and protector,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, gravely, \xe2\x80\x9cI will yet\r\nbe\xe2\x80\x94but mark at what risk, or rather at what certainty, of dishonour;\r\nand then blame me not if I make my stipulations, before I offer up all\r\nthat I have hitherto held dear, to save the life of a Jewish maiden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9cI understand thee not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cI will speak as freely as ever did\r\ndoting penitent to his ghostly father, when placed in the tricky\r\nconfessional.\xe2\x80\x94Rebecca, if I appear not in these lists I lose fame and\r\nrank\xe2\x80\x94lose that which is the breath of my nostrils, the esteem, I mean,\r\nin which I am held by my brethren, and the hopes I have of succeeding\r\nto that mighty authority, which is now wielded by the bigoted dotard\r\nLucas de Beaumanoir, but of which I should make a different use. Such\r\nis my certain doom, except I appear in arms against thy cause. Accursed\r\nbe he of Goodalricke, who baited this trap for me! and doubly accursed\r\nAlbert de Malvoisin, who withheld me from the resolution I had formed,\r\nof hurling back the glove at the face of the superstitious and\r\nsuperannuated fool, who listened to a charge so absurd, and against a\r\ncreature so high in mind, and so lovely in form as thou art!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what now avails rant or flattery?\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca. \xe2\x80\x9cThou hast\r\nmade thy choice between causing to be shed the blood of an innocent\r\nwoman, or of endangering thine own earthly state and earthly hopes\xe2\x80\x94What\r\navails it to reckon together?\xe2\x80\x94thy choice is made.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, in a softer tone, and drawing nearer\r\ntowards her; \xe2\x80\x9cmy choice is NOT made\xe2\x80\x94nay, mark, it is thine to make the\r\nelection. If I appear in the lists, I must maintain my name in arms;\r\nand if I do so, championed or unchampioned, thou diest by the stake and\r\nfaggot, for there lives not the knight who hath coped with me in arms\r\non equal issue, or on terms of vantage, save Richard C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion, and\r\nhis minion of Ivanhoe. Ivanhoe, as thou well knowest, is unable to bear\r\nhis corslet, and Richard is in a foreign prison. If I appear, then thou\r\ndiest, even although thy charms should instigate some hot-headed youth\r\nto enter the lists in thy defence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what avails repeating this so often?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cfor thou must learn to look at thy fate\r\non every side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, turn the tapestry,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jewess, \xe2\x80\x9cand let me see the\r\nother side.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I appear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert, \xe2\x80\x9cin the fatal lists, thou diest by a\r\nslow and cruel death, in pain such as they say is destined to the\r\nguilty hereafter. But if I appear not, then am I a degraded and\r\ndishonoured knight, accused of witchcraft and of communion with\r\ninfidels\xe2\x80\x94the illustrious name which has grown yet more so under my\r\nwearing, becomes a hissing and a reproach. I lose fame, I lose honour,\r\nI lose the prospect of such greatness as scarce emperors attain to\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nsacrifice mighty ambition, I destroy schemes built as high as the\r\nmountains with which heathens say their heaven was once nearly\r\nscaled\xe2\x80\x94and yet, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, throwing himself at her feet, \xe2\x80\x9cthis\r\ngreatness will I sacrifice, this fame will I renounce, this power will\r\nI forego, even now when it is half within my grasp, if thou wilt say,\r\nBois-Guilbert, I receive thee for my lover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink not of such foolishness, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nhasten to the Regent, the Queen Mother, and to Prince John\xe2\x80\x94they cannot,\r\nin honour to the English crown, allow of the proceedings of your Grand\r\nMaster. So shall you give me protection without sacrifice on your part,\r\nor the pretext of requiring any requital from me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith these I deal not,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, holding the train of her\r\nrobe\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit is thee only I address; and what can counterbalance thy\r\nchoice? Bethink thee, were I a fiend, yet death is a worse, and it is\r\ndeath who is my rival.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI weigh not these evils,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, afraid to provoke the wild\r\nknight, yet equally determined neither to endure his passion, nor even\r\nfeign to endure it. \xe2\x80\x9cBe a man, be a Christian! If indeed thy faith\r\nrecommends that mercy which rather your tongues than your actions\r\npretend, save me from this dreadful death, without seeking a requital\r\nwhich would change thy magnanimity into base barter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, damsel!\xe2\x80\x9d said the proud Templar, springing up, \xe2\x80\x9cthou shalt not\r\nthus impose on me\xe2\x80\x94if I renounce present fame and future ambition, I\r\nrenounce it for thy sake, and we will escape in company. Listen to me,\r\nRebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, again softening his tone; \xe2\x80\x9cEngland,\xe2\x80\x94Europe,\xe2\x80\x94is not\r\nthe world. There are spheres in which we may act, ample enough even for\r\nmy ambition. We will go to Palestine, where Conrade, Marquis of\r\nMontserrat, is my friend\xe2\x80\x94a friend free as myself from the doting\r\nscruples which fetter our free-born reason\xe2\x80\x94rather with Saladin will we\r\nleague ourselves, than endure the scorn of the bigots whom we\r\ncontemn.\xe2\x80\x94I will form new paths to greatness,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, again\r\ntraversing the room with hasty strides\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cEurope shall hear the loud step\r\nof him she has driven from her sons!\xe2\x80\x94Not the millions whom her\r\ncrusaders send to slaughter, can do so much to defend Palestine\xe2\x80\x94not the\r\nsabres of the thousands and ten thousands of Saracens can hew their way\r\nso deep into that land for which nations are striving, as the strength\r\nand policy of me and those brethren, who, in despite of yonder old\r\nbigot, will adhere to me in good and evil. Thou shalt be a queen,\r\nRebecca\xe2\x80\x94on Mount Carmel shall we pitch the throne which my valour will\r\ngain for you, and I will exchange my long-desired batoon for a\r\nsceptre!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA dream,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca; \xe2\x80\x9can empty vision of the night, which, were it\r\na waking reality, affects me not. Enough, that the power which thou\r\nmightest acquire, I will never share; nor hold I so light of country or\r\nreligious faith, as to esteem him who is willing to barter these ties,\r\nand cast away the bonds of the Order of which he is a sworn member, in\r\norder to gratify an unruly passion for the daughter of another\r\npeople.\xe2\x80\x94Put not a price on my deliverance, Sir Knight\xe2\x80\x94sell not a deed\r\nof generosity\xe2\x80\x94protect the oppressed for the sake of charity, and not\r\nfor a selfish advantage\xe2\x80\x94Go to the throne of England; Richard will\r\nlisten to my appeal from these cruel men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever, Rebecca!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, fiercely. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I renounce my Order,\r\nfor thee alone will I renounce it\xe2\x80\x94Ambition shall remain mine, if thou\r\nrefuse my love; I will not be fooled on all hands.\xe2\x80\x94Stoop my crest to\r\nRichard?\xe2\x80\x94ask a boon of that heart of pride?\xe2\x80\x94Never, Rebecca, will I\r\nplace the Order of the Temple at his feet in my person. I may forsake\r\nthe Order, I never will degrade or betray it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow God be gracious to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the succour of man is\r\nwell-nigh hopeless!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cfor, proud as thou art, thou hast in\r\nme found thy match. If I enter the lists with my spear in rest, think\r\nnot any human consideration shall prevent my putting forth my strength;\r\nand think then upon thine own fate\xe2\x80\x94to die the dreadful death of the\r\nworst of criminals\xe2\x80\x94to be consumed upon a blazing pile\xe2\x80\x94dispersed to the\r\nelements of which our strange forms are so mystically composed\xe2\x80\x94not a\r\nrelic left of that graceful frame, from which we could say this lived\r\nand moved!\xe2\x80\x94Rebecca, it is not in woman to sustain this prospect\xe2\x80\x94thou\r\nwilt yield to my suit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBois-Guilbert,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Jewess, \xe2\x80\x9cthou knowest not the heart of\r\nwoman, or hast only conversed with those who are lost to her best\r\nfeelings. I tell thee, proud Templar, that not in thy fiercest battles\r\nhast thou displayed more of thy vaunted courage, than has been shown by\r\nwoman when called upon to suffer by affection or duty. I am myself a\r\nwoman, tenderly nurtured, naturally fearful of danger, and impatient of\r\npain\xe2\x80\x94yet, when we enter those fatal lists, thou to fight and I to\r\nsuffer, I feel the strong assurance within me, that my courage shall\r\nmount higher than thine. Farewell\xe2\x80\x94I waste no more words on thee; the\r\ntime that remains on earth to the daughter of Jacob must be otherwise\r\nspent\xe2\x80\x94she must seek the Comforter, who may hide his face from his\r\npeople, but who ever opens his ear to the cry of those who seek him in\r\nsincerity and in truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe part then thus?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, after a short pause; \xe2\x80\x9cwould to\r\nHeaven that we had never met, or that thou hadst been noble in birth\r\nand Christian in faith!\xe2\x80\x94Nay, by Heaven! when I gaze on thee, and think\r\nwhen and how we are next to meet, I could even wish myself one of thine\r\nown degraded nation; my hand conversant with ingots and shekels,\r\ninstead of spear and shield; my head bent down before each petty noble,\r\nand my look only terrible to the shivering and bankrupt debtor\xe2\x80\x94this\r\ncould I wish, Rebecca, to be near to thee in life, and to escape the\r\nfearful share I must have in thy death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast spoken the Jew,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cas the persecution of such\r\nas thou art has made him. Heaven in ire has driven him from his\r\ncountry, but industry has opened to him the only road to power and to\r\ninfluence, which oppression has left unbarred. Read the ancient history\r\nof the people of God, and tell me if those, by whom Jehovah wrought\r\nsuch marvels among the nations, were then a people of misers and of\r\nusurers!\xe2\x80\x94And know, proud knight, we number names amongst us to which\r\nyour boasted northern nobility is as the gourd compared with the\r\ncedar\xe2\x80\x94names that ascend far back to those high times when the Divine\r\nPresence shook the mercy-seat between the cherubim, and which derive\r\ntheir splendour from no earthly prince, but from the awful Voice, which\r\nbade their fathers be nearest of the congregation to the Vision\xe2\x80\x94Such\r\nwere the princes of the House of Jacob.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRebecca\xe2\x80\x99s colour rose as she boasted the ancient glories of her race,\r\nbut faded as she added, with at sigh, \xe2\x80\x9cSuch WERE the princes of Judah,\r\nnow such no more!\xe2\x80\x94They are trampled down like the shorn grass, and\r\nmixed with the mire of the ways. Yet are there those among them who\r\nshame not such high descent, and of such shall be the daughter of Isaac\r\nthe son of Adonikam! Farewell!\xe2\x80\x94I envy not thy blood-won honours\xe2\x80\x94I envy\r\nnot thy barbarous descent from northern heathens\xe2\x80\x94I envy thee not thy\r\nfaith, which is ever in thy mouth, but never in thy heart nor in thy\r\npractice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is a spell on me, by Heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert. \xe2\x80\x9cI almost\r\nthink yon besotted skeleton spoke truth, and that the reluctance with\r\nwhich I part from thee hath something in it more than is natural.\xe2\x80\x94Fair\r\ncreature!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, approaching near her, but with great respect,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cso\r\nyoung, so beautiful, so fearless of death! and yet doomed to die, and\r\nwith infamy and agony. Who would not weep for thee?\xe2\x80\x94The tear, that has\r\nbeen a stranger to these eyelids for twenty years, moistens them as I\r\ngaze on thee. But it must be\xe2\x80\x94nothing may now save thy life. Thou and I\r\nare but the blind instruments of some irresistible fatality, that\r\nhurries us along, like goodly vessels driving before the storm, which\r\nare dashed against each other, and so perish. Forgive me, then, and let\r\nus part, at least, as friends part. I have assailed thy resolution in\r\nvain, and mine own is fixed as the adamantine decrees of fate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThus,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cdo men throw on fate the issue of their own wild\r\npassions. But I do forgive thee, Bois-Guilbert, though the author of my\r\nearly death. There are noble things which cross over thy powerful mind;\r\nbut it is the garden of the sluggard, and the weeds have rushed up, and\r\nconspired to choke the fair and wholesome blossom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cI am, Rebecca, as thou hast spoken me,\r\nuntaught, untamed\xe2\x80\x94and proud, that, amidst a shoal of empty fools and\r\ncrafty bigots, I have retained the preeminent fortitude that places me\r\nabove them. I have been a child of battle from my youth upward, high in\r\nmy views, steady and inflexible in pursuing them. Such must I\r\nremain\xe2\x80\x94proud, inflexible, and unchanging; and of this the world shall\r\nhave proof.\xe2\x80\x94But thou forgivest me, Rebecca?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs freely as ever victim forgave her executioner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, and left the apartment.\r\n\r\nThe Preceptor Albert waited impatiently in an adjacent chamber the\r\nreturn of Bois-Guilbert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast tarried long,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cI have been as if stretched on\r\nred-hot iron with very impatience. What if the Grand Master, or his spy\r\nConrade, had come hither? I had paid dear for my complaisance.\xe2\x80\x94But what\r\nails thee, brother?\xe2\x80\x94Thy step totters, thy brow is as black as night.\r\nArt thou well, Bois-Guilbert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cas well as the wretch who is doomed to die\r\nwithin an hour.\xe2\x80\x94Nay, by the rood, not half so well\xe2\x80\x94for there be those\r\nin such state, who can lay down life like a cast-off garment. By\r\nHeaven, Malvoisin, yonder girl hath well-nigh unmanned me. I am half\r\nresolved to go to the Grand Master, abjure the Order to his very teeth,\r\nand refuse to act the brutality which his tyranny has imposed on me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art mad,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Malvoisin; \xe2\x80\x9cthou mayst thus indeed utterly\r\nruin thyself, but canst not even find a chance thereby to save the life\r\nof this Jewess, which seems so precious in thine eyes. Beaumanoir will\r\nname another of the Order to defend his judgment in thy place, and the\r\naccused will as assuredly perish as if thou hadst taken the duty\r\nimposed on thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tis false\xe2\x80\x94I will myself take arms in her behalf,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the\r\nTemplar, haughtily; \xe2\x80\x9cand, should I do so, I think, Malvoisin, that thou\r\nknowest not one of the Order, who will keep his saddle before the point\r\nof my lance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but thou forgettest,\xe2\x80\x9d said the wily adviser, \xe2\x80\x9cthou wilt have\r\nneither leisure nor opportunity to execute this mad project. Go to\r\nLucas Beaumanoir, and say thou hast renounced thy vow of obedience, and\r\nsee how long the despotic old man will leave thee in personal freedom.\r\nThe words shall scarce have left thy lips, ere thou wilt either be an\r\nhundred feet under ground, in the dungeon of the Preceptory, to abide\r\ntrial as a recreant knight; or, if his opinion holds concerning thy\r\npossession, thou wilt be enjoying straw, darkness, and chains, in some\r\ndistant convent cell, stunned with exorcisms, and drenched with holy\r\nwater, to expel the foul fiend which hath obtained dominion over thee.\r\nThou must to the lists, Brian, or thou art a lost and dishonoured man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will break forth and fly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cfly to some distant\r\nland, to which folly and fanaticism have not yet found their way. No\r\ndrop of the blood of this most excellent creature shall be spilled by\r\nmy sanction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou canst not fly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor; \xe2\x80\x9cthy ravings have excited\r\nsuspicion, and thou wilt not be permitted to leave the Preceptory. Go\r\nand make the essay\xe2\x80\x94present thyself before the gate, and command the\r\nbridge to be lowered, and mark what answer thou shalt receive.\xe2\x80\x94Thou are\r\nsurprised and offended; but is it not the better for thee? Wert thou to\r\nfly, what would ensue but the reversal of thy arms, the dishonour of\r\nthine ancestry, the degradation of thy rank?\xe2\x80\x94Think on it. Where shall\r\nthine old companions in arms hide their heads when Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, the best lance of the Templars, is proclaimed recreant,\r\namid the hisses of the assembled people? What grief will be at the\r\nCourt of France! With what joy will the haughty Richard hear the news,\r\nthat the knight that set him hard in Palestine, and well-nigh darkened\r\nhis renown, has lost fame and honour for a Jewish girl, whom he could\r\nnot even save by so costly a sacrifice!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMalvoisin,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cI thank thee\xe2\x80\x94thou hast touched the\r\nstring at which my heart most readily thrills!\xe2\x80\x94Come of it what may,\r\nrecreant shall never be added to the name of Bois-Guilbert. Would to\r\nGod, Richard, or any of his vaunting minions of England, would appear\r\nin these lists! But they will be empty\xe2\x80\x94no one will risk to break a\r\nlance for the innocent, the forlorn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe better for thee, if it prove so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Preceptor; \xe2\x80\x9cif no\r\nchampion appears, it is not by thy means that this unlucky damsel shall\r\ndie, but by the doom of the Grand Master, with whom rests all the\r\nblame, and who will count that blame for praise and commendation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert; \xe2\x80\x9cif no champion appears, I am but a part of\r\nthe pageant, sitting indeed on horseback in the lists, but having no\r\npart in what is to follow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone whatever,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin; \xe2\x80\x9cno more than the armed image of Saint\r\nGeorge when it makes part of a procession.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will resume my resolution,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the haughty Templar. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\r\nhas despised me\xe2\x80\x94repulsed me\xe2\x80\x94reviled me\xe2\x80\x94And wherefore should I offer up\r\nfor her whatever of estimation I have in the opinion of others?\r\nMalvoisin, I will appear in the lists.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe left the apartment hastily as he uttered these words, and the\r\nPreceptor followed, to watch and confirm him in his resolution; for in\r\nBois-Guilbert\xe2\x80\x99s fame he had himself a strong interest, expecting much\r\nadvantage from his being one day at the head of the Order, not to\r\nmention the preferment of which Mont-Fitchet had given him hopes, on\r\ncondition he would forward the condemnation of the unfortunate Rebecca.\r\nYet although, in combating his friend\xe2\x80\x99s better feelings, he possessed\r\nall the advantage which a wily, composed, selfish disposition has over\r\na man agitated by strong and contending passions, it required all\r\nMalvoisin\xe2\x80\x99s art to keep Bois-Guilbert steady to the purpose he had\r\nprevailed on him to adopt. He was obliged to watch him closely to\r\nprevent his resuming his purpose of flight, to intercept his\r\ncommunication with the Grand Master, lest he should come to an open\r\nrupture with his Superior, and to renew, from time to time, the various\r\narguments by which he endeavoured to show, that, in appearing as\r\nchampion on this occasion, Bois-Guilbert, without either accelerating\r\nor ensuring the fate of Rebecca, would follow the only course by which\r\nhe could save himself from degradation and disgrace.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XL\r\n\r\n\r\nShadows avaunt!\xe2\x80\x94Richard\xe2\x80\x99s himself again.\r\n\r\n\r\nRICHARD III\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the Black Knight\xe2\x80\x94for it becomes necessary to resume the train of\r\nhis adventures\xe2\x80\x94left the Trysting-tree of the generous Outlaw, he held\r\nhis way straight to a neighbouring religious house, of small extent and\r\nrevenue, called the Priory of Saint Botolph, to which the wounded\r\nIvanhoe had been removed when the castle was taken, under the guidance\r\nof the faithful Gurth, and the magnanimous Wamba. It is unnecessary at\r\npresent to mention what took place in the interim betwixt Wilfred and\r\nhis deliverer; suffice it to say, that after long and grave\r\ncommunication, messengers were dispatched by the Prior in several\r\ndirections, and that on the succeeding morning the Black Knight was\r\nabout to set forth on his journey, accompanied by the jester Wamba, who\r\nattended as his guide.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will meet,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cat Coningsburgh, the castle of the\r\ndeceased Athelstane, since there thy father Cedric holds the funeral\r\nfeast for his noble relation. I would see your Saxon kindred together,\r\nSir Wilfred, and become better acquainted with them than heretofore.\r\nThou also wilt meet me; and it shall be my task to reconcile thee to\r\nthy father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he took an affectionate farewell of Ivanhoe, who expressed\r\nan anxious desire to attend upon his deliverer. But the Black Knight\r\nwould not listen to the proposal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRest this day; thou wilt have scarce strength enough to travel on the\r\nnext. I will have no guide with me but honest Wamba, who can play\r\npriest or fool as I shall be most in the humour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cwill attend you with all my heart. I would fain\r\nsee the feasting at the funeral of Athelstane; for, if it be not full\r\nand frequent, he will rise from the dead to rebuke cook, sewer, and\r\ncupbearer; and that were a sight worth seeing. Always, Sir Knight, I\r\nwill trust your valour with making my excuse to my master Cedric, in\r\ncase mine own wit should fail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how should my poor valour succeed, Sir Jester, when thy light wit\r\nhalts?\xe2\x80\x94resolve me that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWit, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cmay do much. He is a quick,\r\napprehensive knave, who sees his neighbours blind side, and knows how\r\nto keep the lee-gage when his passions are blowing high. But valour is\r\na sturdy fellow, that makes all split. He rows against both wind and\r\ntide, and makes way notwithstanding; and, therefore, good Sir Knight,\r\nwhile I take advantage of the fair weather in our noble master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntemper, I will expect you to bestir yourself when it grows rough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Knight of the Fetterlock, since it is your pleasure so to be\r\ndistinguished,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cI fear me you have chosen a talkative\r\nand a troublesome fool to be your guide. But he knows every path and\r\nalley in the woods as well as e\xe2\x80\x99er a hunter who frequents them; and the\r\npoor knave, as thou hast partly seen, is as faithful as steel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9can he have the gift of showing my road, I\r\nshall not grumble with him that he desires to make it pleasant.\xe2\x80\x94Fare\r\nthee well, kind Wilfred\xe2\x80\x94I charge thee not to attempt to travel till\r\nto-morrow at earliest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he extended his hand to Ivanhoe, who pressed it to his lips,\r\ntook leave of the Prior, mounted his horse, and departed, with Wamba\r\nfor his companion. Ivanhoe followed them with his eyes, until they were\r\nlost in the shades of the surrounding forest, and then returned into\r\nthe convent.\r\n\r\nBut shortly after matin-song, he requested to see the Prior. The old\r\nman came in haste, and enquired anxiously after the state of his\r\nhealth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is better,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthan my fondest hope could have anticipated;\r\neither my wound has been slighter than the effusion of blood led me to\r\nsuppose, or this balsam hath wrought a wonderful cure upon it. I feel\r\nalready as if I could bear my corslet; and so much the better, for\r\nthoughts pass in my mind which render me unwilling to remain here\r\nlonger in inactivity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, the saints forbid,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the son of the Saxon\r\nCedric should leave our convent ere his wounds were healed! It were\r\nshame to our profession were we to suffer it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor would I desire to leave your hospitable roof, venerable father,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cdid I not feel myself able to endure the journey, and\r\ncompelled to undertake it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what can have urged you to so sudden a departure?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you never, holy father,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cfelt an\r\napprehension of approaching evil, for which you in vain attempted to\r\nassign a cause?\xe2\x80\x94Have you never found your mind darkened, like the sunny\r\nlandscape, by the sudden cloud, which augurs a coming tempest?\xe2\x80\x94And\r\nthinkest thou not that such impulses are deserving of attention, as\r\nbeing the hints of our guardian spirits, that danger is impending?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI may not deny,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, crossing himself, \xe2\x80\x9cthat such things\r\nhave been, and have been of Heaven; but then such communications have\r\nhad a visibly useful scope and tendency. But thou, wounded as thou art,\r\nwhat avails it thou shouldst follow the steps of him whom thou couldst\r\nnot aid, were he to be assaulted?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrior,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cthou dost mistake\xe2\x80\x94I am stout enough to exchange\r\nbuffets with any who will challenge me to such a traffic\xe2\x80\x94But were it\r\notherwise, may I not aid him were he in danger, by other means than by\r\nforce of arms? It is but too well known that the Saxons love not the\r\nNorman race, and who knows what may be the issue, if he break in upon\r\nthem when their hearts are irritated by the death of Athelstane, and\r\ntheir heads heated by the carousal in which they will indulge\r\nthemselves? I hold his entrance among them at such a moment most\r\nperilous, and I am resolved to share or avert the danger; which, that I\r\nmay the better do, I would crave of thee the use of some palfrey whose\r\npace may be softer than that of my \xe2\x80\x98destrier\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d 56\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely,\xe2\x80\x9d said the worthy churchman; \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall have mine own ambling\r\njennet, and I would it ambled as easy for your sake as that of the\r\nAbbot of Saint Albans. Yet this will I say for Malkin, for so I call\r\nher, that unless you were to borrow a ride on the juggler\xe2\x80\x99s steed that\r\npaces a hornpipe amongst the eggs, you could not go a journey on a\r\ncreature so gentle and smooth-paced. I have composed many a homily on\r\nher back, to the edification of my brethren of the convent, and many\r\npoor Christian souls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pray you, reverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9clet Malkin be got ready\r\ninstantly, and bid Gurth attend me with mine arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but fair sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Prior, \xe2\x80\x9cI pray you to remember that\r\nMalkin hath as little skill in arms as her master, and that I warrant\r\nnot her enduring the sight or weight of your full panoply. O, Malkin, I\r\npromise you, is a beast of judgment, and will contend against any undue\r\nweight\xe2\x80\x94I did but borrow the \xe2\x80\x98Fructus Temporum\xe2\x80\x99 from the priest of Saint\r\nBees, and I promise you she would not stir from the gate until I had\r\nexchanged the huge volume for my little breviary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust me, holy father,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cI will not distress her with\r\ntoo much weight; and if she calls a combat with me, it is odds but she\r\nhas the worst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis reply was made while Gurth was buckling on the Knight\xe2\x80\x99s heels a\r\npair of large gilded spurs, capable of convincing any restive horse\r\nthat his best safety lay in being conformable to the will of his rider.\r\n\r\nThe deep and sharp rowels with which Ivanhoe\xe2\x80\x99s heels were now armed,\r\nbegan to make the worthy Prior repent of his courtesy, and\r\nejaculate,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but fair sir, now I bethink me, my Malkin abideth not\r\nthe spur\xe2\x80\x94Better it were that you tarry for the mare of our manciple\r\ndown at the Grange, which may be had in little more than an hour, and\r\ncannot but be tractable, in respect that she draweth much of our winter\r\nfire-wood, and eateth no corn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you, reverend father, but will abide by your first offer, as I\r\nsee Malkin is already led forth to the gate. Gurth shall carry mine\r\narmour; and for the rest, rely on it, that as I will not overload\r\nMalkin\xe2\x80\x99s back, she shall not overcome my patience. And now, farewell!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvanhoe now descended the stairs more hastily and easily than his wound\r\npromised, and threw himself upon the jennet, eager to escape the\r\nimportunity of the Prior, who stuck as closely to his side as his age\r\nand fatness would permit, now singing the praises of Malkin, now\r\nrecommending caution to the Knight in managing her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is at the most dangerous period for maidens as well as mares,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the old man, laughing at his own jest, \xe2\x80\x9cbeing barely in her\r\nfifteenth year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIvanhoe, who had other web to weave than to stand canvassing a\r\npalfrey\xe2\x80\x99s paces with its owner, lent but a deaf ear to the Prior\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngrave advices and facetious jests, and having leapt on his mare, and\r\ncommanded his squire (for such Gurth now called himself) to keep close\r\nby his side, he followed the track of the Black Knight into the forest,\r\nwhile the Prior stood at the gate of the convent looking after him, and\r\nejaculating,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSaint Mary! how prompt and fiery be these men of war! I\r\nwould I had not trusted Malkin to his keeping, for, crippled as I am\r\nwith the cold rheum, I am undone if aught but good befalls her. And\r\nyet,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, recollecting himself, \xe2\x80\x9cas I would not spare my own old\r\nand disabled limbs in the good cause of Old England, so Malkin must\r\ne\xe2\x80\x99en run her hazard on the same venture; and it may be they will think\r\nour poor house worthy of some munificent guerdon\xe2\x80\x94or, it may be, they\r\nwill send the old Prior a pacing nag. And if they do none of these, as\r\ngreat men will forget little men\xe2\x80\x99s service, truly I shall hold me well\r\nrepaid in having done that which is right. And it is now well-nigh the\r\nfitting time to summon the brethren to breakfast in the refectory\xe2\x80\x94Ah! I\r\ndoubt they obey that call more cheerily than the bells for primes and\r\nmatins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo the Prior of Saint Botolph\xe2\x80\x99s hobbled back again into the refectory,\r\nto preside over the stockfish and ale, which was just serving out for\r\nthe friars\xe2\x80\x99 breakfast. Busy and important, he sat him down at the\r\ntable, and many a dark word he threw out, of benefits to be expected to\r\nthe convent, and high deeds of service done by himself, which, at\r\nanother season, would have attracted observation. But as the stockfish\r\nwas highly salted, and the ale reasonably powerful, the jaws of the\r\nbrethren were too anxiously employed to admit of their making much use\r\nof their ears; nor do we read of any of the fraternity, who was tempted\r\nto speculate upon the mysterious hints of their Superior, except Father\r\nDiggory, who was severely afflicted by the toothache, so that he could\r\nonly eat on one side of his jaws.\r\n\r\nIn the meantime, the Black Champion and his guide were pacing at their\r\nleisure through the recesses of the forest; the good Knight whiles\r\nhumming to himself the lay of some enamoured troubadour, sometimes\r\nencouraging by questions the prating disposition of his attendant, so\r\nthat their dialogue formed a whimsical mixture of song and jest, of\r\nwhich we would fain give our readers some idea. You are then to imagine\r\nthis Knight, such as we have already described him, strong of person,\r\ntall, broad-shouldered, and large of bone, mounted on his mighty black\r\ncharger, which seemed made on purpose to bear his weight, so easily he\r\npaced forward under it, having the visor of his helmet raised, in order\r\nto admit freedom of breath, yet keeping the beaver, or under part,\r\nclosed, so that his features could be but imperfectly distinguished.\r\nBut his ruddy embrowned cheek-bones could be plainly seen, and the\r\nlarge and bright blue eyes, that flashed from under the dark shade of\r\nthe raised visor; and the whole gesture and look of the champion\r\nexpressed careless gaiety and fearless confidence\xe2\x80\x94a mind which was\r\nunapt to apprehend danger, and prompt to defy it when most imminent\xe2\x80\x94yet\r\nwith whom danger was a familiar thought, as with one whose trade was\r\nwar and adventure.\r\n\r\nThe Jester wore his usual fantastic habit, but late accidents had led\r\nhim to adopt a good cutting falchion, instead of his wooden sword, with\r\na targe to match it; of both which weapons he had, notwithstanding his\r\nprofession, shown himself a skilful master during the storming of\r\nTorquilstone. Indeed, the infirmity of Wamba\xe2\x80\x99s brain consisted chiefly\r\nin a kind of impatient irritability, which suffered him not long to\r\nremain quiet in any posture, or adhere to any certain train of ideas,\r\nalthough he was for a few minutes alert enough in performing any\r\nimmediate task, or in apprehending any immediate topic. On horseback,\r\ntherefore, he was perpetually swinging himself backwards and forwards,\r\nnow on the horse\xe2\x80\x99s ears, then anon on the very rump of the animal,\xe2\x80\x94now\r\nhanging both his legs on one side, and now sitting with his face to the\r\ntail, moping, mowing, and making a thousand apish gestures, until his\r\npalfrey took his freaks so much to heart, as fairly to lay him at his\r\nlength on the green grass\xe2\x80\x94an incident which greatly amused the Knight,\r\nbut compelled his companion to ride more steadily thereafter.\r\n\r\nAt the point of their journey at which we take them up, this joyous\r\npair were engaged in singing a virelai, as it was called, in which the\r\nclown bore a mellow burden, to the better instructed Knight of the\r\nFetterlock. And thus run the ditty:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nAnna-Marie, love, up is the sun,\r\nAnna-Marie, love, morn is begun,\r\nMists are dispersing, love, birds singing free,\r\nUp in the morning, love, Anna-Marie.\r\nAnna-Marie, love, up in the morn,\r\nThe hunter is winding blithe sounds on his horn,\r\nThe echo rings merry from rock and from tree,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Tis time to arouse thee, love, Anna-Marie.\r\n\r\n\r\nWamba.\r\n\r\nO Tybalt, love, Tybalt, awake me not yet,\r\nAround my soft pillow while softer dreams flit,\r\nFor what are the joys that in waking we prove,\r\nCompared with these visions, O, Tybalt, my love?\r\nLet the birds to the rise of the mist carol shrill,\r\nLet the hunter blow out his loud horn on the hill,\r\nSofter sounds, softer pleasures, in slumber I prove,\xe2\x80\x94\r\nBut think not I dreamt of thee, Tybalt, my love.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA dainty song,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, when they had finished their carol, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\nswear by my bauble, a pretty moral!\xe2\x80\x94I used to sing it with Gurth, once\r\nmy playfellow, and now, by the grace of God and his master, no less\r\nthan a freemen; and we once came by the cudgel for being so entranced\r\nby the melody, that we lay in bed two hours after sunrise, singing the\r\nditty betwixt sleeping and waking\xe2\x80\x94my bones ache at thinking of the tune\r\never since. Nevertheless, I have played the part of Anna-Marie, to\r\nplease you, fair sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jester next struck into another carol, a sort of comic ditty, to\r\nwhich the Knight, catching up the tune, replied in the like manner.\r\n\r\nKnight and Wamba.\r\n\r\nThere came three merry men from south, west, and north,\r\n    Ever more sing the roundelay;\r\nTo win the Widow of Wycombe forth,\r\n    And where was the widow might say them nay?\r\n\r\nThe first was a knight, and from Tynedale he came,\r\n    Ever more sing the roundelay;\r\nAnd his fathers, God save us, were men of great fame,\r\n    And where was the widow might say him nay?\r\n\r\nOf his father the laird, of his uncle the squire,\r\n    He boasted in rhyme and in roundelay;\r\nShe bade him go bask by his sea-coal fire,\r\n    For she was the widow would say him nay.\r\n\r\n\r\nWamba.\r\n\r\nThe next that came forth, swore by blood and by nails,\r\n    Merrily sing the roundelay;\r\nHur\xe2\x80\x99s a gentleman, God wot, and hur\xe2\x80\x99s lineage was of Wales,\r\n    And where was the widow might say him nay?\r\n\r\nSir David ap Morgan ap Griffith ap Hugh\r\n    Ap Tudor ap Rhice, quoth his roundelay\r\nShe said that one widow for so many was too few,\r\n    And she bade the Welshman wend his way.\r\n\r\nBut then next came a yeoman, a yeoman of Kent,\r\n    Jollily singing his roundelay;\r\nHe spoke to the widow of living and rent,\r\n    And where was the widow could say him nay?\r\n\r\n\r\nBoth.\r\n\r\nSo the knight and the squire were both left in the mire,\r\n    There for to sing their roundelay;\r\nFor a yeoman of Kent, with his yearly rent,\r\n    There never was a widow could say him nay.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would, Wamba,\xe2\x80\x9d said the knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthat our host of the Trysting-tree,\r\nor the jolly Friar, his chaplain, heard this thy ditty in praise of our\r\nbluff yeoman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo would not I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbut for the horn that hangs at your\r\nbaldric.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthis is a pledge of Locksley\xe2\x80\x99s goodwill, though\r\nI am not like to need it. Three mots on this bugle will, I am assured,\r\nbring round, at our need, a jolly band of yonder honest yeomen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would say, Heaven forefend,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, \xe2\x80\x9cwere it not that that\r\nfair gift is a pledge they would let us pass peaceably.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what meanest thou?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight; \xe2\x80\x9cthinkest thou that but for\r\nthis pledge of fellowship they would assault us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, for me I say nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cfor green trees have ears as\r\nwell as stone walls. But canst thou construe me this, Sir Knight\xe2\x80\x94When\r\nis thy wine-pitcher and thy purse better empty than full?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, never, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou never deservest to have a full one in thy hand, for so simple an\r\nanswer! Thou hadst best empty thy pitcher ere thou pass it to a Saxon,\r\nand leave thy money at home ere thou walk in the greenwood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou hold our friends for robbers, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight of the\r\nFetterlock.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou hear me not say so, fair sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cit may relieve a man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsteed to take of his mail when he hath a long journey to make; and,\r\ncertes, it may do good to the rider\xe2\x80\x99s soul to ease him of that which is\r\nthe root of evil; therefore will I give no hard names to those who do\r\nsuch services. Only I would wish my mail at home, and my purse in my\r\nchamber, when I meet with these good fellows, because it might save\r\nthem some trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWE are bound to pray for them, my friend, notwithstanding the fair\r\ncharacter thou dost afford them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray for them with all my heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cbut in the town, not in\r\nthe greenwood, like the Abbot of Saint Bees, whom they caused to say\r\nmass with an old hollow oak-tree for his stall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay as thou list, Wamba,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthese yeomen did thy\r\nmaster Cedric yeomanly service at Torquilstone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, truly,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that was in the fashion of their\r\ntrade with Heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTheir trade, Wamba! how mean you by that?\xe2\x80\x9d replied his companion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarry, thus,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester. \xe2\x80\x9cThey make up a balanced account with\r\nHeaven, as our old cellarer used to call his ciphering, as fair as\r\nIsaac the Jew keeps with his debtors, and, like him, give out a very\r\nlittle, and take large credit for doing so; reckoning, doubtless, on\r\ntheir own behalf the seven-fold usury which the blessed text hath\r\npromised to charitable loans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me an example of your meaning, Wamba,\xe2\x80\x94I know nothing of ciphers\r\nor rates of usage,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9can your valour be so dull, you will please to learn\r\nthat those honest fellows balance a good deed with one not quite so\r\nlaudable; as a crown given to a begging friar with an hundred byzants\r\ntaken from a fat abbot, or a wench kissed in the greenwood with the\r\nrelief of a poor widow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich of these was the good deed, which was the felony?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted\r\nthe Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA good gibe! a good gibe!\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9ckeeping witty company\r\nsharpeneth the apprehension. You said nothing so well, Sir Knight, I\r\nwill be sworn, when you held drunken vespers with the bluff Hermit.\xe2\x80\x94But\r\nto go on. The merry-men of the forest set off the building of a cottage\r\nwith the burning of a castle,\xe2\x80\x94the thatching of a choir against the\r\nrobbing of a church,\xe2\x80\x94the setting free a poor prisoner against the\r\nmurder of a proud sheriff; or, to come nearer to our point, the\r\ndeliverance of a Saxon franklin against the burning alive of a Norman\r\nbaron. Gentle thieves they are, in short, and courteous robbers; but it\r\nis ever the luckiest to meet with them when they are at the worst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so, Wamba?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, then they have some compunction, and are for making up matters\r\nwith Heaven. But when they have struck an even balance, Heaven help\r\nthem with whom they next open the account! The travellers who first met\r\nthem after their good service at Torquilstone would have a woeful\r\nflaying.\xe2\x80\x94And yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, coming close up to the Knight\xe2\x80\x99s side,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthere be companions who are far more dangerous for travellers to meet\r\nthan yonder outlaws.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who may they be, for you have neither bears nor wolves, I trow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarry, sir, but we have Malvoisin\xe2\x80\x99s men-at-arms,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cand let\r\nme tell you, that, in time of civil war, a halfscore of these is worth\r\na band of wolves at any time. They are now expecting their harvest, and\r\nare reinforced with the soldiers that escaped from Torquilstone. So\r\nthat, should we meet with a band of them, we are like to pay for our\r\nfeats of arms.\xe2\x80\x94Now, I pray you, Sir Knight, what would you do if we met\r\ntwo of them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPin the villains to the earth with my lance, Wamba, if they offered us\r\nany impediment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what if there were four of them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey should drink of the same cup,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat if six,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cand we as we now are, barely two\xe2\x80\x94would\r\nyou not remember Locksley\xe2\x80\x99s horn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! sound for aid,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cagainst a score of such\r\n\xe2\x80\x98rascaille\xe2\x80\x99 as these, whom one good knight could drive before him, as\r\nthe wind drives the withered leaves?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cI will pray you for a close sight of that\r\nsame horn that hath so powerful a breath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Knight undid the clasp of the baldric, and indulged his\r\nfellow-traveller, who immediately hung the bugle round his own neck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTra-lira-la,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, whistling the notes; \xe2\x80\x9cnay, I know my gamut as\r\nwell as another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow mean you, knave?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight; \xe2\x80\x9crestore me the bugle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cContent you, Sir Knight, it is in safe keeping. When Valour and Folly\r\ntravel, Folly should bear the horn, because she can blow the best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay but, rogue,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cthis exceedeth thy\r\nlicense\xe2\x80\x94Beware ye tamper not with my patience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUrge me not with violence, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jester, keeping at a\r\ndistance from the impatient champion, \xe2\x80\x9cor Folly will show a clean pair\r\nof heels, and leave Valour to find out his way through the wood as best\r\nhe may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, thou hast hit me there,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight; \xe2\x80\x9cand, sooth to say, I\r\nhave little time to jangle with thee. Keep the horn an thou wilt, but\r\nlet us proceed on our journey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will not harm me, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell thee no, thou knave!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but pledge me your knightly word for it,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Wamba, as he\r\napproached with great caution.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy knightly word I pledge; only come on with thy foolish self.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, then, Valour and Folly are once more boon companions,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nJester, coming up frankly to the Knight\xe2\x80\x99s side; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, in truth, I love\r\nnot such buffets as that you bestowed on the burly Friar, when his\r\nholiness rolled on the green like a king of the nine-pins. And now that\r\nFolly wears the horn, let Valour rouse himself, and shake his mane;\r\nfor, if I mistake not, there are company in yonder brake that are on\r\nthe look-out for us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat makes thee judge so?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I have twice or thrice noticed the glance of a motion from\r\namongst the green leaves. Had they been honest men, they had kept the\r\npath. But yonder thicket is a choice chapel for the Clerks of Saint\r\nNicholas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, closing his visor, \xe2\x80\x9cI think thou be\xe2\x80\x99st\r\nin the right on\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd in good time did he close it, for three arrows, flew at the same\r\ninstant from the suspected spot against his head and breast, one of\r\nwhich would have penetrated to the brain, had it not been turned aside\r\nby the steel visor. The other two were averted by the gorget, and by\r\nthe shield which hung around his neck.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, trusty armourers,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWamba, let us close with\r\nthem,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94and he rode straight to the thicket. He was met by six or seven\r\nmen-at-arms, who ran against him with their lances at full career.\r\nThree of the weapons struck against him, and splintered with as little\r\neffect as if they had been driven against a tower of steel. The Black\r\nKnight\xe2\x80\x99s eyes seemed to flash fire even through the aperture of his\r\nvisor. He raised himself in his stirrups with an air of inexpressible\r\ndignity, and exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat means this, my masters!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94The men made no\r\nother reply than by drawing their swords and attacking him on every\r\nside, crying, \xe2\x80\x9cDie, tyrant!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa! Saint Edward! Ha! Saint George!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, striking\r\ndown a man at every invocation; \xe2\x80\x9chave we traitors here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis opponents, desperate as they were, bore back from an arm which\r\ncarried death in every blow, and it seemed as if the terror of his\r\nsingle strength was about to gain the battle against such odds, when a\r\nknight, in blue armour, who had hitherto kept himself behind the other\r\nassailants, spurred forward with his lance, and taking aim, not at the\r\nrider but at the steed, wounded the noble animal mortally.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was a felon stroke!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the Black Knight, as the steed\r\nfell to the earth, bearing his rider along with him.\r\n\r\nAnd at this moment, Wamba winded the bugle, for the whole had passed so\r\nspeedily, that he had not time to do so sooner. The sudden sound made\r\nthe murderers bear back once more, and Wamba, though so imperfectly\r\nweaponed, did not hesitate to rush in and assist the Black Knight to\r\nrise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShame on ye, false cowards!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed he in the blue harness, who\r\nseemed to lead the assailants, \xe2\x80\x9cdo ye fly from the empty blast of a\r\nhorn blown by a Jester?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnimated by his words, they attacked the Black Knight anew, whose best\r\nrefuge was now to place his back against an oak, and defend himself\r\nwith his sword. The felon knight, who had taken another spear, watching\r\nthe moment when his formidable antagonist was most closely pressed,\r\ngalloped against him in hopes to nail him with his lance against the\r\ntree, when his purpose was again intercepted by Wamba. The Jester,\r\nmaking up by agility the want of strength, and little noticed by the\r\nmen-at-arms, who were busied in their more important object, hovered on\r\nthe skirts of the fight, and effectually checked the fatal career of\r\nthe Blue Knight, by hamstringing his horse with a stroke of his sword.\r\nHorse and man went to the ground; yet the situation of the Knight of\r\nthe Fetterlock continued very precarious, as he was pressed close by\r\nseveral men completely armed, and began to be fatigued by the violent\r\nexertions necessary to defend himself on so many points at nearly the\r\nsame moment, when a grey-goose shaft suddenly stretched on the earth\r\none of the most formidable of his assailants, and a band of yeomen\r\nbroke forth from the glade, headed by Locksley and the jovial Friar,\r\nwho, taking ready and effectual part in the fray, soon disposed of the\r\nruffians, all of whom lay on the spot dead or mortally wounded. The\r\nBlack Knight thanked his deliverers with a dignity they had not\r\nobserved in his former bearing, which hitherto had seemed rather that\r\nof a blunt bold soldier, than of a person of exalted rank.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt concerns me much,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9ceven before I express my full\r\ngratitude to my ready friends, to discover, if I may, who have been my\r\nunprovoked enemies.\xe2\x80\x94Open the visor of that Blue Knight, Wamba, who\r\nseems the chief of these villains.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jester instantly made up to the leader of the assassins, who,\r\nbruised by his fall, and entangled under the wounded steed, lay\r\nincapable either of flight or resistance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, valiant sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, \xe2\x80\x9cI must be your armourer as well as\r\nyour equerry\xe2\x80\x94I have dismounted you, and now I will unhelm you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, with no very gentle hand he undid the helmet of the Blue\r\nKnight, which, rolling to a distance on the grass, displayed to the\r\nKnight of the Fetterlock grizzled locks, and a countenance he did not\r\nexpect to have seen under such circumstances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWaldemar Fitzurse!\xe2\x80\x9d he said in astonishment; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat could urge one of\r\nthy rank and seeming worth to so foul an undertaking?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRichard,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captive Knight, looking up to him, \xe2\x80\x9cthou knowest\r\nlittle of mankind, if thou knowest not to what ambition and revenge can\r\nlead every child of Adam.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRevenge?\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Black Knight; \xe2\x80\x9cI never wronged thee\xe2\x80\x94On me thou\r\nhast nought to revenge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter, Richard, whose alliance thou didst scorn\xe2\x80\x94was that no\r\ninjury to a Norman, whose blood is noble as thine own?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy daughter?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Black Knight; \xe2\x80\x9ca proper cause of enmity,\r\nand followed up to a bloody issue!\xe2\x80\x94Stand back, my masters, I would\r\nspeak to him alone.\xe2\x80\x94And now, Waldemar Fitzurse, say me the\r\ntruth\xe2\x80\x94confess who set thee on this traitorous deed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy father\xe2\x80\x99s son,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Waldemar, \xe2\x80\x9cwho, in so doing, did but\r\navenge on thee thy disobedience to thy father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRichard\xe2\x80\x99s eyes sparkled with indignation, but his better nature\r\novercame it. He pressed his hand against his brow, and remained an\r\ninstant gazing on the face of the humbled baron, in whose features\r\npride was contending with shame.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou dost not ask thy life, Waldemar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe that is in the lion\xe2\x80\x99s clutch,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Fitzurse, \xe2\x80\x9cknows it were\r\nneedless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it, then, unasked,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard; \xe2\x80\x9cthe lion preys not on\r\nprostrate carcasses.\xe2\x80\x94Take thy life, but with this condition, that in\r\nthree days thou shalt leave England, and go to hide thine infamy in thy\r\nNorman castle, and that thou wilt never mention the name of John of\r\nAnjou as connected with thy felony. If thou art found on English ground\r\nafter the space I have allotted thee, thou diest\xe2\x80\x94or if thou breathest\r\naught that can attaint the honour of my house, by Saint George! not the\r\naltar itself shall be a sanctuary. I will hang thee out to feed the\r\nravens, from the very pinnacle of thine own castle.\xe2\x80\x94Let this knight\r\nhave a steed, Locksley, for I see your yeomen have caught those which\r\nwere running loose, and let him depart unharmed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that I judge I listen to a voice whose behests must not be\r\ndisputed,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9cI would send a shaft after the\r\nskulking villain that should spare him the labour of a long journey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou bearest an English heart, Locksley,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nwell dost judge thou art the more bound to obey my behest\xe2\x80\x94I am Richard\r\nof England!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words, pronounced in a tone of majesty suited to the high\r\nrank, and no less distinguished character of C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion, the yeomen\r\nat once kneeled down before him, and at the same time tendered their\r\nallegiance, and implored pardon for their offences.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRise, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard, in a gracious tone, looking on them\r\nwith a countenance in which his habitual good-humour had already\r\nconquered the blaze of hasty resentment, and whose features retained no\r\nmark of the late desperate conflict, excepting the flush arising from\r\nexertion,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cArise,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmy friends!\xe2\x80\x94Your misdemeanours, whether in\r\nforest or field, have been atoned by the loyal services you rendered my\r\ndistressed subjects before the walls of Torquilstone, and the rescue\r\nyou have this day afforded to your sovereign. Arise, my liegemen, and\r\nbe good subjects in future.\xe2\x80\x94And thou, brave Locksley\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCall me no longer Locksley, my Liege, but know me under the name,\r\nwhich, I fear, fame hath blown too widely not to have reached even your\r\nroyal ears\xe2\x80\x94I am Robin Hood of Sherwood Forest.\xe2\x80\x9d 561\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKing of Outlaws, and Prince of good fellows!\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, \xe2\x80\x9cwho hath\r\nnot heard a name that has been borne as far as Palestine? But be\r\nassured, brave Outlaw, that no deed done in our absence, and in the\r\nturbulent times to which it hath given rise, shall be remembered to thy\r\ndisadvantage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue says the proverb,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba, interposing his word, but with\r\nsome abatement of his usual petulance,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98When the cat is away,\r\nThe mice will play.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, Wamba, art thou there?\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard; \xe2\x80\x9cI have been so long of\r\nhearing thy voice, I thought thou hadst taken flight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI take flight!\xe2\x80\x9d said Wamba; \xe2\x80\x9cwhen do you ever find Folly separated\r\nfrom Valour? There lies the trophy of my sword, that good grey gelding,\r\nwhom I heartily wish upon his legs again, conditioning his master lay\r\nthere houghed in his place. It is true, I gave a little ground at\r\nfirst, for a motley jacket does not brook lance-heads, as a steel\r\ndoublet will. But if I fought not at sword\xe2\x80\x99s point, you will grant me\r\nthat I sounded the onset.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to good purpose, honest Wamba,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the King. \xe2\x80\x9cThy good\r\nservice shall not be forgotten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Confiteor!
