Confiteor!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94exclaimed, in a submissive tone, a voice near\r\nthe King\xe2\x80\x99s side\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cmy Latin will carry me no farther\xe2\x80\x94but I confess my\r\ndeadly treason, and pray leave to have absolution before I am led to\r\nexecution!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRichard looked around, and beheld the jovial Friar on his knees,\r\ntelling his rosary, while his quarter-staff, which had not been idle\r\nduring the skirmish, lay on the grass beside him. His countenance was\r\ngathered so as he thought might best express the most profound\r\ncontrition, his eyes being turned up, and the corners of his mouth\r\ndrawn down, as Wamba expressed it, like the tassels at the mouth of a\r\npurse. Yet this demure affectation of extreme penitence was whimsically\r\nbelied by a ludicrous meaning which lurked in his huge features, and\r\nseemed to pronounce his fear and repentance alike hypocritical.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what art thou cast down, mad Priest?\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard; \xe2\x80\x9cart thou\r\nafraid thy diocesan should learn how truly thou dost serve Our Lady and\r\nSaint Dunstan?\xe2\x80\x94Tush, man! fear it not; Richard of England betrays no\r\nsecrets that pass over the flagon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, most gracious sovereign,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Hermit, (well known to the\r\ncurious in penny-histories of Robin Hood, by the name of Friar Tuck,)\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cit is not the crosier I fear, but the sceptre.\xe2\x80\x94Alas! that my\r\nsacrilegious fist should ever have been applied to the ear of the\r\nLord\xe2\x80\x99s anointed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa! ha!\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard, \xe2\x80\x9csits the wind there?\xe2\x80\x94In truth I had forgotten\r\nthe buffet, though mine ear sung after it for a whole day. But if the\r\ncuff was fairly given, I will be judged by the good men around, if it\r\nwas not as well repaid\xe2\x80\x94or, if thou thinkest I still owe thee aught, and\r\nwill stand forth for another counterbuff\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Friar Tuck, \xe2\x80\x9cI had mine own returned, and with\r\nusury\xe2\x80\x94may your Majesty ever pay your debts as fully!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I could do so with cuffs,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, \xe2\x80\x9cmy creditors should have\r\nlittle reason to complain of an empty exchequer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, resuming his demure hypocritical\r\ncountenance, \xe2\x80\x9cI know not what penance I ought to perform for that most\r\nsacrilegious blow!\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak no more of it, brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King; \xe2\x80\x9cafter having stood so\r\nmany cuffs from Paynims and misbelievers, I were void of reason to\r\nquarrel with the buffet of a clerk so holy as he of Copmanhurst. Yet,\r\nmine honest Friar, I think it would be best both for the church and\r\nthyself, that I should procure a license to unfrock thee, and retain\r\nthee as a yeoman of our guard, serving in care of our person, as\r\nformerly in attendance upon the altar of Saint Dunstan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Liege,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, \xe2\x80\x9cI humbly crave your pardon; and you would\r\nreadily grant my excuse, did you but know how the sin of laziness has\r\nbeset me. Saint Dunstan\xe2\x80\x94may he be gracious to us!\xe2\x80\x94stands quiet in his\r\nniche, though I should forget my orisons in killing a fat buck\xe2\x80\x94I stay\r\nout of my cell sometimes a night, doing I wot not what\xe2\x80\x94Saint Dunstan\r\nnever complains\xe2\x80\x94a quiet master he is, and a peaceful, as ever was made\r\nof wood.\xe2\x80\x94But to be a yeoman in attendance on my sovereign the King\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nhonour is great, doubtless\xe2\x80\x94yet, if I were but to step aside to comfort\r\na widow in one corner, or to kill a deer in another, it would be,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98where is the dog Priest?\xe2\x80\x99 says one. \xe2\x80\x98Who has seen the accursed Tuck?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nsays another. \xe2\x80\x98The unfrocked villain destroys more venison than half\r\nthe country besides,\xe2\x80\x99 says one keeper; \xe2\x80\x98And is hunting after every shy\r\ndoe in the country!\xe2\x80\x99 quoth a second.\xe2\x80\x94In fine, good my Liege, I pray you\r\nto leave me as you found me; or, if in aught you desire to extend your\r\nbenevolence to me, that I may be considered as the poor Clerk of Saint\r\nDunstan\xe2\x80\x99s cell in Copmanhurst, to whom any small donation will be most\r\nthankfully acceptable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand thee,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, \xe2\x80\x9cand the Holy Clerk shall have a\r\ngrant of vert and venison in my woods of Warncliffe. Mark, however, I\r\nwill but assign thee three bucks every season; but if that do not prove\r\nan apology for thy slaying thirty, I am no Christian knight nor true\r\nking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Grace may be well assured,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, \xe2\x80\x9cthat, with the grace\r\nof Saint Dunstan, I shall find the way of multiplying your most\r\nbounteous gift.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI nothing doubt it, good brother,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King; \xe2\x80\x9cand as venison is\r\nbut dry food, our cellarer shall have orders to deliver to thee a butt\r\nof sack, a runlet of Malvoisie, and three hogsheads of ale of the first\r\nstrike, yearly\xe2\x80\x94If that will not quench thy thirst, thou must come to\r\ncourt, and become acquainted with my butler.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut for Saint Dunstan?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA cope, a stole, and an altar-cloth shalt thou also have,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nthe King, crossing himself\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cBut we may not turn our game into earnest,\r\nlest God punish us for thinking more on our follies than on his honour\r\nand worship.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will answer for my patron,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Priest, joyously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnswer for thyself, Friar,\xe2\x80\x9d said King Richard, something sternly; but\r\nimmediately stretching out his hand to the Hermit, the latter, somewhat\r\nabashed, bent his knee, and saluted it. \xe2\x80\x9cThou dost less honour to my\r\nextended palm than to my clenched fist,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Monarch; \xe2\x80\x9cthou didst\r\nonly kneel to the one, and to the other didst prostrate thyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the Friar, afraid perhaps of again giving offence by continuing the\r\nconversation in too jocose a style\xe2\x80\x94a false step to be particularly\r\nguarded against by those who converse with monarchs\xe2\x80\x94bowed profoundly,\r\nand fell into the rear.\r\n\r\nAt the same time, two additional personages appeared on the scene.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLI\r\n\r\n\r\nAll hail to the lordlings of high degree,\r\nWho live not more happy, though greater than we!\r\n    Our pastimes to see,\r\n    Under every green tree,\r\nIn all the gay woodland, right welcome ye be.\r\n\r\n\r\nMACDONALD\r\n\r\n\r\nThe new comers were Wilfred of Ivanhoe, on the Prior of Botolph\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npalfrey, and Gurth, who attended him, on the Knight\xe2\x80\x99s own war-horse.\r\nThe astonishment of Ivanhoe was beyond bounds, when he saw his master\r\nbesprinkled with blood, and six or seven dead bodies lying around in\r\nthe little glade in which the battle had taken place. Nor was he less\r\nsurprised to see Richard surrounded by so many silvan attendants, the\r\noutlaws, as they seemed to be, of the forest, and a perilous retinue\r\ntherefore for a prince. He hesitated whether to address the King as the\r\nBlack Knight-errant, or in what other manner to demean himself towards\r\nhim. Richard saw his embarrassment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFear not, Wilfred,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cto address Richard Plantagenet as\r\nhimself, since thou seest him in the company of true English hearts,\r\nalthough it may be they have been urged a few steps aside by warm\r\nEnglish blood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Wilfred of Ivanhoe,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gallant Outlaw, stepping forward,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmy assurances can add nothing to those of our sovereign; yet, let me\r\nsay somewhat proudly, that of men who have suffered much, he hath not\r\ntruer subjects than those who now stand around him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot doubt it, brave man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wilfred, \xe2\x80\x9csince thou art of the\r\nnumber\xe2\x80\x94But what mean these marks of death and danger? these slain men,\r\nand the bloody armour of my Prince?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTreason hath been with us, Ivanhoe,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, thanks to\r\nthese brave men, treason hath met its meed\xe2\x80\x94But, now I bethink me, thou\r\ntoo art a traitor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9ca most disobedient traitor;\r\nfor were not our orders positive, that thou shouldst repose thyself at\r\nSaint Botolph\xe2\x80\x99s until thy wound was healed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is healed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cit is not of more consequence than the\r\nscratch of a bodkin. But why, oh why, noble Prince, will you thus vex\r\nthe hearts of your faithful servants, and expose your life by lonely\r\njourneys and rash adventures, as if it were of no more value than that\r\nof a mere knight-errant, who has no interest on earth but what lance\r\nand sword may procure him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Richard Plantagenet,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, \xe2\x80\x9cdesires no more fame than\r\nhis good lance and sword may acquire him\xe2\x80\x94and Richard Plantagenet is\r\nprouder of achieving an adventure, with only his good sword, and his\r\ngood arm to speed, than if he led to battle a host of an hundred\r\nthousand armed men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut your kingdom, my Liege,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cyour kingdom is threatened\r\nwith dissolution and civil war\xe2\x80\x94your subjects menaced with every species\r\nof evil, if deprived of their sovereign in some of those dangers which\r\nit is your daily pleasure to incur, and from which you have but this\r\nmoment narrowly escaped.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHo! ho! my kingdom and my subjects?\xe2\x80\x9d answered Richard, impatiently; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ntell thee, Sir Wilfred, the best of them are most willing to repay my\r\nfollies in kind\xe2\x80\x94For example, my very faithful servant, Wilfred of\r\nIvanhoe, will not obey my positive commands, and yet reads his king a\r\nhomily, because he does not walk exactly by his advice. Which of us has\r\nmost reason to upbraid the other?\xe2\x80\x94Yet forgive me, my faithful Wilfred.\r\nThe time I have spent, and am yet to spend in concealment, is, as I\r\nexplained to thee at Saint Botolph\xe2\x80\x99s, necessary to give my friends and\r\nfaithful nobles time to assemble their forces, that when Richard\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nreturn is announced, he should be at the head of such a force as\r\nenemies shall tremble to face, and thus subdue the meditated treason,\r\nwithout even unsheathing a sword. Estoteville and Bohun will not be\r\nstrong enough to move forward to York for twenty-four hours. I must\r\nhave news of Salisbury from the south; and of Beauchamp, in\r\nWarwickshire; and of Multon and Percy in the north. The Chancellor must\r\nmake sure of London. Too sudden an appearance would subject me to\r\ndangers, other than my lance and sword, though backed by the bow of\r\nbold Robin, or the quarter-staff of Friar Tuck, and the horn of the\r\nsage Wamba, may be able to rescue me from.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWilfred bowed in submission, well knowing how vain it was to contend\r\nwith the wild spirit of chivalry which so often impelled his master\r\nupon dangers which he might easily have avoided, or rather, which it\r\nwas unpardonable in him to have sought out. The young knight sighed,\r\ntherefore, and held his peace; while Richard, rejoiced at having\r\nsilenced his counsellor, though his heart acknowledged the justice of\r\nthe charge he had brought against him, went on in conversation with\r\nRobin Hood.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cKing of Outlaws,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9chave you no refreshment to\r\noffer to your brother sovereign? for these dead knaves have found me\r\nboth in exercise and appetite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn troth,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Outlaw, \xe2\x80\x9cfor I scorn to lie to your Grace, our\r\nlarder is chiefly supplied with\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d He stopped, and was somewhat\r\nembarrassed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith venison, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard, gaily; \xe2\x80\x9cbetter food at need\r\nthere can be none\xe2\x80\x94and truly, if a king will not remain at home and slay\r\nhis own game, methinks he should not brawl too loud if he finds it\r\nkilled to his hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf your Grace, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Robin, \xe2\x80\x9cwill again honour with your\r\npresence one of Robin Hood\xe2\x80\x99s places of rendezvous, the venison shall\r\nnot be lacking; and a stoup of ale, and it may be a cup of reasonably\r\ngood wine, to relish it withal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Outlaw accordingly led the way, followed by the buxom Monarch, more\r\nhappy, probably, in this chance meeting with Robin Hood and his\r\nforesters, than he would have been in again assuming his royal state,\r\nand presiding over a splendid circle of peers and nobles. Novelty in\r\nsociety and adventure were the zest of life to Richard C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion,\r\nand it had its highest relish when enhanced by dangers encountered and\r\nsurmounted. In the lion-hearted King, the brilliant, but useless\r\ncharacter, of a knight of romance, was in a great measure realized and\r\nrevived; and the personal glory which he acquired by his own deeds of\r\narms, was far more dear to his excited imagination, than that which a\r\ncourse of policy and wisdom would have spread around his government.\r\nAccordingly, his reign was like the course of a brilliant and rapid\r\nmeteor, which shoots along the face of Heaven, shedding around an\r\nunnecessary and portentous light, which is instantly swallowed up by\r\nuniversal darkness; his feats of chivalry furnishing themes for bards\r\nand minstrels, but affording none of those solid benefits to his\r\ncountry on which history loves to pause, and hold up as an example to\r\nposterity. But in his present company Richard showed to the greatest\r\nimaginable advantage. He was gay, good-humoured, and fond of manhood in\r\nevery rank of life.\r\n\r\nBeneath a huge oak-tree the silvan repast was hastily prepared for the\r\nKing of England, surrounded by men outlaws to his government, but who\r\nnow formed his court and his guard. As the flagon went round, the rough\r\nforesters soon lost their awe for the presence of Majesty. The song and\r\nthe jest were exchanged\xe2\x80\x94the stories of former deeds were told with\r\nadvantage; and at length, and while boasting of their successful\r\ninfraction of the laws, no one recollected they were speaking in\r\npresence of their natural guardian. The merry King, nothing heeding his\r\ndignity any more than his company, laughed, quaffed, and jested among\r\nthe jolly band. The natural and rough sense of Robin Hood led him to be\r\ndesirous that the scene should be closed ere any thing should occur to\r\ndisturb its harmony, the more especially that he observed Ivanhoe\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbrow clouded with anxiety. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are honoured,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to Ivanhoe,\r\napart, \xe2\x80\x9cby the presence of our gallant Sovereign; yet I would not that\r\nhe dallied with time, which the circumstances of his kingdom may render\r\nprecious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well and wisely spoken, brave Robin Hood,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wilfred, apart;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand know, moreover, that they who jest with Majesty even in its gayest\r\nmood are but toying with the lion\xe2\x80\x99s whelp, which, on slight\r\nprovocation, uses both fangs and claws.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have touched the very cause of my fear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Outlaw; \xe2\x80\x9cmy men\r\nare rough by practice and nature, the King is hasty as well as\r\ngood-humoured; nor know I how soon cause of offence may arise, or how\r\nwarmly it may be received\xe2\x80\x94it is time this revel were broken off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt must be by your management then, gallant yeoman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfor each hint I have essayed to give him serves only to induce him to\r\nprolong it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMust I so soon risk the pardon and favour of my Sovereign?\xe2\x80\x9d said Robin\r\nHood, pausing for all instant; \xe2\x80\x9cbut by Saint Christopher, it shall be\r\nso. I were undeserving his grace did I not peril it for his good.\xe2\x80\x94Here,\r\nScathlock, get thee behind yonder thicket, and wind me a Norman blast\r\non thy bugle, and without an instant\xe2\x80\x99s delay on peril of your life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nScathlock obeyed his captain, and in less than five minutes the\r\nrevellers were startled by the sound of his horn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the bugle of Malvoisin,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Miller, starting to his feet,\r\nand seizing his bow. The Friar dropped the flagon, and grasped his\r\nquarter-staff. Wamba stopt short in the midst of a jest, and betook\r\nhimself to sword and target. All the others stood to their weapons.\r\n\r\nMen of their precarious course of life change readily from the banquet\r\nto the battle; and, to Richard, the exchange seemed but a succession of\r\npleasure. He called for his helmet and the most cumbrous parts of his\r\narmour, which he had laid aside; and while Gurth was putting them on,\r\nhe laid his strict injunctions on Wilfred, under pain of his highest\r\ndispleasure, not to engage in the skirmish which he supposed was\r\napproaching.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast fought for me an hundred times, Wilfred,\xe2\x80\x94and I have seen it.\r\nThou shalt this day look on, and see how Richard will fight for his\r\nfriend and liegeman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the meantime, Robin Hood had sent off several of his followers in\r\ndifferent directions, as if to reconnoitre the enemy; and when he saw\r\nthe company effectually broken up, he approached Richard, who was now\r\ncompletely armed, and, kneeling down on one knee, craved pardon of his\r\nSovereign.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor what, good yeoman?\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard, somewhat impatiently. \xe2\x80\x9cHave we\r\nnot already granted thee a full pardon for all transgressions? Thinkest\r\nthou our word is a feather, to be blown backward and forward between\r\nus? Thou canst not have had time to commit any new offence since that\r\ntime?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but I have though,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the yeoman, \xe2\x80\x9cif it be an offence to\r\ndeceive my prince for his own advantage. The bugle you have heard was\r\nnone of Malvoisin\xe2\x80\x99s, but blown by my direction, to break off the\r\nbanquet, lest it trenched upon hours of dearer import than to be thus\r\ndallied with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then rose from his knee, folded his arm on his bosom, and in a\r\nmanner rather respectful than submissive, awaited the answer of the\r\nKing,\xe2\x80\x94like one who is conscious he may have given offence, yet is\r\nconfident in the rectitude of his motive. The blood rushed in anger to\r\nthe countenance of Richard; but it was the first transient emotion, and\r\nhis sense of justice instantly subdued it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe King of Sherwood,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cgrudges his venison and his\r\nwine-flask to the King of England? It is well, bold Robin!\xe2\x80\x94but when you\r\ncome to see me in merry London, I trust to be a less niggard host. Thou\r\nart right, however, good fellow. Let us therefore to horse and\r\naway\xe2\x80\x94Wilfred has been impatient this hour. Tell me, bold Robin, hast\r\nthou never a friend in thy band, who, not content with advising, will\r\nneeds direct thy motions, and look miserable when thou dost presume to\r\nact for thyself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch a one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Robin, \xe2\x80\x9cis my Lieutenant, Little John, who is even\r\nnow absent on an expedition as far as the borders of Scotland; and I\r\nwill own to your Majesty, that I am sometimes displeased by the freedom\r\nof his councils\xe2\x80\x94but, when I think twice, I cannot be long angry with\r\none who can have no motive for his anxiety save zeal for his master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nservice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou art right, good yeoman,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Richard; \xe2\x80\x9cand if I had Ivanhoe,\r\non the one hand, to give grave advice, and recommend it by the sad\r\ngravity of his brow, and thee, on the other, to trick me into what thou\r\nthinkest my own good, I should have as little the freedom of mine own\r\nwill as any king in Christendom or Heathenesse.\xe2\x80\x94But come, sirs, let us\r\nmerrily on to Coningsburgh, and think no more on\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRobin Hood assured them that he had detached a party in the direction\r\nof the road they were to pass, who would not fail to discover and\r\napprize them of any secret ambuscade; and that he had little doubt they\r\nwould find the ways secure, or, if otherwise, would receive such timely\r\nnotice of the danger as would enable them to fall back on a strong\r\ntroop of archers, with which he himself proposed to follow on the same\r\nroute.\r\n\r\nThe wise and attentive precautions adopted for his safety touched\r\nRichard\xe2\x80\x99s feelings, and removed any slight grudge which he might retain\r\non account of the deception the Outlaw Captain had practised upon him.\r\nHe once more extended his hand to Robin Hood, assured him of his full\r\npardon and future favour, as well as his firm resolution to restrain\r\nthe tyrannical exercise of the forest rights and other oppressive laws,\r\nby which so many English yeomen were driven into a state of rebellion.\r\nBut Richard\xe2\x80\x99s good intentions towards the bold Outlaw were frustrated\r\nby the King\xe2\x80\x99s untimely death; and the Charter of the Forest was\r\nextorted from the unwilling hands of King John when he succeeded to his\r\nheroic brother. As for the rest of Robin Hood\xe2\x80\x99s career, as well as the\r\ntale of his treacherous death, they are to be found in those\r\nblack-letter garlands, once sold at the low and easy rate of one\r\nhalfpenny.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow cheaply purchased at their weight in gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Outlaw\xe2\x80\x99s opinion proved true; and the King, attended by Ivanhoe,\r\nGurth, and Wamba, arrived, without any interruption, within view of the\r\nCastle of Coningsburgh, while the sun was yet in the horizon.\r\n\r\nThere are few more beautiful or striking scenes in England, than are\r\npresented by the vicinity of this ancient Saxon fortress. The soft and\r\ngentle river Don sweeps through an amphitheatre, in which cultivation\r\nis richly blended with woodland, and on a mount, ascending from the\r\nriver, well defended by walls and ditches, rises this ancient edifice,\r\nwhich, as its Saxon name implies, was, previous to the Conquest, a\r\nroyal residence of the kings of England. The outer walls have probably\r\nbeen added by the Normans, but the inner keep bears token of very great\r\nantiquity. It is situated on a mount at one angle of the inner court,\r\nand forms a complete circle of perhaps twenty-five feet in diameter.\r\nThe wall is of immense thickness, and is propped or defended by six\r\nhuge external buttresses which project from the circle, and rise up\r\nagainst the sides of the tower as if to strengthen or to support it.\r\nThese massive buttresses are solid when they arise from the foundation,\r\nand a good way higher up; but are hollowed out towards the top, and\r\nterminate in a sort of turrets communicating with the interior of the\r\nkeep itself. The distant appearance of this huge building, with these\r\nsingular accompaniments, is as interesting to the lovers of the\r\npicturesque, as the interior of the castle is to the eager antiquary,\r\nwhose imagination it carries back to the days of the Heptarchy. A\r\nbarrow, in the vicinity of the castle, is pointed out as the tomb of\r\nthe memorable Hengist; and various monuments, of great antiquity and\r\ncuriosity, are shown in the neighbouring churchyard. 57\r\n\r\nWhen C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion and his retinue approached this rude yet stately\r\nbuilding, it was not, as at present, surrounded by external\r\nfortifications. The Saxon architect had exhausted his art in rendering\r\nthe main keep defensible, and there was no other circumvallation than a\r\nrude barrier of palisades.\r\n\r\nA huge black banner, which floated from the top of the tower, announced\r\nthat the obsequies of the late owner were still in the act of being\r\nsolemnized. It bore no emblem of the deceased\xe2\x80\x99s birth or quality, for\r\narmorial bearings were then a novelty among the Norman chivalry\r\nthemselves and, were totally unknown to the Saxons. But above the gate\r\nwas another banner, on which the figure of a white horse, rudely\r\npainted, indicated the nation and rank of the deceased, by the\r\nwell-known symbol of Hengist and his Saxon warriors.\r\n\r\nAll around the castle was a scene of busy commotion; for such funeral\r\nbanquets were times of general and profuse hospitality, which not only\r\nevery one who could claim the most distant connexion with the deceased,\r\nbut all passengers whatsoever, were invited to partake. The wealth and\r\nconsequence of the deceased Athelstane, occasioned this custom to be\r\nobserved in the fullest extent.\r\n\r\nNumerous parties, therefore, were seen ascending and descending the\r\nhill on which the castle was situated; and when the King and his\r\nattendants entered the open and unguarded gates of the external\r\nbarrier, the space within presented a scene not easily reconciled with\r\nthe cause of the assemblage. In one place cooks were toiling to roast\r\nhuge oxen, and fat sheep; in another, hogsheads of ale were set\r\nabroach, to be drained at the freedom of all comers. Groups of every\r\ndescription were to be seen devouring the food and swallowing the\r\nliquor thus abandoned to their discretion. The naked Saxon serf was\r\ndrowning the sense of his half-year\xe2\x80\x99s hunger and thirst, in one day of\r\ngluttony and drunkenness\xe2\x80\x94the more pampered burgess and guild-brother\r\nwas eating his morsel with gust, or curiously criticising the quantity\r\nof the malt and the skill of the brewer. Some few of the poorer Norman\r\ngentry might also be seen, distinguished by their shaven chins and\r\nshort cloaks, and not less so by their keeping together, and looking\r\nwith great scorn on the whole solemnity, even while condescending to\r\navail themselves of the good cheer which was so liberally supplied.\r\n\r\nMendicants were of course assembled by the score, together with\r\nstrolling soldiers returned from Palestine, (according to their own\r\naccount at least,) pedlars were displaying their wares, travelling\r\nmechanics were enquiring after employment, and wandering palmers,\r\nhedge-priests, Saxon minstrels, and Welsh bards, were muttering\r\nprayers, and extracting mistuned dirges from their harps, crowds, and\r\nrotes. 58\r\n\r\nOne sent forth the praises of Athelstane in a doleful panegyric;\r\nanother, in a Saxon genealogical poem, rehearsed the uncouth and harsh\r\nnames of his noble ancestry. Jesters and jugglers were not awanting,\r\nnor was the occasion of the assembly supposed to render the exercise of\r\ntheir profession indecorous or improper. Indeed the ideas of the Saxons\r\non these occasions were as natural as they were rude. If sorrow was\r\nthirsty, there was drink\xe2\x80\x94if hungry, there was food\xe2\x80\x94if it sunk down upon\r\nand saddened the heart, here were the means supplied of mirth, or at\r\nleast of amusement. Nor did the assistants scorn to avail themselves of\r\nthose means of consolation, although, every now and then, as if\r\nsuddenly recollecting the cause which had brought them together, the\r\nmen groaned in unison, while the females, of whom many were present,\r\nraised up their voices and shrieked for very woe.\r\n\r\nSuch was the scene in the castle-yard at Coningsburgh when it was\r\nentered by Richard and his followers. The seneschal or steward deigned\r\nnot to take notice of the groups of inferior guests who were\r\nperpetually entering and withdrawing, unless so far as was necessary to\r\npreserve order; nevertheless he was struck by the good mien of the\r\nMonarch and Ivanhoe, more especially as he imagined the features of the\r\nlatter were familiar to him. Besides, the approach of two knights, for\r\nsuch their dress bespoke them, was a rare event at a Saxon solemnity,\r\nand could not but be regarded as a sort of honour to the deceased and\r\nhis family. And in his sable dress, and holding in his hand his white\r\nwand of office, this important personage made way through the\r\nmiscellaneous assemblage of guests, thus conducting Richard and Ivanhoe\r\nto the entrance of the tower. Gurth and Wamba speedily found\r\nacquaintances in the court-yard, nor presumed to intrude themselves any\r\nfarther until their presence should be required.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLII\r\n\r\n\r\nI found them winding of Marcello\xe2\x80\x99s corpse.\r\nAnd there was such a solemn melody,\r\n\xe2\x80\x99Twixt doleful songs, tears, and sad elegies,\xe2\x80\x94\r\nSuch as old grandames, watching by the dead,\r\nAre wont to outwear the night with.\r\n\r\n\r\nOLD PLAY\r\n\r\n\r\nThe mode of entering the great tower of Coningsburgh Castle is very\r\npeculiar, and partakes of the rude simplicity of the early times in\r\nwhich it was erected. A flight of steps, so deep and narrow as to be\r\nalmost precipitous, leads up to a low portal in the south side of the\r\ntower, by which the adventurous antiquary may still, or at least could\r\na few years since, gain access to a small stair within the thickness of\r\nthe main wall of the tower, which leads up to the third story of the\r\nbuilding,\xe2\x80\x94the two lower being dungeons or vaults, which neither receive\r\nair nor light, save by a square hole in the third story, with which\r\nthey seem to have communicated by a ladder. The access to the upper\r\napartments in the tower which consist in all of four stories, is given\r\nby stairs which are carried up through the external buttresses.\r\n\r\nBy this difficult and complicated entrance, the good King Richard,\r\nfollowed by his faithful Ivanhoe, was ushered into the round apartment\r\nwhich occupies the whole of the third story from the ground. Wilfred,\r\nby the difficulties of the ascent, gained time to muffle his face in\r\nhis mantle, as it had been held expedient that he should not present\r\nhimself to his father until the King should give him the signal.\r\n\r\nThere were assembled in this apartment, around a large oaken table,\r\nabout a dozen of the most distinguished representatives of the Saxon\r\nfamilies in the adjacent counties. They were all old, or, at least,\r\nelderly men; for the younger race, to the great displeasure of the\r\nseniors, had, like Ivanhoe, broken down many of the barriers which\r\nseparated for half a century the Norman victors from the vanquished\r\nSaxons. The downcast and sorrowful looks of these venerable men, their\r\nsilence and their mournful posture, formed a strong contrast to the\r\nlevity of the revellers on the outside of the castle. Their grey locks\r\nand long full beards, together with their antique tunics and loose\r\nblack mantles, suited well with the singular and rude apartment in\r\nwhich they were seated, and gave the appearance of a band of ancient\r\nworshippers of Woden, recalled to life to mourn over the decay of their\r\nnational glory.\r\n\r\nCedric, seated in equal rank among his countrymen, seemed yet, by\r\ncommon consent, to act as chief of the assembly. Upon the entrance of\r\nRichard (only known to him as the valorous Knight of the Fetterlock) he\r\narose gravely, and gave him welcome by the ordinary salutation, \xe2\x80\x9cWaes\r\nhael\xe2\x80\x9d, raising at the same time a goblet to his head. The King, no\r\nstranger to the customs of his English subjects, returned the greeting\r\nwith the appropriate words, \xe2\x80\x9cDrinc hael\xe2\x80\x9d, and partook of a cup which\r\nwas handed to him by the sewer. The same courtesy was offered to\r\nIvanhoe, who pledged his father in silence, supplying the usual speech\r\nby an inclination of his head, lest his voice should have been\r\nrecognised.\r\n\r\nWhen this introductory ceremony was performed, Cedric arose, and,\r\nextending his hand to Richard, conducted him into a small and very rude\r\nchapel, which was excavated, as it were, out of one of the external\r\nbuttresses. As there was no opening, saving a little narrow loop-hole,\r\nthe place would have been nearly quite dark but for two flambeaux or\r\ntorches, which showed, by a red and smoky light, the arched roof and\r\nnaked walls, the rude altar of stone, and the crucifix of the same\r\nmaterial.\r\n\r\nBefore this altar was placed a bier, and on each side of this bier\r\nkneeled three priests, who told their beads, and muttered their\r\nprayers, with the greatest signs of external devotion. For this service\r\na splendid \xe2\x80\x9csoul-scat\xe2\x80\x9d was paid to the convent of Saint Edmund\xe2\x80\x99s by the\r\nmother of the deceased; and, that it might be fully deserved, the whole\r\nbrethren, saving the lame Sacristan, had transferred themselves to\r\nConingsburgh, where, while six of their number were constantly on guard\r\nin the performance of divine rites by the bier of Athelstane, the\r\nothers failed not to take their share of the refreshments and\r\namusements which went on at the castle. In maintaining this pious watch\r\nand ward, the good monks were particularly careful not to interrupt\r\ntheir hymns for an instant, lest Zernebock, the ancient Saxon Apollyon,\r\nshould lay his clutches on the departed Athelstane. Nor were they less\r\ncareful to prevent any unhallowed layman from touching the pall, which,\r\nhaving been that used at the funeral of Saint Edmund, was liable to be\r\ndesecrated, if handled by the profane. If, in truth, these attentions\r\ncould be of any use to the deceased, he had some right to expect them\r\nat the hands of the brethren of Saint Edmund\xe2\x80\x99s, since, besides a\r\nhundred mancuses of gold paid down as the soul-ransom, the mother of\r\nAthelstane had announced her intention of endowing that foundation with\r\nthe better part of the lands of the deceased, in order to maintain\r\nperpetual prayers for his soul, and that of her departed husband.\r\nRichard and Wilfred followed the Saxon Cedric into the apartment of\r\ndeath, where, as their guide pointed with solemn air to the untimely\r\nbier of Athelstane, they followed his example in devoutly crossing\r\nthemselves, and muttering a brief prayer for the weal of the departed\r\nsoul.\r\n\r\nThis act of pious charity performed, Cedric again motioned them to\r\nfollow him, gliding over the stone floor with a noiseless tread; and,\r\nafter ascending a few steps, opened with great caution the door of a\r\nsmall oratory, which adjoined to the chapel. It was about eight feet\r\nsquare, hollowed, like the chapel itself, out of the thickness of the\r\nwall; and the loop-hole, which enlightened it, being to the west, and\r\nwidening considerably as it sloped inward, a beam of the setting sun\r\nfound its way into its dark recess, and showed a female of a dignified\r\nmien, and whose countenance retained the marked remains of majestic\r\nbeauty. Her long mourning robes and her flowing wimple of black\r\ncypress, enhanced the whiteness of her skin, and the beauty of her\r\nlight-coloured and flowing tresses, which time had neither thinned nor\r\nmingled with silver. Her countenance expressed the deepest sorrow that\r\nis consistent with resignation. On the stone table before her stood a\r\ncrucifix of ivory, beside which was laid a missal, having its pages\r\nrichly illuminated, and its boards adorned with clasps of gold, and\r\nbosses of the same precious metal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNoble Edith,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, after having stood a moment silent, as if\r\nto give Richard and Wilfred time to look upon the lady of the mansion,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthese are worthy strangers, come to take a part in thy sorrows. And\r\nthis, in especial, is the valiant Knight who fought so bravely for the\r\ndeliverance of him for whom we this day mourn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis bravery has my thanks,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the lady; \xe2\x80\x9calthough it be the\r\nwill of Heaven that it should be displayed in vain. I thank, too, his\r\ncourtesy, and that of his companion, which hath brought them hither to\r\nbehold the widow of Adeling, the mother of Athelstane, in her deep hour\r\nof sorrow and lamentation. To your care, kind kinsman, I intrust them,\r\nsatisfied that they will want no hospitality which these sad walls can\r\nyet afford.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe guests bowed deeply to the mourning parent, and withdrew from their\r\nhospitable guide.\r\n\r\nAnother winding stair conducted them to an apartment of the same size\r\nwith that which they had first entered, occupying indeed the story\r\nimmediately above. From this room, ere yet the door was opened,\r\nproceeded a low and melancholy strain of vocal music. When they\r\nentered, they found themselves in the presence of about twenty matrons\r\nand maidens of distinguished Saxon lineage. Four maidens, Rowena\r\nleading the choir, raised a hymn for the soul of the deceased, of which\r\nwe have only been able to decipher two or three stanzas:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nDust unto dust,\r\nTo this all must;\r\nThe tenant hath resign\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nThe faded form\r\nTo waste and worm\xe2\x80\x94\r\nCorruption claims her kind.\r\n\r\nThrough paths unknown\r\nThy soul hath flown,\r\nTo seek the realms of woe,\r\nWhere fiery pain\r\nShall purge the stain\r\nOf actions done below.\r\n\r\nIn that sad place,\r\nBy Mary\xe2\x80\x99s grace,\r\nBrief may thy dwelling be\r\nTill prayers and alms,\r\nAnd holy psalms,\r\nShall set the captive free.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile this dirge was sung, in a low and melancholy tone, by the female\r\nchoristers, the others were divided into two bands, of which one was\r\nengaged in bedecking, with such embroidery as their skill and taste\r\ncould compass, a large silken pall, destined to cover the bier of\r\nAthelstane, while the others busied themselves in selecting, from\r\nbaskets of flowers placed before them, garlands, which they intended\r\nfor the same mournful purpose. The behaviour of the maidens was\r\ndecorous, if not marked with deep affliction; but now and then a\r\nwhisper or a smile called forth the rebuke of the severer matrons, and\r\nhere and there might be seen a damsel more interested in endeavouring\r\nto find out how her mourning-robe became her, than in the dismal\r\nceremony for which they were preparing. Neither was this propensity (if\r\nwe must needs confess the truth) at all diminished by the appearance of\r\ntwo strange knights, which occasioned some looking up, peeping, and\r\nwhispering. Rowena alone, too proud to be vain, paid her greeting to\r\nher deliverer with a graceful courtesy. Her demeanour was serious, but\r\nnot dejected; and it may be doubted whether thoughts of Ivanhoe, and of\r\nthe uncertainty of his fate, did not claim as great a share in her\r\ngravity as the death of her kinsman.\r\n\r\nTo Cedric, however, who, as we have observed, was not remarkably\r\nclear-sighted on such occasions, the sorrow of his ward seemed so much\r\ndeeper than any of the other maidens, that he deemed it proper to\r\nwhisper the explanation\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cShe was the affianced bride of the noble\r\nAthelstane.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94It may be doubted whether this communication went a far\r\nway to increase Wilfred\xe2\x80\x99s disposition to sympathize with the mourners\r\nof Coningsburgh.\r\n\r\nHaving thus formally introduced the guests to the different chambers in\r\nwhich the obsequies of Athelstane were celebrated under different\r\nforms, Cedric conducted them into a small room, destined, as he\r\ninformed them, for the exclusive accomodation of honourable guests,\r\nwhose more slight connexion with the deceased might render them\r\nunwilling to join those who were immediately effected by the unhappy\r\nevent. He assured them of every accommodation, and was about to\r\nwithdraw when the Black Knight took his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI crave to remind you, noble Thane,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthat when we last\r\nparted, you promised, for the service I had the fortune to render you,\r\nto grant me a boon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is granted ere named, noble Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cyet, at this sad\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf that also,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, \xe2\x80\x9cI have bethought me\xe2\x80\x94but my time is\r\nbrief\xe2\x80\x94neither does it seem to me unfit, that, when closing the grave on\r\nthe noble Athelstane, we should deposit therein certain prejudices and\r\nhasty opinions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir Knight of the Fetterlock,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, colouring, and\r\ninterrupting the King in his turn, \xe2\x80\x9cI trust your boon regards yourself\r\nand no other; for in that which concerns the honour of my house, it is\r\nscarce fitting that a stranger should mingle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor do I wish to mingle,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, mildly, \xe2\x80\x9cunless in so far as\r\nyou will admit me to have an interest. As yet you have known me but as\r\nthe Black Knight of the Fetterlock\xe2\x80\x94Know me now as Richard Plantagenet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRichard of Anjou!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Cedric, stepping backward with the utmost\r\nastonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, noble Cedric\xe2\x80\x94Richard of England!\xe2\x80\x94whose deepest interest\xe2\x80\x94whose\r\ndeepest wish, is to see her sons united with each other.\xe2\x80\x94And, how now,\r\nworthy Thane! hast thou no knee for thy prince?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Norman blood,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cit hath never bended.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReserve thine homage then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Monarch, \xe2\x80\x9cuntil I shall prove my\r\nright to it by my equal protection of Normans and English.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrince,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cI have ever done justice to thy bravery and\r\nthy worth\xe2\x80\x94Nor am I ignorant of thy claim to the crown through thy\r\ndescent from Matilda, niece to Edgar Atheling, and daughter to Malcolm\r\nof Scotland. But Matilda, though of the royal Saxon blood, was not the\r\nheir to the monarchy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not dispute my title with thee, noble Thane,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard,\r\ncalmly; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I will bid thee look around thee, and see where thou wilt\r\nfind another to be put into the scale against it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd hast thou wandered hither, Prince, to tell me so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cTo\r\nupbraid me with the ruin of my race, ere the grave has closed o\xe2\x80\x99er the\r\nlast scion of Saxon royalty?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94His countenance darkened as he spoke.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\nwas boldly\xe2\x80\x94it was rashly done!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so, by the holy rood!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the King; \xe2\x80\x9cit was done in the frank\r\nconfidence which one brave man may repose in another, without a shadow\r\nof danger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou sayest well, Sir King\xe2\x80\x94for King I own thou art, and wilt be,\r\ndespite of my feeble opposition.\xe2\x80\x94I dare not take the only mode to\r\nprevent it, though thou hast placed the strong temptation within my\r\nreach!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now to my boon,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich I ask not with one jot the\r\nless confidence, that thou hast refused to acknowledge my lawful\r\nsovereignty. I require of thee, as a man of thy word, on pain of being\r\nheld faithless, man-sworn, and \xe2\x80\x98nidering\xe2\x80\x99, 581 to forgive and receive\r\nto thy paternal affection the good knight, Wilfred of Ivanhoe. In this\r\nreconciliation thou wilt own I have an interest\xe2\x80\x94the happiness of my\r\nfriend, and the quelling of dissension among my faithful people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this is Wilfred!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, pointing to his son.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy father!\xe2\x80\x94my father!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, prostrating himself at Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfeet, \xe2\x80\x9cgrant me thy forgiveness!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou hast it, my son,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, raising him up. \xe2\x80\x9cThe son of\r\nHereward knows how to keep his word, even when it has been passed to a\r\nNorman. But let me see thee use the dress and costume of thy English\r\nancestry\xe2\x80\x94no short cloaks, no gay bonnets, no fantastic plumage in my\r\ndecent household. He that would be the son of Cedric, must show himself\r\nof English ancestry.\xe2\x80\x94Thou art about to speak,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, sternly, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nI guess the topic. The Lady Rowena must complete two years\xe2\x80\x99 mourning,\r\nas for a betrothed husband\xe2\x80\x94all our Saxon ancestors would disown us were\r\nwe to treat of a new union for her ere the grave of him she should have\r\nwedded\xe2\x80\x94him, so much the most worthy of her hand by birth and\r\nancestry\xe2\x80\x94is yet closed. The ghost of Athelstane himself would burst his\r\nbloody cerements and stand before us to forbid such dishonour to his\r\nmemory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt seemed as if Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s words had raised a spectre; for, scarce had he\r\nuttered them ere the door flew open, and Athelstane, arrayed in the\r\ngarments of the grave, stood before them, pale, haggard, and like\r\nsomething arisen from the dead! 59\r\n\r\nThe effect of this apparition on the persons present was utterly\r\nappalling. Cedric started back as far as the wall of the apartment\r\nwould permit, and, leaning against it as one unable to support himself,\r\ngazed on the figure of his friend with eyes that seemed fixed, and a\r\nmouth which he appeared incapable of shutting. Ivanhoe crossed himself,\r\nrepeating prayers in Saxon, Latin, or Norman-French, as they occurred\r\nto his memory, while Richard alternately said, \xe2\x80\x9cBenedicite\xe2\x80\x9d, and swore,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMort de ma vie!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the meantime, a horrible noise was heard below stairs, some crying,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSecure the treacherous monks!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94others, \xe2\x80\x9cDown with them into the\r\ndungeon!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94others, \xe2\x80\x9cPitch them from the highest battlements!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, addressing what seemed the spectre\r\nof his departed friend, \xe2\x80\x9cif thou art mortal, speak!\xe2\x80\x94if a departed\r\nspirit, say for what cause thou dost revisit us, or if I can do aught\r\nthat can set thy spirit at repose.\xe2\x80\x94Living or dead, noble Athelstane,\r\nspeak to Cedric!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will,\xe2\x80\x9d said the spectre, very composedly, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen I have collected\r\nbreath, and when you give me time\xe2\x80\x94Alive, saidst thou?\xe2\x80\x94I am as much\r\nalive as he can be who has fed on bread and water for three days, which\r\nseem three ages\xe2\x80\x94Yes, bread and water, Father Cedric! By Heaven, and all\r\nsaints in it, better food hath not passed my weasand for three livelong\r\ndays, and by God\xe2\x80\x99s providence it is that I am now here to tell it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, noble Athelstane,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Black Knight, \xe2\x80\x9cI myself saw you\r\nstruck down by the fierce Templar towards the end of the storm at\r\nTorquilstone, and as I thought, and Wamba reported, your skull was\r\ncloven through the teeth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou thought amiss, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cand Wamba lied. My\r\nteeth are in good order, and that my supper shall presently find\xe2\x80\x94No\r\nthanks to the Templar though, whose sword turned in his hand, so that\r\nthe blade struck me flatlings, being averted by the handle of the good\r\nmace with which I warded the blow; had my steel-cap been on, I had not\r\nvalued it a rush, and had dealt him such a counter-buff as would have\r\nspoilt his retreat. But as it was, down I went, stunned, indeed, but\r\nunwounded. Others, of both sides, were beaten down and slaughtered\r\nabove me, so that I never recovered my senses until I found myself in a\r\ncoffin\xe2\x80\x94(an open one, by good luck)\xe2\x80\x94placed before the altar of the\r\nchurch of Saint Edmund\xe2\x80\x99s. I sneezed repeatedly\xe2\x80\x94groaned\xe2\x80\x94awakened and\r\nwould have arisen, when the Sacristan and Abbot, full of terror, came\r\nrunning at the noise, surprised, doubtless, and no way pleased to find\r\nthe man alive, whose heirs they had proposed themselves to be. I asked\r\nfor wine\xe2\x80\x94they gave me some, but it must have been highly medicated, for\r\nI slept yet more deeply than before, and wakened not for many hours. I\r\nfound my arms swathed down\xe2\x80\x94my feet tied so fast that mine ankles ache\r\nat the very remembrance\xe2\x80\x94the place was utterly dark\xe2\x80\x94the oubliette, as I\r\nsuppose, of their accursed convent, and from the close, stifled, damp\r\nsmell, I conceive it is also used for a place of sepulture. I had\r\nstrange thoughts of what had befallen me, when the door of my dungeon\r\ncreaked, and two villain monks entered. They would have persuaded me I\r\nwas in purgatory, but I knew too well the pursy short-breathed voice of\r\nthe Father Abbot.\xe2\x80\x94Saint Jeremy! how different from that tone with which\r\nhe used to ask me for another slice of the haunch!\xe2\x80\x94the dog has feasted\r\nwith me from Christmas to Twelfth-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave patience, noble Athelstane,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, \xe2\x80\x9ctake breath\xe2\x80\x94tell\r\nyour story at leisure\xe2\x80\x94beshrew me but such a tale is as well worth\r\nlistening to as a romance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy but, by the rood of Bromeholm, there was no romance in the matter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Athelstane.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA barley loaf and a pitcher of water\xe2\x80\x94that THEY gave\r\nme, the niggardly traitors, whom my father, and I myself, had enriched,\r\nwhen their best resources were the flitches of bacon and measures of\r\ncorn, out of which they wheedled poor serfs and bondsmen, in exchange\r\nfor their prayers\xe2\x80\x94the nest of foul ungrateful vipers\xe2\x80\x94barley bread and\r\nditch water to such a patron as I had been! I will smoke them out of\r\ntheir nest, though I be excommunicated!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, in the name of Our Lady, noble Athelstane,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, grasping\r\nthe hand of his friend, \xe2\x80\x9chow didst thou escape this imminent danger\xe2\x80\x94did\r\ntheir hearts relent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid their hearts relent!\xe2\x80\x9d echoed Athelstane.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDo rocks melt with the\r\nsun? I should have been there still, had not some stir in the Convent,\r\nwhich I find was their procession hitherward to eat my funeral feast,\r\nwhen they well knew how and where I had been buried alive, summoned the\r\nswarm out of their hive. I heard them droning out their death-psalms,\r\nlittle judging they were sung in respect for my soul by those who were\r\nthus famishing my body. They went, however, and I waited long for\r\nfood\xe2\x80\x94no wonder\xe2\x80\x94the gouty Sacristan was even too busy with his own\r\nprovender to mind mine. At length down he came, with an unstable step\r\nand a strong flavour of wine and spices about his person. Good cheer\r\nhad opened his heart, for he left me a nook of pasty and a flask of\r\nwine, instead of my former fare. I ate, drank, and was invigorated;\r\nwhen, to add to my good luck, the Sacristan, too totty to discharge his\r\nduty of turnkey fitly, locked the door beside the staple, so that it\r\nfell ajar. The light, the food, the wine, set my invention to work. The\r\nstaple to which my chains were fixed, was more rusted than I or the\r\nvillain Abbot had supposed. Even iron could not remain without\r\nconsuming in the damps of that infernal dungeon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake breath, noble Athelstane,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard, \xe2\x80\x9cand partake of some\r\nrefreshment, ere you proceed with a tale so dreadful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPartake!\xe2\x80\x9d quoth Athelstane; \xe2\x80\x9cI have been partaking five times\r\nto-day\xe2\x80\x94and yet a morsel of that savoury ham were not altogether foreign\r\nto the matter; and I pray you, fair sir, to do me reason in a cup of\r\nwine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe guests, though still agape with astonishment, pledged their\r\nresuscitated landlord, who thus proceeded in his story:\xe2\x80\x94He had indeed\r\nnow many more auditors than those to whom it was commenced, for Edith,\r\nhaving given certain necessary orders for arranging matters within the\r\nCastle, had followed the dead-alive up to the stranger\xe2\x80\x99s apartment\r\nattended by as many of the guests, male and female, as could squeeze\r\ninto the small room, while others, crowding the staircase, caught up an\r\nerroneous edition of the story, and transmitted it still more\r\ninaccurately to those beneath, who again sent it forth to the vulgar\r\nwithout, in a fashion totally irreconcilable to the real fact.\r\nAthelstane, however, went on as follows, with the history of his\r\nescape:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFinding myself freed from the staple, I dragged myself up stairs as\r\nwell as a man loaded with shackles, and emaciated with fasting, might;\r\nand after much groping about, I was at length directed, by the sound of\r\na jolly roundelay, to the apartment where the worthy Sacristan, an it\r\nso please ye, was holding a devil\xe2\x80\x99s mass with a huge beetle-browed,\r\nbroad-shouldered brother of the grey-frock and cowl, who looked much\r\nmore like a thief than a clergyman. I burst in upon them, and the\r\nfashion of my grave-clothes, as well as the clanking of my chains, made\r\nme more resemble an inhabitant of the other world than of this. Both\r\nstood aghast; but when I knocked down the Sacristan with my fist, the\r\nother fellow, his pot-companion, fetched a blow at me with a huge\r\nquarter-staff.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis must be our Friar Tuck, for a count\xe2\x80\x99s ransom,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard,\r\nlooking at Ivanhoe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe may be the devil, an he will,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane. \xe2\x80\x9cFortunately he\r\nmissed the aim; and on my approaching to grapple with him, took to his\r\nheels and ran for it. I failed not to set my own heels at liberty by\r\nmeans of the fetter-key, which hung amongst others at the sexton\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbelt; and I had thoughts of beating out the knave\xe2\x80\x99s brains with the\r\nbunch of keys, but gratitude for the nook of pasty and the flask of\r\nwine which the rascal had imparted to my captivity, came over my heart;\r\nso, with a brace of hearty kicks, I left him on the floor, pouched some\r\nbaked meat, and a leathern bottle of wine, with which the two venerable\r\nbrethren had been regaling, went to the stable, and found in a private\r\nstall mine own best palfrey, which, doubtless, had been set apart for\r\nthe holy Father Abbot\xe2\x80\x99s particular use. Hither I came with all the\r\nspeed the beast could compass\xe2\x80\x94man and mother\xe2\x80\x99s son flying before me\r\nwherever I came, taking me for a spectre, the more especially as, to\r\nprevent my being recognised, I drew the corpse-hood over my face. I had\r\nnot gained admittance into my own castle, had I not been supposed to be\r\nthe attendant of a juggler who is making the people in the castle-yard\r\nvery merry, considering they are assembled to celebrate their lord\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfuneral\xe2\x80\x94I say the sewer thought I was dressed to bear a part in the\r\ntregetour\xe2\x80\x99s mummery, and so I got admission, and did but disclose\r\nmyself to my mother, and eat a hasty morsel, ere I came in quest of\r\nyou, my noble friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have found me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric, \xe2\x80\x9cready to resume our brave\r\nprojects of honour and liberty. I tell thee, never will dawn a morrow\r\nso auspicious as the next, for the deliverance of the noble Saxon\r\nrace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTalk not to me of delivering any one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane; \xe2\x80\x9cit is well I\r\nam delivered myself. I am more intent on punishing that villain Abbot.\r\nHe shall hang on the top of this Castle of Coningsburgh, in his cope\r\nand stole; and if the stairs be too strait to admit his fat carcass, I\r\nwill have him craned up from without.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my son,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edith, \xe2\x80\x9cconsider his sacred office.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConsider my three days\xe2\x80\x99 fast,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athelstane; \xe2\x80\x9cI will have their\r\nblood every one of them. Front-de-B\xc5\x93uf was burnt alive for a less\r\nmatter, for he kept a good table for his prisoners, only put too much\r\ngarlic in his last dish of pottage. But these hypocritical, ungrateful\r\nslaves, so often the self-invited flatterers at my board, who gave me\r\nneither pottage nor garlic, more or less, they die, by the soul of\r\nHengist!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the Pope, my noble friend,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94said Cedric\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the devil, my noble friend,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94answered Athelstane; \xe2\x80\x9cthey die, and\r\nno more of them. Were they the best monks upon earth, the world would\r\ngo on without them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor shame, noble Athelstane,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cforget such wretches in\r\nthe career of glory which lies open before thee. Tell this Norman\r\nprince, Richard of Anjou, that, lion-hearted as he is, he shall not\r\nhold undisputed the throne of Alfred, while a male descendant of the\r\nHoly Confessor lives to dispute it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cis this the noble King Richard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Richard Plantagenet himself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric; \xe2\x80\x9cyet I need not\r\nremind thee that, coming hither a guest of free-will, he may neither be\r\ninjured nor detained prisoner\xe2\x80\x94thou well knowest thy duty to him as his\r\nhost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, by my faith!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane; \xe2\x80\x9cand my duty as a subject besides,\r\nfor I here tender him my allegiance, heart and hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy son,\xe2\x80\x9d said Edith, \xe2\x80\x9cthink on thy royal rights!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink on the freedom of England, degenerate Prince!\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother and friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9ca truce to your\r\nupbraidings\xe2\x80\x94bread and water and a dungeon are marvellous mortifiers of\r\nambition, and I rise from the tomb a wiser man than I descended into\r\nit. One half of those vain follies were puffed into mine ear by that\r\nperfidious Abbot Wolfram, and you may now judge if he is a counsellor\r\nto be trusted. Since these plots were set in agitation, I have had\r\nnothing but hurried journeys, indigestions, blows and bruises,\r\nimprisonments and starvation; besides that they can only end in the\r\nmurder of some thousands of quiet folk. I tell you, I will be king in\r\nmy own domains, and nowhere else; and my first act of dominion shall be\r\nto hang the Abbot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd my ward Rowena,\xe2\x80\x9d said Cedric\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI trust you intend not to desert\r\nher?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFather Cedric,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cbe reasonable. The Lady Rowena cares\r\nnot for me\xe2\x80\x94she loves the little finger of my kinsman Wilfred\xe2\x80\x99s glove\r\nbetter than my whole person. There she stands to avouch it\xe2\x80\x94Nay, blush\r\nnot, kinswoman, there is no shame in loving a courtly knight better\r\nthan a country franklin\xe2\x80\x94and do not laugh neither, Rowena, for\r\ngrave-clothes and a thin visage are, God knows, no matter of\r\nmerriment\xe2\x80\x94Nay, an thou wilt needs laugh, I will find thee a better\r\njest\xe2\x80\x94Give me thy hand, or rather lend it me, for I but ask it in the\r\nway of friendship.\xe2\x80\x94Here, cousin Wilfred of Ivanhoe, in thy favour I\r\nrenounce and abjure\xe2\x80\x94-Hey! by Saint Dunstan, our cousin Wilfred hath\r\nvanished!\xe2\x80\x94Yet, unless my eyes are still dazzled with the fasting I have\r\nundergone, I saw him stand there but even now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll now looked around and enquired for Ivanhoe, but he had vanished. It\r\nwas at length discovered that a Jew had been to seek him; and that,\r\nafter very brief conference, he had called for Gurth and his armour,\r\nand had left the castle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFair cousin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane to Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9ccould I think that this\r\nsudden disappearance of Ivanhoe was occasioned by other than the\r\nweightiest reason, I would myself resume\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he had no sooner let go her hand, on first observing that Ivanhoe\r\nhad disappeared, than Rowena, who had found her situation extremely\r\nembarrassing, had taken the first opportunity to escape from the\r\napartment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d quoth Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cwomen are the least to be trusted of\r\nall animals, monks and abbots excepted. I am an infidel, if I expected\r\nnot thanks from her, and perhaps a kiss to boot\xe2\x80\x94These cursed\r\ngrave-clothes have surely a spell on them, every one flies from me.\xe2\x80\x94To\r\nyou I turn, noble King Richard, with the vows of allegiance, which, as\r\na liege-subject\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut King Richard was gone also, and no one knew whither. At length it\r\nwas learned that he had hastened to the court-yard, summoned to his\r\npresence the Jew who had spoken with Ivanhoe, and after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nspeech with him, had called vehemently to horse, thrown himself upon a\r\nsteed, compelled the Jew to mount another, and set off at a rate,\r\nwhich, according to Wamba, rendered the old Jew\xe2\x80\x99s neck not worth a\r\npenny\xe2\x80\x99s purchase.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my halidome!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athelstane, \xe2\x80\x9cit is certain that Zernebock hath\r\npossessed himself of my castle in my absence. I return in my\r\ngrave-clothes, a pledge restored from the very sepulchre, and every one\r\nI speak to vanishes as soon as they hear my voice!\xe2\x80\x94But it skills not\r\ntalking of it. Come, my friends\xe2\x80\x94such of you as are left, follow me to\r\nthe banquet-hall, lest any more of us disappear\xe2\x80\x94it is, I trust, as yet\r\ntolerably furnished, as becomes the obsequies of an ancient Saxon\r\nnoble; and should we tarry any longer, who knows but the devil may fly\r\noff with the supper?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIII\r\n\r\n\r\nBe Mowbray\xe2\x80\x99s sins so heavy in his bosom,\r\nThat they may break his foaming courser\xe2\x80\x99s back,\r\nAnd throw the rider headlong in the lists,\r\nA caitiff recreant!\r\n\r\n\r\nRICHARD II\r\n\r\n\r\nOur scene now returns to the exterior of the Castle, or Preceptory, of\r\nTemplestowe, about the hour when the bloody die was to be cast for the\r\nlife or death of Rebecca. It was a scene of bustle and life, as if the\r\nwhole vicinity had poured forth its inhabitants to a village wake, or\r\nrural feast. But the earnest desire to look on blood and death, is not\r\npeculiar to those dark ages; though in the gladiatorial exercise of\r\nsingle combat and general tourney, they were habituated to the bloody\r\nspectacle of brave men falling by each other\xe2\x80\x99s hands. Even in our own\r\ndays, when morals are better understood, an execution, a bruising\r\nmatch, a riot, or a meeting of radical reformers, collects, at\r\nconsiderable hazard to themselves, immense crowds of spectators,\r\notherwise little interested, except to see how matters are to be\r\nconducted, or whether the heroes of the day are, in the heroic language\r\nof insurgent tailors, flints or dunghills.\r\n\r\nThe eyes, therefore, of a very considerable multitude, were bent on the\r\ngate of the Preceptory of Templestowe, with the purpose of witnessing\r\nthe procession; while still greater numbers had already surrounded the\r\ntiltyard belonging to that establishment. This enclosure was formed on\r\na piece of level ground adjoining to the Preceptory, which had been\r\nlevelled with care, for the exercise of military and chivalrous sports.\r\nIt occupied the brow of a soft and gentle eminence, was carefully\r\npalisaded around, and, as the Templars willingly invited spectators to\r\nbe witnesses of their skill in feats of chivalry, was amply supplied\r\nwith galleries and benches for their use.\r\n\r\nOn the present occasion, a throne was erected for the Grand Master at\r\nthe east end, surrounded with seats of distinction for the Preceptors\r\nand Knights of the Order. Over these floated the sacred standard,\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x9cLe Beau-seant\xe2\x80\x9d, which was the ensign, as its name was the\r\nbattle-cry, of the Templars.\r\n\r\nAt the opposite end of the lists was a pile of faggots, so arranged\r\naround a stake, deeply fixed in the ground, as to leave a space for the\r\nvictim whom they were destined to consume, to enter within the fatal\r\ncircle, in order to be chained to the stake by the fetters which hung\r\nready for that purpose. Beside this deadly apparatus stood four black\r\nslaves, whose colour and African features, then so little known in\r\nEngland, appalled the multitude, who gazed on them as on demons\r\nemployed about their own diabolical exercises. These men stirred not,\r\nexcepting now and then, under the direction of one who seemed their\r\nchief, to shift and replace the ready fuel. They looked not on the\r\nmultitude. In fact, they seemed insensible of their presence, and of\r\nevery thing save the discharge of their own horrible duty.\r\n\r\nAnd when, in speech with each other, they expanded their blubber lips,\r\nand showed their white fangs, as if they grinned at the thoughts of the\r\nexpected tragedy, the startled commons could scarcely help believing\r\nthat they were actually the familiar spirits with whom the witch had\r\ncommuned, and who, her time being out, stood ready to assist in her\r\ndreadful punishment. They whispered to each other, and communicated all\r\nthe feats which Satan had performed during that busy and unhappy\r\nperiod, not failing, of course, to give the devil rather more than his\r\ndue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not heard, Father Dennet,\xe2\x80\x9d quoth one boor to another advanced\r\nin years, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the devil has carried away bodily the great Saxon\r\nThane, Athelstane of Coningsburgh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but he brought him back though, by the blessing of God and Saint\r\nDunstan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d said a brisk young fellow, dressed in a green cassock\r\nembroidered with gold, and having at his heels a stout lad bearing a\r\nharp upon his back, which betrayed his vocation. The Minstrel seemed of\r\nno vulgar rank; for, besides the splendour of his gaily braidered\r\ndoublet, he wore around his neck a silver chain, by which hung the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwrest\xe2\x80\x9d, or key, with which he tuned his harp. On his right arm was a\r\nsilver plate, which, instead of bearing, as usual, the cognizance or\r\nbadge of the baron to whose family he belonged, had barely the word\r\nSHERWOOD engraved upon it.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHow mean you by that?\xe2\x80\x9d said the gay\r\nMinstrel, mingling in the conversation of the peasants; \xe2\x80\x9cI came to seek\r\none subject for my rhyme, and, by\xe2\x80\x99r Lady, I were glad to find two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well avouched,\xe2\x80\x9d said the elder peasant, \xe2\x80\x9cthat after Athelstane\r\nof Coningsburgh had been dead four weeks\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Minstrel; \xe2\x80\x9cI saw him in life at the\r\nPassage of Arms at Ashby-de-la-Zouche.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead, however, he was, or else translated,\xe2\x80\x9d said the younger peasant;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfor I heard the Monks of Saint Edmund\xe2\x80\x99s singing the death\xe2\x80\x99s hymn for\r\nhim; and, moreover, there was a rich death-meal and dole at the Castle\r\nof Coningsburgh, as right was; and thither had I gone, but for Mabel\r\nParkins, who\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, dead was Athelstane,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man, shaking his head, \xe2\x80\x9cand the\r\nmore pity it was, for the old Saxon blood\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, your story, my masters\xe2\x80\x94your story,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Minstrel, somewhat\r\nimpatiently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay\xe2\x80\x94construe us the story,\xe2\x80\x9d said a burly Friar, who stood beside\r\nthem, leaning on a pole that exhibited an appearance between a\r\npilgrim\xe2\x80\x99s staff and a quarter-staff, and probably acted as either when\r\noccasion served,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYour story,\xe2\x80\x9d said the stalwart churchman; \xe2\x80\x9cburn not\r\ndaylight about it\xe2\x80\x94we have short time to spare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn please your reverence,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dennet, \xe2\x80\x9ca drunken priest came to\r\nvisit the Sacristan at Saint Edmund\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt does not please my reverence,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the churchman, \xe2\x80\x9cthat there\r\nshould be such an animal as a drunken priest, or, if there were, that a\r\nlayman should so speak him. Be mannerly, my friend, and conclude the\r\nholy man only wrapt in meditation, which makes the head dizzy and foot\r\nunsteady, as if the stomach were filled with new wine\xe2\x80\x94I have felt it\r\nmyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Father Dennet, \xe2\x80\x9ca holy brother came to visit the\r\nSacristan at Saint Edmund\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94a sort of hedge-priest is the visitor, and\r\nkills half the deer that are stolen in the forest, who loves the\r\ntinkling of a pint-pot better than the sacring-bell, and deems a flitch\r\nof bacon worth ten of his breviary; for the rest, a good fellow and a\r\nmerry, who will flourish a quarter-staff, draw a bow, and dance a\r\nCheshire round, with e\xe2\x80\x99er a man in Yorkshire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat last part of thy speech, Dennet,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Minstrel, \xe2\x80\x9chas saved\r\nthee a rib or twain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTush, man, I fear him not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dennet; \xe2\x80\x9cI am somewhat old and stiff,\r\nbut when I fought for the bell and ram at Doncaster\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the story\xe2\x80\x94the story, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d again said the Minstrel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, the tale is but this\xe2\x80\x94Athelstane of Coningsburgh was buried at\r\nSaint Edmund\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a lie, and a loud one,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, \xe2\x80\x9cfor I saw him borne to\r\nhis own Castle of Coningsburgh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, then, e\xe2\x80\x99en tell the story yourself, my masters,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dennet,\r\nturning sulky at these repeated contradictions; and it was with some\r\ndifficulty that the boor could be prevailed on, by the request of his\r\ncomrade and the Minstrel, to renew his tale.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThese two \xe2\x80\x98sober\xe2\x80\x99\r\nfriars,\xe2\x80\x9d said he at length, \xe2\x80\x9csince this reverend man will needs have\r\nthem such, had continued drinking good ale, and wine, and what not, for\r\nthe best part for a summer\xe2\x80\x99s day, when they were aroused by a deep\r\ngroan, and a clanking of chains, and the figure of the deceased\r\nAthelstane entered the apartment, saying, \xe2\x80\x98Ye evil shep-herds!\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is false,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, hastily, \xe2\x80\x9che never spoke a word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo ho! Friar Tuck,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Minstrel, drawing him apart from the\r\nrustics; \xe2\x80\x9cwe have started a new hare, I find.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell thee, Allan-a-Dale,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Hermit, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw Athelstane of\r\nConingsburgh as much as bodily eyes ever saw a living man. He had his\r\nshroud on, and all about him smelt of the sepulchre\xe2\x80\x94A butt of sack will\r\nnot wash it out of my memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPshaw!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Minstrel; \xe2\x80\x9cthou dost but jest with me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever believe me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Friar, \xe2\x80\x9can I fetched not a knock at him\r\nwith my quarter-staff that would have felled an ox, and it glided\r\nthrough his body as it might through a pillar of smoke!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Saint Hubert,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Minstrel, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it is a wondrous tale, and\r\nfit to be put in metre to the ancient tune, \xe2\x80\x98Sorrow came to the old\r\nFriar.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLaugh, if ye list,\xe2\x80\x9d said Friar Tuck; \xe2\x80\x9cbut an ye catch me singing on\r\nsuch a theme, may the next ghost or devil carry me off with him\r\nheadlong! No, no\xe2\x80\x94I instantly formed the purpose of assisting at some\r\ngood work, such as the burning of a witch, a judicial combat, or the\r\nlike matter of godly service, and therefore am I here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs they thus conversed, the heavy bell of the church of Saint Michael\r\nof Templestowe, a venerable building, situated in a hamlet at some\r\ndistance from the Preceptory, broke short their argument. One by one\r\nthe sullen sounds fell successively on the ear, leaving but sufficient\r\nspace for each to die away in distant echo, ere the air was again\r\nfilled by repetition of the iron knell. These sounds, the signal of the\r\napproaching ceremony, chilled with awe the hearts of the assembled\r\nmultitude, whose eyes were now turned to the Preceptory, expecting the\r\napproach of the Grand Master, the champion, and the criminal.\r\n\r\nAt length the drawbridge fell, the gates opened, and a knight, bearing\r\nthe great standard of the Order, sallied from the castle, preceded by\r\nsix trumpets, and followed by the Knights Preceptors, two and two, the\r\nGrand Master coming last, mounted on a stately horse, whose furniture\r\nwas of the simplest kind. Behind him came Brian de Bois-Guilbert, armed\r\ncap-a-pie in bright armour, but without his lance, shield, and sword,\r\nwhich were borne by his two esquires behind him. His face, though\r\npartly hidden by a long plume which floated down from his barrel-cap,\r\nbore a strong and mingled expression of passion, in which pride seemed\r\nto contend with irresolution. He looked ghastly pale, as if he had not\r\nslept for several nights, yet reined his pawing war-horse with the\r\nhabitual ease and grace proper to the best lance of the Order of the\r\nTemple. His general appearance was grand and commanding; but, looking\r\nat him with attention, men read that in his dark features, from which\r\nthey willingly withdrew their eyes.\r\n\r\nOn either side rode Conrade of Mont-Fitchet, and Albert de Malvoisin,\r\nwho acted as godfathers to the champion. They were in their robes of\r\npeace, the white dress of the Order. Behind them followed other\r\nCompanions of the Temple, with a long train of esquires and pages clad\r\nin black, aspirants to the honour of being one day Knights of the\r\nOrder. After these neophytes came a guard of warders on foot, in the\r\nsame sable livery, amidst whose partisans might be seen the pale form\r\nof the accused, moving with a slow but undismayed step towards the\r\nscene of her fate. She was stript of all her ornaments, lest perchance\r\nthere should be among them some of those amulets which Satan was\r\nsupposed to bestow upon his victims, to deprive them of the power of\r\nconfession even when under the torture. A coarse white dress, of the\r\nsimplest form, had been substituted for her Oriental garments; yet\r\nthere was such an exquisite mixture of courage and resignation in her\r\nlook, that even in this garb, and with no other ornament than her long\r\nblack tresses, each eye wept that looked upon her, and the most\r\nhardened bigot regretted the fate that had converted a creature so\r\ngoodly into a vessel of wrath, and a waged slave of the devil.\r\n\r\nA crowd of inferior personages belonging to the Preceptory followed the\r\nvictim, all moving with the utmost order, with arms folded, and looks\r\nbent upon the ground.\r\n\r\nThis slow procession moved up the gentle eminence, on the summit of\r\nwhich was the tiltyard, and, entering the lists, marched once around\r\nthem from right to left, and when they had completed the circle, made a\r\nhalt. There was then a momentary bustle, while the Grand Master and all\r\nhis attendants, excepting the champion and his godfathers, dismounted\r\nfrom their horses, which were immediately removed out of the lists by\r\nthe esquires, who were in attendance for that purpose.\r\n\r\nThe unfortunate Rebecca was conducted to the black chair placed near\r\nthe pile. On her first glance at the terrible spot where preparations\r\nwere making for a death alike dismaying to the mind and painful to the\r\nbody, she was observed to shudder and shut her eyes, praying internally\r\ndoubtless, for her lips moved though no speech was heard. In the space\r\nof a minute she opened her eyes, looked fixedly on the pile as if to\r\nfamiliarize her mind with the object, and then slowly and naturally\r\nturned away her head.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, the Grand Master had assumed his seat; and when the chivalry\r\nof his order was placed around and behind him, each in his due rank, a\r\nloud and long flourish of the trumpets announced that the Court were\r\nseated for judgment.
