Malvoisin, then, acting as godfather of the\r\nchampion, stepped forward, and laid the glove of the Jewess, which was\r\nthe pledge of battle, at the feet of the Grand Master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cValorous Lord, and reverend Father,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9chere standeth the good\r\nKnight, Brian de Bois-Guilbert, Knight Preceptor of the Order of the\r\nTemple, who, by accepting the pledge of battle which I now lay at your\r\nreverence\xe2\x80\x99s feet, hath become bound to do his devoir in combat this\r\nday, to maintain that this Jewish maiden, by name Rebecca, hath justly\r\ndeserved the doom passed upon her in a Chapter of this most Holy Order\r\nof the Temple of Zion, condemning her to die as a sorceress;\xe2\x80\x94here, I\r\nsay, he standeth, such battle to do, knightly and honourable, if such\r\nbe your noble and sanctified pleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHath he made oath,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cthat his quarrel is just\r\nand honourable? Bring forward the Crucifix and the \xe2\x80\x98Te igitur\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, and most reverend father,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Malvoisin, readily, \xe2\x80\x9cour\r\nbrother here present hath already sworn to the truth of his accusation\r\nin the hand of the good Knight Conrade de Mont-Fitchet; and otherwise\r\nhe ought not to be sworn, seeing that his adversary is an unbeliever,\r\nand may take no oath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis explanation was satisfactory, to Albert\xe2\x80\x99s great joy; for the wily\r\nknight had foreseen the great difficulty, or rather impossibility, of\r\nprevailing upon Brian de Bois-Guilbert to take such an oath before the\r\nassembly, and had invented this excuse to escape the necessity of his\r\ndoing so.\r\n\r\nThe Grand Master, having allowed the apology of Albert Malvoisin,\r\ncommanded the herald to stand forth and do his devoir. The trumpets\r\nthen again flourished, and a herald, stepping forward, proclaimed\r\naloud,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cOyez, oyez, oyez.\xe2\x80\x94Here standeth the good Knight, Sir Brian de\r\nBois-Guilbert, ready to do battle with any knight of free blood, who\r\nwill sustain the quarrel allowed and allotted to the Jewess Rebecca, to\r\ntry by champion, in respect of lawful essoine of her own body; and to\r\nsuch champion the reverend and valorous Grand Master here present\r\nallows a fair field, and equal partition of sun and wind, and whatever\r\nelse appertains to a fair combat.\xe2\x80\x9d The trumpets again sounded, and\r\nthere was a dead pause of many minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo champion appears for the appellant,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master. \xe2\x80\x9cGo,\r\nherald, and ask her whether she expects any one to do battle for her in\r\nthis her cause.\xe2\x80\x9d The herald went to the chair in which Rebecca was\r\nseated, and Bois-Guilbert suddenly turning his horse\xe2\x80\x99s head toward that\r\nend of the lists, in spite of hints on either side from Malvoisin and\r\nMont-Fitchet, was by the side of Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s chair as soon as the herald.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this regular, and according to the law of combat?\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin,\r\nlooking to the Grand Master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlbert de Malvoisin, it is,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Beaumanoir; \xe2\x80\x9cfor in this appeal\r\nto the judgment of God, we may not prohibit parties from having that\r\ncommunication with each other, which may best tend to bring forth the\r\ntruth of the quarrel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the meantime, the herald spoke to Rebecca in these terms:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDamsel,\r\nthe Honourable and Reverend the Grand Master demands of thee, if thou\r\nart prepared with a champion to do battle this day in thy behalf, or if\r\nthou dost yield thee as one justly condemned to a deserved doom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay to the Grand Master,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I maintain my\r\ninnocence, and do not yield me as justly condemned, lest I become\r\nguilty of mine own blood. Say to him, that I challenge such delay as\r\nhis forms will permit, to see if God, whose opportunity is in man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nextremity, will raise me up a deliverer; and when such uttermost space\r\nis passed, may His holy will be done!\xe2\x80\x9d The herald retired to carry this\r\nanswer to the Grand Master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod forbid,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lucas Beaumanoir, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Jew or Pagan should impeach\r\nus of injustice!\xe2\x80\x94Until the shadows be cast from the west to the\r\neastward, will we wait to see if a champion shall appear for this\r\nunfortunate woman. When the day is so far passed, let her prepare for\r\ndeath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe herald communicated the words of the Grand Master to Rebecca, who\r\nbowed her head submissively, folded her arms, and, looking up towards\r\nheaven, seemed to expect that aid from above which she could scarce\r\npromise herself from man. During this awful pause, the voice of\r\nBois-Guilbert broke upon her ear\xe2\x80\x94it was but a whisper, yet it startled\r\nher more than the summons of the herald had appeared to do.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, \xe2\x80\x9cdost thou hear me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no portion in thee, cruel, hard-hearted man,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nunfortunate maiden.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, but dost thou understand my words?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cfor the\r\nsound of my voice is frightful in mine own ears. I scarce know on what\r\nground we stand, or for what purpose they have brought us hither.\xe2\x80\x94This\r\nlisted space\xe2\x80\x94that chair\xe2\x80\x94these faggots\xe2\x80\x94I know their purpose, and yet it\r\nappears to me like something unreal\xe2\x80\x94the fearful picture of a vision,\r\nwhich appals my sense with hideous fantasies, but convinces not my\r\nreason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mind and senses keep touch and time,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cand tell\r\nme alike that these faggots are destined to consume my earthly body,\r\nand open a painful but a brief passage to a better world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDreams, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x94dreams,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Templar; \xe2\x80\x9cidle visions,\r\nrejected by the wisdom of your own wiser Sadducees. Hear me, Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said, proceeding with animation; \xe2\x80\x9ca better chance hast thou for life\r\nand liberty than yonder knaves and dotard dream of. Mount thee behind\r\nme on my steed\xe2\x80\x94on Zamor, the gallant horse that never failed his rider.\r\nI won him in single fight from the Soldan of Trebizond\xe2\x80\x94mount, I say,\r\nbehind me\xe2\x80\x94in one short hour is pursuit and enquiry far behind\xe2\x80\x94a new\r\nworld of pleasure opens to thee\xe2\x80\x94to me a new career of fame. Let them\r\nspeak the doom which I despise, and erase the name of Bois-Guilbert\r\nfrom their list of monastic slaves! I will wash out with blood whatever\r\nblot they may dare to cast on my scutcheon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTempter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cbegone!\xe2\x80\x94Not in this last extremity canst thou\r\nmove me one hair\xe2\x80\x99s-breadth from my resting place\xe2\x80\x94surrounded as I am by\r\nfoes, I hold thee as my worst and most deadly enemy\xe2\x80\x94avoid thee, in the\r\nname of God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlbert Malvoisin, alarmed and impatient at the duration of their\r\nconference, now advanced to interrupt it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHath the maiden acknowledged her guilt?\xe2\x80\x9d he demanded of Bois-Guilbert;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cor is she resolute in her denial?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is indeed resolute,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bois-Guilbert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin, \xe2\x80\x9cmust thou, noble brother, resume thy place to\r\nattend the issue\xe2\x80\x94The shades are changing on the circle of the\r\ndial\xe2\x80\x94Come, brave Bois-Guilbert\xe2\x80\x94come, thou hope of our holy Order, and\r\nsoon to be its head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he spoke in this soothing tone, he laid his hand on the knight\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbridle, as if to lead him back to his station.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFalse villain! what meanest thou by thy hand on my rein?\xe2\x80\x9d said Sir\r\nBrian, angrily. And shaking off his companion\xe2\x80\x99s grasp, he rode back to\r\nthe upper end of the lists.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is yet spirit in him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin apart to Mont-Fitchet,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwere it well directed\xe2\x80\x94but, like the Greek fire, it burns whatever\r\napproaches it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Judges had now been two hours in the lists, awaiting in vain the\r\nappearance of a champion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd reason good,\xe2\x80\x9d said Friar Tuck, \xe2\x80\x9cseeing she is a Jewess\xe2\x80\x94and yet, by\r\nmine Order, it is hard that so young and beautiful a creature should\r\nperish without one blow being struck in her behalf! Were she ten times\r\na witch, provided she were but the least bit of a Christian, my\r\nquarter-staff should ring noon on the steel cap of yonder fierce\r\nTemplar, ere he carried the matter off thus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was, however, the general belief that no one could or would appear\r\nfor a Jewess, accused of sorcery; and the knights, instigated by\r\nMalvoisin, whispered to each other, that it was time to declare the\r\npledge of Rebecca forfeited. At this instant a knight, urging his horse\r\nto speed, appeared on the plain advancing towards the lists. A hundred\r\nvoices exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cA champion! a champion!\xe2\x80\x9d And despite the\r\nprepossessions and prejudices of the multitude, they shouted\r\nunanimously as the knight rode into the tiltyard. The second glance,\r\nhowever, served to destroy the hope that his timely arrival had\r\nexcited. His horse, urged for many miles to its utmost speed, appeared\r\nto reel from fatigue, and the rider, however undauntedly he presented\r\nhimself in the lists, either from weakness, weariness, or both, seemed\r\nscarce able to support himself in the saddle.\r\n\r\nTo the summons of the herald, who demanded his rank, his name, and\r\npurpose, the stranger knight answered readily and boldly, \xe2\x80\x9cI am a good\r\nknight and noble, come hither to sustain with lance and sword the just\r\nand lawful quarrel of this damsel, Rebecca, daughter of Isaac of York;\r\nto uphold the doom pronounced against her to be false and truthless,\r\nand to defy Sir Brian de Bois-Guilbert, as a traitor, murderer, and\r\nliar; as I will prove in this field with my body against his, by the\r\naid of God, of Our Lady, and of Monseigneur Saint George, the good\r\nknight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe stranger must first show,\xe2\x80\x9d said Malvoisin, \xe2\x80\x9cthat he is good\r\nknight, and of honourable lineage. The Temple sendeth not forth her\r\nchampions against nameless men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy name,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight, raising his helmet, \xe2\x80\x9cis better known, my\r\nlineage more pure, Malvoisin, than thine own. I am Wilfred of Ivanhoe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not fight with thee at present,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar, in a changed\r\nand hollow voice. \xe2\x80\x9cGet thy wounds healed, purvey thee a better horse,\r\nand it may be I will hold it worth my while to scourge out of thee this\r\nboyish spirit of bravado.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa! proud Templar,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9chast thou forgotten that twice\r\ndidst thou fall before this lance? Remember the lists at Acre\xe2\x80\x94remember\r\nthe Passage of Arms at Ashby\xe2\x80\x94remember thy proud vaunt in the halls of\r\nRotherwood, and the gage of your gold chain against my reliquary, that\r\nthou wouldst do battle with Wilfred of Ivanhoe, and recover the honour\r\nthou hadst lost! By that reliquary and the holy relic it contains, I\r\nwill proclaim thee, Templar, a coward in every court in Europe\xe2\x80\x94in every\r\nPreceptory of thine Order\xe2\x80\x94unless thou do battle without farther delay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBois-Guilbert turned his countenance irresolutely towards Rebecca, and\r\nthen exclaimed, looking fiercely at Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9cDog of a Saxon! take thy\r\nlance, and prepare for the death thou hast drawn upon thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes the Grand Master allow me the combat?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI may not deny what thou hast challenged,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cprovided the maiden accepts thee as her champion. Yet I would thou\r\nwert in better plight to do battle. An enemy of our Order hast thou\r\never been, yet would I have thee honourably met with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThus\xe2\x80\x94thus as I am, and not otherwise,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cit is the\r\njudgment of God\xe2\x80\x94to his keeping I commend myself.\xe2\x80\x94Rebecca,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\nriding up to the fatal chair, \xe2\x80\x9cdost thou accept of me for thy\r\nchampion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do,\xe2\x80\x9d she said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI do,\xe2\x80\x9d fluttered by an emotion which the fear of\r\ndeath had been unable to produce, \xe2\x80\x9cI do accept thee as the champion\r\nwhom Heaven hath sent me. Yet, no\xe2\x80\x94no\xe2\x80\x94thy wounds are uncured\xe2\x80\x94Meet not\r\nthat proud man\xe2\x80\x94why shouldst thou perish also?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Ivanhoe was already at his post, and had closed his visor, and\r\nassumed his lance. Bois-Guilbert did the same; and his esquire\r\nremarked, as he clasped his visor, that his face, which had,\r\nnotwithstanding the variety of emotions by which he had been agitated,\r\ncontinued during the whole morning of an ashy paleness, was now become\r\nsuddenly very much flushed.\r\n\r\nThe herald, then, seeing each champion in his place, uplifted his\r\nvoice, repeating thrice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cFaites vos devoirs, preux chevaliers!\xe2\x80\x9d After\r\nthe third cry, he withdrew to one side of the lists, and again\r\nproclaimed, that none, on peril of instant death, should dare, by word,\r\ncry, or action, to interfere with or disturb this fair field of combat.\r\nThe Grand Master, who held in his hand the gage of battle, Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nglove, now threw it into the lists, and pronounced the fatal signal\r\nwords, \xe2\x80\x9cLaissez aller\xe2\x80\x9d.\r\n\r\nThe trumpets sounded, and the knights charged each other in full\r\ncareer. The wearied horse of Ivanhoe, and its no less exhausted rider,\r\nwent down, as all had expected, before the well-aimed lance and\r\nvigorous steed of the Templar. This issue of the combat all had\r\nforeseen; but although the spear of Ivanhoe did but, in comparison,\r\ntouch the shield of Bois-Guilbert, that champion, to the astonishment\r\nof all who beheld it reeled in his saddle, lost his stirrups, and fell\r\nin the lists.\r\n\r\nIvanhoe, extricating himself from his fallen horse, was soon on foot,\r\nhastening to mend his fortune with his sword; but his antagonist arose\r\nnot. Wilfred, placing his foot on his breast, and the sword\xe2\x80\x99s point to\r\nhis throat, commanded him to yield him, or die on the spot.\r\nBois-Guilbert returned no answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSlay him not, Sir Knight,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cunshriven and\r\nunabsolved\xe2\x80\x94kill not body and soul! We allow him vanquished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe descended into the lists, and commanded them to unhelm the conquered\r\nchampion. His eyes were closed\xe2\x80\x94the dark red flush was still on his\r\nbrow. As they looked on him in astonishment, the eyes opened\xe2\x80\x94but they\r\nwere fixed and glazed. The flush passed from his brow, and gave way to\r\nthe pallid hue of death. Unscathed by the lance of his enemy, he had\r\ndied a victim to the violence of his own contending passions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is indeed the judgment of God,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, looking\r\nupwards\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Fiat voluntas tua!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XLIV\r\n\r\n\r\nSo! now \xe2\x80\x99tis ended, like an old wife\xe2\x80\x99s story.\r\n\r\n\r\nWEBSTER\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the first moments of surprise were over, Wilfred of Ivanhoe\r\ndemanded of the Grand Master, as judge of the field, if he had manfully\r\nand rightfully done his duty in the combat? \xe2\x80\x9cManfully and rightfully\r\nhath it been done,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master. \xe2\x80\x9cI pronounce the maiden free\r\nand guiltless\xe2\x80\x94The arms and the body of the deceased knight are at the\r\nwill of the victor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not despoil him of his weapons,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Knight of Ivanhoe,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnor condemn his corpse to shame\xe2\x80\x94he hath fought for Christendom\xe2\x80\x94God\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narm, no human hand, hath this day struck him down. But let his\r\nobsequies be private, as becomes those of a man who died in an unjust\r\nquarrel.\xe2\x80\x94And for the maiden\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was interrupted by a clattering of horses\xe2\x80\x99 feet, advancing in such\r\nnumbers, and so rapidly, as to shake the ground before them; and the\r\nBlack Knight galloped into the lists. He was followed by a numerous\r\nband of men-at-arms, and several knights in complete armour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am too late,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, looking around him. \xe2\x80\x9cI had doomed\r\nBois-Guilbert for mine own property.\xe2\x80\x94Ivanhoe, was this well, to take on\r\nthee such a venture, and thou scarce able to keep thy saddle?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeaven, my Liege,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Ivanhoe, \xe2\x80\x9chath taken this proud man for\r\nits victim. He was not to be honoured in dying as your will had\r\ndesigned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeace be with him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richard, looking steadfastly on the corpse,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif it may be so\xe2\x80\x94he was a gallant knight, and has died in his steel\r\nharness full knightly. But we must waste no time\xe2\x80\x94Bohun, do thine\r\noffice!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA Knight stepped forward from the King\xe2\x80\x99s attendants, and, laying his\r\nhand on the shoulder of Albert de Malvoisin, said, \xe2\x80\x9cI arrest thee of\r\nHigh Treason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Grand Master had hitherto stood astonished at the appearance of so\r\nmany warriors.\xe2\x80\x94He now spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho dares to arrest a Knight of the Temple of Zion, within the girth\r\nof his own Preceptory, and in the presence of the Grand Master? and by\r\nwhose authority is this bold outrage offered?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI make the arrest,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Knight\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI, Henry Bohun, Earl of Essex,\r\nLord High Constable of England.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he arrests Malvoisin,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, raising his visor, \xe2\x80\x9cby the\r\norder of Richard Plantagenet, here present.\xe2\x80\x94Conrade Mont-Fitchet, it is\r\nwell for thee thou art born no subject of mine.\xe2\x80\x94But for thee,\r\nMalvoisin, thou diest with thy brother Philip, ere the world be a week\r\nolder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will resist thy doom,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProud Templar,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King, \xe2\x80\x9cthou canst not\xe2\x80\x94look up, and behold the\r\nRoyal Standard of England floats over thy towers instead of thy Temple\r\nbanner!\xe2\x80\x94Be wise, Beaumanoir, and make no bootless opposition\xe2\x80\x94Thy hand\r\nis in the lion\xe2\x80\x99s mouth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will appeal to Rome against thee,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, \xe2\x80\x9cfor\r\nusurpation on the immunities and privileges of our Order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the King; \xe2\x80\x9cbut for thine own sake tax me not with\r\nusurpation now. Dissolve thy Chapter, and depart with thy followers to\r\nthy next Preceptory, (if thou canst find one), which has not been made\r\nthe scene of treasonable conspiracy against the King of England\xe2\x80\x94Or, if\r\nthou wilt, remain, to share our hospitality, and behold our justice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be a guest in the house where I should command?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Templar;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnever!\xe2\x80\x94Chaplains, raise the Psalm, \xe2\x80\x98Quare fremuerunt Gentes?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94Knights,\r\nsquires, and followers of the Holy Temple, prepare to follow the banner\r\nof \xe2\x80\x98Beau-seant!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Grand Master spoke with a dignity which confronted even that of\r\nEngland\xe2\x80\x99s king himself, and inspired courage into his surprised and\r\ndismayed followers. They gathered around him like the sheep around the\r\nwatch-dog, when they hear the baying of the wolf. But they evinced not\r\nthe timidity of the scared flock\xe2\x80\x94there were dark brows of defiance, and\r\nlooks which menaced the hostility they dared not to proffer in words.\r\nThey drew together in a dark line of spears, from which the white\r\ncloaks of the knights were visible among the dusky garments of their\r\nretainers, like the lighter-coloured edges of a sable cloud. The\r\nmultitude, who had raised a clamorous shout of reprobation, paused and\r\ngazed in silence on the formidable and experienced body to which they\r\nhad unwarily bade defiance, and shrunk back from their front.\r\n\r\nThe Earl of Essex, when he beheld them pause in their assembled force,\r\ndashed the rowels into his charger\xe2\x80\x99s sides, and galloped backwards and\r\nforwards to array his followers, in opposition to a band so formidable.\r\nRichard alone, as if he loved the danger his presence had provoked,\r\nrode slowly along the front of the Templars, calling aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\r\nsirs! Among so many gallant knights, will none dare splinter a spear\r\nwith Richard?\xe2\x80\x94Sirs of the Temple! your ladies are but sun-burned, if\r\nthey are not worth the shiver of a broken lance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Brethren of the Temple,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Grand Master, riding forward in\r\nadvance of their body, \xe2\x80\x9cfight not on such idle and profane quarrel\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nnot with thee, Richard of England, shall a Templar cross lance in my\r\npresence. The Pope and Princes of Europe shall judge our quarrel, and\r\nwhether a Christian prince has done well in bucklering the cause which\r\nthou hast to-day adopted. If unassailed, we depart assailing no one. To\r\nthine honour we refer the armour and household goods of the Order which\r\nwe leave behind us, and on thy conscience we lay the scandal and\r\noffence thou hast this day given to Christendom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words, and without waiting a reply, the Grand Master gave\r\nthe signal of departure. Their trumpets sounded a wild march, of an\r\nOriental character, which formed the usual signal for the Templars to\r\nadvance. They changed their array from a line to a column of march, and\r\nmoved off as slowly as their horses could step, as if to show it was\r\nonly the will of their Grand Master, and no fear of the opposing and\r\nsuperior force, which compelled them to withdraw.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the splendour of Our Lady\xe2\x80\x99s brow!\xe2\x80\x9d said King Richard, \xe2\x80\x9cit is pity\r\nof their lives that these Templars are not so trusty as they are\r\ndisciplined and valiant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe multitude, like a timid cur which waits to bark till the object of\r\nits challenge has turned his back, raised a feeble shout as the rear of\r\nthe squadron left the ground.\r\n\r\nDuring the tumult which attended the retreat of the Templars, Rebecca\r\nsaw and heard nothing\xe2\x80\x94she was locked in the arms of her aged father,\r\ngiddy, and almost senseless, with the rapid change of circumstances\r\naround her. But one word from Isaac at length recalled her scattered\r\nfeelings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmy dear daughter, my recovered treasure\xe2\x80\x94let us\r\ngo to throw ourselves at the feet of the good youth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cO no\xe2\x80\x94no\xe2\x80\x94no\xe2\x80\x94I must not at this moment dare to\r\nspeak to him\xe2\x80\x94Alas! I should say more than\xe2\x80\x94No, my father, let us\r\ninstantly leave this evil place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my daughter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, \xe2\x80\x9cto leave him who hath come forth like\r\na strong man with his spear and shield, holding his life as nothing, so\r\nhe might redeem thy captivity; and thou, too, the daughter of a people\r\nstrange unto him and his\xe2\x80\x94this is service to be thankfully\r\nacknowledged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is\xe2\x80\x94it is\xe2\x80\x94most thankfully\xe2\x80\x94most devoutly acknowledged,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nRebecca\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit shall be still more so\xe2\x80\x94but not now\xe2\x80\x94for the sake of thy\r\nbeloved Rachel, father, grant my request\xe2\x80\x94not now!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but,\xe2\x80\x9d said Isaac, insisting, \xe2\x80\x9cthey will deem us more thankless\r\nthan mere dogs!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut thou seest, my dear father, that King Richard is in presence, and\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x94-\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue, my best\xe2\x80\x94my wisest Rebecca!\xe2\x80\x94Let us hence\xe2\x80\x94let us hence!\xe2\x80\x94Money he\r\nwill lack, for he has just returned from Palestine, and, as they say,\r\nfrom prison\xe2\x80\x94and pretext for exacting it, should he need any, may arise\r\nout of my simple traffic with his brother John. Away, away, let us\r\nhence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd hurrying his daughter in his turn, he conducted her from the lists,\r\nand by means of conveyance which he had provided, transported her\r\nsafely to the house of the Rabbi Nathan.\r\n\r\nThe Jewess, whose fortunes had formed the principal interest of the\r\nday, having now retired unobserved, the attention of the populace was\r\ntransferred to the Black Knight. They now filled the air with \xe2\x80\x9cLong\r\nlife to Richard with the Lion\xe2\x80\x99s Heart, and down with the usurping\r\nTemplars!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNotwithstanding all this lip-loyalty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe to the Earl of\r\nEssex, \xe2\x80\x9cit was well the King took the precaution to bring thee with\r\nhim, noble Earl, and so many of thy trusty followers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Earl smiled and shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGallant Ivanhoe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Essex, \xe2\x80\x9cdost thou know our Master so well, and\r\nyet suspect him of taking so wise a precaution! I was drawing towards\r\nYork having heard that Prince John was making head there, when I met\r\nKing Richard, like a true knight-errant, galloping hither to achieve in\r\nhis own person this adventure of the Templar and the Jewess, with his\r\nown single arm. I accompanied him with my band, almost maugre his\r\nconsent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what news from York, brave Earl?\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cwill the rebels\r\nbide us there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more than December\xe2\x80\x99s snow will bide July\xe2\x80\x99s sun,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Earl;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthey are dispersing; and who should come posting to bring us the news,\r\nbut John himself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe traitor! the ungrateful insolent traitor!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cdid not\r\nRichard order him into confinement?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO! he received him,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Earl, \xe2\x80\x9cas if they had met after a\r\nhunting party; and, pointing to me and our men-at-arms, said, \xe2\x80\x98Thou\r\nseest, brother, I have some angry men with me\xe2\x80\x94thou wert best go to our\r\nmother, carry her my duteous affection, and abide with her until men\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nminds are pacified.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this was all he said?\xe2\x80\x9d enquired Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cwould not any one say\r\nthat this Prince invites men to treason by his clemency?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Earl, \xe2\x80\x9cas the man may be said to invite death, who\r\nundertakes to fight a combat, having a dangerous wound unhealed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI forgive thee the jest, Lord Earl,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ivanhoe; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, remember, I\r\nhazarded but my own life\xe2\x80\x94Richard, the welfare of his kingdom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThose,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Essex, \xe2\x80\x9cwho are specially careless of their own\r\nwelfare, are seldom remarkably attentive to that of others\xe2\x80\x94But let us\r\nhaste to the castle, for Richard meditates punishing some of the\r\nsubordinate members of the conspiracy, though he has pardoned their\r\nprincipal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom the judicial investigations which followed on this occasion, and\r\nwhich are given at length in the Wardour Manuscript, it appears that\r\nMaurice de Bracy escaped beyond seas, and went into the service of\r\nPhilip of France; while Philip de Malvoisin, and his brother Albert,\r\nthe Preceptor of Templestowe, were executed, although Waldemar\r\nFitzurse, the soul of the conspiracy, escaped with banishment; and\r\nPrince John, for whose behoof it was undertaken, was not even censured\r\nby his good-natured brother. No one, however, pitied the fate of the\r\ntwo Malvoisins, who only suffered the death which they had both well\r\ndeserved, by many acts of falsehood, cruelty, and oppression.\r\n\r\nBriefly after the judicial combat, Cedric the Saxon was summoned to the\r\ncourt of Richard, which, for the purpose of quieting the counties that\r\nhad been disturbed by the ambition of his brother, was then held at\r\nYork. Cedric tushed and pshawed more than once at the message\xe2\x80\x94but he\r\nrefused not obedience. In fact, the return of Richard had quenched\r\nevery hope that he had entertained of restoring a Saxon dynasty in\r\nEngland; for, whatever head the Saxons might have made in the event of\r\na civil war, it was plain that nothing could be done under the\r\nundisputed dominion of Richard, popular as he was by his personal good\r\nqualities and military fame, although his administration was wilfully\r\ncareless, now too indulgent, and now allied to despotism.\r\n\r\nBut, moreover, it could not escape even Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s reluctant observation,\r\nthat his project for an absolute union among the Saxons, by the\r\nmarriage of Rowena and Athelstane, was now completely at an end, by the\r\nmutual dissent of both parties concerned. This was, indeed, an event\r\nwhich, in his ardour for the Saxon cause, he could not have\r\nanticipated, and even when the disinclination of both was broadly and\r\nplainly manifested, he could scarce bring himself to believe that two\r\nSaxons of royal descent should scruple, on personal grounds, at an\r\nalliance so necessary for the public weal of the nation. But it was not\r\nthe less certain: Rowena had always expressed her repugnance to\r\nAthelstane, and now Athelstane was no less plain and positive in\r\nproclaiming his resolution never to pursue his addresses to the Lady\r\nRowena. Even the natural obstinacy of Cedric sunk beneath these\r\nobstacles, where he, remaining on the point of junction, had the task\r\nof dragging a reluctant pair up to it, one with each hand. He made,\r\nhowever, a last vigorous attack on Athelstane, and he found that\r\nresuscitated sprout of Saxon royalty engaged, like country squires of\r\nour own day, in a furious war with the clergy.\r\n\r\nIt seems that, after all his deadly menaces against the Abbot of Saint\r\nEdmund\xe2\x80\x99s, Athelstane\xe2\x80\x99s spirit of revenge, what between the natural\r\nindolent kindness of his own disposition, what through the prayers of\r\nhis mother Edith, attached, like most ladies, (of the period,) to the\r\nclerical order, had terminated in his keeping the Abbot and his monks\r\nin the dungeons of Coningsburgh for three days on a meagre diet. For\r\nthis atrocity the Abbot menaced him with excommunication, and made out\r\na dreadful list of complaints in the bowels and stomach, suffered by\r\nhimself and his monks, in consequence of the tyrannical and unjust\r\nimprisonment they had sustained. With this controversy, and with the\r\nmeans he had adopted to counteract this clerical persecution, Cedric\r\nfound the mind of his friend Athelstane so fully occupied, that it had\r\nno room for another idea. And when Rowena\xe2\x80\x99s name was mentioned the\r\nnoble Athelstane prayed leave to quaff a full goblet to her health, and\r\nthat she might soon be the bride of his kinsman Wilfred. It was a\r\ndesperate case therefore. There was obviously no more to be made of\r\nAthelstane; or, as Wamba expressed it, in a phrase which has descended\r\nfrom Saxon times to ours, he was a cock that would not fight.\r\n\r\nThere remained betwixt Cedric and the determination which the lovers\r\ndesired to come to, only two obstacles\xe2\x80\x94his own obstinacy, and his\r\ndislike of the Norman dynasty. The former feeling gradually gave way\r\nbefore the endearments of his ward, and the pride which he could not\r\nhelp nourishing in the fame of his son. Besides, he was not insensible\r\nto the honour of allying his own line to that of Alfred, when the\r\nsuperior claims of the descendant of Edward the Confessor were\r\nabandoned for ever. Cedric\xe2\x80\x99s aversion to the Norman race of kings was\r\nalso much undermined,\xe2\x80\x94first, by consideration of the impossibility of\r\nridding England of the new dynasty, a feeling which goes far to create\r\nloyalty in the subject to the king \xe2\x80\x9cde facto\xe2\x80\x9d; and, secondly, by the\r\npersonal attention of King Richard, who delighted in the blunt humour\r\nof Cedric, and, to use the language of the Wardour Manuscript, so dealt\r\nwith the noble Saxon, that, ere he had been a guest at court for seven\r\ndays, he had given his consent to the marriage of his ward Rowena and\r\nhis son Wilfred of Ivanhoe.\r\n\r\nThe nuptials of our hero, thus formally approved by his father, were\r\ncelebrated in the most august of temples, the noble Minster of York.\r\nThe King himself attended, and from the countenance which he afforded\r\non this and other occasions to the distressed and hitherto degraded\r\nSaxons, gave them a safer and more certain prospect of attaining their\r\njust rights, than they could reasonably hope from the precarious chance\r\nof a civil war. The Church gave her full solemnities, graced with all\r\nthe splendour which she of Rome knows how to apply with such brilliant\r\neffect.\r\n\r\nGurth, gallantly apparelled, attended as esquire upon his young master\r\nwhom he had served so faithfully, and the magnanimous Wamba, decorated\r\nwith a new cap and a most gorgeous set of silver bells. Sharers of\r\nWilfred\xe2\x80\x99s dangers and adversity, they remained, as they had a right to\r\nexpect, the partakers of his more prosperous career.\r\n\r\nBut besides this domestic retinue, these distinguished nuptials were\r\ncelebrated by the attendance of the high-born Normans, as well as\r\nSaxons, joined with the universal jubilee of the lower orders, that\r\nmarked the marriage of two individuals as a pledge of the future peace\r\nand harmony betwixt two races, which, since that period, have been so\r\ncompletely mingled, that the distinction has become wholly invisible.\r\nCedric lived to see this union approximate towards its completion; for\r\nas the two nations mixed in society and formed intermarriages with each\r\nother, the Normans abated their scorn, and the Saxons were refined from\r\ntheir rusticity. But it was not until the reign of Edward the Third\r\nthat the mixed language, now termed English, was spoken at the court of\r\nLondon, and that the hostile distinction of Norman and Saxon seems\r\nentirely to have disappeared.\r\n\r\nIt was upon the second morning after this happy bridal, that the Lady\r\nRowena was made acquainted by her handmaid Elgitha, that a damsel\r\ndesired admission to her presence, and solicited that their parley\r\nmight be without witness. Rowena wondered, hesitated, became curious,\r\nand ended by commanding the damsel to be admitted, and her attendants\r\nto withdraw.\r\n\r\nShe entered\xe2\x80\x94a noble and commanding figure, the long white veil, in\r\nwhich she was shrouded, overshadowing rather than concealing the\r\nelegance and majesty of her shape. Her demeanour was that of respect,\r\nunmingled by the least shade either of fear, or of a wish to propitiate\r\nfavour. Rowena was ever ready to acknowledge the claims, and attend to\r\nthe feelings, of others. She arose, and would have conducted her lovely\r\nvisitor to a seat; but the stranger looked at Elgitha, and again\r\nintimated a wish to discourse with the Lady Rowena alone. Elgitha had\r\nno sooner retired with unwilling steps, than, to the surprise of the\r\nLady of Ivanhoe, her fair visitant kneeled on one knee, pressed her\r\nhands to her forehead, and bending her head to the ground, in spite of\r\nRowena\xe2\x80\x99s resistance, kissed the embroidered hem of her tunic.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat means this, lady?\xe2\x80\x9d said the surprised bride; \xe2\x80\x9cor why do you offer\r\nto me a deference so unusual?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause to you, Lady of Ivanhoe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, rising up and resuming\r\nthe usual quiet dignity of her manner, \xe2\x80\x9cI may lawfully, and without\r\nrebuke, pay the debt of gratitude which I owe to Wilfred of Ivanhoe. I\r\nam\xe2\x80\x94forgive the boldness which has offered to you the homage of my\r\ncountry\xe2\x80\x94I am the unhappy Jewess, for whom your husband hazarded his\r\nlife against such fearful odds in the tiltyard of Templestowe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDamsel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, \xe2\x80\x9cWilfred of Ivanhoe on that day rendered back\r\nbut in slight measure your unceasing charity towards him in his wounds\r\nand misfortunes. Speak, is there aught remains in which he or I can\r\nserve thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, calmly, \xe2\x80\x9cunless you will transmit to him my\r\ngrateful farewell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou leave England then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, scarce recovering the surprise\r\nof this extraordinary visit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI leave it, lady, ere this moon again changes. My father had a brother\r\nhigh in favour with Mohammed Boabdil, King of Grenada\xe2\x80\x94thither we go,\r\nsecure of peace and protection, for the payment of such ransom as the\r\nMoslem exact from our people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd are you not then as well protected in England?\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena. \xe2\x80\x9cMy\r\nhusband has favour with the King\xe2\x80\x94the King himself is just and\r\ngenerous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLady,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cI doubt it not\xe2\x80\x94but the people of England are a\r\nfierce race, quarrelling ever with their neighbours or among\r\nthemselves, and ready to plunge the sword into the bowels of each\r\nother. Such is no safe abode for the children of my people. Ephraim is\r\nan heartless dove\xe2\x80\x94Issachar an over-laboured drudge, which stoops\r\nbetween two burdens. Not in a land of war and blood, surrounded by\r\nhostile neighbours, and distracted by internal factions, can Israel\r\nhope to rest during her wanderings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you, maiden,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou surely can have nothing to fear.\r\nShe who nursed the sick-bed of Ivanhoe,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, rising with\r\nenthusiasm\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cshe can have nothing to fear in England, where Saxon and\r\nNorman will contend who shall most do her honour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThy speech is fair, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rebecca, \xe2\x80\x9cand thy purpose fairer; but\r\nit may not be\xe2\x80\x94there is a gulf betwixt us. Our breeding, our faith,\r\nalike forbid either to pass over it. Farewell\xe2\x80\x94yet, ere I go indulge me\r\none request. The bridal-veil hangs over thy face; deign to raise it,\r\nand let me see the features of which fame speaks so highly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are scarce worthy of being looked upon,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena; \xe2\x80\x9cbut,\r\nexpecting the same from my visitant, I remove the veil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe took it off accordingly; and, partly from the consciousness of\r\nbeauty, partly from bashfulness, she blushed so intensely, that cheek,\r\nbrow, neck, and bosom, were suffused with crimson. Rebecca blushed\r\nalso, but it was a momentary feeling; and, mastered by higher emotions,\r\npast slowly from her features like the crimson cloud, which changes\r\ncolour when the sun sinks beneath the horizon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLady,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe countenance you have deigned to show me will\r\nlong dwell in my remembrance. There reigns in it gentleness and\r\ngoodness; and if a tinge of the world\xe2\x80\x99s pride or vanities may mix with\r\nan expression so lovely, how should we chide that which is of earth for\r\nbearing some colour of its original? Long, long will I remember your\r\nfeatures, and bless God that I leave my noble deliverer united with\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe stopped short\xe2\x80\x94her eyes filled with tears. She hastily wiped them,\r\nand answered to the anxious enquiries of Rowena\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI am well, lady\xe2\x80\x94well.\r\nBut my heart swells when I think of Torquilstone and the lists of\r\nTemplestowe.\xe2\x80\x94Farewell. One, the most trifling part of my duty, remains\r\nundischarged. Accept this casket\xe2\x80\x94startle not at its contents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRowena opened the small silver-chased casket, and perceived a carcanet,\r\nor neck lace, with ear-jewels, of diamonds, which were obviously of\r\nimmense value.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, tendering back the casket. \xe2\x80\x9cI dare not\r\naccept a gift of such consequence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet keep it, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Rebecca.\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYou have power, rank, command,\r\ninfluence; we have wealth, the source both of our strength and\r\nweakness; the value of these toys, ten times multiplied, would not\r\ninfluence half so much as your slightest wish. To you, therefore, the\r\ngift is of little value,\xe2\x80\x94and to me, what I part with is of much less.\r\nLet me not think you deem so wretchedly ill of my nation as your\r\ncommons believe. Think ye that I prize these sparkling fragments of\r\nstone above my liberty? or that my father values them in comparison to\r\nthe honour of his only child? Accept them, lady\xe2\x80\x94to me they are\r\nvalueless. I will never wear jewels more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are then unhappy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Rowena, struck with the manner in which\r\nRebecca uttered the last words. \xe2\x80\x9cO, remain with us\xe2\x80\x94the counsel of holy\r\nmen will wean you from your erring law, and I will be a sister to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Rebecca, the same calm melancholy reigning in her\r\nsoft voice and beautiful features\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x94may not be. I may not change\r\nthe faith of my fathers like a garment unsuited to the climate in which\r\nI seek to dwell, and unhappy, lady, I will not be. He, to whom I\r\ndedicate my future life, will be my comforter, if I do His will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you then convents, to one of which you mean to retire?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nRowena.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jewess; \xe2\x80\x9cbut among our people, since the time of\r\nAbraham downwards, have been women who have devoted their thoughts to\r\nHeaven, and their actions to works of kindness to men, tending the\r\nsick, feeding the hungry, and relieving the distressed. Among these\r\nwill Rebecca be numbered. Say this to thy lord, should he chance to\r\nenquire after the fate of her whose life he saved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was an involuntary tremour on Rebecca\xe2\x80\x99s voice, and a tenderness\r\nof accent, which perhaps betrayed more than she would willingly have\r\nexpressed. She hastened to bid Rowena adieu.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cMay He, who made both Jew and Christian, shower\r\ndown on you his choicest blessings! The bark that waits us hence will\r\nbe under weigh ere we can reach the port.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe glided from the apartment, leaving Rowena surprised as if a vision\r\nhad passed before her. The fair Saxon related the singular conference\r\nto her husband, on whose mind it made a deep impression. He lived long\r\nand happily with Rowena, for they were attached to each other by the\r\nbonds of early affection, and they loved each other the more, from the\r\nrecollection of the obstacles which had impeded their union. Yet it\r\nwould be enquiring too curiously to ask, whether the recollection of\r\nRebecca\xe2\x80\x99s beauty and magnanimity did not recur to his mind more\r\nfrequently than the fair descendant of Alfred might altogether have\r\napproved.\r\n\r\nIvanhoe distinguished himself in the service of Richard, and was graced\r\nwith farther marks of the royal favour. He might have risen still\r\nhigher, but for the premature death of the heroic C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion, before\r\nthe Castle of Chaluz, near Limoges. With the life of a generous, but\r\nrash and romantic monarch, perished all the projects which his ambition\r\nand his generosity had formed; to whom may be applied, with a slight\r\nalteration, the lines composed by Johnson for Charles of Sweden\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nHis fate was destined to a foreign strand,\r\nA petty fortress and an \xe2\x80\x9chumble\xe2\x80\x9d hand;\r\nHe left the name at which the world grew pale,\r\nTo point a moral, or adorn a TALE.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER I.\r\n\r\n\r\nNote A.\xe2\x80\x94The Ranger or the Forest, that cuts the foreclaws off our dogs.\r\n\r\nA most sensible grievance of those aggrieved times were the Forest\r\nLaws. These oppressive enactments were the produce of the Norman\r\nConquest, for the Saxon laws of the chase were mild and humane; while\r\nthose of William, enthusiastically attached to the exercise and its\r\nrights, were to the last degree tyrannical. The formation of the New\r\nForest, bears evidence to his passion for hunting, where he reduced\r\nmany a happy village to the condition of that one commemorated by my\r\nfriend, Mr William Stewart Rose:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmongst the ruins of the church\r\nThe midnight raven found a perch,\r\nA melancholy place;\r\nThe ruthless Conqueror cast down,\r\nWoe worth the deed, that little town,\r\nTo lengthen out his chase.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe disabling dogs, which might be necessary for keeping flocks and\r\nherds, from running at the deer, was called \xe2\x80\x9clawing\xe2\x80\x9d, and was in\r\ngeneral use. The Charter of the Forest designed to lessen those evils,\r\ndeclares that inquisition, or view, for lawing dogs, shall be made\r\nevery third year, and shall be then done by the view and testimony of\r\nlawful men, not otherwise; and they whose dogs shall be then found\r\nunlawed, shall give three shillings for mercy, and for the future no\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s ox shall be taken for lawing. Such lawing also shall be done by\r\nthe assize commonly used, and which is, that three claws shall be cut\r\noff without the ball of the right foot. See on this subject the\r\nHistorical Essay on the Magna Charta of King John, (a most beautiful\r\nvolume), by Richard Thomson.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER II.\r\n\r\n\r\nNote B.\xe2\x80\x94Negro Slaves.\r\n\r\nThe severe accuracy of some critics has objected to the complexion of\r\nthe slaves of Brian de Bois-Guilbert, as being totally out of costume\r\nand propriety. I remember the same objection being made to a set of\r\nsable functionaries, whom my friend, Mat Lewis, introduced as the\r\nguards and mischief-doing satellites of the wicked Baron, in his Castle\r\nSpectre. Mat treated the objection with great contempt, and averred in\r\nreply, that he made the slaves black in order to obtain a striking\r\neffect of contrast, and that, could he have derived a similar advantage\r\nfrom making his heroine blue, blue she should have been.\r\n\r\nI do not pretend to plead the immunities of my order so highly as this;\r\nbut neither will I allow that the author of a modern antique romance is\r\nobliged to confine himself to the introduction of those manners only\r\nwhich can be proved to have absolutely existed in the times he is\r\ndepicting, so that he restrain himself to such as are plausible and\r\nnatural, and contain no obvious anachronism. In this point of view,\r\nwhat can be more natural, than that the Templars, who, we know, copied\r\nclosely the luxuries of the Asiatic warriors with whom they fought,\r\nshould use the service of the enslaved Africans, whom the fate of war\r\ntransferred to new masters? I am sure, if there are no precise proofs\r\nof their having done so, there is nothing, on the other hand, that can\r\nentitle us positively to conclude that they never did. Besides, there\r\nis an instance in romance.\r\n\r\nJohn of Rampayne, an excellent juggler and minstrel, undertook to\r\neffect the escape of one Audulf de Bracy, by presenting himself in\r\ndisguise at the court of the king, where he was confined. For this\r\npurpose, \xe2\x80\x9che stained his hair and his whole body entirely as black as\r\njet, so that nothing was white but his teeth,\xe2\x80\x9d and succeeded in\r\nimposing himself on the king, as an Ethiopian minstrel. He effected, by\r\nstratagem, the escape of the prisoner. Negroes, therefore, must have\r\nbeen known in England in the dark ages. 60\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER XVII.\r\n\r\n\r\nNote C.\xe2\x80\x94Minstrelsy.\r\n\r\nThe realm of France, it is well known, was divided betwixt the Norman\r\nand Teutonic race, who spoke the language in which the word Yes is\r\npronounced as \xe2\x80\x9coui\xe2\x80\x9d, and the inhabitants of the southern regions, whose\r\nspeech bearing some affinity to the Italian, pronounced the same word\r\n\xe2\x80\x9coc\xe2\x80\x9d. The poets of the former race were called \xe2\x80\x9cMinstrels\xe2\x80\x9d, and their\r\npoems \xe2\x80\x9cLays\xe2\x80\x9d: those of the latter were termed \xe2\x80\x9cTroubadours\xe2\x80\x9d, and their\r\ncompositions called \xe2\x80\x9csirventes\xe2\x80\x9d, and other names. Richard, a professed\r\nadmirer of the joyous science in all its branches, could imitate either\r\nthe minstrel or troubadour. It is less likely that he should have been\r\nable to compose or sing an English ballad; yet so much do we wish to\r\nassimilate Him of the Lion Heart to the band of warriors whom he led,\r\nthat the anachronism, if there be one may readily be forgiven.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER XXI.\r\n\r\n\r\nNote D.\xe2\x80\x94Battle of Stamford.\r\n\r\nA great topographical blunder occurred here in former editions. The\r\nbloody battle alluded to in the text, fought and won by King Harold,\r\nover his brother the rebellious Tosti, and an auxiliary force of Danes\r\nor Norsemen, was said, in the text, and a corresponding note, to have\r\ntaken place at Stamford, in Leicestershire, and upon the river Welland.\r\nThis is a mistake, into which the author has been led by trusting to\r\nhis memory, and so confounding two places of the same name. The\r\nStamford, Strangford, or Staneford, at which the battle really was\r\nfought, is a ford upon the river Derwent, at the distance of about\r\nseven miles from York, and situated in that large and opulent county. A\r\nlong wooden bridge over the Derwent, the site of which, with one\r\nremaining buttress, is still shown to the curious traveller, was\r\nfuriously contested. One Norwegian long defended it by his single arm,\r\nand was at length pierced with a spear thrust through the planks of the\r\nbridge from a boat beneath.\r\n\r\nThe neighbourhood of Stamford, on the Derwent, contains some memorials\r\nof the battle. Horseshoes, swords, and the heads of halberds, or bills,\r\nare often found there; one place is called the \xe2\x80\x9cDanes\xe2\x80\x99 well,\xe2\x80\x9d another\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cBattle flats.\xe2\x80\x9d From a tradition that the weapon with which the\r\nNorwegian champion was slain, resembled a pear, or, as others say, that\r\nthe trough or boat in which the soldier floated under the bridge to\r\nstrike the blow, had such a shape, the country people usually begin a\r\ngreat market, which is held at Stamford, with an entertainment called\r\nthe Pear-pie feast, which after all may be a corruption of the\r\nSpear-pie feast. For more particulars, Drake\xe2\x80\x99s History of York may be\r\nreferred to. The author\xe2\x80\x99s mistake was pointed out to him, in the most\r\nobliging manner, by Robert Belt, Esq. of Bossal House. The battle was\r\nfought in 1066.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER XXII.\r\n\r\n\r\nNote E.\xe2\x80\x94The range of iron bars above that glowing charcoal.\r\n\r\nThis horrid species of torture may remind the reader of that to which\r\nthe Spaniards subjected Guatimozin, in order to extort a discovery of\r\nhis concealed wealth. But, in fact, an instance of similar barbarity is\r\nto be found nearer home, and occurs in the annals of Queen Mary\xe2\x80\x99s time,\r\ncontaining so many other examples of atrocity. Every reader must\r\nrecollect, that after the fall of the Catholic Church, and the\r\nPresbyterian Church Government had been established by law, the rank,\r\nand especially the wealth, of the Bishops, Abbots, Priors, and so\r\nforth, were no longer vested in ecclesiastics, but in lay impropriators\r\nof the church revenues, or, as the Scottish lawyers called them,\r\ntitulars of the temporalities of the benefice, though having no claim\r\nto the spiritual character of their predecessors in office.\r\n\r\nOf these laymen, who were thus invested with ecclesiastical revenues,\r\nsome were men of high birth and rank, like the famous Lord James\r\nStewart, the Prior of St Andrews, who did not fail to keep for their\r\nown use the rents, lands, and revenues of the church. But if, on the\r\nother hand, the titulars were men of inferior importance, who had been\r\ninducted into the office by the interest of some powerful person, it\r\nwas generally understood that the new Abbot should grant for his\r\npatron\xe2\x80\x99s benefit such leases and conveyances of the church lands and\r\ntithes as might afford their protector the lion\xe2\x80\x99s share of the booty.\r\nThis was the origin of those who were wittily termed Tulchan 61\r\n\r\nBishops, being a sort of imaginary prelate, whose image was set up to\r\nenable his patron and principal to plunder the benefice under his name.\r\n\r\nThere were other cases, however, in which men who had got grants of\r\nthese secularised benefices, were desirous of retaining them for their\r\nown use, without having the influence sufficient to establish their\r\npurpose; and these became frequently unable to protect themselves,\r\nhowever unwilling to submit to the exactions of the feudal tyrant of\r\nthe district.\r\n\r\nBannatyne, secretary to John Knox, recounts a singular course of\r\noppression practised on one of those titulars abbots, by the Earl of\r\nCassilis in Ayrshire, whose extent of feudal influence was so wide that\r\nhe was usually termed the King of Carrick. We give the fact as it\r\noccurs in Bannatyne\xe2\x80\x99s Journal, only premising that the Journalist held\r\nhis master\xe2\x80\x99s opinions, both with respect to the Earl of Cassilis as an\r\nopposer of the king\xe2\x80\x99s party, and as being a detester of the practice of\r\ngranting church revenues to titulars, instead of their being devoted to\r\npious uses, such as the support of the clergy, expense of schools, and\r\nthe relief of the national poor. He mingles in the narrative,\r\ntherefore, a well deserved feeling of execration against the tyrant who\r\nemployed the torture, which a tone of ridicule towards the patient, as\r\nif, after all, it had not been ill bestowed on such an equivocal and\r\namphibious character as a titular abbot. He entitles his narrative,\r\n\r\nTHE EARL OF CASSILIS\xe2\x80\x99 TYRANNY AGAINST A QUICK (i.e. LIVING) MAN.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaster Allan Stewart, friend to Captain James Stewart of Cardonall, by\r\nmeans of the Queen\xe2\x80\x99s corrupted court, obtained the Abbey of\r\nCrossraguel. The said Earl thinking himself greater than any king in\r\nthose quarters, determined to have that whole benefice (as he hath\r\ndivers others) to pay at his pleasure; and because he could not find\r\nsic security as his insatiable appetite required, this shift was\r\ndevised. The said Mr Allan being in company with the Laird of Bargany,\r\n(also a Kennedy,) was, by the Earl and his friends, enticed to leave\r\nthe safeguard which he had with the Laird, and come to make good cheer\r\nwith the said Earl. The simplicity of the imprudent man was suddenly\r\nabused; and so he passed his time with them certain days, which he did\r\nin Maybole with Thomas Kennedie, uncle to the said Earl; after which\r\nthe said Mr Allan passed, with quiet company, to visit the place and\r\nbounds of Crossraguel, [his abbacy,] of which the said Earl being\r\nsurely advertised, determined to put in practice the tyranny which long\r\nbefore he had conceived. And so, as king of the country, apprehended\r\nthe said Mr Allan, and carried him to the house of Denure, where for a\r\nseason he was honourably treated, (if a prisoner can think any\r\nentertainment pleasing;) but after that certain days were spent, and\r\nthat the Earl could not obtain the feus of Crossraguel according to his\r\nown appetite, he determined to prove if a collation could work that\r\nwhich neither dinner nor supper could do for a long time. And so the\r\nsaid Mr Allan was carried to a secret chamber: with him passed the\r\nhonourable Earl, his worshipful brother, and such as were appointed to\r\nbe servants at that banquet. In the chamber there was a grit iron\r\nchimlay, under it a fire; other grit provision was not seen. The first\r\ncourse was,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98My Lord Abbot,\xe2\x80\x99 (said the Earl,) \xe2\x80\x98it will please you\r\nconfess here, that with your own consent you remain in my company,\r\nbecause ye durst not commit yourself to the hands of others.\xe2\x80\x99 The Abbot\r\nanswered, \xe2\x80\x98Would you, my lord, that I should make a manifest lie for\r\nyour pleasure? The truth is, my lord, it is against my will that I am\r\nhere; neither yet have I any pleasure in your company.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98But ye shall\r\nremain with me, nevertheless, at this time,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Earl. \xe2\x80\x98I am not\r\nable to resist your will and pleasure,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Abbot, \xe2\x80\x98in this\r\nplace.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Ye must then obey me,\xe2\x80\x99 said the Earl,\xe2\x80\x94and with that were\r\npresented unto him certain letters to subscribe, amongst which there\r\nwas a five years\xe2\x80\x99 tack, and a nineteen years\xe2\x80\x99 tack, and a charter of\r\nfeu of all the lands (of Crossraguel), with all the clauses necessary\r\nfor the Earl to haste him to hell. For if adultery, sacrilege,\r\noppression, barbarous cruelty, and theft heaped upon theft, deserve\r\nhell, the great King of Carrick can no more escape hell for ever, than\r\nthe imprudent Abbot escaped the fire for a season as follows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter that the Earl spied repugnance, and saw that he could not come\r\nto his purpose by fair means, he commanded his cooks to prepare the\r\nbanquet: and so first they flayed the sheep, that is, they took off the\r\nAbbot\xe2\x80\x99s cloathes even to his skin, and next they bound him to the\r\nchimney\xe2\x80\x94his legs to the one end, and his arms to the other; and so they\r\nbegan to beet [i.e. feed] the fire sometimes to his buttocks, sometimes\r\nto his legs, sometimes to his shoulders and arms; and that the roast\r\nmight not burn, but that it might rest in soppe, they spared not\r\nflambing with oil, (basting as a cook bastes roasted meat); Lord, look\r\nthou to sic cruelty! And that the crying of the miserable man should\r\nnot be heard, they dosed his mouth that the voice might be stopped. It\r\nmay be suspected that some partisan of the King\xe2\x80\x99s [Darnley\xe2\x80\x99s] murder\r\nwas there. In that torment they held the poor man, till that often he\r\ncried for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake to dispatch him; for he had as meikle gold in his\r\nawin purse as would buy powder enough to shorten his pain. The famous\r\nKing of Carrick and his cooks perceiving the roast to be aneuch,\r\ncommanded it to be tane fra the fire, and the Earl himself began the\r\ngrace in this manner:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Benedicite, Jesus Maria, you are the most\r\nobstinate man that ever I saw; gif I had known that ye had been so\r\nstubborn, I would not for a thousand crowns have handled you so; I\r\nnever did so to man before you.\xe2\x80\x99 And yet he returned to the same\r\npractice within two days, and ceased not till that he obtained his\r\nformost purpose, that is, that he had got all his pieces subscryvit\r\nalsweill as ane half-roasted hand could do it. The Earl thinking\r\nhimself sure enough so long as he had the half-roasted Abbot in his own\r\nkeeping, and yet being ashamed of his presence by reason of his former\r\ncruelty, left the place of Denure in the hands of certain of his\r\nservants, and the half-roasted Abbot to be kept there as prisoner. The\r\nLaird of Bargany, out of whose company the said Abbot had been enticed,\r\nunderstanding, (not the extremity,) but the retaining of the man, sent\r\nto the court, and raised letters of deliverance of the person of the\r\nman according to the order, which being disobeyed, the said Earl for\r\nhis contempt was denounced rebel, and put to the horne. But yet hope\r\nwas there none, neither to the afflicted to be delivered, neither yet\r\nto the purchaser [i.e. procurer] of the letters to obtain any comfort\r\nthereby; for in that time God was despised, and the lawful authority\r\nwas contemned in Scotland, in hope of the sudden return and regiment of\r\nthat cruel murderer of her awin husband, of whose lords the said Earl\r\nwas called one; and yet, oftener than once, he was solemnly sworn to\r\nthe King and to his Regent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Journalist then recites the complaint of the injured Allan Stewart,\r\nCommendator of Crossraguel, to the Regent and Privy Council, averring\r\nhis having been carried, partly by flattery, partly by force, to the\r\nblack vault of Denure, a strong fortalice, built on a rock overhanging\r\nthe Irish channel, where to execute leases and conveyances of the whole\r\nchurches and parsonages belonging to the Abbey of Crossraguel, which he\r\nutterly refused as an unreasonable demand, and the more so that he had\r\nalready conveyed them to John Stewart of Cardonah, by whose interest he\r\nhad been made Commendator. The complainant proceeds to state, that he\r\nwas, after many menaces, stript, bound, and his limbs exposed to fire\r\nin the manner already described, till, compelled by excess of agony, he\r\nsubscribed the charter and leases presented to him, of the contents of\r\nwhich he was totally ignorant. A few days afterwards, being again\r\nrequired to execute a ratification of these deeds before a notary and\r\nwitnesses, and refusing to do so, he was once more subjected to the\r\nsame torture, until his agony was so excessive that he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cFye\r\non you, why do you not strike your whingers into me, or blow me up with\r\na barrel of powder, rather than torture me thus unmercifully?\xe2\x80\x9d upon\r\nwhich the Earl commanded Alexander Richard, one of his attendants, to\r\nstop the patient\xe2\x80\x99s mouth with a napkin, which was done accordingly.\r\nThus he was once more compelled to submit to their tyranny. The\r\npetition concluded with stating, that the Earl, under pretence of the\r\ndeeds thus iniquitously obtained, had taken possession of the whole\r\nplace and living of Crossraguel, and enjoyed the profits thereof for\r\nthree years.\r\n\r\nThe doom of the Regent and Council shows singularly the total\r\ninterruption of justice at this calamitous period, even in the most\r\nclamant cases of oppression. The Council declined interference with the\r\ncourse of the ordinary justice of the county, (which was completely\r\nunder the said Earl of Cassilis\xe2\x80\x99 control,) and only enacted, that he\r\nshould forbear molestation of the unfortunate Comendator, under the\r\nsurety of two thousand pounds Scots. The Earl was appointed also to\r\nkeep the peace towards the celebrated George Buchanan, who had a\r\npension out of the same Abbacy, to a similar extent, and under the like\r\npenalty.\r\n\r\nThe consequences are thus described by the Journalist already quoted.\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe said Laird of Bargany perceiving that the ordiner justice could\r\nneither help the oppressed, nor yet the afflicted, applied his mind to\r\nthe next remedy, and in the end, by his servants, took the house of\r\nDenure, where the poor Abbot was kept prisoner. The bruit flew fra\r\nCarrick to Galloway, and so suddenly assembled herd and hyre-man that\r\npertained to the band of the Kennedies; and so within a few hours was\r\nthe house of Denure environed again. The master of Cassilis was the\r\nfrackast [i.e. the readiest or boldest] and would not stay, but in his\r\nheat would lay fire to the dungeon, with no small boasting that all\r\nenemies within the house should die.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was required and admonished by those that were within to be more\r\nmoderate, and not to hazard himself so foolishly. But no admonition\r\nwould help, till that the wind of an hacquebute blasted his shoulder,\r\nand then ceased he from further pursuit in fury. The Laird of Bargany\r\nhad before purchest [obtained] of the authorities, letters, charging\r\nall faithfull subjects to the King\xe2\x80\x99s Majesty, to assist him against\r\nthat cruel tyrant and mansworn traitor, the Earl of Cassilis; which\r\nletters, with his private writings, he published, and shortly found sic\r\nconcurrence of Kyle and Cunynghame with his other friends, that the\r\nCarrick company drew back fra the house: and so the other approached,\r\nfurnished the house with more men, delivered the said Mr Allan, and\r\ncarried him to Ayr, where, publicly at the market cross of the said\r\ntown, he declared how cruelly he was entreated, and how the murdered\r\nKing suffered not sic torment as he did, excepting only he escaped the\r\ndeath: and, therefore, publickly did revoke all things that were done\r\nin that extremity, and especially revoked the subscription of the three\r\nwritings, to wit, of a fyve yeir tack and nineteen year tack, and of a\r\ncharter of feu. And so the house remained, and remains (till this day,\r\nthe 7th of February, 1571,) in the custody of the said Laird of Bargany\r\nand of his servants. And so cruelty was disappointed of proffeit\r\npresent, and shall be eternallie punished, unless he earnestly repent.\r\nAnd this far for the cruelty committed, to give occasion unto others,\r\nand to such as hate the monstrous dealing of degenerate nobility, to\r\nlook more diligently upon their behaviuours, and to paint them forth\r\nunto the world, that they themselves may be ashamed of their own\r\nbeastliness, and that the world may be advertised and admonished to\r\nabhor, detest, and avoid the company of all sic tyrants, who are not\r\nworthy of the society of men, but ought to be sent suddenly to the\r\ndevil, with whom they must burn without end, for their contempt of God,\r\nand cruelty committed against his creatures. Let Cassilis and his\r\nbrother be the first to be the example unto others. Amen. Amen.\xe2\x80\x9d 62\r\n\r\nThis extract has been somewhat amended or modernized in orthography, to\r\nrender it more intelligible to the general reader. I have to add, that\r\nthe Kennedies of Bargany, who interfered in behalf of the oppressed\r\nAbbot, were themselves a younger branch of the Cassilis family, but\r\nheld different politics, and were powerful enough in this, and other\r\ninstances, to bid them defiance.\r\n\r\nThe ultimate issue of this affair does not appear; but as the house of\r\nCassilis are still in possession of the greater part of the feus and\r\nleases which belonged to Crossraguel Abbey, it is probable the talons\r\nof the King of Carrick were strong enough, in those disorderly times,\r\nto retain the prey which they had so mercilessly fixed upon.\r\n\r\nI may also add, that it appears by some papers in my possession, that\r\nthe officers or Country Keepers on the border, were accustomed to\r\ntorment their prisoners by binding them to the iron bars of their\r\nchimneys, to extort confession.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER XXIX\r\n\r\n\r\nNote F.\xe2\x80\x94Heraldry\r\n\r\nThe author has been here upbraided with false heraldry, as having\r\ncharged metal upon metal. It should be remembered, however, that\r\nheraldry had only its first rude origin during the crusades, and that\r\nall the minutiae of its fantastic science were the work of time, and\r\nintroduced at a much later period. Those who think otherwise must\r\nsuppose that the Goddess of \xe2\x80\x9cArmoirers\xe2\x80\x9d, like the Goddess of Arms,\r\nsprung into the world completely equipped in all the gaudy trappings of\r\nthe department she presides over.\r\n\r\nAdditional Note\r\n\r\nIn corroboration of said note, it may be observed, that the arms, which\r\nwere assumed by Godfrey of Boulogne himself, after the conquest of\r\nJerusalem, was a cross counter patent cantoned with four little crosses\r\nor, upon a field azure, displaying thus metal upon metal. The heralds\r\nhave tried to explain this undeniable fact in different modes\xe2\x80\x94but Ferne\r\ngallantly contends, that a prince of Godfrey\xe2\x80\x99s qualities should not be\r\nbound by the ordinary rules. The Scottish Nisbet, and the same Ferne,\r\ninsist that the chiefs of the Crusade must have assigned to Godfrey\r\nthis extraordinary and unwonted coat-of-arms, in order to induce those\r\nwho should behold them to make enquiries; and hence give them the name\r\nof \xe2\x80\x9carma inquirenda\xe2\x80\x9d. But with reverence to these grave authorities, it\r\nseems unlikely that the assembled princes of Europe should have\r\nadjudged to Godfrey a coat armorial so much contrary to the general\r\nrule, if such rule had then existed; at any rate, it proves that metal\r\nupon metal, now accounted a solecism in heraldry, was admitted in other\r\ncases similar to that in the text. See Ferne\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cBlazon of Gentrie\xe2\x80\x9d p.\r\n238. Edition 1586. Nisbet\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cHeraldry\xe2\x80\x9d, vol. i. p. 113. Second Edition.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER XXXI\r\n\r\n\r\nNote G.\xe2\x80\x94Ulrica\xe2\x80\x99s Death song.\r\n\r\nIt will readily occur to the antiquary, that these verses are intended\r\nto imitate the antique poetry of the Scalds\xe2\x80\x94the minstrels of the old\r\nScandinavians\xe2\x80\x94the race, as the Laureate so happily terms them,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStern to inflict, and stubborn to endure,\r\nWho smiled in death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe poetry of the Anglo-Saxons, after their civilisation and\r\nconversion, was of a different and softer character; but in the\r\ncircumstances of Ulrica, she may be not unnaturally supposed to return\r\nto the wild strains which animated her forefathers during the time of\r\nPaganism and untamed ferocity.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER XXXII\r\n\r\n\r\nNote H.\xe2\x80\x94Richard C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion.\r\n\r\nThe interchange of a cuff with the jolly priest is not entirely out of\r\ncharacter with Richard I., if romances read him aright. In the very\r\ncurious romance on the subject of his adventures in the Holy Land, and\r\nhis return from thence, it is recorded how he exchanged a pugilistic\r\nfavour of this nature, while a prisoner in Germany. His opponent was\r\nthe son of his principal warder, and was so imprudent as to give the\r\nchallenge to this barter of buffets. The King stood forth like a true\r\nman, and received a blow which staggered him. In requital, having\r\npreviously waxed his hand, a practice unknown, I believe, to the\r\ngentlemen of the modern fancy, he returned the box on the ear with such\r\ninterest as to kill his antagonist on the spot.\xe2\x80\x94See, in Ellis\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nSpecimens of English Romance, that of C\xc5\x93ur-de-Lion.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER XXXIII\r\n\r\n\r\nNote I.\xe2\x80\x94Hedge-Priests.\r\n\r\nIt is curious to observe, that in every state of society, some sort of\r\nghostly consolation is provided for the members of the community,\r\nthough assembled for purposes diametrically opposite to religion. A\r\ngang of beggars have their Patrico, and the banditti of the Apennines\r\nhave among them persons acting as monks and priests, by whom they are\r\nconfessed, and who perform mass before them. Unquestionably, such\r\nreverend persons, in such a society, must accommodate their manners and\r\ntheir morals to the community in which they live; and if they can\r\noccasionally obtain a degree of reverence for their supposed spiritual\r\ngifts, are, on most occasions, loaded with unmerciful ridicule, as\r\npossessing a character inconsistent with all around them.\r\n\r\nHence the fighting parson in the old play of Sir John Oldcastle, and\r\nthe famous friar of Robin Hood\xe2\x80\x99s band. Nor were such characters ideal.\r\nThere exists a monition of the Bishop of Durham against irregular\r\nchurchmen of this class, who associated themselves with Border robbers,\r\nand desecrated the holiest offices of the priestly function, by\r\ncelebrating them for the benefit of thieves, robbers, and murderers,\r\namongst ruins and in caverns of the earth, without regard to canonical\r\nform, and with torn and dirty attire, and maimed rites, altogether\r\nimproper for the occasion.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO CHAPTER XLI.\r\n\r\n\r\nNote J.\xe2\x80\x94Castle of Coningsburgh.\r\n\r\nWhen I last saw this interesting ruin of ancient days, one of the very\r\nfew remaining examples of Saxon fortification, I was strongly impressed\r\nwith the desire of tracing out a sort of theory on the subject, which,\r\nfrom some recent acquaintance with the architecture of the ancient\r\nScandinavians, seemed to me peculiarly interesting. I was, however,\r\nobliged by circumstances to proceed on my journey, without leisure to\r\ntake more than a transient view of Coningsburgh. Yet the idea dwells so\r\nstrongly in my mind, that I feel considerably tempted to write a page\r\nor two in detailing at least the outline of my hypothesis, leaving\r\nbetter antiquaries to correct or refute conclusions which are perhaps\r\ntoo hastily drawn.\r\n\r\nThose who have visited the Zetland Islands, are familiar with the\r\ndescription of castles called by the inhabitants Burghs; and by the\r\nHighlanders\xe2\x80\x94for they are also to be found both in the Western Isles and\r\non the mainland\xe2\x80\x94Duns. Pennant has engraved a view of the famous\r\nDun-Dornadilla in Glenelg; and there are many others, all of them built\r\nafter a peculiar mode of architecture, which argues a people in the\r\nmost primitive state of society. The most perfect specimen is that upon\r\nthe island of Mousa, near to the mainland of Zetland, which is probably\r\nin the same state as when inhabited.\r\n\r\nIt is a single round tower, the wall curving in slightly, and then\r\nturning outward again in the form of a dice-box, so that the defenders\r\non the top might the better protect the base. It is formed of rough\r\nstones, selected with care, and laid in courses or circles, with much\r\ncompactness, but without cement of any kind. The tower has never, to\r\nappearance, had roofing of any sort; a fire was made in the centre of\r\nthe space which it encloses, and originally the building was probably\r\nlittle more than a wall drawn as a sort of screen around the great\r\ncouncil fire of the tribe. But, although the means or ingenuity of the\r\nbuilders did not extend so far as to provide a roof, they supplied the\r\nwant by constructing apartments in the interior of the walls of the\r\ntower itself. The circumvallation formed a double enclosure, the inner\r\nside of which was, in fact, two feet or three feet distant from the\r\nother, and connected by a concentric range of long flat stones, thus\r\nforming a series of concentric rings or stories of various heights,\r\nrising to the top of the tower. Each of these stories or galleries has\r\nfour windows, facing directly to the points of the compass, and rising\r\nof course regularly above each other. These four perpendicular ranges\r\nof windows admitted air, and, the fire being kindled, heat, or smoke at\r\nleast, to each of the galleries. The access from gallery to gallery is\r\nequally primitive. A path, on the principle of an inclined plane, turns\r\nround and round the building like a screw, and gives access to the\r\ndifferent stories, intersecting each of them in its turn, and thus\r\ngradually rising to the top of the wall of the tower. On the outside\r\nthere are no windows; and I may add, that an enclosure of a square, or\r\nsometimes a round form, gave the inhabitants of the Burgh an\r\nopportunity to secure any sheep or cattle which they might possess.\r\n\r\nSuch is the general architecture of that very early period when the\r\nNorthmen swept the seas, and brought to their rude houses, such as I\r\nhave described them, the plunder of polished nations. In Zetland there\r\nare several scores of these Burghs, occupying in every case, capes,\r\nheadlands, islets, and similar places of advantage singularly well\r\nchosen. I remember the remains of one upon an island in a small lake\r\nnear Lerwick, which at high tide communicates with the sea, the access\r\nto which is very ingenious, by means of a causeway or dike, about three\r\nor four inches under the surface of the water. This causeway makes a\r\nsharp angle in its approach to the Burgh. The inhabitants, doubtless,\r\nwere well acquainted with this, but strangers, who might approach in a\r\nhostile manner, and were ignorant of the curve of the causeway, would\r\nprobably plunge into the lake, which is six or seven feet in depth at\r\nthe least.
