This must have been the device of some Vauban or Cohorn of\r\nthose early times.\r\n\r\nThe style of these buildings evinces that the architect possessed\r\nneither the art of using lime or cement of any kind, nor the skill to\r\nthrow an arch, construct a roof, or erect a stair; and yet, with all\r\nthis ignorance, showed great ingenuity in selecting the situation of\r\nBurghs, and regulating the access to them, as well as neatness and\r\nregularity in the erection, since the buildings themselves show a style\r\nof advance in the arts scarcely consistent with the ignorance of so\r\nmany of the principal branches of architectural knowledge.\r\n\r\nI have always thought, that one of the most curious and valuable\r\nobjects of antiquaries has been to trace the progress of society, by\r\nthe efforts made in early ages to improve the rudeness of their first\r\nexpedients, until they either approach excellence, or, as is more\r\nfrequently the case, are supplied by new and fundamental discoveries,\r\nwhich supersede both the earlier and ruder system, and the improvements\r\nwhich have been ingrafted upon it. For example, if we conceive the\r\nrecent discovery of gas to be so much improved and adapted to domestic\r\nuse, as to supersede all other modes of producing domestic light; we\r\ncan already suppose, some centuries afterwards, the heads of a whole\r\nSociety of Antiquaries half turned by the discovery of a pair of patent\r\nsnuffers, and by the learned theories which would be brought forward to\r\naccount for the form and purpose of so singular an implement.\r\n\r\nFollowing some such principle, I am inclined to regard the singular\r\nCastle of Coningsburgh\xe2\x80\x94I mean the Saxon part of it\xe2\x80\x94as a step in advance\r\nfrom the rude architecture, if it deserves the name, which must have\r\nbeen common to the Saxons as to other Northmen. The builders had\r\nattained the art of using cement, and of roofing a building,\xe2\x80\x94great\r\nimprovements on the original Burgh. But in the round keep, a shape only\r\nseen in the most ancient castles\xe2\x80\x94the chambers excavated in the\r\nthickness of the walls and buttresses\xe2\x80\x94the difficulty by which access is\r\ngained from one story to those above it, Coningsburgh still retains the\r\nsimplicity of its origin, and shows by what slow degrees man proceeded\r\nfrom occupying such rude and inconvenient lodgings, as were afforded by\r\nthe galleries of the Castle of Mousa, to the more splendid\r\naccommodations of the Norman castles, with all their stern and Gothic\r\ngraces.\r\n\r\nI am ignorant if these remarks are new, or if they will be confirmed by\r\ncloser examination; but I think, that, on a hasty observation,\r\nConingsburgh offers means of curious study to those who may wish to\r\ntrace the history of architecture back to the times preceding the\r\nNorman Conquest.\r\n\r\nIt would be highly desirable that a cork model should be taken of the\r\nCastle of Mousa, as it cannot be well understood by a plan.\r\n\r\nThe Castle of Coningsburgh is thus described:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe castle is large, the outer walls standing on a pleasant ascent\r\nfrom the river, but much overtopt by a high hill, on which the town\r\nstands, situated at the head of a rich and magnificent vale, formed by\r\nan amphitheatre of woody hills, in which flows the gentle Don. Near the\r\ncastle is a barrow, said to be Hengist\xe2\x80\x99s tomb. The entrance is flanked\r\nto the left by a round tower, with a sloping base, and there are\r\nseveral similar in the outer wall the entrance has piers of a gate, and\r\non the east side the ditch and bank are double and very steep. On the\r\ntop of the churchyard wall is a tombstone, on which are cut in high\r\nrelief, two ravens, or such-like birds. On the south side of the\r\nchurchyard lies an ancient stone, ridged like a coffin, on which is\r\ncarved a man on horseback; and another man with a shield encountering a\r\nvast winged serpent, and a man bearing a shield behind him. It was\r\nprobably one of the rude crosses not uncommon in churchyards in this\r\ncounty. See it engraved on the plate of crosses for this volume, plate\r\n14. fig. 1. The name of Coningsburgh, by which this castle goes in the\r\nold editions of the Britannia, would lead one to suppose it the\r\nresidence of the Saxon kings. It afterwards belonged to King Harold.\r\nThe Conqueror bestowed it on William de Warren, with all its privileges\r\nand jurisdiction, which are said to have extended over twenty-eight\r\ntowns. At the corner of the area, which is of an irregular form, stands\r\nthe great tower, or keep, placed on a small hill of its own dimensions,\r\non which lies six vast projecting buttresses, ascending in a steep\r\ndirection to prop and support the building, and continued upwards up\r\nthe side as turrets. The tower within forms a complete circle,\r\ntwenty-one feet in diameter, the walls fourteen feet thick. The ascent\r\ninto the tower is by an exceeding deep flight of steep steps, four feet\r\nand a half wide, on the south side leading to a low doorway, over which\r\nis a circular arch crossed by a great transom stone. Within this door\r\nis the staircase which ascends straight through the thickness of the\r\nwall, not communicating with the room on the first floor, in whose\r\ncentre is the opening to the dungeon. Neither of these lower rooms is\r\nlighted except from a hole in the floor of the third story; the room in\r\nwhich, as well as in that above it, is finished with compact smooth\r\nstonework, both having chimney-pieces, with an arch resting on triple\r\nclustered pillars. In the third story, or guard-chamber, is a small\r\nrecess with a loop-hole, probably a bedchamber, and in that floor above\r\na niche for a saint or holy-water pot. Mr. King imagines this a Saxon\r\ncastle of the first ages of the Heptarchy. Mr. Watson thus describes\r\nit. From the first floor to the second story, (third from the ground,)\r\nis a way by a stair in the wall five feet wide. The next staircase is\r\napproached by a ladder, and ends at the fourth story from the ground.\r\nTwo yards from the door, at the head of this stair, is an opening\r\nnearly east, accessible by treading on the ledge of the wall, which\r\ndiminishes eight inches each story; and this last opening leads into a\r\nroom or chapel ten feet by twelve, and fifteen or sixteen high, arched\r\nwith free-stone, and supported by small circular columns of the same,\r\nthe capitals and arches Saxon. It has an east window, and on each side\r\nin the wall, about four feet from the ground, a stone basin with a hole\r\nand iron pipe to convey the water into or through the wall. This chapel\r\nis one of the buttresses, but no sign of it without, for even the\r\nwindow, though large within, is only a long narrow loop-hole, scarcely\r\nto be seen without. On the left side of this chapel is a small oratory,\r\neight by six in the thickness of the wall, with a niche in the wall,\r\nand enlightened by a like loop-hole. The fourth stair from the ground,\r\nten feet west from the chapel door, leads to the top of the tower\r\nthrough the thickness of the wall, which at top is but three yards.\r\nEach story is about fifteen feet high, so that the tower will be\r\nseventy-five feet from the ground. The inside forms a circle, whose\r\ndiameter may be about twelve feet. The well at the bottom of the\r\ndungeon is piled with stones.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Gough\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cEdition Of Camden\xe2\x80\x99s Britannia\xe2\x80\x9d.\r\nSecond Edition, vol. iii. p. 267.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFOOTNOTES\r\n\r\n\r\n1 (return)\r\n[ The motto alludes to the Author returning to the stage repeatedly\r\nafter having taken leave.]\r\n\r\n2 (return)\r\n[ This very curious poem, long a desideratum in Scottish literature,\r\nand given up as irrecoverably lost, was lately brought to light by the\r\nresearches of Dr Irvine of the Advocates\xe2\x80\x99 Library, and has been\r\nreprinted by Mr David Laing, Edinburgh.]\r\n\r\n3 (return)\r\n[ Vol. ii. p. 167.]\r\n\r\n4 (return)\r\n[ Like the Hermit, the Shepherd makes havock amongst the King\xe2\x80\x99s game;\r\nbut by means of a sling, not of a bow; like the Hermit, too, he has his\r\npeculiar phrases of compotation, the sign and countersign being\r\nPasselodion and Berafriend.
